Fodor on Concepts: How to be a non-Atomist without being a Holist Introduction
 
The papers in the volume put forth clear answers to questions relating to:
 
*The nature of emotion
*The relevance of a correct analysis of emotion to ethics
*The nature of conception
*The nature of certain kinds of causation, and finally
*The bearing of correct theories of conception and causation on questions as to the nature of mind.
 
Proof that we have always known the theory of evolution to be true
 
     These days it is pretty much agreed that human beings evolved from other, “lower” life forms and that, ultimately, we come from the same stock as monkeys, reptiles, and insects. This discovery was, of course, a massive blow to our self-esteem. Given that our forbears are single-celled organisms, it becomes hard to see how, in any cosmic sense, we could be special. We are, it would seem, just very sophisticated protozoa.
       Once it is agreed that we came into existence by a process of evolution, it becomes hard to maintain that we were created by an almighty God. (Of course, it could be said that he created us by creating organisms from which we evolved. But somehow that position isn’t very satisfying.) Further, the creatures from which we evolved  -- reptiles, amphibians, single-celled organisms – are ones which we are used to holding in contempt. Now that we know about evolution, we cannot hold them in contempt. For we are them, at least in a phylogenetic sense.
    There is at least one other reason why the theory of evolution upsets us. It makes it very hard to believe in an afterlife. We don’t believe that amoebas or lizards or baboons go to heaven. So given that we evolved from such creatures, or from creatures of their ilk, it seems very arbitrary to maintain that we go to heaven when we die. Which species was the first to have an afterlife? Homo Erectus? Australopithecus? Cro-magnon? Any choice seems arbitrary. The only non-arbitrary thing to say is that since baboons don’t go to heaven, neither do we; for we are just baboons with big brains.
      It is generally thought that, prior to Darwin’s work in the mid 19th century, people didn’t know about evolution. Before Darwin, we believed that we were cosmically special and that we were of divine, not reptilian, origin.
     In any case, it is generally held that we believed this. I believe that people have always known about evolution, at least at some level. I cannot prove this here; but the idea is, I think, worth considering and developing. Also, it isn’t hard to make some case for it.  If we leave aside our wishes, and consider the facts in plain view, the most obvious thesis is not that we were of divine origin but that, on the contrary, we are related to dogs, monkeys, and other “lower” organisms. In fact, it is painfully obvious that we are related to such creatures. And this makes it hard to believe that people haven’t always known that we are related to them and thus come from a common stock. Of course, once it is granted that monkeys, lizards, and amoebas are our brethren, it is a very short step (if it is a step at all) to seeing that human beings emerged by from other “lower” life-forms. So I would suggest that – in some way, at some level --  people knew that our forbears were “lower” organisms and, consequently, that people evolved from such creatures.      Of course, people didn’t know about evolution at a conscious level. They repressed this knowledge; they knew it only unconsciously. Humankind’s insistence that it was of divine origins can be seen as a way of warding off or defusing this ugly piece of unconscious knowledge.
   None of this is to belittle Darwin’s discoveries. Oftentimes it takes genius to make conscious what is known unconsciously. In fact, given how strong our resistances were to believing in evolution – given what a massive emotional investment people had in not believing in evolution - the fact that Darwin’s positions have received near universal acceptance is an unambiguous indication of his genius.
    Why believe that we have, at some level, always known about evolution? First of all, there are extremely obviously anatomical similarities between us and other, “lower” animals. We have the same basic anatomical configuration as virtually all mammals and many reptiles and amphibians. For example, we have two eyes, four limbs, a spinal cord. And anyone who has seen the innards of a human being and those of, say, a cow or a dog knows that the differences are miniscule compared to the similarities. (Presumably people in earlier cultures were more likely to be involved preparing their own food and were more likely than people today to have direct knowledge of these similarities.)
     Of course, we are very different from many animals. We are, at least in terms of overt anatomy, quite different from snakes and squids. (At the same time, there are some very obvious similarities. No one can look at a squid in a museum without having the haunting feeling that one is looking at another thinking being. The eyes of a squid are eerily human.) But it is very easy to establish an indirect resemblance between ourselves and practically any species. Snakes directly resemble certain four-legged lizards. (There are some lizards that have four tiny limbs, but otherwise look like snakes.) And it is easy to establish a direct resemblance between those reptiles and others that have four large limbs and a tail. Those obviously resemble various mammals, at least in terms of their overt morphology. And so on, until we arrive at a species – like the Orangutan – which obviously resembles us. So even though there are some organisms we do not obviously resemble, we indirectly resemble all organisms.
    It does not take any acumen to see that, in terms of morphology, we are very similar to dogs and monkeys. Any two-year-old notices the similarities. (Actually, I would not be surprised if, in the earliest phases of their cognitive development, people thought humans and monkeys and dogs all belonged to the same species.) Now when a number of things resemble one another, it is simple common sense to suppose that they all have a common cause. If four pairs of shoes all have the same logo on them, they were probably made by the same company. If four houses have the same architecture, they were probably designed – if not by the same person – then by people belonging to the same architectural school. And the different adherents of that school can trace their lineage back to a common source (e.g. Frank Lloyd Wright). So ultimately the houses in question probably had a common origin.
   This is not a rarified point about scientific methodology. This is how people actually think. Every human being, when confronted with two very similar things, instinctively looks for a common cause. In fact, the ability to accept coincidence is the mark of non-instinctive thought. (A person in a reduced psychological condition – e.g. schizophrenia – sees practically nothing as coincidence. If the cab-driver says “nice day isn’t it?”, and the schizophrenic is having a bad day, the latter will see the cab driver as mocking him and, perhaps, as being part of some conspiracy to make his day worse.) Instinctively people are very liberal at drawing connections and looking for common causes. Given this, and given how incredibly obvious the anatomical similarities between us and (e.g.) dogs and monkeys are, it is hard not to believe that, at some level, people practically leapt to the conclusion that we share a common ancestry with them.
       Also, humankind’s conception of itself – or, rather, what it puts forth as its conception of itself - is discrepant with some painfully obvious realities. And that self-concept, it seems reasonable to hold, embodies a defensive attempt to ward off these painful and humiliating truths.  First of all, we cherish the idea that we are morally superior to animals, and that we are driven not by base urges, but by ideals: by a rational and humane conception of what is right.
     It is true, of course, that people are, to some extent, motivated by a desire to do good. But it is also obvious that the desire to do good, and to live the “right” way, plays a decidedly less important role than animal drives in what people do. If you base your predictions of somebody’s behavior on the supposition that he will always act out self-interest, then – leaving aside computational error on your part – the deviation between your predictions and the person’s behavior will be minimal. On the other hand, if you base your predictions of a person’s conduct on the supposition that he wishes to live the “right” way, the discrepancy between the predications and the facts will probably be total.
     Of course, it would be simple-minded to suppose that people are motivated entirely by self-interest. Most people do have values and do wish to live lives that have moral worth. Very few people are pure pragmatists. But when we consider the psychology of human motivation – the ratio of selfinterest to morality in our motives --  it is hard to see any real discontinuity between ourselves and animals.
     Another painful blow to our self-concept has to do with the biological basis of love. Everybody wants to be in love with a special someone. And the phenomenon of being in love is seen not just as something pleasurable, but as the highest actualization of the human spirit. I know that my life is richer and better when I am with someone I love. Obviously I’m not alone in this. And it is no mystery why we see love as being so valuable – why, indeed, we see love as a sine qua non of a meaningful existence and also as something of the highest excellence.
    But when we look at the anatomical basis of love, this sine qua non of the good life - -this highest actualization of the human spirit – takes on quite a different countenance. Biologically speaking, the sexual act is the purest expression of our erotic instincts. And, emotionally speaking, it is also the most intense way to express love. So it is surely an irony of major proportions that male sexual organ is also an excretory organ, and that the act of ejaculating – of consummating one’s love for another – has an obvious resemblance to the act of urinating. Also, love between two men involves both of our excretory organs. And, finally, the vagina, though obviously distinct from the anus, is anatomically and psychologically very close to it. There can be no doubt that many men see the vagina as a kind of para-anus: that is surely connected with the fact that many love to perform anal sex with women. And, as a matter of empirical fact, many women think of their vaginas as dirty and shameful because, at least in part, of the proximity to, and resemblance of, the anus.
    No function besides excreting makes as liberal use of the excretory organs as the sexual act. And yet this act is the most fulfilling thing a person can do and is also, supposedly, the consummation of all that is best about humankind.
   Note that that two people on a date will feel embarrassment when they see dogs fucking – embarrassment because they know that what they will be doing – in the highest moments of love – is no better. Note also that dogs sniff women’s genitals, indicating that dogs see us as fair game and thus as of their own ilk. Finally, note how ambiguous are our attitudes towards. Though sex, at least in certain contexts, is believed, supposedly, to be the highest manifestation of the human condition, it is also, evidently believed to be the lowest. It is only when performed under narrowly defined conditions, and thus when hyper-contextualized, that it is regarded as something holy, as opposed to profane. The need for those contextualizing is the proof positive that we are animals and that Darwin is right. Given that, for as long as civilization has existed, sexual intercourse has always been regarded as utterly indecent, except when done under such specific circumstances, shows that, as long as civilization has existed we have been aware of the fact that we are animals. And given the additional fact that a tribe’s totem is almost always an animal, this awareness has always been coupled with an awareness that we are descended from animals. This is confirmed that virile men are described as “tigers” and “stallions” and that attractive women are described as “vixens” (female foxes) and the like.
 
The Analogue/Digital Distinction and the Cogency of Kant’s Transcendental Arguments
 
 
 
I.  By a “proposition” I mean the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence. I do not mean the sentence itself. “La neige est blanche” and “snow is white” mean the same thing. This common meaning is what I will refer to as a “proposition”. 
     Kant held that some propositions are both synthetic and also a posteriori. (We will soon define these terms.)This contention is the heart of the system of thought set forth in the Critique of Pure Reason.
     The purpose of this paper is to examine this contention of Kant’s. I will argue that it is false and that Kant’s argument for it is spurious. But I will also argue that Kant’s false contention can readily be turned into a correct one and that his spurious argument can readily be turned into a cogent one. Nothing more than a few terminological changes are needed to accomplish this. Let me now outline the arguments I will give.
      First, I will argue that the premises of Kant’s argument turn out to entail the opposite of the thesis that there are synthetic a priori truths. Those premises entail that there are virtually no a priori truths, let alone synthetic a priori truths. Kant turns out to be even more of an opponent of a priori truth than John Stuart Mill.
       Second, I will argue that Kant’s reasoning involves a confusion concerning the two different epistemological roles that mental imagery can play. On the one hand, mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis. On the other hand, mental images are spatiotemporal phenomena in their own right, and can thus be the object of empirical study. Kant fails to distinguish the two quite distinct roles that mental images can have; and his views concerning the synthetic a priori are a reflection of that.
      But I will also argue that, despite the problems just discussed, the really important parts of the Critique are a success. Kant’s astonishing claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality turn out to be correct and founded on cogent arguments. But if this is to be made apparent, Kant’s reasoning must be “de-psychologized”: his statements about psychology must be reinterpreted as statements about logic. For the most part, this can be done by making a few adjustments to Kant’s choice of words.
 
§  Let us begin with a point about terminology. The proposition triangles have three sides is necessarily true; there is no possible circumstance where it is false. Its truth is guaranteed by the structures of the concepts composing it – the concepts triangle, three, and so forth. It is clear that, even if there were no sentient beings, triangles would still have three sides, and the proposition
[1]
triangles have three sides 	would still be true. So in this context, the word “concept” obviously does not refer to a mental entity of any kind, even though that is what it refers to elsewhere. So in this context, the word “concept” refers to non-psychological, presumably platonic, entities of some kind. When I describe a proposition as “conceptually necessary”, I mean that it holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the non-psychological sense of the word. I thus will use the term “conceptually necessary” to denote the non-psychological necessity characteristic of triangles have three sides.
Sometimes I will use the expression  “conceptually true” as a synonym for “conceptually necessary.
     As we will see, Kant recognizes a different category of necessary truth. In his view, some propositions are necessarily true because of facts about our minds. When I wish to discuss that kind of necessity, I will use the term “representational necessity.”
 
II.  The first thing we must do is to say just what is meant by the terms “synthetic” and “a priori” and, therefore, what is meant by the conjugate terms “analytic” and “a posteriori.”
    Consider the proposition 1+1=2. To know that is it true, one doesn’t do empirical work; one doesn’t perform experiments or make observations.
1+1=2 is thus a priori.  
    If a proposition is known to be true in some way other than through empirical work, Kant describes it as “a priori.”
      For Kant, a priority is an epistemological category. A priority is a property of our knowledge of propositions. Of course, Kant does describe propositions themselves as “a priori.” But when Kant does so, he is really saying something about our knowledge of those propositions.
    For Kant, a proposition is “a posteriori” if it is not a priori. The proposition Smith weighs over 200 lbs is not a priori; it is a posteriori. To know that is true, one must do empirical work.
      Now let us turn to the expressions “analytic” and “synthetic.” Here we must be careful. These days the term “analytic” is often meant to describe sentences. A sentence is “analytic” exactly if its semantics guarantees its truth. So “triangles have three sides” is analytic because, given what it means, it must be true.  But this is not how Kant was using that term.
    Kant uses the term “analytic” to describe propositions – not sentences, and not our knowledge of anything. Kant’s official definition of “analytic” is this: a proposition is analytic if “nothing is contained in the predicate which is not contained in the subject.” So all tall males are males is analytic because nothing is “contained” in the predicate (“males”) which is not “contained” in the subject (“all tall males”). A proposition is “synthetic” if it is not analytic.
    As Quine pointed out, there are two problems with Kant’s definition of analyticity. First, the notion of containment” is “left at a metaphorical
[2]
	level.” Physical objects can contain other physical objects; but meanings don’t contain meanings, at least not in the same sense. Second, Kant’s
[3] 	formulation only applies to statements having subject-predicate form. So it isn’t immediately obvious how to apply it to statements not having that form, for example: A=A or  if p implies q, then p implies anything that q implies.    
    But it isn’t hard to adapt Kant’s formulation to meet these two objections. Consider the proposition: a+b is larger than a.  This proposition is composed of various concepts – a+b, larger than, and so on. By themselves, the structures of these concepts guarantee that a+b is larger than a is true.
      a+b is larger than a is in a very different category from John and Mary like to play tennis. Consider the concepts that compose the latter proposition – John, Mary, and so on. The structures of these concepts do not guarantee the truth of that proposition.
      For Kant, a+b is larger than a is a paradigm case of an “analytic” proposition, and John and Mary like to play tennis is a paradigm case of a proposition that Kant would describe as “synthetic”. These facts suggest that, for Kant, a proposition is analytic exactly if it is “conceptually true” – exactly if it holds entirely in virtue of facts about the structures of concepts. It must be kept mind that, in this context, the concepts in question are not psychological entities.
    It is easy to find support for this reconstruction of Kant’s view. Consider
the proposition A=A. [4] Kant describes this very proposition as analytic. But in so doing, he is not being true to his official definition of analyticity, namely “the predicate is contained in the subject”. There is no clear sense in which this proposition has subject-predicate form, and there is no clear sense in which any constituent of this proposition contains any other constituent. So if Kant’s conception of analyticity were expressed by the definition just mentioned, then it would be inexplicable why he described A=A as analytic.       But in light of what we’ve said, it is clear what is motivating Kant.  How is A=A different from John and Mary like to play tennis?  The first is conceptually true; the second is not. In each case that Kant describes a proposition as “analytic”, he believes that proposition to be conceptually true. In each case that Kant describes a proposition as “synthetic”, he believes it not to be conceptually true. We may conclude that, for Kant, a proposition is “analytic” exactly if it is conceptually true – exactly if it holds entirely in virtue of the structures of the concepts composing it. A proposition is synthetic exactly if it is not analytic.
      Now we can say what Kant means when he describes a proposition as both “synthetic” and “a priori.” A proposition is a priori if it is known in some way other than through empirical work. A proposition is synthetic if its truth is not guaranteed by the structures of the concepts composing it. A proposition is synthetic a priori if it has both these properties.
 
III.   According to Kant, examples of synthetic a priori truths are: 7+5=12 and a straight line is the shortest distance between two points. 7+5=12 is a priori, in Kant’s view, because no sense-experience is needed to know that it is true. It is synthetic because the concepts composing it do not, by
[5]
themselves, make it true.
     Why does Kant think these truths are synthetic? Surely the truth of 7+5=12 is guaranteed by, and follows quite transparently from, the constitutions of the concepts  7, 5, +, and so on. So off-hand it is hard to see how that proposition could qualify as synthetic. Of course, 7+5=12 is not nearly as obvious as, say, 1+1=2. But, apart from that, the two propositions seem to be comparable.
     Here we must consider an argument made by Arthur Pap. Kant held that
1+1=2 is analytic. In Kant’s view, one cannot think 1+1 without thinking 2. So given Kant’s conception of analyticity, 1+1=2 must be classified as analytic – and this is exactly how Kant classifies it. 7+5=12 can be shown to follow analytically from 1+1=2 along with some other premises that Kant
[6]
	would regard as analytic. Surely anything that follows analytically from an analytic proposition is itself analytic. So given his premises, Kant should regard 7+5=12 as analytic, even though he doesn’t. Thus Kant’s is guilty not only of error, but of inconsistency with his own premises, in believing that 7+5=12 is synthetic.
     What about a straight line is the shortest distance between two points?  It is hard to see how this could be synthetic. To avoid confusing mathematical technicalities, let us qualify the proposition in question.  Let us consider the proposition in a Euclidean space a straight line is the shortest distance between two points. I don’t know if this proposition is obvious. But given that it is true, it is hard to see  how anything other than the constitution of the concepts involved could make that proposition be true.
     What is Kant’s reason for regarding these propositions as synthetic? To begin with, when you think 7+5 you don’t necessarily think  =12. Kant is right about this. When you think m+n, you don’t necessarily think the sum of that operation. (That is why we need calculators.)
   But at this point, Kant’s reasoning becomes fuzzy. The fuzziness is due to the fact that Kant was not clear about whether he is using the term “concept” in the logical, or the psychological sense; he seems to go back and forth.  It does not appear that he registered this distinction. But I think it is fair to reconstruct his reasoning as follows.
    Given that you don’t think =12 when you think 7+5, it seems to follow
that your concept of 7+5 doesn’t contain your concept =12. So in exercising your grasp of the concept 7+5,  you are not exercising your grasp of the concept =12. Therefore your grasp of the concept =12 is altogether distinct
[7]
from your grasp of the concept 7+5.
      When you think straight line, you don’t necessarily think shortest distance between two points. What you think, says Kant, is purely qualitative, not quantitative; you think of a line with a certain shape, not a line of a certain distance. So your grasp of the concept straight-line is distinct from
[8]
your grasp of the concept distance.
      From this Kant apparently infers that the concept 7+5 is entirely distinct from the concept =12. But this inference involves a muddle of the two meanings of the word “concept”. My concept of 7+5 is distinct from my concept of =12. But this doesn’t show that the concept 7+5 is distinct from the concept =12.
     For Kant to make his case, he needs to appeal to some principle like the following: the structure of concepts (in the objective sense) of the word can be read off of the way in which they are represented in our minds. Facts about our grasp of concepts must parallel facts about the concepts themselves. So if my grasp of 7+5 doesn’t comprise my grasp of =12, then the first concept doesn’t comprise the latter.
      Once that principle is granted, Kant’s argument goes through. But why grant it? What is the motivation for it? That principle presupposes that concepts are completely transparent: you cannot grasp a concept without at once grasping everything definitive of it. There is no more to them than meets the eye. Their esse lies in their percipi. It thus seems to me that the principle in question presupposes, and is probably motivated by, a kind of anti-realism about concepts – by a kind of psychologism concerning them.
They are creatures of the mind, not entities in their own right.
        Let us now close Kant’s argument. As we’ve seen, in Kant’s view, the truth of 7+5=12 does not follow wholly from the concepts involved in that proposition: it is therefore synthetic. At the same time, Kant denies that it is an empirical truth:  he denies that it is made true by what happens when apples are laid next to apples, when quarts of liquid are added to other quarts of liquid, and so on. Arithmetical truths are not inductive generalizations that we could, in principle, find to be false. You don’t know them through empirical work: you know them a priori. So such truths are a priori and synthetic. For analogous reasons, the same is true of  a straight line is the shortest distance between two points and any other proposition that is nonempirical but (unlike A=A) non-trivial.
      The very existence of synthetic a priori propositions raises difficult questions. Such propositions are not made true by facts about concepts. At the same time, they are not made true by the kinds of facts that can be discovered through empirical investigation. There doesn’t seem to be anything left to make them true. So what, in Kant’s view, makes a synthetic a priori be true? And how do we know such propositions be true?
 
IV.  Let us now give Kant’s answers to the questions just posed. How do you know that 7+5=12?  Not through conceptual analysis. Not through the senses. You learn it through an act of the imagination. You must imagine seven objects laid next to five other objects, and then see that the resulting aggregate comprises exactly 12 objects.
    How do you know that a straight line is the shortest between two points? Not through conceptual analysis. Not through the senses. You must have a certain kind of para-sensory experience: you must imagine a line connecting two dots.
    Kant refers to images of this sort as “intuitions”. So it is through “intuition” that you learn the truth of 7+5=12.
     It must be made clear that Kant is not using this term in the way it is used today. These days, philosophers usually use the term to refer to a putative insight into concepts (“my intuition is that killing someone is morally worse than passively allowing him to die”). This is not what Kant means. By
[9] “intuition” Kant means an act of imaging	: a kind of para-perception.      Let us continue with Kant’s story. How exactly do these para-perceptual experiences reveal the truth of 7+5=12? The idea seems to be as follows. First of all, these para-sensory experiences don’t show conceptual or logical necessity. Kant’s whole point is that the concepts involved in 7+5=12 do not, by themselves, guarantee its truth. Taken by themselves, those concepts are consistent with the truth of 7+5≠12. So the para-perceptions that teach us the truth of 7+5=12 do not do so by apprising us of necessary relations holding among the components of that proposition. 
     At the same time, those para-sensory experiences don’t tell us anything about the external world: you can’t learn anything new about the external world through an act of imagination.
    So, for Kant, these para-perceptual experiences show neither empirical truth nor conceptual necessity. What they show is representational necessity. They show us facts, not about the world or about concepts, but about how we must sense-perceive the world.
   These para-perceptual experiences show us what we can and cannot imagistically represent. We cannot represent in an image a straight line between two points that is longer than some other line between those two points. We cannot form an image of four apples that isn’t also an image of two apples and two other apples.
   Let us sum up. Recourse to “intuition” apprises us of what we can, and cannot, imagistically represent. So these “intuitions” apprise us of what we can, and cannot, represent in perception; they tell us how we must see things, in the literal sense of “see.”
    At this point, we must be careful. One might be tempted to ground these “representational” facts in conceptual facts:
 
    There can’t be an image of four apples that isn’t an image of two apples and two other apples because the concepts 2, + etc. are such that they don’t permit this. It is a conceptual or logical truth that 2+2=4, and this fact underlies the representational limitation Kant has in mind.
 
   This may be true. (In my view, it is true.) But it is just what Kant cannot, and does not, say. He thinks that 7+5=12 is such that its truth is not guaranteed by the concepts composing that statement. So the representational limitations he has in mind do not have a purely conceptual or logical foundation.
      In Kant’s view, these necessities are really of a psychological nature. Our “forms of thought” are such that we must see the world (literally see it) as being such that, in it, parallel lines don’t meet, a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, two objects coupled with two other objects make four objects, and so on. We are wired in such a way that we (though perhaps not other life forms) must see objects as being in a space and time with a certain structure: a structure that does not permit parallel lines to meet, that does not permit 2+2 to equal 3, and so on. So “intuition”, i.e. paraperceptual experience, shows us how we must sense-perceive the world.
   
IV. Is there any room in this picture for synthetic a priori truth? And supposing that it does have room for it, does it have room for knowledge of it? Both questions must be answered with a “no”.  My argument for this owes
[10]
much to Laurence Bonjour.
      For the sake of argument, let us concede a couple of key assumptions to Kant. First, let’s concede that we do sense-perceive the world as being such that 7+5=12, a straight line is the shortest distance between two points,
[11]
	parallels don’t meet, and so on. Second, let’s concede that we learn these facts about how we perceive the world through “intuition” (some kind of para-perceptual experience), and not through conceptual analysis or through sense-perception.
     Given only that we are psychologically compelled to see the world as being such that, in it, thus and such is the case, it doesn’t follow that thus and such really is the case. A psychotic may be psychologically compelled to see pink elephants, but that doesn’t mean there are pink elephants. So our parasensory experiences don’t tell us anything about the world, but only (at most) about how we perceive it. They tell us not that 7+5 really equals 12, but only that we are psychologically compelled to sense-perceive the world as being
[12]
such that, in it, 7+5=12.
    Actually, Kant himself admits this. These intuitions, he says, tell us about the “phenomenal” world, not the “noumenal” world. By Kant’s own definition, the “phenomenal world” is just the world as it appears to us: it is how we see the world. The “noumenal” world is the actual world. So by Kant’s own admission, these intuitions inform us only about how we see the world, not about how it is. We must see the world as being such that, in it, parallels don’t meet. But whether this is true in the “noumenal” world  is a totally separate issue. (Kant says that we simply cannot know whether they
[13]
	meet in the noumenal world or not.) So intuition doesn’t really tell us anything about the external world.
      At the same time, for Kant, intuition doesn’t tell us anything about the structure of concepts either. Intuitions are not insights into concepts. Kant is adamant about this. Intuition begins precisely where conceptual analysis ends.
      So, on Kant’s view, intuitions don’t tell us anything about the spatiotemporal world and they don’t tell us anything about concepts. Thus, given only that intuition tells us that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, we simply have no reason to believe that straight line is the shortest distance between two points. At most, we can conclude that we are psychologically compelled to see the world as being such that, in it, a straight line is the shortest distance between two points.
    So “intuition”, on Kant’s view, doesn’t give us knowledge of the fact that 7+5=12. Intuition gives us only the knowledge that we are psychologically compelled to see the world as being such that, in it, 7+5=12 and   parallels don’t meet. A fortiori intuition doesn’t give us a priori knowledge of the fact that 7+5=12. If it gives us a priori knowledge of anything, it is of the fact that we must perceive the world as being such that, in it, 7+5=12.  But, as we’ll see in a moment, it doesn’t even give us a priori knowledge of this; it gives
[14]
us, at most, a posteriori knowledge. 
    

	A. 7+5=12 obviously is true. So something makes it true. For Kant, facts about concepts don’t make it true. As we’ve seen, facts about our own psychology don’t make it true. The only thing left to make it true is the spatiotemporal world. So on Kant’s view, followed to its logical conclusion, for us to know whether 7+5 really equaled 12, we’d have to learn about the actual world (which, for reasons that don’t concern us, Kant says we cannot do). So it becomes a kind of empirical truth. In any case, it becomes a truth that cannot be known in any way other than through examination of the external world. So, by any definition of a priori, it is not a priori.
   The same thing holds of any truth that we would characterize as “a priori”, apart from completely trivial ones (e.g. 1=1). If they can be known at all, it is through knowledge of the noumenal world. According to Kant, we can’t know anything about the noumenal world. Therefore we don’t have any knowledge of such truths, let alone a priori knowledge.
 

	* One might make the following claim on Kant’s behalf:
 
       How could we learn the truths of geometry, if not through visual intuitions? In any case, whether or not we could learn them in some other way, we do learn at least some of them through intuition. This would seem to support Kant’s view.
 
When you learn through mental imagery that a straight line intersects a circle at no more than two points, you are learning something that is made true by the concepts CIRCLE and LINE, and so forth. You are not learning something that is made true by our cognitive machinery. Nothing about circles could be made true by our cognitive machinery. When we do learn facts about geometry or perhaps arithmetic through an exercise of powers of imaging, what is really going is conceptual analysis, the vehicle for which, in those cases, happens to be mental imagery. There is no reason why images should not mediate conceptual analysis. So given only that some truth is discovered through thought involving mental imagery, it doesn’t follow that it is synthetic.
      What led Kant astray was a failure to distinguish the different roles that mental imagery can play in the acquisition of knowledge. Kant noted that mental imagery is a kind of para-perception. He concluded from this that, when mental imagery is involved in the discovery of some truth, that truth is synthetic – like those truths that we use perception to discover. The idea is that, if the truth in question were purely conceptual, then we wouldn’t need to use para-perception to ascertain it.
     But that is simply false. If somebody asks me “what is the minimum number of sides a solid can have?”, I base my answer on a mental image that
[15]
	I produce. I imagine trying to produce a solid out of four sides, then note that it doesn’t work, then try to do the same thing with five sides, and note that it does work. But surely the fact that a solid has to have a minimum of five sides is not synthetic. That proposition holds entirely in virtue of mathematics – in virtue of the structure of the concepts  five and solid and so forth. It is true that I rely to some extent on imagery to learn this truth. But the imagery is a vehicle for conceptual analysis.
    It might seem that Kant did show that we have some a priori knowledge: we have a priori knowledge of facts about the phenomenal world, i.e. about how we must perceive the world. We know a priori that the world, as we perceive it, is such that parallel lines don’t meet in it, triangles have interior angles adding up to 180°, and so on.
    The truth is that, on Kant’s account, even this knowledge turns to be a posteriori. Once again, what led Kant astray was a failure to distinguish the two very different epistemic roles that attention to our own mental processes can have.
     As we just noted, mental imagery can sometimes serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis. But it can also play a very different epistemic role. Suppose I want to find out facts about my own psychology; suppose, for example, I want to find out if I can imagine a 17-sided figure. Here I will, of course, generate mental imagery, and attend to the content of that imagery.
But in this case, the imagery is not serving as a vehicle for conceptual analysis. In attending to my mental imagery, I am actually doing empirical work, and the truth that I discover (I cannot visualize a 17-sided figure) is as a posteriori as Socrates was bald.  Here the mental imagery is the actual subject-matter of the truth-learned. 
     For Kant, you learn that you can’t represent parallel lines as intersecting by noting that you cannot imagine it; you observe your own mental imagery. So you learn this putative fact about your representational powers through a kind of self-observation, and not through any kind of conceptual analysis. This knowledge turns out to be quite a posteriori. When Kant says that “in the phenomenal world” parallels don’t meet, he is just saying that we cannot visually represent a world where parallels don’t meet. So our knowledge of this fact about the phenomenal world turns out to be a posteriori.    
     Consider a point made by Leibniz about the role that imagery plays in the acquisition of mathematical knowledge:
 
    But I do not agree with you what seems to be your [Locke’s] view, that some kind of general certainty is provided in mathematics by “particular demonstrations” concerning the diagram that has been drawn. You must understand that geometers do not derive their proofs from diagrams, although the expository approach makes it seem so. The cogency of the demonstration is independent of the diagram, whose only role is to make it easier to understand what is meant and to fix one’s attention. It is universal propositions, i.e. definitions and axioms and theorems which have already been demonstrated, that make up the reasoning, and they would sustain it
[16]
even if there were no diagram.
 
     Diagrams serve as vehicles for a priori reasoning. The fact that I use a diagram to prove the intermediate value theorem or the Pythagorean theorem doesn’t prove that either of those theorems is synthetic. They aren’t synthetic.
This point applies to mental imagery – to mental diagrams.
     Leibniz’s point was made more recently by Christopher Peacocke:
 
    When you come to know a logical truth by way of your having a proof of it, you may need to perceive the inscription of the proof, and you may need various perceptual capacities to appreciate that it is a proof. But the justification for your belief in the logical truth is the proof itself. Perceptual experience gives access to the proof, which provides an experienceindependent justification for accepting its conclusion. By contrast, if you come to believe “That’s Mikhail Gorbachev”, when you see him at the airport, what entitles you to your belief is (in part) the perceptual experience by which you recognize Gorbachev. Your perceptual experience is not a mere means which gives you access to some experience-independent entitlement to
[17]
believe “That’s Gorbachev.” 
 
 
   
      When you use a mental image to figure out whether a line can intersect a circle at more than two points, the image gives you the justification for believing a certain proposition, but the image is not itself a justification-- at least not in the sense in which seeing Gorbachev at the airport is justification for believing that Gorbachev is still alive.
 
VII.    I should respond to a possible misgiving about our analysis:
 
 
    You have belittled and caricatured Kant’s views. Kant says we must see the world as being such that, in it, parallel don’t meet, 7+5=12, and so on; and he says that this due to our forms of thought. You have taken this to mean that, for Kant, our seeing the world as having these features is due to some merely psychological compulsion, like a neurotic’s compulsion to wash his hands twenty times a day. But this is to misunderstand the nature of the necessity Kant has in mind. The necessity that attaches to the proposition parallels don’t meet is epistemological, not psychological; transcendental, not empirical. That proposition describes a necessary precondition for our being able to have any experience at all of the world. Obviously parallels don’t meet  won’t be made true by a mere psychological compulsion, just as pink elephants aren’t brought into existence by a psychotic’s hallucinations. But Kant in no way holds that the necessity attaching to parallels don’t meet is psychological. In fact, he goes out of his way to make it clear that the necessity in question is non-psychological. In characterizing what is in fact transcendental necessity as mere psychological compulsion, you have misrepresented Kant’s view, and made it far easier to destroy than it really is.
 
  
    In the end, “transcendental” necessity reduces either to mere psychological necessity or to conceptual necessity. We cannot coherently think of a world where triangles have two sides or where 2+2=3. That is because propositions like 2+2=3 and triangles have two sides are conceptually false and consequently draw a limit to what we can conceive of. What cannot be
[18]
conceived cannot be per	ceived. Conceptual necessities thus impose sharp limits on how the world can be visually represented. So it is clear how conceptual falsity translates into representational impossibility.
    At the same time, if a proposition is conceptually possible, then it is hard
to see how it could ground a representational impossibility. Because we have certain cognitive machinery -- certain “forms of thought” -- we are compelled to see the world in a certain way. But unless those forms of thought embody conceptual necessities of some kind, I don’t see why we couldn’t, in principle, have different forms of thought.
    An example might help. We could obviously imagine having a cognitive architecture such that we could only see two different colors or hear two different pitches. Under those circumstances, given the forms of thought operative in our sense-perception, we simply couldn’t see a third color or hear a third pitch. But obviously it is conceptually possible that there be more than two colors. (It is actual; so it is possible.) So it is representationally possible.
      There are limits to what our perceptual machinery can do. But it is very hard to see how these limits could be necessary unless they were  grounded in conceptual impossibilities.
 

	* There is an incoherence in Kant’s thinking even more radical than anymentioned so far. He rightly wants to hold that propositions like 7+2=9 and the area of a (Euclidean)  triangle is ½ the base×height are a priori. But he also says that we sense-perceive the world as being such that these propositions are true in it. Of course, if the world can be seen (literally seen) as being such that 7+2=9 is true in it, then 7+9=12 is descriptive of the spatiotemporal world. If 7+2=9 said absolutely nothing about the spatiotemporal world, then the truth or falsity of that proposition couldn’t make any difference to how the spatiotemporal world seemed to us. So, on Kant’s view, these propositions say something about the spatiotemporal world.
    But 7+2=9  doesn’t say anything about the spatio-temporal world; it doesn’t say that if you hold up two fingers and then hold up seven fingers, nine fingers are on display. For there could, in principle, be a causal law that falsified just that sort of statement – a law that didn’t allow more than five fingers to be simultaneously on display in a certain region.
    The same is true  of Kant’s claim that we must sense-perceive the world as being such that, in it, straight lines are the shortest distances between pairs of points. The proposition a straight line is the shortest distance between two points says nothing at all about the spatio-temporal world; it defines a certain kind of space. Of course, there are empirical propositions – concerning light rays and point-masses – that are analogous to that purely mathematical proposition. But surely Kant doesn’t have these in mind when he says it is a priori that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points.      So Kant’s position is self-undermining. He needs mathematical propositions to be two things at once. They must be descriptive of the world: they must say something about beams of light. But they must also not be descriptive of the world: they must not be capable of falsification by anything having to do with beams of light and the like.
    A Kantian might reply by saying:
 
     Propositions like 7+2=9 and a straight line is the shortest distance between two points do describe the empirical world. They describe necessary features of it. So 7+2=9 is like grass is green in one respect: it is descriptive of the empirical world. But 7+2=9 is unlike grass is green in another respect: it describes necessary features of the world. That is why 7+2=9 is a priori, unlike grass is green. There is no inference from P describes the world to P is an empirical and contingent proposition. So the point you just made fails. [19]
    But there is an inference from 	P is necessary to P doesn’t describe the empirical world (in any way at all). If P is necessary, then P’s being true in world 1 doesn’t distinguish world 1 from world 2 or from world 897. P therefore doesn’t say anything about the world that distinguishes it from other possible worlds. So P doesn’t say anything at all about the world. A
“description” of a thing that fails to distinguish that thing from other things in any way at all is no description at all.
 

	* So far I’ve said a lot about why Kant is wrong. But I think that, with afew adjustments, Kant’s position might possibly be correct.
    Ultimately, there is one thing wrong with Kant’s view: his conception of analyticity is much too narrow. Everything else that is wrong about Kant’s position can be traced back to this one mistake.     Kant grants analytic status only to propositions like
 

	* circles are round.
 
  He denies analytic status to propositions like
 

	* a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane. 
 
Thus he says the following is analytically false:
 

	* circles are not round.
 
But he denies that the following is analytically false:
 

	* a circle is not a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane. 
 
 
    His reasoning seems to be this:
 
  A proposition is analytic exactly if one is guilty of incoherence in virtue of countenancing its negation. One is guilty of incoherence if one thinks that (*) is false. But is not guilty of incoherence if one thinks that (**) is false. One is wrong to think that (**) is false, but not incoherent.
   To be incoherent is to think in a way that is counter-conceptual. Thus (*) is counter-conceptual. (**) is not counter-conceptual.
    An analytic proposition is one that is made true by concepts. An analytically false proposition is one that is made false by concepts: a counterconceptual proposition. One can countenance the negation of (**) without being guilty of incoherence, and without countenancing a counter-conceptual proposition. Thus (**) is not analytic.
  But (**) is a priori. So we must suppose that it is made true by facts about our conceptual machinery; it embodies a fact about our conceptual schema.
That is why no empirical discovery could confute it.
 
    The word “coherent” has two entirely different meanings: a psychological meaning and a purely logical meaning.
     If you believe (d), you are guilty of logical incoherence: the proposition you believe entails a contradiction. But a perfectly sane person could believe the negation of (d). In virtue of believing it, one is perhaps guilty of stupidity, and of incoherence in the logical sense, but not of incoherence in the psychological sense.
     By contrast, if you believe (c), you are guilty not just of logical, but of psychological, incoherence. You couldn’t possibly think that circles are not round; to think of something as a circle just is to think of it as round. So to think of something as a non-round circle – if such a thought is even possible - would involve a kind of double-think, a fragmentation of the psyche.
     The following story might be helpful. Somebody tells you:
 
 

	* a triangle is the area bounded by three straight lines such that any two ofthem intersect but not all three intersect.
 
But you don’t immediately see the truth of that proposition. Initially, you reject you it; you say:
 
 

	* A triangle is not the area bounded by three straight lines such that any two of them intersect but not all three intersect.
  
 
   Are you guilty of psychological incoherence? It seems not. A perfectly sane person could believe (f). Belief in (f) constitutes mathematical, but not psychological incoherence.
  But a sane person could not believe:
 

	* A triangle is not a three sided figure.
 
  
   If one believed (g), one would be guilty not only of logical, but of psychological incoherence. Thinking of x as a triangle and as not being threesided would involve  a fragmentation of the thinker’s psyche.
      Logical coherence is a relation among concepts. Psychological coherence is a relation among our grasp of concepts.
      All of the following are analytic:
 

	* circles are round.

	* a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane.      (e) a triangle is the area bounded by three straight lines such that any two of them intersect but not all three intersect.

	* triangles have three sides.
 
   But (a) and (h) are different from (b) and (e). One is guilty, not only of logical, but of psychological incoherence in virtue of believing (a) and (h). One is guilty of logical, but not of psychological incoherence, in virtue of believing (b) and (e).
     Let us set say that (b) and (e) are “hard analytic”, and let us say that (a) and (h) are “easy analytic”. It is hard to know that (b) and (e) are true. It is not hard to know (a) and (h) are analytic; a grasp of those propositions by itself suffices for a knowledge of their truth. (Kant describes such propositions as “apodictic.”)
     What Kant refers to as “synthetic a priori” truths are nothing other than what we are describing as hard analytic truths. What Kant refers to as analytic truths are what we are describing as easy analytic truths.
     Once it is recognized that (b) and (e) are analytic, albeit hard analytic, we must say that they hold entirely in virtue of facts about the concepts that compose them; and there is no longer any temptation to say that they are made true by facts about the mind. So that obliterates any possible warrant that might otherwise be had by Kant’s psychologistic analysis of those propositions.
 
§     But we must remember what Kant’s larger concern is. Kant’s main concern is not a taxonomy of propositions. That is incidental to what he is doing.
    We have experience; we have sequences of thoughts and perceptions that cohere. The world is intelligible to us. We sense-perceive it; we think about it; and, up to a point, our perceptions and thoughts are accurate. In Kant’s view, given the very fact that these things are true, we can deduce certain things about the structure of the world. Given only that we have coherent ideation, the world must satisfy certain minimal conditions.
     Kant refers to those conditions as “transcendental”: they are the conditions that are necessarily satisfied by any world in which there are entities that have coherent (if not always accurate) thoughts and representations. The “necessity” just mentioned is not causal: it is of a deeper kind. 
    A “transcendental argument” is one having the form: given only that we have experiences of such and such a kind, it follows that the world must have thus and such features.
     Kant gives transcendental arguments for many things. I think that some of these arguments are cogent, provided that we make some terminological changes. Where Kant talks about “synthetic a priori”, we should instead talk of “hard analytic”. This minor adjustment de-psychologizes Kant’s arguments, and makes them go through.
      Consider the fact that we have coherent sequences of mental representations. That  fact does show that the world satisfies certain very basic conditions. I will argue that there is an analytic connection – a hard analytic connection, but an analytic connection no less – between the proposition there exist beings who have the cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions and propositions concerning the structure of the world itself. 
    I will argue for another significant claim. Consider the following propositions: any two events are related in space or in time; there are causal relations among states of affairs; objects are not mere bundles of properties, but are things in which properties inhere; human beings are not mere bundles of perceptions (or thoughts), but are things in which such entities inhere. These propositions describe the world. I will argue that, just as Kant maintained, each of those propositions is entailed by the proposition there exist beings who have the cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions.
 
§   One of Kant’s main objectives is to show that there are necessary connections among the events that we experience. Hume said that there are sequences and regularities of events, but there is never any kind of internal connection holding among them. For event x to cause event y is just for that sequence of events to instantiate a general regularity.
    Hume’s analysis is counter-intuitive. Intuitively, it seems that pushing the button makes the computer turn on, that flipping the switch makes the light turn on.  Understandably, Kant wanted to do justice to that intuition. He tries to justify this intuition with a transcendental argument. (Here I will give a transcendental argument for that view; whether it is Kant’s own argument, or even one he would consider credible, is an exegetical question I wish to avoid.) Given the very fact that we are even here to raise the question whether there are “inner connections” among events, it follows that there are such connections. Imagine a world where there is no causation, where there are merely sequences of events. Such a world would comprise nothing enduring. Persistence is itself a causal notion. If something persists, there is ipso facto a causal sequence of some kind. So where there is no causation, there is no persistence. Where there is no persistence, there is no coherent ideation. For surely, as a matter of necessity, a coherent thought process involves some kind of persistence. So given only the fact that there are beings who have the ability to raise questions about anything, let alone about the necessary preconditions for experience, it follows that causal relations do not consist in mere sequences of events, but in internal relations of some kind. [20]
 
§  Here is a similar argument. The very existence rational thought shows that, in addition to thoughts, there must things which have those thoughts. This contradicts Hume’s contention that the self is a mere “bundle” of thoughts.  
   Suppose the following. I think if P then Q . Fred thinks P. Sam thinks Q.
 That sequence of thoughts is not a coherent or rational thought process.  . Suppose I think if P then Q, Fred thinks Q, and Sam thinks P. That sequence of thoughts was not an irrational thought-process. Suppose one person thinks: if P then Q, and P, therefore Q.  Here we have a case of rationality. Suppose one person thinks: if P then Q, Q, therefore P. Here we have a case of irrationality.
    Hume says that there are only sequences of perceptions and thoughts; there are not things that have those thoughts. So a Humean cannot distinguish among the cases above. For there to be rational or irrational thought processes, there must be things which have those thoughts: there must be people beneath the thoughts. Only then will a precondition of rationality (or irrationality) be met. There obviously are such things as coherent and incoherent sequences of thoughts. Therefore, there are such things as persons. The very existence of coherent (and incoherent) thought processes shows something about the structure of the world: it shows that, if there are to be such things as thoughts, there must be things underneath the thoughts which have them. So here we have a transcendental argument for the existence of
[21]
	selves. In the same stroke, we have a transcendental argument for the existence of internal relations among distinct mental events.
 
§    But notice that these transcendental arguments turn on the existence of entirely analytic connections among propositions; no “synthetic a priori” is involved. Given the very concept of a rational thought process, it follows that not just any sequence of thoughts constitutes a case of rationality or irrationality: only certain sequences do so. Given the existence of coherent and incoherent thought processes, it follows analytically that there are things underlying thoughts which have them: it follows analytically that the Humean conception of person identity is false. The analyticity in question is hard analyticity, but it is analyticity no less.

Burge, Tyler. 2000. “Frege on Apriority”. In New Essays on the A Priori edited by Paul Boghossian and Christopher Peacocke  Clarendon Press
Oxford: 2000
 
 
Kant, Immanuel. 1965. Critique of Pure Reason. Translated by Norman Kemp Smith.  St. Martin’s Press New York.
 
 
Kuczynski, John-Michael. “A Solution to the Paradox of Causation.” Philosophy in Science. Volume 8. 1999.
 
Montague, Richard. Formal Philosophy. Edited by Richard Thomason. New Haven: Yale University Press.

Moderate Rationalism”. In New Essays on the A Priori edited by Paul
Boghossian and Christopher Peacocke  Clarendon Press Oxford: 2000

Can One Grasp Propositions Without Knowing a Language? Defending Cognitive Realism against Robert Brandom
 
RESUMEN
 
¿Debe uno conocer un lenguaje para captar proposiciones? De acuerdo con la opinión de muchos la respuesta es ‘sí’. Generalmente la idea que está detrás de esta posición es que las proposiciones, siendo entidades platónicas, no pueden ser contempladas directamente: así uno debe captarlas a través de representaciones de las mismas. Y, por supuesto, se supone que las representaciones en cuestión son símbolos lingüísticos. Wittgenstein añadió una nueva dimensión a esta línea de pensamiento: defendió que el lenguaje y por tanto los símbolos lingüísticos, son esencialmente públicos: un lenguaje es un conjunto de símbolos gobernados por reglas y éstas son esencialmente públicas: esto se debe a que una regla ‘privada’ puede desobedecerse con impunidad y por esto vale tanto como si no fuese una regla. Así, en opinión de Wittgenstein, uno debe ser miembro de una comunidad para conocer un lenguaje y de este modo poder captar una proposición. Robert Brandom da un paso más allá y afirma que las comunidades son los únicos seres realmente capaces de captar proposiciones y que los individuos las captan sólo en un sentido derivado. En este artículo voy a defender que uno puede captar proposiciones sin captar un lenguaje y que la capacidad de aprender un leguaje presupone la capacidad para captar proposiciones. Se seguirá de lo que digo que son los individuos y no las comunidades los que de un modo genuino captan proposiciones.
 
ABSTRACT
Must one know a language to grasp propositions? According to many, the answer is ‘yes’. Generally, the idea behind this position is that propositions, being platonic entities, cannot be beheld directly: so one must grasp them by way of grasping representations of them. And, of course, the representations in question are usually taken to be linguistic symbols. Wittgenstein added a new dimension to this line of thought: he argued that language, and thus linguistic symbols, are essentially public: a language is a set of rule-governed symbols, and rules are essentially public: this is because a ‘private’ rule can be disobeyed with impunity, and is therefore as good as no rule. So, in Wittgenstein’s view, one must be a member of a community to know a language and therefore to grasp a proposition. Robert Brandom goes a step further and says that communities are the only beings truly capable of grasping propositions, and that individuals grasp them only in a derivative sense. In this paper, I will argue that one can grasp propositions without grasping a language, and that the ability to learn a language presupposes the ability to grasp propositions. It will follow from what I say that it is individuals, and not communities, that genuinely grasp propositions.
I: INTRODUCTION
 
In Making It Explicit Robert Brandom contends that, in order to grasp propositions — that is, to grasp truths or falsehoods — a creature must be a member of some kind of community. In fact, Brandom holds a much stronger position: he says that intentionality can be ‘non-derivatively’ [Brandom
(1998), p. 151] attributed only to communities of individuals, and only
[22]
derivatively applied to individuals. In taking this latter position, Brandom is of course opposing common sense: it is ordinarily thought that communities cannot think, or in any way be conscious, except in a metaphorical sense; and that to say of a community that it thinks a certain way or has a certain kind of ‘consciousness’ is really just to make some kind of statement about the individuals belonging to it.
Why does Brandom hold that, in order to grasp propositions, an individual must belong to a community? Because, says Brandom, to be able to grasp propositions a creature must know a language [Brandom (1998), pp.
[23]
148-59] ; and, as Brandom also holds, a creature that isn’t a member of some kind of community cannot possibly know a language [Brandom (1998), p. 155]. These views coincide with views held by the later Wittgenstein. Moreover, Brandom’s reasons for holding these views are heavily derivative of  reasons set forth by Wittgenstein. We will presently consider both Brandom’s and Wittgenstein’s reasons.
In this paper I wish to show that, in order to learn a language, a creature must already be able to grasp propositions and, more generally, that for a creature to become conscious of some norm it must already be conscious of norms. Consciousness of norms is either innate or non-existent. Of course, consciousness of this or that norm needn’t be, and usually isn’t, innate. But a creature that is not innately aware of some norms couldn’t possibly become aware of any. Experience – so I will try to show -- apprises us of new norms only by articulating some innate connectedness to normativity in general.
I will also try to show that, given a group of creatures none of whom are aware of norms, there is no way that they could come to be aware of norms by interacting with one another; and there is no way that a group of creatures could collectively be aware of norms unless some of the individuals composing that group were previously aware of norms.
Finally, we will consider Brandom’s arguments against the position just described. This will involve our considering Wittgenstein’s arguments against that same position. We will find that both Brandom’s and Wittgenstein’s arguments involve identifiable fallacies.
This paper will defend a version of what is called ‘cognitive realism’.
What does this term mean? Many of our abilities — e.g. our ability to understand language, to solve mathematical problems, to play musical instruments — seem to result from our having an ‘implicit awareness’ of certain rules. They seem to result from an awareness of such rules because our mental and behavioural productions can, without artifice, be made out to accord with such rules: there is a kind of isomorphism between these productions and such rules. And it would be an extraordinary coincidence if this isomorphism obtained without our cognitive productions’ actually resulting from some kind of awareness of these rules. As a competent English speaker, I will say ‘the dog chased the cat’ and I certainly won’t ever say ‘dog cat chased the.’ Why won’t I ever say this? One hypothesis is: I have an ‘implicit grasp’ of certain grammatical rules; I have mastered rules governing what concatenations of sound betoken well-formed sentences of English; and according to these rules ‘the dog chased the cat’ is grammatical and ‘dog cat chased the’ is not grammatical. This kind of explanation would seem to apply mutatis mutandis to virtually every kind of cognitive competence. There is no shortage of thinkers who have taken this position, in at least some form — Chomsky, Dummett, Kant.
Chomsky and Dummett are ‘cognitive realists’: we really are aware of certain rules — these rules have ‘cognitive reality’ — and this awareness determines what we think and do. I will sometimes refer to this position as ‘cognitivism’.
There is no shortage of thinkers who reject cognitivism. They usually argue as follows. First of all, given only that a process or event can be described as though it resulted from consciousness of some rule R, it doesn’t follow that it did result from such consciousness. The movements that my fingers are currently making could be described as though they resulted from my following some kind of complex rule involving the relative distances of various comets from one another. But this rule is not in fact operative. This is the first leg of the anti-cognitivist argument [Searle (1992) and (1999)].
The next leg is as follows. The idea of sub-personal cognitive activity is incoherent: so not only is it not de rigueur to see (e.g.) my visual perceptions or linguistic intuitions as resulting from such activity: it is de rigueur not to see them that way. Why is the idea of sub-personal cognition held to be incoherent? At this point, different anti-cognitivists give different answers. But their various arguments tend to fall into one of a very few categories.
One line of attack is this: there can be no such thing as a ‘private language.’ Sub-personal cognition would make use of just such a language. (Cognition obviously involves the processing of information; and information must be mediated. Anything mediating information is ipso facto a language [Dennett (1978) and Fodor (1975)]. Obviously the sub-personal processes posited by e.g. Chomsky and Marr are not inter-personal: they are intrapersonal. So they involve intra-personal, i.e. private, languages.) So such
[24]
cognition is an impossibility. [JK1] We will soon enough discuss at some length why private languages are held to be impossible [Wittgenstein (1999)].
[25]
Another line of attack on cognitivism is this. Supposing that there are sub-personal cognitive processes, who is doing this processing? Not the person in whose mind they occur: for, by hypothesis, they underlie his cognitive performances. (Surely you do not perform the computations that supposedly mediate between the disturbance of your retinae by various photons and you’re your subsequent visual perception. These computations are done in your mind, but not by you: they are sub-personal.) There cannot be cognition without a cognizers. So the cognizers is some ‘homunculus’. But then his cognitive performances have to be explained. If we are cognitivists about his mental activity, then a vicious regress threatens. On the other hand, if we are not cognitivists about his mental activity, then we are conceding that we don’t need cognitivism to explain mental activity. (See Appendix 1.)
Yet another attack on cognitivism is this: the very idea of sub-conscious — let alone sub-personal (‘deeply unconscious’) — processes is absurd. It is a contradictio in adjecto to speak of non-conscious mental phenomena; the essence of mentality is consciousness. The kinds of processes posited by cognitive scientists are sub-conscious. Indeed they are deeply unconscious:
unlike the contents of the Freudian unconscious, they cannot be made
[26]
conscious. So the very idea of such processes is an absurd one. (See Appendix 2.)
For reasons of space, I will only be able to provide a substantive response[JK2] the first of these arguments (though I briefly deal with each of these arguments in the appendices)[JK3]. As I will try to show, one error in it is the idea that the sub-personal cognition posited by cognitive scientists necessarily involves a private language. The existence of a language, I will show, presupposes that users of that language have some independent access to the meanings borne by at least some of the expressions of that language. So if indeed there is sub-personal cognition — and I will try to show that there must be — it is not mediated through a language. Therefore, even if
(what is doubtful) there can’t be a private language, that has no bearing on
[27] [28]
	whether cognitivism is correct or not. 
II. WITTGENSTEINIAN PRELIMINARIES
Years before Brandom, Wittgenstein held (i) that what we call ‘grasping’
[29]
propositions really consists in knowing a language and (ii) that one must be a member of a community to know a language. Brandom’s reasons for holding (i) and (ii) draw heavily on Wittgenstein’s reasons for holding them.
So let me set forth Wittgenstein’s reasons before I set forth Brandom’s.
Wittgenstein’s reasons for holding both of these views are to be found in his so-called ‘Rule Following’ and ‘Private Language’ arguments.
 
The Rule Following Argument
Suppose that you grasp some rule; suppose, for example, that you grasp the rule that is expressed by the symbol ‘Fx=2x’. Let R be this rule. Obviously if you don’t know how to apply R to particular values of x, then you can’t be said to truly grasp R. If you don’t know, or cannot readily figure out, that F(3)=6, then surely you don’t really grasp R. So grasping R consists in, or at least involves, knowing how to apply it to particular cases.
How are you to know how to apply R? How are you to know, e.g., what F(37) is? Unquestionably there are correct and incorrect ways of applying R. (You are applying R correctly if you conclude that F(37)=74; incorrectly if you conclude that F(37)=80.) Let us suppose for a moment that there is such a thing as ‘grasping R in a flash’, as ‘beholding’ or ‘intuiting’ R; and let us suppose that you have managed to do this. In other words, let us assume, for argument’s sake, that Plato was right: we grasp propositions (and a fortiori rules) through some analogue of perception. Surely, in intuiting R, you did not behold absolutely every instance of this rule; you did not behold that F(980)=1960. In any case, even if you did behold this particular application of R, there were others that you didn’t behold. So you didn’t behold every ordered pair constituting this function. Most, if not all, of these pairs were given to you only implicitly, i.e. they were given to you only in the sense that you grasped some rule that paired off the appropriate x’s with the appropriate y’s. So you do not know that F(980)=1960 merely in virtue of knowing R. Knowing R only enables you to figure this out. What would it be to figure this out? It would be to apply R to some particular case; and this, in turn, would be to interpret R. By itself, your knowledge of R is inert: you must figure out that F(980)=1960; you must interpret R; you must bring your knowledge of R to bear on some particular case. Rules are like maps: maps don’t tell you where to go: you figure out where to go by consulting a map. Similarly, you figure out that F(980)=1960 by consulting R.
But not just any interpretation of R will do; some interpretations are right and others are wrong. You must interpret R in some principled way; you must follow some kind of a rule in order to interpret R correctly. Let R2 be such a rule. What we said about R is true of R2. R2 tells you how to apply R1 to each of infinitely many situations. Obviously R2 doesn’t explicitly concern each of these situations: it only implicitly concerns them: so you must figure out how to apply R2 to each of these situations. Thus, you must know some rule that tells you how to apply R2. So one must grasp some rule R3 to know to apply R2. But what we said about R2 is true of R3. It is clear that we have launched ourselves on an infinite regress [Wittgenstein (1999), sections 139241].
What is this supposed to tell us? As I see it, there are two lessons that we can extract from this argument. (It isn’t clear to me whether these lessons are incompatible or, on the contrary, whether they are actually identical: the same message in two different forms.) The one message is this: the idea that we grasp norms — that we behold them in some way — leads to a vicious regress: we must grasp infinitely many norms to grasp a single one. Therefore there is no such thing as grasping norms: we simply aren’t aware of norms.
This lesson is, it seems, to me too radical. There is plainly some sense in which people are aware of norms; and Wittgenstein seems to concede this. So I think the right lesson to extract from the foregoing is this: we do grasp norms; but we don’t grasp them through some ‘intellectual intuition’; we don’t grasp them through some analogue of perception. The traditional view is this: we behold physical objects through the five senses; and we behold abstract ones through some sixth sense. Wittgenstein is trying to undermine this view: whatever it is to grasp norms, this grasping doesn’t have the ternary (subject-verb-object) structure that sense-perception (supposedly) has. In fact, in Wittgenstein’s view, grasping a norm is not a cognitive affair at all: the cognitivist account of norm-grasping, argues Wittgenstein, leads to a vicious regress.
What could it possibly mean to say that grasping a norm is not a ‘cognitive’ affair? For it seems self-contradictory to say that ‘grasping’ a norm is not a ‘cognitive’ affair. We can’t really answer this question until we set forth Wittgenstein’s positive account of what it is to grasp a norm: and once we do that, this thesis will start to seem a little less paradoxical. But in the meantime we can make a couple of clarificatory remarks. To have a sense-perception of an object is to have a mental ‘representation’ of that object in one’s mind. (In any case, this is the traditional analysis: significantly, it has been vigorously criticised in recent years by, among other, Wittgensteinians.) A ‘representation’ of an object is some kind of relatively discrete mental entity: a kind of icon or ‘inner’ counter-part to the external object in question. Wittgenstein rejects the idea that this model can be applied to our grasp of norms. Grasping a norm doesn’t consist in having some kind of internal icon corresponding to that norm. So given that grasping a norm doesn’t consist in being in possession of some ‘inner counterpart’ of that norm, what does it consist in? By way of anticipation, Wittgenstein’s answer is essentially this. Having an ability — e.g. knowing how to play tennis — doesn’t consist in being in possession of some mental icon; it consists in having certain dispositions. Similarly, grasping a norm doesn’t consist in having some mental icon that represents that norm; it consists in having certain dispositions. (Grasping a norm is more like being able to play tennis than it is like seeing a rock.) More specifically, grasping a norm in being disposed to act and think in ways that are consistent with that norm.
So grasping a norm is ‘non-cognitive’ in the sense that such a grasping doesn’t strictly speaking consist in being aware of anything: at least not in any sense even remotely comparable to that in which we are aware of things through sense-perception. Being aware of something seems to consist in being in possession of some representation of that thing. We do not grasp norms by being in possession of representations of them. So our grasp of them is in some important sense non-cognitive.
What Wittgenstein says about the question ‘how do we grasp norms?’ is supposed to apply to the question ‘how do we grasp propositions?’ (Actually, Wittgenstein is unclear about why, in his view, what he says the grasping of norms applies to the grasping of propositions. But it is clear that he does think that what we says about the former applies to the latter. What follows in the next few paragraphs is a reconstruction of Wittgenstein’s thinking, not a direct exegesis of it). This is because a proposition is a special kind of norm: a proposition is a kind of standard against which reality is compared. The proposition the dog at the cat constitutes a kind of norm to which I compare existing reality: if the dog did not the eat cat, then reality falls short of the norm; if the dog has eaten the cat, then reality has conformed to the norm.
