So we can think of a proposition as a kind of rule that assigns a truth-value to each of several different situations; in effect, a proposition is a rule assigns a false to a situation in which the dog has not eaten the cat, and a true to a situation in which the dog has eaten the cat. Given that propositions are rules or norms, it follows that what Wittgenstein says about norms applies to propositions: since we don’t grasp norms, we don’t grasp propositions.
This last line of thought no doubt requires elucidation. To grasp a proposition is to know what would make that proposition be true and what would make it be false. So to grasp a proposition is, in effect, to know some rule that assigns truth to some situations and falsity to others. The proposition the dog ate the cat is thus a rule that assigns truth to some situations and falsity to others. Let R be this rule. There are infinitely many qualitatively[JK4] different possible situations which make this proposition true, and infinitely many which make it false; there are infinitely many qualitatively[JK5] different possible states of affairs in which the dog has eaten the cat, and infinitely many in which the dog has not eaten the cat. Obviously R doesn’t explicitly concern each of these situations individually: R is not some infinitely long conjunction; it is not of the form situation S1 is assigned truth and S2 is assigned falsity and S3 is assigned truth…So R deals only implicitly with each of these possible situations. So to grasp R — that is, to know which truth-value it assigns to different situations — one must figure out how to apply R. Of course, one must be able to apply it in a principled — that is, a rule-governed — way. So to know how to grasp the first rule, one must grasp some second rule R2. But then what we said about the first rule applies to R2. R2 tells me how to apply R to each of infinitely many different situations. Obviously R2 cannot deal with each of these situations individually; R2 is surely not of the form R1 assigns truth to situation S1, and R2 assigns falsity to S2, and R2 assigns truth to S2…R2 deals only implicitly with each of these cases. So to grasp R2 — that is, to know how it applies to each of these situations — one must know how to apply it. Of course, must be able to apply it in a principled — that is, a rule-governed — way. So one needs to grasp some rule R3 to know how to grasp R2. Of course, what we said about R2 applies to R1: we have launched ourselves on an infinite and vicious regress.
Again, there are two ways to interpret this line of thought. The first is this: the idea that we grasp propositions is incoherent, as it leads to an infinite and vicious regress: so there is no such thing as grasping propositions. But this seems too radical, and it seems inconsistent with certain remarks Wittgenstein makes. So the right way to understand it is this: we do grasp propositions, but we don’t grasp propositions through some analogue of sense-perception. In fact, the grasping of propositions is not a cognitive affair at all.
What could it possibly mean to say that grasping a proposition is not a cognitive affair? Once again, we cannot fully answer this question until we set forth Wittgenstein’s account of what it is to grasp a proposition. But what we said a moment ago about norms applies here. Grasping a proposition does not, in Wittgenstein’s view, consist in being aware of anything. Being aware of something involves being in possession of some representation of that thing. And grasping a proposition doesn’t consist in having some inner representation of that proposition: it consists in having certain dispositions.
But before we can state the nature of these dispositions, we must address a problem that Wittgenstein’s anti-cognitivism leads to. Traditionally, it is thought that to understand a sentence S is to know what proposition to assign to that sentence: it is, in effect, to know some Tarski-biconditional — ‘snow is white’ is true just in case snow is white. But this conception seems to presuppose just the kind of ‘cognitivist’ account of what it is to grasp a proposition that Wittgenstein rejects. For presumably if one isn’t capable of representing a proposition to oneself — that is, if one is not able to have a proposition ‘in’ one’s mind — then a fortiori one cannot represent a Tarskibiconditional to oneself. So what answer does Wittgenstein give to the question: What is it for someone to understand a sentence?
His answer is basically this: Someone understands a sentence S when he knows how to use it. ‘But doesn’t someone’s knowing how to use a sentence correctly depend on his first grasping some proposition?’ No, says Wittgenstein. What a verbal symbol means is ultimately determined by when people use it; it is only people’s usage of a symbol that determines when it is correct to use it and thus what it means. So to know how to use a symbol, it is sufficient to use it in a way that is consistent with ‘communal forms of life’, i.e. that is consistent with other people’s usage of it. Basically, to understand a verbal symbol, e.g. a sentence, is to know how use it in a way that is consistent with conventional usage of it: to know a language is to be coordinated with other people in respect of when one uses certain symbols. So knowing a language consists not in grasping various Tarski-biconditionals — consists not in knowing that ‘Bob is true’ means Bob is tall — but in being sensitized to other people — in being acculturated in a certain way.
‘But this account suffers from circularity’, one might argue. ‘Wittgenstein says that one knows what S means when, and only when, one knows how to use S. This analysis is supposed to show that for one to ‘grasp a proposition’ isn’t for one to have some kind of intuition of a mysterious, other-worldly being, but only to be sensitized to certain behaviours. But to know how other use a symbol S is itself to know a proposition. So Wittgenstein explains what it is to grasp a proposition in terms of itself.’
This objection fails to distinguish between knowing-that and knowinghow. To know how to hit a baseball or to ride a bike is not to be in touch with
[30]
some proposition; it is simply to be competent in a certain way. Knowledge-how is not cognitive, i.e. it doesn’t involve a grasp of propositions. One can know how to ride a bicycle without knowing any propositions. There are no ontological mysteries associated with knowinghow. For Wittgenstein ‘knowing what S means’ is a kind of knowing-how, not a kind of knowing-that. To know what S means is to be co-ordinated with other people in a certain way; it is to be competent to play a certain communal game. Knowing how to box doesn’t consist in grasping certain propositions: it consists in knowing-how to react to certain situations; it consists in a certain kind of sensitivity, not a certain kind of cognitivity.
Analogously, knowing how to use a symbol is to have a certain kind of sensitivity, not cognitivity. If Wittgenstein were explaining what it is to know what S means in terms of some other kind of propositional knowledge — i.e. in terms of knowing-that — then his analysis of what it is to grasp a proposition would be circular. But he doesn’t; so it isn’t. (For the record, my own view is that knowing-how does reduce to knowing-that — that knowing how play the piano or do math does consist in internally representing various rules and is thus comparable to knowledge of a fact. To be sure, where knowledge-how is concerned, the internal representation is housed in a much deeper stratum of mental activity than where knowledge-that is concerned. But, apart from this, there is no structural difference between knowing-how and knowing-that. So I will presently argue, in any case.)
Let us sum up. For Wittgenstein, to know what S means is to know how to use S; and to know how to use S is simply to co-ordinated with other people in a certain, pre-cognitive way. Grasping a proposition is not a matter of having certain intuitions, but only of having certain kinds of sensitivity to the symbol-producing behaviour of one’s brethren.
If Wittgenstein’s analysis is correct, it is inconceivable that one should grasp a proposition prior to knowing a language; for grasping a proposition
[31]
consists solely in knowing a language.
The Private Language Argument
Now we must ask: why does Wittgenstein hold that one must be a member of a community to speak a language? Couldn’t one know a ‘private language’? Couldn’t one invent a language of one’s own, and grasp propositions by knowing how to use sentences belonging to that language? Wittgenstein’s answer is: no. His reason for holding this lies in his ‘Private Language Argument.’ What is this argument?
For an expression S to have meaning, there must be correct and incorrect ways of using it. If it is correct to use S under any circumstances, then S will be infinitely ambiguous and therefore meaningless. This is the idea underlying the alleged impossibility of a private language: an expression belonging to a private language can be used in any way with impunity; therefore, in effect, any way of usage such an expression is right; and, consequently, any such expression is infinitely ambiguous and thus meaningless.
Suppose someone tries to invent a private language of his own. By a ‘private’ language I mean a language that is not simply a translation of some existing public language. Obviously I could invent a private language by translating words of English into words that I come up with. What I wish to consider now is: Could someone invent a language of his own that was not merely a translation, an isomorph, of some existing public language? Could someone who did not already have a word meaning cat undertake to assign this meaning to some sound-type? Let us suppose that someone could to see if any contradiction or absurdity follows. Let us suppose that someone (call him ‘Fred’) who did not already speak a language considered some sound — say ‘blark’ — and stipulated that ‘blark’ was to mean cat; and then considered some other sound — say ‘snark’ — and stipulated that this was to mean dog; and so on. Of course, Fred will have to do more than assign referents to certain sounds; he must also (e.g.) assign meaning to grammatical devices (an example of a ‘grammatical device’ would be adding s to a noun to pluralize it); he must also give meaning to non-lexical terms (terms like ‘not’, ‘or’, ‘if’): basically, Fred will have to assign meaning to each of several primitive symbols, and he will also have to lay down recursive rules that specify the meanings of complex expressions of his language in terms of the meanings of these simple expressions.
Let us suppose Fred does all of this, and that he thereby creates a fairly rich language for himself. Let L be this language. Let us suppose that Fred records his thoughts in a diary, and that the states these thoughts in L. If Fred uses a particular sentence S, how will know that he has used it correctly? To what standard will he appeal?
If a member of a linguistic community uses or interprets an expression incorrectly, there are consequences. If I turn right when it says ‘no right turn’, I will be given a ticket. If I ask for ‘chocolate’ when I really want vanilla, I will not get what I want. Basically, if I use an expression incorrectly there are negative consequences; and these consequences are imposed on me by other people. Fred uses L only to communicate with himself; so no one besides Fred will punish his incorrect uses of expressions of L. But whenever Fred uses some expression of L, he will always think that he is using it correctly. He has only his own opinion as to whether he is using such an expression correctly. As a matter of logic, Fred can’t really consider his own opinion to be wrong. (If you consider some opinion to be wrong, then it isn’t your opinion, even if it used to be.)
Of course, there will be some fact of the matter. Fred’s original definitions may be such that, according to those definitions, S means ‘I saw a cat today’, even though Fred currently takes S to mean ‘I killed a dog today.’ But of what consequence would these original definitions be? These definitions form a part of L only in so far as they have some effect on how expressions belonging to L are used; and they have such an effect only through the medium of Fred’s opinion as to what these original definitions were. Fred’s opinion will be no less efficacious when it is dead wrong than when it is right. So these definitions would be idle. (Even though they might have been a part of Fred’s language in the past, they are no longer such.) Only Fred’s opinions will be effective. Consequently, expressions of L will mean whatever Fred thinks they mean. Since Fred is the only user of L, and since Fred will always think that he is using a given expression correctly, it follows that expressions of L cannot be used incorrectly. This in turn means that these expressions will be completely ambiguous and therefore meaningless. So a private language is an absurdity. Only a creature that belongs to a community can speak a language: for only a public rule has the stability — the imperviousness to this or that person’s mistaken opinions — characteristic of a true rule [Wittgenstein (1999), pp. 243-71].
 
Brandom’s View
Why does Brandom hold (i) that we must know a language to grasp propositions and (ii) that we must be members of a community to know a language? His reasons are close to Wittgenstein’s. The individual cannot privately grasp rules or therefore propositions, as the rule-following and private language arguments supposedly show [Brandom (1998), pp. 18-22]. Norms are embodied in communal linguistic practices: it is here that they are initially ‘made real’ [Brandom (1998), pp. 34-46]. These norms cannot be embodied in the practices of a ‘private linguist’, as Wittgenstein, to Brandom’s mind, has shown. So for the individual to grasp norms and therefore propositions, it is necessary that the individual enter into these practices [Brandom (1998), p. 53].
At this point Brandom goes a little bit beyond Wittgenstein. It is certainly necessary to be in step with others, in a certain way, to know a language and, therewith, to grasp propositions. But is it sufficient? Care must be taken to avoid the fallacy of regularism, the view that a creature is really governed by some kind of norm so long as it is acting as if it were governed by that norm. A person can be ‘in step’ with others, at least as far as his overt behaviour is concerned, without thereby being governed by any norms: he could just be a zombie who, without being conscious of anything (let alone norms), speaks and acts as though he grasped the relevant norms. So falling into step with others is not enough to convert a creature that is oblivious to norms into one that is governed by them [Brandom (1998), pp. 40-41]. What else is required?
According to Brandom, norms are ‘implicit’ in the activity of certain social groups, and people that are not yet governed by norms come to be governed by norms by entering into these groups. How does this happen exactly? The group rewards the individual for following the relevant norms and punishes him for disobeying them. (The group does not always know that this is what it is doing: after all, the group has only an ‘implicit’ awareness of its own norms.) As a result of this conditioning, the individual assimilates the norms that are embodied in the group’s behaviour; these norms become his norms [Brandom (1998), pp. 42-46].
Why, in Brandom’s view, are norms initially implicit rather than explicit in the group-psyche? Brandom thinks that the rule-following argument is sound and that, consequently, were one to suppose an explicit awareness of norms to be antecedent to an implicit awareness of them, this would lead to a vicious regress: an explicit awareness of a rule (or, more generally, a proposition) R1 needs to be supplemented by some awareness of some rule R2 — otherwise one won’t know how to apply R1 — and an explicit knowledge of R2 needs, in its turn, to be supplemented by a knowledge of some rule R3, and so on ad infinitum [Brandom (1998), pp. 18-21, also pp.
26-30].
With regard to the doctrine that one must grasp rules explicitly to be governed by them, Brandom refers to this doctrine regulism. The rulefollowing argument, thinks Brandom, shows that regulism is false [Brandom (1998), pp. 18-21]. But at the same time, as we have already remarked, in order for one’s thought and behaviour to be norm-governed, one must have some kind of awareness of rules. So, reasons Brandom, this awareness must be implicit, not explicit. But as we know, according to Brandom, one cannot have such an awareness privately: one must be a member of a community. So, Brandom concludes, it is ultimately communities that have this awareness (individuals have it only by virtue of their participating in communal practices); and, once again, this awareness must, initially at least, be implicit. In a word, awareness of norms is ‘implicit’ in a community’s practices (in particular, in its linguistic practices); and the individual acquires such awareness by becoming a member of a community — in particular, by participating in its linguistic practices [Brandom (1998), pp. 37-46].
Let us sum up. What is Brandom’s answer to the question: how do individuals come to be aware of norms? It is this. They enter into groups that, collectively, have an implicit awareness of these norms. The individual is punished for behaving in ways proscribed by the relevant norms, and rewarded for behaving in ways mandated by them; and this somehow makes him aware of these norms.
III. CRITICISMS
Both Wittgenstein and Brandom agree that it is not possible to grasp meanings or rules prior to knowing some language. This position, I will now try to show, leads to an untenable analysis of linguistic competence and, indeed, of every type of cognitive competence.
Suppose that, by all appearances, Joe is a good mathematician; he consistently solves hard problems. A cognitive psychologist, like Chomsky, would explain this by saying that Joe has an ‘implicit grasp’ of some set of rules or principles which he brings to bear on particular problems. (In this, cognitive psychology would probably be in agreement with common sense, so far as the latter has any opinion on the matter.)
But this kind of explanation would not be satisfactory to everyone. Some would regard it as defective on methodological grounds: it explains the obscure by the more obscure; a certain kind of competence is ‘explained’ by positing an utterly mysterious ‘inner condition.’ This is, we are told, like explaining the soporific properties of opium by ascribing a ‘dormitive virtue’ to it.
As we have seen, Wittgenstein has a more specific reason for deploring this kind of explanation: no mental state or condition can possibly constitute a grasp of a rule; no mental state can have such scope. Brandom accepts Wittgenstein’s view. So Brandom and Wittgenstein identify the grasping of propositions with the having of dispositions. They reject the ‘perceptual model’ of what it is to grasp a proposition; they reject the idea that grasping a proposition consists in having some internal representation of that proposition. This leads them to identify the grasping of a proposition with the having of dispositions.
But how are these philosophers to account for the fact that Joe consistently solves difficult problems? In what, according to them, does his mathematical competence consist? They reject the idea that Joe’s mathematical competence consists in his grasping certain truths. So in what is that competence supposed to consist? There is only one line they can take: Joe’s competence consists solely in his having certain dispositions to act a certain way or to have certain mental states. Joe is disposed to make certain noises or to have certain awareness; and his understanding consists entirely in these dispositions.
Of course, by hypothesis, these dispositions do not spring from any underlying grasp of rules: if one says that a disposition springs from a grasp of a proposition, one is barred from identifying the disposition with the grasping of the proposition. The dispositions are cognitive rock-bottom. To be a good pianist, a good poet, a good mathematician — to have any kind of cognitive competence — is to have certain dispositions, and that the dispositions in question do not rest on top of some kind of cognizance of rules: the dispositions are the cognizance in question.
This last qualification is crucial. The purpose of dispositionalist analyses is to eliminate the need to hypothesize some kind of ‘inner representation’ of rules or propositions. So a dispositionalist analysis cannot say that the dispositions in question exist because of such a representation. In so far as one has any kind of representation of a proposition, the dispositions are that representation. The dispositions are one’s cognizance of the proposition.
I should clarify an important component of the foregoing line of thought.
Wittgenstein and Brandom make the inference from ‘grasping a proposition (or, more generally, a norm) doesn’t consist in having an internal representation of that norm’ to ‘grasping a proposition (or rule) consists entirely in the having of dispositions of some kind.’ What is the warrant for this inference? Any kind of cognitive competence expresses itself entirely in various productions — in various behaviours and mental contents. Suppose we reject the idea that these various productions emanate from some understanding — that is, from a grasp of propositions. In that case, we are obviously barred from explaining these productions in terms of the operation of reasons and motivations. For these reasons and motivations would inevitably incorporate just the kind of ‘cognitive’ grasp of propositions that Wittgenstein and Brandom believe not to be possible: these reasons and motivations would inevitably be such that it would not be possible to conceive of them except as just being, or at least involving, representations of propositions. An illustration may help. Joe is asked ‘if Fred has two apples, and Mary has two apples, then how many apples to Fred and Mary have collectively?’. Joe says ‘4 apples.’ Obviously one explanation of Joe’s conduct is this: Joe internally represents some arithmetical proposition and, on the basis of the content of that representation, is motivated to produce what he perceives to be the correct response. Obviously Joe’s response betokens some kind of disposition: a disposition to respond with certain outputs to certain inputs. This is uncontroversial. But this disposition is grounded in some representation of a proposition: the disposition is not cognitive rock-bottom. No — what is cognitive rock-bottom is some kind of internal representation of a proposition; and the disposition emanates from this disposition. This is the view I wish to defend; and it is the traditional view.
But Wittgenstein and Brandom cannot take this view. So they have set themselves a difficult task: they must explain why (e.g.) Fred says ‘four’ after hearing ‘what is 2+2?’ Now unquestionably Fred’s responding with that output to that input expresses some kind of disposition: that is undeniable. In general, any performance that betokens cognitive competence obviously corresponds to some kind of disposition. In virtue being a competent pianist, one has a disposition to play certain notes at certain times. In virtue of being a competent mathematician, one has a disposition to give certain answers to certain questions. This is not controversial. What is controversial is whether these dispositions are grounded in internal representations of rules of some kind: what is controversial is whether these dispositions radiate from some inner grasp of a proposition. As we’ve seen, Wittgenstein and Brandom say: No — this disposition doesn’t radiate from an internal representation of a proposition. Given that it doesn’t radiate from an internal representation of a proposition, it would seem to follow that it doesn’t radiate from any internal representation. What kind of representation could possibly do the job in question besides a representation of a proposition? What kind of representation other than a representation of some general rule could possibly ground or validate the multifarious dispositions associated with, say, musical or linguistic or mathematical competence. Surely none. Indeed, it seems that no kind of mental content — whether a representation or not — other than a representation of a proposition could ground the various dispositions associated with a given type of cognitive competence. So if anything mental grounds the dispositions associated with a kind of cognitive competence, it must surely be a representation of some general proposition or rule. So, since Wittgenstein and Brandom reject the idea that there are such representations, they are forced to see the dispositions in question as ungrounded: as cognitive rock-bottom. So for Wittgenstein and Brandom to have a kind of cognitive competence is not to have dispositions that are grounded in a grasp of propositions or rules: it is just to have disposition; it is to have dispositions that are not in any way grounded. The dispositions are rock-bottom. To sum up, given their anti-Platonist epistemology, Wittgenstein and Brandom must take a dispositionalist view of (e.g.) mathematical competence; and this is just the view that they do take.
But is such a ‘dispositionalism’ about cognitive competence tenable? No. There are a couple of different reasons for this. The first reason must be set forth in stages. To begin with, everyone — including Brandom and Wittgenstein — must concede that if Joe’s saying ‘4’ is to betoken any kind of cognitive competence at all, then it must have some mental cause. If a creature’s performances are the result of purely physical dispositions (by ‘purely physical’ I mean ‘lacking a mental dimension altogether’), then those performances would be the work of a robot. Even hard-line materialists hold that physical processes must have a mental dimension if they are to qualify as cognitive.
To be sure, materialists hold that a physical process qualifies as mental wholly in virtue of its physical characteristics. But every materialist holds that if a physical process does not qualify as mental, then it is not cognitive: it does not embody understanding of any kind. So some kind of mental activity must mediate between Joe’s being stimulated in a certain way (his seeing, e.g., the following inscription on a piece of paper: 2+2=?) and his subsequently acting a certain way (his writing 4): even Wittgenstein and Brandom will concede this.
But — this takes us to the next stage of the argument — not just any kind of mental mediation will do: the mental states intervening between stimulus and response must be such that, by virtue of having those mental states, Joe’s response embodies some kind of understanding of the stimulus.
Suppose that after seeing the inscription 2+2=? Joe has a variety of mental states: he is joyful, then melancholy, then he feels a tickle, then he has an itch; let us also suppose that he has no mental states besides these. After having these mental states, Joe ends up writing 4; it may even have been one of these states that caused Joe to write this. To be sure, Joe is not a complete robot; after all, robots don’t feel joy or melancholy. But Joe’s performance was still robotic because, although it had a mental cause, it didn’t have the right kind of mental cause. A performance that has a mental cause is not, on that account alone, cognitive or non-robotic. (By ‘cognitive’ I mean ‘embodying understanding or a grasp of a proposition.’) If Joe has been trained by a hypnotist to write 4 every time he sees 2+2=?, then Joe cannot be said to have solved any problem if, on some particular occasion, he writes 4 after seeing 2+2=?. So what kinds of mental states of affairs must mediate between stimulus and response — between seeing 2+2=? and writing 4 — if Joe is to be said to have solved a problem of mathematics? The answer is obvious: some kind of understanding must intervene. In so far as no understanding intervenes, Joe’s response is ‘robotic.’ But if we say that understanding mediates between Joe’s seeing 2+2=? and writing 4 then we have given up on dispositionalism. Joe has the right response because he understands the input he is given. So Joe’s disposition to have the right response is grounded in understanding. Thus understanding grounds the disposition; the disposition does not ground the understanding. Put another way, a disposition that is not grounded in understanding is ‘robotic’. But once we concede that a disposition must presuppose the presence of understanding if that disposition is to qualify as a kind of cognitive competence, then we are obviously giving up on the idea that dispositions ground understanding — we are giving up on the idea that to have understanding, to have a kind of cognitive competence, just is to have a disposition of some sort.
There is a second reason to reject dispositionalism, at least as a general explanation of cognitive competence. A good mathematician, like Joe, is able to solve an indefinitely extensible class of problems. Ascribing one disposition to Joe won’t even come close to accounting for his mathematical performances. If my knee is struck a certain way, my leg jerks: that is an example of a disposition. So supposing that we are dispositionalists about cognitive competence, then we must say that Joe’s mathematical competence comprises, not just one, but several dispositions. But will any finite number of dispositions suffice? A good mathematician is always able to assimilate new principles and techniques. There isn’t any pre-set limit to the variety of such principles and techniques. So we would have to ascribe an infinite number of different dispositions to any good mathematician. Actually, we’d have to do the same for anyone who had mastered so much as grade school arithmetic: for no two mathematical problems, no matter rudimentary, are quite alike. (If they were completely alike, then there would only be one problem, not two.) So one disposition can enable Joe to solve, at most, one problem. So we end up having to postulate an infinite number of different dispositions to Joe. But how do we explain the fact that Joe just happens to have all these dispositions? If we account for this by saying that all these dispositions flow from some underlying grasp of mathematical principles, then their existence is totally intelligible. But if we deny that there is any such underlying representation, then every time we postulate a disposition to explain how Joe solves problem, this postulate is completely ad hoc.
Any kind of cognitive competence is associated with infinitely many different dispositions. The disposition associated with one’s saying ‘5’ in response to hearing ‘what is 2+3’ is obviously not identical with the disposition associated with one’s saying ‘4’ in response to ‘what is 2+2’. But just as obviously these dispositions are connected with each other. Now if we say that the definitions are one’s mathematical competence, then we are saying that these various dispositions are not grounded in anything and, therefore, that they are not grounded in the same thing: so if we are dispositionalists about e.g. mathematical competence, then we end up saying that the various dispositions associated with such competence are not connected to each other: Joe’s disposition to say ‘4’ after hearing ‘what is 2+2’ becomes unrelated to his disposition to say ‘5’ after hearing ‘what is 2+3’. But it is patently obvious that these dispositions are connected: what connects them is that they emanate from some common source: some underlying understanding binds them. Since the understanding underlies them, it cannot be identical with them.
The basic problem with the dispositionalist view is that it tries to assimilate the normative to the causal order. Joe’s performances can, without artifice, be mapped onto some normative order. If we ascribe an understanding of this order to Joe, then this isomorphism is explicable. But if we deny that Joe has any such understanding, then this isomorphism is pure happenstance. But it obviously isn’t pure happenstance.
Given that we cannot ‘dispositionalize’ mathematical competence, how are we to explain it? It is true that mathematical competence comprises an infinite number of dispositions. It is also true, as we’ve just seen, that mathematical competence doesn’t consist of such dispositions. For these dispositions must have a common ground; and if they are the mathematical competence, there will be no such ground. Clearly what we must say is that mathematical competence consist in internal representations of mathematical principles, and that it these internal representations that provide the common ground for, and source of, the aforementioned multiplicity of dispositions.
IV. THESE CRITICISMS EXTENDED
Now I would like to show that what we have said about cognitive competence generally applies to linguistic competence specifically.
On Wittgenstein’s view, knowing a language does not consist, even in part, in knowing rules; for according to Wittgenstein, one must know a language in order to grasp rules. (For Wittgenstein, we know rules by way of knowing language. The traditional view — the Chomsky/Tractatus view — is that we know language by way of knowing rules. I am trying to defend the latter view.) But knowing a language certainly seems to presuppose a knowledge various rules: it seems to consist in, or at least involve, knowing rules like: ‘snow is white’ means snow is white. We easily understand sentences that they have never encountered before. The obvious explanation of this is to say that we have internalized some set of rules saying how sentencemeanings result from word-meanings: that we have internal representations of some rules and that these representations guide us in assigning meaning to sentences that we haven’t heard before. Michael Dummett puts this point very well:
The fact that anyone who has a mastery of any given language is able to understand an infinity of sentences of that language, an infinity which is, of course, principally composed of sentences which has never heard before...can hardly be explained otherwise than by supposing that each speaker has an implicit grasp of a number of general principles governing the use in sentences of words of the language [Dummett (1978)].
Wittgenstein-Brandom cannot countenance this point of view. So how would Wittgenstein-Brandom account for our being able to understand sentences we have never encountered before? He must say that we are simply disposed to have certain reactions to them; that we are disposed to have certain mental and behavioural reactions to them: it is just some structural property of our minds or brains — some property that doesn’t embody cognizance of norms — that induces us to react with the right sentences to new situations and with the right mental contents to new sentences.
This is surely untenable. If we haven’t grasped the relevant rules, then how is it that we so frequently have the right reactions to new sentences? What would account for our dispositions’ so often being the right ones unless these dispositions were themselves the results of some deeper awareness of norms? It seems that, unless we were aware of the relevant norms or rules, we wouldn’t have the right dispositions.
You frequently talk of having the right reactions to sentences, and of producing the right sentence under a given set of circumstances (i.e. of having the right linguistic reaction to a given set of circumstances). But right relative to what? Your argument against a dispositionalist analysis of mathematical competence made some sense because there is a body of objective mathematical truths: consequently, if a dispositionalist analysis of our mathematical competence were correct, then it would be a miracle that our dispositions so frequently resulted in our having the right beliefs about this domain. But is there any domain of grammatical truths? Surely not. If everyone believe that the twice two were five, this belief would not, on that account, be correct. But if everyone regarded as grammatical the sentence ‘John Mary loved’ (meaning: John loved Mary) then this sentence would, on this account, be correct. So your criticisms of the dispositionalist view of mathematical competence do not transfer over to a viable criticism of linguistic competence.
This objection ultimately doesn’t carry much weight. It is true that, if everyone said ‘John Mary loved’ instead of ‘John loved Mary’ then the former would be grammatical while the latter wouldn’t be. But grammaticality is a property of an infinite number of sentences of any given language; linguistic behaviour can directly result in only a finite number of sentences’ being grammatical. Linguistic behaviour does indeed result in an infinite number of sentences’ being grammatical. But it does this only indirectly, i.e. it does this through the mediation of rules — rules that are projected somehow from those linguistic productions whose correctness is directly determined by human conduct. These rules constitute the standard against which it is to be determined whether a person’s linguistic productions are appropriate to a given situation and whether a person’s intellectual productions are appropriate given a particular linguistic stimulus. So it does make sense to talk of right and wrong linguistic productions, just as much as it does to talk of right and wrong mathematical productions.
But mathematical rules aren’t arbitrary. The commutative law for addition is a fact. By contrast, grammatical rules are arbitrary. How can it make sense to speak of right and wrong relative to an arbitrary set of rules?
It is true that in mathematics the rules are not arbitrary, whereas in grammar they are. But this is irrelevant. Given that certain grammatical rules are in place, it makes perfectly good sense to speak of right and wrong linguistic productions. It is a hard fact that 2+2=4 and that 2+2¹5. It is just as hard a fact that, given the rules of English grammar, the sentence ‘if Smith weren’t so parsimonious, he would enjoy life more’ is grammatically correct.
Consider the class of expressions that have actually been produced. There
is an infinite number of different grammars that can be projected from these expressions. So one person’s linguistic productions are no more right or wrong than the next person’s. If Joe says ‘me no love Mary’, he cannot be said to be wrong, only deviant (in a statistical, not a normative, sense). Similarly, if Joe takes ‘I love Mary’ to mean ‘I want to have a blue suit’, he can only be said to have extrapolated in a non-standard way from a give set of data. So there is no right and no wrong where linguistic productions are concerned.
This objection virtually answers itself. It is true, as the objector points out, that the rules that we project from linguistic behaviours are arbitrary; different rules could be projected from them. There is no reason why, given how people’s actual linguistic behaviour, a grammar could be projected, from this behaviour, whereby ‘I love Mary’ meant I want to have a blue suit. But this isn’t the projection that is in fact operative; certain rules are projected and not others. Given these rules, it is a hard fact that ‘I love Mary’ means I love Mary and not I want a blue suit. Given these rules, certain linguistic and intellectual productions are right and others are wrong. The fact that some other set of rules, some other grammar, could have been projected is irrelevant.
It is a fact that a certain grammar has been countenanced. When we talk about rightness and wrongness in people’s linguistic productions, we mean rightness and wrongness relative to this grammar. Consider the sentence ‘if Alfred were more easy-going, and if he had little more money, he would be capable of enjoying a quick trip to Naxos.’ I know that this sentence is perfectly grammatical. I don’t have to go out and examine people to determine this. I know right now that every English person I might query (with some obvious and irrelevant exceptions — e.g. people with certain cognitive defects) would agree with me that this sentence was grammatical. I know this because I know that all these people countenance one grammar and not some different one. There is no other way that I could know this. If people were not law-like in their linguistic productions and in their intellectual responses to linguistic productions, then I’d have no way of knowing whether they would regard a given sentence as grammatical or not. But you and I are both unerring in our judgement as to what people of our dialect of English will regard as grammatical, even where sentences that no one has ever heard before are concerned; and this is possible only because people are law-like in their linguistic behaviour. Straight induction off of people’s linguistic behaviour wouldn’t enable us to do this (by ‘straight’ induction I mean induction that didn’t involve imputing a cognizance of rules to people); we can predict people’s linguistic behaviour only by imputing to them cognizance of a certain rules and by ascribing causal efficacy to this cognizance. The dispositionalist account of linguistic competence cannot account for this law-likeness, this predictability, in people’s linguistic behaviour.
Basically, there is a grammar that people in fact conform to, whether cognizance of this grammar is causally efficacious in people’s conduct or not. (This grammar is not all that hard to state, at least in rough outline; every elementary school grammar book does a passably good job.) It would be an utter miracle if (i) people’s linguistic behaviour were such that it could be described as though people were following these rules, even though (ii) they were not in fact in following these rules (or at least some rules isomorphic thereto). Basically, in order to explain the isomorphism between the normative and the actual order — between what people do and what, given a certain grammar, they ought to do — it is necessary to suppose that some kind of cognizance of the normative order (in this case a grammar) is responsible for people’s productions. What we said about dispositionalism as an analysis of mathematical competence applies to dispositionalism as an analysis of linguistic competence.
Also, to echo a point made earlier, if my ability to speak English consisted in my having various dispositions that weren’t bound together by some kind of internal representations of rules, then these various dispositions would have no connection to each other: not being bound together by anything, it would be pure happenstance that they all co-existed. But they are not just fortuitously co-existence. I have a disposition to regard instances of the sentence-type ‘the dog ate the cat’ as well formed, and also to regard instances of the sentence-type ‘the mouse ate the tiger as well formed. These are obviously different dispositions. But just as obviously, they are connected. Now if my grasp of English were identical with my having so many dispositions, then nothing would underlie the two dispositions just mentioned: for those two dispositions would be cognitive rock bottom. Consequently those two dispositions would be unconnected to each other: indeed given any two of the dispositions associated with my grasp of English, they would be unconnected to each other, if we accept the dispositionalism of Wittgenstein and Brandom. But obviously these various dispositions are connected. Now what could possibly connect them — what could possibly provide a common ground for them — if not internal representations of the propositions that validate them?
V. WITTGENSTEINIAN-BRANDOMIAN COUNTER-OBJECTIONS[JK6]
If knowledge of rules doesn’t underlie, and thus pre-exist, knowledge of language, then knowledge of language consists entirely in having a lot of dispositions. But having a lot of dispositions doesn’t add up to having a grasp of meanings or, therefore, to being able to understand sentences. Pavlov’s dog doesn’t understand the ringing of the bell; it just reacts to it. Reacting to the sound ‘fire’ isn’t understanding it. Reactions that are not mediated through a grasp of concepts are not cognitive; they don’t betoken understanding.
In response to this, Wittgenstein could say that I have the situation backwards. What really happens is that we are first disposed to have certain reactions to certain sounds, and to react with certain sounds to certain situations, and we then elevate these de facto dispositions to the status of norms. In other words, there are first various mental and physical behaviours that embody no awareness of norms. But later on these behaviours are taken to embody norms. (For charity’s sake, we won’t ask how it is that normless creatures manage to convert some pre-normative practice into a normgoverned one. Surely a grasp of norms is required to pull this off.) A comparison might be illuminating. It is now de rigueur to buy presents for a friend on his birthday: one is violating a kind of law if one fails to do this. But it is quite conceivable that, a long time ago, people bought presents for their friends on their birthdays out of a spontaneous desire to them happy. So a behaviour that didn’t embody awareness of norms came to do so later on. Similarly, a long time ago people might simply have reacted to the presence of fire by blurting out ‘fire’. Later on, this behaviour was taken to be the appropriate reaction to fire.
This line of thought could, at most, explain why words like ‘fire’ mean what they do (though I will question this in a moment). But it definitely couldn’t explain why expressions like:
‘if Mr. Smith were to see this in his current condition, he would probably die of a heart attack, assuming he didn’t have his heart pills with him’
mean what they do. This expression has probably never been used before. So it is not only people’s usage of this expression that gives it its meaning. Of course, people would be disposed to use this sentence in response to certain kinds of situation. (It would be easy to think of a situation where you might be inclined to use this expression.)
Of course, it would certainly be correct to say that this sentence means what it does because of how people use the expressions occurring in it, even though no one has ever used that expression, as a whole, itself. But if that is true, then there must be rules saying how the meaning of complex expressions (like ‘if Mr. Smith saw this...’) results from combinations of simple expressions. Unless the meaning of ‘if Mr. Smith saw this...’ is to be fixed purely by convention — unless it means what it does because of when people happen to use that exact expression, taken as a whole — we are led back to the position that ability to understand certain expressions, namely complex ones, involves an implicit grasp of rules. This, of course, is just what Wittgenstein-Brandom cannot say.
A die-hard Wittgensteinian-Brandomian might contest this last point. He might say that this sentence (‘if Mr. Smith...’) means what it does because of when we would be disposed to use it. But people would be disposed to use this sentence only because they already knew a language; i.e. because they were already aware of some set of rules or norms and, in light of this awareness, they regarded a certain sentence as being appropriate to the circumstances. In general, people are disposed to use complex expressions when they do only because they already know a language. Most of our sound-producing behaviour presupposes a knowledge of language. So language is not just a lot of initially non-norm-governed sound-producing behaviour that becomes, in some mysterious way, norm-governed soundproducing behaviour. In particular, in so far as knowing a language involves knowing how to use complex expressions, then knowing a language is not reducible to having certain dispositions. So language cannot result entirely from pre-cognitive reactions. (By a ‘pre-cognitive’ reaction, I mean one that doesn’t result from awareness of norms.)
A Wittgensteinian-Brandomian might disagree with this last point; he might argue as follows. The basis of any language is just a lot of soundproducing behaviour elevated (in some way or other — we won’t ask how) to the status of norm-governed behaviour. (People used to say ‘fire’ when there was a fire nearby. At first they just did this: it wasn’t right or wrong. But then it came to be de rigueur to say this when, and only when, there was a fire nearby.) Although it is implausible to say that
‘Mr Smith would die of a heart-attack if he saw this, provided he didn’t have his part pills with him’
means what it does because people just blurt it out in certain situations, it is not implausible to assume that ‘fire’ means what it does because people just blurted it out in certain situations (though, by way of anticipation, we will see that this is false). Moreover, it is reasonable to assume that people have certain set reactions to combinations of blurtings. For example, people might just have a disposition to react a certain way to ‘fire and bear’ or to ‘no fire’ or to ‘if no fire then no hot meal’. These complex blurtings would, in some or way or other, be promoted to the level of norm-governed sound-productions, just like their simple counterparts: so just as ‘fire’ went from being a sound that people simply happened to produce to one that it was correct to produce; so ‘fire and bear’ went from being a sound that people simply would be disposed to produce to being one that it would be right to produce. If people had dispositions of this second class, then we could account for the meaningfulness of complex expressions without supposing that anyone had an implicit grasp of any rules: it would just be ‘dispositions all the way down.’
Is this tenable? No. It isn’t hard to see the problem with this analysis: we end up having to hypothesize an infinite hierarchy of dispositions, without these dispositions’ having any raison d’être other than that their existence enables us to hold on to some essentially a priori belief that it must be possible to explain linguistic competence without assuming that people have a pre-linguistic grasp of rules. To explain why people understand ‘bear and fire’, we have to hypothesize that people just happen to have a disposition to respond to ‘bear and fire’ the right way, even though they’ve never encountered this exact expression; and to explain why the end up why people respond the right way to ‘if bear and fire and spear, then bear-meat for dinner’ the right way, we end up having to posit another disposition; and so on, for each complex expression. If we assume, as Chomsky and Dummett do, that linguistic competence involves a pre-linguistic grasp of rules, then we have no trouble accounting for the existence of such dispositions: we have the right reactions because we grasp propositions and therefore know what the right reactions are. But if don’t make this assumption, then we have to impute an infinite number of dispositions to people, without having justification for so doing.
Let us sum up. There is no way to account for our being able to understand produce new sentence without assuming that we have some kind of pre-linguistic grasp of rules. So linguistic competence doesn’t just consist in having a lot of dispositions; for we couldn’t have the right dispositions without having a grasp of rules. This means that Wittgenstein’s rule following argument is not sound; for this argument is supposed to show that ability to follow rules is the product, not the cause, of the ability to speak a language.
VI. ANOTHER CRITICISM OF WITTGENSTEIN-BRANDOM
If Wittgenstein-Brandom is right, then to understand an expression is to be competent to use it in accordance with convention; and to be competent to use it in accordance with convention is to have certain dispositions: it is to react in certain ways to certain stimuli. (Wittgenstein-Brandom cannot say that to be competent to use an expression consists in grasping rules or meanings. He would incur a vicious regress if he said this. So he must say such competence consists in having certain blind dispositions.) But does having a lot of dispositions add up to understanding? What distinguishes us from Pavlov’s dog is specifically that our reactions to stimuli are, in at least some cases, mediated through awareness of norms. You could train a dog to believe that there was a fire nearby whenever it heard the sound ‘there’s a fire’: if you repeatedly burned it while saying ‘there’s a fire’, the dog would probably come to react to the sound ‘there’s a fire’ by bolting in terror. But, for all this, would the dog really understand the expression ‘there’s a fire’? Would ‘there’s a fire’ be an expression for the dog the way it is for us?
It seems not. Understanding a phenomenon — e.g. a tokening of a particular expression — consists in deriving its meaning from knowledge of rules or general truths: that is what understanding is. Understanding an expression — e.g. ‘there’s a rock’ — is knowing the rules that enable you to derive its meaning. This is obviously true of complex expressions. (For understanding a complex expression involves knowing how its meaning relates to that of its parts; and this involves a grasp of derivation-rules. If you are reacting to ‘thereisafire’, and not to ‘there is a fire’, then no matter what your reaction is, you do not understand the sound ‘there is a fire’.) But the same is true of simple expressions like ‘fire’. If you simply react to the sound
‘fire’, then this sound does not really represent an expression for you, even if
[32]
your reaction is superficially appropriate.
VII. THE MISSTEP IN THE RULE-FOLLOWING ARGUMENT
Why isn’t the rule following argument sound? What is the misstep in it? There are two. First, grasping a rule or concept involves grasping how to apply it; one doesn’t need to grasp a second rule or concept to know how to apply the first one. So no regress is generated. Knowledge of a rule contains — to some extent is — knowledge of how to apply that rule. Anyone who knows what a stop-sign means knows that, by the time his vehicle is a certain distance from one, he has to have stopped driving. Whenever such a person sees a stop sign, he doesn’t need to grasp some second-order rule to know how to apply his knowledge that he should stop; his knowing what the sign means contains — in fact, is — his knowledge that he should stop. It would be absurd to speak of someone who knew what stop signs meant but didn’t know, that when he saw a particular stop sign, he should stop his car. Wittgenstein’s regress-of-interpretations argument is generated by assuming that such a person could exist. But such a person couldn’t exist; so there is no regress.
Second: Expressions are ambiguous. But meanings are not ambiguous. (Ambiguity is a property of symbols, not of things symbolized.) One can misunderstand the sentence ‘grass is green’. But one cannot misunderstand the proposition expressed by this sentence. One either grasps this proposition or one doesn’t. The idea that rules can always be misapplied presupposes that rules are always given to one through some kind of language. But must they be? Why? Every person, at some point in his life, has had a thought that he couldn’t put into words. How would this be possible if one couldn’t grasp propositions directly, i.e. not through the medium of language? Of course, if it is possible to directly grasp meanings, then why not rules? (Rules are just a certain kind of meaning.) If one directly grasps rules, then these rules are not ambiguous for him; he cannot misapply them. For rules cannot be ambiguous, only the verbal expressions thereof. A fortiori we don’t have to suppose that public practice is what disambiguates rules — they are not in need of disambiguation.
In light of this point, we can, I believe, prove false a point made by Searle and several others [Searle (1992)]. According to Searle, Chomsky’s view that language learning is conditioned by a pre-linguistic grasp of rules is false. Why? Because, says Searle, it implies a vicious regress. Rules are only given to us in language. So to grasp some set of rules R1, I must already speak some language L1. If Chomsky is right, then to speak L1 I must grasp some set of rules R2; and to grasp R2, I must already know some language L2 (or some ‘homunculus’ within my mind must know L2); and so on ad infinitum.
Chomsky’s view doesn’t imply such a regress. For there is no reason, apart from a naturalistic prejudice, to suppose that rules need be given to one through language. So one could grasp R1 without having to know L2. ‘But doesn’t the rule-following argument show that rules need to be given through some language?’ No we’ve already shown the rule-following argument to have no validity — to falsely presuppose that there is a distinction between grasping a rule and knowing how to apply it. So, as far as I can tell, there is no legitimate to reject the idea that we internally represent propositions and, more generally, norms.
VIII. THE FLAW IN BRANDOM’S ARGUMENT
According to both Brandom and Wittgenstein, norms are creatures of society. Only after society creates them, do individuals internalize them and come to governed by them. For clarity’s sake, let us briefly revisit Brandom’s argument.
Let us suppose, along with Brandom, that the mental activity of pre-social creatures is in fact not governed by awareness of norms. Then how does a group of such creatures generate (or discover) norms? As Brandom himself realizes, it would not be enough for a group of such creatures to act in regular ways — e.g. to act in unison. The collective behaviour of group of molecules or robots might embody beautiful regularities; but this behaviour wouldn’t embody any consciousness of norms. So how would these creature get from having no awareness of norms to being norm-governed? Brandom’s answer is this: norms may be implicit in the collective behaviour of such creatures. Individuals come to be aware of norms by being integrated, in some way or other, into these collective practices.
Prima facie this answer is circular; it assumes the existence of norms in order to explain their existence. But Brandom thinks he has a way of avoiding circularity. Imagine the following. Every time it says ‘turn right’, I turn left. Whenever I do this, people beat me with sticks. (So far I am not conscious of norms.) Eventually, I start turning right when it says ‘turn right’. When I do this, I am given a hug. Through this regimen of positive and negative reinforcement, I figure out that ‘turn right’ means turn right. Norms were ‘implicit’ in people’s collective behaviour. They beat when I turn left and hugged me when I turned right. Their norms became my norms; I became aware of their norms [Brandom (1998), pp. 34-36].
This account is inadequate: depending on how it is interpreted, it is either circular, as it first appears, or it is based on non-sequitur. As we’ve noted, for Pavlov’s dog, the ringing of the bell doesn’t mean anything, at least not in the sense in which ‘dinner is served’ has meaning for us; the dog just reacts to the ringing of the bell. For a physical token to constitute a symbol, one must already be in possession of concepts: otherwise one is just reacting like Pavlovian dog to tokens of that symbol. So beating someone with a stick, thereby getting him to turn right when he sees signs marked ‘turn right’, won’t get someone to be aware of norms, unless he already has some latent awareness of norms. (Experience can articulate an existing awareness of norms, but it cannot create an awareness of norms where there was none beforehand.) Behavioural conditioning cannot turn a non-normative creature into a normative one; it can simply turn a creature whose behaviour obviously is not norm governed into one whose behaviour is like that of a normgoverned creature.
If no individuals are aware of norms, then awareness of norms cannot be implicit in the behaviour of any aggregate of individuals. A group of normless individuals is a normless group. Of course, this group may act as if it were aware of norms. But that is irrelevant. Brandom has avoided the fallacy of regularism in his analysis of the individual’s grasp of meaning only to commit this same fallacy in his analysis of the group’s awareness of meanings.
Your dismissal of Brandom’s position is much too brief. You say that society cannot be conscious of norms unless some individuals are conscious of norms. But wholes can have properties that none of their parts have. So your argument is based on a non sequitur. No individual neuron is
[33] conscious, but certain aggregates of neurons (brains) are conscious. Maybe, in an analogous way, society is conscious of norms even though no individual is (initially) conscious of norms.
So if Brandom’s analysis is correct, then societies are individuals in their own right, not just metaphorical or as-if individuals. For the sake of argument, let us grant Brandom this. How then does he explain how these super-individuals become conscious of norms? By Brandom’s reasoning, they would have to members of societies in their turn (societies of societies) to become conscious of norms. This would lead to an infinite regress; so it couldn’t possibly be correct. In any case, it is empirically false. (Societies are not members of societies of societies. Or even if they are, they certainly don’t acquire whatever consciousness they might have by belonging to these second-order societies.) Of course, Brandom could just say that societies are innately conscious of norms. But if he said that, he would be inconsistent with himself. If societies really are individuals — and surely they are such if they are aware of things that no individual is aware of (what better criterion of really being an individual could we ask for?) — then what Brandom says about individuals (in particular, that individuals must be members of societies to be aware of norms) applies to societies.
Of course, Brandom might say that societies are not really individuals, except in some irrelevant metaphorical sense. But then, as we have seen, he would have to reject the idea that societies are aware of things that no individual is aware of.
Depending on how he is interpreted, Brandom is making one of two claims. (i) A completely non-norm-governed creature can be turned into a norm-governed creature through some kind of behavioural conditioning that is imposed upon him by his brethren. (ii) Brandom says that individuals become aware of norms because norms are already ‘implicit’ in the social practices of its species.
Is (i) true? No. A creature that has no grasp of concepts can be made to act as if it understood the expression ‘roll over’. But it won’t really understand this expression; it will just react to it. So if this is the correct interpretation of Brandom’s argument, then Brandom’s argument is no longer circular, but it is based on a non-sequitur.
Is (ii) true? No. As we have seen, if by ‘implicit’, Brandom means ‘nonexistent’, then his analysis fails. (One ‘can’t bake a normative cake out of non-normative ingredients’, as Brandom himself says). On the other hand, if by ‘implicit’ Brandom means ‘existent in some way or other’, then his analysis is circular. Given a group of creatures who are oblivious to norms, be they people or molecules or billiard balls, the behaviour of these individuals, considered individually or collectively, may be like that of norm governed creatures; but it won’t really be that of norm governed creatures. In order for the group to be aware of norms, at least some of the individuals composing this group must be aware of norms. (Anyway, what does it mean to say that a group is aware of norms except that some of its members are aware of norms?) So, on this interpretation, Brandom is ‘explaining’ how individuals can be aware of norms only by assuming, at least implicitly, that some individuals are aware of norms.
In a word, given a group of creatures who are not, individually, aware of norms, there is no way that any of them will ever become aware of norms, no matter how they interact with each other. Awareness of norms is either there ab initio or it isn’t there at all.
IX. ANOTHER CRITICISM OF BRANDOM
As Brandom himself points out, according to Locke, Kant, and other classical philosophers, speaking is a kind of externalized thinking. Brandom, Wittgenstein, and Sellars say that thinking is a kind of internalized speaking. We have seen reason to believe that Brandom’s view is false. Given a creature who is completely oblivious to norms, concepts, and rules, there is no way to get it to become aware of these things: the best that can be done is to instil in it, through behavioural conditioning, a lot of dispositions to act as if it were aware of these things. The buck cannot be passed onto society. A society of normless individuals will itself be normless; it will be no different, in the relevant respects, from a bunch of robots. Saying that norms can be ‘implicit’ in a society of normless creatures is either false or questionbegging.
On the other hand, if per impossibile a group of normless individuals were, collectively, aware of some kind of norms, then it would have to explained how this individual (this super-individual) were aware of norms; and Brandom doesn’t explain this.
I have said many times that, unless a creature is already aware of rules, a sound cannot constitute an expression for that creature. For it is consciousness of rules that makes a mere sound into an expression for somebody. But why is this? Suppose that you are not aware of any rules, but that some sound (e.g. ‘fire’) makes you think about fire — as Pavlov’s bell made the dog expect dinner. To use a slightly modified version of one of Wittgenstein’s own examples: by ringing a bell or uttering a sound, you could cause a dog to expect dinner now; but you couldn’t cause it to expect dinner tomorrow, let alone three days from now or three days and two hours from now. Ordinary stimuli (by this I mean stimuli that are not tokens of expressions) have no internal structure or articulations. By contrast, sentences are articulate, as Wittgenstein himself said early in his career; they have internal structure; they are built up in stages. Sentences are not homogeneous blocks; their parts stand in significant relations to one another; the meaning of the whole is a function of the meanings of its parts. Through a kind of Pavlovian training, you could train a dog to react differently to different stimuli. You could train to expect dinner when it heard the sound ‘dinner time’, to fear fire when it heard the sound ‘fire’, to fear choking on smoke when it heard ‘smoke’, to attack when it heard ‘attack’; and so on. But you couldn’t compound these Pavlovian expressions into complex parts. If the dog heard ‘smoke, fire, attack’, it wouldn’t be reacting to the compound sentence ‘there’s smoke, and there’s fire, and I want you to attack’; it would just be reacting to ‘smoke’, and then to ‘fire’, and then to ‘attack’; it wouldn’t be reacting to one complex expression, but to three separate stimuli. For the dog to hear the compound sentence ‘there’s a fire, there’s smoke, and now I want you to attack’, the dog would have to be conscious of the concepts of fire, smoke, and attacking. Let me elucidate this.
There is no way to reduce understanding a sentence like ‘if there’s smoke, there’s fire’ to having a lot of precognitive reactions. To understand such a sentence, one must grasp, not a particular fire or cloud of smoke, but the concepts of fire and smoke. The sentence ‘if there’s smoke, there’s fire’ is general; understanding it involves de dicto, and not merely de re, awareness. [34]
The dog can expect dinner now, but not tomorrow, because expecting dinner tomorrow involves having a relation to the concept of dinner. (It is not a particular dinner you expect tomorrow. Expecting this dinner is to be analysed relationally, i.e. in terms of your consciousness of some particular dinner; expecting dinner three days from now is to be analysed notionally, i.e. in terms of your consciousness of the concept of dinner.) Sentences can have an internal structure precisely because their component parts correspond to
[35]
concepts and not to individuals. Individuals cannot be compounded, only concepts of individuals. ‘If there’s smoke, there’s fire’, doesn’t express a relation between some actual plume of smoke and some actual fire; it expresses a relation between the concepts of smoke and fire. It is not fires and plumes of smoke that are being compounded here, but concepts or meanings. But the dog that hears ‘dinner! smoke! fire!’ wants this dinner, fears choking on this smoke, fears being burned by this fire. So long as one is always conscious of this fire and this dinner, one cannot grasp complex sentences about fires and dinners; for this fire and this dinner cannot be compounded in the way that the concepts of fire and dinner can be. (No regimen of conditioning can enable the individual to make the leap from having purely de re awareness to having de dicto awareness.)
Basically there is no way to understand complex sentence without grasping concepts. To grasp a concept is to grasp a rule. So an understanding of complex sentences presupposes a grasp of rules. This is because to understand a complex sentence you must know how the meanings of its constituents are being compounded with one another.
Of course, to understand a complex sentence, one must not only grasp the concepts corresponding to the constituents of this sentence; one must also grasp the rules governing how these concepts are compounded. To understand the sentence ‘the bear chased the cat’, it is not enough to grasp the concepts bear, chase, cat and to associate these concepts with the appropriate words. Someone who mistakenly took this sentence to mean the cat chased the bear would know all of that; but such a person obviously wouldn’t understand the sentence. What such a person lacks is knowledge of the rules governing how sentence-meanings are compounded out of word meanings.
Of course, a Wittgensteinian-Brandomian may say:
In light of what you’ve said, I’ll admit that a behaviourist analysis cannot account for our understanding of complex sentences like ‘if there’s smoke, there’s fire.’ But it can account for our understanding of simple sentence like ‘fire’ (meaning: there is a fire).
This is obviously untenable. The word ‘fire’ has the same semantics in ‘fire!’ as it does in ‘where there’s fire, there’s heat’ or in ‘kitchen fires should be extinguished with salt, not water’. If the word ‘fire’ in one word sentences like ‘fire!’ or ‘fire?’ affected the listener ‘directly’, i.e. not through the medium of the listener’s grasp of some concept; and if the word ‘fire’ in complex sentences like ‘when there’s smoke, there’s fire’ did affect the listener through the latter’s grasp of some concept; then the word ‘fire’ would be quite ambiguous. But it isn’t.
Also, if the word ‘fire’, when it occurred alone, didn’t operate through the medium of some concept, then it necessarily couldn’t occur in complex expressions — just as Pavlov’s bell couldn’t be a constituent of a complex expression. Like Pavlov’s bell, it could at most be preceded and followed by other stimuli. It’s ‘meaning’ wouldn’t be a part of the meaning, if there were any, of this concatenation of stimuli. (This is simply because psychological and physiological effects, unlike meanings, cannot be compounded, at least not in any sense of ‘compounded’ that is relevant to semantics.) So in such a case, ‘fire’ would no more constitute an expression, a bit of language, than would Pavlov’s bell; it would just be a stimulus. So rules must form the nucleus of any true language. Therefore one cannot grasp a language until one grasps rules. (Wittgenstein’s ‘language games’ thus wouldn’t seem to constitute languages at all.)
X. OUR ANSWER TO BRANDOM’S QUESTION
In light of this discussion, we are able to answer a question that Brandom poses at the beginning of Making it Explicit. As Brandom points out, a parrot never really says it’s getting hotter even though it has been trained to say ‘it’s getting hotter’ when, and only when, it is getting hotter. The parrot can produce the sounds ‘it’s getting hotter’, but it can’t express the proposition it’s getting hotter. So why can a human being say that it’s getting hotter whereas a parrot cannot? This is Brandom’s question.
Our answer to Brandom’s question is a pretty traditional one. If the temperature is increasing in my room, this may indeed cause me to say ‘it’s getting hotter’. But this causation will operate via my grasp of certain concepts and semantic rules. For me the sentence ‘it’s getting hotter’ has inner structure; it consists of various words, bearing certain markers (e.g. ‘ing’), arranged in a certain way; and its meaning is compounded out of multiple different meanings. For the parrot ‘it’s getting hotter’ has no inner structure; it has no inner articulations. (Of course, the physical token ‘it’s getting hotter’ has physical articulations. But this is irrelevant.) This inner structure consists primarily in (i) the fact that different constituents of this sentence express different concepts and (ii) the fact that the meaning of this sentence as a whole is some kind of a resultant, and not a mere heaping together, of these concepts.
Our answer to Brandom’s question may not be all that different from Brandom’s own answer. Actually, it seems to coincide with it:
Suppose a spectrophotometer is hooked up to a tape-recorder in such a way that it produces a noise of the acoustic type ‘that’s red’ when and only when it is irradiated with the light of the proper frequency. And suppose that a fanatical human red-reporter nearly has just the same responsive disposition to produce those noises....What makes the noise the one produces merely a signal on the basis of which someone else might conclude that something red is present, while the very same noise, reliably elicited under just the same circumstances from the other, counts as a noninferential report, expressive of a perceptually acquired belief, with an intentional content the includes the content red?...[T]he key element missing from the parrot and measuring instrument — the difference between merely responsive classification and conceptual classification —
[36]
is their mastery of the practice of giving and asking for reasons , in which their responses can play a role as justifying beliefs and claims’ [Brandom (1998), pp. 88-89].
Basically, I mean that’s red when I say ‘that’s red’ because I am motivated to produce that sound by my perception of the appropriateness of producing them, i.e. because I know that it is right to produce these sounds, given my present situation and given the nature of the English language. I grasp some proposition about rules and situations; and because I grasp this proposition I can really mean something by the sounds I produce. By contrast, a spectrophotometer doesn’t grasp any such proposition; so it doesn’t mean anything by the sounds ‘that’s red’.
This analysis is certainly correct. But it is clear that Brandom cannot give this answer without contradicting himself. I must grasp propositions before I can mean anything by words (and, therefore, before words can mean anything to me). But according to Brandom, there is no pre-linguistic intentionality and therefore no pre-linguistic grasp of propositions.
XI. DOES SENTENCE-MEANING PRECEDE WORD-MEANING?
It remains to consider to one last point. I have claimed that sentencemeanings are built up out of word-meanings — or, at least, out of the meanings of some kind of sub-sentential parts. (Of course, this is a very main-stream, traditional view.) Wittgenstein and Brandom seem to hold that sentence-meaning is primary; that individual terms do not, in and of
[37] themselves, have meaning or reference, except derivatively of sentences.
There are couple of reasons to hold this view. First, there is, it seems, no way to understand word meaning except in terms of sentence meaning. A word w can be given meaning only by of giving a rule that assigns truthconditions to sentences containing w: and this is no less true if w is a ‘lexical’ item than if it is a non-lexical item.
What does it mean to say that ‘Bill Clinton’ refers to Bill Clinton? What does it mean to say that ‘smokes’ refers to the property of smoking? It means that the truth of a sentences containing ‘Bill Clinton’ and ‘smokes’ depends in a certain way on Bill Clinton and the property of smoking.
Anyone familiar with Tarski-style semantics knows that words are given meaning through rules that assign meanings to the sentences in which those words occur. To say that ‘Bill Clinton’ refers to Bill Clinton is not to say that ‘Bill Clinton’ makes me think about Bill Clinton. For x to refer to y it is not enough that x make people think of y; guns make people think of death, but a gun doesn’t refer to death. To say that ‘Bill Clinton’ refers to Bill Clinton is, ultimately, to say that sentences of the form ‘…Billl Clinton…’ are true just
[38]
in case…Bill Clinton….  In other words, for ‘Bill Clinton’ to refer to Bill Clinton is just for sentences ascribing a predicate to the expression ‘Bill Clinton’ to be true just in case Bill Clinton has the property denoted by that predicate. (For example, ‘Bill Clinton smokes’ is true just in case Bill Clinton has the property denoted by ‘smokes’.) And to understand the term ‘Bill Clinton’ is to recognize that sentences of the form ‘…Bill Clinton…’ are thus dependent for their truth on its being the case that…Bill Clinton…Basically, reference can only be defined in terms of the truth-conditions of sentences.
So it is reasonable to say that ‘Bill Clinton’ has no meaning in isolation but
[39]
only in the context of a sentence.
And to say that ‘smokes’ refers to the property of smoking is just to say that sentences of the form ‘so and so smokes’ are true just in case the object denoted by ‘so and so’ has the property of smoking. So, like ‘Bill Clinton’, there is no way to assign meaning to ‘smokes’ except by way of assigning meaning to sentences containing that expression.
Of course, if ‘Bill Clinton’ and ‘smokes’ have no meaning outside of a sentence, then ‘of’ and ‘and’, and non-lexical items generally, cannot possibly have meaning outside of a sentence. If any kind term had meaning in isolation, it would surely be a referring term. And indeed a term like ‘and’ cannot be given meaning except by way of assigning meaning to sentences in which it occurs; it must be assigned meaning through some rule like ‘S1 and S2’ is true just in case S1 is true and S2 is true.
Second, it seems that one cannot just think about Bill Clinton; one must think about him as having this or that property, as wearing a red tie or as being tall. All thought is predicational. One cannot think about objects except by thinking about states of affairs involving objects.
