And this epistemological fact seems to correspond to the linguistic fact we must noted, namely, meaning is assigned to sub-sentential expressions by way of being assigned to sentences. [40]
Given these two points, it would seem that sub-sentential parts per se are meaningless and, therefore, that my analysis is misguided.
It may be true that sentences must be meaningful before individual words can be. For the sake of argument, let us grant Brandom this point. But once a term like ‘Bill Clinton’ occurs in a sentence, it seems to acquire a meaning that is independent of that particular sentence, even though it may still have to occur in some sentence to be meaningful. So ‘Bill Clinton’ has no meaning outside of some sentence; but it is meaningful outside of any particular sentence. ‘Bill Clinton’ obviously has the same meaning in ‘Bill Clinton is tall’, ‘Bill Clinton is angry’, ‘is Bill Clinton coming?’. So ‘Bill Clinton’ has a kind of semantic priority over any sentence, even though it cannot have semantic priority over all sentences. How could we understand new sentences — like ‘if Bill Clinton had been a more avid athlete in his youth, he wouldn’t have pursued a career in politics with enough zeal to become President’ — unless the words ‘Bill Clinton’, ‘athlete’, ‘President’, and so on, had some meaning that were independent of this particular sentence and indeed of any particular sentence that they might occur in?
XII. WHY THERE COULD BE A PRIVATE LANGUAGE
Wittgenstein and Brandom also claim that there could not be a ‘private’ language. (We’ve already considered their reasons for this.) So far we have not explicitly said whether this claim is true or false. But given what we’ve seen, it is clear that we must reject it. In fact, given what we’ve already seen, we must go so far as to say that all languages are grasped privately and that — although there may not in fact be any private languages — there is no important difference between grasping a public language, like English, and grasping a private language. A public language is really just a private language that many people share.
Wittgenstein’s main argument against the existence of private languages is this. A language is a set of symbols whose use is rule-governed. A rule cannot be obeyed privately; for a private rule is no rule. To obey a rule, one must be part of a communal practice. A fortiori to obey a linguistic rule, and thus to grasp a language, one must be a part of a communal practice. So a language is essentially public.
In fact, the existence of these ‘communal practices’ presupposes that the people who participate in them privately grasp the relevant linguistic rules. We’ve seen that one must grasp propositions in order to learn a language. A language is given by a set of biconditionals — e.g. ‘P and Q’ is true if and only P is true and Q is true. One cannot grasp these biconditionals through a language, since it is only as a result of knowing them that one can know a language. So one must have non-linguistic access to propositions — in effect, to meanings. Once this is seen, it becomes apparent that in the end all rules are grasped privately.
Obviously one’s interaction with others — one’s being engaged in a ‘communal practice’ — can cause one to grasp the right biconditionals. But it cannot constitute one’s grasp of these biconditionals. We’ve seen that given a group of creatures each of whom is individually incapable of grasping a norm, that group of creatures as a whole is incapable of grasping a norm. If a group collectively grasps a norm, that is because its members privately grasp norms. To grasp a language is just to have internalized a set of norms. So languages are, in the end, grasped privately.
Of course, languages are, typically, created publicly. Presumably the word ‘dog’ means dog because of the efforts of many interacting people. But the rule ‘dog’ means dog must be grasped privately by each individual English speaker. So, in the end, linguistic rules are grasped privately: they can only be grasped privately. Once this is granted, there is no obstacle to the idea that there could be a private language. Since one’s engagement in a communal practice has a causal, but not a constitutive role in one’s knowing a language, it follows trivially that, in principle, a ‘society’ of one person could have a language: it follows, in other words, that there could be a private language. In fact, each language quite obviously is grasped privately; so, in effect, each ‘public’ language is really so many private languages: what we call public languages are really idealizations obtained by factoring out the differences among so many private idiolects; the grammar of a ‘public’ language is a grammar that captures the intersection of so many private
[41]
languages.
CONCLUSION
There is no doubt that the acquisition of speech enormously enhances and alters one’s cognitive abilities. Some (Wittgenstein, Sellars, Brandom) seem to have concluded from this that the ability to speak a language constitutes
[42]
one’s ability to think. But we have seen that this cannot be so. This leaves us with the question: why does linguistic competence so dramatically increase a creature’s ability to think? Obviously we can’t answer this question here. But my guess is this: speech allows existing ratiocinative abilities to be transferred to new domains. Cognitive abilities that are, initially, in the service of quite specific mental operations are permitted, by language, to operate on new contents.
This of course demands elaboration.[JK7] First of all, it is pretty clear that perception is the original, and the most basic, form of awareness: more precisely, it is the original and most basic form of personal awareness. I have no doubt that there are wholly non-perceptual sub-personal processes — e.g. those posited by Chomsky and Marr. But, again, I think that at the level of personal mental activity, sense-perception is the prototype for all awareness. And I think that — although, even at the personal level, we obviously have non-perceptual modes of awareness (for example, we have mental images and we also have abstract thoughts) — these are derivatives or sublimations of perception. Now if a creature knows a language, he is able to give his very own thoughts a perceptible form. What we cannot perceive — or cannot access by way of some derivative or sublimation of sense-perception — is no object for us (at the persona level of cognitive activity). So until our thoughts
[43]
are ‘clothed’ in a perceptible form, they are no objects for us. So if a person learns a language, his thoughts become objects for him; he grasps them, and does not merely have them. I think, in fact, that before a creature knows language, most actually thinking occurs at a sub-personal level. The end-products of that thinking make their way into consciousness; but the
[44]
thinking itself is sub-personal. Once thoughts are given a linguistic dress, the thinking can occur at a personal level — for the thoughts have become perceptible and thus accessible to personal awareness — and can thus interact with the contents of the personal stratum of mental activity. So the subject becomes rational: previously only the sub-subject was rational, where by the ‘sub-subject’ I mean, of course, the sub-personal stratum of mental activity. To sum up, the possession of language does not give us rationality; it merely increases the scope of our rationality; or, rather, it extends our rationality from the sub-personal to the personal level.
 
Appendix 1: Why the idea of Sub-personal rule-following doesn’t involve a homunculus fallacy
 
As we noted, Searle (1992) condemns as incoherent the idea that there is sub-personal rule-following: rules cannot just be followed – someone must follow them. So if, as Chomsky and Marr maintain, our conscious mental productions result from rules being followed at some sub-personal level, then somebody within us -- some ‘homunculus’ -- must be following them. But if we say that his mental productions result from rule following, then we incur a vicious regress. On the other hand, if we deny that his mental productions thus result, we are conceding the gratuitousness of the whole idea that rulefollowing underlies our mental lives.
  Searle’s argument is compelling, but fallacious; for there can, I submit, be rule-following without a rule-follower. It is clear that, where representational mental phenomena are concerned, the causal order to some tracks the normative order. If you believe that Bill has exactly two apples, and you also believe that two is less than three, then you will probably form the belief that Bill has less than three apples. Obviously the first two beliefs not only cause but also justify the resulting belief. (This point generalizes practically without limit to all cases of ‘intentional’ causation.) And there can be no doubt that the transition from the first pair of beliefs to the third embodied deference to some logical norm and thus constituted a case of rulefollowing. But does this mean that some agency behind the mental contents was needed to make that transition embody awareness of that norm? No. It would seem to be constitutive of representational mental entities that their representational contents are implicated in, and condition, their causal liaisons. If you are thirsty and see water, this will (ceteris paribus) cause you to drink the water, and it will also (logically, though not perhaps ethically) justify your drinking the water. These causal properties of your state of thirst and your perception are inseparable from – are constitutive of – the mental states themselves: given a mental state x that had no tendency, when coupled with a perception of water, to result in an intention to drink that water, x would ipso facto fail to be a feeling of thirst. So we needn’t posit a being behind the mental states who makes their causal paths track some normative order. No – it is of the essence of representational mental states that their causal properties track nor mative properties and that they belong to sequences of states that embody sensitivity to norms or logical rules, and therefore qualify as cases of rule-following. To sum up, given what representational mental contents are, they cannot but be instalments in cases of rule-following: nothing behind them is needed to make this happen. I also think that, ultimately, nothing behind them could make this happen. Such a notion requires a subject who is intimately enough related to mental contents to have them, but sufficiently divorced from them that he has some kind of causal powers over them (x can have causal powers over y only if x and y are distinct). And there is, I think, no way to make this idea coherent.
 
Appendix 2: Why consciousness is not the essence of mentality
 
Searle (1992) argues that ‘non-conscious mental phenomenon’ is as much a contradiction in terms as ‘four-sided triangle.’ Searle’s view is not a new one, and  was often directed at Freud. Freud produced empirical counterarguments; I’d like to present a purely logical counter-argument.
  First of all, the term ‘conscious’ is ambiguous. To say that x is ‘conscious’  could mean either (i) that one is conscious of x or (ii) it could mean that x is a content of consciousness. To say ‘his hatred of his wife is concious’ means that he is conscious of this hatred. To say ‘pains are necessarily conscious’ is to say that pains are necessarily contents of consciousness. Obviously when people say that anything mental must be ‘conscious’, they cannot have sense (i) in mind. For it is obviously viciously regressive, as well as circular, to say that we are conscious of everything mental: that would mean that, for any mental entity E, there was some consciousness of E – call it C(E) – and some consiousness of C(E) – call it C(C(E)) – and so on ad infinitum. Also, there are obviously things we are conscious of that are not mental (stars, chairs). But people who say that everything mental is conscious cannot have sense (ii) in mind either. For, as everyone will admit, a belief is not a content of consciouenss; my belief that 2 is prime is surely not a content of consciousness, though I am obviously conscious of it. So the thesis that everything mental is ‘conscious’ cannot even be delineated without its incoherence being apparent.

MACDOWELL, J. (1994), Mind and World, Cambridge, Mass., Harvard
University Press.
— (1998), ‘Meaning, Communication, and Knowledge’ in Meaning, Knowledge, and Reality, Cambridge, Mass, Harvard University Press, pp. 29-50.
SEARLE, J. (1992), The Rediscovery of the Mind, Cambridge, Mass., The M.I.T. Press.
— (1999), Mind, Language and Society: Philosophy in the Real World, London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson.
WITTGENSTEIN, L. (1976), The Blue Book and the Brown Book, New York: Harper Torchbooks.
—    (1999), The Philosophical Investigations, Translated by G.E.M. Anscome, Englewood-Cliffs, Prentice Hall 3rd Edition.[JK8]
—     
 
 
Emotions and the Content of Moral Statements
 
Abstract: According to a “realist” analysis of moral statements,  “letting children starve” is made true by some moral fact, just as “Paris is in France” is made true by some geographical fact and “2+2=4” is made true by some mathematical fact. According to an emotivist analysis, “letting children starve” is tantamount to saying “Boo to letting children starve”: it expresses one’s feelings about letting children starve. It is typically held that a realist analysis of moral statements is incompatible with an emotivist analysis of them. This is the case, I argue, only if emotions are not judgments or beliefs of some kind. I also argue that, in fact, emotions are plausibly analyzed as beliefs of a special kind, and that any alternative analysis of them fails to do justice to some of their obvious features (e.g. that we seek reasons, and not merely causes, for them). This analysis of emotions is also, I argue, the one to which every human subscribes, in his practice if not in his conscious opinions. So emotivism is, I argue, a form of moral realism.
 
      Some sentences are obviously true or false. The sentence “Paris is in Europe” is true, and the sentence “2+2=3” is false. Sentences expressing moral sentiments – sentences like “letting children starve is evil” and “you shouldn’t encourage your children to smoke” -- are widely thought to be in a different category. According to a theory that has many adherents, such sentences merely express emotion. To say “murder is wrong” is essentially to say: “Boo murder!” It is to express a negative feeling about murder. The same is held to be true mutatis mutandis of all sentences expressing moral sentiments. To say “you shouldn’t encourage your children to smoke” is really just to say “boo encouraging your children to smoke!”  Let us refer to
[45]
this position as emotivism.
    Of course, many hold that moral sentences are true or false, just like arithmetical or geographical sentences. “Letting children starve is evil” is true and “letting children starve is good” is false, the same being true of all other moral sentences. (By a “moral sentence” I mean one expressing a moral evaluation or sentiment.) Let us refer to this position as “value realism” or, simply, “realism.”
    It is typically thought that emotivism and realism are incompatible positions. I think that this is a mistake. I think that they are compatible and possibly even coincident doctrines. It is the purpose of this essay to make a case for this claim.
    A disclaimer is in order. I will be able to make, at most, a conditional case for the claim just mentioned. If a certain reasonable, but highly debatable, doctrine concerning emotions is correct, then emotivism is a form of value realism. I will not be able to make an airtight case for that doctrine, but only to provide some reason, however minimal, for thinking it credible. But that, by itself, will be enough to warrant our rethinking the relation between emotivism and realism.
     First of all, indicative sentences have two functions. They bear propositions and they also express (or can be used to express) beliefs. The sentence “snow is white” bears the proposition snow is white. And when someone says “snow is white”, that person is expressing his or her belief that snow is white. When I say “snow is white”, I am not saying anything about my own mental contents. But I am expressing a belief, and thus showing you something about my mind.
    Sentences are capable of truth and falsity precisely because uses of them express beliefs. The sentence “snow is white” is true precisely because uses of it express a true belief – the belief that snow is white. The sentence “Paris is in Russia” is false precisely because uses of it express a false belief. (If uses of “Paris is in Russia” expressed the belief that 2 is an even number, then “Paris is in Russia” would be true.) So sentences are true or false
[46]
precisely because they express true or false beliefs. 
     There is more to say in this connection. Many things we do express beliefs. But not all such things are cases of our producing sentences. If I put my coat on a table in front of me, I am expressing a belief I have – the belief, roughly, that a physical object in my vicinity is capable of supporting my coat. But my putting my coat on the table is not itself true or false; it is thus not in the same category as my saying “snow is white” or “grass is not green.” The reason that my performing that act doesn’t constitute a case of producing a bit of language is that it is not a conventionalized way of expressing a belief.
   This no doubt demands clarification. Once again consider the proposition:
 
(P) There is an object in my vicinity capable of supporting my coat.
 
  In English we express (P) with the words: “There is an object in my vicinity capable of supporting my coat.” But we don’t have to use those words to express that proposition. We could invent a code (not a very convenient one, but a code no less) in which the canonical way of affirming P was to put one’s coat on a nearby object. (If one isn’t wearing a coat, then one can’t affirm P in that code – just as a speaker of English who can’t write or say an
“s” can’t express P in English.) We could, in principle, make the conventionalized way of expressing P be the act of putting one’s coat on a nearby object. If we did that, then one would, in effect, be producing a sentence (or, more exactly, a sentence-token) which bore P.
      A lot of things we do express beliefs. Not all such things are cases of our producing sentences. When such acts are conventionalized ways of expressing beliefs, they are cases of producing sentences.
   The verbiage “snow is white” is a conventionalized way of expressing a certain belief. That is why, in producing that sound, one is saying something and is thus doing something that can be characterized as true or false. So an indicative sentences is, at bottom, a conventionalized way of expressing a belief.
      The emotivist says that moral sentences express emotions. This seems like a reasonable view. It is hard to see how someone could sincerely say “it is wrong not to feed starving children” without having some kind of emotion – a negative one -- in connection with the fact that there are starving children. [47]
     This doesn’t mean that whenever one makes a moral statement one is in the throes of emotion. If I say “letting children starve (when there is plenty of food to give them) is evil”, I don’t necessarily have to be in a fit of rage or of outrage. But emotions are not always occurrent. I can hate somebody for forty years and not always be in a fit of anger. The emotion shouldn’t be confused with the occurrent manifestations of that emotion. Now if somebody felt nothing – had no emotion in connection with the phenomenon of children needlessly starving – then it is hard to see how that person could sincerely say “letting children starve is evil”.
    I will operate on the assumption that emotions do express emotions
(though not necessarily occurrent ones). I admit that this is an arguable point. But it is, I think, reasonable enough to warrant our investigating the consequences of it. And one of those consequences, I submit, is that Emotivism is a form of moral realism.
   So let us accept, if only provisionally, that to sincerely say “letting children starve is evil”, one must have some kind of emotion in connection with letting children start.
       Now it is hard to deny that moral sentences are conventionalized ways of expressing emotion. The sentence “we are morally obligated to feed starving children” is obviously a conventionalized way of expressing a certain sentiment. It is, in this respect, very different from a natural or nonconventional way of expressing sentiment. If one were to gasp in horror at the spectacle of some starving children, that would, perhaps, express one’s sentiment that starving children ought to be fed. But that performance would not a natural or non-conventional way of expressing that sentiment, and would thus not be in the same category as one’s saying “starving children ought to be fed.”  
    To sum up, it is very hard to deny that moral sentences are conventionalized ways of expressing emotions. In any case, for the sake of argument, let us assume that this is correct, and see where it takes us.      Given this supposition, if emotions are true or false beliefs of a certain kind, then sentences expressing emotions, and thus moral sentences, are themselves true or false. If “we are morally obligated to feed starving children” is a conventionalized way of expressing an emotion, and if that emotion is a true or false belief, then that sentence is true or false.
    To sum up: If emotions are beliefs, then moral sentences – sentences like “letting children starve is wrong” – are true or false, just like sentences expressing geographical or arithmetical propositions. And in that case emotivism actually becomes a kind of moral realism.
     The question, then, is: Are emotions beliefs? This is a large question, and of course it cannot be disposed of in a few pages. But it is, I think, possible to
[48]
outline a prima facie case for this position.
      If you are angry that Bob stole your bicycle, that means not merely that you believe that Bob stole your bicycle, but also that you have some kind of attitude towards that fact. Clearly if you didn’t have an attitude towards that fact, you wouldn’t have any emotion in connection with it. What is it to have an attitude towards a fact? Well, it is not merely to have a feeling that is caused by that fact. Anything can cause anything. Suppose that, unbeknownst to myself, I inhale small amounts of some gas that subtly alters my brainchemistry, causing me to feel elation. My inhaling the gas causes me to feel elated, but I am not elated about inhaling the gas: I did not even know that I did so. In general, to have an emotion about x is not the same thing as to have a feeling that is caused by x.
     To have an emotion about something is to have an attitude towards that thing. To have an attitude towards a thing is to feel a certain way about that thing. If a feeling is to be about something, it must represent that thing as being a certain way. Barry Stroud says that all perception is
[49]
	“predicational”; one cannot just see a thing; one must see it as having these or those properties – as having a certain shape or being a certain distance from one. This point generalizes to all mental representations. A thing cannot just be represented; it must be represented as having this or that
[50]
property, as 	standing in this or that relation. In particular, a feeling cannot just represent a thing; it must represent it as having this or that property. To have a feeling that represents a thing is to have a feeling about a thing. To have an emotion about a thing is to have a feeling about that thing. So given what we said a few sentences a go, it follows that in having an emotion, one represents a thing as being a certain way – as having some property or standing in some relation. So to have an emotion is, in effect, to see a thing as having a certain property or standing in a certain relation: it is thus to have a belief to the effect that that thing has some property or stands in some relation.
     Of course, many philosophers will resist any analysis that turns emotions [51]
	into beliefs. We feel that, in some way, emotions are the opposite of beliefs. A belief is what you don’t have when you have an emotion. In any case, a good belief – an objective belief – is what you don’t have when you are emotional. A belief is a window onto reality; an emotion is like tar smeared on that window.
     It is true that emotions do cloud our judgment. But that doesn’t necessarily mean that they are non-beliefs. It could be that emotions embody the functioning of a more retrograde and primitive dimension of mental functioning than do, say, mathematical or geographical beliefs. So emotions might render opaque our epistemic window onto reality not because they are not themselves beliefs -- not because they are not themselves such windows –   but because they are beliefs that result from a less high-grade form of cognition. (Our world view is as much distorted by false or simplistic beliefs as it is by non-beliefs.) 
      Let us consider a point made by Donald Davidson. Every rational human being knows that wrenching and twisting your body after rolling a balling bowl will not make it more likely to land a strike. But just about every human being engages in such wrenching and twisting. What is going on here is a conflict within the bowler’s belief-system. Speaking roughly, the bowler’s reptile-brain believes that wrenching and twisting will make the ball land a strike. The bowler’s fore-brain knows otherwise. The belief formed by the reptile-brain clouds the bowler’s judgment. But, notice, what is doing the clouding is a belief.
   Basically, beliefs can cloud beliefs. Irrational beliefs can retard the generation or execution of more rational beliefs. So given only that emotions fog up our belief-window onto reality, it doesn’t follow that they are not themselves beliefs. I will return to this point later.
     Right now I’d like to give a more positive reason to think that emotions
are beliefs. The argument consists of two steps. The first step is uncontroversial.
      Emotions obviously incorporate beliefs. If you are angry that Bob didn’t do the dishes, that means you believe that he didn’t do the dishes. If you are afraid that Mary will kill you, that means you believe there to be a nonnegligible probability that she may kill you. (It doesn’t mean, obviously, that you know she will kill you. But it does mean that you have some beliefs concerning the probability of such an occurrence.) If you hope that Mary will not kill you, you believe there to be a possibility of her not killing you. (If you know that she will kill you, you can’t really hope that she won’t kill you. If you know that P, you cannot hope that not-P. I know that my best friend just died. Therefore I cannot hope that he hasn’t died.) Uncontroversially emotions all involve beliefs. This much must be granted.
     This brings us to the second step of the argument. Given someone who says that emotions are not beliefs, that person must say that emotions merely involve them – that beliefs are a proper part of emotions, but are not the whole of them. So such a person will say that an emotion is a belief plus something else. What is that something else? Well surely it is a feeling. If you are angry that Bob didn’t do the dishes, then you believe that he didn’t do the dishes. But in addition to that you have some kind of feeling. (If you knew that Bob didn’t do the dishes, but had no feelings at all – if you didn’t care – then you wouldn’t have any emotion about his not doing the dishes.) And the emotion is the sum of the belief plus the feeling.
    But what kind of feeling must it be? It must be a feeling about Bob’s not doing the dishes. If you know that Bob didn’t do the dishes, and you have some feeling about something else – say, about the fact that you didn’t get tenure – then you don’t have an emotion about Bob’s not doing the dishes. So the feeling in question must be about Bob’s not doing the dishes. But one thing cannot just be ‘about’ another. A book cannot just be about Spain. It must say something about Spain. A dream cannot just be about your mother. It must have her riding on a broomstick or baking cookies. Remember what Stroud says: things cannot just be represented; they must be represented as having these or those properties. So if that feeling is about Bob’s not doing the dishes, it cannot just be about it; it must, as it were, say something about. Your feeling is to some effect. Presumably, it is to the effect that it was wrong of him not to the dishes or that he failed you by not doing them.
    In any case, the feeling must be about Bob’s not doing the dishes. So, in effect, it must represent Bob’s not doing the dishes. But it cannot just represent Bob’s not doing the dishes; it must represent his not doing the dishes as having these or those properties. So the feeling must be a feeling to the effect that Bob’s not doing the dishes has these or those properties – say property phi.. So the feeling says: Bob’s not doing the dishes has phi. But in that case, it is very hard to see how that feeling is anything other than a belief. The feeling is one to the effect that Bob’s not doing the dishes has phi. So in having that feeling, you see Bob’s not doing the dishes as having property phi. So you believe that Bob’s not doing the dishes has phi.        Let us sum up. Emotions obviously involve beliefs; if you are angry that Bob didn’t do the dishes, you obviously believe that he didn’t. But that belief by itself is not an emotion. Something – a feeling – must be added to it. But that feeling must be about the right thing – it must be about Bob’s not doing the dishes. (Otherwise you will an emotion about something else, or perhaps you won’t have an emotion at all.)  But if the emotion is about Bob’s not doing the dishes, then it represents that fact in a certain way – as having these or those properties. So in having that feeling, you see Bob’s not doing the dishes as having some property, and thus believe his not doing the dishes to have that property. (Later on, we will discuss what kind of property that must be.) Given any emotion, an exactly analogous argument shows that it is a belief.
    Attempts to turn the emotion into something other than a belief are failure. Such attempts turn my anger that Bob didn’t do the dishes into the sum of two things: (i) a belief that he didn’t do the dishes  And (ii) a feeling of some kind. No one can deny that my anger incorporates such a belief. So if we are to turn emotions into non-beliefs, we must see to it that (ii) – the feeling part of my anger that Bob didn’t do the dishes -- is something other than a belief. But if the feeling part isn’t about Bob’s not doing the dishes – if it doesn’t represent his not doing the dishes – then the sum of (i) and (ii) won’t be an emotion about Bob’s not doing the dishes. On the other hand, if (ii) is about Bob’s not doing the dishes, then we end up with a belief. So, we’ve seen at least one good theoretical reason to hold that emotions are beliefs.         This analysis corresponds to our pre-theoretical intuitions. If I am not mistaken, we pre-theoretically believe that our emotions are insights of sorts. Everyone wants to get rid of an unpleasant feeling, such as a headache or a twinge in one’s elbow. But people cling to their emotions, even the most unpleasant ones. A person who is violently angry towards somebody doesn’t want to take a pill to get rid of his emotion, even though that anger may be extremely distressing. If I am angry that my child was kidnapped, what I want is not to directly get rid of the emotion, but to change the world so that the emotion is no longer justified. If somebody kidnaps my child, the last thing I would choose to do is to take a pill, or undergo an operation, that would get rid of the emotion. What I want is to change the world so that the emotion is no longer appropriate: I want my child back; I want the kidnapper brought to justice. This suggests that, in having the emotion, I am seeing the world as being deficient in some way – as being such that it ought to be changed. And this, in turn, means that in having the emotion, I believe the world to have a certain property – as being deficient and in need of change.      Once again, suppose that my child has been kidnapped. Naturally, I am enraged and distressed beyond all belief. But because of recent developments in psycho-active medications, I have the option of taking a pill that will actually make me happy that my child was kidnapped. Taking the pill will involve no effort at all. At the same time, I also know that, if I make some effort and go to some expense – if, say, I hire a detective and, perhaps, do some detective work myself -- I stand a good chance of getting my child back. What will I do? Any human being would choose to make the effort – to endure some distress and expense – and get his child back rather than to take the pill.
     If you take a pill to get rid of a head-ache, you are not reducing yourself in any way. If you take a pill to get rid of your desire to find your lost child, you are reducing yourself; you are narrowing the scope of your consciousness. In any case, this is how we feel about our emotions. We part with them – with our hatreds, our loves, our regrets -- only grudgingly, only when, in the light of contrary evidence, we feel them to be unreasonable.
     This suggests that we do not see emotions as being merely subjective conditions like headaches, but as having some meaning. No one will hesitate to take a pill to get rid of a headache. For we do not feel that, in getting rid of the headache, we are blinding ourselves to some kind of truth. But, in our view, the parent of the kidnapped child would be blinding himself to some meaning, and also succumbing to some delusion,  if he took a pill to convert his misery into joy. So, we feel, the anger is a genuine recognition of some kind, and the joy that the parent would feel, if he took the pill, would be a delusion of some kind. It thus seems to us that, in having the anger, the parent is seeing things the right way – is having the right belief – and that, in having the joy induced by the pill, the parent is seeing things the wrong way – is having the wrong belief. So we have very strong pre-theoretical intuitions to the effect that emotions are recognitions of meanings or truths of some kind.      Of course, it is true that people take pills to change their feelings. But it seems to me that we do that as a last resort: what we really want is to change the world in the way consistent with the insight that is, we believe, embodied in the emotion. A depressed person’s initial desire is to change the world in such a way that the emotion is no longer appropriate. If I am unhappy because I did not get tenure, what I initially want is to change the world in such a way that the emotion is no longer appropriate: I want some (perceived) deficiency on the part of the world to be corrected. (I want to get tenure, or I want the people who denied me tenure to be punished.) But I may know that that will not happen (the tenure committee simply will not revise its decision, nor will they be brought to justice). So, under that circumstance, I may indeed take Prozac. But I do that only because other, more desirable options are closed: I want to change the world; since I cannot do that, I change my biochemistry.
     Also, when we do decide to take a pill to change our feelings,  that is often
[52]
	(though not always) because we believe that the emotion in question – the one we are trying to get rid of – is irrational. At first this might seem to bear against the contention that we see our emotions as being beliefs, or insights, of a certain kind. But the opposite is the case, as a little analysis will show.
     No one thinks that a headache is irrational. Headaches are unpleasant, but not irrational. But emotions can be irrational. In any case, this is what we tend to think. We describe people as prone to irrational emotional highs and lows. I am not saying that we are necessarily right to speak this way. I am merely registering the fact that we do speak this way – that human discourse is replete with such talk. And this fact surely suggests that, at some level, we see emotions as somehow being answerable to canons of rationality and thus as being quite unlike headaches, which we do not see as being irrational or rational. We don’t say that people are prone to irrational headaches or stomachaches. Of course, something cannot be answerable to canons of rationality – cannot be rational or irrational – unless it is a belief. So, it would seem, at some level, we see our emotions not as things merely undergone, like headaches, but as true or false insights, as beliefs.
[53]       People defend their emotions. People justify their anger or hatred. People give grounds for their emotions; and this suggests that people take their emotions to be true or false, and thus to be beliefs. People do not justify, and do not give grounds for, their headaches.
    It must be pointed out that giving grounds for something is different from giving the causes of it. I can give the causes of my headache (having too little caffeine or too little sleep); but I cannot give grounds for my headache. But I can give grounds for my hatred of so and so or my delight that such and such. If grounds can be meaningfully given for emotions, then they are true or false, right or wrong. And any mental entity that is right or wrong is ipso facto a belief.
         So it certainly appears that emotions can be justified: that we can do more than give their causes; we can give grounds for them. To give grounds for something is to show that it is rational. The only things that can be rational or irrational are beliefs. So if – as we all pre-theoretically believe –
[54]
grounds can be given for emotions, then emotions are beliefs.
    We’ve seen a theoretical reason to hold that emotions are beliefs of some kind, and we’ve also seen that we pre-theoretically see emotions as being beliefs of some kind. So the idea that emotions are beliefs is not to be dismissed lightly. And, as we’ve also seen, if emotions are beliefs, then moral sentences are true or false; and emotivism becomes a kind of value-realism.        We’ve spoken a great deal about why emotions are beliefs, and also about how this view has deep roots in our pre-theoretical outlook. But we have not spoken about another aspect of our conception of emotions. Although, arguably, emotions are beliefs, they appear to be very different from paradigmatic beliefs, like the belief that snow is white or the belief that 2+2=4. I think that this appearance has led many to see emotions as not being beliefs: given how different anger is from, say, an arithmetical belief, we must surely hold that anger is not a belief. 
    There is, I grant, a crucial difference between emotions and, say, arithmetical or geographical beliefs. But this difference is between kinds of belief, not between beliefs and non-beliefs. The belief that Paris is in France is purely “factive”: it is not a belief to the effect that something is good or bad, that something has or lacks value. The same is true of arithmetical beliefs, historical beliefs, and economic beliefs. Arguably, it is true of anything that is uncontroversially a belief.
     But if emotions are beliefs – and we’ve seen some reason to think that they are – they are valuative beliefs, and not purely factive ones. Given any purely factive belief, one can, in principle, have any emotion in connection with it. My believing that 2+2=4 doesn’t necessarily involve my having any emotion at all. In fact, even my believing that Stalin killed 10 million people doesn’t necessarily involve my having this or that emotion. It is true, given the psychological make-up of any ordinary human being, that one is likely to experience horror or outrage in connection with such a belief. But this is still a contingent fact about certain human beings. It is not necessarily the case that one has any particular emotion in connection with that belief. In fact, there are probably are people who, dreadful as it sounds, have little or no emotion in connection with that belief (or with beliefs concerning similarly horrible truths). So no factive belief is such that, in virtue of having it, one necessarily has any particular emotion. Thus, if emotions are beliefs, they must be valuative beliefs. An emotion, then, must be a belief to the effect that something is good or bad.
     We have seen some theoretical grounds for this last contention. And, I think, it is very much consistent with our pre-theoretical intuitions. My being angry at so and so for doing such and such seems to involve my believing that it was wrong of so and so to do such and such – that I was slighted, not given my due. The same point holds mutatis mutandis for all other emotions. My being happy that such and such happened seems to involve my seeing such and such as right.
   There are some apparent counter-examples to this thesis. I have said that if a person has a positive emotion towards something – if, say, he delights in it – that means that he sees it as good. Now a person may delight in such and such, but feel guilty about delighting in it, and thus think that he is wrong to delight it in. For example, a person may delight in some misfortune that happened to someone else, and also think he is wrong to have that feeling. And he thinks it is wrong to have that feeling because, presumably, he thinks that it is bad that the misfortune happened to that person. So, if my analysis is correct, then a person simultaneously sees a certain thing as good and as bad. Offhand, this seems to bear against our analysis. People do not see a given number as being both even and odd. Similarly, people don’t see acts as being both good and bad. Surely people are not that irrational
        It is, I grant, a simple fact that people often think themselves wrong for having certain emotions. But this doesn’t necessarily bear against our analysis. For, it seems to me, what is going on in those cases is that one has conflicting beliefs as to the goodness or badness of the state of affair in question: people do have contradictory views – and the error in the argument given in the last paragraph lies in its denying this obvious truth.    This demands amplification. First of all, it is hard to shake off the conviction that, in having an emotion in connection with something,  one is at some level having a belief as to the goodness or badness of that thing. I cannot be angry at somebody without at some level believing that he has somehow fallen short. I cannot delight in something without at some level seeing that thing as good.
    It seems that, in some cases, our forebrains (if I may so speak) generate beliefs that are at variance with the beliefs generated by our back-brains. (Here, of course, I am using the term “forebrain” as a label for that cognitive system associated with rationally produced beliefs, and “back-brain” as a label for that cognitive system associated with instinctively produced beliefs.) Our forebrain tells us that contorting our bodies after rolling a bowling ball will have no influence on whether that ball goes into the gutter or not. Our back-brain, it would appear, tells us otherwise. As Davidson pointed out, even the ablest of philosophers will wrench and contort his body after rolling
[55]
	the ball, in an apparent to influence its course. Our forebrain tells us that astrology is nonsense. Our back-brain tells us otherwise: that is why, if the astrologer tells us we have two weeks to live, we shudder in horror (unless we are extraordinarily disaffected people). It could be that, when a person delights in something that he condemns, or is unhappy about something the he approves of, what is going on is a similar conflict between forebrain and back-brain. My back-brain sees it as a good thing that my department head just fell off a cliff. My forebrain sees it as a bad thing. (My forebrain has been enculturated, and has possibly even read Kant and Mill. None of this is true of my back-brain, which thus has much a more egocentric understanding of the concepts of goodness and badness.) So when I simultaneously delight in his falling of a cliff and see myself as wrong to experience that delight, what is going on is not that I don’t believe it good that he fell off a cliff: rather, I simultaneously see it as bad that he fell of a cliff – this is the forebrain at work – and also as good that he fell off a cliff – this is the backbrain at work.
    (All this talk of  “forebrain and back-brain” may sound like pseudoscientific bunk. But it just helps us state, in an abbreviated way, things that practically everybody countenances. We say things like: “Smith thinking with his heart, not his head: he really shouldn’t give all his money to Charlene” Obviously, Smith isn’t literally thinking with his heart. But what we mean when we say things like “Smith is thinking with his heart…” are often true. The same applies to my talk of “forebrain” and “back-brain”. It is just an analogue of our often veridical, though anatomically under-informed, talk of “head versus heart”.)
    Once again, these remarks are rough and ready. But they provide a not entirely implausible way of reconciling the fact that we often condemn our emotions – see them as wrong -- with the (as we’ve seen) very reasonable thesis that emotions are beliefs as to the rightness or wrongness of things.
 
Conclusion
 
    What makes a sentence true or false is, ultimately, that it expresses a potential belief. According to emotivism, moral sentences express emotion. If emotions are beliefs, then moral sentences are true or false; and emotivism is a form of value realism, contrary to what has been maintained for centuries. There is some reason to think that emotions are beliefs. An emotion is necessarily about something. Consequently, it must represent a thing as being a certain way. Now if an emotion represents a thing as being a certain way, then it is a belief to the effect that that thing is that way. Also, people give grounds for their emotions. So people see their emotions as answering to canons of rationality – as being rational or irrational. The only things that can be irrational or irrational are beliefs. So if – as everyone pre-theoretically believes --  emotions are rational or irrational, then emotions are in fact beliefs.
 
References
 
Blackburn, Simon
 

	* Spreading the Word: Groundings in the Philosophy of Language. New York: Oxford University Press, 1984
 

	* Ruling Passions: A Theory of Practical Reasoning  New York: Oxford University Press, 1998
 
Calhoun and Solomon
 
[1] What is an Emotion? Oxford University Press: 1984 edited by Cheshire Calhoun and Robert Solomon.
 
Hume, David
 

	* A Treatise of Human Nature ed. Selby-Bigge; 2nd edition with text revised and variant readings by P.H. Nidditch. Oxford at the Clarendon Press 1978.

	* Hume, David. Inquiry into the Principles of Morals. Oxford University
Press, 1998
    
 
Why conceivability sometimes entails possibility:
a Neo-Cartesian argument for dualism
 
 
Abstract: Kripke and Putnam showed that what can coherently be conceived of is not always a guide to what is possible. But in some cases conceivability is a guide to possibility: whether it is or not depends on the structure of the proposition being considered. I make it clear under what conditions possibility and conceivability coincide, and I then show that that, where the propositions relevant to the mind-body problem are concerned, they do coincide. Thus, given that mind-body dualism is conceivable, it follows that it is actual – even though, as Kripke and Putnam were right to say, conceivability is not generally a guide to possibility. Of course, if dualism is correct, then the validity of physicalistically oriented research programs in psychology would have to be reevaluated.
 
Introduction
 
      It used to be thought that the possibility, if not the actuality, of some kind of mind-body dualism could be established through a conceivability
[56]
	argument. Kripke and Putnam showed that conceivability is not nearly as reliable a guide to possibility as used to be thought: I can coherently conceive of x as being water and also as not being H2O: but if x is water, then it is necessarily H2O. So what can coherently be conceived of is not necessarily possible. Thus, even though I can  coherently conceive of mind as not consisting of (say) patterns of neuro-chemical activity, it doesn’t follow that mind could be anything other than such activity – let alone that it is something other than such activity. Understandably, this line of thinking has convinced many that dualism cannot be established by means of conceivability arguments. 
    In this paper I will try to show that – even though Kripke and Putnam were basically right in what they said about conceivability as a guide to possibility
– it is still possible to construct a viable conceivability argument for dualism.
 
The classical conceivability argument
 
[57]
	   The old argument for dualism was basically this. What is not contrary to the laws of logic is possible. Triangles can be green because x is a triangle is logically consistent with x is green. Now x is a pain or a belief that 2+2=4 does not logically entail x is a brain event. So it is logically possible that beliefs, pains, etc. should be distinct from brain-events (or any other kind of physical event.).
   The next step in the argument is this. Identity holds necessarily.  If A can be distinct from B, then A must be distinct from B. Proof: B obviously doesn’t have the property that it can be distinct from B. So if A has the property that it can be distinct from B, then A has a property that B does not
[58]
have and so, by Leibniz’s law, A is simply not B.
     To sum up the argument so far: (i) Identity is necessary. (ii) x is a pain (or a belief that 2+2=4…) doesn’t entail x is a brain-event. (iii) If P is not ruled out by logic (i.e. if not-P is not logically necessary), then P is possible.     (i)-(iii) imply that pains, beliefs, etc. are not brain-events: dualism proved.     These days, of course, the counter-argument is to deny (iii) – it is to deny that logical possibility entails actual (‘metaphysical’) possibility (singlespaced statements are those of an imaginary objector):
 
Given only that x is a pain (or a belief that 2+2=4…) is logically consistent with x is not a brain event, it does not follow that pains are necessarily distinct from brain events. Why not? Well, x is water is logically consistent with x is not H2O, but we know from chemistry that water is H2O. Some necessities are a posteriori, and logical possibility therefore proves nothing as to actual (‘metaphysical’) possibility.
 
  The conclusion, I submit, is vastly overdrawn. Surely logical possibility sometimes indicates actual possibility. x is a triangle is logically consistent with x is green, and this does mean that there could be green triangles. At the same time, of course, x is Hesperus is logically consistent with x is not Phosphorous, but nothing that is Hesperus could not be Phosphorous. And x is water and x is not H2O is logically consistent, but this does not  mean that water could be something other than H2O. What is the relevant difference among these cases?
 
The relationship between conceivability and possibility
 
    Now I would like to state, without giving any argumentation, my position regarding the relationship of conceivability to possibility. I will argue for this position in the next section.
    Whenever there is a disparity between logical possibility and actual (metaphysical) possibility, or between metaphysical necessity and logical necessity, that is because the possibilities/necessities in question are underwritten by facts about the structure of object-dependent concepts. And whenever a necessity is underwritten wholly by facts about the structure of object-independent concepts, actual necessity/possibility coincides with logical necessity/possibility.
     (In this paper, I will use the word ‘concept’ to denote a certain kind of platonic entity: the meaning of a predicate, essentially. I will not be using it to denote concepts in the psychological sense. So I will use the word ‘concept’ in the sense it has in the sentence ‘for any x, if x falls under the concept square, x falls under the concept closed figure.’)
    Before we continue, we must make it clear what is meant by the terms ‘object-dependent concept’ and ‘object-independent’ concept. Consider the proposition.
 
(*)Socrates drank hemlock
 
Socrates himself is an actual constituent of (*). But what does this mean exactly? The idea will become more clear if we consider a proposition that does not have Socrates for a constituent (i.e. that is not ‘de re’ about, or ‘object-involving with respect to’, Socrates):
 
(**) there was a philosopher of antiquity who exceeded all others in philosophical  ability and any philosopher answering that description drank hemlock.
 
  (**) is made true by the fact that Socrates was the greatest philosophers of antiquity and that he drank hemlock. But (**) does not have Socrates himself as a constituent. That very proposition does not depend for its truth on Socrates’ having those characteristics. (**) would have been true if Socrates had never existed, and some other person had been the greatest philosopher and drank hemlock. So Socrates himself is not a constituent of (**).    By contrast, (*) would not be true if anyone other than Socrates had the property of being the greatest philosopher of antiquity and of drinking hemlock. (*) depends for its truth on Socrates -- specifically Socrates -having those properties. So Socrates himself figures in the truth-conditions of (*). And, in as much as propositions are internally or essentially related to their truth-conditions, Socrates himself can be said to be a constituent of that proposition.
     Now it seems reasonable, if not truistic, to say that propositions are built out of concepts and, therefore, that (*) is constructed out of certain concepts, these being Socrates, hemlock, and so forth. Given this last fact, and given – what we saw a moment ago – that Socrates himself is a constituent of (*), it seems to follow that the concept Socrates has Socrates himself for its content, or at least for a part of its content. Obviously Socrates manages to be a constituent of (*) only by way of his involvement in the concept Socrates. So the concept Socrates has an actual constituent of the spatio-temporal world for its content (or at least a part of its content), this constituent being Socrates. So the concept Socrates is object-involving, as it is generally put (it is object-involving with respect to Socrates).
    (If a concept has only a platonic object for its content, it does not count as ‘object-involving’ – at least not as I will be using this expression -- even though platonic objects are presumably objects of sorts.)
      Object-involving concepts can have natural kinds for their contents – their contents needn’t always be spatio-temporal individuals. Consider the proposition
 
(***) water freezes at 32°
 
This proposition is object-involving with respect to the natural kind water.  What does this mean? The best way to see what this means is to contrast it with a proposition that is not object-involving with respect to water:
 
(****) there is some substance that human beings bathe in that freezes at 32°.
 
(****) is made true by the fact that we bathe in water and that water freezes at 32°. But (****) doesn’t depend for its truth on water’s having a certain freezing point. If there were some other substance with a freezing point of 32° that we bathed in, then (****) would be true. But (***) is not like this: for (***) to be true, it is necessary that water – specifically water --  be such that we bathe in it and that it have a certain freezing point. So water itself figures in the truth-conditions of (***). And in as much as propositions are internally or essentially related to their truth-conditions, water itself – the natural kind -- can be said to be a constituent of (***).
    To echo what we said a moment ago: It seems reasonable, if not truistic, to say that (***) is built out of various concepts, these being water, 32°, and so forth. Given this last fact, and given that water itself – the natural kind – is a constituent of (***), it seems to follow that the concept water has the natural kind water for its content, or at least part of its content. Presumably that natural kind succeeds in being a constituent of (***) only by way of its involvement with the concept water. So that concept must have the natural kind water for its content. Thus, the concept water is object-involving; for it has a natural kind for its content.
        The concept triangle is not object-involving; for its content is some purely platonic object, not an individual, and not some natural kind like water. The same is true of various other concepts: number, justice, truth, knowledge, implication. These concepts do not – so my intuition tells me -- have  spatio-temporal individuals or kinds for their contents; they are not like the concepts Socrates or light. (Later on I will discharge that intuition.)       When a proposition is necessarily true, and its truth is underwritten wholly by facts about the structure of object-independent concepts, that proposition is a priori. Consider the proposition squares have four sides. The truth of this proposition is guaranteed by the structure of object-independent concepts, and that is why it is a priori.
    Of course, I am taking it for granted that four, square, and so on, are object-independent. In a little while, I will defend that assumption. But it is clear, I think, that four and square are in a different category from Socrates and water. Facts about the essences of the first two concepts are epistemically
[59]
	transparent, while the corresponding facts about the latter are epistemically opaque: capable of being known only through empirical investigation. If I want to learn what it is for something to be a square, I do mathematics: I engage in a priori reasoning; I don’t do empirical work. If I want to learn what is for something to be water, or if I want to learn what properties Socrates has in all possible worlds, I must do empirical work; I must look into, say, Socrates’ conditions of origination; I must investigate the chemical structure of water. So what I investigate to learn about the essence of the concept square is not something that belongs to the empirical world; it is something that belongs to a purely platonic realm. Otherwise I would have to do empirical work to learn what it is for something to be a square: but I don’t. But I do have to do empirical work to learn what it is for something to be water; and that, surely, is because that concept is object-dependent; it has an actual spatiotemporal entity for its content (or at least part of its content); and spatiotemporal things can be known only through empirical work. So it is at least prima facie plausible to suppose that square is object-independent – doesn’t have for its content any constituent of the spatiotemporal world – while water is object-dependent. We will develop this argument shortly.     When a proposition is necessarily true, and its truth is underwritten by the structure of object-dependent concepts, that proposition is a posteriori. The truth of Hesperus is lovely necessitates the truth of Phosphorous is lovely. But this necessity is underwritten by object-dependent concepts (Hesperus, Phosphorous) is therefore a posteriori; it is not a logical necessity, it is not an entailment. The same is true mutatis mutandis of the necessary connection between x is water and x is H2O. 
    On the other hand, the concepts of triangularity and of two-sidedness are not object-involving, and that is why the necessary relation between x is a triangle and x has more than two-sides is epistemically transparent – that is why one can know a priori that, if x has only two sides, then x is not a triangle.
   
 
Our argument for this position
 
   In the previous section we said the following two things. First, where object-independent concepts are concerned, logical possibility does correspond to actual possibility. But, second, this is not the case where object-dependent concepts are concerned.
   We’ve considered specific examples of necessary propositions (squares have four sides, water is H2O), and what we found certain bore out the two contentions just stated. But that fact doesn’t constitute anything resembling a general justification or proof of those propositions. Is there some such general justification?
   There is. By definition, object independent concepts do not have any part of the spatio-temporal world for their contents. Now whether some kind of necessary relation holds between two concepts C1 and C2 has to do entirely with the constitutions of those concepts. Why? Necessary relations hold in all possible worlds. So whether a necessary relation holds between two concepts cannot be contingent on what is the case in this or that world; it must, therefore, have to do with what is invariant from world to world. Now the only things that are invariant from world to world are platonic things – are, in
[60]
	effect, concepts. So if there is a necessary relation between C1 and C2 that must hold in virtue of world-invariant facts, and thus facts about the structures of concepts. And, presumably, it must have to do with the structures of those two concepts specifically. (x is a triangle necessitates the truth of x has more than two sides because of something about the constitutions of the concepts triangle and two sides. The same is true mutatis mutandis in the case of x is water necessitates the truth of x is H2O – even though the relevant facts about the constitution of the concepts water and
H2O are not epistemically transparent.)
    So given two object-independent concepts C1 and C2, no empirical work – no investigation of the spatio-temporal world – is needed to know in what necessary relations they stand with respect to each other. Only purely conceptual – purely a priori – work is involved. This point, of course, generalizes to any pair of object-independent concepts.
  Of course, if one can know a priori in what necessary relations C1 and C2 stand with respect to each other, then one can know what a priori what
[61]
possible relations hold between them.
   To sum up, if C1 and C2 are object-independent concepts, then one can know a priori in what necessary relations C1 and C2 stand with respect to each other, and (therefore) in what relations it is possible for them to stand with respect to each other.
    But, of course, where object-dependent concepts are concerned, this is not the case. One has to do empirical work to know the constitutions of such concepts; for such concepts have stretches of the empirical world for their contents, and nothing can be known about the empirical world save through observation (empirical work). So it cannot typically be known a priori in what necessary relations object-dependent concepts stands with respect to each other.
     Consider the proposition ‘if x is H2O, then x is water’. This proposition is true in any possible world. Which means that its truth is not contingent on what obtains in this or that world. Its truth is therefore underwritten by something world-invariant; it is, therefore, underwritten by facts about the structure of concepts – specifically, it would seem, the concepts water and H2O. These concepts are object-involving; they have actual spatiotemporal kinds for their contents (or, at least, for part of their contents). Of course, there are many things one cannot know about these kinds without doing empirical work. (One cannot know, without doing empirical work, the facts about those kinds that are relevant to determining whether ‘if x is H2O, then x is water’ is true or not.) That is why ‘if x is H2O, then x is water’ is not a priori.
   In a word, that proposition is a posteriori because the concepts involved – water and H2O – are object-involving; they have for their contents (or, at least, for part of their contents) spatiotemporal kinds.
     Let us sum up. Where object-independent concepts are concerned, logical possibility coincides with actual possibility. Where object-dependent concepts are concerned, this is not the case. I will use this fact as a way of arguing for dualism – as a way of reviving the conceivability argument described a moment ago.
 
A test of object-independence
 
    It will help if we a have test by which to determine, for any concept C, whether C is object-dependent or object-independent. It is not hard to produce such a test. In this section I will simply state the test. In the next section I will justify it.
[62]
	   The test is this: If grasping C constitutively involves being casually connected to the external world, then C is object-dependent. If grasping C does not constitutively involve being casually connected to the external world, then C is object-independent.
    Let me now justify this. To grasp propositions that are de re about water or
Socrates, one has to be causally connected to Socrates or water. So to think Socrates was wise or water quenches thirst, one has to be causally connected to Socrates or water. Thus, to grasp the concepts Socrates or water one has to be causally connected to these things. A brain in a vat couldn’t grasp these
[63]
	concepts, and thus couldn’t grasp the propositions Socrates was wise or water quenches thirst. (In this paper, when I talk about ‘brains in vats’, I mean brains that are just like the brains of living, cognitively normal people, and are subject to the some proximal, but not the same distal, stimulations. So the brains in vats I will be talking about are just like my brain and your brain – except that they are in vats. Of course, in reality, there are brains in vats.
But they are dead. They are not what I mean by ‘brains in vats.’)
   In general, to grasp any object-involving concept, one has to be causally connected to something in the non-mental world. A brain in a vat couldn’t grasp such concepts.
   But a brain in a vat could grasp the proposition 2+2=4. Thus a brain in a vat could grasp the concepts 2, =, + and so on. Surely a brain that was just like yours, but was disembodied, could think 2+2=4. Would it really be fair to say of a brain just like Gauss’s, but disembodied, that it didn’t know that 2+2=4?Thus the proposition 2+2=4 is thus object-independent, and so therefore are the concepts 2,+,= and so on.
   So the way to test whether a concept C is object-dependent or not is this. If grasping C involves having a causal connection to the non-mental world, then C is object-dependent. If grasping C does not involve having a causal connection to the non-mental world, then C is object-independent.    The concept Socrates is object-dependent, because to grasp it, one’s thoughts have to have a certain causal origin; one has to be connected to the non-mental world in a certain way. (A brain in a vat cannot think about Socrates.) The concept even number is object-independent, because to grasp it, it isn’t necessary that one’s thoughts have a certain causal origin or, therefore, that one be connected to the non-mental world in this or that way.
(A brain in a vat can do math – can think about the number 2.)
   If a brain in a vat can grasp a concept C, then C is object-independent. If a brain in a vat cannot grasp C, then C is object-dependent.
 
The justification for this test
 
    Let me now provide the justification for this test of object-(in)dependence. Let Charlie be some brain in a vat. If Charlie can grasp a proposition P, that means that it is possible to grasp P without having any causal connections to the non-mental world. That, in turn, means that grasping P does not, at least not in principle, have anything to do with what is going on in the world outside one’s mind. The state of Charlie’s mind by itself – without relying on the existence of spatiotemporal things outside that mind -- determines whether P is being grasped or not. Given that fact, it is clear that P’s being grasped doesn’t depend on there being any spatiotemporal thing outside of Charlie’s mind. (Of course, if Charlie’s grasping P doesn’t involve the existence of any state of affairs outside Charlie’s mind, then Bob’s grasping it – and Mary’s grasping it and Fred’s grasping – doesn’t involve the existence of any extra-mental state of affairs.) And given that fact, in turn, it is clear that P doesn’t have anything spatiotemporal for any of its constituents. So P is object-independent.
     In a word, if grasping P doesn’t involve having a causal connection to anything non-mental, then P is object-independent. And so, therefore, are all the concepts which P comprises.
   Let us sum up. If whether one grasps C is not sensitive to facts about one’s causal liaisons to the external world, then C is object-independent. Otherwise, C is object-dependent.
 
 
A proto-argument
 
    Let us say that C1 is some mental concept. (By a ‘mental concept’ I mean some concept such that, if x falls under it, then x is ipso facto mental: the concept belief that 2+2=4 is such a concept. By a ‘mental concept’ I do not mean anyone’s grasp of anything.) And let’s say that C2 is some physical concept. (So C2 is some concept such that, if x falls under it, then x is ipso facto physical. An example of such a concept would be has a positive electrical charge.)
    If C1 and C2 are object-independent, and x falls under C1 is logically compatible with x does not fall  under C2, then things falling under C1 are not identical with things falling under C2. For, to reiterate, where objectindependent concepts are concerned, logical possibility/necessity coincides with actual possibility/necessity. So if x falls under C1 is logically consistent with x does not fall under C2, then it is possible for things falling under C1 to be distinct from things falling under C2. More formally, for any x, any y, if x falls under C1 and y falls under C2, it is possible that x is distinct from y.
And since identity holds necessarily, it follows that x is distinct from y.         In what remains of this paper I will  show, first, that at least some mental and physical states of affairs can be described entirely in terms of objectindependent concepts; and, second, that the concepts involved are logically consistent with some mental entities not being physical entities.    Since, where object-independent concepts are concerned, logical consistency implies actual possibility, it can be inferred that some mental entities really can be distinct from physical entities. And since x can be distinct from y only if x is distinct from y, it follows that some mental entities are not physical.
 
 
The argument proper
 
   Now at least we can put forth our argument for dualism. Suppose the following. Joe and twin-Joe are exactly alike as far as their mental contents narrowly individuated are concerned. But Joe and twin-Joe are in utterly different physical environments. Now Joe, like any cognitively normal human being, grasps the concept belief that 2+2=4.  (In other words, he knows what it is for somebody to believe that 2+2=4.) Given the facts, as we’ve just described them, does it make any sense to suppose that twin-Joe does not have the concept belief that 2+2=4?
     Surely not. To illustrate this, let us consider the most extreme realization of the facts as we’ve just described them. Suppose the following. Joe is an ordinary human being on Earth. Twin-Joe is a brain in a vat. But twin-Joe’s mental life, narrowly individuated, is just like Joe’s. (In other words, twinJoe’s mental life -- considered apart from his being a brain in a vat,  and apart from the all the causal facts associated therewith – is just like Joe’s.) Surely twin-Joe, despite his unfortunate predicament, knows just as well as Joe what it is to have the belief that 2+2=4. Surely twin-Joe can manipulate this concept (i.e. the concept believes that 2+2=4), and knows its applicationconditions, as well as Joe. So we must conclude that the concept  belief that 2+2=4 is object-independent.
    An exactly analogous argument can be given to show that various other mental concepts – e.g. desire for a meaningful life, ticklish sensation, love of poetry – are object-independent. (Some may have misgivings about applying what we said about belief that 2+2=4 to is a pain or is a ticklish sensation. These misgivings are unwarranted, and I deal with them below.)
   Not all mental concepts are object-independent; for some mental concepts  implicate object-dependent concepts. For example, the concept belief that Socrates was smarter than Plato implicates the object-dependent concepts Plato and Socrates. So even if two people are exactly alike as far as their mental contents, narrowly individuated, are concerned, it might be the case that one of them has the concept belief that Socrates was smarter than Plato while the other does not; for possession of this concept involves, not merely having certain contents, but also having certain causal liaisons to one’s environment. Twin—Joe, being a brain in a vat, will not have these causal liasons, and will not grasp this concept, even though Joe does.
     But plainly some mental concepts are object-independent. The concept belief that 3 is greater than 2 is object-independent: a brain in a vat could, in principle, grasp this concept as well as anyone. Suppose that twin-Gauss is mentally just like Gauss, except that twin-Gauss is a brain in a vat. Surely twin-Gauss has the same mathematical acumen as Gauss – has the same intelligence about number as Gauss. And surely twin-Gauss is just as able to apply the associated mental concepts – e.g. believes that there are infinitely many primes – as Gauss.
    Let us now turn to physical concepts. Obviously some physical concepts are object-dependent, e.g. identical with water, identical with heat. But it seems to me that the most fundamental physical concepts cannot be objectdependent. The purpose of any science is to provide as complete a description of the objects falling in its purview as possible. The purpose of e.g.
theoretical physics is to provide as accurate, as fine-grained, and as complete a description of the states of affairs falling in its scope. Now to the extent that a proposition is object-involving – i.e. to the extent that it involves objectinvolving concepts – it has (by definition) actual objects, rather than descriptions of those objects, for its content. The proposition Socrates was bald is object-involving: Socrates himself is a constituent. Inevitably, a proposition that has Socrates himself as a constituent is (ceteris paribus) less information rich than one that contains a description of Socrates.  If you replace Socrates, in the just mentioned proposition, with some description of, say, the mental and physical events associated with Socrates, the resulting proposition will be incomparably more fine-grained, more information-heavy than the former. (I am not saying – what Kripke proved false – that Socrates was bald is synonymous with some statement of the form the unique such and such was bald. All I am maintaining is that, when objects occurring in propositions are replaced with descriptions, then – holding everything else constant – the resulting proposition, though perhaps not synonymous with the original, is quite obviously much richer in information than the former.) In general, there can be no doubt that, in so far as objects are constituents of a proposition, rather than descriptions of objects,  that proposition is of a lower degree of complexity, and of information-richness, than it would otherwise be. 
    When objects-occur in propositions, they occur as simples – even though objects per se are not simple. The proposition Socrates was bald has a very simple structure -- one of the form  a has phi – even though Socrates himself was very complex. For whatever reason, Socrates’ complexity is not implicated in the proposition Socrates was bald.  Socrates, when transported into that proposition, somehow becomes a simple. (Why this is so is not clear, but that it is so is clear.) Somehow, when Socrates becomes a constituent of a proposition, his internal structure is not implicated in that proposition. And this point applies to any object that becomes a constituent of a proposition. Water is complex; it has a molecular and atomic structure. But this complexity is not implicated in the proposition water freezes at 32°; that proposition has a maximally simple form – it has the form a has phi. To sum up, whenever a spatio-temporal entity figures as a constituent of a proposition, its complexity – its internal structure – is not implicated in that proposition; spatio-temporal objects, in propositional contexts, are utterly simple.
     But when a description occurs in a proposition, all of its complexity is implicated in that proposition.  So the greatest bald philosopher of all time was Greek  is more complicated a proposition – and therefore, if true, more information-rich – than Socrates was bald; the same being true for any other proposition that results from Socrates was bald by replacing Socrates with a description. (Once again, I do not deny the following: given only that a proposition P results from Socrates was bald by replacing Socrates with a description, it doesn’t follow that P is synonymous with Socrates is bald. In fact, if anything, it seems to follow that P is not synonymous with Socrates is bald.)
   In general, in so far as a proposition involves object-dependent concepts, it is not as information-rich as it could be.
    Now theoretical physics is concerned with generating maximally precise – maximally information-rich – propositions about sub-atomic phenomena. An idealized theoretical physics really just is a set of maximally accurate such propositions. As we’ve just seen, to the extent that a proposition employs object-dependent concepts, that proposition is not as fine-grained as it would otherwise be. So the foundational concepts of theoretical physics – the concepts in terms of which the most precise and exhaustive description of sub-atomic reality are to be couched – must be object-independent. These must not comprise actual chunks of the spatio-temporal world; for in so far as they do, they do not do justice to the internal structure of those chunks.
