So the propositions of a physics which captures the fine-grain of the subatomic world must be couched in object-independent concepts. The concepts of such a physics must be object-independent.
     Now let us move on to the next of the argument. As we noted earlier, for a state of affairs to occur in space-time region R is just for some concept to be instantiated in that region. For there to be a particle of such and such charge and mass, moving at such and such velocity in region R, just is for the concept particle with such and such charge and mass moving with such and such velocity to be instantiated in R – the same being true mutatis mutandis for any other state of affairs that might occur in R (or any other region).  So for some sub-atomic state of affairs to obtain in R is just for some microphysical concept to be instantiated in R.
   Everyone agrees that whatever physical states of affairs hold in a region R supervenes on what microphysical states of affairs hold in R. The biological, the chemical, the geological, and so on, supervene on the microphysical. This is equivalent to saying: what physical concepts are instantiated in R – whatever biological or chemical or geological…concepts are instantiated in R – supervenes on what microphysical concepts are instantiated in R.
   The materialist holds that whatever mental states of affairs are instantiated in R supervenes on (is strictly determined) by what physical concepts are instantiated in R. This is equivalent to saying: for the materialist, whatever mental concepts are instantiated in R supervenes on what microphysical (atomic and sub-atomic) concepts are instantiated in R. So the materialist holds that some necessary relation holds between certain microphysical and mental concepts: some relation of the form when C1 is instantiated in R, C2 is also instantiated in R, where C1 is a microphysical concept (e.g. object with such and such charge…) and C2 is a mental concept (e.g. belief that 2+2=4).
     We’ve observed that, where object-independent concepts are concerned, necessary relations among those concepts can be excogitated a priori; since (by the definition of object-independent), such concepts do not have any component  of the spatio-temporal world for any of their content, and are therefore to be known through non-empirical – purely conceptual or a priori – labour.
   We’ve also noted that many mental concepts – e.g. belief that 2+2=4 -- are object-independent, and that the foundational concepts of theoretical physics are, or ought to be (ultimately), object-independent.
   So if materialism is right – if any belief that 2+2=4 is identical with some physical state of affairs – then the following must be true: if the concept belief that 2+2=4 is instantiated in R, that is in virtue of the fact that some object-independent microphysical concept C (or, more likely, set of such concepts) is instantiated in R. In other words, the instantiating of C in R necessitates the instantiating of belief that 2+2=4 in R. (More plainly, if C is instantiated in R, that necessitates that there be a belief that 2+2=4 in R.)    Further, because C and belief that 2+2=4 are object-independent, the following holds: the fact that C is instantiated in R would entail – would logically, not (just) metaphysically, necessitate --  that belief that 2+2=4 was also instantiated in R. For recall that, if materialism is right, the truth of C is instantiated in R necessitates the truth of the concept belief that 2+2=4 is instantiated in R. And because the concepts C and belief that 2+2=4 are object-independent, this necessity is an entailment; it is a logical necessity – one that can be excogitated a priori.
    But I find it very hard to believe that there is any purely logical entailment from C is instantiated in R, where C is an object-independent microphysical concept, to there is a belief that 2+2=4 in R. It follows that a belief that 2+2=4. It is very hard to believe that the instantiating of some microphysical concept logically necessitates the instantiating of the concept belief that
2+2=4.
   Let us now put all the pieces together and close the argument. Recall that where object-independent concepts are concerned, necessary relations are the same thing as entailment relations. There is, presumably, no entailment from C is instantiated in R to the concept  belief that 2+2=4 being instantiated in R. (In other words, there is no entailment from C is instantiated in R to there is a belief that 2+2=4 in R.)  Both C and belief that 2+2=4 are objectindependent concepts. So the just mentioned lack of entailment coincides with the absence of a necessary connection. So there is no necessary relationship between C’s being instantiated in R, on the one hand, and there being a belief that 2+2=4 in R – where, once again, C is any microphysical concept.
    Let us sum up what we’ve said so far. For a state of affairs to obtain in a region R just is for a concept to be instantiated in R. So for a microphysical state of affairs to obtain in R just is for some microphysical concept to obtain in R. We’ve established the following: there is no object-independent microphysical concept C such that C’s being instantiated in R necessitates there being a belief that 2+2=4 in R. So the truth of any proposition of the form C is instantiated in R --  where C is any object-independent microphysical concept --  is compatible with the falsity of there is a belief that 2+2=4 in R.. Since both C and belief that 2+2=4 are object-independent, this lack of an entailment relation coincides with a lack of any necessary relation.  It follows that given any microphysical state of affairs S, if S can be described by an object-independent proposition (a proposition that uses only object-independent concepts), then S’s obtaining in R does not necessitate there being a belief that 2+2=4 in R.
   This by itself does not prove that a belief that 2+2=4 is not physical. But it does prove that such a belief that 2+2=4 is not identical with, or supervenient on, any microphysical state that can be described by object-independent concepts. From this, however, it is a short step to showing that such a belief is not identical with, or supervenient upon, any micro-physical state, or therefore any physical state at all.
   Remember what we said earlier. To the extent that a proposition employs an object-dependent concept, it doesn’t do justice to the complexity, the structure, of the thing which it concerns. The internal structure of a thing is obliterated when that thing becomes a veritable constituent of a proposition. So any proposition that gives that gives the fine-grain of the microphysical world will use only object-independent concepts. So any microphysical state of affairs, when it is described in its fine-grain, is given by objectindependent propositions, i.e. propositions which use only objectindependent concepts.
    A while ago we established the following. For any  microphysical state of affairs S, if S can be described by an object-independent proposition, then S’s obtaining in R does not necessitate that there is a belief that 2+2=4 in R. Since any microphysical state of affairs is, ultimately, given by an objectindependent proposition, this means that no microphysical state of affairs in 
a region R necessitates that  there be a belief that 2+2=4 in R. This, in turn, means that a belief that 2+2=4 is not identical with or supervenient upon the occurrence of any microphysical state of affairs in R. So the belief that 2+2=4 is not physical.
    Now some analytic functionalists will register the following objection to the argument we just gave:
 
   You say – and your argument essentially presupposes – that there is no entailment from C is instantiated in R, where is an object-independent microphysical concept, to there is a belief that 2+2=4 in R.  But there is such an entailment. Given a knowledge of the kinematic and dynamic interrelation of the physical objects in R, it could be deduced, quite literally, whether there was a belief that 2+2=4 in R. Consider: let R be the region occupied by some computer. If you knew all the microphysical facts in R – i.e. if you knew just what microphysical concepts were instantiated in R – then you would have as fine-grained a knowledge as possible of the character and organization of the states of affairs obtaining in R. You would, in effect, know everything there was to know about the distribution of mass-energy in R – about the course and intensity of electric currents, the mechanical interactions, and so forth. But it seems to me that, on the basis of this knowledge, you could deduce that something in R believed that 2+2=4. You would know that the computer generated such and such and output in response to thus and such input, and you would know the intervening electrical and mechanical facts. Now if we are functionalists about the belief that 2+2=4 – that is, if we say that x qualifies as such a belief wholly in virtue of its causal liaisons – then, on the basis of the aforementioned physical facts, one could deduce that the computer believed that 2+2=4. So there would be an entailment from C1, C2…Cn  is instantiated in R – where C1, C2…Cn are microphysical concepts [64] – to there is a belief that 2+2=4 in R.
 
 
    This seems to me to involve a very wrong-headed and overly reductive conception of belief. But I cannot pursue that here. Nonetheless, what the analytic functionalist says about the belief that 2+2=4 has virtually no bearing on examples involving concepts of phenomenally pregnant states – for such states are not plausibly regarded functionally. (It is exceedingly implausible to say that the essence of being a pain or a ticklish sensation is having certain
[65]
	causes or effects.) And we can use this fact to circumvent the objector’s point.
   Consider the concept is a pain. For reasons we’ve seen, if materialism is right, then the concept is a pain is instantiated in R wholly in virtue of the fact that some object-independent microphysical concept C is instantiated in R. Now is a pain is object-independent. Suppose that Bob and twin-Bob are exactly alike in respect of their mental states, narrowly individuated (i.e. considered apart from any environmental facts). And suppose that Bob has the concept is a pain (i.e. he knows what it is to attribute pain to someone or something). Under those circumstances, could it possibly be denied that twinBob had the concept is a pain? Surely not. Surely if Bob knows what a pain is, then so does twin-Bob: facts about the environmental causes of Bob’s and twin-Bob’s mental contents are totally irrelevant. If Bob has the concept is a pain, and twin-Bob is his exact duplicate – in all respects modulo those having to do with the environmental causes of his mental contents – then if Bob grasps the concept is a pain, so does twin-Bob.
    So is a pain is an object-independent concept. And, so by assumption, is C.
But surely there is no entailment from C is instantiated in R to the concept is
a pain is instantiated in R.  For any object-independent microphysical concepts C1, C2…Cn, from the fact that C1, C2…Cn are instantiated in R, it surely does not logically follow that is a pain is instantiated in R; there is no entailment from C1, C2…Cn are instantiated in R  to the concept is a pain is instantiated in R. In other words,  there is no entailment from C1, C2…Cn are instantiated in R  to there is a pain in R. Now since C1, C2…Cn and is a pain are object-independent, necessary relations that hold between the former and the latter are entailment (basically, logical) relations. So if, from the fact that C1, C2…Cn were instantiated,  it were really necessary that  is a pain be instantiated, there would be an entailment from C1, C2…Cn are instantiated in R to the concept  is a pain is instantiated in R (i.e. there is a pain in R). But there is no entailment; so there is no necessary connection between the concepts C1, C2…Cn being instantiated in R, on the one hand, and is a pain being in instantiated in R, on the other. (That is, there is no necessary connection between C1, C2…Cn being instantiated in R, on the one hand, and there being a pain in R, on the other.)  Now C1, C2…Cn stand for any objectindependent microphysical concepts one might choose. So for any objectindependent microphysical concepts one might choose, there is no necessary relation between those concepts being instantiated in R, on the one hand, and there being in a pain in R, on the other. For a microphysical state of affairs to obtain in R just is for some microphysical concept to be instantiated in R.     So, it follows that for any microphysical state of affairs S that can be described in object-independent concepts, S’s obtaining in R does not necessitate there being a pain in R. From this, of course, it follows that no such microphysical state of affairs (in R, or any other region) is identical with the occurrence of some pain in that region.
   So if the occurrence of a pain is to be identical with some microphysical state of affairs (and therefore with some physical states of affairs), that microphysical state of affairs must be identical with one that cannot be described in object-independent terms. But remember what we said earlier. The microstructure of the world must, ultimately, be embodied in objectindependent propositions – i.e. in propositions which use only objectindependent concepts. For in so far as a proposition uses object-dependent concepts, it does not do justice to the complexity, the structure, of the thing which it concerns. So all maximally precise statements about the microphysical are object-independent. As we’ve seen, the occurrence of a pain is not necessitated  by the occurrence of any microphysical state of affairs that is amenable to object-independent description. And this means, as we’ve just seen, that the occurrence of a pain is not necessitated by the occurrence of any microphysical state of affairs. And this, in turn, means that pain is not identical with or supervenient upon, any microphysical state of affairs; and therefore isn’t identical with or supervenient anything physical (for everything physical is identical with or supervenient upon the microphysical). So not everything mental is physical; materialism is false.
 
 
 
Fodor, Jerry. 1983. Representations. Cambridge: M.I.T. Press.
 
Kripke, Saul. 1980. Naming and Necessity. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
 
Putnam, Hilary. 1975. “The Meaning of ‘Meaning’”. In Collected
Philosophical Papers vol.2. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
 
 
 
Program-causes and the Inertness of the Mental
 
 

	A. There are some compelling prima facie reasons to think that functionalism and certain forms of externalism strip mental content of any causal powers. If that is the case, then we have a good reason to reject those doctrines. Frank Jackson and Phillip Pettit have produced a brilliant argument purporting to show that, in fact, functionalism and the relevant forms of externalism are compatible with the presumption that mental content has causal powers. Their argument involves an original and (in my view) correct point about causation. But I believe that their application of this correct point to this particular set of problems is flawed. They have not, I will argue, given us any reason to think functionalism and the relevant forms of externalism are in fact compatible with the presumption that mental content has causal powers. 
 

	* It seems reasonable to suppose that, in some cases, brain-states realizemental contents. (I wish the word “state” to be taken as broadly as possible – to apply to both enduring brain-structures and occurrent phenomena.)  My belief that 1+1=2 is realized by certain brain-states. My belief that water is wet is realized by a different set of brainstates.
    Let x be an arbitrary brain-state of mine. According to functionalism, for x to realize mental content C is for x to have a certain causal role. For x to have a certain causal role is, at least in part, for x to have such and such effects. So x realizes a belief that bread nourishes at least partly in virtue of the fact that x has certain effects – for example, it leads to my choosing to eat bread (in certain contexts).
     There is an obvious prima facie problem with functionalism. Mental content is causally efficacious. In any case, this is what we are inclined to think. My believing that bread nourishes is causally effective: it leads me to drive to the store, buy bread, eat said bread, and so on. Given this, suppose that brain-state x has effects E1…En. x’s having C presumably has a causal hand in bringing about at least some of E1…En. As we just saw, supposing that x is a brain-state realizing my belief that bread nourishes, x’s being such a belief is what causes me to buy bread, eat it, and so forth. But if x’s having those effects is what x’s realizing that content consists in, then x’s realizing that content cannot possibly be what causes E1…En to come about. If x’s realizing a belief that bread nourishes consists in x’s causing me to drive to the store and buy bread, eat said bread, and so on, then x’s realizing that belief cannot possibly be what causes me to drive to the story, to eat the just purchased bread, and so on.
    So if functionalism is right, my belief that bread nourishes ends up not having a causal hand in my going the store to buy bread; and, by an exactly similar argument, it ends up not having a causal hand in my wanting to eat bread, bake bread, and so on. It ends up not having a causal hand in any of the contexts where, quite obviously, it does have a causal hand.
       The nature of this problem for functionalism becomes clear if we are careful to make a certain distinction. Strictly speaking, it is not things that have causal powers. It is not the rock which breaks the window, but the rock’s moving with a certain velocity, and having a certain mass, and so on. The rock doesn’t do anything. What does the work is really the rock’s having certain properties – a certain mass, solidity, velocity, and so on – along with various other things’ having various properties (e.g. the window’s having a certain micro-structure).
    Not every one of the rock’s properties is causally effective in every causal transaction involving the rock. Suppose the rock has a certain dimple on one of its sides. In some contexts, the rock’s having that property will be causally effective. (For example, if you pour water down that side of the rock, the presence of the dimple will affect the course of the water.) But in other contexts, the presence of that dimple will not be causally effective. (For example, if you drop the rock in a vacuum, the presence of the dimple won’t have any effect on the trajectory of the rock.)
    Suppose, once again, that x is a brain-state realizing my belief that bread nourishes. Strictly speaking, x doesn’t do anything: what does the work is x’s having certain properties – e.g. x’s having certain electrical, chemical, and cellular properties. Not every causal transaction involving x is one where x’s electrical properties are causally effective. Perhaps in certain contexts it is x’s mass, not its electrical properties, that are causally effective. Similarly, not every causal transaction involving x is one where x’s mental properties are causally effective. In some contexts, x’s mental properties might be causally irrelevant: what is doing the work in those contexts might be x’s having a certain electrical charge or its having a certain specific shape. So there is a difference between x’s being involved in some causal transaction, on the one hand, and x’s realizing a belief about bread being causally effective in that context. The latter might or might not be causally effective on that occasion.     But, of course, we want to believe that, in at least some cases, my believing that bread nourishes is causally effective. So we want to believe that, in certain contexts, x’s having a certain mental content is causally effective. What leads me to eat the bread in front of me is my believing that bread nourishes. Here what is effective is not just x, but is x’s having the right mental properties.
     Here is where the problems for functionalism begin. The functionalist obviously allows that x has causal powers (it isn’t in the same category as a number or a disembodied spirit). If x’s being a belief that bread nourishes is consists in its having such and such effects – e.g.  its leading me to choose to eat bread, to decide to teach my children how to bake bread, and so on – then x’s having that content cannot be causative of my choosing to eat bread, bake it, teach my children how to bake it, and so on.
     Surely x’s being a belief that bread nourishes is what makes it have a certain causal role: it has a regulatory effect on that causal role . x’s being such a belief is what causes me to eat bread, to buy bread, to teach those I like how to bake bread. But if x’s being such a belief is identical with its having those effects – with its bringing about those states of affairs – then x’s being such a belief cannot be a cause of those states of affairs. After all, nothing is a cause of itself. Functionalism doesn’t allow mental content to regulate, or otherwise effect, x’s causal role, since functionalism identifies
[66]
x’s having such and such with x’s causal role.
      Let us sum up. If content is identified with causal role, then content cannot be what governs  causal role. But in that case, content doesn’t do anything; it becomes inert, a free-wheel or epiphenomenon. But plainly content is not inert; plainly content does a lot. So functionalism must be wrong.
 
 
III.     Another doctrine – content externalism – also seems to make content inert. Smith and Twin-Smith are atom for atom duplicates. But Smith is thinking about Mary, while twin-Smith is thinking about twin-Mary. The reason is that Smith’s brain-state has one distal cause (Mary), while twin-
Smith’s has another (twin-Mary). The difference in distal cause makes for a
[67]
	difference in content. But this difference in content seems to be inert. What does all the work is local: the spatially and temporally local property of Smith’s brain are what cause him to pick up the phone and dial those numbers; the same is true (mutatis mutandis) of Twin-Smith. The differences in distal causes are causally irrelevant: everything that does causal work is in the here and now – is lodged inside Smith’s and twin-Smith’s respective crania. It is irrelevant that Smith’s state was distally caused by Mary, as opposed twin-Mary or hologram-Mary or Robo-Mary. Smith’s state might as well have been caused by any one of them, so far as the causal properties of that state are concerned.
     But if the externalist is right, then Smith and twin-Smith have qualitatively different mental contents, corresponding to the differences in distal causes. Smith is having a thought about Mary, while twin-Smith is having a thought about twin-Mary. So, if externalism is right, that difference in content is inert.
[68]
 What is not inert – what does all the causal work – is precisely what Smith and twin-Smith have in common; and what they have in common is neutral between Mary and twin-Mary. The fact that Smith is thinking about Mary – as opposed to twin-Mary or Robo-Mary – is without causal consequences. So far as what he is doing right now, his current condition could have been caused by any one of the three. So to the extent that mental content is to be understood in externalist terms – to the extent that Smith and twin-Smith have qualitatively different mental contents in virtue of their differing causal liasons --  mental content doesn’t do anything. Externalism
[69]
thus appears to strip mental content of causal power.
 
IV.       Jackson and Pettit deal with these problems in a brilliant way. We must distinguish causal efficacy from they refer to as causal relevance.
    In everyday discourse, we say things like the following.
 
“The liquid in the glass froze (thus expanding); and that is what is caused the glass to shatter.”
 
The truth is: what caused the glass to shatter is something much more specific; it is the fact that, in certain very specific places, certain very specific pressures were put on the walls of the container.
     Consider the statement:
 
“The presence of a flame under the container caused the liquid to boil.”
 
Well, what really caused the container to heat up is much more specific: 
certain specific displacements of energy led to some other specific displacements of energy; and these displacements happened in a very specific region – a region coincident with, or vanishingly close to, the region occupied by the under-surface of the pan. Not every displacement of energy constitutive of the flame caused the increase in temperature. It wasn’t really the flame which did the work: it was certain very specific micro-events constitutive of the flame.
    One last example: 
 
“The pianist hit a wrong note because somebody coughed too loud.”
 
    Well, what really caused the pianist to hit a wrong note is much more specific. Smith coughed too loud – it wasn’t just somebody
   Causes are much more specific than our statements typically indicate; and the things we describe as “causes” – somebody’s coughing too loud, a flame’s being underneath the container, the temperature’s being too high – are not really what is doing the causal work; there is always something much more specific going on; some specific molecule (or atom or quark…) bouncing off of some other molecule (or atom…). In fact, in the end, the only things that are doing causal work are specific, minute displacements of mass-energy. The flame is much too expansive and gross an entity to be responsible for the fact that this, that, or any other specific part of the pan heats up; what heats up place x on the pan is always some specific mass-energy displacement.     But when we say things like “someone’s coughing caused the pianist to hit a wrong note”,  “the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up”, and “the freezing of the liquid caused the vessel to shatter”, what we are saying is surely not altogether wrong. There is plainly a sense in which it is true to say that somebody’s coughing is what caused the pianist to error, a sense in which it is true to say that the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up, and so on.
     Here is how Jackson and Pettit deal with it. The presence of the flame programs for the heating-up of the pan. Put another way, it is causally relevant without being causally efficacious in the heating of the pan. What does this mean? Given that there is a flame present, it necessarily follows that something which is causally efficacious in the heating up of the pan will be present. The flame is constituted by the specific displacements which did the causal work. And the presence of a flame in that place guarantees that some such displacements will be present which will do the causal work. So even though the flame per se is not what does the work, the presence of the flame is causally relevant to the heating up of the pan: the presence of the flame guarantees or “programs for” the presence of something which would do said work.
    The same principle (mutatis mutandis) applies in the other cases. What causes the glass to shatter is not the fact that the liquid inside has a certain temperature or volume. It is something more specific: the impact of certain molecules on certain other molecules. (Actually it is even more specific than that.) But the temperature of the glass is causally relevant. Given that the glass has such and such temperature, it is guaranteed, or “programmed for”, that there will be the kind of thing which is causally efficacious in the shattering of the glass. 
    What caused Horowitz to hit the wrong note was Smith’s coughing or Brown’s coughing: some specific person had to cough. The general fact that somebody or other in the vicinity coughed isn’t what did the trick. But that general fact does guarantee or program for the existence of the sort of singular fact which would do the trick. Given that somebody or other coughed, it follows that, for some specific x, x coughed: and the fact that x coughed is causally efficacious as regards Horowitz’s erring. So somebody or other’s coughing is causally relevant, though not causally efficacious, to Horowitz’s erring. It programs for the existence of something which is causally efficacious, even though it does not itself have that property.    Sometimes Jackson and Pettit describe the thing which causally relevant, but not causally efficacious, as the “program cause”. So the fact that somebody coughed is the program-cause of Horowitz’s erring; the fact that the flame was underneath the pan was the program cause of the pan’s heating
[70]
up to such and such temperature.
 
V.      Jackson and Pettit say that, if we take into account the distinction between causal efficacy and causal relevance, we can be functionalists or externalists and hold onto the idea that content has an important causal role. For the reason earlier given, what is causally efficacious in Smith’s reaching for the phone and dialing those numbers is not the fact that Smith is thinking about Mary. But Smith’s thinking about Mary is causally relevant. His doing so “programs for” the kind of thing that will do the trick – that will be causally efficacious in his hitting those seven numbers. So content has causal relevance (though not causal efficacy). So as far what is causally efficacious is concerned, it is irrelevant whether the distal cause of his current condition was Mary, twin-Mary, robo-Mary, or a hallucination. Thus Smith’s thinking about Mary – as opposed to twin-Mary or robo-Mary – is not causally efficacious. But Smith’s thinking about Mary is still causally relevant: his thinking about Mary programs for his dialing those seven numbers.     The flame programs for the specific micro-events E1…En which are causally efficacious in the heating of the pan, even though the flame is not itself thus efficacious. By distinguishing causal relevance (the property of programming for something causally efficacious) from causally efficacy, we recover our intuition that the flame has an important causal role in the heating of the pan. Similarly, Smith’s thinking about Mary programs for the occurrences of events E*1…E*n, which are causally efficacious as regards his dialing those seven numbers, even though his thinking about Mary – as opposed to twin-Mary or robo-Mary – is not thus efficacious. Once again, By distinguishing causal relevance from causally efficacy, we recover our intuition that Smith’s thinking about Mary has an important causal role in Smith’s thinking and acting. In general, by making that distinction, we reconcile our intuitions about the causal importance of representational content in mental and behavioral life with the evident truth of some kind of content externalism.
 
§    The same principle applies in the case of functionalism. (In this context, let us forget about the problems relating to differences between thinking about water/twin-water, and the like.) For the reasons we described earlier, Smith’s wanting water cannot be causally efficacious in Smith’s reaching for the glass: it cannot, strictly speaking, what causes Smith to do that. But it can be causally relevant. Smith’s being thirsty “programs for” his doing that sort of thing; the presence of thirst guarantees the presence of the kinds of things which would to the causal work in Smith’s reaching for the glass.
   

	* I believe that Jackson and Pettit have had a profound insight intocausality and causal explanation. But I don’t think that insight helps out functionalism or externalism in the way that they think. First we will deal with the functionalist case.
      Let us start with some platitudes. Nothing can be “causally relevant” to itself. A state of affairs cannot be “causally relevant” to its own existence. Obviously things are relevant to themselves. But the relevance isn’t causal.      Of course, the term “causal relevance” (as Jackson and Pettit are using it) is an invented one; so we can give it any meaning we wish. But surely it would be  deeply misleading to say describe the kind of relevance that event E has to itself as causal. The relation is better described as logical, or perhaps metaphysical. E is not causally related to itself; and it doesn’t matter whether we are taking about causal efficacy or causal relevance. Obviously the kind of relation Jackson and Pettit have in mind, when they talk about “causal relevance” is some kind of causal relation; it is not a relation which something can have to itself; the word “causal” is there for a reason. So nothing can be “causally relevant” to itself.
      The functionalist says that x’s causing E1…En is what x’s having C consists in. There is an identity here, not a causal relation. At the same time, it is clear, from a common-sense point of view, that x’s having content C –
e.g. x’s being a desire for water – has some kind of causal hand in bringing about E1…En (i.e. that it has a causal hand in bringing it about that Smith reaches for the glass). If x’s having C is identical with x’s bringing about
E1…En, x’s having C cannot be causally effective in bringing about E1…En: after all, x’s bringing about E1…En cannot cause x’s bringing about E1…En. By the same token, x’s having C cannot be causally relevant to the bringing about of E1…En. Nothing can be causally relevant to itself. If the functionalist is right, then x’s bringing about E1…En is identical with x’s having C. So if the functionalist is right, then x’s having C – i.e. its bringing about E1…En – cannot be causally relevant to its bringing about E1…En. It cannot be causally relevant, any more than it be causally effective. So the Jackson and Pettit maneuver fails.
 

	* To deal with the externalist-case, a background point is in order.Sometimes Jackson and Pettit analyze the notion of causal relevance in counter-factual terms:  x is causally relevant to the occurrence of y if, in any counterfactual circumstance where x exists, there also exists something causally effective in bringing about y. The problem is that this is too generous. My striking the glass with the hammer is sufficient, in the counterfactual sense just defined, for the breaking of the glass. The same is true my of striking the glass while wearing a yellow hat and having green teeth and wearing a spacesuit…But surely my wearing a yellow hat/spacesuit/having green teeth…is not in any sense “causally relevant” to the breaking of the glass. The counterfactual analysis is too broad, too expansive.      The counter-factual analysis of causal relevance needs to be tightened. But we don’t want to tighten it too much. For example, we don’t want to say that the program-cause is the smallest thing x such that x counterfactually guarantees the presence of something causally efficacious. After all, the smallest thing that gives that guarantee is the mass-energy displacement itself. But we don’t want to say that only that mass-energy displacement is causally relevant: surely we want to allow the flame of which it is a part is causally relevant; we don’t want to shrink causal relevance down to causal efficacy.
       The notion of causal relevance is, I believe, to be understood in terms of the notion of redundancy – in terms of the notion of a back-up mechanism. Consider the case where, as we loosely say, the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up. Let x be the specific mass-energy displacements constitutive of the fire which, in the actual case, did the trick. The flame is causally relevant because in any case where you have the flame, but where x (for some reason) didn’t do the trick, the flame guarantees that some other mass-energy displacements y will do the trick. So, it seems, causal relevance can be understood in terms of “back-up” mechanisms. In any situation where someone or other in the vicinity coughed loud enough, but where Smith (the actual cougher) did not cough, that is enough to make Horowitz hit the wrong key.
    Now Smith’s wearing a yellow hat is not causally relevant to Horowitz’s erring, because it doesn’t constitute the right kind of back-up mechanism; it doesn’t amplify the range of cases where something is causally efficacious in getting Horowitz to err. By contrast, the whole flame is causally relevant to the heating because, if the flame were smaller, that would eliminate some back-up mechanisms; it would shrink the range of mass-energy displacements that would step into the breach in situations where x  (the totality of mass-energy displacements that in fact did the trick) isn’t being causally efficacious. But Smith’s wearing a yellow hat, the flame’s coming from a green as opposed to a blue lighter – or its coming from a lighter as opposed to a newspaper – doesn’t provide this sort of counterfactual reinforcement. It is inert in this respect.
      The same is true of the fact that Smith’s brain-state has its origin in Mary, as opposed to twin-Mary, or Mary-7, or Robo-Mary, or hologram-Mary or a Cartesian demon or bent light-rays. What is causally efficacious is some congeries X of mass-energy displacements at various contact-points in Smith’s nervous system. What is causally relevant are the structures that guarantee, in counter-factual situations where X didn’t do the trick, some congeries Y would. What is not causally relevant is anything that doesn’t provide this sort of reinforcement; where that ends, so does causal relevance. Now consider the things going on outside Smith’s cranium. Are any of these things going to step into the breach in counter-factual situations where X isn’t doing the trick? Consider a counter-factual situation where X isn’t doing the trick. Is the fact that Smith’s brain-state originates with Mary (as opposed to twin-Mary or Mary3) going to help out? Is it going provide needed back-up? No. It is inert. It would provide back-up only to the extent that it led to the right kind of brain-structure or, in any case, the right kind of local phenomenon that would provide back-up.
    

	* In this context, we have to make sure that our terminology isn’t doingthe thinking for us. Jackson and Pettit are using the term “causally relevant” in a technical sense. But, of course, that expression has a non-technical sense; one could use it in ordinary speech, and be understood. In the non-technical sense, the Big Bang is obviously “causally relevant” to everything that is now the case, including the fact that I’m typing on a computer. In fact, give or take a few niceties relating to quantum-indeterminacy, the Big Bang was causally sufficient for that, and every other, contemporary fact. But the Big Bang is not “causally relevant” in Jackson and Pettit’s technical sense.      The concept that Jackson and Pettit are labeling with the expression “causal relevance” is an important, coherent, and explanatorily fecund
[71]
	one, and that concept deserves some kind of label. But it is easy to conflate  the technical meaning of “causally relevant” with its original, nontechnical meaning. And such a conflation could easily create the illusion that the concept of causal relevance has application where it really does not. In fact, I feel that, in their application of  their insights into causation to the issues under discussion, Jackson and Pettit themselves may be guilty of this sort of conflation.
     Let us use the expression “causally relevant JP” to refer to causal relevance in the technical Jackson-Pettit sense.   And let us use the expression “causally relevant” to refer to causal relevance in the non-technical, preJackson-Pettit sense. The Big Bang is obviously causally relevant to the fact that I am not typing– after all, it is the ultimate cause: and how could it be more causally relevant than that? But the Big Bang is not causally relevant JP to my typing. (Having made this point, let us now go back to using the term “causal relevance” – no subscript – in the technical sense in which Jackson and Pettit use it.)
    Now let us consider the paradigms through which Jackson and Pettit give meaning to their technical use of the term “causal relevance”. Horowitz hits the wrong note. What causes that to happen is Smith’s coughing or Brown’s coughing: it isn’t just someone’s coughing. (Causal efficacy resides in singular facts.) But the general fact that someone or other coughed is causally relevant to Horowitz’s hitting the wrong note . Why? Because that general fact guarantees that there will be a singular fact of the right kind; it guarantees that, for some individual x, there will be a singular fact of the form x coughed.  Now what is the nature of this guarantee? We are not talking about a causal guarantee. It is not as though someone’s coughing at time t causes Smith’s coughing at time t+1, which in turn causes Horowitz to hit the wrong note. No – the guarantee here is much tighter than that. It is in the nature of a logical or metaphysical guarantee. Given that someone coughed (in the right vicinity), it follows logically – not causally – that, for some specific x, x coughed. So the fact that someone coughed logically guarantees that the right kind of singular fact will obtain.
        What causes the pan to heat up is the fact that there are certain specific events in an area coincident with, or vanishingly close to, the bottom of the pan. The much more encompassing fact that there is a flame underneath the pan isn’t what does the trick. What does the trick is much more specific. But the just mentioned more encompassing fact is causally relevant to the heating of the pan. Why? Because it guarantees that the right kind of specific events will occur. What is the nature of that guarantee? It isn’t a causal guarantee. The specific mass-energy displacements which do the trick are constitutive of the flame. The flame comprises innumerable mass-energy displacements; and the ones which are causally efficacious in the heating of the pan are among them. The aforementioned guarantee is not causal. Here is the wrong story. The flame exists at t, and that causes there to be certain other events E1…En at time t+1; and, in their turn, E1…En cause the pan to heat. That isn’t how it works. Here is the right story. The flame is simultaneous with E1…En. This is to be expected, since E1…En are constituents of the flame. The flame guarantees the existence of the right kind of specific pan-heating events in the sense that the flame is constituted by all manner events which will do the trick. If the flame were present but, for some reason, E1…En didn’t occur, other events E*1…E*n would occur, where E*1…E*n would do the trick. It isn’t that the flame would cause E*1…E*n to happen; it is that the flame would comprise those events. The flame is constituted by the kinds of things which will be causally efficacious in the heating of the pan. And that is the sense in which the presence of the flame underneath the pan “programs for” the heating of the pan; that is the nature of the guarantee previously mentioned. The presence of the right kind of events is guaranteed not in a causal, but a metaphysical (for lack of a better word) sense: the flame doesn’t cause there to be the right kind of events; the flame is constituted by the right kind of events.
     Exactly similar remarks apply to the case of the liquids shattering the walls of the vessel. Here is wrong picture. The liquid expands at t. That expansion causes certain other events E1…En. E1…En, in their turn, cause the walls to crack. Here is the right picture. The liquid expands at t. That expansion involves the occurrence of certain events E1…En. And E1…En (the specific mass-energy displacements at, or vanishingly close to, the interior surface of the vessel) cause the vessel to crack. If the  liquid-expands, among the events involved in that expansion – among the events constitutive of it – are such as will be causally efficacious in the cracking of the glass. So it is not in a causal sense that the expanding of the liquid guarantees the existence of causally efficacious events. The guarantee is metaphysical (for lack of a better word): the expansion is constituted by the right kind of events.
     Let us bring these points to bear on the Mary/twin-Mary case. Smith decides to hit seven numbers on his phone. Mary  -- or, better, some state of affairs involving Mary -- is a (contributory) distal cause of this. Let S1 be that state of affairs, that distal (contributory) cause. And let S2 be the event of Smith’s hitting those seven numbers. It may be that the occurrence of S1 in some sense “guarantees” the occurrences of S2. But the guarantee here is causal. S1 is buried in the remote recesses of space-time. (To fix our ideas, suppose that Mary and Smith haven’t seen each other in sixty years.) There is no sense in which S2 is constitutive of S1 (or vice versa). And, of course, there is no purely logical between them. So the sense in which S1 guarantees S2 isn’t remotely comparable to the sense in which someone’s coughing guarantees that, for some specific x, x coughs; and it isn’t remotely comparable to the sense in which the presence of the flame guarantees the existence of the right kind of specific mass-energy displacements at, or vanishingly near, the surface of the pan.
        Now there are events which, while not themselves being causally efficacious in making Smith dial those seven numbers, do yet guarantee that he will do so, where “guarantee” is being used to denote the right logical or metaphysical relationship – the kind that holds between someone’s coughing and Smith’s coughing, between the flame’s being underneath the pan and the pan’s being heated. What is it that is causally efficacious in making Smith dial (or at least choose to dial) those numbers? Certain specific mass-energy displacements at, or vanishingly near, certain neural contact points. So what is causally efficacious isn’t exactly some chemical (or electrical) storm in Smith’s brain – some flurry of z-fibers or whatnot. The storm is much too encompassing an entity to be causally efficacious (just as the flame is too encompassing an entity to be causally efficacious in heating the pan): causal efficacy resides at (or vanishingly near) contact points; the storm includes things that happens at those contact points, but it also includes things that are (relatively speaking) far away from them. Nonetheless, that chemical storm – the thing that neurologists speak of as “the cause” of Smith’s number-pushing muscle-spasms – in some sense guarantees that the right kind of events will happen at those contact points. What is the nature of that guarantee? The chemical storm consists of those events (and others). The occurrence of the storm guarantees the existence of the right events at the contact points because the storm consists of events that will do the trick. In the actual world, the storm comprises E1…En – these being the relevant events at the contactpoints. But if the storm hadn’t comprised specifically E1…En, it would have comprised E*1…E*n, where E*1…E*n would have done the trick. It would have done this because the chemical storm is composed of the right kind of events – not because it would have caused the right kind of events. So what is causally relevant to, but not causally efficacious in, Smith’s dialing those numbers is not some long gone state of affairs involving Mary: it is some contemporaneous state of affairs which comprises the causally efficacious events. Events buried in the past – whether they involve Mary, twin-Mary, or
Robo-Mary – are not, in Jackson and Pettit’s technical sense of the phrase, “causally relevant” at all. They are causes; but they are not causally efficacious – for causal efficacy resides in what is doing the work right now – and they are not “causally relevant” (in the technical sense) because what is causally relevant comprises what is doing the work right now.
   Notice that, in the paradigms through which Jackson and Pettit define their technical term “causal relevance”, the state of affairs that is causally relevant is always contemporaneous with the state of affairs that is causally efficacious. Someone’s coughing must happen at the same time as Smith’s coughing. The flame’s being underneath the pan happens at the same time as E1…En occurring at, or vanishingly near, the under-surface of the pan. The liquid’s expanding happens at the same time as E*1…E*n happening at, or vanishingly near, the interior surface of the beaker. But with regard to the state of affairs involving Mary – or, better, involving long dead star Beta – in virtue of which I am now thinking about Mary as opposed to twin-Mary, about Beta as opposed to twin-Beta – that state of affairs is quite definitely not contemporaneous with the events which are causally efficacious in my dialing those numbers, not even after we take into account the adjustments to our concept of simultaneity demanded by relativity-theory and the like. And this should tell us something as to whether the Mary/twin-Mary case is on all fours with the Smith-someone/flame-E1…En case.

THE USELESSNESS OF THE RAMSEY-LEWIS SENTENCE
 
Functionalism may be defined as follows. For something x to qualify as an instance of mental type T just is for x to have a certain ‘causal role’, where having a certain ‘causal role’ means having certain causes and certain effects. For any mental type T, and any object or state of affairs x, x qualifies as an instance of wholly in virtue of having certain causes and certain effects.
   So for functionalism, there is nothing to being a certain kind of pain, or a certain kind of belief, or a certain kind of intention, besides having certain causes and certain effects. In general, for functionalism, there is nothing to being an instance of a mental type other than having certain causes and effects.
  Functionalism is almost always used to abet some form of materialism. A little background will help make it clear why this is so.
    For functionalism, what makes x  qualify as (say) a belief that snow is white is not that x is made of this or that material, but that x is caused by certain things and causes certain other things.  And there seems to be no reason why a brain state shouldn’t have just those causes and effects. Consider the causes and effects characteristic of a belief that snow is white. There doesn’t seem to be any reason why a brain state shouldn’t have those causes and those effects. Anything can cause anything; causal connections hold only contingently. So there is no reason why (say) a certain pattern of neuro-chemical activity shouldn’t have just those causes and effects characteristic of a belief that snow is white. So if all there is to being a belief that snow is white is having those characteristics and effects, then there is no reason why a certain pattern of neuro-chemical activity shouldn’t be a belief that snow is white.
    And therewith the relationship of mind to body vanishes. Since anything with the right causal connections qualifies as (say) a belief that snow is white, and since anything physical could in principle have those connections, there is no problem assimilating beliefs that snow is white to physical states of affairs. The same applies, of course, to any mental type. Thus functionalism successfully reduces the mental to the physical – or, in any case, shows that such a reduction is possible.
    But  a certain prima facie circularity characterizes this picture. Given practically any mental type T, instances of that type have other mental entities among their characteristic causes and effects. Consider the belief that snow is white. Instances of this type – that is, particular cases of the belief that snow is white – characteristically have certain mental causes and characteristically have certain mental effects. For example, a belief that snow is white might characteristically be caused by certain sense-perceptions, operating in conjunction with certain back-ground concepts and beliefs. And a belief that snow is white might, in conjunction with other background beliefs and concepts, characteristically result in other beliefs (e.g. the belief that snow is not green or the belief that snow absorbs less light than tar). 
  Given any mental type, even those whose instances have the most tenuous connections with other mental entities, we still find that those instances have other mental entities among their characteristic causes and effects. Arguably, even tickles and itches have, among their characteristic effects, other mental states of affairs.
   So the attempt to use functionalism to reduce the mental to the physical seems guilty of a certain circularity. Functionalism says that a belief that snow is white will be identical with, or constituted by, a certain pattern of electrical activity provided that that electrical activity has the right causes and effects. So up to this point functionalism seems to be doing a good job of reducing the belief the electrical activity. But then it turns out that among the ‘right’ causes and effects are other mental entities. So functionalism, it turns out, reduces the belief that snow is white to electrical activity plus various other mental entities. So functionalism reduces the mental to the physical plus the mental, and thus doesn’t reduce the mental at all. (Cf. Quine’s point that conventionalism reduces logic to convention plus logic and thus doesn’t reduce logic to convention at all.)
[72]
	  David Lewis came up with an argument that -- so it is widely thought – shows functionalism not to be guilty of the circularity just described or, if you prefer, that shows the circularity just described not to threaten the possibility of using functionalism to reduce the mental to the physical. 
   I do not believe that Lewis has really succeeded in ridding functionalism of any kind of circularity. That is what I will try to show in this paper. He has, I admit, outlined a way to ‘decircularize’ functionalism. But once we scrutinize this outline, we find that, if it were stated in ‘non-outline’ form, it would itself turn out to be embody a vicious circularity.
     Lewis’ attempt to de-circularize functionalism makes essential use of the idea that there is a ‘Ramsey sentence’ for mental phenomena. (We will spend a great deal of time stating just what this means.) Lewis doesn’t actually give us that Ramsey sentence itself. He just gives us a recipe for constructing it. But if Lewis’ solution is to work, the Ramsey sentence must exist; it must be possible, at least in principle, to construct that sentence.  If the Ramsey sentence for the mental cannot be constructed – if, in effect,  that sentence doesn’t exist -- then Lewis’ solution fails. I will show, in effect, that there is no way to construct the Ramsey sentence for the mental.  The idea that Lewis’ solution works is based on tendency look at that solution only at a very abstract and schematic level – a failure not to consider what is really involved in constructing the Ramsey sentence of which Lewis speaks, but which he never actually produces.
 
II.      Let us spend the next few pages stating Lewis’ alleged solution. As we know, for a functionalist the nature of any mental type – e.g. the type pain – is given by a set of propositions saying what characteristically causes instances of that type and what instances of that type characteristically result in. Imagine that, for each mental type, you have identified the propositions which give the characteristic causes and effects of instances of that mental type. Let P1, P2…Pn be this set of propositions. (So P1 says e.g. for some specific kind of ache, what the characteristic causes and effects of aches of that kind are.) These propositions may, of course, be conjoined. Let us refer to the conjunction of these propositions as S1.
 A couple of clarificatory points are in order. First of all, S1 is not a statement about this or that person’s psychology; S1 says in general what are the characteristic causes and effects of types of mental entities. So the ‘mental constants’ in S1 are not going to be anything like ‘Buddy’s fear of heights’ or ‘Tom’s love of tobacco’; the mental constants will be of the form ‘the type fear of heights.’ So S1 will (very roughly) have the form ‘the characteristic causes and effects of instances of the type “fear of heights’ are such and such and thus and such.’ To sum up, the mental constants in S1 will refer, not to specific mental entities (not e.g. to Harry’s anger at having been given a C on a paper) but to mental types (to the type ‘anger at having been given a C on a paper’).
Closely connected with this last point is another. S1 does not state that such and such actual mental states of affairs obtained. (For – to echo what we said a moment ago – S1 is not a psycho-biography of Tom or Dick or Harry – of any actual individual.) It describes possible sequences of mental states of affairs. More specifically, it says, for each type of mental entity, what are the characteristic causes and effects of instances of that type.
It must be pointed out that, for at least some mental types, among the characteristic causes and/or effects of instances of those types are merely physical events (or states). (By a merely physical entity I mean something that is physical and is not also mental. So e.g. an explosion is merely physical because it doesn’t mediate mental activity. By contrast, c-fibre stimulation – if it really is identical with pain – is not merely physical, although it obviously is physical.) For example the characteristic causes of pain are surely certain merely physical states, e.g. certain kinds of tissue damage, and among the characteristic effects of pain are other merely physical states, e.g. heightened blood pressure, dilation of the pupils. Consequently S1 is going to contain terms referring to types of merely physical events, as well as terms referring to types of mental events.
  It will be useful to stipulate some terminology. Consider some existence claim, say ‘for some x, x is green.’ Let us suppose that α is a term that denotes something green (e.g. α  might be the term ‘grass’ or ‘Kermit the frog’). In that case, let us say that α – or, more strictly, the sequence <α> -‘satisfies’ the existence claim ‘for some x, x is green.’ In general, given any existence claim ‘for some x1, x2…xn,  <x1, x2…xn> has property P’ (where P is an n-place predicate, i.e. a relation which takes n arguments), let us say of any sequence <a1, a2…an> which has property P that it satisfies that existence claim. So for example, consider the existence claim ‘for some x1, for some x, x loves y’ (equivalently: ‘for some x1, for some x2 <x1, x2> has the two place property loves’). The pair <Romeo, Juliet> satisfies that existence claim, while the pair <Saddam, Bush> does not.
   Another related bit of terminology will be useful. Consider an arbitrary existence claim ‘for some x1, for some x2…for some xn <x1, x2….xn> has property P.’ (Again, P must be an n-place property, i.e. a relation which takes n arguments.) And suppose that α is a constant such that, if α replaces xi, and the corresponding existential quantifier is dropped (i.e. the ‘for some xi’ is dropped), the result is a true claim. In that case, let us say, α satisfies the existence claim in question with respect to the ith variable. So consider the existence claim ‘for some x1, for some x2 <x1, x2> stands in the relation loves’ (equivalently: ‘for some x1, for some x2, x1 loves x2’). Now if we substitute the constant Romeo for the variable x1, and drop the corresponding quantifier, the result is ‘for some x2, Romeo loves x2’; which is obviously true (for there is somebody whom Romeo loves – namely, Juliet). So, as we will say, the constant Romeo satisfies this existence claim with respect to the first variable. (Of course, Romeo also satisfies that existence claim with respect to the second variable; for Romeo is loved by somebody – namely, Juliet.)
 With these bits of terminology in place, let us proceed. S1 is presumably going to contain a number of occurrences of the term ‘pain’ (or some synonym: we are assuming for the sake of convenience that S1 is in English).
Suppose that you replace each occurrence of this term with a variable, say x1. The result will, of course, be an open sentence. Now suppose that you prefix this open sentence with the quantifier ‘for some x1’. The result will, of course, be an existence claim; let S2 be this existence claim. Now anything which satisfies that existence must have exactly the same causal relations as pain. (This clearly follows from the way in which S2 is constructed out of S1, and from the way in which S1 is constructed out of P1, P2…Pn.) So, if functionalism is correct – that is, if something qualifies as pain (or as a belief that snow is white or as a regret at not having majored in pharmacology…) wholly in virtue of its causal relations – then anything which satisfies S2 is pain.
    Now suppose we do the following with S2. We take every occurrence of the term ‘anger’ (or its synonyms) and replace it with a variable x2. Again, the result is an open sentence. Now prefix this open sentence with the quantifier ‘for some x2’; and let this new existence claim be S3. Given how S3 was formed, it is clear that any sequence which satisfies it will consist of a sequence containing a term denoting something which has the same causal relations as a anger and a term denoting something that has the same causal relations as pain, in that order. So if functionalism is right – if something is anger or pain wholly by virtue of its causal relations – then any sequence which satisfies S3 must consist of a term denoting anger and one denting pain, in that order. And – what follows more or less trivially from what we’ve said – anything which satisfies S3 with respect to the second variable has the same causal relations as anger, and – if functionalism is correct – therefore is anger.
   Obviously the just described process can be continued until every mental term in S1 has been replaced by a variable and the resulting open sentence pre-fixed by the appropriate existential quantifier. Let Sn be the resulting giant existence claim. Given how Sn was formed, it is clear that any sequence <a1, a2…an> which satisfies Sn has the following property: for each i, ai will have the exact same causal relations as the term which xi replaced. So let us say that Si was formed by replacing each occurrence of the term ‘belief that snow is white’ (or its synonyms) with xi, and then pre-fixing the resulting open sentence with the quantifier ‘for some xi’. The term ai in the sequence <a1, a2…an> will have the same causal relations as the term ‘belief that snow is white’. So if functionalism is correct – if mental things are wholly individuated by their causes and effects – then given any sequence <a1, a2… an> such that, for each i, ai has the same causal relations as the term in S1 which xi replaced,  that sequence will contain each of the mental terms occurring in S1. More to the point: Sn will completely describe the causal relations of all of the mental terms occurring in Sn; this is because, to reiterate, for each i, ai has the exact same causal relations as the term in S1 which xi replaced.
  Sn will, of course, contain no terms referring to physical objects – each of these having been ‘Ramsified out’ (i.e. having been removed and replaced by a variable, with the resulting open sentence being prefixed by an existential quantifier). So Sn (in effect) describes the causal relations characteristic of mental types (at any rate, those mentioned in S1) entirely in terms of physical inputs and outputs. At the same time, Sn does justice to the fact that mental entities are individuated (at least in part) by their relations to other mental entities.
    So, to sum up: (i) Sn gives a complete statement of the causal relations characteristic of all the mental entities referred to in S1; (ii) it describes these relations entirely in terms of physical inputs and outputs (i.e. without using any terms denoting mental entities); and (iii) it does justice to the fact mental entities are individuated (at least in part) by their relations to other mental entities. Condition (iii) is important because a functionalism that does not recognize that mental entities have constitutive ties to other mental entities collapses into behaviorism or, in any case, some kind of eliminativism about the mental.
    This sums up Lewis’ way of making functionalism be non-circular – of reducing (in a functionalist manner) the mental to the physical, as opposed to reducing the mental to the physical plus the mental. The essence of Lewis’ solution, it should be apparent, is to describe the causal relations characteristic of the class of mental entities as a whole in terms of inputs and outputs: this can be done wholly in terms of physical inputs and outputs. By contrast, any attempt to describe the causal relations of a particular kind of mental state of affairs in terms of physical inputs and outputs – e.g. the type pain – will necessarily be a description of that state of affairs in terms of physical inputs and outputs and mental inputs and outputs.
 
III.      Recall how the Lewis sentence is formed. For each mental type Mi, we consider the sentence (or proposition) that says what the characteristic causes and effects are of instances of Mi; and we let Pi be that sentence. We then conjoin P1, P2…Pn; and we let S1 be this sentence. Finally, we ‘Ramsify out’ the mental terms in S1.
     There is a major problem with this analysis. Any given mental type can be caused by infinitely many different types of states of affairs and can result in infinitely many different types of states of affairs. (I will defend this point in a moment.) What I will now try to show is that, because this is the case, the sentence that Lewis describes either (depending how you look at it) doesn’t exist or must contain unreduced mental terms.
Consider the belief that snow is white. There are infinitely many ways a person could arrive at this belief. A person could arrive at it by seeing white snow. Or a person could arrive at it by taking somebody else’s word for it. Or, most importantly, a person could arrive at it through some kind of scientific inference. Imagine a race of people so small that they couldn’t actually see that snow is white: they could nonetheless figure out that snow is white by inferring what the reflective properties of snow are through some complicated theoretical apparatus. Plainly there are, in principle, infinitely many belief systems – infinitely many deductive or cognitive machineries -through which one could figure out, or otherwise ascertain, that snow is white.
   And just as plainly, the belief that snow is white could feed into infinitely many different belief systems and thus have infinitely many different effects.
If you are forced to learn that snow is white through some elaborate body of physical theory – because, say, you are too small (or too big) to see that snow is white – then obviously the repercussions of your learning that snow is white will be very different from the repercussions of, say, an ordinary sized human’s learning that snow is white. To sum up, there is no limit to the variety of different ways one could learn that snow is white, and no limit to the variety of different effects having this belief might have within the economy of one’s intellect. In a word, there are infinitely many causal roles that this belief could play.
Obviously someone who wishes to state the Ramsey-Lewis sentence cannot individually mention each of these causal roles. Remember, the functionalist says that for x to be a belief that snow is white just is for x to play a certain causal role. Now if you then ask the functionalist, ‘what is the causal role played by the belief that snow is white?’, he cannot say ‘well, it is the causal role played by the belief that snow is white’: obviously that would not be a satisfactory answer – at least from his point of view. Remember that someone trying to construct the Ramsey-Lewis sentence for the mental is trying, in effect, to eliminate mental terms (like ‘belief that snow is white’) in favor of statement about the causes and effects of instances of the mental type corresponding to that term. So terms like ‘belief that snow is white’, ‘delight in the fact that snow is white’, etc. cannot figure in a completed RamseyLewis sentence; they must all be Ramsified out. So someone trying to construct the Ramsey sentence for the mental has to get rid of terms like ‘belief that snow is white’, in favor of mention of the causal roles of instances of the mental types associated with those terms. So if you ask someone trying to construct the Ramsey sentence for the mental ‘what is the causal role played by the belief that snow is white?’, his answer cannot be ‘well, it is just that - -the causal role played by the belief that snow is white.’ That cannot be his final answer because, if it were, then his version of the Ramsey sentence would contain an ‘unreduced’ mental term (namely ‘belief that snow is white’ or some synonym), and it is the main purpose of the Ramsey-Lewis to get rid of such terms. No – he must specify the causal role of the belief that snow is white without using the term  like ‘belief that snow is white’  or any cognate term.
   To put this point another way: suppose you say to the functionalist ‘look, there are infinitely many causal roles that could be played by the belief that snow is white: what do all these causal roles have in common?’ The functionalist cannot answer this by saying ‘what they all have in common is that they are all occupied by the belief that snow is white.’  He must be able to say what that causal role is without having to define that causal role in terms of the belief that snow is white. For if he cannot do this, then he will be left with an ‘unreduced’ mental term, and his Ramsey sentence for the mental will not do what it is supposed to – it will not eliminate mental terms and thus, a fortiori, will not eliminate them in favor of non-mental terms.
   But mental types are typically such that their instances can be caused in infinitely many different ways and are such that their instances can have infinitely many different effects. There are infinitely many different ways that the belief that snow is white could be acquired, and there are infinitely many different effects that such a belief could have. So there are infinitely many different causal roles that such a belief could play. A belief that snow is white can be located on infinitely many different causal paths.
    Given that there are infinitely many causal roles that a belief that snow is white could have, the person tasked with giving the Lewis sentence now has a problem; for he obviously cannot mention each of these causal roles individually: he cannot just give a list of all these causal roles. So, plainly, he must mention something that all of these different causal roles have in common; he must identify some property that all (and only) these causal roles have in common. There is, of course, something that all and only these causal roles have in common: they are all causal roles occupied by the belief that snow is white. But remember what we said a moment ago: the functionalist must be able to state what these various roles have in common other than their all being occupied by the belief that snow is white. (For if he does not do this, then his Ramsey sentence will contain an ‘unreduced’ mental term, and will thus not do its job of eliminating the use of such terms.) So let us ask: apart from all being occupied by the belief that snow is white, what do these infinitely many causal roles have in common? Equivalently, without using a term like ‘belief that snow is white’ (or a cognate term), is there some way to state  what all these causal roles have in common.
   I very much doubt that that there is any property that all and only these causal roles have in common apart from being occupied by the belief that snow is white. Obviously the causal role of such a belief will be determined (at least in part) by what kinds of inferences people make from that belief, and also what kinds of inferences lead them to form that belief. So (assuming that sentient beings have some minimal tendency to be rational), the causal role of the belief that snow is white will ‘track’ the inferential role of the proposition snow is white. Now think about all the inferences that involve this belief – that this belief ‘validates’. Jerry thinks that grass is the color of snow; so Jerry infers that grass is white. Zeldar thinks that tennis ball are either the color of snow or are round-squares; so Zeldar thinks that tennis balls are white. I very much doubt that there is some property that all and only these transitions have other than there being validated by the belief that snow is white. (More exactly, I doubt that there is some property that all these transitions have in common other than there being validated by the belief that snow is white and other than their being validated by beliefs that contain or involve commitment to this belief  – e.g. the belief that either snow is white or 2=3 or the belief that if snow is not white, then the Pythagorean theorem doesn’t hold for Euclidean triangles. If we say that what the aforementioned transitions have in common is that they are validated by one of these exotic equivalents of the belief that snow is white, then we are still stuck with an unreduced mental term: for we are still identifying the class of all these transitions by saying that what all its members have in common is that they are validated by the belief that e.g. either snow is white or 2=3.)
To sum up, any given belief can occupy infinitely many causal roles. In fact, as a matter of empirical fact, the same belief (i.e. belief in the same proposition) occupies different causal roles in any two people you might choose. The functionalist has to say what all these causal roles have in common other than their being occupied by the belief in question. In any case, the Lewis sentence eliminates mention of ‘the belief that snow is white’ in favor of mention of its causal role. So anyone trying to give the Lewis sentence must mention what all these causal roles have in common other than being occupied by the belief that snow is white. There doesn’t seem to be any way to do this. The belief that snow is white can validate infinitely many different transitions. There is no way – at least no way I can see -- to identify this class of transitions except as the class of all and only those inferences validated by the belief that snow is white.  This class is, of course, infinitely large; so its members cannot be listed. So this class must be identified by citing some property that all its members have in common. There is such a property, of course: all its members have the property that they are validated by the belief that snow is white. But someone trying to construct the RamseyLewis sentence for the mental cannot identify this class in that way. For reasons we stated earlier, in order to avoid having an unreduced – un-‘Ramsified out’ – mental term in his Ramsey-Lewis sentence for the mental, one must identify some property that all members of this class have in common other than that they are validated by the belief that snow is white (or trivial variants of this belief, e.g. grass is either green or not green).  And, it is safe to say, there is no such property: the only way to identify to say what objects (events, states of affairs) fall into this class is in terms of the belief that snow is white (or in terms of some equivalent belief, e.g. if snow is not white, then 2 is greater than 4). In any case, I challenge anyone to
produce some other way of singling out the membership of this class. [1]    
Stephen Stich makes some points very similar to those made in the last few pages:
 
Typically, if a person believes that everyone aboard the morning flight to Bamako was killed in a crash, and if he comes to believe that the prime minister of Mali was on that flight, those two beliefs together will cause him to believe that the prime minister is dead. Typically, if a person wants to go to New Zealand, and if she comes to believe that she must get a visa in order to make the trip, she will acquire a desire to get a visa. Endlessly many further examples might easily be constructed. But therein lies a problem, for there is no hyperbole in the prospect of endlessly many [Stich’s emphasis] further examples. There are literally infinitely many inferential paths leading both to and from every belief…If a person believes [that Niger is west of Mali] and comes to belief that if Niger is west of Mali then Niger has more than two million inhabitants, he will typically come to believe that Niger has more than two million inhabitants. And so on, ad infinitum. Moreover, obviously, this is just the beginning. (Suppose he believes that if Niger is west of Mali, then Niger grows 5 percent more grain, or that if Niger is west of Mali, then Mali is more politically stable, or…[Stich’s ellipsis]) If we are to construct our implicit functional definition of ‘believes that Niger is west of Mali’ from the conjunction of these commonsense platitudes about inference, then the definition will have to be infinitely long! [Stich’s emphasis.] Now some stout-hearted souls are not intimidated by infinitely long conjunctions, provided they can be recursively summarized….But it is far from clear that the class of inferences recognized by common sense is
[73] 	[Stich’s emphasis] recursively characterizable.  
 
  What I have been maintaining is that the list of inferences – the list of inferences leading both  to and from (say) a belief that Niger is west of Mali is (i) infinite and (ii) not capable of any recursive characterization– except a characterization that  employs the term ‘belief that Niger is west of Mali’ (or some synonym) or some analytically equivalent mental term (perhaps an analytically equivalent term would be. ‘pro-attitude towards the proposition Niger is west of Mali’). The point is that, unless we help ourselves to the very mental terms we are trying to define – in this case belief that Niger is west of Mali – we cannot recursively characterize the causal role of that belief (and therefore cannot define it at all: for a non-recursive characterization of it would be an infinitely long, and therefore unstateable, conjunction). At the same time, if we do help ourselves to that mental term, or some analytic equivalent, then our characterization will obviously not be appropriately eliminative; we will be stuck with an unreduced mental term and will have failed to state the causal roles of instances of mental types wholly in terms of physical entities.
I would like to discharge a bold assertion I made a moment ago. Once again consider the type belief that snow is white. Let C be the class of characteristic causes and effects of instances of that type. I said:
