  The only way to say what objects fall into this class is in terms of the belief that snow is white (or in terms of some equivalent belief, e.g. if snow is not white, then 2 is greater than 4). In any case, I challenge anyone to produce some other way of singling out the membership of this class.
 
  I would like to substantiate this arrogant claim. For I think that, as a matter of logic, it is provable that the challenge in question cannot be met.
   As we’ve noted, the functional role of the belief that snow is white tends to track its inferential role. In any case, any functionalist will want to say that this is the case. (Maybe certain kinds of non-functionalists could deny it.) It makes little sense, for a functionalist, to say that the functional role of a belief is totally divorced from its inferential role. After all, a functionalist individuates beliefs by their functional roles; so if a belief doesn’t have the functional role that it would be inferentially appropriate for the belief that snow is white to have, then ipso facto that is good reason – at least for the functionalist – not to see that belief as the belief that snow is white. So, to sum up this leg of the argument, for the functionalist, it is nearly enough analytic that the functional role of a belief should, to some  degree of approximation at least, track the inferential role of the proposition it bears. Put another way, for the functionalist, a belief that snow is white should at least tend to track the inferential role of the proposition that snow is white.
   Now consider the class of all ordered pairs of propositions <P, Q> such that given P and given also the proposition that snow is white, Q can be inferred. There are infinitely many such pairs, of course. And as a matter of logic, there is no way to identify this class except in terms of either the proposition snow is white or some logically equivalent proposition (e.g. either snow is white or 4 is an odd number). In other words, there is no way to give the membership of this class except by saying that it consists of all pairs <P, Q> such that given P and given either the proposition snow is white or some logically equivalent proposition, Q follows. For the functionalist, as we’ve noted, the functional role of the belief that snow is white tends to track the inferential role of the proposition snow is white. In fact, for the functionalist, it is definitive of a belief that snow is white that it tend to track  the inferential role of snow is white. So, for the functionalist, the functional role of the belief that snow is must be understood (at least in part) as a tendency to track this inferential role. And there is no way to define this inferential role except as that which is occupied by the proposition snow is white (and propositions logically equivalent thereto, e.g. either snow is white or there are square circles). So, for the functionalist, the belief that snow is white just is (inter alia) something which tracks a certain inferential role; and there is no eliminative definition of this inferential role – that role can be stated only by stating the proposition which occupies that role. So, in the Ramsey-Lewis sentence, there will be ineliminable mention of the proposition snow is white. And the definition of the belief that snow is white which the Ramsey-Lewis sentence provides will include some clause like: that entity whose causal role tracks the inferential role of the proposition snow is white. And (at least arguably) there is no way to state that causal role except in terms of ‘tracking the inferential role proposition that snow is white’ (or some cognate expression): there is no way to describe the belief that snow is white except in terms of the property of tracking the inferential role of the proposition that snow is white, and there is no way to describe this inferential role except in terms of the proposition snow is white – there is no ‘eliminative’ description of that role. So the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is irreducibly committed to describing the belief that snow is white as something that (inter alia) ‘tracks the inferential role of the proposition that snow is white’.
     But – to close this argument --  to speak of a spatiotemporal entity (and mental entities are in this category) as tracking the inferential role of a proposition: to speak of an entity in those terms is, it seems to me, to speak of it in mentalistic terms. Why is it mentalistic, exactly? First of all, it is a description that makes use of a normative notion – the notion of a correct inference. So in describing something as ‘tracking a certain inferential role’, we are describing it in terms of correctness conditions – in terms of its conforming to some logical or normative standard. Now when we describe a spatio-temporal process as being correct or incorrect, right or wrong, valid or invalid – when we describe it normative terms – it seems we are describing it
[74]
in mental 	terms. Non-mental spatio-temporal things aren’t right or
[75]
	wrong, valid or invalid (except in a derivative sense). Mental things are right or wrong, valid or invalid. So if there is no way to give the causal role of the belief that snow is white except in terms of its being something that tracks a certain inferential role – that is, if there is no way to state this causal role except in normative terms – then it seems to me that there is no nonmentalistic description of that causal role. Now if we could cash out that causal role in, say, purely neural or bio-chemical terms, then we would have a non-mentalistic description of it. But, as we’ve seen, we cannot identify that causal role except in terms of its being the role of something that ‘tracks’ a certain ‘inferential role’: there is no non-normative way to identify that causal role.  Now a ‘normative’ description of some spatio-temporal process is a mentalistic one. And if that normative description cannot be cashed out in terms of some non-normative one – e.g. in terms of one using only normneutral concepts like neural interaction, electric current etc. – then that description is irreducibly mentalistic. Now we’ve seen that the RamseyLewis sentence will ineliminably contain norm-heavy terms – e.g. terms like ‘tracks the inferential role of the proposition snow is white – for, as we’ve also seen, there is no way to describe the causal role of the belief that snow is white without using such ‘norm-heavy’ terms. Since irreducibly norm-heavy descriptions of spatio-temporal entities are irreducibly mentalistic descriptions of them, it follows that the Ramsey-Lewis sentence will ineliminably and irreducibly contain mentalistic terms. And this means that it is a failure, since the sole purpose of that sentence is to give an entirely nonmentalistic description of the mental – one that uses only the non-normative, purely descriptive terms  of bona fide physicalistic inquiry: terms like ‘synaptic transmission’, ‘neural pathway’, etc.
  To put this more clearly, the purpose the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is to reduce the mental to the physical. The Ramsey-Lewis sentence does  this only to the extent that it gives the causal roles of mental entities in purely non-mental terms. But we’ve seen that it gives those causal roles, at least in part, in ineliminably mentalistic terms. So it doesn’t succeed in reducing the mental to the physical. This isn’t to say that the mental doesn’t in some sense reduce to the physical – I think it does. It is to say that the Ramsey-Lewis sentence doesn’t give this reduction. And since the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is, as far as I can tell, the best way of eliminating functionalist forms of materialism from circularity, we have a case here that functionalist forms of materialism are in fact guilty of the circularity of which (as we saw earlier) they are prima facie guilty. Which would suggest that the reduction of the mental to the physical is to be carried out along non-functionalist lines (supposing, what there is some reason to think is the case, that such a reduction can be done).
   I should consider one more objection:
 
  You say that if something spatio-temporal is describable in normative
terms, then it is ipso facto mental. But this is wrong. Consider the sentence token ‘Socrates is bald’. To describe that thing as a ‘sentence token’ is to describe it as having truth-conditions, meaning etc. So it is to describe it in normative terms. But that thing is completely non-mental – it is just a pattern of ink on a page.
 
 
  If the token “Socrates was bald” was just a pattern of ink on a page, then it wouldn’t have truth-conditions, meaning etc. In a world where there were no sentient beings, that entity would in fact be just a pattern of ink on a page – and in such a world it would have no normative dimension. This means that what has a normative dimension – what has semantics etc. – is not the pattern of ink per se, but is rather the pattern of ink as  something that is associated with various intentions, beliefs etc. To put it another way, what is meaningful, and what has a normative dimension, is not, strictly speaking, the pattern of ink by itself, but something like the ordered pair of that pattern of ink and various mental entities which, in some way or other, assign it meaning. But that ordered pair obviously is something mental, at least in part. So with regard to the objector’s point that something altogether non-mental can have a normative dimension, that point is simply false.
    Just to be clear on this: what has a normative dimension is not the pattern of ink “Socrates is bald” per se; for if that thing per se had a normative dimension, it would have that dimension in a world devoid of sentient beings. But in such a world it would have no normative dimension; it would just be dead ink. So the existence of sentient beings is a conceptually necessary condition for that thing’s having a normative dimension. And this means, in effect, that what has a normative dimension is not that thing, taken by itself, but some complex – some ordered pair or sequence, perhaps – which includes some mental things (presumably, beliefs, linguistic intentions, linguistic practices etc). And that complex is not altogether non-mental, as it includes mental things (e.g. linguistic intentions, apprehensions of propositions etc). So the objector’s point that altogether non-mental things can have a normative dimension is superficial (it is based on the superficial idea that a sentence is just a deposit of ink/stream of noise) and false.
   I will end by making a point that will forestall a possible confusion concerning the structure of our argument. It is patently obvious that a finite sentence, or finite list of finitely long sentences, can generate an infinite list of sentences or, perhaps, can generate an infinitely long sentence. (I can say: consider the sentence formed by adding “and snow is white” infinitely many times to the sentence “grass is green”. Here, at least arguably, I have given a finite rule for constructing an infinitely long sentence.) Any axiomatization of a discipline  (e.g. Hilbert’s axiomatization of geometry) consists of a finite number of sentences/propositions that generate finitely many such propositions.
      The problem with the sentence we have been calling the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is not that it generates an infinitely long sentence or that it generates infinitely many sentences. (Remember, the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is the sentence which Lewis describes whose purpose is to de-circularize functionalism.) That wouldn’t be a problem at all; it would be a virtue. The problem with the Ramsey-Lewis sentence lies in two points. First, it is that it itself is infinitely long. Second, there is no rule by which the Ramsey-Lewis sentence can be constructed except for some rule which contains terms which it is the Ramsey-Lewis sentence’s whole purpose to eliminate. So either the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is an infinitely long sentence such that there is no rule for constructing it. Or the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is a finite sentence which ineliminably contains the terms which it is the Ramsey-Lewis sentence’s purpose to eliminate, and thus irremediably committed to the existence of the things which it is the Ramsey-Lewis sentence’s purpose to eliminate.
   Of course, some might say:
 
  I don’t see anything wrong with the idea of a sentence such that (i) it is infinitely long and (ii) there is no rule for constructing it. So the RamseyLewis sentence is one of those sentences. I don’t see what is so wrong with that. Frank Ramsey said that there were infinitely long series of numbers such
[76]
	that there was no rule for generating those series. So why couldn’t there be infinitely long sentences that cannot be generated by finite rules?
 
 
     First of all, what Ramsey said about numbers is highly controversial. Second, even if it weren’t controversial, it isn’t clear whether it applies to propositions or sentences. The idea of a sentence or proposition that is infinitely long but that cannot be generated by a finite rule is hard to make sense of. A proposition is the kind of thing that is grasped; there is, I should think, an internal connection between the concept of being a proposition and the concept of being graspable. But something that is infinitely long and cannot be generated by a finite, graspable rule could not itself be grasped.    But, most importantly, even if we do concede that there are infinitely long propositions  that cannot be generated by a finite rule – even if we concede
[77]
	that there are ungraspable propositions – Lewis’ solution would still fail.
Lewis point is this:
 
  We can show that functionalism is not circular. Here how you do it. You do it by means of the following sentence [which we have called the RamseyLewis sentence]. Here’s how you construct the Ramsey-Lewis sentence; in other words, the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is the thing you get by following these rules.
 
 
   So Lewis’ whole solution goes through only if the Ramsey-Lewis sentence can be produced or, in any case, identified in some way or other. Lewis hasn’t actually given us the Ramsey-Lewis sentence. So Lewis hasn’t given us any proposition at all – not one that is finitely long, not one that is infinitely long. He’s only given us a recipe for constructing this proposition. But what we have seen that either there is no way to apply this recipe at all or, if we can apply this recipe, the resulting sentence contains the very terms it is supposed to eliminate.  For the recipe tells us that the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is formed out infinitely long lists; for the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is formed by taking all the causes/effects of instance of the type belief that snow is white – all infinitely many of them – and replacing each occurrence with a variable…But an infinitely long list things cannot be generated, except by rules.  And a sentence cannot contain an infinitely long list; it can contain, at most, a rule for generating that list. So the Ramsey-Lewis sentence contains rules for generating lists of all the causes/effects of instance of the type belief that snow is white. The Ramsey-Lewis sentence cannot itself contain mention of each individual cause/effect. But we’ve seen that these rules themselves ineliminably contain the terms that the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is supposed to eliminate. So the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is formed out of rules  which ineliminably contain terms like belief that snow is white, desire for world peace, and so on. But the whole raison d’etre of the Ramsey-Lewis sentence is to eliminate such terms. So if the Ramsey-Lewis sentence can be constructed, it doesn’t’ do its job (which is to eliminate terms like belief that snow is white). But to say that the Ramsey-Lewis sentence cannot be constructed is just another way of saying that the Ramsey-Lewis sentence doesn’t exist.  So Lewis’ solution is a failure.
 
 
 
Intentionalism
 
Abstract
 
     Recently, many have argued that phenomenal content supervenes on representational content; i.e. that the phenomenal character of an experience is wholly determined (metaphysically, not causally) by the representational content of that experience. This paper does two things. First, it identifies many counter-examples to intentionalism. Second, it shows that, if intentionalism were correct, that would require that some extreme form of representational atomism also be correct: a form of atomism that is widely held to have been refuted by Sellars (among others). An argument, not found in the existing literature, is set forth to the effect that a sufficiently extreme form of representationalism atomism is not feasible. Various intentionalist counter-ploys are considered and neutralized.
 
Introduction 1-3
Part I: Some Counter-examples to intentionalism   3-9
Part II. A theoretical argument against intentionalism  9-32
   An outline of our argument 11-12
   Why some form of conceptual non-atomism is true 13-17
   Why conceptual non-atomism entails that intentionalism is false: a prima facie case 17-19
   Why phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on propositional content 19-22   Why the phenomenal content of sensations doesn’t supervene on nonpropositional content (supposing that there        is such a thing) 23-26
  An argument against  the existence of non-propositional content 26-32 Introduction
 
    The sole purpose of the present inquiry is to make a case against a doctrine often referred to as “intentionalism.”  Some background will help to make it clear what intentionalism is.
     Consider an arbitrary perception – say, a perception of a brightly colored object. There seem to be two quite distinct senses in which this perception has ‘content’. On the one hand, this perception represents the world as being a certain way. So, as we might say, the perception has ‘representational content.’ On the other hand, there is, to use Nagel’s expression, ‘something it is like’ to have that perception. So, as we might say, the perception has ‘phenomenal content’. Alternatively, it has a ‘phenomenology’. (In this paper, the expressions ‘such and such has phenomenal content’ and ‘such and such has a phenomenology’ will be used interchangeably.)
      Not every mental entity that has representational content has phenomenal content. For example, I believe that 2+2=4. But there is not ‘something it is like’ to have this belief (though, of course, there is something it is like to experience the conscious manifestations of that belief). All ‘non-occurrent’ or ‘dispositional’ mental entities lack phenomenal content (so it would seem, at any rate, and so I will assume). At the same time, if cognitive scientists are right, some occurrent mental processes lack phenomenal content. Consider the sub-personal computational processes mediating vision or language comprehension, if such exist: presumably these are not phenomenally pregnant, even though they are occurrent.
     What seems clear is that conscious experiences have phenomenal content.
Seeing a sunset, tasting burnt toast, imagining a funeral -- there is something it is like to have such experiences.
      The question arises: given a mental entity that has both phenomenal and representational content, what is the relationship between these two dimensions of that mental entity? What is the relationship between the representational content of e.g. seeing a sunset, on the one hand, and the phenomenal content of that experience, on the other hand? Is this relationship purely contingent? Could an experience with that exact representational content have a utterly different phenomenal content? Or does a difference in the former necessarily involve a difference in the latter?
   A doctrine sometimes referred to as ‘intentionalism’ provides a clear answer to these questions: according to intentionalism, the phenomenal content of an experience is wholly determined by its representational content. What is meant by this is not that the representational content of an experience causally determines what phenomenal content it has. What is meant is that it is impossible in the strictest sense of the word – metaphysically impossible – that two experiences should have exactly the same representational content but differ phenomenal content: just as it is impossible that two statues should have the exact same physical properties but different aesthetic properties; and just as it is impossible that two creatures should consist of atoms and subatomic particles interrelated in the exact same way but differ in their chemical and biological properties.
   Consequently, for intentionalism, it is metaphysically impossible that two experiences should have the same representational content, but different phenomenal content -- there cannot be representational identity alongside phenomenal diversity. To embody this in the current jargon: for
[78]
	intentionalism,  phenomenal content ‘supervenes’  on representational
[79] [80]
	content.  
 
 
The Purpose and Structure of the Present Inquiry
 
     This purpose of this paper is to argue against intentionalism. The structure of this paper is basically this. First, I will show that there are a number of apparent counter-examples to intentionalism; there are, by all appearances, many cases where the same bit of representational content is associated with different types of phenomenal content. This happens in Part 1.
      Part 2 gives a very different argument against intentionalism. There I will try to show that phenomenal content supervenes on representational content only if an extremely implausible doctrine that I will refer to as ‘representational atomism’ is true. So part 2 gives a kind of conditional refutation of intentionalism: if conceptual atomism is false, then so is intentionalism. And I will give some prima facie reasons to think that, indeed, conceptual atomism is false.
 
 
Part 1  Some counter-examples to intentionalism
 
     In this section, I will identify some apparent counter-examples to intentionalism, and I will try to discredit ways of neutralizing these counterexamples.
   To begin with, perceptions associated with different modalities can obviously overlap (possibly even coincide) in representational content, while differing dramatically (perhaps completely) in respect of phenomenal content. I can smell the rottenness of the fish and I can also taste it: here we seem to have identity of representational content and diversity phenomenal content. I can feel the roundness of the ball and I can also see it: identity (or at least overlap) of representational content without a corresponding overlap in phenomenal content.
       There is another prima facie problem for intentionalism. Let us begin by considering the proposition: “The representational content of an experience wholly determines its phenomenal content.” Given this, suppose that experience E has representational content R and phenomenal content P. If E’s phenomenal content is wholly determined by E’s representational content, that means, presumably, that there is nothing about E other than its having R in virtue of which E has P. So, it would seem to follow,  having R is a sufficient condition for having P. From this, in turn, it very much seems to follow that given any mental entity, if that entity is to have P, it is enough that it have R. (If we deny that having R is, in general, enough for having P, then we are denying that the one thing about M that enables it to have P is that it has R; and we are therefore denying that M has P wholly because it has R. But intentionalism just is the position that phenomenal content is wholly determined – not partially determined – by representational content.) So to say that, where experiences are concerned, phenomenal content is wholly determined  by representational content – to say this is to say that, if an experience has phenomenal content P and representational content R, that means that having R is sufficient for having P; and this, in turn, means that anything – whether an experience or not – that has R must also have P. So intentionalism – which I have defined as the view that two experiences cannot differ in representational content without differing in phenomenal content – entails the view that no two entities can differ in representational content without differing in phenomenal content.
  Once this is seen, a rather striking shortcoming on the part of intentionalism becomes evident. Ordinarily it is thought that the representational contents of perceptions can be stored (in their entirety) in non-occurrent memories; so that a non-occurrent memory sometimes (at least in principle) has the same representational content as a perception. But, of course, non-occurrent memories have no phenomenal content, while perceptions do have phenomenal content. So, vacuously, non-occurrent memories do not have the same phenomenal content as perceptions, even though (presumably) they may have the same representational content as perceptions. But – if what we said a paragraph ago is correct – intentionalism is (at least implicitly) committed to the view that no two mental entities can differ in phenomenal content while coinciding in representational content.      These are not, I grant, insuperable problems for the intentionalist. For example, the intentionalist may deny that non-occurrent can have quite the same representational content as perceptions. He may say that, although a perception can certainly overlap in representational content with a nonoccurrent memory, there is never identity of representational content; and this margin of representational difference accounts for the total disparity in phenomenal content.
   This is not, in my view, a very promising response. Even if it is granted that non-occurrent memories do not have quite the same representational content as perceptions, they obviously can overlap in representational content to an extremely high degree; so we’d expect there to be a corresponding phenomenal overlap. Also, the bits of representational content that can be stored in non-occurrent memory are oftentimes strongly associated with phenomenal contents when those bits of information are embodied in perceptions. For example, you can have a non-occurrent memory of a colour or a smell or a taste; and obviously these bits of representational content, when they occur in perceptions, subserve phenomenal contents: so why don’t they subserve phenomenal content when they are embodied in non-occurrent memories? In any case, it is strange that non-occurrent memories never have any phenomenal overlap with perceptions, given to what a high degree the former may overlap with the latter in terms of representational content.       The intentionalist may try to neutralize our second objection in a similar way:
 
      To be sure, one can feel the roundness of the ball and one can also see it; and yet there is no apparent phenomenal overlap between these perceptions. But any visual perception of the ball will have representational content not had by a tactile representation of it, and vice versa. (When you see the ball, you don’t just see its shape; you see its colour, its distance from you etc.; but you can’t really feel these things. When you feel the ball, you don’t just feel its shape; you feel its firmness, its temperature etc.; but you can’t really see these things.)
 
But – to echo our last counter-objection – granting that visual perceptions don’t (fully) coincide in representational content with tactile perceptions, it seems problematic for intentionalism that my visual perception of the roundness of the ball should have no phenomenal overlap with my  tactile perception of the roundness of the ball. In fact, if you focus on the bit of phenomenal content that, in your visual perception, mediates your perception of the roundness of the ball; and if you focus on the bit of phenomenal content that, in your tactile perception, mediates your perception of the roundness of the ball; you find that even these have no phenomenal overlap. This is, presumably, no small problem for intentionalism.
    Before moving, I’d like to consider a couple more attempts to neutralize the foregoing:
 
    You said that non-occurrent memories can have the same representational content as perceptions, while having no phenomenal overlap with them – it being the case that non-occurrent memories have no phenomenal content, while perceptions obviously do. But maybe nonoccurrent memories are really just dispositions to have certain conscious experiences (of course, all conscious experiences have phenomenal content). So, if that is the case, then – at least after a fashion – non-occurrent memories
[81]
do have phenomenal content.
 
 
To begin with, there is one technical objection to this point of view. If nonoccurrent memories are, as the objector says, mere dispositions, then strictly speaking they have no phenomenal content; for a disposition per se doesn’t have phenomenal content, even if it is a disposition to have certain phenomenal contents. But, quite possibly, this is a mere technicality, which doesn’t really speak to the larger point the objector is making. So I do concede that if non-occurrent memories are dispositions to have conscious experiences, this may well undermine one of the arguments I gave against intentionalism.
   The objector’s move is, from a dialectical standpoint, a good enough one; for I cannot really refute the conception of memory that he puts forth. What I can say is that this move commits the objector to what is demonstrably some highly dubious psychology, one that prima facie does a serious injustice to the psychodynamics of non-conscious mental activity. If psychoanalysis and cognitive science are to be given any credence (some say they aren’t), then a great deal of mental activity happens at an unconscious level and that there is more to being an non-conscious mental entity than being a disposition to produce certain conscious mental entities. You go to sleep remembering P and also believing if P then Q. But, priori to going to sleep, you haven’t ‘inferentially integrated’ these two contents; you haven’t inferred Q. But you wake up believing Q. The obvious explanation is that, while you were unconscious, you (or some component of your mind) inferred Q. Obviously the contents of your recollection that P and your belief that P implies Q were implicated in this operation. So the obvious explanation is that a grasp of representational content – e.g. a non-occurrent memory --  can be operative at an unconscious level. Now there is no reason why your recollection that P, and your belief that if P then Q, shouldn’t heavily overlap in representational content with an occurrent perception. Your recollection that P might be your recollection that a certain apple looked like that (where the that corresponds to some visual presentation – say, of an apple that is firm and green and healthy looking). And your belief that P then Q might be your belief that, if an apple looks like that on Monday (nice and firm and green), then it looks like that (brown and soft and rotten) a month later. Basically, there is good reason to believe that representational contents can be integrated at the subconscious level – that qua item not falling within the purview of consciousness, a mental content can be operative. And there is also every reason to believe that such entities can overlap heavily with phenomenally pregnant conscious perceptions. (Leaving aside the niceties in the foregoing: Obviously we sometimes  have mental ‘records’ of appearances of objects, and such records per force overlap in representational content with phenomenally pregnant sense-perceptions. And it is very hard to believe that there is nothing to such records besides their being dispositions to have certain conscious experiences; if 80 years of psychology are to be given any credence, they have a little more autonomy that than allows. And, plainly, such records are of things – e.g. colors, smells – that are represented in consciousness by phenomenally pregnant conditions.)
   Now, as I said earlier, I do concede that the objector has identified an intentionalist counter-attack that would be hard to refute. But, it seems to me, that counter-attack is embedded in some controversial, if not downright implausible, psychology.
     The next intentionalist response has, I think, even less force against the foregoing anti-intentionalist arguments (though, as we will see later, it has some force against other anti-intentionalist arguments):
 
    Some philosophers of mind distinguish between propositional and non-
[82] [83] [84]
			propositional representational content.  The former is the kind of representational content that can be embodied in a  proposition; the latter, the kind of representational content that cannot be so embodied. It seems that the only kind of content you’ve spoken of so far is propositional content. As you point out, a visual perception of a round ball and a tactile perception have no phenomenal overlap but a lot of representational overlap. Now both perceptions share a certain propositional content, viz. the ball is round. And, as you’ve pointed out, the two perceptions do not have any phenomenal content corresponding to that representational content. But maybe what the intentionalist should say is that, while phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on propositional content, it supervenes on non-propositional content.
 
 
[85]
	    Of course, one thing we could say, by way of a counter-response, is that the distinction between propositional and non-propositional content is
		[86][87]
		spurious (this is what MacDowell and Sellars would say). Of course, such a position is much too controversial to take for granted (though I will [88]
	argue for it later on). So, if only for the sake of argument, I will take it for granted that there is a valid distinction here, and will evaluate the objector’s proposal accordingly.
       It is, I think, pretty clear that two perceptions that are associated with different sensory modalities, and that don’t have any phenomenal overlap, can have a significant degree of representational overlap. The example above shows this. Surely I can feel the roundness of the ball, and I can also see it: and if I were a bat I could, in effect, hear the roundness (I could determine through echo-location that the ball was round); and if I were a mole, I could, in effect, smell the roundness of the ball. So, in principle, the representational contents of, respectively, an auditory, an olfactory, a visual, and a tactile perception could overlap. But I very much doubt that any two of these perceptions would have any phenomenal overlap. So regardless of whether the content of a perception is ‘propositional’ or ‘non-propositional’ – ‘conceptual’ or ‘non-conceptual’, ‘analogue’ or ‘digital’ – we do seem to have a case of representational overlap that is not matched by any corresponding phenomenal overlap. And this fact is surely threatening to intentionalism.  So even if the objector is right in distinguishing between propositional and non-propositional content – and I leave it open for now that he may be – his point doesn’t have much force against our argument; for his objection leaves intact our point that there can be representational overlap without a corresponding phenomenal overlap.
     We have identified what seem to be fairly obvious problems for intentionalism. Strangely, in the now extensive pro-intentionalist literature, none of these problems for intentionalism has even been recognized, let alone dealt with. And that is why the objections we considered were made by a hypothetical interlocutor, and not by actual authors.
      Consider, for example, Alex Byrne’s important article ‘Intentionalism Defended’ (Byrne [1]), which is the most recent major defence of intentionalism. Byrne doesn’t consider any of the problems cited above: he doesn’t consider the fact that (e.g.) the rottenness of the fish can be given to me through smell or taste, and thus through different phenomenal contents; he doesn’t consider the fact that the roundness of the ball can be given to me through touch or sight, and thus through different phenomenal contents. In fact, Byrne’s argument embodies a complete disregard for all of these problems.
  Byrne’s argument is essentially this. Focus on some object, e.g. a blue chip. (This is Byrne’s own example.) Your cognizance of the blue of the chip involves your having a certain kind of phenomenal content -- a certain kind of visual phenomenal content. Now if there is a change in that particular bit of content, then there is a change in how the chip is represented to you –
[89] more specifically, in what colour the chip is represented to you as being.      The same thing is true mutatis mutandis of any perception. Suppose that you are tasting a drop of honey, i.e. that you are having a ‘gustatory perception’ of a drop of honey. Now suppose that the phenomenology of your gustatory perception changes. In that case there is ipso facto in the taste that the drop of honey is represented to you as having.
     In general, given any perception, there can be no change in the phenomenal content of that perception without a concomitant change in its representational content. Consequently, the representational supervenes on the phenomenal, i.e. there cannot be a variation in the phenomenal content of an experience cannot unless there is a variation in the representational content
[90]
of that experience.
  Byrne’s argument is a formidable one: but the conclusion is vastly
[91]
	overdrawn. This argument shows at most that where perceptions belonging to the same modality are concerned, there cannot be a difference in phenomenal content without a difference in representational content. But there seems to be no straightforward way to adapt this argument to show that
e.g. given perceptions belonging to different modalities, or given a perception and a non-occurrent memory  there cannot be a difference in phenomenal content without a difference in representational content. So as against Byrne’s argument one can say this:
 
There are cases where  there is difference in phenomenal content without a different representational content  I need only consider a visual perception of the roundness of the ball and a tactile perception of the roundness of the ball, and note that the two perceptions have no phenomenal overlap (at least none corresponding to their representational overlap); I need only consider a perception and a non-occurrent memory of that perception, and note that the two have no phenomenal overlap, despite identity, or near identity, of representational content.
 
    Of course, these putative counter-examples to Byrne’s argument are not necessarily decisive; but they certainly have prima facie force. And Byrne doesn’t even address them. In failing to do this, Byrne is by no means alone: no intentionalist, to my knowledge, has dealt with these problems, or even acknowledged them.
 
Part II.  A theoretical argument against intentionalism
 
    So far we’ve attacked intentionalism by identifying some apparent counterexamples to it. I would now like to propose a very different kind of argument against intentionalism: one that is not based on putative counter-examples to it, but on considerations of a deeper kind. I’d like to set forth what might be described as a theoretical  reason to hold that phenomenal content is not identical with, and doesn’t supervene upon, representational content.      More specifically, I will try to show that, given the truth of a doctrine we will call ‘representational non-atomism’, it is simply not feasible to hold intentionalism in any form. By ‘representational non-atomism’ I mean the doctrine that any ability to represent something to oneself (e.g. the ability to represent things to oneself as being a certain color or as having a certain shape or pitch) presupposes the ability to represent other, related things to oneself. In effect, there are no ‘foundational’ representational capacities.     The structure of my argument must be understood in terms of a distinction that we talked about earlier. We noted earlier that, according to some philosophers, there is such a thing as non-propositional content: in other words, not all representational content can be embodied in a proposition. One of the main motivations for this view is as follows. A proposition is essentially a ‘digital’ representation; it is neatly decomposable into minimal parts. The sentence ‘Mary kissed Bob’ seems to be neatly decomposable into ‘Mary’ , ‘Bob’, ‘kiss’ plus the tense-marker ‘-ed’. And presumably the proposition expressed by that sentence is capable of some kind of similar decomposition. Now a sense-perception (or a photograph) doesn’t seem to be capable of this kind of decomposition. Given this, some people have inferred that the representational content of (e.g.) a visual perception cannot be embodied in its entirety in a proposition (or set of propositions).
Consequently, the representational content of (e.g.) a visual perception is, at least in part, ‘non-propositional’.
    As I said earlier, some philosophers (e.g. MacDowell, Sellars) think that all representational content is propositional. But this position is hotly debated; and I will not take its truth for granted here.
    Given this, my argument will have the following  form. First, I will argue for ‘representational non-atomism.’ I will also make it more clear just what I mean by that term.
    Then, I will argue that, because representational non-atomism is true, phenomenal content cannot supervene on the kind of representational content that is embodied in propositions.   
     I will then consider the proposal that there might be some other kind of representational content – that there is such a thing as ‘non-propositional’ content -- and that phenomenal content might supervene on this other kind of content. I will try to show that  the truth of representational non-atomism is every bit as incompatible with the idea that representational content supervenes on non-propositional content (supposing, for the sake of argument, that there is such a thing) as it is with the idea that representational content supervenes on propositional content.
      Finally, I will outline some reason to hold that, indeed, all representational content can be embodied in propositions – that, in effect, there is no such thing as non-propositional content. If this is correct, then obviously the intentionalist cannot say that phenomenal content supervenes on non-propositional content. (So, in effect, we will provide two arguments against the idea that phenomenal content might supervene on nonpropositional content.)
 
An outline of our argument
 
   There are different ways in which we can be conscious of things; different ways in which we can have things in mind. I can have a sensory perception of John. I can have a mental image of John. And I can have a belief about John.
With regard to any ability to have a certain thing or kind of thing in mind, let us refer to this ability as a representational capacity. So in virtue of being able to have John in mind, I have a certain representational capacity.     And with regard to one’s ability to experience a certain kind of phenomenal content – to have an experience that has a  certain phenomenology -- let us refer to this as a ‘phenomenal capacity’. So consider the experience of tasting of vanilla ice-cream; consider what it is like to have such an experience. In virtue of your having the ability to have an experience with that phenomenology, you have a certain ‘phenomenal capacity’.
      A terminological point is in order. I will often talk about a creature’s ability to ‘represent’ things as having some property; I will often say things like ‘a creature’s ability to represent things as triangular presupposes an ability to represent things as being closed.’  For a creature to ‘represent’ x as having property P is, as I am using these terms, merely for it grasp things – either perceptually or cognitively or imagistically – as having P. So for a creature to ‘represent’ x to itself as triangular is for it to see it as triangular, or to think about it as triangular, or to imagine it as triangular, and so on.     When I say that a creature can ‘represent’ things as being (say) triangular or as being a certain shade of pink, I don’t mean necessarily that that creature can grasp the property of triangularity or of that shade of pink in the abstract – I don’t mean that it necessarily has concepts of triangularity or of that shade of pink in isolation of particular objects that are triangular or have that shade of pink. As I am using the term ‘represent’, if a creature can see things as being a certain shade of pink, or as being triangular, then ipso facto it can ‘represent’ the properties of triangularity and of pinkness. (Of course, if a creature can grasp the concepts of triangularity and pinkness in the abstract, then ipso facto it can ‘represent’ the concepts of triangularity and pinkness. But the converse may well not be true.) So, to sum up, when I say that a creature can ‘represent’ things as having a certain shade or as having a certain shape, I don’t mean necessarily that it can grasp the concepts of that shade or that shape in the abstract – I don’t mean that it can necessarily cognitively isolate the concepts of that shape or of that shade. I mean only that it either see things as having that shape or shade, or that it can imagine things as having that shape or shade, that it can think about things as having that shape or shade, and so on.
   Given how we defined the term ‘representational capacity’, for a  creature to be able to ‘represent’ things as having a certain property is the same thing as for that creature to have a certain ‘representational capacity.’       Now if intentionalism is correct, then there is obviously a very close connection between our representational and our phenomenal capacities. To be more precise, supposing that intentionalism is correct, then whatever phenomenal capacities we have, we have these entirely in virtue of having representational capacities; and it is impossible that a creature should be able to have a phenomenal capacity without having some representational capacity. It is clear why representational is committed to this. If intentionalism is correct, then whatever phenomenal content a mental state has, it has it wholly in virtue of having a certain kind of representational content. Consequently, it would not be possible for one to be able have a mental content with a certain phenomenal content unless one were able to have a mental content with a certain representational content.
   But reflection exposes what appears to be a massive difference between representational capacities, on the one hand, and phenomenal capacities, on the other: a difference that is incompatible with the claims of intentionalism. Recently, probably beginning with Wilfred Sellars, philosophical and psychological work has stressed the non-atomistic character of our representational capacities: basically, any one representational capacity presupposes a whole slew of others; one cannot have a single representational capacity without being in possession of a vast and articulated network of
[92]
	them. Now it is extremely hard to believe that one’s capacity to feel woozy or to have an itch involves such a network: it seems, at least intuitively, that one could have the capacity to feel woozy without being in possession of a vast network of representational capacities. If this is correct, then one’s phenomenal capacities are independent, at least in some measure, of one’s representational capacities. Consequently, one could have mental contents with at least certain kinds of phenomenal content that altogether lacked any kind of representational content. 
    In what remains of this paper, I will defend the controversial assumptions made in the argument just sketched -- in particular, the assumption that representational capacities come in networks, and not in isolation – and I will consider multiple objections that might be made to this argument.
 
   Why some form of conceptual non-atomism is true
 
    Let us begin by defending the conceptual non-atomism just mentioned. To begin with, one cannot just see an object: one must see it as having this or that property; as being round or square or blue. And one cannot just think about, or imagine, an object. One must think about it/see it/imagine it as round or square or sweet. In general, one cannot just represent an object to oneself; one must represent it as having these or those properties.     Now it seems that if one can represent one property to oneself, then one can ipso facto represent others to oneself: each representational capacity has ‘constitutive’ connections to other representational capacities. For example, consider the property of triangularity. If one can represent something as triangular – if one can see/think about/ imagine/…something as triangular – then ipso facto one can represent things as having other properties: as e.g. being straight, being planar, being closed. And in order to grasp any of these properties, one must be able to grasp others. For example, if one can think about the property of being closed, one can think about the property of geometrical continuity (for a closed figure is one with a continuous periphery); and if one can think about this property, then presumably one can think about others; for the property of continuity is presumably not a simple one. (Exactly what one must grasp to grasp the property of continuity is a delicate question. But it seems unlikely that one could grasp this property in a vacuum. Presumably  the ability to represent things as continuous presuppose the ability to represent things as having spatial location and a spatial arrangement. And, by all appearances, the abilities needed to represent things as having these properties involve possession of other representational capacities: perhaps e.g. these abilities presupposes the ability to represent things as persistent which, in its turn, involves the ability to represent things as having temporal properties, and so on.)
   What we just said about thinking about triangularity is true of seeing (or otherwise sense-perceiving) things as being triangular. Surely if one can see things as being triangular, then one must also be able to see things as being straight: for one couldn’t see any objects as being triangular unless one could see some objects as being straight – one must see straight lines to see a triangle. And one must be able to see figures as being closed and planar: for one couldn’t see things as being triangular unless one could see things as being flat or closed – one must see flat and closed things to see triangular things. So the ability to perceive things as triangular presupposes the ability to see things as having other properties.
    To sum up, it is pretty clear that one could not represent things as triangular unless one had various other representational capacities.    I submit that this point can be generalized to all properties: given any property P, if one is to be able to represent things as having property P, then one must be able to represent things to oneself as having properties other than P. How is this to be shown? Well, first of all, all properties are individuated –- are constituted --  at least in part, by their relations to other properties. And it seems impossible that one should be able to represent things as having some property  unless it was also able to represent things as having at least some of the properties constitutively related to P.
   Permit me to elucidate this. It is an essential fact about the property of weighing 300 lbs that, if something has that weight, it weighs more than 200 lbs and less than a 1000 lbs. It is an essential or individuating fact about the property of being square that is something has that property, it has the property of being rectangular and does not have the property of being round. It is a essential fact about the property of being pink that if something is pink it is closer in colour to something which is red than to something which is green. These points hold mutatis mutandis for any property one might think of. Each property exists in a ‘space’ of other properties; and, I suggest,  one can no more represent things as having a given property without being able to locate that property in a space of other properties  than one could represent a given spatial co-ordinate without being able to represent a space comprising other co-ordinates.
   This is obviously the case with degree-properties: properties like that of weighing a thousand pounds or even the property of simply being heavy. For such properties are clearly relational; and the information one acquires in learning of a thing that it has such a property has a patently contrastive or relational character. (Surely one couldn’t represent things as weighing 1000 lbs unless one could represent things as weighing more than a 1000lbs and as weighing less than a thousand lbs: it is totally inconceivable that I should be able to entertain the idea that someone might weigh 1000 lbs unless I should also be able to entertain the idea that one might weigh less or more than a 1000 lbs. And – what is connected with this -- the information that one obtains in learning of a thing that it is 1000 lbs is obviously  contrastive: in learning a thing a thing weighs 1000 lbs one is learning, inter alia, that it weighs more than one pound.)
    The question is whether this point (mutatis mutandis) holds of all properties. For example, is the property of being a certain shade of pink in any sense a ‘degree’-property? Is it, in any relevant way, like the property of weighing 1000 lbs? Or could one represent things as having this property without being able to represent things as having any other properties? I now wish to show that what is obviously true of one’s ability to represent things as having degree properties -- and, more generally, as having obviously relational properties -- is true of one’s ability to represent things as having any property, even those that seem quite non-relational.
   For the sake of argument, suppose that there were a creature that could represent things as being some specific shade of pink but that could not represent a thing as having any other colour. (Let P be the just mentioned specific of shade of pink.) Obviously that creature could not, even in principle, represent things as having any colour besides P. So, from that creature’s viewpoint, everything would either have colour P or would not have any colour at all. So that creature could not distinguish the colour of a thing having P from a thing having some other colour. That creature couldn’t even imagine an object with a colour other than P – for the ability to do that obviously presupposes the ability to represent things as having some colour other than P. So, from that creature’s viewpoint, everything – everything perceptible, imaginable, thinkable – would either have the same colour or would have no colour. So that creature could not represent to itself what is distinctive about having P – could not represent what makes a thing having P different, in respect of colour, from a thing with some other completely different colour. But obviously such a creature simply couldn’t represent things as having P: being able to represent things as having P obviously presupposes being to represent how with that colour are different (in respect of colour) from things with other colors -- presupposes being able to represent what is distinctive about things with that colour. Surely if one cannot represent what is different about things with P, then one cannot represent things as having P at all.
    To sum up, being able to represent what is distinctive about things with a certain colour presupposes being able to represent how things with that colour differ, in respect of colour, from things with other colors.  And being able to do the latter obviously presupposes being able to represent things as having those other colors.
    The following analogy might help clarify the structure of the argument just given. Suppose someone had a concept of what it was to weigh 323 lbs, but not of what it was to have any other weight. In that case, that creature’s concept of having any weight at all would coincide with its concept of having a weight of 323 lbs. So that creature could not possibly know how a creature weighing 776 lbs was different, in respect of weight, from one weighing 323 lbs (or 4 lbs). But if one doesn’t know how a creature weighing 323 lbs is different from one weighing 321 lbs or 776 lbs, then surely it can’t really be said to know what it is to weigh specifically 323 lbs
     To sum, it makes no sense to suppose that a creature could represent things as having P, but not as having any other colour: being able to represent things as having some specific colour involves being able the difference (in respect of colour) between things with that colour and things with other colors: and being able to do the latter obviously involves being able to represent things as having different colors. So being able to represent a specific colour presupposes the ability to represent things as having other colors.
     An exact analogue of this argument can be given for any property: the property of being a square, of being an A-flat, or of having the timbre of a French-horn. To take one of these examples: suppose that a creature could represent sounds as having the pitch A-flat but couldn’t represent sounds as having any other pitch. In that case, it couldn’t represent what is special or distinctive about sounds having that pitch; it couldn’t represent how sounds that have that pitch differ from sounds that are some other pitch – say, a Dsharp. For if it is to be able to do any of these things, a creature must be able to represent different pitches: and it is just this that, by hypothesis, the creature in question cannot do. Now if a creature cannot hear, imagine, conceive of the difference in pitch between any two pitches, then surely it cannot represent things as having some specific pitch – as being (say) an Aflat. Being able to represent sounds as having the pitch A-flat  presupposes being able to represent what is distinctive about sounds with that pitch – presupposes being able to represent what makes  sounds with that pitch different from sounds with some other pitch. And it is just this that the creature in question cannot do. So with regard to the idea that a creature could represent things as having the pitch A-flat, but not as having any other pitch – that idea is self-defeating. So being able to represent sounds as having some specific pitch presupposes being able to represent sounds as having other pitches.  
      Basically, to be able to represent things as having a certain property, one must be able to represent what is distinctive about things with that property. And the ability to do that latter presupposes being able to represent things with other properties.
      There is more to say on this matter. For a creature to be able to represent (e.g.) a specific shade of pink, it is not necessary merely that it be able to represent other colours to itself. It would seem that to represent the specific character of (e.g.) P, one must be able to represent  how P differs from other colours and shades. Surely a creature that cannot represent how things having P are different from things having other colors ipso facto simply cannot represent the difference (in respect of colour) between things with P and things of other colors: being able to represent the difference (in respect of colour) between things that have P and things that have some other colour is surely the same thing as being able to represent how things with P differ from things with other colors. And the ability to represent how things with P differ from things with other colors would seem to require possession not just of a multiplicity of representational capacities, but of an organized multiplicity of representational capacities: of a network of such capacities. Knowing how red things differ from pink things and from green things seems to involve knowing how the ‘color-distance’ between red things and pink things compares with that between (say) red things and green things. So knowing how red differs from pink seems to involve having some kind of a map of a system of color-differences, and thus seems to presuppose possession of a network of representational capacities.
    To sum up, being able to represent things as being P presuppose being able to represent how things with P differ from things with other colors. And being able to do this  seems to involve having an organized network of representational capacities. So being able to represent things as having P involves having an organized network of representational capacities.        Let us sum up. There is some reason to believe that representational capacities have a non-atomistic character; that if one can represent one thing or property to oneself, that is at least partly in virtue of his being able to represent other things or properties to himself: so if one is to have a single representational capacity, one must have a whole network of them.
   Although this view is quite popular, I have tried to give a defence of it. My defence may or may not have been credible. But the position defended is, I think, credible independently of my defence and is also very widely held.
[93]
 
 
Why conceptual non-atomism entails that intentionalism is false: a prima facie case
 
If what we just said is correct, then in order for one to have a single representational capacity, one must have a whole ‘battery’ of them:
representational capacities come, ‘not singly, but in articulated networks.’
[94]
 But it is very hard to believe that, for a creature to have a woozy feeling, or a tickle, or an itch, or a morphine-induced good feeling, it must be in
[95] possession of an articulated network of representational capacities.      These considerations make it very hard to believe that intentionalism is true. As we noted earlier, if intentionalism is correct, then whatever phenomenal capacities are creature has, it has them wholly in virtue of having certain representational capacities. So if intentionalism is correct, then a creature has the ability to experience (say) a woozy feeling wholly in virtue of having certain representational capacities. Now we just argued that representational capacities come only in networks, not singly. So if intentionalism is correct, then a creature has the ability to experience a woozy feeling wholly in virtue of having a vast network of representational capacities. So a creature’s ability to experience a woozy feeling presupposes a vast network of representational capacities. But the italicized statement is very hard to believe. It is very hard to believe that so much representational horse-power is needed to have a woozy feeling or a feeling of nausea.     To be sure, there are some kinds of phenomenal content that a creature must have sophisticated representational capacities to enjoy. Consider the feeling a music lover has when listening to Chopin’s ballade in G-minor, or the feeling and art-lover when looking at a Rembrandt. But intuitively it seems unlikely that one’s ability to experience any kind of phenomenal content presupposes a whole slew of representational capacities. If we are right about this, then one’s ability to experience certain kinds of phenomenal content is independent of one’s ability to have mental entities with any representational content. And this would imply that one could have mental entities that had phenomenal content but no representational content; which means that phenomenal content is something altogether different from representational content – not identical with it, or supervenient on it.
     I should address an objection:
 
   You say that a creature whose mind is empty of representational capacities could experience an itch or a tickle. Well, an itch or a tickle must be experienced as being in a particular body part; so to experience an itch or a tickle, one must have the ability to represent different body parts to oneself.
[96]
 Surely this ability does involve having a network of representational capacities. So, contrary to what you see, the ability to experience a
[97] phenomenal content does involve being in possession of such a network.
 
 
 There are a couple of points to make in response to this: a small one and a big one. Here is the small one. Not all phenomenal contents have felt bodilylocation. Consider a morphinated feeling of euphoria. Is that felt in one’s hand or foot? No; it is a ‘generalized’ feeling. So it doesn’t seem that any concepts of body-parts are involved in this kind of feeling. In fact, no spatial representations  -- or any representational capacities, for that matter – seem to be involved the having of such a sensation.
     The big point is this. To be sure, many sensations are felt in certain body parts, and their possession therefore does involve some ability to represent spatial location. But even when we confine our attention to sensations of that type, the facts just don’t square with the supposition that phenomenal content supervenes on representational content. More specifically, we will find that if intentionalism were true, then sensations – even those that must be felt in certain body parts – would deliver vastly more information than they in fact deliver.
    So, for example, we will see that, if intentionalism were true, then a tickle felt in one’s knee would deliver far more information to the subject than such a sensation does in fact deliver; it would tell the subject far more than that there was some kind of disturbance in his knee – and, in fact, it would transmit far more information to the subject than it would be even remotely plausible to see it as transmitting. 
    In a word, intentionalism over-predicts the amount of information borne by sensations, even those that involve reference to body parts.  Let us refer to this thesis as (OP).
    Our argument for OP will consist of three parts. First we will consider the hypothesis that the phenomenal content of sensations – even those that involve reference to specific bodily locations – supervenes on propositional content. We will find that this hypothesis simply isn’t consistent with the amount of information actually borne by such sensations.
   Next we will consider the hypothesis that the phenomenal content of sensations supervenes on non-propositional representational content. And we will find that this hypothesis simply isn’t consistent with the amount of information actually borne by sensations. For argument’s sake, we will provisionally take it for granted that there is such a thing as non-propositional content.
    Finally, in the last section of the paper, we will see some reason to believe that all representational content is essentially propositional.
    So our argument for OP will have the following form. Phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on propositional content. Phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on non-propositional, supposing that there is such a thing. And, finally, there is some reason to deny that there is such a thing as nonpropositional content – so our argument t that phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on propositional content is, if cogent, enough to prove that phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on representational content at all.
 
Why phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on propositional content
       
      Consider some one part of your body; say, a specific part of your knee. Supposing that you are anatomically normal, you are capable of having an extremely wide range of sensations in that one part of your knee. Indeed, given any one type of sensation – say, the type twinge – you are capable of having a wide range of sensations of that one type, in that one part of your knee. As a squash player, I’ve injured my knees many times; and given practically any part of my knee, I’ve had many different twinges there. I don’t think that any two of those twinges have had quite the same phenomenal content. Now remember that, according to the intentionalist, there is no difference phenomenal content of one’s experience without there being some concomitant difference in the representational content of one’s experience.  So, according to the intentionalist, any two of the twinges I had in my knee supervened on graspings of different propositions. In general, according to the intentionalist, any two qualitatively different sensations – no matter how minute the difference in question – correspond to graspings of distinct propositions.
    This means that, if indeed the intentionalist is correct – if indeed the having of sensations (twinges, tickles, etc.) corresponds to the grasping of propositions – it follows that, typically, the propositions grasped will be highly specific  ones; they will not be highly generic propositions like there is damage to my knee.  
   Does it make sense to suppose that the having of (e.g.) a twinge involves the grasping of highly specific propositions? There is reason to think not. What kind of proposition might be borne by a twinge in one’s knee, given – what we’ve seen reason to believe – that this proposition must be fairly specific (cannot be anything nearly as generic as my knee has been damaged in some way or other)? Presumably it is some proposition about the condition of one’s knee: about certain tissues, whether/how they are
misaligned/inflamed/torn/…To put this another way: if a twinge in one’s knee bears any proposition, it can only be assumed to be a proposition about one’s knee, about its condition. So given that this proposition must be more specific than there is some kind of damage in such and such part of my knee, then presumably that proposition must, to some degree, specify the kind of damage or -- if the condition in question is not one of being damaged -- the kind of state one’s knee is in. And, presumably, there is no way this information can be specified except in terms of the components of one’s knee – the tissues, ligatures, bone, and so on – that make it up. So the proposition borne by the twinge will involve reference to quite specific states born by quite specific structures.
  So, if intentionalism is correct, then merely by virtue of having a twinge in one’s knee,  one can acquire a quite specific idea of what tendons, cartilage, and so on are, and a quite specific idea of the kinds of states that might befall them. But it is plain that a person could have a twinge and have absolutely no idea what e.g. a tendon was.
   (Of course, to someone who had some independent access to knowledge of anatomy, a twinge in the knee might indicate some specific kind of damage. So e.g. a doctor who was an expert on knees might learn from a certain twinge that he had a highly specific kind of damage to his knee. But here ulterior or collateral information – information not derived solely from the twinge – would be at work. Strictly speaking, the twinge by itself wouldn’t bear a proposition about a specific kind of damage; that would be done, not by the twinge itself, but by  the doctor’s correlating that twinge with independently obtained knowledge.)
    Also, it simply seems wrong to suppose that e.g. mere tickles and twinges bear such heavy informational loads. A tickle seems to be much too simple and homogenous a thing to bear a fine-grained proposition about muscle exhaustion and misaligned tendons. Propositions are complex. To grasp a proposition, one must grasp its various constituents. (To grasp the proposition Bob hit Bill one must presumably grasp Bob, Bill, and the relation of hitting. Further, one must arrange these constituents in a certain way.) In any case, this seems like a not unreasonable proposal. Now could something as homogenous and amorphous as a twinge constitute a grasping of some highly structured proposition about sometimes quite recondite anatomical structures? Intuitively, it very much seems not.
   (The intentionalist might say that, although twinges, tickles etc. appear too simple to mediate complex propositions, that appearance is misleading: how mental entities seem to be is not always how they are, pace Descartes. I will address this objection in a moment.)
To sum up, it isn’t reasonable to suppose that the having of sensations supervenes on/reduces to the grasping of propositions. The propositions in question would have to be highly specific ones – ones loaded with differential information – and there is every reason  to think that this is not the case.
    I should respond to one last objection before ending this long section:
 
    You have said repeatedly that bits of phenomenal simply don’t seem to have the internal complexity needed to bear complex propositions -propositions or factive propositions containing anything other than highly generic information. Presumably, you are basing this comment on your own reflection, on the ‘data of introspection’. But such data are notoriously unreliable. Haven’t we learned from cognitive science, and perhaps also from psychoanalysis, how little we can know of our own minds through introspection?
 
   This point is well-taken. But there are a couple of points to be made in response. First of all, I should say that I agree that vast portions of our mental landscapes cannot be known through introspection. But surely if we can know anything on the basis of introspection, it is the nature of our phenomenal contents. If introspection is not completely useless as a means of gathering information about ourselves, it is probably pretty good at apprising us of the nature and character of our phenomenal states. And, given what introspection tells us about our phenomenal contents, it is hard to believe that they can bear the complex propositions that, if intentionalism is correct, they would have to bear. To my mind, there is nothing intuitively strange about mental computational processes (like those posited by Chomsky and Marr) that are completely unknowable through introspection. But the idea that I might be similarly blind to e.g.  the pain I’m feeling in my shin right now (having just banged it) is, to say the least, a radical one (though it has had its proponents). Of course, the objector could say that I am just begging the question: what is at issue is whether introspection is a valid source of information about our phenomenal contents, and I am simply assuming that they are.
    But – this is the third counter-objection -- there is a more specific rejoinder to be made, and this one is not question-begging. If intentionalism is right, then phenomenal contents deliver information. This means that our minds must have some way of retrieving this information from them. So our minds must, at some level, be aware of the complexities, the articulations, that (if intentionalism is correct) enable them to bear this information. Could this awareness be sub-conscious? It seems not. The notion of phenomenal content is very closely bound up with that of consciousness. It seems that if phenomenal contents deliver information to any part of our minds, then presumably it is to our conscious minds. So if phenomenal contents deliver propositions to us,  it is presumably the conscious mind that retrieves these propositions; and in this case, presumably, the conscious mind must have a pretty good grip on the character and structure of our phenomenal contents. So if intentionalism is right, then it seems to follow that our conscious minds do know our phenomenal contents pretty well. So given that consciousness tells us that our phenomenal contents lack the structure needed to  mediate the heavy-duty propositions that, if intentionalism is right, they do in fact mediate – given this, we ipso facto have strong evidence that intentionalism is false.
 
 
 
 
 
Why the phenomenal content of sensations doesn’t supervene on nonpropositional content (supposing that there is such a thing)
 
So far we’ve seen some reason think that phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on the grasping of propositions. Some philosophers hold that the kind of representational content embodied in propositions is not the only kind of representational content: they say that there is also ‘non-propositional’ representational content. (For some reason, the term ‘non-conceptual’ is typically used instead of ‘non-propositional.’ But I will use the term ‘non-
[98]
	propositional.’) Obviously if there is such a thing as ‘non-propositional’ representational content, then we have not shown that intentionalism tout court is false, only that a specific kind of intentionalism is false: for  the intentionalist could counter-attack by saying:
 
 Phenomenal content supervenes on non-propositional content. Whenever there is a difference in phenomenal content, that fact does correspond to a difference in representational content. It corresponds to a difference in nonpropositional content. So, for example, if two tickles are qualitatively a bit different from each other, that means that they supervene on states that bear different non-propositional content. Thus, intentionalism is true, after all: whenever there is a difference in phenomenal content, there is a difference in representational content. But the latter is non-propositional, not propositional. [99]
 
 
    In this section, I will show that even if there is such a thing as nonpropositional content, that doesn’t threaten our defence of OP. So if there is such a thing as non-propositional content, that does not (so I will argue) enable the intentionalist to sidestep the arguments we’ve already set forth.     (In the next section, we will question the hypothesis that there is such a thing as non-propositional content.)
     The main things we said about propositional content are true of nonpropositional content (supposing for the sake of argument that there is such a thing as non-propositional content). And the arguments we used earlier – when we were attacking the idea that phenomenal content might supervene on propositional content – work with equal force against the idea that it might supervene on non-propositional content. Accordingly, what we say here will closely parallel what we said earlier.
       Consider any given perception – e.g. the visual perception you are having right now of the journal in front of you. The journal is being given to you as having innumerable properties – as having a certain colour, shape, size, spatial location, and so on.
    For the sake of argument, let us suppose that there is such a thing as nonpropositional content and that, consequently, some representations bear nonpropositional content. Surely what we said a moment ago is true of representations that bear non-propositional content (supposing that there are such things). Surely such a representation must represent things as being a certain way and thus as having certain properties. It is a contradiction in terms to say that there is a representation that fails to represents things as being a certain way.
