So if there are representations that bear nonpropositional content, those representations must – like any other kind of representation – represent things as being a certain way and thus as having such and such properties. So the ability to have any kind of representation  -regardless of whether those representations bear propositional or nonpropositional content – presupposes the ability to represent things as having properties; it presupposes possession of what we earlier referred to as
‘representational capacities.’ 
        Earlier we argued that, for any property P, if a creature can represent things as having P to itself – if it can see things/ hear things/ imagine things/ …as having P – then it necessarily has the ability to represent things to itself as having various other properties. Representational capacities, we argued, come not singly, but in vast, interconnected networks. The argument was basically that a creature cannot represent things as having P to itself unless it can ‘locate’ P in a ‘space’ of related, but distinct properties. Now as we just noted, any representation – whether it bears propositional or nonpropositional content – presupposes the ability to represents things as having certain properties to oneself. So one cannot have mental states that bear nonpropositional content (supposing that there is such a thing) unless one possesses a “vast, interconnected” network of representational capacities.     Given this, suppose that, in fact, phenomenal content does supervene on non-propositional content. In that case, given what we just said, the ability to have a tickle, or a twinge, or a feeling of nausea presupposes the ability to represent things as having various properties to oneself, and therefore presupposes that one is in possession of a vast, interconnected network of representational capacities. So, to reiterate, if phenomenal content does supervene on non-propositional content, then the ability to experience any quale – any twinge, or tickle, or woozy feeling – presupposes that one is in possession of a vast arsenal of representational capacities.
    But this is very unlikely to be the case. Intuitively, it is very hard to believe that the having of a feeling of nausea, or of a morphinated high presupposes possession of a vast network of representational capacities.
    Of course, the intentionalist could say: ‘You are just begging the question.
Given that representational capacities come in vast networks, what follows is that the ability to have (e.g.) a tickle or a twinge does presuppose possession of a veritable battery of representational concepts.’
      But there is good reason to be suspicious of this counter-move. By definition, intentionalism says that each difference in phenomenal content corresponded to a difference in representational content. Now as we noted earlier, given how many different phenomenal contents we can have – indeed, given how many different phenomenal contents one can have in practically any given part of one’s body -- it follows that if each difference in phenomenal content corresponded to a difference in representational content, then each bit of phenomenal content – each twinge, each nauseas feeling, each tickle – would have to contain an enormous amount of differential information and would thus be enormously informative. If intentionalism is correct, then any difference between two phenomenal states – even the merest nuance of a difference -- corresponds to a representational difference. Now our phenomenal ‘palate’ is extremely rich: we seem capable of having indefinitely many different kinds of phenomenal contents in practically any given body part. In fact, we seem to be capable of having indefinitely many phenomenal contents of a given kind in a given body part. There are indefinitely many different kinds of tickles, or twinges, or pains, or itches that one can have on (say) a given part of one’s neck. For intentionalism, each of these phenomenal differences corresponds to an informational difference. So given how many different kinds of phenomenal contents we can have – given how many different kinds of such content we can have in practically any given body part – any phenomenal content would have to contain an enormous amount of differential information, and would that have to be enormously information-heavy. Given how information-heavy a tickle or twinge would have to be, for intentionalism to be correct, it follows that a tickle or twinge would not bear highly generic messages like there is a disturbance of some kind in such and such part of my body, but would bear much more fine-grained, precise messages.
       But a tickle or a twinge simply seems not to bear that much information. Here we need do little more than repeat what we said earlier. For the sake of argument, suppose that, in fact, a tickle did contain such a large amount of information. What would that information be about? If (e.g.) a tickle were in fact a treasure-chest of differential information, what would that information be information about? It could only be information about some bodily condition– information about some somatic disturbance or event. So if intentionalism were correct, then (e.g.) a tickle in one’s neck would tell one an enormous amount about the condition of that part of one’s neck: it would do much more than to give one some highly generic message like disturbance of some kind in such and such a part of my neck. But tickles and twinges simply don’t tell one that much.
    We said all of this before. The important point is that the argument we just gave goes through regardless of whether we are talking about propositional or non-propositional content. Even if the kind of information borne by (e.g.) a tickle is non-propositional, it still follows, for the reasons just given, that intentionalism would require of that tickle that it bear an enormous amount of differential information. But tickles simply don’t bear that much information. They don’t bear that propositional information – as we saw before – and they don’t bear that much non-propositional information. For even if (say) tickles and twinges bore a large amount of non-propositional information, that information would still, inevitably, be about one’s body – about somatic disturbances: so each tickle or twinge would constitute an extremely highresolution, information-heavy apprehension of the condition of a given part of one’s body. But while it could credibly be maintained that tickles and twinges give one some information about one’s body, it cannot credibly be maintained that they constitute high-resolution apprehensions of bodily conditions: in so far as tickles, and twinges, and feelings of nausea are representations, they are fairly opaque and uninformative. Intentionalism – whether it construes phenomenal content as supervening on propositional or non-propositional information – demands that tickles, twinges, etc. be very much non-opaque and high-resolution. So intentionalism, of either of the two varieties just mentioned, simply lacks credibility.
 
 
A reason to doubt that there is such a thing as non-propositional content
 
So far we have allowed, for the sake of argument, that there is such a thing as non-propositional content. Here I will argue, in effect, that propositional content is the only kind of representational content. If this is the case, then of course it cannot be maintained that phenomenal content supervenes on nonpropositional content. Consequently, our earlier argument that phenomenal content cannot supervene on propositional content would, if cogent, amount to a demonstration that phenomenal content cannot supervene on any kind of representational content.
    I warn this section is highly speculative and is in no way probative. Its purpose is not to refute the idea that there is non-propositional content, but only to put some pressure on this idea – to delineate some of the obstacles that view will run into.
         Once again, consider an arbitrary visual perception. (Supposing that, indeed, some representations have non-propositional content, visual perceptions are paradigm cases of such representations; so we might as well focus on them.) Uncontroversially, the representational content of a visual perception can to some degree be put into words and, thus, embodied in a proposition. People can tell you what they saw, at least up to a point (‘I saw a man in an orange shirt smoking a pipe…’) So obviously the representational content of a visual perception overlaps to some extent with the representational content of a sentence (‘I saw a man in orange shirt…’): a paradigmatically ‘digital’ representation. Again, I do not think this is controversial: who could possibly maintain that the representational content of a visual perception is utterly ineffable – is totally incapable of being embodied in a sentence? Surely when I say ‘I saw a red apple sitting on a desk…’ I am succeeding in transmitting some of the representational content of a visual perception of mine. 
       Now the next step is also, I think, fairly uncontroversial. Visual representations are, in an important sense, homogeneous. When we consider a visual perception, there is no reason to believe that it has two, totally different kinds of representational content; visual perceptions seem to be (in this respect) ‘seamless’; the representational content of a visual perception seems not to be patchwork of totally different kinds of content – of propositional and non-propositional content. Visual perceptions are not cobbled together out of discrete parts.
      What I mean by this can best be understood by contrasting visual representations with patently hybrid –-  patently heterogeneous  ---  representations. A comic strip is a patently hybrid kind of representation: there is a picture (e.g. of a superhero performing some great feat) and there are also words (which are put in a bubble emanating from the mouth of the featured character). So comics are both analogue and digital and are thus, in an obvious way, heterogeneous representations; they are characterized by a certain kind of internal division. Now when we consider purely analogue representations – e.g. visual perceptions, photographs – there seems to no comparable internal division. Analogue representations have a kind of seamlessness, a kind of homogeneity. And, one would think, a representation would not have this seamless, homogenous quality if it were built up out of two, totally different kinds of content.
   In any case, there is a great deal of intuitive support for the idea that a visual perception or a photograph or a painting does not consist of two different kinds of representational content – for they do not have that ‘cobbled together’ quality characteristic of e.g. comics. There is simply no intuitive support for the idea that visual perceptions and photographs bear two, totally different kinds of content.
       Hence, the facts we have to work with are as follows. (i) The content of an analogue (e.g. a visual) representation can, at least up to a point, be expressed by a sentence and thus, presumably, embodied in a proposition. (ii) An analogue representation does not bear two, completely distinct kinds of representational content.
      Now given both (i) and (ii), it seems to follow that the representational content of a visual perception is in its entirety propositional. But this conclusion is in deep tension with the following fact, viz.: (iii) There is, plainly, some kind of important distinction between analogue (e.g. visual) and digital representations (e.g. propositions): the latter are, whereas the former are not, decomposable into minimal representational units.
     The best way to make sense of these three facts is, I would suggest, as follows: the difference between propositions and e.g. visual representations is not a difference in what is represented but in how it is represented. Each of (i)-(iii) is correct. The difference between e.g. a sentence and a visual perception lies not in what is represented, but in how what is represented is packaged. A sentence tidies everything up, putting it in discrete parcels. A visual representation leaves it, as it were, strewn all over the floor. A proposition is not a special kind of information; it is a special packaging of information.
    I think that this line of thought does less violence to our intuitions than the alternatives. First of all, we do want to say that the information borne by a visual perception can (at least up to a point) be embodied in a proposition. But we don’t want to say that the representational content of a visual perception is a proposition (or conjunction of propositions), for the simple reason that propositions are, whereas the contents of visual representations are not, neatly decomposable into minimal units. (Surely the proposition Bob is smarter than Fred is decomposable into discrete parts while the representational content of a visual perception of a forest is not thus decomposable.) We also probably don’t want to say that a visual perception has two wholly distinct kinds of representational content: propositional and other. Given these data, it seems reasonable to say the following: A visual
(more generally, an analogue) representation bears only kind of representational content; and this content can be packaged in a proposition, but it doesn’t have to be.
      So it is true that sentences bear propositions while visual perceptions do not; but it is also true that the content of a visual perception can be embodied in propositions. If propositions were one kind of representational content while the representational contents of visual perceptions were some totally different kind of content, this would not be possible. But propositions are not a kind of content; they are a way of packaging content. Visual representations don’t package content in this way; but what they do package can be packaged propositionally.
      Now if this is even remotely on the mark, then there are two quite distinct dimensions to the ‘representational load’ of a representation: there is the representational content of that representation; and there is also the packaging of that content. Now the packaging of this content has too often been identified with the representation itself. But this is a mistake. A visual perception of a round ball and the sentence ‘that ball is round’ obviously overlap in what they represent; but the way they package this common content differs. So what is borne by a sentence is not just representational content, but a certain way of packaging this content; and the same is true of a visual perception. (The sentence itself is not identical with the packaging. The sentence ‘Bob is intelligent’ packages the same representational content in the same way as the sentence ‘Bob is smart’. But these sentences are obviously different.) But what it is that is packaged is not a proposition: and that is why visual representations – and, more generally, analogue representations: representations which do not have propositions for the representations contents – can have their contents embodied in propositions.      With these points in place, we can neutralize the objector’s point. Earlier in the paper we showed that phenomenal content probably doesn’t supervene on the kind of representational content embodied in propositions. Now we’ve just seen that, in all probability, there are not two kinds of representational contents: there is only one.
   (There is an important distinction between e.g. visual perceptions, on the one hand, and sentences, on the other: but this difference has to do not with the representational content borne by such things, but by the way in which this representational content is packaged. The difference that is referred to as ‘the difference between conceptual and non-conceptual content’ does exist, but it is not a difference between kinds of content, but between ways of packaging that content.)
     So since (i) there is not  a difference in the kind of representational content borne by propositions, on the one hand, and visual perceptions (and photographs) on the other (though there is a difference in the way these
things ‘package’ their representational content); and (ii) since, as we’ve seen, the having of phenomenal content probably doesn’t supervene on the grasping of the kind of representational content embodied in propositions; it follows by simple logic (iii) that the having of  phenomenal content doesn’t supervene on the kind of content embodied in visual sensations, photographs. And once (iii) is granted, the intentionalist counter-attack put forth by the objector (page 23) ceases to have any viability.
      There is a less formal, more intuitive, way of nullifying the objector’s counter-attack (p.23). Suppose for the sake of argument that there is such a thing as non-propositional content. Now if there is such a thing as nonpropositional content, then indeed phenomenally pregnant mental states – e.g. sense-perceptions, sensations (twinges, tickles, etc.) – are presumably the kinds of things that would bear such content. Given this, consider any given phenomenally pregnant state – consider e.g. a tickle. Now a tickle does, it would seem, tell you something. It tells you that there is some kind bodily disturbance in a certain region of your body. Now consider the information borne by the tickle, and subtract away all the information that can be embodied in propositions. The first thing you’d have to subtract would be a reference to any bodily location. For obviously information about bodily location can be embodied in a proposition. In fact, you’d have to subtract any kind of spatial or even temporal information: for all such information can be embodied in propositions. So any information, in that sensation, to the effect that such and such is happening at such and such a time and at such and such place – all that information would have to be removed. For these things can be stated in words, and thus embodied in propositions. Of course, once information about spatial and temporal location is gone, it isn’t really clear what kind of information is left over: for, it would seem, any kind of information about the external world will presuppose some kind of spatiotemporal information. So once propositional information is removed from a phenomenal content – once the kind of information that can be embodied in propositions is taken away – there doesn’t really seem to be any information left.
    Our ‘framework’ concepts – the concepts in terms of which the external world is given to us: space, time, object, event, change etc. – are all capable of being embodied in propositions. For nothing is more obvious than that we talk about space, time, change etc. So given a mental state, once we remove the ‘propositional’ information from it, we ipso facto divest that state of its being able to tell us anything about the world. This consideration obviously favours the thesis that there is no non-propositional content.
   Another example might help. Consider a visual perception. As we’ve noted, it is undeniable that some of the information borne by that perception can be embodied in propositions. I can tell you what I see, at least up to a point: I see ‘a man wearing a green shirt, holding a tennis racket’ etc. Now strip away all the information from that perception that can be embodied in propositions. What are you left with? Not with a perception of an object of such and such shape, occupying such and such a place. For this information is clearly of the kind that can be embodied in propositions: I can obviously tell you that I see a man of such and such shape in such and such a location etc. But once this information is taken away, it isn’t really clear if anything representational is left. Once all propositional information is taken away, the possibility of any kind of representation is taken away. Once I remove from the visual perception all reference to things that can be stated – which includes location and state of motion – it very much seems that the pre-condition for there be any kind of representation is taken away.
    In sum, the kind of information that can be embodied in propositions must be borne by any representation worthy of the name. There is no way to subtract propositional information from a representation without making it cease to be a representation: in effect, you can’t get rid of propositional content without  getting rid of all content. This, of course, favours the conclusion that there is no non-propositional content. 
    Now one might reject the last inference:
 
   Given only that you can’t get rid of propositional content without getting of all representational content, it doesn’t follow that all propositional content is propositional. This inference involves a non-sequitur. You can’t get rid of extension without getting rid of colour. But extension and colour are different things.
  
  There are two points to make in response. First of all, I grant that technically the objector is right. Given only that propositional content cannot be removed from a representation without divesting that representation of all content – given only that fact, it doesn’t technically follow that all representational content is propositional content. But surely that fact gives some credence to the idea that all content is propositional content.
  But we have a stronger counter-response at our disposal. Even if it is granted that there is such a thing as non-propositional content, once it is conceded that a mental entity cannot be stripped of its propositional content without being stripped of all its representational content, the idea that phenomenal content supervenes on non-propositional content becomes null and void. Permit me to defend this thesis.
    We’ve just seen that non-propositional content, if such a thing exists, is not autonomous, but is necessarily mixed together with propositional content. This seems to imply that two mental states cannot differ in non-propositional content (supposing for the sake of argument that there is such a thing)
without also varying in propositional content. After all, if two mental states could vary in non-propositional content without varying in propositional content, that would very much seem to indicate that non-propositional content has just the kind of independence form propositional content that we have seen that it could not possibly have. So if there is such a thing as nonpropositional content, then given that it is parasitic on propositional content, it follows that two states could not differ in non-propositional content without also differing in propositional content. So any difference in non-propositional content is associated with a difference in propositional content. Now the version of intentionalism we are considering now says that differences in phenomenal content correspond to differences in non-propositional content. We’ve just seen that differences in non-propositional content correspond to differences in propositional content. So, by implication, the kind of intentionalism we are considering now implies that differences in phenomenal content correspond to differences in propositional content. But we’ve seen, over and over again (pp.11-22), that this is not the case.      In sum, even if there is such a thing as non-propositional content, this doesn’t help the intentionalist: for a change in non-propositional content (supposing that such a thing exists) involves a change in propositional content; consequently, if differences in phenomenal content correspond to differences in non-propositional content, then they also correspond to differences in propositional content. But we’ve seen many reasons to reject the idea that differences in phenomenal content always correspond to differences in propositional content.

Simulated versus actual thought
 
Part I.  In this paper, I wish to discuss the relation between simulating thought, on the one hand, and actually thinking, on the other. I believe that this relation has been distorted by a failure to take into account some basic facts about the conditions under which separate thoughts can combine to form a single molecular thought.
      Let us start with a story. At one moment, you think snow is white. At a later time, you think something is white. But your thinking something is white has nothing to do with your previously thinking snow is white. Under these circumstances, have you thought snow is white, therefore something is white? Have you thought snow is white and something is white? Have you thought any molecular proposition comprising both snow is white and something is white?
     “No” to all of these questions. Because your thinking snow is white didn’t have anything to do with your subsequently thinking something is white, your two thoughts didn’t “combine”, so to speak, into a single thought-process.        Let us extend these remarks by telling another story. You think Socrates. 
[100]
Later you think hit. Still later you think 	Plato. But your thinking Socrates has nothing to do with your thinking hit, and your thinking hit has nothing to do with your subsequently thinking Plato. Under these circumstances, have you thought Socrates hit Plato? You have not. In order to think Socrates hit Plato, it is necessary not only to have the sequence of thoughts Socrates*hit*Plato (each * is meant to indicate a break of a kind): it is necessary also that your thinking Socrates have something to do with your thinking hit and also with your thinking Plato.
      There is a difference between having a series of cognitive episodes, on the one hand, and having a unified thought-process, on the other. Not just any sequence of representations constitutes a thought-process. One’s thinking such and such must have something to do with one’s later thinking thus and such, if one is to think such and such, therefore thus and such or such and such and thus and such or if such and such, then such and such, and so on.     These banal facts give us some leverage on a question that is anything but banal, namely: “Is there a difference between simulated thought and actual thought?”
    Let me break the question down. Let M be some physical object in which there are representations or symbols of some kind. We may leave it open whether M is an artifact, like a computer, or a naturally occurring object, like a brain. Because of M’s structure, the representations it produces follow one another in utterly “rational” ways – in ways that are consistent with the strictures of logic. If M produces a snow is white-representation, then – as an inevitable and perfectly reliable consequence of M’s structure – M will duly produce a something is white-representation. If M produces a 2+2representation, then M will duly produce an =4-representation.  In general, for any chunk of information i, if M produces an i-representation, then M inevitably produces an i*-representation, where i* is a chunk of information that stands in an appropriate logical relation to i.    
     Here is the question I am asking: “Given only that M reliably follows up representations with other, logically appropriate representations, does it follow that M is rational?” My answer is: “No.” Given only that M perfectly simulates rational thought, it doesn’t follow that M is rational. Of course, M
[101]
might still be a rational thinker for some other reason.
    
 
 Part II. Let us begin with some pedestrian facts about causality. Causal relations hold among states of affairs, not among things. The rock doesn’t break the window. Some state of affairs involving the rock does so. The rock has a certain mass; it is moving with a certain velocity; it collides with a window of a certain thickness. These things – the rock’s having a certain mass, moving with a certain velocity etc. – are what cause the window to break. The rock simpliciter does not do so.
     This is equivalent to saying: it is not the rock per se that breaks the window. It is the rock’s having certain properties that does so. It is the rock’s moving with a certain velocity, colliding with a window of a certain thickness, and so on.
     Not every property of the rock is involved in the window-breaking. Suppose the rock has a dimple on one of its sides. The rock’s having that dimple is causally effective in some contexts. For example, if you were to pour water on the dimpled side of the rock, the presence of the dimple would affect the course of the stream of water. But the dimple needn’t be causally effective in this particular context.  Perhaps the side of the rock that collided with the window wasn’t the side with the dimple on it.
      The main point is that an object doesn’t cause anything.  What does so is an object’s having this or that property; equivalently, it is a state of affairs comprising that object.
     Let us apply these platitudes about causation to the nature of thoughtprocesses. It might seem that any sequence of mental representations constitutes a thought-process. First there is the thought: snow is white. Then there is the thought: grass is green. Then there is the thought: snow is white and grass is green.
    Here we have a sequence of mental representations. That, it might seem, is enough for the existence of a thought-process. Indeed, in this particular case, we have enough for the existence of a rational thought process – a proof or logical derivation. A thought that snow is white and grass is green occurred after a thought that snow is white and a thought that grass is green. So that conjunction was appropriately derived from those conjuncts.
     This reasoning is spurious. There was not necessarily any thought-process at all, let alone a rational one. Consider the following scenario. X thinks snow
[102]
is white 	at t. (Let C be this thought, i.e. this cognitive episode.) Y thinks something is white at t*. (Let C* be this cognitive episode.) Y’s thought has nothing to do with X’s. The two thoughts happen independently. There is no causal connection. Has a single thought-process occurred? Has there been a thought to the effect that snow is white, something is white? No. There have been two disjoint thoughts. The two thoughts didn’t combine into a single thought-process. The occurrence of the second thought didn’t have anything to do with the occurrence of the first. The lack of a causal connection prevents that.
    It seems, then, for thoughts to “molecularize”, a causal connection between them is necessary. But not just any causal connection will do. We could easily imagine a case where Bill’s thinking grass is green causes Fred to think something is green. It suddenly occurs to Fred that grass is green. For some random psychoanalytic reason, this causes Fred to dump green paint on Fred’s car. Fred sees his car, and thinks (among other things) something is green. Here the sequence of thoughts grass is green…something is green doesn’t constitute a thought-process, even though the first thought caused the second one to occur. So if distinct thoughts are to form a single thoughtprocess, a causal connection is necessary, but not sufficient.
     For illustrative reasons, we spoken about thoughts had by different people. But what we’ve said so far can apply to thoughts occurring within a single mind. To see this, let us tell a new story. For whatever reason, Bill thinks: grass is green. A moment later, out of the blue – for reasons totally unrelated to his having the first thought --  he thinks: something is green.
    Here, within a single mind, we have a sequence of thoughts: grass is green, something is green. But that sequence of thoughts does not constitute a single thought-process, let alone a coherent one. The second thought has nothing to do with the first. There is no causal relation. That, among other things perhaps, prevents the two thoughts “molecularizing” into a single thought-process.
     The propositions involved – grass is green, something is green – stand in the right logical relations to each other. So the reason Bill isn’t having a coherent thought-process has nothing to do with a lack of bearing-relations among the propositions he believes. As we said, it has to do with (inter alia) a lack of a causal connection among the mental states embodying his beliefs.     Let us now change the story.  Again, suppose Bill suddenly thinks grass is green. Let B1 be that cognitive episode. A little later, Bill suddenly thinks something is green. Let B2 be that cognitive episode. Of course, B1 and B2 are spatio-temporal entities: they are mental states, and they are also, presumably, brain-states.
      For reasons we’ve seen, if the sequence B1-B2 is to constitute a thoughtprocess, it is necessary that they be causally related. But it is not sufficient. Here we have to start taking into account the points made earlier about causation.
      B1 and B2 are physical entities. As such, they have causal powers. So B1 causes things to happen. But not every case where B1 causes something to happen is a case where B1’s being a thought that grass is green causes something to happen. Because of its chemical properties, B1 may cause you to have a headache or to feel elated. But those are not, at least not necessarily, cases where B1’s being a belief that grass is green causes anything to happen. Of course, B1 is a belief that grass is green; and presumably that fact about B1 is causally effective, at least in some contexts. But that doesn’t mean that, every time B1 does something, B1’s being a belief that grass is green is involved.
       Suppose, if only for the sake of argument, that B1’s having a certain shape is not involved in B1’s realizing that content. (If you think that shape is essential to representational content, then simply substitute my talk of shape with talk of some other property that you think to be incidental to B1’s being a belief that grass is green.) Given this, suppose that B1 causes B2 to come about, but that B1’s being a belief that grass is green is not involved in this transaction. So what is causally effective is B1’s having a certain shape, not its having a certain representational content.
     Here we have the sequence B1-B2, but the generation of that sequence has nothing to do with B1’s being a belief that grass is green. What we have here is a sequence of thoughts, where the first thought causes the second to exist, and where the representational content of the first thought entails that of the second. But we don’t have a case of valid reasoning.
      In fact, we don’t even have a thought-process, let alone a valid one. Suppose that Bob is the person whose mind-brain houses B1 and B2. In the scenario described, Bob’s believing that grass is green is causally inert with respect to his subsequently believing that something is green. So Bob’s coming to believe that something is green has nothing to do with Bob’s previously believing that grass is green.  In order for the sequence B1-B2 to constitute a thought-process – whether logical or illogical – it is necessary not just that B1 cause B2 to come about, but that B1’s having a certain representational content be implicated in that transaction. So under the
[103]
circumstances, Bob has not had a single thought-process.
     A thought process is not just a series of a series of mental representations.
It is a series of representations such that, for each entry in that series, that entry’s having a certain representational content is causally effective in generating later entries.
         Even that condition, though clearly necessary, is probably not sufficient. We can imagine analogues of points made by Davidson (in
[104]
	connection with action-theory) and Gettier (in connection with
[105]
	epistemology) showing that bi’s being a belief that such and such is what brings about bi+1, but where, nonetheless, the sequence bi-bi+1 is not a thought-process.
     Let us illustrate this with a new story. (Let B1 and B2 be defined as before.) For whatever reason, Bob finds it terribly exciting that grass is green. So whenever the thought grass is green flashes through his mind, his heart starts to race, his palms start to sweat, and so on. Prior to all this, a hypnotist programmed Bob to think something is green whenever his (Bob’s) heart rate went above ninety beats per minute. One day, the thought grass is green flashes through Bob’s mind -- B1 occurs. For the reasons just described, B1’s being a belief that grass is green – not just B1, but B1’s being a belief of that kind – causes Bob to think something is green.
   Nonetheless, it seems that, even in this circumstance, the sequence B1-B2 does not constitute thought-process. B1’s having a certain representational content is indeed causally effective. But it is it not, evidently, effective in the right way. So for the sequence B1-B2 to constitute a thought-process, as opposed to a sequence of isolated thoughts, it is not sufficient that B1’s having such and such representational content be causally effective in bringing about B2.
      But it is necessary. It is not enough that B1 cause B2 to happen. It is also necessary that B1’s being a belief that grass is green be causally involved.
          To consolidate these points, it will help if we introduce some terminology. We speak of certain entities as being “truth-evaluable”. Such entities include propositions, beliefs, and sentences. Some entities can be evaluated, not for truth, but for validity or invalidity, logicality or illogicality.
[106]
 A series of thoughts can involve false premises but, aside from that, be impeccable. Such a series could be described as valid, but not sound. Ordinarily, we use the terms “valid” and “sound”, and the like, to describe sequences of propositions, not cognitive episodes. But it will expedite discussion if we now those terms, or homonyms thereof, to describe sequences of cognitive-episodes. Given anything that can be evaluated for logicality, let us describe it as logic-evaluable.
      Using this terminology, we may summarize our findings thus. For a sequence of brain-states b1...bn to constitute a logic-evaluable thought process, it is necessary that, for each i, bi’s having such and such content be what generates later entries in that series. (This is necessary but not, as we just saw, sufficient.)  Indeed, this condition must be met if b1…bn is to constitute any thought-process, and not just a series of disjoint entries.
     
 
Part III.  Let us continue to talk about our old friend Bob. Let us suppose we do a bit of neuro-surgery on Bob. We “tweek” Bob’s brain so that, when B1 occurs, B2 must also occur. Through some clever neuro-engineering, we make it a physical necessity that, if B1 happens, Bob’s brain will produce B2.     But there is a qualification. We make sure that what makes B2 happen is not B1’s being a belief that grass is green. So even though B1 necessarily, and therefore reliably, leads to B2, nonetheless B1’s being a belief that grass is green has nothing to do with B2’s coming into existence.
      Perhaps this qualifier requires clarification. Let p be some property of B1 that is not involved B1’s being a belief that grass is green. But suppose that, in general, p is a causally effective property. So p isn’t a property like is a thing x such penguins either do or do not fly. p is, perhaps, the property of having a specific temperature or a specific micro-morphology. So even though it is causally effective, p is not involved in B1’s being a belief that
[107]
	grass is green.  Our neuro-surgeons set things up in such a way that it is B1’s having p – and not B1’s being a belief that grass is green – that is causally responsible for B2’s coming into existence.
     Make no mistake. The causal connection between B1 and B2 is reliable. Our engineers rigged Bob’s brain in such a way that, given the laws of physics, B2 absolutely must happen if B1 happens (at least in so far as anything must happen, given the apparently probabilistic character of physical law). So the connection between B1 and B2 is as reliable as a connection can be.
    At the same time, B1’s causing B2 to occur has nothing to do with B1’s having a certain representational content. It has to do entirely with some property of B1’s that is irrelevant to B1’s representational content.      So under this circumstance, Bob’s thinking something is green has nothing to do with his thinking grass is green. True – Bob has a brain-state (B1) encoding a belief that grass is green. True – that brain-state brings about a brain-state (B2) to the effect that something is green. True – the first brainstate brings about the second via a reliable mechanism. But Bob’s thinking grass is green doesn’t have anything to do with Bob’s thinking something is green. So Bob has not thought grass is green, therefore something is green. Nor has Bob thought grass is green and something is green. Bob hasn’t thought any “molecularization” of those propositions. The sequence B1-B2 does not, under this circumstance, constitute a thought-process at all. A fortiori it does not constitute a piece of valid reasoning. Even though the propositions in question – grass is green and something is green --- are being thought in the right order, nonetheless the sequence B1-B2 does not constitute a valid thought-process. It doesn’t constitute any thought process, valid or invalid.
       What we said about B1-B2 applies to any sequence of brain-states – or, indeed, to physical states of any kind -- and, thus, to any sequence of mental representations. Let P and Q be any two propositions such that P entails Q. With that one qualification, there is no restriction on what P and Q may be. Let BP be a brain-state of Bob’s (or Mary’s or Fred’s…) mediating a belief that P, and let BQ be a brain-state of the same person that mediates a belief that Q. Finally, let p* be some causally effective property of BP that is not relevant to BP’s being a belief that P. Through clever neuro-engineering, we can ensure that, if BP happens, then BQ must happen. And we can also make sure that BP’s being a belief that P is not involved in that causal transaction: we set things up so that it is BP’s having p* -- and not BP’s being a belief - that causes BQ to come about.
   For reasons we’ve seen, the sequence BP-BQ will not constitute a valid, or even a logic-evaluable, thought-process. In fact, it won’t even constitute a thought-process. It will just be a series of disjoint entries.
   So far we’ve been talking about brain-states. But exactly the same principle applies if we were to talk about states of a punch-card automaton or a Texas Instruments calculator or any other physical entity.
   This line of thought can be extended to the sub-propositional level. Let b1, b2, and b3 be the brain-states mediating, respectively, your thinking Socrates, your thinking hit, and your thinking Plato. If b1’s being a Socrates-thought has nothing to do with b2’s coming into existence, or if b2’s being a hitthought has nothing to do with b3’s coming into existence, then the sequence b1-b2-b3 doesn’t add up to your thinking Socrates hit Plato. You have thought Socrates and then thought hit and then thought Plato. But you have not thought Socrates hit Plato. For these three thoughts to molecularize, it is necessary not only that they be causally interrelated; it is necessary that their
[108] having certain representational contents be what drives the sequence.         Through clever neuro-engineering, we could “tweek” Bob’s brain in such a way that, if b1 occurs, then b2 and b3 must occur, in that order, where the “must” corresponds to the strongest kind of nomic necessity imaginable. But as we have just seen, b1’s causing b2 and b3 to happen will not add up to the thought Socrates hit Plato, unless b1’s being a Socrates-thought is what is causally responsible.
   What we just said about Bob applies to any entity, whether artificial or natural. Suppose M thinks Socrates and then hit and then Plato. Let m1, m2, and m3 be the physical states realizing these thoughts. Unless m1’s being a Socrates-thought is what brings about m2, and unless m2’s being a hitthought is what brings about m3, M hasn’t thought Socrates hit Plato. It doesn’t matter how reliable the mechanisms involved are. Of course, it is immaterial whether the engineer that designed M is a human being, or a Martian, or the invisible hand of evolution.
     No matter how perfectly a physical system simulates thought, that system doesn’t think unless what drives the relevant sequences of states are their representational properties. It doesn’t matter whether the system is natural or artificial, whether it is the product of artifice or evolution.    
 
Part IV.  A compelling objection to our position is found in Jerry Fodor’s work:
 
 
 
[109]
    (CTM*) Let b1…bn be an arbitrary sequence of brain-states. You say that, if b1…bn is to constitute a rational thought-process – indeed, if it is to constitute a thought-process at all – then a condition more or less like this must be fulfilled:
 
 
 
(#) for each i, bi’s having such and such representational content must be what brings about later entries in that series. It isn’t enough that bi do so.
 
 
 
  
    But this simply isn’t true. For the sake of argument, suppose that the condition described by (#) is not met. In other words, the sequence b1…bn is not driven by those states’ having such and such representational contents. Suppose that sequence is driven by the non-representational properties of the brain-states involved. Let us go further. Suppose that sequence is driven entirely by the forms, the morphologies, of those brain-states. In that case, we have a purely form-driven sequence of representations: a purely formal operation.
     We know that computations are entirely form-driven operations. No consideration of meaning is involved. A computation is a kind of inference: a formal-inference. An inference is a thought-process. So for b1…bn to constitute a thought-process, it is not necessary that b1’s having such and such representational content have any causal role in brining about b2. It is necessary only that b1’s formal -- its syntactico-morphological properties -be involved in the right way.
    So, in direct contradiction to what you say, the causal effectiveness of semantics (representational content) is not a necessary condition for the
[110]
existence of thought-processes. The very existence of computations – of purely formal thought processes -- shows as much.
     A calculator is an environment in which representations follow one another in ways that are consistent with the demands of rationality. Further the behavior of a calculator is entirely form-driven: semantics plays no part. Syntax alone is operative – and syntax is all that is needed. So calculators do engage in formal thought and, therefore, in thought of some kind.
    
   
 
 
           (CTM*) involves a confusion of two radically different meanings of the term “form”. Once this confusion is exposed, the argument in question collapses.
[111]       The confusion is that between syntactic form and physical form. These are two entirely different things. A form-driven operation is a computation only if the form in question is syntactic form. Physical form won’t do. But a syntax-driven operation is a semantics-driven operation, contrary to what is generally thought. So, contrary to what CTM* says,  if b1…bn is to constitute a thought-process – whether “formal” or “informal” – it is de rigueur that bi’s having such and such representational content be causally effective in bringing about later entries in that series.
       In order to clarify the relevant issues, it will help if we momentarily leave aside brain-states, and instead discuss sentences. In due course, we will map what we say back onto brain-states.
      First of all, sentences don’t have physical form. The sentence “snow is white” is an abstract object. It can be instantiated by sounds, by inscriptions on a piece of paper, by hand-signals, or by smoke-signals. Tokens of that sentence have physical form. But the sentence per se does not.       Notice that tokens of that sentence can have very different physical forms. In terms of its physical form, a stream of sound has very little in common with a series of hand-movements or an inscription on a piece of paper. Even if we confine ourselves to written tokens of that sentence, any two tokens can have radically different forms. SNOW IS WHITE and snow is white have quite different physical forms.
      But any two tokens of “snow is white” have the same syntactic form. A spoken token of that sentence has the same syntactic form as any written token of it. SNOW IS WHITE and snow is white both have the same syntactic form. They consist of a noun, followed by a one place-predicate.       It is clear what physical form is. The physical form of a sentence token is its shape – its “morphology”. Obviously the syntactic form of a sentencetoken isn’t its morphology, since syntactically identical sentence tokens can have virtually no morphological properties in common (consider a pattern of hand-signals and a series of sounds). So what is syntactic form?
    The syntactic form of a sentence is a function of the more generic facts about its semantics. Consider the following two sentences:
 

	* “Jerry is a genius, and all geniuses smoke cigarettes.”
 

	* “Philmore is a moron, and all morons eat automobiles.”
 
These sentences are said to have the same syntactic form, namely:
 

	* so and so is a phi, and all phi’s stand in relation R to psi’s.
 
     (a) has (c) for its form because the constituents of (a) have certain semantic properties. “Jerry” is a singular term, “is a genius” is a predicate of some kind, “all” is a certain kind of quantifier (roughly, it denotes a certain quantity), “smoke” denotes a two-place relation, and that “cigarettes” is a noun of some kind. (a)’s syntactic structure is a reflection of its semantics. Exactly similar remarks apply to (b). (a) and (b) are syntactically the same because their semantic profiles are relevantly similar.
      Nothing about semantics, or therefore about syntax, can be read off of the purely morphological facts about (a). A brilliant Martian who saw a token of (a) would have no reason to believe that (a) had (c) for its form. He would have no reason to believe such a thing until he knew that “Jerry” was a singular term, that “is a genius” is a predicate, and so forth. Morphology to no degree fixes semantics or, therefore, syntax. So, by itself, sensitivity to morphology does not qualify as sensitivity to semantics or, therefore, to syntax. If the term “form” is taken to denote morphology, then a purely “formal” operation is not a syntax-driven process. If the term “form” is taken to denote syntax, then a purely “formal” operation involves sensitivity to semantics. So contrary to what CTM* says, purely “formal” inferences are semantics-driven.
      In this connection, it is worth bringing up a development in semantics.
Until recently, the standard view is that syntax-defining terms e.g. “not”,
“all”, and “for some”, do not denote anything. This is quite possibly false.
Consider the sentence
 

	* “snow is not white”.
 
This is equivalent to
 
[112]

	* “the sequence <snow is white> is such that its one member is false.”
 
So the “not” in (1) is a second-level predicate; it picks out a property had by
[113]
	sequences of propositions (or propositional functions). So “not” picks out the property of being such that its sole member is false. The same is true of  “and”. Consider the sentence
 

	* “snow is white and grass is green”.
 
This is equivalent to
 

	* “the sequence <snow is white, grass is green> is such that both itsmembers are true.
 
The “and” that occurs in (3) is converted, so to speak, into the predicate “is such that both its members are true.” So, in effect, “and” picks out the property of having two true members. Exactly similar remarks apply to “for some”, “for all”, “or”, and so on. So-called formal truth does turn on semantics; it turns on what is picked out by “and”, “or”, and the like. “Snow is white and grass is green” has a different syntax from “snow is white or grass is green”, but only because what “and” picks out is different from what “or” picks out. Sensitivity to semantics is needed to register the syntactic, and logical, differences between those sentences. In general, syntactic differences turn out to be semantic; and syntactic differences are no more a matter of morphology than are any other semantic differences.
     Consider the following sentence-token
 

	* “Cornelius III is a pusillanimous ambulatory psychotic.”
 
If that sentence is true, then so is
 

	* “Cornelius III is pusillanimous.”
 
  
   But for every language in which the transition from (A) to (B) is logical, there are infinitely many in which it is illogical. There are infinitely many possible languages in which tokens morphologically identical with (A) mean aardvarks never play checkers and in which tokens morphologically identical with (B) mean aardvarks always play checkers.
    By itself, morphology doesn’t impose any constraints at all on logical form. So if we take into account only the morphologies of (A) and (B), and leave aside facts about their semantics, then (depending on one’s views on the arithmetic of infinite quantities) the chances of the transition from (A) to (B) being logic-tracking are either vanishingly close to zero or they are no better than 50%. Given that (A) and (B) have certain semantic profiles, it follows that the transition in question is logic-tracking. So given the operative semantic background, that transition is logical. But from the viewpoint of a purely morphology-driven being, that semantic background is non-existent. So such a being would not be acting logically in transitioning from (A) to
(B).
    Here is a widely held position. 
 
   Semantics can be “mirrored” in syntax. Thus, semantic relations like that of logical consequence are capable of a purely syntactic characterization. Syntactical facts are, in their turn, capable of a purely morphological characterization. Because of this, it is possible for purely morphology-driven operations to constitute logic-driven operations. Thus thought can be
[114] “mechanized” – it can be “morphologized”.
 
 
     There are two points to make here. First, in light of recent work in semantics, it is pretty clear that logical form cannot be adequately mirrored in syntactic form. So even if syntactical facts were capable of a purely morphological characterization, it would not follow that logical form was capable of such a characterization. Second, and more importantly, even if logical form could be perfectly mirrored in morphology, that would be irrelevant to the prospect of “morphologizing” (or otherwise “mechanizing”) thought.   
   Let us start with the second point. In English, sentences that seem to have the same syntax may diverge in logical form. “Bill is a green duck, therefore Bill is duck” is valid; “Bill is a decoy duck, therefore Bill is a duck” is not valid. For this reason, we are told that, in natural languages, syntactic identities conceal differences in logical form: in English, a given syntactic form can (supposedly) be associated with different logical forms, and there is
[115]
thus no function from syntactic form to logical form. 
     To simplify discussion, let us focus on languages in which this divergence of logical and syntactical form doesn’t occur. For the sake of argument, suppose that, in some language L, syntactic facts adequately reflect facts about logical form. So, in L, there a function from logical to syntactical form.      For the sake of argument, let us further suppose that, in L, there is a purely morphological characterization of  syntactic form. There is a function from the morphologies of L sentences to their logical forms.
    L is thus the kind of language that logicians dream about. In L, there is a purely syntactic characterization of logical form, and also a purely morphological characterization of syntactic form. In L, there is therefore a purely morphological characterization of logical form.
     Here is where matters become problematic. Any morphological characterization of  logical form will be relative to a language and, thus, to a semantic system. Let S1 and S2 be two sentence-tokens of L such that S1 entails S2. To fix our ideas, let us suppose that, in L, S1 means grass is green and S2 means something is green. In L, a sequence consisting of S1 followed by S2 is logic-tracking, and, for the reasons described a moment ago, that fact will be reflected in the morphology of that sequence. (Let S1-S2 be our shorthand for that sequence.)
    But there are infinitely many languages such that, relative to any one of them, a sequence morphologically identical with S1-S2 is logically false or altogether meaningless. Let L* be any such language. The difference between a case where that transition is logical and one where it isn’t has to do entirely with the background semantics. If L is operative, the transition is logictracking. If L* is operative, that transition is not logic-tracking.
    By itself, the morphology involved is as consistent with the operation’s being fallacious (or nonsensical) as it is with that operation’s being logictracking. The difference between a sequence that tracks logic and one that doesn’t lies in the semantics involved. If the right semantic background is absent, it doesn’t matter if S1 leads to S2.   What must be operative, therefore, is S1’s having a certain semantics or representational content. The sequence S1-S2 is logical relative to L, but illogical relative to infinitely many other languages. Given only the morphology of that sequence, it is just as much an expression of L* as it is of L. If that sequence is to constitute an expression of L, that means It is not enough that S1 cause S2. If the sequence S1-S2 is to be logic-tracking, that means that a certain semantic system – a certain assignment of meanings to S1 and S2 – must be operative. So if S1-S2 is to be logic-tracking, it is necessary that S1’s having a certain semantics be operative.
      
closing the argument
 
      Let us sum up. Let B1 be a physical-state realizing a belief that P and let B2 be a physical-state realizing a thought that Q. If the sequence B1-B2 is to constitute a thought-process, it is not enough that B2 cause B2 via a reliable mechanism. It is necessary also that B1’s having representational content be causally involved. When content is inert, there is no thought.
    (CTM*) responds to this by saying:
 
   “False! B1’s having that representational content needn’t be causally involved. The sequence B1-B2 could be a purely form-driven – a purely morphology-driven – operation; and in that case, it would qualify as a formalinference, and thus as a cognitive achievement. After all, a formal-inference is one that is not driven by anything’s having such and such representational content. So even if B1’s having a certain representational content is completely inert, the sequence B1-B2 can qualify as a formal inference (a computation).”
 
   But a so-called formal inference is semantics-driven. If the sequence B1-B2 is to constitute a formal inference, B1’s having such and such representational content absolutely must be involved. Otherwise we don’t have anything logic-evaluable. Indeed, we don’t have a thought-process at all.

Davidson’s Misconceptions about Rationality
 
 
Abstract:  Alan Turing advocated a kind of functionalism: A machine M is a thinker provided that it responds in certain ways to certain inputs. Davidson argues that Turing’s functionalism is inconsistent with a certain kind of epistemic externalism, and is therefore false. In Davidson’s view, concepts consist of causal liasons of a certain kind between subject and object. Turing’s machine doesn’t have the right kinds of causal liasons to its environment. Therefore it doesn’t have concepts. Therefore it doesn’t think. I argue that this reasoning is entirely fallacious. It is true that, in some cases, a causal liason between oneself and an object is part of one’s concept of that object. Consequently, to grasp certain propositions, one must have certain kinds of causal ties to one’s environment.  But this means, at most, that we must rethink some old views on what rationality is. It does not mean, pace Davidson, that a precondition for being rational is being causally embedded in one’s environment in a certain way. If Turing’s machine isn’t capable of thinking (I leave it open whether it is or is not), that has nothing to do with its lacking certain kinds of causal connections to the environment. The larger significance of our discussion is this: rationality consists either in one’s ability to see the bearing of purely existential propositions on one another or rationality is simply not to be understood as the ability see the bearing that propositions have on one another.
 
1.   In this paper, I’d like to make a narrow point and a broad point. The narrow point is that what Donald Davidson says about Turing machines – specifically, his argument for holding that they don’t think – doesn’t go
[116]
	through. The broad point is: Given that these reasons of Davidson’s don’t go through,  there is some  reason to believe that one of the following two claims holds.
 

	* Intelligence is not to be understood as the ability to see the bearing that propositions have on other propositions.
 

	* Intelligence is to be defined as the ability to see the bearing of purely existential propositions on other purely existential propositions.
 
    Of course, (a) and (b) cannot both hold.
 
2.     First some background. Putnam showed that one’s concepts of objects – one’s abilities to have thoughts about objects -- often have a causal component. At least a part of one’s concept of water or of Bob consists in there being some kind of causal connection between oneself and those things. [117]
     Putnam showed this through thought-experiments like this one. Twin-John and John are molecule for molecule duplicates of each other. So John and Twin-John are exactly alike leaving aside facts about the (distal) causes of their conditions. Given this, suppose that John has a visual sensation that is caused by Bob, and that twin-John has a qualitatively identical visual sensation that is caused by twin-Bob. John is perceiving Bob, not twin-Bob. And twin-John is perceiving twin-Bob, not Bob. From his perception, John thus ‘uploads’ a concept of Bob, not of twin-Bob. And from his perception,
[118]
twin-John uploads a concept of twin-Bob, and not of Bob.
   The fact that John has a concept of Bob, and not twin-Bob, derives from the fact that John has a causal connection to Bob that he doesn’t have to twinBob. And the same thing mutatis mutandis explains why twin-John has a concept of twin-Bob, and not of Bob.
     Thus John has thoughts about Bob in virtue of (at least in part) his having a certain causal connection to Bob. Thus John’s concept of Bob – his ability to have thoughts about Bob – consists, at least in part, in his having a certain causal connection to Bob. (The same thing is true mutatis mutandis of twinJohn and twin-Bob.) In this way, Putnam (successfully) shows that a causal connection to an object may be, at the very least, a part of one’s concept of that object. 
    In many publications, Jerry Fodor says our concepts of objects consist in
[119]
	causal relations of a certain kind between ourselves and objects. As
[120]
	we’ll see in a moment, Donald Davidson takes the same view.   
     I now want to show that this view of Davidson’s seriously lead him astray in his analysis of a famous problem posed by Alan Turing.
 
3.      Turing posed the following problem. Let M be some machine, and suppose that M  responds to inputs in exactly the way that a thinking being
[121]
	would respond to those inputs. So if you say to M ‘should we go back to the gold-standard?’ or ‘what did you think of the game last night?’, M gives you just the kind of answer that a cognitively normal human gives you. And, of course, the same is true for any other question or assertion that you might direct to M. Turing asks: under that circumstance, does M qualify as a thinker? Turing’s implicit answer is ‘yes’.
    Turing is not, I think, making an epistemological point. He is not saying that, since there is as much data to support the view that the machine is thinking as there is to support the view that the person is thinking, there is good reason to hold that the machine thinks; he is not saying the machine’s behavior is merely evidence of thought. (For it is obvious and trivial to say that if M acts just like a person that is evidence – though, perhaps, defeasible evidence -- that he has the mental capacities of a person.). Turing is saying, it seems, that if the machine behaves indistinguishably from the thinking person, then ipso facto the machine is a thinker.
    Davidson thinks that Turing is wrong. Now I myself agree with Davidson that Turing is wrong; I don’t think that M thinks. (More specifically, I don’t think that M qualifies as a thinker merely in virtue of behaving in the right way in response to certain inputs. M might qualify as a thinker for some other reason.) But my purpose here is not to discuss whether Turing is right or wrong. It is to discuss Davidson’s criticisms of Turing. I submit that Davidson has given us no reason to think Turing wrong.
 
4.     Davidson’s criticism is this. Let John be some normal human being whose thoughts, and therefore whose sentence-tokenings, are causally ‘hooked up’ to external objects in the right kind of way. So John has de re thoughts about Bush, Socrates, light and water; and he expresses these when uses sentences containing the terms ‘Bush’, ‘Socrates’, etc.
      Now let us suppose that we assemble some being that behaves just like John in terms its verbal and behavioral responses to inputs – externally, it responds in the same way as John to the sound ‘was Plato more conservative than Aristotle?’ and ‘is there an even prime?’ Let Robo-John be this artificial John-proxy. Of course John actually means Plato by ‘Plato’, actually means water by ‘water’, and so on. This is not (merely) because John is possessed of some mysterious subjectivity or mentality; it is (at least in part) because John is causally connected in the right kind of way to Plato and water, and his verbal behavior derives from this connectedness. John’s current psychological condition is the fall-out, at least in part, of his being embedded in a certain physical environment in a certain way: and it is this embeddedness which enables him to think about Plato and thus to mean Plato by ‘Plato’. This, in effect, is what we learn from the Putnamian thought experiment described above.
    Now Robo-John was put together in some laboratory; so his psychological condition is an artifact; it is definitely not the fall-out, even in part, of his being embedded in a certain environment in a certain way. (Of course, one might say: ‘well, the scientists who put Robo-John together knew about Plato and water, and so on, and their ability to thinks about things was incorporated into Robo-John.’ But we can easily side-step this complication by supposing that Robo-John wasn’t created in a laboratory, but rather came together as a
[122]
	result of a sandstorm or some random quantum event.) In any case, his relation to his environment is definitely not such as to underwrite his having concepts of Plato or water. So Robo-John just cannot think about Plato or water or Bush. He acts just like John; and he says (or rather mouths) the same things. But when he says ‘Plato was wise’, he isn’t referring to Plato. He is shooting a blank; he cannot mean Plato by ‘Plato’, for he hasn’t got the right causal connection to the man. And, Davidson says, this point applies mutatis mutandis to anything else Robo-John says or does.
    Davidson concludes that Robo-John does not think: for he hasn’t got the causal connections to his environment to underwrite the having of the concepts needed to think. Thus, even though Robo-John is indistinguishable
(externally) from John, Robo-John doesn’t think, while John does think. And Turing is therefore wrong.
 
5.    Again I agree with Davidson that Turing is wrong. But Davidson’s argument has little force against Turing. A brain in a vat cannot think about
[123]
	Socrates or about water. But it can still think.  When you dream about unicorns and goblins, your dream-images are images of nothing; and the
[124]
	narrative of your dream represents nothing real. But in dreaming – in experiencing this play of dream images – you are still thinking. Whatever the line is between thinking and non-thinking beings – between being a rock and being a being a Shakespeare --  you are, in dreaming, well on the right side of it. Obviously a brain in a vat can dream. What it cannot do is have thoughts that are object-involving with respect to Socrates or water. But clearly something mental – indeed, something cognitive --  can still go on in it.       Turing’s machine may or may not be thinker: I leave it open whether it is. But if it isn’t a thinker, that has nothing to do with its lacking the right kinds of causal connections. The fact that there are certain things Turing’s machine cannot think about – e.g. Socrates – has to do with its not having the right causal connections. But if Turing’s machine cannot think at all, that is not to be explained by saying that it doesn’t have the right causal connections. What led Davidson astray here is his holding that concepts consist in causal connections with the external world, rather than merely involving them.
  
6.  Of course, the following objection will be made:
 
   To think is to entertain propositions or, at any rate, is to handle information. Turing’s machine – and its cousins: the subject of a Cartesian nightmare, the brain in a vat – just cannot grasp things; it can’t grasp the constituents of propositions (water, Plato, redness….). Therefore it can’t grasp propositions, and thus cannot think at all.
 
  There are a number of things to say in response to this. First of all, when you dream of griffins or unicorns, it certainly seems that you are grasping a great many existential propositions, even though you are not grasping any object-involving ones. Suppose you are dreaming of a non-existent pink elephant. Now given somebody who was in a phenomenologically identical state who was causally connected to a pink elephant in a certain way, that
[125]
person would 	be grasping an object-dependent proposition that you are not. In the cognitive ‘place’, to so speak, where that person is grasping an
[126]
	object-dependent proposition, you are grasping nothing. But you are still grasping various existential propositions: there is a four-legged creature moving about in such and a such a way…      Now one might counter-respond by saying:
 
   The constituents of these existential propositions are such that your grasping them consists, at least in part, in your standing in certain causal relations to the external world. Consider, for example, the existential proposition: there is a four-legged creature moving about…Surely your concept of a leg is an object-involving one, the same being true of concept of a creature and perhaps even of your concept of movement. Indeed, So once you take away all of a causal liaisons, you take away its ability to entertain even existential propositions like there is a four-legged creature.
 
   I find this highly dubious. A brain in a vat, it seems to me, has a concept of a leg, of a creature, of movement, as much as anyone else, notwithstanding that the kinds of connections it has to the outer world don’t sustain de re
[127]
awareness of any of its constituents. 
   Suppose you discovered – let us set aside, as irrelevant, how you discover this – that you are a brain in a vat. Your Plato-concept will thus turn out to be empty, and so will your Nathan Salmon-concept. But your leg-concept? Your movement-concept? Would you then think to yourself: “Gosh, I guess my leg-concepto turned out to be empty after all, just like my Socrates-concept”?
No – leg is a functionally defined concept. You don’t have to be causally connected to an actual leg to grasp the concept of a leg; you just have to know what functional role legs have. And it is very hard to see how your brain-twin could lack such knowledge.
 

	1. What is true of one’s concept of Plato or of water seems not to apply to all of one’s other concepts, but only some of them. Suppose there is a brain in a vat that is just like your brain modulo those properties of you (and your brain) that supervene on your not being a brain in a vat. Further, suppose that, one day, you put that brain in a body – so it can speak, move, and so forth. That creature will produce sounds like ‘that creature is moving rather quickly’. Is that creature really ‘shooting blanks’ when it says such things? To be sure, where attempts to make certain statements are concerned, it will be shooting blanks. If it says ‘Socrates drank hemlock’ it will not mean by that sentence what you and I mean by it.  But a disembodied brain in a vat can have an appreciation of what it is for an object to move from one place to another, of what sentience is, of what a leg does for a sentient creature.      Also that creature would surely have just as much a grip on mathematical and purely rational truths as you. It would be nonsense to say that, in virtue of the fact that you had certain causal liaisons to the external environment, you were a better mathematician than your recently embodied brain-twin.
 

	1. There is no denying that the behavior of the recently embodied braintwin is replete with mentality. And it is hard to deny that some of this mentality is cognitive and involves intelligence. Surely your brain-twin is not stupid; he is obviously not in the same category as something inanimate. Surely it is as intelligent as you, notwithstanding that it doesn’t have a grasp of Plato or Socrates.
    But suppose that, despite all this, someone taking Davidson’s line digs in his heels and insists that one cannot grasp any propositions without having certain kinds of causal liaisons to one’s environment – without being (or having been) embedded in a certain physical environment in a certain way. (The idea would be, perhaps, that such causal liaisons so totally infect our cognitive lives that nothing proposition-bearing would be left over if one were stripped of these liaisons.)
    I would suggest that, if that is really the case – and maybe it is -- then we must define intelligence not in terms of seeing relations among propositions, but in some other way. For it seems to me quite obvious that a brain in a vat and the victim of a Cartesian nightmare can have all the intelligence in the world; Einstein’s disembodied brain-twin is surely not stupid, even though he will shoot a lot of conceptual blanks. In other word, where the real Einstein -who is appropriately embedded in a physical and social environment --will be entertaining various object-dependent thoughts, Einstein’s brain-twin will (at least according to Evans) be entertaining thought-like things that have gaps in them, due to its lacking the right causal connections to the outside world. But in virtue of having these pseudo-thoughts, or “empty” thoughts, Einstein’s brain-twin still obviously has intelligence. Einstein’s brain-twin is not stupid: it is obviously not in the same category as a rock or a cactus.
     So if one needs to be embedded in a physical environment in a certain way to grasp any propositions at all, then what that means is that intelligence, and cognitive capacity, are not to be defined in terms of proposition-manipulating ability. It doesn’t mean that a thing, like Turing’s machine, which is not appropriately embedded fails to think.
 

	1. It is, of course, strange to say that intelligence consists in somethingother than the ability to the bearing that propositions have on other propositions But such a view is not without a foundation; it is, I think, the distillation of epistemic externalism.
  Kripke (1977) made a very compelling case that one can assent to a proposition and to its negation without being irrational. Pierre believes the proposition expressed by ‘London is not lovely’ and also that expressed by ‘London est jolie’. And this is not because Pierre lacks acumen. It isn’t that he has failed to deduce some proposition from some other proposition that he accepts. Pierre is not irrational; he isn’t even guilty of logical laziness – of not making the right inferences from what he already knows. (If we stipulated that Pierre was logically omniscient, he would still be in the predicament that Kripke describes.) One lesson that might be drawn from this is: rationality (intelligence) is not to be defined in terms of what one does with the propositions one grasps. This has a certain similarity to the idea that intelligence (rationality) is not be defined in terms of propositionmanipulating ability.
     Actually it seems that this last point – intelligence is not to be defined as the ability to manipulate propositions – is, in some respect, the essence of externalism.
        In any case, it seems plain that a disembodied brain in a vat can have plenty of intelligence, even though it has no de re awareness of anything external, and is therefore incapable of grasping many propositions that you and I can grasp. So if Turing’s machine lacks intelligence, that is not because it doesn’t have right kind of causal connection to the outside world; it would be for some totally different reason. Its lack of causal connections deprives it of certain concepts but not of intelligence. So Davidson’ has by no means proven that Turing’s machine cannot think; for given only what Davidson says, it is still an open question whether Turing’s machine is intelligent. Thus Davidson’s attack on Turing is misguided.    
 

	* I should qualify something said earlier. We’ve seen that Davidson’sattack on Turing doesn’t go through. We’ve also seen that this fact gives some credence to a conception of intelligence (or rationality) that is different from the traditional one. (The traditional one is: intelligence consists in some kind of proposition-manipulating ability.) But the spuriousness of Davidson’s attack by no means proves that intelligence is not to be thought of the traditional way. As I suggested earlier, whenever one is grasping some object-dependent proposition, one is also, it seems, grasping many existential propositions. When I see Toonces the cat chasing Fido the dog, I am aware of some object-dependent fact, namely Toonces is chasing Fido. But necessarily involved in this grasp is a grasp of various existential propositions.
