But, judging by his examples, he wrongly took the uniquely individuating descriptions in question to be historically momentous ones: the guy who invented the theory of forms and drank hemlock. He was wrong about the nature of those uniquely individuating description, but right, apparently, that one must have some uniquely
[215]
	individuating description. 
     So be able to think about and refer to Einstein, it is necessary to have some uniquely individuating description of the man. But that uniquely individuating description may be of no historical moment; it may be, and probably is, something like: the guy who so and so was talking about on such and such occasion…That is why one can be so wrong about what Einstein did – about whether he invented the atom bomb, for example – and still refer to and think about Einstein.
     Notice, also, that this account involves a causal connection between Socrates and between people today who think about and refer to him. In other words, the account we’ve given is a causal account, even though it is also a descriptivist account. Larry sees Socrates: obviously there is a causal connection there. And that is how Larry gets his uniquely individuating description of Socrates. Fred sees or hears Larry refer to Socrates on some particular occasion: obviously there is a causal connection there. And so on, until this chain reaches you. So you are causally connected to Socrates: and it is this causal connection that enables you to refer to and think about Socrates. But this causal connection is embedded in various uniquely individuating descriptions (or perhaps it would be better to say that these uniquely individuating descriptions are embedded in it).
  
§ Clearly not just any causal connection between a person and a thing enables that person to refer to that thing. The causal connection operates by way of some conception. I am directly causally connected to many individual atoms (which bounce off many surfaces). But given some one of those atoms – call it “Alpha” – can I refer to Alpha? Is my being hit by Alpha enough for me to refer to it? It seems not. I have to have some way of singling out Alpha in thought. That way of singling out Alpha may – indeed probably will –exploit my causal connection to Alpha. But it is not the causal connection by itself that enables me to think about or refer to Alpha. It is some conception which (probably) uses that causal connection.
 
§     These points map onto – and derive considerable support from – the case of sense-perception. To see the sun, I must indeed be causally connected to the sun. But how does that causal connection give me cognitive (visual) access to the sun? It cognitively connects to the sun through the indexicals in a certain piece of existential-descriptive information. You don’t just see the sun; you see a total situation involving the sun. Your visual perception “says”: that [indicating the sun] is an object with such and such properties (it is luminescent…)…Or: over there [indicating a certain place, above the horizon perhaps] is a luminescent object… The “that” and the “there” obviously involve a causal connection. And they connect you, cognitively, to the object. But they operate in the context of an informational-tableau that gives you a uniquely individuating description  of the sun. The uniquely individuating description  will be something like: the unique luminescent object there…Or: the unique luminescent celestial body I am now attending to…
    All perception is “predicational”, as Barry Stroud (2001) says. You don’t just see Fido. You see a thing with such and such properties….The content
[216]
	of your perception is not given by a noun, but by an existence-claim:
[217]
	over there, there is a four-legged furry… It would be impossible to see something as being property-less. Any situation visually represented is represented as having properties. So the content of your perception is not just some thing – it is not just the sun or Fido or Dad. What is represented to you is a situation having various properties. When you do what we call “seeing the sun”, what you see doesn’t correspond to the noun-phrase “the sun”; it corresponds more closely to a whole sentence: there is a bright orb over
[218]
yonder…
     Of course, you can see the sun only if you are causally connected to it. But the causal connection operates within a uniquely individuating description : it is a part of a uniquely individuating description. The content of your perception of the sun is at least in part, given by existential information: there is a bright orb over there (in that region)…Said information has an indexical-component (or, more accurately, a linguistic representation of it would have such a component), corresponding to the “over there, in that region”. The causal connection between yourself and the sun is represented in the presence of this indexical component.  So the causal theory of perception (“I see the sun because I am causally connected to it”) and what we might call the “descriptivist” theory of perception (“I see the sun because my visual state encodes a description that applies to the sun”) are by no means incompatible: they are both true. And the same is true of the relationship between the causal theory of reference (“I can refer to Socrates because I have a certain causal connection to the man”) and the descriptivist theory of reference (“I can refer to Socrates because I know of a description that singles him out”). They are not incompatible; they supplement each other; they are two parts of a single true story. [219]
   
§ Now we can return from the steamy jungles of epistemology to the cool waters of semantics. Given what Kripke argued (not to mention Putnam,
Soames, and others), it seems pretty likely that *Hesperus has phi* has for its literal meaning the proposition: Hesperus has phi. But nobody will deny that 
[220] 	*Hesperus has phi* and *Phosphorous has phi* have (or may have) very different cognitive values. Some have reacted to this latter fact by trying to come up with a new and better form of descriptivism. But given what we said a moment ago, I don’t think such a drastic measure need be taken.     We saw that (notwithstanding what is, or seems to be, alleged in Naming and Necessity) in order to know what is meant by “Socrates”, one does have to know some existence of the claim of the form: something x uniquely has phi, and “Socrates” refers to x. Now when you hear a sentence-token, you don’t automatically know its meaning. In principle, one can hear the sound without knowing the meaning. (This would happen if you didn’t speak the relevant language or if you had sustained brain-damage of a certain kind.) You must make your way from the sound to the meaning. You can’t do that in a vacuum; you have to exploit your background knowledge. As we saw, if you know what (to switch examples) “Hesperus” refers to, it is by way of some existence claim, which might be something like:
 
(#H)  yesterday  there was a unique star x such that I was gazing at x and x alone remained in the morning sky after all the others had disappeared; moreover “Hesperus” names x.
 
  If you are to understand an utterance that you hear of *Hesperus has phi*, you have to hook up that token of “Hesperus” with the right referent. And to do that, you have to exploit the existence claim that embodies your knowledge of what it refers to. So to assign the right referent to “Hesperus”, you have to work through some existence claim like (#): that existence claim (or some other) is your only lead. So even though what *Hesperus has phi* literally means is simply Venus has phi, nonetheless you can assign it the right meaning only via (#). So what “Hesperus is lovely” ends up imparting to you is some descriptively rich existential proposition:
 
(#HL) yesterday  there was a unique star x such that I was gazing at x and x alone remained in the morning sky after all the other stars  had disappeared; moreover “Hesperus” names x; and x is lovely.
 
    For exactly similar reasons, what “Phosphorous is lovely” conveys to you will be something like:
 
(#PL) yesterday  there was a unique star x such that I was gazing at x and x alone appeared in the evening sky before all the other stars; moreover “Phosphorous” names x; and x is lovely.
 
So even though “Phosphorous  is lovely”  has for its literal meaning some descriptively impoverished singular proposition (Venus is lovely), nonetheless what it conveys to you – thanks to the descriptive information through which you assign it the right meaning – is some descriptively rich existence claim. It is clear why, given these principles,
“Hesperus=Phosphorous” will communicate a complicated existence claim, even though what it literally means is some bare identity.
 
§   This analysis is on the right side of Kripke’s powerful modal and semantic points. Consider the sentence:
 
(*) “Hesperus is the last star to disappear from the morning sky.”
 
Kripke makes the (correct) point that (*) is not analytic. “Hesperus is  not the last star to disappear from the morning sky” is not self-contradictory.    Our analysis is consistent with this. Let us suppose, once again, that the proposition through which you assign “Hesperus” to Hesperus (Venus) is this:
 
(#H)  yesterday  there was a unique star x such that I was gazing at x and x alone remained in the morning sky after all the others had disappeared; moreover “Hesperus” names x.
 
Notice that “Hesperus” gets narrow-scope with respect to the descriptive information. Nothing – no descriptive information, no Fregean sense – comes between Hesperus names and the thing named. To use Kripke’s important distinction, the descriptive information has a “reference-fixing” but not a “meaning-giving” role. So you know that “Hesperus” is just a name, and not a description, and that all it does is to label a certain thing. So on our analysis (*) is not analytic – at the level of literal meaning, it encodes a proposition of the form O the last star to disappear from the morning sky. It does not encode a proposition of the form the last star to disappear from the morning sky is the last star to disappear from the morning sky. 
   Further, on our analysis, you know that (*) is not analytic: you have the right intuition about this. You assign “Hesperus” to Hesperus by way of your knowledge of (#H). In that proposition, the descriptive information is given “wide-scope”. So you know that no descriptive information comes between “Hesperus” and the thing it labels; you know that “Hesperus” is just a label, and not a description. So you know that (*) is not analytic. So you have the right intuitions where the modal status of the sentence is concerned.     In connection with this, our analysis is consistent with the fact that you also have the right intuitions about the modal status of the proposition meant by (*) and also about the modal properties of the thing named by “Hesperus”. Suppose that the (#H) is the proposition through which you affix “Hesperus” to right entity. In knowing (#H),  you know that “Hesperus” names the celestial body which in fact disappears from the morning sky after any other. But you will believe that the thing which “Hesperus” names had to have that property. In virtue of knowing (#H), you know that something x in fact is a celestial body that disappears after all others from the morning sky. Your knowledge of (#H) is not knowledge to the effect that something had to have that property. That knowledge is consistent with the position that the thing which in fact had that property might not have had it at all. For any object x having that property, your knowledge of (#H) is consistent with your believing the truth of the proposition x might not have been a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky.  Put in positive terms, for any object x, your believing (#H) is consistent with your believing the proposition x might not have been a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky.    Another example might be appropriate. Suppose you believe the proposition
 
(**)  “Benjamin Franklin” names the unique person x who in fact invented bifocals.
 
There is no object x such that, in virtue of believing (**) to be true, you believe that x had to invent bifocals. Put in positive terms, for any object x, your believing (**) is consistent with your believing the proposition x did not have to invent bifocals – x might have done something else with his life. So our descriptivist account of conception does not saddle anyone with the wrong modal intuitions about propositions or objects.
     On our descriptivist account, you do indeed think of Hesperus (Venus) by way of some descriptive proposition. But you still have the right modal intuitions. This is because your concept of Venus consists in knowledge of a proposition of the form something x in fact has phi: it does not consist in knowledge of a proposition of the form something x necessarily has phi.        One other point should be made explicit. On our account, it is necessary that you think of Hesperus by way of some claim of the form something x uniquely has phi. But there is no one proposition of that form such that you must think of Hesperus by way of that particular proposition. On the contrary, it is essential to our analysis that it be possible to think of Hesperus by way of different propositions of that form. That feature of our analysis is essential to our way of solving Frege’s puzzle. So our account does not by any means make it necessary that you think of Hesperus as the last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky. It allows that you can think of it through infinitely many different descriptions.
      That said, it might seem that there is still a sense in which our analysis is not modally innocuous. On our account, you think of an object O s by way of your knowledge of proposition  of the form something x uniquely  has phi, where phi is a property had by O. So, on our account, you think of Hesperus through some such proposition. Of course, our account allows that there are several such propositions. But, for the sake of argument, suppose that in your case, there is only one such proposition; and suppose it is:
 
(****) something x is  uniquely being  a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky. 
 
So on our account, when you think Hesperus has phi, you are really thinking:
 
(*****)  something x in fact has the property of uniquely being  a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky, and x has phi.
 
So what you think when you think Hesperus is lovely is:
 
something x in fact has the property of uniquely being  a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky, and x is lovely.
 
A special case of this principle is that, when you think
 

	* Hesperus is the last a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky,
 
what you are thinking is:
 

	* something x is  uniquely being  a last celestial body to disappear fromthe morning sky, and something y  is  uniquely being  a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky, and x=y.
 
 
  Here is the apparent problem for our analysis. The proposition:
 
(AN) Necessarily, Hesperus is uniquely a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky,
 
 is simply false, and nobody thinks otherwise. But what about (B)? At first glance, (B) looks like the kind of proposition that might be necessary. If that is the case, then our analysis is false.
  The truth is that our analysis does not put us on the wrong side of any modal facts.
    Let us consider the operator necessarily. This operator can combine in different ways with (B): more exactly, it can be given varying degrees of scope.
 
(B1) Necessarily:  something x is  uniquely a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky, and x is identical with a unique a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky.
 
(B2) Something x is  uniquely a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky, and necessarily: x is identical with a unique a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky.
 
 
(B1) and (B2) are simply false; and nobody would ever think otherwise. So in the relevant respects, they just like (AN). So our analysis does not turn true modal claims into false ones, or vice versa.
    Nonetheless, it might seem that our analysis has a peculiar consequence. We have said that you think of Hesperus through either (****) or through some other proposition of the same form. So it seems that, on our analysis, you must think of Hesperus a certain way: you must think of it as a last celestial body to disappear from the morning sky or a first celestial body to appear in the evening sky: in any case, you must think of it through some uniquely individuating description. But this seems wrong: for there doesn’t seem to be any that anyone has to think of Hesperus. For reasons we’ve seen, it seems that cognitively “locking onto” a thing O involves knowing some proposition of the form something x uniquyely has phi, where O has phi. But after that lock-on has been established, I don’t have to think about O by way of that proposition. I can drop the proposition. Suppose that I lock onto Sam by having a visual perception of him. In that case, as we saw, I do  lock onto Sam by way of some propostoin of the form of something x uniquyely has phi. In this case, that proposition might be somebody x is uniquely a person standing over there, at this time…or perhaps somebody x is uniquely a person whom I am focusing on at this time… So forging a concept of a Sam involves knowing some such propositoi. But once that concept has been forged, I can, and probably will, forget that proposition. Suppose Sam becomes a life-long acquaintance of mine. I will almost certainly not remember the proposition through which I initially locked onto him. So it seems that, after a certain point, the uniquely individudating proposition can simply be dropped: after which point, one has a “pure”, non-descriptive, object-tracking concept. So, after a certain point, one does not have to think of Sam (or anything else) by way of some descriptive proposition.  If that is right, then obviously our anslysis is false. After all, our analysis nearly enough just is the claim that conception is knowledge of some such description.
    Here is what I will argue. Any given descriptive proposition can be dropped, and probably will be. But at no point does concpetoin become “pure”. What happens is simply that one’s knowledge of the old proposition is replaced with knowledge of a new (but related) proposition. At any given point in the career of one’s concept of a thing, one’s ability to think about that thing consists in one’ s knowing some such proposition. But there is typically not some one such proposition such that, any any point in the career of one’s concept of a thing, one must think about that thing through that specific proposition. Let us now turn to this matter.
 
 
§     One can easily forget the information through which one first acquires a conception of an object. Indeed, this is what happens most of the time. I meet Sam in 1985. At that point, I am told: “that [pointing to some guy on the jungle gyms, wearing a hat with a propeller on it…] is Sam”. So it is indeed through some kind of existence claim that I hook up the name to the right person: there is some guy x who was just pointed out to me, and whom I am now  looking it, who is  over there on the jungle gyms, wearing a hat with a propeller on it…and “Sam” names x.  But it would be very easy for me to forget that “start-up” existence claim. In fact, with very few exceptions, I never remember those start-up claims; they drop out.
   This might be taken to show that, at some point, I acquire a “pure” conception of Sam: a conception that is no longer paved with knowledge of existential-descriptive information. So the idea would be this. Perhaps knowledge of a uniquely individuating description was needed to initiate the concept. But after that, it isn’t needed anymore.
     I think this is a big mistake. The “start-up” existential information certainly does drop out. I may not remember, even sub-consciously, the circumstances under which I met Sam. But this absolutely does not mean that, at any point, I have some kind of “pure” conception of him, i.e. one that is not paved with existential information. Indeed, if such “pure” conceptions were possible, it is hard to see how it could be possible for
Hesperus/Phosphorous cases to arise. But, I fully grant, the point in question definitely requires that we supplement our analysis.
    Suppose my first encounter with Sam is through existential information like: there is guy wearing a green shirt and a bowler hat, whom I am now (on occasion t) meeting and…and, consequently, that such information is, at least initially, implicated in my interpretetings of “Sam”.
   I meet Sam again, four days later. And I do so with knowledge: I recognize him. What is happening here? My recognizing him obviously doesn’t consist in my becoming aware of some bare identity; it doesn’t consist in its being the case, that for some object O, I suddenly become aware that O is identical with O. No doubt we do recognize the truth of such bare identities. But that is not what recognition consists in. Recognition is not so informationally impoverished.
   The story I would tell is this. I realize that there was some chap whom I met a few days earlier, on occasion t, who had such and such features (e.g. he was wearing a bowler hat)…and I also realize that, right now, on occasion t*, there is some chap, who has thus and such properties (e.g. he is wearing a baseball cap)…and I also realize that there is some one individual who uniquely satisfies both of these existential propositions.      Let E be the first existence claim, and let E* be the second.
     We see that recognizing a thing consists in seeing that some one thing uniquely satisfies each of two existence claims. This means that E -- the “start-up” existential information -- can be dropped.  My recognizing Sam involves my seeing that some one entity satisfies both E and E*. Having made this recognition, I am at liberty to drop E. My awareness of Sam will be sustained, for the time being, by my knowledge of E*. And, in its turn, E* may be dropped and replaced by a third existence claim.
    So what sustains a conception of an entity is knowledge of a series of interlocking  existence claims. Any given one of these claims may be dropped, and probably will be. But at any juncture in the career of one’s having a conception of a thing, that conception involves knowledge of an existence claim. And this point, as we’ve seen, enables us to account for the cognitive difference between “Hesperus is lovely” and “Phosphorous is
[221] 	lovely”.  
 
  
The nature of emotions in relation to the central question of meta-ethics
 
         
I.    Let us refer to sentences like ‘Stalin was evil’ and ‘murder is wrong’ as valuative sentences. By a ‘valuative’ sentence I mean one that expresses a moral attitude or sentiment. Different ways of analyzing such sentences have been proposed. In this paper I wish to show that two such analyses that are thought to be incompatible may in fact be compatible. More specifically, I will try to show that a doctrine known as ‘emotivism’ may be compatible with – may indeed be a certain kind of -- a doctrine known as ‘moral realism’ (or ‘realism’ for short). Emotivism, I will argue, is a kind of realism provided that a certain plausible thesis concerning the nature of emotions is accurate. I will provide some case for that thesis, though I will certainly not be able to establish it with anything approaching certainty.
      According to emotivism, statements like ‘Stalin was evil’ express emotions or emotionally laden attitudes towards objects or states of affairs. If you say ‘Stalin was evil’ you are expressing some kind of negative emotion
[222]
or attitude towards Stalin.
    According to realism, sentences like ‘Stalin was evil’ ascribe properties to objects. The sentence ‘Stalin was evil’ ascribes a property to Stalin, just like the sentence ‘Stalin was short’ and ‘Stalin was born in Tblisi.’ So ‘Stalin was evil’ is as much capable of truth or falsity as ‘2+2=4’ and ‘snow is green’. [223]
    It is generally taken for granted that emotivism and realism are
[224]
	incompatible. This viewpoint is correct, I will show, only if emotions are not beliefs. If emotions are beliefs, then emotivism is a form of realism.
Or so I will argue.
    For the record, I myself think that emotions are beliefs and that, consequently, emotivism is a form of realism. I also think that this position is in reasonably good accord with our pre-theoretical intuitions, even though it might seem at first to conflict with them. In any case, the view that emotions are beliefs or judgments is fairly widely held by philosophers of mind (though it is probably not a majority position), and its bearing on ethics should be investigated.
    A couple of disclaimers are in order. My argument works only if certain controversial, but highly plausible, assumptions are granted. These assumptions are not innocuous, and I will not be able to provide compelling arguments for them in such a short paper. But I will outline arguments for them, if only to show that they deserve some credence and that my ultimate destination – proving that emotivism may well be a form of realism – is one that might be legitimately arrived at. When I make use of one of these controversial assumptions, I will try to indicate that fact.
    One other qualification is in order. The words ‘good’ and ‘bad’ have meanings that relate to morality as well as meanings that have nothing to do with morality. Sentences like ‘this is a good machine gun’ and ‘Bob is a good assassin’ are obviously not moral statements. ‘Bob is a good assassin’ means
‘Bob is an effective assassin’; the word ‘good’ is being used in an instrumental, not a moral, sense. And, of course, if you say ‘this is a bad atomic bomb’, you are using the word ‘bad’ in an instrumental, not a moral, sense. The words ‘good’ and ‘bad’ also have aesthetic meanings, of course. The aesthetic meanings of these words may be more closely connected to their moral meanings than are the instrumental meanings of these terms. But the aesthetic meanings of ‘good’ and ‘bad’ are still to be distinguished from their moral meanings. When you say ‘that was a good concert’ or ‘Bach was a good composer’, you are not using the term ‘good’ in its moral meaning. For we can aesthetically praise something that we morally condemn. The movie Triumph of the Will , which was a Nazi propaganda film, is held to be a cinematic masterpiece. But it was obviously not something morally good. So it would be no contradiction to say ‘Triumph of the will was aesthetically good, but morally bad.’ But, of course, if the aesthetic meaning of ‘good’ coincided with the moral meaning of that word, that sentence would be selfcontradictory.
    In this paper, when I use the terms ‘good’ and ‘bad’, I will be using them only in their moral sense. The claims that I make about these terms will usually not be true if these words are taken in their non-moral senses.
 
II.    Leaving aside various niceties that will have no special bearing on the present inquiry, a string of verbiage qualifies as a declarative sentence if it is a conventionalized way of expressing a certain kind of belief. (In this paper, by ‘sentence’ I mean ‘declarative’ sentence.) Consider the verbiage ‘snow is white’. If you utter this, you are producing a sentence, and this is ultimately because that verbiage is a conventionalized expression of a certain kind of belief – the belief that snow is white. [225] 
    So ‘Stalin was short’ is meaningful because it is a conventionalized way of expressing a certain kind of belief. If ‘Stalin was evil’ is meaningful, that is because it is a conventionalized way of expressing a certain belief.   There can be no doubt that valuative sentences are conventionalized ways of expressing attitudes. ‘Abortion is wrong’ and ‘Stalin was evil’ are conventionalized ways of expressing some kind of negative attitude towards murder and Stalin.
   Some case can be made that the attitudes expressed by sentences like
‘abortion is wrong’ and ‘Stalin was evil’ have emotional content. In fact, a case can be made that those attitudes are emotions. (This is of course controversial; I will give a bare outline of a way to discharge this contentious point.) In effect, a case can be made for emotivism. Here is such a case. (For the record I believe that emotivism is correct. But I admit that the argument I’m about to present falls short of proving it, though it probably gives it some credence and will, in any case, set forth a reason why one might be an emotivist.)
 
An Argument for Emotivism
 
       Suppose that you have no negative emotion towards abortion. In that case, you could not sincerely say ‘abortion is wrong.’ A precondition for sincerely saying ‘x is good’ or ‘x is bad’ is that one feel a certain way towards x – that one feel positively or negatively towards x.
     One might think that one can sincerely say ‘abortion is wrong’ or ‘feeding the hungry is good’  and yet not have any emotion towards abortion or towards feeding the hungry. But this position is hard to sustain. Consider a being who was completely devoid of emotions. Ask yourself: could that being really see abortion as wrong? Obviously that being would be indifferent to the fact that abortions occur; for if it were not indifferent to that fact – if it were moved by that fact – then ipso facto it would have emotions. So it wouldn’t care whether abortions were performed. If it didn’t care, then how could it sincerely condemn abortion? How could it sincerely say that abortion was wrong? If a being was completely indifferent to whether abortions were performed – and obviously this is how an emotionless being would be  --then it would be misrepresenting its state of mind in saying ‘abortions are wrong’ or ‘I disapprove of abortions.’ I simply don’t see how the making of value judgments about x can be disentangled from the having of emotions concerning x. (This is one of the controversial assumptions that I spoke of earlier.)
     Admittedly, it might seem as though one can sincerely but emotionlessly say ‘lying is wrong’ or ‘Hitler was evil.’ But I think that this point of view is superficial. I think, in fact, that it confuses emotion with the occurrent manifestations of emotion. To be sure, one can sincerely say ‘lying is wrong’ or ‘Hitler was evil’ without having any occurrent feeling in connection with those words. But if one had no emotion in connection Hitler, then one would ipso facto be indifferent to Hitler and his deeds. And if one were truly indifferent to these deeds, could one really sincerely condemn them? Surely there is some intuitive pull to say ‘no.’
    Another prima facie objection the argument just given is this: “A psychopath – e.g. Ted Bundy – can know that what he is doing is wrong, but have no feeling towards his evil deeds, or having nothing but positive feelings towards those deeds. But if believing that e.g. rape is wrong just is having some kind of a negative emotion towards rape, then there would be no Ted Bundy’s – there would be no people who knew that what they did was wrong, and yet had no negative feelings towards those deeds.”     This objection has some force. But surely it is not conclusive. The emotivist can respond, and usually does respond, by saying that a psychopath is incapable of grasping the concepts of good and evil. Indeed, this is not only how emotivists characterize psychopaths: this is how many psychiatrists characterize them. According to this point of view, Ted Bundy and Jeffrey Dahmer knew that what they were doing was wrong only in a derivative sense: they knew that what they were doing was wrong in the sense that they
[226]
	knew that society disapproved of it. They grasped society’s disdain for their deeds, but they themselves didn’t really grasp the wrongness of their deeds. (Whether this counter-reply is correct, I do not know. But it has some credibility.)
    Thus, there is at least some reason to hold that a precondition for sincerely uttering a valuative of sentence is that one have an emotion of some kind. (Admittedly, these reasons are inconclusive. Vide the two objections to it just considered.) If this is right, then a precondition for sincerely saying ‘x is good’ or ‘x is bad’ is  that one have some kind of a positive or negative emotion towards x.  It is plain, in fact, that in sincerely saying ‘x is good’ or ‘x is bad’, one is expressing one’s positive or negative emotions towards x. Further, it is clear that ‘x is good’ and ‘x is bad’ are conventionalized ways of expressing such emotions. There are no linguistic rules governing when to groan. So groaning, although obviously an expression of some kind of psychological state, is not a linguistic expression of such a state: for it is not regulated by linguistic rules. But there are obviously linguistic rules governing when to say ‘x is good’ and ‘x is bad’. There are linguistic conventions regulating the use of ‘good’ and ‘bad’. So in as much as these terms, in virtue of their functions within some conventionalized means of self-expression, embody positive and negative emotions, it follows that there are linguistic rules governing when to say ‘x is good’ and ‘x is bad’: it follows, in effect, that ‘x is good’ and ‘x is bad’ are conventionalized ways of expressing emotional attitudes, just as ‘x is tall’ and ‘x has a positive charge’ are conventionalized ways of expressing beliefs. (My statement that ‘x is good’ is a conventionalized way of expressing an emotion is obviously not free from controversy. I hope, not to have established it conclusively, but only given it enough credence to give some credibility to what follows.)    So (i) valuative sentences have emotional content and (ii) this emotional content is central to their significance: it is not incidental to the semantics of ‘x is good’ that, when sincerely uttered, it expresses a positive attitude towards x. On the contrary, the semantics of ‘x is good’ nearly enough consists in that sentence’s being a conventionalized way of expressing a positive attitude towards x. Obviously the same point applies mutatis mutandis to ‘x is bad’, ‘x is evil’, ‘x is honorable’ and so on.
   
 
      Whatever the merits of the argument just given, it is clear that emotivism is to be taken seriously. Now for some reason, emotivism is held to be incompatible with realism. It is held that if emotivism is correct, then ‘x is good’ and ‘x is evil’ do not express facts about x – do not really say anything about x (they only show how the speaker feels about x). It is held that if ‘x is good’  and ‘x is bad’ express our emotions about x – our feelings about x – then they do not have any ‘cognitive value’, they do not say anything objective about x.
   Evidently, it is thought that, in so far a sentence-token expresses how the speaker feels, then to that extent it provides no information about anything other than the speaker’s emotions. We will  presently see  that this line of thought involves a serious non-sequitur -- it confuses what is expressed by a sentence token, on the one hand, and what is said by it, on the other.
 
III.   The truth is that emotivism is opposed to realism only if a highly dubious thesis about emotions is correct; i.e.  ‘x is good’ and ‘x is bad’ do make true or false statements about x unless a certain highly dubious thesis about emotions happens to be true. Put in positive terms, emotivism is a form of realism if a highly credible thesis about emotions – one held by Sartre, Robert Solomon, Merleau-Ponty, and various others – is correct.
    That thesis is this: emotions are beliefs or judgments of a certain kind. I myself hold that this thesis is correct – in my view, emotions are beliefs of a certain kind: they are valuative beliefs. And I will outline an argument for this thesis. (That outline will fall far short of proving that cognitivism is correct, but it will give that doctrine some credence.) Let us refer to this thesis as ‘cognitivism.’ So ‘cognitivism’, as I will be using this expression, is the thesis that emotions are beliefs of a certain kind.
     The term ‘cognitivism’ has various meanings in philosophy; it sometimes refers to what I have been calling ‘moral realism’. In the philosophy of mind, it refers to various different, and not always compatible, doctrines. My use of this term is not meant to be consistent with any existing usage of it; it is entirely stipulative. To be maximally clear: by ‘cognitivism’ I mean the doctrine that emotions are beliefs of some kind.
        At first, it might seem that cognitivism is an outrageous view:
 
“Admittedly emotions incorporate beliefs. But surely there is more to an emotion than just a belief. Surely there is more to my being angry at Mary
[227]
than my just having a belief.”
 
    But given some rudimentary and uncontroversial truths about emotions, it turns out to be much harder, I think, to make a case against cognitivism than
[228]
to make a case for it.
 
An Argument for Cognitivism
 
     I will now offer an argument for cognitivism. Whether it proves cognitivism to be correct, I do not know. But it probably gives it enough credibility to make its consequences worth exploring.
 
     First of all, an emotion is not just a feeling. If one has an object-less feeling, one is not thereby having an emotion. Suppose one feels good but
[229]
does not feel good about 	anything. Such a state, surely, is not an emotion: it is a mere feeling. So emotions are directed. They have the property of ‘intentionality’: ‘emotional consciousness is…consciousness of
[230]
	the world.’ In having an emotion, one is feeling a certain way about something. To love Mary is to feel a certain way about her; to be angry that Bob stole my bicycle is to feel a certain way about the fact that Bob stole my bicycle.
  I should clarify what I mean by the term ‘feeling’. When I say that, to have an emotion is to ‘feel’ a certain way about something, I don’t mean that to have an emotion is to be in a state that has phenomenal content – in a state that has a phenomenology.  
   To say that a mental condition has ‘phenomenal content’ – or, equivalently, that it has a ‘phenomenology’ – is to say that there is something
[231]
it is like to be in that state. There is something it is like to smell coffee or taste mustard. So those conditions have phenomenal content. By contrast, there is not anything it is like to believe that two is the only even prime: so that mental condition – if ‘condition’ is the right word – has no phenomenal content:  no phenomenology.
   To be sure, some emotions – so-called occurrent ones – do have phenomenal content. If I see a rabid dog running towards me, I will feel a surge of fear; and that emotion has phenomenal content. But not all emotions are occurrent; and it is therefore not always the case that, in having an emotion, one’s mental life has a certain phenomenology. For example, I am happy that my uncle’s chemotherapy was a success. But it is not the case that, in virtue of having that emotion, I am at every waking moment in a state with a certain phenomenology. There are people who I currently love/hate who I haven’t even thought about in months, and in connection with whom I therefore haven’t been in any phenomenally pregnant states for some time. So when I say that to have an emotion is to ‘feel’ a certain way about something, I am not using the term ‘feeling’ to denote an occurrent, phenomenally pregnant condition; I am using to denote an attitude of some
[232]
kind. 
   Once it is granted that emotions are essentially directed – more specifically, that they are attitudes of a certain kind --  it becomes very hard to see them as anything other than beliefs. Uncontroversially, my being angry that Bob stole my bicycle consists in my having a certain attitude – a negative one – towards a certain (putative) fact, viz. that Bob stole my bicycle. (Analogous remarks apply to all other emotions.) What is it to have an attitude towards a fact? One plausible answer is this: to have an attitude towards something is to see that fact thing in a certain light. And to see something in a certain light is, presumably, to see it as being a certain way -as having certain properties. To have an attitude towards the Russian revolution to see it in a certain light; and this, in turn, is presumably to see it as being a certain way. To see the Russian revolution as being a certain way is to presumably to have some kind of view as to what properties the  Russian revolution had, and is thus to have some set of beliefs about it. (Again, here I am making use o several debatable, but highly plausible, assumptions. First, I am assuming that to have an attitude towards something – to be angry at it or happy for it – is to see it ‘in a certain light.’ Next, I am assuming that to see something in a certain light is to see it as being a certain way. And I am also assuming that to see something as being a certain is to see it as having certain properties. One might contest these identifications. But there can be no doubt that there is some presumption in favor of each of them.)
   This line of thought suggests that emotions are beliefs of some kind. But
it doesn’t yet show that emotions are valuative beliefs. But once it is granted that emotions are beliefs of some kind, it is not hard to show that they must be valuative beliefs. (A valuative belief may incorporate a factive or nonvaluative component. In order to believe that it was evil of Stalin to kill millions of people, I must have the non-valuative belief that Stalin killed millions of people. By a ‘valuative’ belief, I don’t mean a belief that has no factive component; I mean a belief that involves the ascription of some positive or negative value to something. Valuative beliefs, it seems to me, typically involve factive or non-valuative components.)
    Given any purely non-valuative  belief, one does not, in principle, have to have any specific emotion in connection with it; and, in principle, one can have no emotion in connection with it. Consider the belief that Stalin killed thirty million people. We can imagine some sadist who had this belief, and delighted in it. (Maybe Stalin himself is an example of such a person.) And we can imagine someone else who had this belief and had no emotion, positive or negative, in connection with it – someone who was indifferent to Stalin’s atrocities. (Maybe Molotov is an example of such a person.) Clearly, given any belief that has no valuative component, we can imagine a being that had no emotion, or had different emotions, in connection with that fact.
   Given this, it is not possible that an emotion should be identical with a non-valuative belief. If my having emotion of type E were identical with having non-valuative belief of type B, then it would not be possible to have different emotions in connection with B and it would not be possible to have no emotion in connection with B. If my being angry that income is not evenly distributed were identical with my believing that income is not evenly distributed, then it would not be possible, even in principle, to have no emotion in connection with the belief that income is unevenly distributed, and it would not be possible, even in principle, to have some emotion in
place of anger in connection with that belief.
   Also, given that one can have different emotions, or no emotion at all, in connection with a given non-valuative belief, it follows straightaway that emotions do not supervene on non-valuative beliefs. Given that one can have different emotions, or even no emotion, in connection with any type of nonvaluative belief, it follows, by the definition of ‘supervenience’, that
[233]
emotions do not supervene on non-valuative beliefs.
    So, if the having of emotions consists in the having of beliefs, it cannot be identical with, or supervene on, the having of non-valuative or purely factive beliefs. It follows that if emotions are beliefs, they must be valuative ones.
  This position is borne out by consideration of individual emotions. Suppose that Bob stole my bicycle and that I am angry that Bob did that. That emotion obviously consists in my having some kind of an attitude – a negative one – towards the fact that Bob stole my bicycle. And having such an attitude would seem to consist in my seeing that fact in a certain light: in my seeing it as a bad thing, as having negative value. Suppose that Mary just won the Nobel prize and that I am happy about that. My being happy that Mary won the Nobel prize consists in my having a certain attitude towards that fact. And my having that attitude would seem to consist in my seeing that fact in a certain light: in my seeing it as a good thing. My fearing that Mary will kill me consists in my believing it to be at least not entirely out of the question that Mary might kill me, and in my feeling a certain way about – having a certain attitude towards – that fact: in my seeing her killing me as something that, if it were to happen, would have some kind of negative value.
  There is a slightly different way to give support to this line of thought. For me to be angry that Bob stole my bicycle, I must obviously believe that Bob stole my bicycle. But, in principle, I could believe that Bob stole my bicycle without having any emotion in connection with that fact. (Maybe I want Bob to have a bicycle so badly that I am glad he stole my bicycle. Maybe, as part of some elaborate plot to frame Bob, I wanted Bob to steal that bicycle. Would Mr. Spock be angry if he knew that Bob stole his bicycle? What about the Dalai Lama?) So my being angry that Bob stole my bicycle cannot consist merely in my believing that Bob stole my bicycle. But if what we said about emotions is correct, they are beliefs of some kind. So what kind of a belief could the aforementioned anger be? Well, there is no purely factive belief – no purely non-valuative – belief that this anger could consist in. For given any purely factive belief, I don’t have to have any emotion in connection with it and I could, in principle, have very different emotions in connection with it. So if – what we’ve seen some reason to hold – emotions, are belief, they must be valuative beliefs. So my being angry that Bob stole my bicycle cannot consist in my having this or that non-valuative belief. So it must consist in my having some valuative belief. And when we examine this anger, it seems to consist in my seeing Bob’s theft of my bicycle as having a certain negative value – as being a bad thing.
  Let us sum up. Emotions are attitudes towards things. To have an attitude towards a thing is to see it in a certain light. To see something in a certain light is to see it as having certain properties. To see something as having certain properties is to have a belief about it. Thus emotions are beliefs. (But, of course, not all beliefs are emotions. My belief that 2+2=4 is not an emotion.) Emotions cannot be identical with, or supervene on, non-valuative beliefs; for any non-valuative belief can be associated with different emotions or with no emotion. Therefore they must be valuative beliefs. So here we have a plausible, purely theoretical argument for the position that emotions are valuative beliefs. Consideration of individual emotions provides a kind of empirical support for this purely theoretical argument. My being happy that Mary did such and such seems to consist in my seeing her doing such and such in a positive light, and thus in my believing it to have some kind of positive value.
       The temptation is very strong to say that, although emotions incorporate beliefs, they are not just beliefs: they can be decomposed into doxastic and non-doxastic components. So, according to this view, my negative attitude towards Bob’s theft of my bicycle – i.e. my anger in connection with this fact – is decomposable into a belief (viz. that Bob stole my bicycle) plus something other than a belief. I cannot state with certainty that this view is wrong, but there is no obvious way to effect this decomposition (I challenge anyone to try) and, beyond that, there is some reason to think that it cannot be done.
    Suppose we say that this anger consists in (i) my believing that Bob stole my bicycle plus (ii) some non-directed (object-less) bad feeling. Well, in that case, I plainly don’t have a bad feeling about Bob’s stealing my bicycle; so I do not have a negative attitude towards this fact – and I don’t have any kind of emotion towards it.
    On the other hand, suppose we try to decompose my anger into (i) my believing that Bob stole my bicycle plus (ii) some directed (representational) bad feeling. In that case, we have to ask: what is it to have a representational bad feeling? Presumably, it is a feeling which represents something as being a certain way: it is my having a bad feeling to a certain effect. But such a thing is nothing other than a belief.
   To sum up, the ‘de-cognitivizing’ of emotion – the attempt to recover the quite understandable intuition that there is more to an emotion than just a belief – is not such an easy enterprise: there is no obvious way to carry it out. And this, in itself, constitutes a kind of argument, if only a weak one, for cognitivism.
 
IV. Obviously, we have not proven that cognitivism is true; our argument was replete with controversial assumptions. But we have, I think, shown that it is a doctrine to be taken seriously. Now I want to show that if cognitivism is true, then emotivism is a form of moral realism. Of course, this ‘if-then’ statement is of interest precisely because the ‘if’ part may be true -cognitivism may be accurate; so emotivism may well be a form of realism.    According to emotivism,  when one says ‘x is good’ or ‘x is bad’ one is expressing an emotion towards x. Now it is plain that if cognitivism is true, then when one says ‘x is good’ or ‘x is evil’ one is expressing a belief. (Of course, when one says ‘x is tall’ or ‘x has a positive charge’ one is expressing a belief.) So if cognitivism is correct, then emotivism is a form of realism, and is thus --- contrary to popular opinion – in no way opposed to it.     Obviously people who see a conflict between emotivism and realism think that in so far as ‘x is good’ expresses how the speaker feels about x, to that
[234]
	extent it doesn’t say anything about x. The truth is that, even if ‘x is good’ expresses how the relevant speaker feels about x, that does not by itself mean that ‘x is good’ to any extent fails to make a true or false statement about x. To believe otherwise is to fail to distinguish to between what a sentence expresses and what it says.   
        The sentence ‘Smith is short’ is about Smith; it is obviously not about the person who produces that sentence (unless, by sheer accident, that person happens to Smith). Suppose Bob says ‘Smith is short’. Bob is obviously not saying anything about himself. But he is obviously expressing a belief that he has. So, in effect, Bob is showing something about himself – he is showing that he believes Smith to be tall – even though he (Bob) is not saying anything about himself. One cannot say anything without expressing some belief that one has – without showing something about one’s own beliefs and, therefore, about oneself. Now suppose – what we’ve seen some reason to be the case – that one is expressing an emotion in saying ‘x is good’ or ‘x is bad’. In other words, suppose that emotivism is correct. Given only that emotivism is correct, it doesn’t follow that, in saying ‘x is good’ or ‘x is bad’, one is not also making a true or false statement about x. For if cognitivism is correct, then in having an emotion, one is also having a belief; and in that case, if sentences like ‘x is good’ and ‘x is bad’ serve to express emotions, that means they serve to express beliefs. And if that is the case, then ‘x is good’ doesn’t operate differently from ‘x is tall’: both sentences express beliefs and both make objective statements.

NO SUCH THINGS AS MENTALESE Abstract
According to Jerry Fodor, for someone to grasp a proposition – to have a thought – is just for some sentence of an internal language to be tokened. This internal language is thus the ‘language of thought’. In this essay I will provide some reasons to think that this idea is untenable. For someone to know a language L, that person must know the rules giving meaning to the expressions of L. (Admittedly, this idea may be questioned; but reasons are provided for it.) So for someone to know the language of thought, he must know the rules which assign meaning to the expressions belonging to that language. Now we know from Tarski that no language can express the rules that give its own expressions meaning. So if one is to grasp the semantical rules for some language L, one must either grasp them (i) in some ‘Meta’-language (that comprises L as a proper part of itself) or (ii) one must grasp them in some altogether non-linguistic form. Someone who holds that all thinking consists in the tokening of symbols cannot take path (ii). So he must take path (i). This means that if one is to understand a language L, one must understand the relevant meta-language and, therefore, must grasp the rules that give meaning to the expressions of this meta-language. But by Tarski’s theorem, these rules cannot be given in the meta-language itself. So if one is to grasp these rules – and, therefore, if one is to understand the meta-language – these rules must be given to one either (i’) in some meta-meta-language or (ii’) in some nonlinguistic form. If we adopt path (ii’) we are abandoning the idea that thinking consists in the tokening of symbols, and thus abandoning the idea of a language of thought. On the other hand if we take (i’) we are launched on a vicious regress. Ways of blocking this regress, without abandoning the idea that there is a language of thought, are considered and, ultimately, deemed inadequate.
 
I. Fodor’s Thesis and My Counter-Thesis
 
According to Jerry Fodor, there is a ‘language of thought’. Fodor does not mean by this that English speakers think in English, that Albanian speakers think in Albanian, and so on. (In fact, Fodor does not hold this. He thinks that in order to know a natural language – e.g. English, Albanian – one must already be able to have thoughts; and that, consequently, thinking does not ultimately take place in any natural language.) What Fodor means is that there is some innately known language – some language that doesn’t have to be learned – such that all thinking consists in the tokening of expressions of this language.
Fodor’s argument is, very roughly, this. (i) Thought consists in, or at least involves, the entertaining of propositions. (ii) All representation involves some kind of medium. (iii) Any medium capable of representing propositions is ipso facto a language. (iv) Therefore the medium in which thought takes place is a language of some kind. (v) Therefore there is a ‘language of thought’: thought consists in the tokening of expressions of some language. (Fodor refers to this
[235]
putative language as ‘Mentalese’.) 
In this essay, I will provide just one reason to hold that there couldn’t possibly be a language of thought; that thinking could not, in any literal sense, consist in the tokening of expressions.
I should make it clear that I am not approaching this question from an anticognitive science perspective. In fact, I am biased in favor of a cognitivescientific conception of mental activity. I have no doubt that the basic postulates of cognitive science are correct: virtually all of our mental productions involve the existence of sub-conscious and, what is more, subpersonal  mentation, and this mentation consists in the occurrence of inferences or computations. So, for example, mediating between the impact of various of photons one’s retinae, on the one hand, and the subsequent having of visual experiences, on the other, are not only various physiological processes, but also various  cognitive processes: data is integrated; inferences are made; conclusions are drawn – all at a level far beneath that of personal awareness and, indeed, necessarily inaccessible to introspection. So, just to be clear, my purpose is not to undermine cognitive science; it is rather to eliminate an erroneous way of thinking about cognitive scientific inquiry.
II. A Problem for Fodor’s Thesis: Its Need for Our Knowledge of an Infinite Hierarchy of Meta-Languages
 
Any English-speaker is capable of understanding sentences of English that he hasn’t encountered before. (You can understand the sentence ‘feathered pigs play tennis with zeal’ even though you’ve probably never encountered it before.) It is not an accidental fact that any English-speaker can understand sentences he has never encountered before: having this ability seems to be constitutive or definitive of being an English speaker. Suppose someone could only understand some finite stock of sentences – e.g. ‘John is tall’, ‘Sam is fat’, and ‘cats like dogs’. (Actually, later on I will try to show that, unless one could understand an infinite number of English sentences, one could not, ultimately, understand any. But for now let us operate on the fiction that one could understand only some finite number of English sentences.) Such a person – though he might understand some English sentences – could nevertheless not really be said to know English. For knowing English involves being able to understand – to assign meaning to – sentences one has not encountered before: if one really knows English, then the set of English sentences one can understand is, in some sense, ‘unbounded’. 
So knowing a natural language involves being able to understand sentences
that one has not previously encountered, and whose meanings one has therefore not memorized. Given this, it seems reasonable to suppose that,  in order to know a natural language, one must know some set of rules assigning meaning to expressions of that language.
These rules are, presumably, of two types: rules that assign meaning to simple expressions (e.g. ‘cat’, ‘dog’, ‘red’, ‘Sam’); and those that assign meanings to complex expressions on the basis of the meanings of the simple expressions composing them (‘recursive’ rules). You can understand ‘Bill Clinton smokes cigars’ because (a) you know what ‘Bill Clinton’, ‘smokes’, and ‘cigars’ means and (b) you know how these meanings combine, as it were, to form the meaning of the sentence in question.
Now if there is a language of thought,  one could not know this language simply by memorizing the meanings of its expressions. There is no pre-set limit to the thoughts a cognitively normal human being can have. It is not as though there is some finite stock of thoughts – e.g. snow is white, grass is green, girls play tennis, and baboons write poetry.- such that one can have only those thoughts and no others. The set of thoughts one can have is, at least along certain dimensions (though not all, to be sure) ‘unbounded’. If one can grasp certain thoughts, then one can generate new ones by combining and iterating those thoughts. So one cannot understand the language of thought, supposing that there is such a thing, by memorizing the sentences belonging to that language; for there are infinitely many of them; and, presumably, an infinite list of sentences cannot be memorized.
Also, thought has a ‘non-atomistic’ character. If one can have one thought, one can have many others; any given thought has ‘constitutive’ connections to other thoughts. (It seems  impossible that a creature should be able to have just the thought that the interior angles of a triangle add up to 180. For if one can have one thought, one can have many others: many other thoughts about arithmetic, geometry, rigidity, direction, causality, and so on. For example, it is impossible that you should be able to grasp  the proposition that x, y, and z add up to 180 without grasping the proposition that x, y, and z add up to 179 or 181; for the thought  that x, y, and z add up to 180 is an essentially contrastive thought: it can exist only in a space of other arithmetical beliefs. And there doesn’t appear to be any definite limit to the number of beliefs required to generate the appropriate ‘space’.) So it seems a bit unlikely that a being capable  of understanding the language of thought – capable of understanding ‘Mentalese’ – can simply have memorized the meanings of Mentalese sentences; for any one thought is, apparently, embedded in a matrix of other thoughts: a matrix that would appear to extend indefinitely in at least some directions. Therefore, it seems reasonable to presume, anything capable of understanding Mentalese must know some set of rules assigning meaning to these sentences.
So we must ask: given a being that understands Mentalese sentences, how are the rules assigning meaning to these sentences given to that being? How are they represented to it? Trivially, either these rules are given to that being through a language or not through a language. If they are not given to it through a language, then ipso facto that being can grasp propositions that are not embodied in an expression of a language, i.e. thought does not (at least not in general) consist in the tokening of expressions of some language. So anyone who believes in Mentalese – who believes that thought consists in the tokening of expressions in a language – cannot hold that the rules assigning meaning to Mentalese sentences are given in some non-linguistic form. So, it follows trivially that these rules must be given in some linguistic form: in some language.
Trivially, either these rules are either given in Mentalese or they are not. Now Tarski proved that no language can contain the rules assigning meaning [236]
to the expressions of that language. As it is sometimes put, no language can contain its own ‘truth-predicate’. Put yet another way, given any language L, the rules giving meaning to sentences of L cannot themselves be expressed in L. This is a theorem of mathematics, not a psychological or linguistic hypothesis: as a matter of mathematics, it is not possible for a language to be capable of expressing the rules that assign meaning to its own sentences.   
So anything capable of understanding Mentalese must either (i) grasp the rules giving meaning to Mentalese expressions through some language other than Mentalese or (ii) it must grasp these rules  in some non-linguistic form. We’ve already seen that anyone who believes in a ‘language of thought’ cannot accept (ii). So anyone holding that there is a language of thought –that thoughts are tokenings of expressions - must accept (i); he must hold that one knows the rules  giving meaning to Mentalese sentences by virtue of grasping sentences of some language L’ (distinct from Mentalese). So anything capable of understanding Mentalese must grasp some language L’ distinct from Mentalese (though L’ may contain Mentalese as a proper part of itself). Now L’ must be rich enough to give meaning to all the expressions of Mentalese; so it must have a similarly ‘unbounded’ nature. So one cannot understand L’ by virtue of memorizing the sentences belonging to it. One must know the rules assigning meaning to these sentences. By Tarski’s theorem, these rules cannot be stated in L’ itself: they must be given in some other language L’’. But, by an argument exactly analogous to that just stated, one cannot understand L’’ by memorizing the sentences belonging to it; one must know the rules assigning meaning to these sentences. These rules, by Tarski’s theorem, cannot be stated in L’’, but must be stated in some other language L’’’ – and so on ad infinitum. So with regard to the idea that rules can be grasped only in some linguistic form, this idea leads to a vicious regress: it involves the idea that, to grasp a single language, one must grasp an infinite hierarchy of languages. But it is unreasonable to suppose that everyone knows an infinite hierarchy of languages; indeed the idea is probably absurd. So if one is to know any language – at least any language rich enough to mediate the potentially unbounded set of thoughts any human can have -  then propositions are not always given in linguistic form: the grasping of propositions does not consist, at least not universally, in the tokening of expressions.
So the idea that there is a language of thought is self-defeating. If there is a language of thought, then to understand the sentences of this language, certain rules, certain propositions (viz. those assigning meaning to said sentences), must be given to one in non-linguistic form; so that the grasping of does not consist in the tokening of expressions of some language. But if the grasping of propositions – the having of thoughts – does not consist in the tokening of expressions of some language, then the hypothesis that there is a language of thought is false: for that hypothesis just i s the idea that the grasping of propositions consists in the tokening of ‘Mentalese’ expressions.
 
III. Fodor’s Response and My Counter-response
Fodor’s Response
At this point, I must address several objections that might be leveled against my argument. One of these is due to Fodor himself, who was responding to an earlier draft of the present article. I quote:
 
[Y]ou don't have to represent the rules of a language that you are able to use; all that's required is that you are so constructed as to conform to the rules. (Cf the way computers are `built to use' their machine language.) Of course, it's plausible that you DO internally represent the rules of (say) English; but that's not because English is a language; it's because it's a language that you LEARN; and it's quite plausible that to learn a language is to come to internally represent its syntax and semantics. (Presumably in `Mentalese').     
    
Here, in essence, is what Fodor is saying. You mentally represent the rules of English (in Mentalese); but you don’t represent the rules of Mentalese themselves. Hence the regress I discussed is blocked. How, then, do you (or the relevant part of your mind) understand Mentalese expressions? Well, you are simply ‘built’ to understand them; you are structured in such a way that, when confronted with a token of Mentalese, you arrive at an understanding of its meaning without applying knowledge of the rules which give that expression meaning. So if you are confronted with the Mentalese sentence if snow is white, then something is white you don’t apply some knowledge of rules to assign meaning to the ‘snow’, ‘white’, etc. and then use some knowledge of recursions to get the meaning of the whole sentence: you don’t do that, because that would involve your having a knowledge of the rules giving meaning to Mentalese expressions – which rules cannot be given in Mentalese itself, given Tarski’s result – and the regress I discussed gets started. Rather you ascertain the meaning of if snow is white, then something is white by virtue simply of being ‘so constructed’ that you automatically – i.e. in some way not involving knowledge of linguistic rules, not involving computation: indeed, not involving cognition (for surely cognition is mentation that involves consideration of rules)  – arrive at a knowledge of its meaning.
My Counter-Response
 
This position is untenable on a number of levels. But, ultimately, I think, there are two problems with it. (1): Given a linguistic expression E, if you don’t have to figure out what E’s meaning is on  the basis of any constituent expressions that it might have, then ipso facto E is a primitive expression, at least from your point of view. Now if Fodor’s counter-objection (quoted above) is correct, then you never figure out what Mentalese expressions mean. (You don’t have to compute their meanings.) A fortiori given any Mentalese expression, you don’t figure out what they mean on the basis of the meanings of any expressions that might compose them. So, from the point of view of the person (or sub-personal agency) that has to understand mentalese expressions, each of these expressions is semantically primitive (if they are semantic at all). So the Mentalese sentence if snow is white, the something is white is primitive; it is not a compound of the Mentalese sentences snow is white and something is white. Now Fodor holds that to grasp a proposition just is to grasp a Mentalese sentence. So he must also hold that to grasp relations among propositions – e.g. the relation that holds between snow is white and if snow is white then something is white – just is to grasp relations (of meaning, presumably: semantic relations) among sentences. But if each Mentalese sentence is semantically primitive, then there are no semantic relations among them; which implies that any creature thinking in Mentalese could (indeed must)  grasp if snow is white then something is white without grasping how the constituent sentences in this complex sentence relate to the latter. But this is absurd.
(2) With regard to the idea that one could understand an expression without knowing the rules that assign it meaning: that idea, I submit, is incoherent. Suppose that S is some sentence and that you know what proposition it encodes, but that you arrived at this knowledge without applying some set of semantic rules: in that case S is not, at least not from your point of view, a bit of language. In any case, this is what I will now argue.
I admit that both of these claims are far from self-evident. So I would now like to elucidate and defend them. Let’s start with (1).
(1) Fodor’s response incompatible with our ability to grasp logical relations holding among propositions
 
 First I’d like to illustrate the idea of a ‘semantic primitive’. Suppose that the following is a long sentence of Finnish:
 

	* xyz
 
And suppose that this sentence means
 

	* If pigs are the only flying creatures, and only flying creatures havehorns, then only pigs have horns.
 
You now know what proposition (i) encodes. But you don’t really understand the sentence, at least not in the sense in which a Finn does. For you have no idea what contribution the various components of (i) make to the proposition expressed by that sentence. So at least one of the dimensions of (i)’s meaning that is known to any Finn is unknown to you. We can characterize this difference by saying that for you (i) is a primitive expression, whereas for a Finn (i) is a highly complex expression. So even though the proposition expressed by (i) is complex, nevertheless the sentence itself is, from your point view (though not a Finn’s), semantically primitive: for, from your point of view (though not a Finn’s) its meaning is not to be arrived by performing a computation on the meanings of simpler expressions.
Now suppose that Fodor is right: suppose that you (or the relevant subpersonal agency within you) doesn’t understand Mentalese sentences by consulting any set of rules; that you are simply ‘so constructed’ that you understand them. (Incidentally, the understanding of Mentalese sentences, if there are such things, occurs at an entirely sub-personal level. So, strictly speaking, it is incorrect to speak of you processing such sentences; for this term obviously refers to a person, and not to a network of sub-personal computational processes. But for brevity’s sake, I will speak of ‘you’ grasping, processing etc. Mentalese sentences. Simply realize that, in these contexts,  I am using the term ‘you’ to refer to some sub-personal entity within you.) This means that, given any Mentalese sentence S,  you don’t compute its meaning. In that case, no Mentalese sentence that you come across is semantically complex, no matter how complex the proposition that it encodes. 
Given this, consider the English sentence
 

	* If snow is white, and all cows eat snow, and all things that eat whitethings like grass, then cows like grass.
 
It is pretty obvious that you understand (i) by virtue (inter alia) of understanding the sentences
 

	* snow is white
 

	* all cows eat snow;
 

	* all things that eat white things like grass;
 
and
 

	* cows like grass.
 
It is pretty obvious, then, that you arrive at the meaning of (i) by, in some way or other, ‘integrating’ the meanings of these other sentences. And, of course, your ‘integrating’ these meanings consists in your applying some set of rules that are defined over these meanings. In light of this, consider the Mentalese sentence:
 
(i’) If snow is white, and all cows eat snow, and all things that eat white things like grass, then cows like grass.
 
One would presume that you can understand (i’) by virtue of understanding the Mentalese sentences
 
(ii’) snow is white
 
(iii’) all cows eat snow;
 
(iv’) all things that eat white things like grass;
 
and
 
(v’) cows like grass.
 
But if Fodor is right, this is not the case. If Fodor is right, (i’) is not – at least nor from your point of view: from the point of view the person who has to figure out what (i’) means - semantically complex; its meaning is not to be computed in any way. For computation involves consideration of rules, and Fodor’s way of blocking the regress discussed above is to say that one understands Mentalese sentences without consulting any rules.  A fortiori, as far as you can tell –- for, if Fodor’s objection is correct,  you have no access to the recursions relating (i’) to (ii’)-(v’) --  (i’)’s meaning is not a function of the meanings of (ii’)-(v’).
But this idea is  multiply incoherent. For Fodor –  for anyone who believes that there is a language of thought - grasping the proposition snow is white simply is grasping the Mentalese sentence (ii’)  snow is white, and grasping the proposition If snow is white, and all cows eat snow, and all things that eat white things like grass, then cows like grass simply is grasping the Mentalese sentence (i’) If snow is white, and all cows eat snow, and all things that eat white things like grass, then cows like grass. For Fodor, you have no way of grasping the propositions other than by grasping these sentences of Mentalese. (This is what the whole ‘language-of-thought’ hypothesis amounts to.) Now there’s obviously no way to grasp the proposition (i) without grasping (ii)-(v): your grasp of (i) is surely ‘built up’ in some way from your grasp of (ii)-(v). For Fodor, grasping (i) simply is to grasp (i’). So, if Fodor is right, one cannot grasp (i’) without grasping (ii’)-(v’); and one’s grasp of (i’) is ‘built up’ in some way from one’s grasp of (ii’)-(v’).
If grasping propositions simply is grasping sentences of Mentalese, then grasping relations among propositions consists in grasping relations among Mentalese sentences. What kinds of relations among Mentalese sentences? Presumably, relations of meaning: semantic relations. But if Fodor’s objection is correct, you have no way of grasping such relations. Each Mentalese sentence is, for you, a semantic primitive. Your grasp of the Mentalese sentence (i’) does not involve your grasping the Mentalese sentences (ii’)-(v’). Your grasp of the proposition (i) is identical with your grasp of (i). So, if Fodor is right, your grasp of the proposition (i) does not involve your grasping the propositions (ii)-(v): you grasp the proposition If snow is white, and all cows eat snow, and all things that eat white things like grass, then cows like grass without grasping the propositions snow is white; all cows eat snow; and so on. But that is patently absurd.
Let us sum up what we’ve said so far. If the language of thought hypothesis
is correct, then to grasp a proposition is simply to grasp the Mentalese sentence representing that proposition. So to grasp relations among propositions is just to grasp relations among sentences: relations of meaning, presumably. Now Fodor’s way of blocking the regress I mentioned earlier is to say that one doesn’t ascertain the meanings of Mentalese sentences by performing computations, i.e. one does not derive the meanings of these sentences from the meanings of their parts. One is simply ‘so structured’ that one understands these sentences. So one does not understand such a sentence by taking in the meanings of its parts and, on the basis, computing the meaning of the whole sentence. Consequently, each of these sentences is, from the point of view of the person apprehending them, a semantic primitive. So no two Mentalese sentences have any semantic connection to each other, at least not as far as the person (or sub-personal agency) comprehending these sentences can tell. Now if grasping propositions is identical with grasping sentences of Mentalese, then grasping relations among propositions is identical with grasping semantic relations among Mentalese sentences. It follows that, if grasping propositions were identical with grasping Mentalese sentences, then one could grasp e.g. if snow is white, then something is white without grasping the proposition snow is white. But this is absurd.
A Fodorian might counter-respond as follows:
 
It is obviously true that if you grasp the proposition  if snow is white, and all cows eat snow, and all things that eat white things like grass, then cows like grass, then you must grasp the propositions snow is white, cows like grass, etc. And, as you’ve pointed out, I hold that to grasp propositions simply is to grasp (tokens of) Mentalese sentences. So it does, admittedly, follow from my position that for someone to grasp relations of meaning among propositions is for him to grasp relations of meaning among sentences. But these relations need not be recursive relations. For me to grasp the Mentalese sentence if snow is white, then something is white I must obviously grasp the Mentalese sentences snow is white and something is white and I must also grasp the relation that these two sentences bear to the sentence if snow is white, then something is white. But this relationship is not a semantic relationship; it is just a logical relationship. In other words, my grasping this relationship doesn’t consist in my knowing the recursion by which if snow is white, then something is white is assigned meaning on the basis of the meanings of its constituents; my grasping this relationship consists wholly in my grasping some relationship among propositions: some non-linguistic relationship.
 
This is precisely the view that a Fodorian cannot take. For the Fodorian, the grasping of logical relations coincides with the grasping of semantic – indeed, of recursive –relations. To grasp if snow is white, then something is white one must obviously grasp, first, the two propositions contained in it and, second, the way in which these propositions combine to form the larger proposition. For Fodor, to grasp a proposition is to grasp a sentence; so to grasp a complex sentence (one composed of other sentences) one must grasp, first, its constituent sentences and, second, the way in which these combine to form the larger sentence.
