Now to grasp the way in which the meaning of a complex sentence is determined by the meanings of constituent sentences – to grasp this is to grasp a recursive relationship among expressions. So there is no way for Fodor to avoid saying that one grasps recursions among sentences of Mentalese. Given Tarski’s result, these recursions cannot be given in Mentalese itself; so they must be given in some meta-language. And the vicious regress we spoke of earlier starts again.
(2) Fodor’s response incompatible with what it is to know a symbol’s meaning
 
There is another problem with Fodor’s response (this is connected with – is perhaps a different facet of – the problem just discussed). I begin with a simple question: can one understand a linguistic expression without knowing the rule that gives it its meaning? At first it seems not. If I hear the sentence ‘snow is white’, I understand that sentence just in case I know some biconditional like: ‘snow is white’ means snow is white. Fodor (in the quotation above) is saying that, where Mentalese sentences are concerned, I do not know such biconditionals. So I know the meaning of the Mentalese sentence snow is white without knowing any biconditional like snow is white means snow is white. So I don’t know that snow is white means snow is white. So I don’t know what snow is white means…? In that case, it would seem, a Mentalese token of snow is white would fall on deaf ears, as would (by an exactly analogous argument) every other token of a Mentalese sentence.
In response, Fodor would presumably say that one doesn’t have to interpret Mentalese sentences: they wear their meanings on their sleeves; their meanings are ‘self-presenting’; perhaps they simply are meanings and therefore don’t have to be interpreted. (Meanings are not interpreted; things that bear meanings are interpreted: to interpret something is to figure out what meaning it bears. So meanings are not the sort of things that are interpreted.) To put it less metaphorically, the idea would seem to be this:
 
You don’t interpret your visual perceptions. You just have them. They wear their meanings on their sleeves. Similarly, you don’t interpret Mentalese sentence-tokens; for they were their meanings on their sleeves.
 
It may be true that we don’t interpret visual perceptions. They seem to have a certain transparency. They are not (let us suppose) ciphers which have to be decoded. But (supposing that this is the case) why is this? Because, presumably, the perception is itself a presentation of some kind of content. In having a perception, it is the content itself that is given to one, rather than some cipher which represents that content.  In having a perception whose representational content is R, one is given, not some cipher which represents R, but R itself. (Of course, people differ as to what R is. Some people say it is a sense-datum. Others say that it is a completely mind-independent object. But, it seems, there is general agreement that the sense-perception is not a giving of something which represents this content – whatever it may be – but a giving of the content itself.) The idea suggested by the objector is that Mentalese sentences have the same kind of transparency as perceptions: when a Mentalese sentence is tokened in one’s mind, the sentence itself is not given: only the thing that the sentence represents. But in that case the sentence drops out of consideration altogether.  If there is nothing that has to be interpreted,  then there is a direct grasp of meaning. But if there is a direct grasp of meaning, then the grasp of meaning in question is not mediated through any kind of symbol; and if it is not mediated through any kind of symbol, then a fortiori it doesn’t involve any kind of linguistic symbol. So the idea that Mentalese expressions ‘wear their meanings on their sleeves’ – that they don’t have to be interpreted – is self-defeating. A ‘self-interpreting’ symbol is  not a symbol: if no interpretation is required to access meaning, then ipso facto no symbolic, and so no linguistic, intermediary is involved.
Where nothing has to be interpreted, there is no intermediary. Where there is no intermediary, there is no symbol and, a fortiori, no sentence and, therefore, no language.
This same point may be accessed from a slightly different angle.  We don’t want to say that everything representational is linguistic. We don’t want to say that perceptions, mental images, attitudes etc. are linguistic; for that would trivialize the idea of something being linguistic: of its being representational in a semantic way. It seems that at least part of the reason why my perception of the cat is not identical with some symbol’s being tokened in my mind is that the perception doesn’t have to be interpreted: what is given to me is not something which bears content; what is given to me is the content itself: what is given to me is not something  which represents a cat, but must be deciphered; what is given to me is the cat itself. Now if I see the words ‘the cat is on the mat’, what is initially given to me is something which bears content, but which is distinct from that content. (The words ‘the cat is on the mat’ are presumably distinct from the proposition the cat is on the mat – unless we accept some kind of an extreme nominalism -- and the latter is the semantic content of the former.)  In order to get at that content itself, I must, as it were, penetrate the thing which bears the content to get at the content itself; in effect, I must perform some act of interpretation. Now if nothing has to be interpreted – if the content itself is given, rather than something which bears that content – then we are not dealing with symbols. If things themselves are given to the subject, not representations thereof, then we are not dealing with symbols of things; and if we are not dealing with symbols of things, then we are not dealing with language. As we’ve seen, Fodor must deny that Mentalese sentences are interpreted (otherwise his view involves a vicious regress). And we’ve seen that, if Mentalese sentences are not interpreted, but are nevertheless understood, that is because the tokening of the Mentalese sentence is identical with the grasping of some meaning. So the tokening of such a sentence constitutes a direct grasp of meaning: the meaning itself is given, not some intermediary. But when we are dealing with a situation where there is no intermediary between the subject and the propositional content, then we are ipso facto not dealing with a linguistic situation. To sum up: if Mentalese sentences don’t have to be interpreted that is because each tokening of a Mentalese sentence is an unmediated grasp of meaning. But if a grasp of meaning is not mediated, then ipso facto there is no symbolic medium – no symbolic intermediary - between subject and the meaning grasped and, consequently, no sentence at all. So Fodor’s position is self-defeating. 
Saussure pointed out that, where natural language is concerned, the relation between sign and meaning is arbitrary. (‘Snow’ could mean grass or omelet.) Let us examine Fodor’s hypothesis from the standpoint of Saussure’s insight. Trivially, the relation between a linguistic expression is either arbitrary or it is non-arbitrary. So – what is also trivial -  if there is such a language  as Mentalese, the relations between its sentences and their meanings is either arbitrary or non-arbitrary. Let’s consider each case. First Case: suppose the relation is non-arbitrary. In other words, suppose that any Mentalese symbol has to mean what it does. So snow is white has to mean snow is white; etc. Now what would make the relation between a symbol and its meaning nonarbitrary? Again, a comparison with the case of perception is helpful. The relationship between my current visual perception and its content is not arbitrary; is not a matter of convention or artifice. It is constitutive of this perception that it is a perception of a black computer on a brown desk, etc. (By contrast, it is not constitutive of the following ink-mark – ‘grass is green’ – that it means grass is green.) The reason is that the perception is not the presentation to me of something which mediates between representational content and myself; rather it is the presentation of representational content itself. So the non-arbitrary connection between the perception and its representational content is due, specifically, to the fact that the perception is a presentation, not of a symbolic medium, but of propositional content itself. So if the relationship between snow is white and snow is white is non-arbitrary, that is because any tokening of that sentence is an unmediated presentation of the proposition snow is white itself. But if no medium is involved, then a fortiori no symbolic medium is involved: no sentence. So Fodor cannot say that the relation between snow is white and snow is white is non-arbitrary.
So he must say that it is arbitrary. But if this relationship is arbitrary, then it must be explained why Mentalese sentences are paired off with the propositions in the way they are -- just as it must be explained why ‘snow is white’ (the English sentence) means snow is white:  some kind of psychological or historical explanation is called for. (We can’t say: ‘snow is white’ just means snow is white.) Now the reason why ‘snow is white’ means snow is white is due – at least in part (though perhaps not entirely) – to what people think. In other words, it is human cognitive processes that get ‘snow is white’ to mean snow is white. In general, in cases where the relation of a symbol to its meaning is arbitrary, it supposed that it is human cognitive activity that makes that symbol have that meaning. So, if the relation between (e.g.) snow is white (the Mentalese sentence) and snow is white (the proposition) is arbitrary, then the former means the latter because of human cognitive activity. In general, if the relation between Mentalese sentences and their meanings is arbitrary, then it is human cognitive activity – it is what people think – that gets the former to mean the latter. But if Mentalese symbols are given meaning by what people think, then the meaningfulness of such symbols is posterior to human thought, and thus cannot be identical with it.
There is a related difficulty with Fodor’s position. Suppose for the moment that there is such a thing as Mentalese. In the quotation above, Fodor said that you (or the relevant sub-personal entity within you)  don’t apply knowledge of rules to ascertain the meanings of Mentalese expressions; for you don’t represent these rules: you don’t know what they are. Is this feasible?
Presumably one of the semantic rules of English is that ‘red’ means red. Now suppose that no one knew of this rule. In that case, would it still be a semantic rule of English? What makes ‘red’ mean red? Well, semantical rules are, at least to some extent, descriptive: they say what people understand by expressions and what they mean by them. It would make absolutely no sense to say: ‘red’ means red in English, but no English speaker takes ‘red’ to mean red and no English speaker means red by ‘red’. If no one meant red by ‘red’, and no one took ‘red’ to mean red, then ‘red’ simply wouldn’t mean red. So semantical rules are ultimately  descriptive: they describe  how people use expressions -- what they mean by them and how they interpret them. (Again, primitive semantical rules are descriptive: it is in this sense that semantical rules are ‘ultimately’ descriptive. I concede that derived semantical rules – e.g. the rule that assigns flying penguins are good at three-dimensional chess to the sentence ‘flying penguins are good at three-dimensional chess’ – are not descriptive , or at least not strictly descriptive. I will elucidate this in a moment.)
It is pretty clear that, if someone is to be able to communicate in English, he must have some grasp of the semantical rules of English: in fact, this is trivially true, as I will now try to show. If someone has no idea what people mean by the word ‘red’, then any sentence containing that word will, to that extent, be meaningless to him. And if he does know what people mean by the word ‘red’, then ipso facto he knows (at least partially) a semantical rule for
English: for the semantical rule in question – viz. “‘red’ means red’ – just is a
[237]
	description (inter alia) of what people mean by that word.
To be sure, not all semantical rules are descriptive: the ‘derived’ ones tend not to be descriptive of actual use. For example it is a semantical rule of English that ‘flying penguins are good at three-dimensional chess’ means flying penguins are good at three-dimensional chess. But this rule does not describe what people actually mean, or understand, by the sentence in question; for that sentence has probably never been used. But any basic semantical rule – any rule not derived from other semantical rules – does describe what people mean and understand by expressions. The rule “’red’ means red’ is true precisely because people mean, and understand, red by ‘red’. (The rule is a somewhat idealized description of the facts, but it is a description no less.) So semantical rules are ultimately descriptive.
Given this, it follows trivially that one cannot know a language without knowing the semantical rules for it.  For the semantical rules are just descriptions of what people mean by expressions of that language, and of how they interpret them; and if someone doesn’t know what people mean by expressions, or how they interpret them, then he simply doesn’t know the language. To know the language just i s to know what people mean, and understand, by a certain class of expressions. So it is trivial to say that to know a language involves knowing its semantical rules.
Now if there is such a thing as Mentalese, then there is some set of propositions describing the way in which Mentalese expressions are paired off with meanings; i.e. there are semantical rules for Mentalese. (This is trivially true: it would be meaningless, or nearly meaningless, to say of some language L that there were no propositions stating what meaning are borne by expressions of L.) Of course, Mentalese sentence-tokens (supposing that there are such things) are presumably  understood. (If Mentalese is the language of thought,  then surely something in each of us understands Mentalese sentences.) To understand a sentence token is to know what meaning it bears; and what meaning it bears is, ultimately, determined by what is meant by it or, at any rate, by what is meant – by what thought is intended to be conveyed - by the primitive expressions occurring in it. To know this, in turn, is to know the semantical rule giving meaning to that expression. So with regard to the idea that one (or something with one) could understand Mentalese sentences without knowing the semantical rules for such sentences, that idea is selfcontradictory.
Let me elucidate this last argument. The primitive semantical rules of a language L are really just descriptions (if somewhat idealized ones) of the way the primitive expressions of L are used: of what is meant by them and what is understood by them. (It would be meaningless to say that ‘red’ means red but that no one  ever understands or means red by ‘red’: for ‘red’ to mean red just is for people to mean and understand red by ‘red’.) Ultimately, what ‘red’ means objectively is determined by what people mean by it So there is no way to distinguish knowing what is meant by expressions of a language from knowing the rules that give meaning to those expressions. So with regard to the idea that one could know a language like English without knowing the rules giving meaning to it – that idea is non-sensical.
This point can be brought to bear on the notion that there is a language of thought.  The primitive semantical rules for Mentalese (supposing, for the moment, that there is such a thing) cannot be anything other than descriptions of what contents are in fact borne by primitive expressions of Mentalese. Suppose that the Mentalese expression Red always in fact bore the meaning green. In that case red would mean green; and it would be meaningless to say that red actually meant red. In general, if a mental symbol x in fact bears the message x, then it would be meaningless to say that x really means something other than x; it would be meaningless to say that the semantical rule for x actually assigns it the meaning y. So where Mentalese is concerned, no less than where natural language is concerned, semantical rules are ultimately descriptive: there is no distinguishing what is in fact meant and understood by x, on the one hand, and what it ‘really’ means – what meaning it is assigned by the semantical rules for Mentalese – on the other. So, where Mentalese is concerned, knowing the semantical rules for Mentalese ultimately coincides with knowing what Mentalese expressions means. So with regard to the idea that one could know the rules of Mentalese without knowing the semantical rules for it, that idea is nonsense.
In conclusion,  Fodor’s way of blocking the regress discussed above fails. Fodor’s way of doing this, recall, is to say that we can understand Mentalese sentences without knowing the semantical rules for them. But we’ve just seen that this idea is, to be quite blunt, self-contradictory.
I would like to close with one other point. It has been said (though more often merely insinuated) that only a creature that knows a language can have thoughts, can grasp propositions. Given what we’ve seen, it is clear that this is not the case. It is not possible to know a language L without knowing the rules giving meaning to L. Those rules, for reasons we’ve seen, must ultimately be grasped in some non-linguistic form. So if a creature is to know a language, it must be able to grasp some propositions in some non-linguistic way.
Notes
 
 
 
 
NO SUCH THING AS MENTALESE REVISITED
 
 
Abstract: Another Argument Against the Thesis That There is a Language of Thought.
      Jerry Fodor maintains that we think in a language – that thought is ‘mediated’ by some kind of internal symbolism. Every language has minimal units of significance whose meanings cannot be a function of the meanings of other expressions. Therefore, if we think in a language, then we have minimal concepts that are not to any degree ‘interdefinable’, i.e. that are such that possession of any one of them doesn’t presuppose possession of any other concepts. But it is demonstrably the case that there are no such minimal or ‘atomic’ concepts. Also, if there is a language of thought then any constitutive connections that obtain among complex thoughts become containment relations holding among symbols: my concept of 1,423 becomes a symbol that contains a concept of 1,422, and that concept is itself a symbol that contains my concept of 1,421, and so on. So my concept of 1,423 contains each of these other 1,422 concepts in the same sense that the word ‘hereditary’ contains the word ‘red’. A consequence of this is that, when I exercise my 1,423-concept I am ipso facto exercizing my 1,422-concept, my 1,421-concept, and so on; that is, when I think about 1,423,  I am ipso facto thinking about 1,422, 1,421, and so on. But this is decidedly implausible. There are two possible responses to this: one is to deny that constitutive relations among concepts are containment relations; the other is to deny that there are any constitutive relations among concepts. Fodor takes the latter path – so, on his view, I can have a concept of 1,423 without having a concept of 1,422 or of 1,421. But such an extreme representational ‘atomism’ is demonstrably false; and as long as constitutive relations among concepts are not crudely construed as containment relations, there is no reason to advocate such a position. Indeed Wittgenstein observed long ago that constitutive connections among concepts are not to be equated with relations of decomposability or containment: one’s concept of azure is constitutively related to one’s concept of navy blue, but neither concept is decomposable, even partially, into the other.
 
I.   According to Jerry Fodor, one grasps the proposition Fred is coming home by way of grasping some sentence (or, at any rate, some kind of symbol) that has this proposition as its meaning. Consequently propositional attitudes are mediated through sentences that express the propositions in question. For me to hope that Fred is coming home is for me to stand in a certain relation to a sentence that means Fred is coming home; for me to fear that Fred is coming home is for me to stand in some other relation to this same sentence; and so on mutatis mutandis for every other propositional attitude that I might have towards Fred is coming home. Finally, for me to make some kind of an inference involving this proposition is for me to recognize that the aforementioned sentence stands in some relationship to some other sentence; for example, for me to infer that someone or other is coming home from the proposition Fred is coming home is for me to recognize that a sentence meaning someone or other is coming home stands in a certain relation (a computational – that is, a syntactico-morphological – relation) to a sentence meaning Fred is coming home.
       Basically, one grasps propositions entirely through sentences that have those propositions as their meanings: consequently, there is a ‘language of thought’; cognitive (i.e. proposition-bearing) mental activity is thus ‘symbolic’. In a word: we think in a language.
     One point must be made clear. In maintaining that we think in a language, Fodor does not mean that English speakers think in English, that Spanish speakers think in Spanish, and so on. He means that each of us thinks in an innate, internal language. (Fodor holds – rightly, in my view – that one must be able to think in order to learn a language like English or Spanish. So he is committed to holding that the language of thought is not a learned language like English or Spanish.)
     Why does Fodor think that there is a language of thought – that we think in language? His reasoning is basically this. We are computers. (In any case,
[238]
	the ‘best models of cognitive activity are computational’. So, pending some extraordinary development in cognitive psychology, we should work on the assumption that we are computers.) A computer is an information processing engine. Information is embodied in a computer in a kind of internal code: in something that is, in effect, a language. Consequently, a computer processes information by processing strings of code – things that are, in effect, sentences. So any access to information, and thus to propositions,  that a computer has is mediated through its access to a sentence that bears that information.
     If this characterization of what it is to be a computer is correct, and if we are computers, then it very much seems to follow that our mental activity consists in sentence processing, and that our access to information is mediated entirely through sentences that bear that information.
     In this paper I will set forth one reason – not found, to my knowledge,  in the growing literature on this question – to reject the idea that there is a language of thought. The argument set forth in this paper, supposing it cogent, has a fair amount of scope. As we just noted,  if we are computers, then there must be a language of thought. In any case, this follows if the just given characterization of what it is to be a computer is accurate: and that characterization is a fairly standard one. So if there is no language of thought, then (assuming the correctness of that characterization), it follows that we are not computers: and this, of course, would not be a trivial result.
    It must be said that virtually everyone who believes in the computational theory of mind believes that there is some kind of language of thought or, at any rate, some kind of internal code. And prima facie the former position seems to presuppose the latter. In any case, I think that Fodor is right to say that if we are computers, then there is a language of thought.
     But of course the question whether there is a language of thought is worth investigating in its own right, regardless of any bearing it might or might not have on the validity of this or that theory of mind.
      The question whether there is, or even could be, a language of thought is an acutely controversial one. Usually, when the idea of a language of thought is attacked, the attack is to the effect that the intentionality borne by symbols is derivative of that borne by mental entities: basically, symbolic intentionality – and thus the very existence of symbols – presupposes some other kind of intentionality and, therefore, some non-symbolic mental
[239]
	activity. Those who believe that there is a language of thought counterattack by saying that this criticism begs the question: if there is a language of thought, then with regard to the age-old view that symbolic intentionality is, in general, derivative, that view is simply false and needs to be thrown out or
[240]
circumscribed.
    The argument set forth in this paper represents a completely different line of attack and is therefore not vulnerable to anything that has been said in connection with the question whether symbolic intentionality is derivative.
II.     Let us refer to one’s ability to represent an object or property as a ‘representational capacity’ or as a ‘concept’. (So I will use the terms
[241]
	‘concept’ and ‘representational capacity’ interchangeably.) So, for example, in virtue of being able have thoughts about Bob, one has a certain representational capacity or concept. In virtue of being able to see objects as being of a certain color, or as having a certain shape, one has a certain representational capacity.
     Now these days it is widely held that representational capacities have ‘constitutive connections’ to one another; that they come in bundles and not singly. To embody this point in some terminology: some kind of ‘molecularism’ or ‘holism’ – some kind of ‘non-atomism’ -- about representational capacities is widely countenanced; and representational ‘atomism’ is generally held to be false. Significantly, Fodor himself is an
[242] atomist. 
        What does all of this mean? What does it mean to say that representational capacities have ‘constitutive’ connections to one another? Obviously we can see physical objects as being triangular. Presumably, one could not represent things as being triangular to oneself unless one could also represent various other things to oneself: e.g. space, straight lines, angles. So if one can represent  things to oneself as being triangular, then necessarily one can represent things to oneself as being straight, and as being in space, and as intersecting. Also, one must presumably have some grasp of number: to grasp a triangle, one must grasp the idea of three different lines. And to grasp the concept three, one must surely grasp other number concepts. (One couldn’t grasp the concept three unless one grasped the concepts two and one, not to mention various other concepts.) The concept of number would seem to have constitutive connections to the concept of order: if one grasps the former concept, surely one necessarily has some concept, however vague, of the latter.
     The ‘necessarily’ here is not causal. The connection between being able to represent things to oneself as being in space does not have a causal connection to one’s being able to represent things to oneself as triangular. The connection is much stronger than that: what it is to be able to represent things as being triangular is to be able to see them as being in space, and as being bounded by intersecting lines, etc. So the one representational capacity makes up the other.
       Prima facie every representational capacity one might think of has constitutive connections to others. This is obviously true of those capacities whereby we are able to represent complex things (in their complexity) to ourselves. And it is also true – though, perhaps, less obviously – of our ability to represent to ourselves those things that are ‘simple’ or, at any rate, those things that are the best candidates for that title. In fact, by a curious reversal, it sometimes takes a heavier representational arsenal to represent simple things (in their simplicity) to oneself than it does to represent complex things. Just as a formidable technology is needed to isolate, say, pure oxygen or to produce a hard vacuum, so a formidable cognitive machinery is needed to isolate, say, the concept of a point or that of a line. Surely a space-time point is as good a candidate as any for the title ‘simple object’. But the concept of a space-time point is a highly sophisticated and derivative concept, and is necessarily deeply embedded in other concepts; for the concept of a point can (at least by some reasonable accounts) only be grasped via other concepts. A point is the intersection of two lines or is a kind of degenerate line; or a point is (this is Whitehead’s definition) a maximal class of spheres such that, given any two of them, one contains the other. (Whitehead’s definition is counterintuitive  but logically unexceptionable.) And one’s ability to represent these concepts, in their turn, is necessarily embedded in yet other representational capacities. (A line can only be thought of in a roundabout way: as, for example, the intersection of two planes or as a degenerate space. So one’s ability to represent lines is necessarily embedded in some other representational capacities – e.g. one’s ability to represent planes etc.) Basically, ontological simplicity often corresponds to staggering conceptual and, therewith, cognitive complexity.
     What these all too brief remarks are meant to illustrate is that there is good reason to believe that representational capacities are constitutively (not just causally) connected to one another; that they are not discrete -- not separable into distinct, mutually exclusive bundles.
   I will provide a genuine argument for this thesis later on. So far, I’ve only been trying to show that a non-atomism about representational capacities is to be given some credence.
     Let me now outline the argument I will set forth. Any language that is represented in our minds – and presumably the language of thought, supposing that it exists, is such a language – must have  a finite number of primitive symbols. These symbols will, of course, be completely discrete; they will be completely separate from each other. If two symbols are not separate, that means one contains the other. And if one contains the other, then ipso facto one of them is not primitive. (The word ‘doghouse’ contains the word ‘house’ and is ipso facto not a primitive expression of English.) So the primitive expressions of the language of thought must be separate – must not contain one another. Now if we think in a language, then these expressions will be our basic concepts: if we think in a language, then expressions are our concepts, and primitive expressions are our primitive concepts – our basic representational capacities. But if the conceptual nonatomism just outlined is correct – and I will argue at length (in section VI) that it is -- then there are no primitive concepts: there are no basic representational capacities: any such capacity necessarily exists in a ‘space’ of others. Therefore, we cannot literally think in a language: there is no language of thought – there is no internal code that mediates our thoughts.
Now I would like to delineate and defend this line of thought.
    
III. According to the thesis under examination,  we access propositions – e.g. a square peg of such and such dimensions cannot fit in a round hole of thus and such dimensions – by way of grasping a sentence that expresses that proposition. It would very much seem to follow that we grasp the concepts composing this proposition by way of symbols that represent them. If I can access the proposition a square peg of  such and such dimensions cannot fit in a round hole of thus and such dimensions only by way of accessing some sentence that has this proposition as its meaning, then, surely, I can access the concepts composing this proposition by way of grasping certain symbols that denote them: a symbol meaning round, one meaning square, etc.
      So, assuming that there is a language of thought,  one grasps the concept roundness wholly by way of grasping a symbol that denotes (or expresses) this concept. Supposing that roundness is the Mentalese symbol denoting the concept roundness -- one’s ability to represent roundness to oneself is, in effect, identical with the Mentalese symbol roundness (or, to speak more strictly, with one’s being in possession of this symbol): if we think in Mentalese, then the Mentalese expression roundness is one’s concept of roundness. In general, if we think in Mentalese, then Mentalese expressions are our concepts.
      As we noted earlier, it is widely held that representational capacities are not discrete; they permeate one another; or, to use a different image, they come only in mutually entangled bundles. But symbols are utterly discrete. To make this clear: one’s ability to represent triangles to oneself is permeated by one’s ability to represent lines, space, angles, etc. to oneself. And each of these abilities is, by all accounts, permeated by other representational abilities. But any symbol that denotes the property of being a triangle or a line is perfectly discrete; the words ‘line’, ‘angle’, ‘plane’, ‘point’, ‘rigidity’, etc. are as discrete – as distinct from one another – as they could possibly be. Symbols are, of their very nature, discrete things; it makes no sense to speak of symbols that have ‘constitutive connections’ to one another or that ‘permeate one another’. Such talk applies to concepts (and abilities), but not to symbols. Therefore such talk does not apply to Mentalese symbols, supposing that there are such things. The Mentalese symbols ‘line’ and ‘triangle’ are (if they exist) as distinct from each other as the English words ‘line’ and ‘triangle’.
      So if representational capacities are interconnected, and do not come in mutually isolable packages, then these capacities are in no way identical with discrete symbols; and, consequently, my ability to think about roundness is in no way identical with my being in possession of a Mentalese word that means round.
     This point applies to our ability to grasp propositions. Obviously if one’ s ability to think about triangles is constitutively bound up with one’s ability to think about e.g. planes, then so is one’s ability to grasp propositions involving the concept of triangularity. Indeed, it is highly reasonable to suppose – and deeply counter-intuitive not to suppose – that one’s ability to grasp the proposition alpha is a triangle is constitutively bound up with one’s ability to grasp the propositions alpha is planar and alpha is in space etc. Basically, not surprisingly, what is true of our abilities to represent concepts is true of our abilities to grasp propositions: the latter, like the former, are interconnected.
   Of course, according to the thesis under scrutiny, one’s grasp of the propositions alpha is a triangle and alpha is planar is identical with one’s grasp of sentences that express these propositions. As  we just noted, one’s ability to grasp the one proposition is not isolable from one’s ability to grasp the other. But the sentence ‘alpha is a triangle’ is utterly distinct from the sentence ‘alpha is flat’; and the same, presumably, is true of the Mentalese translations of these sentences. So the Mentalese sentences Alpha is flat and Alpha is a triangle are distinct; and, for reasons already discussed, if we think in sentences, then one’s ability to grasp the corresponding propositions is identical with one’s being in possession of tokens of these sentences. Obviously the sentences are completely distinct; they are as distinct as can be. So, presumably, one’s possession of the one sentence is as distinct as can be from one’s possession of the other. But obviously one’s ability to grasp the one proposition is not isolable – at least not in its entirety – from one’s ability to grasp the other.  So – if some kind of representational non-atomism is the case – then one’s ability to think alpha is flat is not identical with some sentence.
    To summarize: we do not think alpha is flat ‘in’ a sentence; we do not grasp that proposition by way of grasping (or tokening) an internal sentence that expresses that proposition. For any sentence that means alpha is flat will be completely and utterly distinct from any sentence that means alpha is a triangle. But one’s grasp of the one proposition is very much not separate from – is indeed essentially connected to – one’s ability to grasp the other. So we don’t grasp e.g. alpha is flat ‘in’ any language (in any case, we do not have to so grasp it); we do not – at least not  in general -- grasp propositions ‘in’ any language: there is no language of thought.
     The foregoing was really just a sketch and, like any sketch for a controversial position, is open to innumerable objections. Before considering some of these objections, I’d like to slightly touch up what was just said. One point in particular needs to be addressed.
      Obviously the English words ‘line’ and ‘triangle’ are totally different from each other. But the corresponding Mentalese words are not different from each other. Obviously one’s concept of triangularity is bound up with one’s concept of linearity. This is perfectly consistent with the thesis that we think in Mentalese. We just say that the Mentalese expression for triangle is defined in terms of the Mentalese word for line. In English ‘triangle’ is a simple expression. In Mentalese – since this is the medium of thought – the word for ‘triangle’ is complex, and its connectedness to other concepts -- e.g. ‘line’, ‘plane’ -- can be read off its formal structure: so the Mentalese expression for ‘triangle’ would be (perhaps) ‘closed, three sided, planar figure.’ Given this, it isn’t true that Mentalese expression for ‘triangle’ is distinct from the Mentalese symbol for e.g. ‘line’: the two symbols are interconnected in just the same way as the corresponding concepts. So your argument falls through.
 
      This is an important counter-objection. But there are several reasons why it doesn’t work. First of all, any language has ‘minimal units of significance’ (morphemes). This is not a contingent fact about natural languages; it is a necessary fact about any language – at least any that can be known by a human. Mentalese, supposing that it exists, can obviously be known. So Mentalese cannot have an infinitely large primitive vocabulary. (Surely we should reject any model of cognition that imputes to us knowledge of infinitely many primitive semantic rules.)
     If we think in Mentalese, then the morphemes of Mentalese are the basic units of our thought. Those concepts would be primitive, at least from our point of view. This means that they would not have constitutive interconnections to one another: if one concept C1 is to any degree constitutive of some other concept C2, then ipso facto C2 is not primitive; it represents some kind of an intersection or derivative of other concepts.       So if we really think in a language, then some of our concepts are primitive: for a language has minimal units of significance. Consequently, if we think in Mentalese, then its primitive units of significance – and it must have such units -- are our primitive concepts. So we must have primitive concepts. Primitive concepts are isolated; given that they are primitive, they ipso facto do not presuppose other concepts and thus exist in a kind of vacuum.
      But there are no primitive concepts. So we do not think in a language. Of course, the view that there are no primitive concepts needs to be defended: I will provide an extensive defense of it in a moment. This defense is not, so far as I know, already in the literature and, importantly, it is therefore not considered by Fodor in Concepts.
        Permit me to clarify the line of thought just set forth. The term ‘triangle’ can be defined in terms of  ‘line’, ‘intersection’ etc. Given this, it seems feasible to maintain that the Mentalese expression triangle is defined in terms of the Mentalese expressions angle, intersection, etc. As we’ve noted, Mentalese, like any other (knowable) language, must have minimal units of significance. So the definition for triangle must terminate in such units. Obviously, these minimal units are not defined in terms of one another: they are wholly discrete. So once again consider the Mentalese term triangle and suppose that m1, m2…mn are the ultimate Mentalese expressions  in terms of which triangle is defined. In that case, each of m1, m2…mn is totally isolated from every other expression in the language; each of these terms corresponds to a concept that does not presuppose any others. So we cannot say about m1, m2…mn what the object says about ‘triangle’ and ‘line’. It is arguable that, while the English expression ‘triangle’ is distinct form the English expression ‘line’, the same is not true of the corresponding Mentalese expressions. But we cannot coherently take this view of m1, m2…mn: these expressions are distinct and completely non-interdefinable. Consequently, supposing we think in Mentalese, these expressions  are the minimal units of thought, and they bound our thought: they are, in short, concepts that have no constitutive connections to one another.
    But there are no such concepts. One of the most striking and celebrated failings of logical positivism was precisely its belief that there are such concepts: that there are primitive, foundational concepts such that all concepts are either identical with, or built out of, these.
    So our initial point prevails. Concepts come bundled; lexical items do not come bundled. Therefore, lexical items cannot be our concepts. Therefore we do not think in lexical items; we do not think in any language.        There is another reason why the objector’s point fails; it conflates semantic analysis with conceptual analysis. It makes thoughts like that is a sphere be identical with very different, but necessarily equivalent, thoughts – e.g. thoughts like that is a closed three-dimensional figure of uniform curvature.
   Consider the sentences ‘alpha is an object whose surface points are a given distance from some particular point’ and ‘alpha is a closed three-dimensional figure of uniform curvature.’ Obviously these sentences necessarily have the same truth-conditions. But, just as obviously, they are not synonymous. The propositions they express involve very different concepts. (One involves the concept curvature, the other does not; one involves the concept point, the other does not.) So, plainly, these propositions are different from each other, even though they are necessarily equivalent.
    Now each of the two propositions just considered gives an unexceptionable analysis of the sentence ‘that is a sphere.’ Each of these propositions makes explicit what is, in some sense, implicit in ‘that is a sphere.’
     At the same time, the sentence ‘alpha is a sphere’ is not, on that account, ambiguous. It is a sentence that has onesemantics, but that admits of different conceptual analyses. In fact, there are as many different conceptual analyses of ‘that is a sphere’ as there are axiomatizations of geometry: infinitely many. But ‘that is a sphere’ is surely not infinitely ambiguous; it is not ambiguous at all. So conceptual analysis and semantic analysis are not the same thing: a single semantic analysis may correspond to a multiplicity of conceptual analyses. 
            What is the bearing of this on the question whether we think in a language or symbolic code? According to the proposal under examination, we grasp the proposition that is a sphere entirely through some Mentalese sentence that has that proposition for its meaning. Now our ability to grasp that proposition obviously has constitutive connections to our ability to grasp other propositions (e.g. that is planar). So given that we grasp these propositions wholly through sentences, it follows that the constitutive connections holding between these different propositional capacities must be reflected in the structure of the sentences themselves: the Mentalese sentence for that is a sphere must quite literally contain the Mentalese sentence for that is planar and also for that is in space and also for that has a continuously changing perimeter and that has a uniform radius. For the only constitutive relations that obtain among symbols are containment relations: like the relation holding between the expression ‘figure with three sides’ and the expression ‘sides’. So, if we think in Mentalese, then the thought that is a sphere must, in a literal sense, ‘decompose’ into some thought containing all the concepts that are constitutively connected to that thought: it must decompose into a thought that is composed of the concepts for curvature, closure, space, uniformity, and so on. Basically, if we think in Mentalese, then the thought that is a sphere must be identical with some analysis of that thought: with some thought like that is a closed three-dimensional figure of uniform curvature or that is a closed three-dimensional figure with a uniform radius.
      But the thought that is a sphere is different from, though constitutively connected with, the thought that is a closed planar figure of uniform curvature. If they weren’t different, then the thought if that is a sphere, then that is a closed planar figure of uniform curvature would be as trivial, and would involve as little intelligence, as the thought if that is a sphere, then that is a sphere. So the thought ‘that is a sphere’ – while constitutively connected with the ability to think that is a closed planar figure of uniform curvature – does not in any sense contain the latter thought or vice versa. Now if we think in symbols, then constitutive connections among thoughts are containment relations among symbols. So the thought that is a sphere would literally contain the thought that is a closed figure of uniform curvature and also that is a closed figure of uniform radius – along with every other thought constitutively connected to that is a sphere. But this picture doesn’t correspond to how our thoughts interrelate: the thought that is a sphere does not – in any but an extremely tenuous and metaphorical sense – contain the thought that is a closed figure of uniform radius or, indeed, any of the other thoughts that are constitutively connected to it.
    This, I think, is one of the great weaknesses of the ‘symbolic conception of thought’: it turns all constitutive relations among thoughts into containment relations. Further delineation of this idea shows just how untenable it is.
 
V.     Given what we’ve just observed, there is yet another reason to hold that we don’t think in Mentalese.  As we noted a moment ago, the only way that a symbol can be constitutively connected to another symbol is if one of them contains the other – literally constitutes it (as e.g. the symbol ‘figure with three sides’ contains the symbol ‘sides’).  So if we think in Mentalese sentences, then the constitutive relations obtaining among our thoughts become containment relations holding among sentences. To illustrate this: Obviously our ability to think that is a sphere presupposes our ability to think that is a closed figure. So if we grasp the proposition that is a sphere entirely through some sentence having that proposition for its meaning,  that sentence must actually contain some sentence meaning that is a closed figure.       But constitutive relations among concepts are demonstrably not containment relations. This is most obvious in the case of color thoughts. Suppose you have a concept of some specific shade of pink – say pink1. It is impossible that you should be able to have this concept unless you had concepts of other colors or shades. (I will give an extensive defense of this in a moment. But it obviously has plausibility.) Any given color-concept necessarily exists in a space of other color concepts. But one’s concept of pink1 is not some complex concept consisting of one’s concepts of other shades of pink or other colors. Such a proposal would make no sense. First of all, the idea that one’s pink1 concept is composed of other color-concepts that one has – say, concepts C1, C2…Cn --- presupposes that colors can be defined in terms of other colors. But this is patently not the case; colors are famously not inter-definable. (It may be true that red and white make pink; but ‘pink’ cannot be defined in terms of ‘white’ and ‘red’; and the concept
[243] pink cannot be analyzed in terms of the concepts red and white.) 
     Let us sum up: according to the proposal in question, one’s pink1-concept is some symbol that contains all the concepts constitutively connected to one’s pink1-concept; and these other concepts are themselves symbols. So one’s pink1-concept, according to the proposal in question, becomes a complex symbol defined in terms of – indeed, composed of – other colorsymbols. But color-symbols are famously not mutually-definable; and color concepts are famously not decomposable into other color concepts.  ‘Azure’ is not definable in terms of ‘blue’;  and the concept azure is not analyzable in terms of the concept blue. (Of course, one can say ‘azure is a certain shade of blue’; but this is no analysis of the concept azure. The concept azure is not some compound consisting of the concept blue and some other concept.) But one couldn’t have azure-thoughts unless one had blue-thoughts; these are constitutively interconnected concepts. So the lesson is that constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations.
     There is a second reason to think that one’s color-concepts do not in any literal sense contain other color concepts.  Any color-concept exists in a space of other color-concepts, i.e. any color-concept has constitutive connections to other color concepts. So if constitutive connections among concepts were containment relations among symbols, then any color concept one had would be some color symbol, and that color symbol consists of other color concepts, and each of these color concepts would, in their turn, be color-symbols. But then each of these symbols would, by the same reasoning,  consist of yet other color-symbols; and each of these symbols of yet other color symbols, and so on ad infinitum. Basically, any color thought would actually consist of (not presuppose: but actually be built out of) other color-thoughts. So in having a single color thought, one would actually be having infinitely many color thoughts: but this is not the case; indeed, it would be absurd to suppose that it were the case.
    There is a way to block this infinite regress: say that each color-concept C1 is defined in terms of other concepts, and these latter in terms of still other ones, but that sooner or later we loop back to C1, i.e. we reach some color concept that is defined in terms of C1; so that only finitely many colorthoughts are implicated in any one color thought. But this is patently just as untenable as the regress mentioned before; it makes it a precondition for being able to have e.g. azure-thoughts that one already be able to have azurethoughts: one must be able to have azure thoughts before one is able to have azure thoughts.
      So  constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations of any kind, and a fortiori are  not containment relations among symbols. We’ve seen one illustration of this point. But another one is probably in order.
      Presumably, to have the concept 1,143, one must have the concepts 1,142 and also the concept 1,141 and so on. Now if constitutive connections among concepts were identical with containment relations among Mentalese symbols, then  one’s 1,143  thoughts would be 1,143-symbols that consisted of one’s 1,142-symbol and one’s 1,141-symbol, and so on. But it is very hard to believe that when you have a thought like there are 1,143 apples in the warehouse, you are having a 1,142-thought, and a 1,141-thought, and so on. At the same time, it is patently obvious that someone who was totally oblivious to the concept 1,142 would ipso facto be incapable of grasping the concept 1,143; it is patently obvious, in other words, that the latter concept is constitutively connected to the former. So given (i) that these concepts are constitutively connected, and given (ii) that 1,143 thoughts are not cobbled together out of 1,142-thoughts and 1,141-thoughts and 1,140-thoughts…and so on, it follows that constitutive connections are not identical with any kind of containment relation and a fortiori are not identical with containment relations holding among symbols.
    This consideration demolishes one of Fodor’s main arguments for atomism. Fodor says that there are primitive concepts – indeed, that most of our concepts are primitive. By this, Fodor means, or at least implies, that we do have a stock of concepts C1, C2…Cn such that each of these concepts lacks any constitutive connections to others. (Fodor obviously grants that we can construct concepts that are constitutively connected to others; e.g. the concept is either a man or a horse is obviously constitutively connected to the concepts man and horse. And, Fodor also admits, concepts belonging to ‘bona fide axiomatic systems’ – e.g. triangle, square – have constitutive connections to others: the concept triangle can, Fodor obviously admits, be defined in terms of the concepts three-sided closed figure and therefore has constitutive connections to these others. And Fodor is willing to grant that, besides these, there may be a few other cases of constitutive interconnections among concepts: e.g. the concept bachelor is constitutively connected to those of male and married. But he thinks that the concepts that populate our thoughts are, for the most part, not constitutively connected to others: the concepts doorknob, horse, man, carburetor – practically any concept entering into a thought exists in isolation from all others. One of Fodor’s main arguments for this claim is that most of these concepts are not definable in terms of others. The concept man is not definable – not decomposable into other, simpler concepts. Concomitantly, there is no complex symbol S such that S is necessarily coextensive with ‘man’.
    Fodor is, in my view, right to say that most concepts resist decomposition into others; in other words, Fodor is right to maintain that concepts are not typically composed of – do not typically contain – other concepts. (Fodor makes a good case for this.) But this doesn’t mean that concepts do not have constitutive connections to one another: for constitutive relations among concepts are not containment relations, as we’ve just seen. So this undercuts Fodor’s primary argument for atomism.
VI.     So far I’ve taken it for granted that there are no concepts C1, C2…Cn such that each of these has no constitutive connections to others and such that all our concepts are identical with, or decomposable into, these. But, obviously, this assumption of mine is contentious: now I will discharge it. I will present an argument for ‘non-atomism’ that is completely general, i.e. it shows that any concept has constitutive connections to others, not just some concepts belonging to some privileged class. (Sellars’ classic argument against atomism does not concern, at least not explicitly, all concepts. It concerns, at most, only empirical concepts, i.e. concepts implicated in sense-
[244]
	perception.) My argument has, so far as I know, never appeared in the literature.
    One cannot just see an object: one must see it as having this or that property; as being round or square or blue. And one cannot just think about, or imagine, an object. One must think about it as round or square or sweet. In general, one cannot just represent an object to oneself; one must represent it as having these or those properties. Now it seems that if one can represent one property to oneself, then one can ipso facto represent others to oneself:
each representational capacity has ‘constitutive’ connections to other representational capacities. For example, consider the property of triangularity. If one can represent something to oneself as triangular – if one can see or think about or imagine…something as triangular – then ipso facto one can represent things as having other properties: as e.g. being straight, being planar, being closed. And in order to grasp any of these properties, one must be able to grasp others. For example, if one can think about the property of being closed, one can think about the property of geometrical continuity (for a closed figure is one with a continuous periphery); and if one can think about this property, then presumably one can think about others; for the property of continuity is presumably not a simple one. (Exactly what one must grasp to grasp the property of continuity is a delicate question. But it seems unlikely that one could grasp this property in a vacuum. Presumably one must have some conception of order and, presumably, of location in some kind of space. And, by all appearances, these concepts are, in their turn, not simple ones.) To sum up, it is pretty clear that one could not represent the property of triangularity to oneself unless one had various other representational capacities.
        I submit that this point can be generalized to all properties: given any property P, if one is to be able to represent things as having property P, then one must be able to represent things to oneself as having properties other than P. How is this to be shown? First of all, all properties are individuated, at least in part, by their relations to other properties. And it is, as I will now show, impossible that one should be able to grasp one property (i.e. to represent things to oneself as having that property) without having any conception at all of any other property.
         It is an essential fact about the property of weighing 300 lbs that, if something has that weight, it weighs more than 200 lbs and less than 1000 lbs. It is an essential fact about the property of being square that if something has that property, it has the property of being rectangular and does not have the property of being round. It is a essential fact about the property of being pink that, if something is pink, it is closer in color to something which is red than to something which is green. These points hold mutatis mutandis for any property one might think of. Each property exists in a ‘space’ of other properties; and, I suggest,  one can no more grasp a given property without being able to locate it in a space of other properties than one could have the concept of a given spatial co-ordinate without being able to relate it to other co-ordinates.
   This is obviously the case with degree-properties: properties like that of weighing a thousand pounds or even the property of simply being heavy. For such properties are clearly relational; and the information one acquires in learning of a thing that it has such a property has a patently contrastive or relational character. (Surely one couldn’t grasp the property of weighing 1000 lbs unless one could grasp the properties of weighing more than  1000 lbs and of weighing less than 1000 lbs. And – what is connected with this -the information that one obtains in learning of a thing that it weighs 1000 lbs is obviously  contrastive: in learning a thing a thing weighs 1000 lbs one is learning, inter alia, that it weighs more than one pound.) The question is whether this point (mutatis mutandis) holds of all properties. For example, is the property of being a certain shade of pink in any sense a ‘degree’property? Is it, in any relevant way, like the property of weighing 1000 lbs? Or could one grasp this property without grasping any other properties? I now wish to show that what is obviously true of one’s grasp of degree properties (and of obviously relational properties) is true of one’s grasp of any property, even those that seem quite non-relational.
   For the sake of argument, suppose that there were a creature that could represent to itself the property of being a certain shade of pink but that could not represent a thing as having any other shade. (Let P be this shade.) To that creature, it would literally be inconceivable that an object should be of a color other than P. So from that creature’s view-point there would be no distinction between having the property of being P and that of simply being colored. So this creature wouldn’t really grasp the property of being P (of being a specific shade of pink) after all. To be P is to be a specific shade of a specific color. If you are completely incapable of representing that specificity, then you can’t represent pink, let alone some specific shade of pink. Obviously a creature that can represent only one color can’t distinguish between colors. And a creature that can’t distinguish between colors is incapable of representing the specific character of any color; and thus cannot represent any particular shade of pink. So with regard to the supposition that a creature could represent just one shade to itself, that supposition is a self-defeating one.
   To sum up, if a creature can’t represent multiple colors to itself, then it can’t grasp what is specific about any a particular color. And if a creature can’t do the latter, then it obviously can’t represent that color to itself at all. So a creature must be able to represent multiple colors to itself if it can represent any.
     Before continuing, I’d like to present a different way of establishing this same point. Once again, for the sake of argument suppose that some creature could represent to itself only some specific shade of red R. Since this creature, by hypothesis, wouldn’t be capable of considering different shades/colors, and wouldn’t be able to distinguish between different colors, its concept of color would coincide with its concept of R. From that creature’s standpoint, it would literally be inconceivable that anything colored should not have color R; for to be able to entertain such a concept, the creature would obviously have to conceive of colors different from R and this, by hypothesis, is just what it cannot do. But obviously any adequate concept of R – any concept that deserves the name – must be much more specific, must contain much more differential information, than a concept of color in general. So the creature in question wouldn’t really have any concept of R: it would, at most (though even this is almost certainly false, as I will show presently), have a concept of color in general. But it could not be said to have a concept of any specific shade/color and thus could not be said to have a concept of R. So, with regard to the idea that a creature might have a concept of a specific color without having a concept of any other colors, this supposition is self-defeating.
    An exact analogue of this argument can be given for any property: the property of square-hood, of being an A-flat, of having the timbre of a Frenchhorn. To take one of these examples: suppose that a creature could represent to itself the pitch A-flat but couldn’t represent any other pitch. In that case its concept of pitch in general – of having some pitch or other – would coincide with its concept of being an A-flat. But any concept of A-flat that deserves
the name will be much more specific than a concept of having some pitch or other. So it cannot be maintained that a creature could have a concept of (e.g.) A-flat without being able to distinguish different pitches within the genus of pitch in general. I should address an objection:
 
    Maybe you’re right to say that a creature couldn’t have a concept of some specific color without having a concept of multiple colors. But – by your own admission, practically – a creature could have the concept color (i.e. the concept of being colored – though not of being e.g. mauve) without having a concept of multiple colors. So doesn’t this show that a creature could have a single concept without having a multitude of them?
 
     No, it does not show this. For what we said about having a concept of some specific color (say, R) applies (mutatis mutandis) to the having of any concept, including in particular the concept of being colored (i.e. of having some color or other). For the sake of argument, suppose that some creature had the concept of being colored, but didn’t have any concepts besides. Then that creature’s concept of being colored would coincide with its concept of merely being propertied (i.e. of having some property or other), as that creature could not – by hypothesis – consider, and thus distinguish between, a multitude of properties. But any concept of being colored that deserves the name is surely much more specific than a concept of merely being properties. So the supposition that a creature could have the concept of being colored without having a multitude of other concepts is incoherent. To sum up, there is good reason to believe that, if a creature is to have a concept of one property, then it must have a concept of several.
     There is more to say on this matter. For a creature to be able to represent
(e.g.) a specific shade of pink to itself, it is not just necessary that it be able to represent other colors to itself. It would seem that to grasp the specific character of (e.g.) P, one must (in some way, at some level) grasp how P differs from other colors and shades. To grasp the specific character of P involves grasping what is distinctive about it; and this involves grasping how it is distinguished from other shades and colors. Just to be clear: Grasping what is distinctive about a color presumably involves what distinguishes that color from other colors; and this involves (maybe is identical with) grasping how that color differs from other colors. So being able to represent P to oneself (and to represent things as having P to oneself) involves, not just being able to represent other colors to oneself, but being able to have some kind of a grasp (at some level, in some way) of how P relates to these other colors. And of course, exactly this is true of one’s grasp of each of these other colors. So being able to represent a single property to oneself would seem to involve grasping how a multiplicity of different properties relate to one another; it involves  having an interconnected or articulated multiplicity of representational capacities. 
   This exact argument works for any property, not just P. If you can’t represent shapes other than squares to yourself, then you can’t distinguish squares from other shapes: for to make such a distinction, you’d have to be able to represent these other shapes to yourself (and, by hypothesis, you cannot represent any shapes besides squares to yourself). If you can’t represent these other shapes to yourself, then you can’t represent the specific character of squares to yourself. And if you can’t do that, you can’t represent squares to yourself. Further, to represent the specific character of square-ness to oneself – i.e. of what is distinctive about squareness: what distinguishes it from other shape-properties -- one must have some kind of a grasp (at some level, in some way) of how square objects are (geometrically) different from objects that have a different shape. (And, of course, to represent any of these other shapes to oneself, one must be able to grasp that shape’s specific character and thus how that shape differs from other shapes.) So one can grasp a specific shape-property only if one has some kind of a grasp of a whole ‘space’ of such properties:one must be in possession of an articulated network of representational capacities.
 
 
  Conclusion 
 
  A language can be seen as a two-tiered structure. It must comprise basic expressions (e.g. ‘dog’, ‘cat’) and also complex expressions whose meanings are determined by those of the basic expressions composing them (e.g. ‘the dog ate the cat’). Any language -- at least any knowable language -- must comprise basic expressions. If a language contained no basic expressions, then the meaning of any given expression would be a function of the meanings of other expressions, and the meanings of each of those expressions would be a function of the meanings of yet further expressions, and so on ad infinitum. Consequently, knowledge of the meaning of any expression of that language would presuppose knowledge of an infinitely large lexicon; and we may infer, on both logical and psychological grounds, that such a language would not be knowable.
    If we think in a language, then the language of thought must have a similarly two-tiered structure. It must comprise basic expressions, whose meanings are not a function of the meanings of other expressions, and complex expressions, whose meanings are a function of the meanings of other expressions. The basic expressions would be the minimal units of our thought; these basic expressions would be basic concepts or representational capacities. Given this, let C be an arbitrary one of these basic concepts. What C picks out– what it represents – cannot to any degree be a function of what any other concepts represent. For if what C picks out is a function of what other concepts pick out, then ipso facto C is not, contrary to our supposition, a basic expression in the language of thought. So if we think in a language, it follows that we have some concepts such that what any given one of those concepts picks out is to no degree a function of what any other concept picks out. This is just another way of saying that, if we think in a language, then we have some concepts that operate in complete isolation of other concepts – that pick out what they do in complete independence of other concepts. And this, in turn, means that there are foundational concepts, i.e. concepts such that possession of any one of them doesn’t presuppose possession of any other concepts at all.
   But there are no such concepts. Possession of any concept presupposes possession of other concepts. This is an immediate consequence of some basic facts about representation. It is impossible to represent something without representing it as having this or that property. It is impossible to represent something as having a property unless one can represent what is specific about that property. Doing this involves representing how things with that property are different from things without it. And doing this, in turn, involves being able to represent those other properties. So if one is to represent anything, one must be able to represent other things. So there are no basic representational capacities. For reasons just seen, if we thought in a language, there would have to be basic representational capacities. Therefore, we do not think in a language. For that matter, our thoughts cannot be mediated by anything that is even remotely language-like. For surely one of the essential properties of language is possession of the two-tiered structure just discussed; and anything lacking that structure bears no resemblance to any conceivable language. Therefore, the network of concepts that enables us to think not only isn’t a language, but lacks even the most tenuous resemblance to any language.
 
 
References
FODOR, J., The Language of Thought Thomas Y. Crowell 1975
FODOR, J., Concepts The M.I.T. Press 1998
HORST, S., Symbols, Computation, and Intentionality   University of California Press 1996
SELLARS, W., ‘Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind’ in Science, Perception, and Reality Routledge Kegan Paul 1956
	WITTGENSTEIN, L., 	Philosophical Remarks edited by Rush Rhees.
Translated by Raymond Hargreaves and Roger White.  Basil Blackwell Oxford 1975
 
The Bundle Theory of Personal Identity
 
Abstract: According to common sense, there is more to a person’s mind than the mental contents which that mind comprises: there is some ‘self’, underlying these contents, which has them (in roughly the manner in which a physical ‘substance’ is supposed to ‘have’ certain properties). Many psychologists and philosophers reject this notion, saying that, ultimately, there is nothing to a person’s mind besides the mental contents which it comprises. This view is sometimes referred to as the ‘bundle theory’ of personal identity. A popular objection to the bundle theory is that it is circular: when asked to say under what circumstance two mental contents belong to the same mind, the bundle theorist (it is alleged) is forced to say that they belong to the same self. So the bundle theorist (it is alleged) implicitly defines a self as a bundle of mental contents that belong to the same self. Thus his analysis is circular. In this essay, I wish to show that the bundle theory is in no way guilty of circularity. For two mental contents belong to the same mind is not for them to inhere in some common mental substrate, but for them to have certain causal powers vis a vis one another. A mind can then be defined as the class of mental contents (past, present, future, possible) that bear this causal relation to a given mental content.
 
 
I.   According to one point of view:
 
[245]
	(i) A person's mental contents are all there is to his mind. A person is
[246]
	wholly constituted by the particular mental contents that he has. There is not some entity, some 'self' underlying any collection of mental contents. [247]
 This is not to deny that there are selves. It is to say that selves are composed of (constituted by) the mental contents which they have.
 
 
   Let us refer to this view as the ‘bundle theory of personal identity.’ (We are, if I am not mistaken, following customary usage here.) The alternative to the bundle theory is essentially this:
 

	* A person is not wholly constituted by the mental contents which he has. A person is, at least in part, something which underlies – or, in any case, stands apart from – his mental contents.
 
 (i) has been criticized on a number of grounds. My objective in this paper is to show that one of these criticisms can be met, i.e. that one of these criticisms does not invalidate the bundle theory. It is by no means a weak criticism. (Indeed, given how much work we will have to do to neutralize it, it is clear that it is quite powerful.)
 The criticism in question is essentially this:
 

	* Clearly some pairs of mental contents belong to the same mind while others do not. Your feeling of thirst and your perception of the ice-water belong to the same mind. By contrast, my feeling of thirst and your perception of the ice-water do not belong to the same mind. Supposing that the bundle theory is correct, what is it that makes two mental contents belong to the same mind? The proponent of (**) has no trouble dealing with this problem: two mental belongs to the same mind just in case they are had by the same self. But the bundle theorist cannot avail himself of this response. If he did, his position would be circular. According to the bundle theorist, a self just is certain class of mental contents. So for a mental content to belong to a certain self is just for that mental content to have a certain relation to other mental contents. Let R be this relationship, whatsoever it might turn out to be. R cannot be defined in terms of the notion of f ‘being had by the same self’ since, for the bundle theorist, it is this very relation that R is meant to explain. So the bundle theorist must say what R is without helping himself to the notion of ‘belonging to the same self.’ But there is no way – or, at any rate, no non-circular way -- to do this. With regard to every attempt to define R independently of the notion of being had by the same self, every such attempt has failed outright or has involved some kind of covert circularity. [248]
 
   
     My objective in this essay is to show that R can be defined independently of the notion of ‘being had by the same self’. In other words, I wish to show that we can say what it is for two mental contents to belong to the same mind without any circularity – without appealing to the notion of ‘being had by the same self.’ In a word, we can show that the bundle theory is not guilty of
[249]
circularity. 
[250]
	      By way of anticipation, my analysis is very roughly as follows. It is pretty clear that two mental contents that belong to the same mind have causal powers vis a vis one another that mental contents belonging to different minds do not. My mental contents can interact with one another with a directness with which my mental contents cannot interact with yours. (To be sure, my mental contents can affect, and thus interact with, yours. But various intermediaries – e.g. sounds, overt body movements – are required to do this, and such intermediaries are not required for my mental contents to affect one another.) Typically, it is thought that, if two mental contents can interact with the aforementioned directness, that is because they belong to the same self: in other words, their belonging to the same self is what enables them to interact with that kind of directness. As against this, I will argue that what it is for two mental contents to belong to the same self just is for them to be able to interact with that kind of directness. The relation of being-able-tointeract-with-a-certain-directness is primary, and the relation of belonging to the same self is derivative of thereof. A self, then, can naturally be seen as constituted by the class of all mental contents (past, present, future) that bear a certain causal relation to a given mental content.
        This position may seem obvious. But it is extremely difficult to work the details associated with it. And what I do in this paper that has not (so far as I know) been done elsewhere is to work through these thorny details.
 
II.   Suppose that I feel thirst but do not see a certain glass of ice-water, and that you see that same glass of ice-water but do not feel thirst. Ceteris paribus, the conjunction of that feeling with that perception will not result in anyone's reaching for the glass: no new mental content (no intention) will result from the co-existence of these two contents. By contrast, if I perceive I the glass of ice-water and I feel thirst, then there probably will (ceteris paribus) result a new mental entity from this co-existence of mental entities: I will intend to reach out and grab that water (or I will at least be tempted to do so).
Of course, my mental contents can affect your mental contents. If I am angry, I may yell at you, making you sad or angry. But my mental contents can affect your only through physical intermediaries - certain motions of my body. By contrast, it seems (at least at first glance) that for a single person's mental contents to affect one another, no such intermediaries are needed.
