This suggests a certain way of defining R: ‘two mental contents belong to the same mind just in case they can directly interact.’ (We will soon see need to revise this analysis. But, I submit, it points us in the right direction.)
     Before we proceed to these revisions, one point must be made clear. Given two distinct mental contents that belong to a single mind, those two mental contents may not interact; they may remain isolated from each other. Human minds are not perfectly integrated. Joe's knowledge that pi is irrational may never interact with his hatred of pistachio ice-cream; no mental content need arise from their coexistence. But that is perfectly compatible with our provisional analysis. Two mental contents, according to this analysis, belong to a single mind just in case they could directly interact with each other; it isn't necessary that they actually interact. Given any two contemporaneous mental contents, no matter how different, if those mental contents belong to a single mind, it will always be possible to hypothesize some circumstance under which they might directly interact to form a new mental content. (If Joe is told that either he must yell out the name of some irrational number or he will have to eat a gallon pistachio ice-cream, Joe will form an intention to yell out 'pi!' Here we actually have two cases of mental contents' directly interacting with one another. First, Joe's knowledge that pi is irrational, in conjunction with his horror of pistachio ice-cream, results in Joe's believing that he must yell out 'pi' if he is to avoid eating pistachio ice-cream. Second, this belief combines with his desire not to eat pistachio ice-cream to form an intention to yell out 'pi'.) 
    Unfortunately, our work has just begun. For some profound objections can be made to our analysis; and we must show that it can survive them. More accurately: we will consider some criticisms that warrant the rejection of our analysis. What we will now show is that an analysis very similar to that one in spirit, but slightly augmented, can survive those same criticisms.
    Again, our initial analysis is this: two mental contents belong to the same mind just in case they can directly interact. But it is clear that some mental contents that cannot possibly directly interact can belong to the same mind. For example, ten years ago I had all kinds of experiences. Let A be any one of these experiences. Right now I am having various sensory experiences. Let B be any one of these experiences. A and B belong to the same mind. But clearly they couldn't possibly interact, at least not directly, since A no longer exists.
    There is an obvious way to amend our hypothesis to cover such cases. Two mental contents A1 and An belong to the same mind if there is some chain of mental contents A1, A2...An such that, for each i, Ai can directly interact with Ai+1. (If one mental entity creates another one, that seems to qualify as a kind of limiting case of interaction. So if my experience of eating squid leaves me with a memory of eating squid, that experience may be said to have 'interacted' with that memory by virtue of bringing it into existence.) It seems fairly clear that any two contents belonging to a single person satisfy this condition. Twenty years ago I ate squid. The experience was extremely unpleasant. I know that tonight, if I go over to Mary's house, I will be forced to eat squid (for that is what she is serving). I thus form the intention not to go to Mary’s house. So my experience of eating squid those many years ago has interacted with a piece of knowledge of mine to form an intention. But this interaction was not direct; for at no point did that experience coexist with that piece of knowledge. The experience left a memory of itself; and this memory interacted directly with my knowledge to form an intention. So, mediating between my experience and my knowledge, there was a chain of mental entities (in this case a chain of one - but clearly there might have been more).
   The next qualification to my analysis will require quite a bit more explaining. Our newly amended hypothesis is this: Two mental contents A1 and An belong to the same mind if there is some chain of mental contents A1, A2...An such that, for each i, Ai can directly interact with Ai+1. We must ask: what is it for two mental entities to interact 'directly' with each other? Earlier I said that direct interaction is interaction that doesn't involve any 'physical intermediaries.' (For my mental contents to have any effect on yours, I must produce certain noises or act in certain ways: so for my mental contents to affect yours there must be 'physical intermediaries' linking them. By contrast, when two of my mental contents interact with each other, no such intermediaries seem to be involved.) But to this point, an important objection can be made:
 
    First of all, if any form of materialism is correct, then any two mental contents are physical; and if that is the case, then whenever two mental contents interact, this interaction does involve physical events. From this, presumably, it would follow any such interaction involves 'physical intermediaries.'
 
      
   If materialism is correct, then whenever two mental contents interact, this interaction certainly involves physical processes. But it doesn't follow these any of these processes qualify as intermediaries. Suppose that mental contents A and B interaction through some physical process C. If C is to be an intermediary process, it cannot be constitutive of either A or B; it must (so to speak) lie between them and must therefore not be a part of either. What I wish to show is that direct interaction between two mental contents doesn't involve any physical intermediaries, though (if materialism is correct) it certainly involves physical processes.
   The concept of direct interaction must be analyzed one way if materialism is correct, and another way if dualism is correct. (Actually, as we will later see, these two analyses collapse into one. But it will conduce to clarity to state them separately.) In this section I will try to show (a) that if dualism is correct, two mental entities interact directly if their interaction involves no physical intermediaries. Then I will try to show (b) that if materialism is correct, then two mental entities directly interact if at least some of the physical processes constitutive of the one mental entity can affect at least some of the physical processes of the other mental entity without having to do so through any physical intermediary whatsoever - if, in other words, these two sets of processes can, to some extent at least, affect each other not via any intermediary processes.
    A parenthetical point:  (b) might seem circular: I am saying that two mental entities directly interact if the physical processes constitutive of them directly interact. So I seem to be defining 'direct interaction' in terms of itself. But what is really happening is that I am defining the obscure concept of direction interaction of mental entities in terms of the quite distinct, and much less problematic (in any case, much less philosophically problematic) notion of direct of interaction of physical entities. So I am not defining any concept in terms of itself.
     First let us try to prove (b). Suppose I have a desire for money, and suppose that you have a strong desire to help out anyone who needs money. If I make certain noises - if, for example, I say 'I desperately need money; otherwise my life will meaningless. You're the only one who will help me' this may well affect what mental contents you have. In particular, it may create in you an intention to give me money. But consider the physical act by means of which I got you to have this intention. This act consisted of various movements in my body which resulted in various disturbances of the atmosphere in your vicinity. Though they are causally related to my desire and to your intention, these bodily movements and atmospheric disturbances have absolutely no logical relation to either. In other words, these physical processes do not constitute either of these mental contents. So, in principle, and even in fact, I could have that desire and you could have that intention quite independently of whether the aforementioned bodily and atmospheric phenomena occurred.
     Now let us consider a case where two mental contents belonging to a single mind interact with each other. Suppose that my desire for ice-water interacts with my perception of a glass of ice-water to form an intention to reach out and grab the glass. If materialism is correct - as it may well be - this interaction consists entirely of some physical process. But what physical processes are involved in this interaction? Those that constitute the two mental contents. So two mental contents directly interact if (a) they interact and (b) no physical processes other than those constituting those mental contents are involved in this interaction. Of course, this amounts to saying that two mental contents directly interact if they interact and nothing other than those mental contents are involved in that interaction - if, in effect, this interaction doesn't involve any intermediaries. (This, of course, is just what we've held all along.)
    But this proposal will no doubt be met with an objection:
 
   Suppose that a desire of mine directly interacts with a perception of mine to form an intention. Maybe the desire and the intention are 'connected' to each other via physical processes that do not to any degree constitute either of those contents - just as the flicking of a switch is connected to the subsequent illumination of a certain light-bulb via processes that are not constitutive of either of these events.
 
    To respond adequately to this objection I must anticipate a point that I will fully develop only later on. Let A be my feeling of thirst, and let B be my perception of the glass of ice-water. Given this, imagine the following. A and B interact to form an intention to reach and grab the glass of ice-water. (Let C be this intention.) A and B are connected to each other by various physical processes. These mediating physical processes do not to any degree constitute either A or B: A and B are logically and metaphysically completely independent of these intervening physical processes.
     Notice that C is not just the result of A and B. C is in some sense appropriate to A and B. If someone is thirsty and he sees a glass of ice-water, it makes sense for him to have an intention (or at least a desire) to reach out and grab the glass. Such an intention is normatively - if not logically or ethically - appropriate to the mental contents from which it arose. Given that C is appropriate to A and B, it seems to follow that A and B were involved in C's creation, not just in a causal sense, but in some more intimate sense: it seems to follow that A's content - not (merely) its content in a physical or spatio-temporal sense, but what might be called its semantic or thematic content -  and B's content (its thematic content) are implicated in this transaction. (In the jargon of social scientists, the interaction of A and B, whereby they cause C to occur, is not merely causal but also explicative.)      What is true of this particular case is true of many, possibly all, cases where a single person's mental contents interact. The result of such an interaction - the new mental content that comes out of it - is appropriate in a thematic or semantic sense to the mental entities involved in that interaction. I see Wendy walking towards me; I dislike Wendy; I form an intention to run away. This intention is thematically or semantically appropriate to the mental contents whose interaction created it. It would of course be easy to multiply examples of this principle. In fact, it would, I submit, be impossible to identify a single case where two mental contents belonging to a single person directly interacted and yet did not produce a new mental content that was appropriate to them.
There is nothing comparable to this in the non-mental world. Purely
[251]
	physical interactions (i.e. physical interactions that are not also mental) do not have any normative dimension; the results of such interactions are neither appropriate nor inappropriate to the nature of the entities and
[252]
processes involved therein. 
       Let us return to our hypothetical scenario. By hypothesis, certain physical processes that do not constitute either A or B mediate between them:
it is through these processes that A and B interact to produce C. Trivially, either these intervening physical processes transmit or bear A and B's respective contents or they do not. To put it more bluntly, with regard to these intervening physical processes, either they themselves have the same thematic contents as A and B - i.e. they themselves either transmit or constitute a feeling of thirst and a perception of a glass of ice-water -  or they do not have such contents. Let us consider each case. Suppose that they do not have such contents, that the content of none of these processes is a feeling of thirst or a perception of ice-water. Remember these intervening processes result in an intention to reach out and grab the ice-water; remember also that this intention is, in some very profound way, appropriate to the feeling of thirst and the perception of the ice-water. If the aforementioned intervening processes did not bear a feeling of thirst or a perception of ice-water, then it would be an absolute miracle that they resulted in a mental content that was appropriate to such a perception and desire. In other words, if those intervening processes did not transmit the content of the feeling of thirst or the content of the perception of the ice-water, then it would be completely inexplicable why those intervening processes resulted in a new content (namely, an intention to drink the ice-water) that was so obviously appropriate to the aforementioned contents.
     An analogy might help. Suppose you and I are talking on the phone. Obviously what comes out of the receiving at your end is very similar to what goes into the mouth-piece at my end. We explain this similarity by citing the fact that there is a telephone wire transmitting an electrical impulse initiated by the sound of my voice that is retrieved and re-converted into sound in your ear-piece. Obviously if the telephone wire (or the satellite hook-up) were severed, then, although it would not strictly speaking be impossible that what you hear at your end resembled what I say at my end, it would nonetheless be extraordinarily improbable that this should happen – if it were to happen, it would be a virtual miracle. An exact analogue of this holds in the case where my thirst and my perception of the ice-water interact to form an intention to drink the ice-water. As a result of my having the perception of the ice-water and the desire to drink it, a new mental content that is appropriate to these two contents is formed, viz. an intention to drink the water. The feeling of thirst and the perception are what cause the intention to arise (in any case, they obviously bear some of the causal responsibility for this). Now suppose (what may in fact be true) that materialism is correct, and that consequently the thirst and the perception exert this causal influence through physical intermediates. Trivially these intermediaries either do or do not transmit the contents of the feeling of thirst and of the perception. Let us consider each case. If they do not bear these contents, then it becomes inexplicable why it is that these processes should result in a new mental entity (viz. an intention to drink the ice-water) whose content is appropriate to that of the feeling of thirst and the perception of the ice-water – just as, if the telephone line (or satellite hook-up or whatnot) mediating between my telephone and yours is severed (destroyed), then it becomes inexplicable why the sounds going into my mouthpiece should resemble those leaving your ear-piece. So we must assume that these intervening processes do bear these contents.  Now if they do transmit this content, then ipso facto they bear it; and if they bear it then ipso facto these intervening processes – while physical – are mental. (For as we noted, if something non-derivatively bears content it is ipso facto mental, whatever else it is.) In which case, we have two mental entities directly interacting. So once again, the feeling of thirst and the perception of the icewater satisfy our definition of belonging to the same mind: for although they themselves do not directly interact, there is nonetheless some chain of mental entities A1, A2…An such that the feeling of thirst and the perception are in direct causal contact with the terminal links in this sequence and such that, for each i, Ai directly interacts with Ai+1. And, as we saw a moment ago, if we make that assumption, then our criterion of belonging to the same mind is satisfied.
     I admit that the foregoing was dense and therefore to be regarded with suspicion. Perhaps the following will render it more perspicuous and less suspicious. In general, if mental contents interacted with each other through the medium of physical processes that did not themselves bear these contents, then it would be absolutely inexplicable how it is that, so often, when mental contents interact, the results of this interaction are thematically appropriate to the thematic contents of the participants in this interaction. So it cannot reasonably be said that the physical processes mediating between A and B do not themselves bear A and B's contents. Now trivially, either these intervening processes are themselves constitutive of A and B or they are not. (For x to be 'constitutive of' y is, roughly, for x to be a part of y, or for x to make up y.) Let us consider each case. If these intervening processes are constitutive of A and B, then we have proved our point, namely, that A and B interact directly (not through any processes other than such as constitute them).
     But if these intervening processes are not constitutive of either A or B, it by no means falsifies our analysis. Remember, our analysis is this: A and B belong to the same mind if they are both links in some chain of mental states such that, given any two adjacent links in this chain, those two links interact with each other directly, i.e. not through the medium of any intermediaries whatever, be they physical or mental.  At least some of the physical processes bearing A's content must directly interact with some of the processes bearing B's content. We have already seen why this must be so: if it doesn't so, then it becomes impossible to explain why a mental content that is thematically or semantically appropriate to A and B arises from their coexistence. So even if A and B do not themselves directly interact, we must assume that some processes transmitting A's content directly interact with some processes transmitting B's content. Of course, these intervening processes are mental, even if they are also physical. (I will justify this claim in a moment.) Moreover, we must assume that some of the processes transmitting A's content directly interact with A and that some of the processes transmitting B's content directly interact with B. (Again, if we do not assume this, then we cannot explain why A and B share their contents with these intervening processes.) So A and B satisfy our criterion for belonging to the same mind. A directly interacts with some mental processes that bear A's content; these latter contents directly with some that bear B's content; and, finally, these latter directly interact with (are produced by) B. So A and B are terminal links in some chain of mental states or events such that any two adjacent links in this chain directly interact with each other.
   I said a moment ago that at least some of the processes mediating between A and B must themselves be mental. What is the justification for this claim? These intervening processes transmit thematic or representational content. (They transmit A's content and B's content.) Moreover, their power to do so doesn't derive from human convention or artifice: so in this respect they are unlike paintings or sentences, whose intentionality is derivative. Surely anything that non-derivatively bears thematic or semantic content is mental: surely that is sufficient, even if it is not necessary, for being mental. So these intervening processes are mental.
    To sum up:  we have shown that, even if the interlocutor  is right, our analysis still goes through. Even if no process constitutive of A directly interacts with any process constitutive of B, and even if the processes mediating between A and B are physical, we are still forced to hold that some mental processes directly interact with some other mental process: for we are forced to hold that the physical processes transmitting A's content interact without any physical intermediaries with those physical processes transmitting B's content. We are forced to hold this because, if we do not hold it, we cannot explain why a mental content that is appropriate to A and B arises from their coextensive.
   So our analysis still stands: two mental contents,  A1 and An, belong to the same mind if they are terminal links in some chain of mental contents A1...An such that, for each i, Ai and Ai+1 directly interact; and (assuming materialism is correct) two mental contents directly interact if at least some of the physical processes constitutive of the one directly interact with those constitutive of the other; in other words, if, at least to some extent , these two mental contents interact not through any intermediaries. (Remember that, although it looks as though I am defining 'direct interaction' in terms of itself and that my analysis is therefore circular, I am not defining anything in terms of itself. I am defining the problematic concept of direct interaction for
mental states in terms of the less problematic - and, in any case, different concept of direct interaction for physical states.) So  two mental contents directly interact with each just in case they can (at least to some extent) they affect each other not via any physical intermediaries (i.e. not via any physical processes that lie between them but are constitutive of neither of them).    This definition rules out exactly the kinds of interactions that we want to rule out and rules in exactly the kinds of interactions that we want to rule in. My mental contents can affect your mental contents. But none of the processes constitutive of any of my contents interacts directly with any of the processes constitutive of any of your mental contents. So, our analysis ascribes my mental contents to one mind and it ascribes yours to a separate: and this is just what it should do. On the other hand, given any two of my mental contents, it does seem possible either (i) that their interaction should involve the direct interaction of some processes constitutive of the one content with some of those constitutive of the other mental content; or (ii) that it should be possible to interpose some chain of mental contents between them such that each link in this chain directly interacts with its neighbours. So our analysis ascribes these contents to the same mind: and this, of course, is as it should be.
   So far we have said what it is for two mental contents to interact directly assuming that materialism is correct. Now let us defend analysis (a). In other words, let us try to prove that, if dualism is correct, then two mental contents directly interact if their interaction involves no physical processes - and a fortiori no physical intermediaries - whatsoever.
       Suppose (a) that dualism is correct and (b) that for two mental contents to interact with each other, physical intermediaries are necessary. Given that dualism is correct, it follows trivially that no physical event is identical with, or constitutes, any mental event. So, assuming (a) and (b), it follows that something non-mental must mediate between any two mental contents.
   At first it might seem that this non-mental something could be a physical process that represented, but wasn't identical with or constitutive of a mental content. (Of course, this physical process would have to be non-derivatively intentional. If there are brain processes mediating between mental states, surely they are intrinsically intentional, and not intentional in the secondclass sense in which sound tokens and ink-deposits are intentional.) But, in fact, this would not be compatible with dualism. As we noted earlier, if a physical process non-derivatively represents a mental content, then ipso facto that process is, at least to that extent, itself mental. So if (a) and (b) are correct, then mental contents can interact with each other only through physical processes that do not intrinsically represent mental contents. But, as we have now seen many times over, unless we assume that mental contents interact with each other through processes that themselves have mental content, it would be absolutely impossible to explain why it is that, so often, when mental entities interact, the result is thematically or semantically appropriate to the participants in that interaction; in other words, unless we make the aforementioned assumption, we cannot account for the normative dimension of mental interaction. So if we assume (a) that dualism is correct, then we cannot assume (b) that mental entities interact with each other through the medium of physical processes.
    Let recapitulate what we have established. If dualism is correct, then physical processes are not intrinsically representational. If they aren't intrinsically representational, then we cannot assume that interaction among mental states is always mediated by physical processes; for if we did make this assumption, then we would have no way of accounting for the normative dimension of certain cases of mental interaction. So if dualism is correct, then two mental contents directly interact if their interaction involves no physical intermediaries whatsoever.
    Of course, if A is any mental content belonging to me and B is any mental content belonging to you, then any interaction of these two contents will necessarily involve physical intermediaries. So our analysis correctly ascribes A and B two different minds.
   What about if A and B belong to the same mind? Will our analysis ascribe them to the same mind? We have seen that if two mental contents belong to the same mind, then it is possible for them to interact in a normatively or semantically significant way. We have also seen that, whenever two mental contents interact in this way, it is because any events mediating between them bear their respective contents. If dualism is correct, these mediating events must be mental (since, as we've seen, if dualism is correct, physical processes cannot non-derivatively transmit mental content). So we must assume that, given any two mental contents that interact in a normatively significant way, these two contents are mediated, if at all, only by other mental contents - in other words, they are mediated, if at all, by a chain of mental contents such that each link in this chain interacts directly (through no intermediaries, mental or physical) with its neighbours. This concords with our analysis. For that analysis, it will be remembered, is this: A and B belong to the same mind just in case they are link in a chain such that each link in that chain interacts directly with its neighbours. So our analysis ascribes two mental contents to the same mind when, in fact, they belong to the same mind.
    We have given two separate analyses of what it is for two mental contents to interact directly. But it is clear that these two analyses really collapse into one. If materialism is correct, two mental contents directly interact just in case the physical processes constitutive of the one affect those constitutive of the other without there having to be any intervening physical events. (Physical events are involved, but only such events as constitute the two mental contents in question; so no physical events intervening between the two contents are involved.) So, if materialism is correct, two mental contents directly interact just in case there are no intervening physical events. If dualism is correct, then two mental contents interact directly just in case no physical events - and a fortiori no intervening physical events - are involved in their interaction. So, regardless of whether materialism is correct or not, two mental contents directly interact just in case their interaction doesn't involve any intervening physical events.
Now we are in a position to give a bundle-theoretic definition of what a self is. Two mental contents, A1 and An, belong to the same person just in case there is some chain of mental contents A1, A2...An such that, for each i, Ai interacts directly with Ai+1. (If one mental contents creates another, that may be regarded as a limiting case of interaction.) Let us say that A1 and An are Irelated to each other. A self or person may be defined as the class of all
[253]
mental contents I-related to a given mental content. 
 
  Chomsky, Marr, and other cognitive scientists have given us reason to believe that there are deeply unconscious mental processes: mental processes that (unlike those belonging to the Freudian unconscious) cannot possibly be made conscious. (For example, the computational processes mediating language-learning and visual processing simply couldn’t be made conscious.
They are part of a framework that underlies consciousness – that supports it – and that cannot, therefore, itself be conscious.) Let P1 be one of these deeply unconscious processes that is occurring in my mind, and let Pn be some conscious content of mine. Obviously (by assumption, really) P1 and Pn belong to the same mind. But I don’t see how your analysis can accommodate this fact. For I don’t see that there could be any chain of mental contents P1, P2…Pn such that, for each i, Pi directly interacts with Pi+1.
 
(Let us suppose for the sake of argument that there are such ‘deeply unconscious’ process: for obviously if there are not, then the objector’s point becomes null and void) The objector’s point is singularly misguided. With regard to the deeply unconscious processes in question, though they cannot themselves be conscious, they obviously have effects on our conscious contents. Indeed, items of consciousness are supposed, according to these models, to be the results of deeply unconscious processes: the latter are posited (among other reasons) precisely in order to explain why we have the items of consciousness that we do (why have we certain conscious visual perceptions, why we have certain conscious linguistic intuitions, why we experience certain chords as dissonant and others as consonant, and so on). Further, the connections obtaining between items of consciousness and the deeply unconscious processes which, according to the view in question, create them is supposed to be explicative and not (merely) causal; in other words, the contents of the items of consciousness are supposed to be appropriate to the contents of the said deeply unconscious processes. So, if the view of Chomsky, Marr, and cognitive scientists generally, are to be correct, then there must be content-preserving connections holding between deeply unconscious mental entities and items of consciousness. (More specifically, these deeply unconscious processes are supposed to be computational; they are supposed, in effect, to embody the making of certain kinds of inferences – a  computation is a special kind of inference: a purely formal (syntax-driven) inference.  So if the models in question are correct, then our conscious mental items are the conclusions of sequences of inferences beginning with the aforementioned deeply unconscious processes.
From this it follows trivially that our conscious mental contents are in some sense -- actually, in this case a very strict sense: an inferential or logical sense -- appropriate to our deeply unconscious processes.)  The transmission of content, as we’ve seen, involves direct interaction between mental entities. (For as we’ve noted, if an entity is content-bearing it is ipso facto mental; and, as we’ve also seen, if a non-content bearing entity mediates between two content-bearing ones, then if the content borne by the first of those entities is picked up by the second, it can only be through some accident or coincidence.) So if the psychological models in question are correct, then – in direct contradiction to what the objector says -- it is actually de rigueur  to suppose that, given any deeply unconscious content C1 and any conscious content Cn, such that both belong to the same mind,  there is some possible chain (if not an actual one) of mental contents C2, C3…Cn-i such that C1 directly interact with C2, Cn-1 directly interacts with Cn, and for each i, Ci directly interact with Ci+1.
     We have, I think, shown a way to meet one criticism of the bundle theory. But there are others. And we have provided no positive argument for that theory. Right now I would like to briefly show that one of these other criticisms is misguided; and, in doing this, we will find positive reason to think not only that the bundle theory is reasonable, but that it is all but analytically true.
    The criticism is this:
 
     The bundle theory says that a person’s self is nothing but the mental contents which that person has. Now that is the same as saying the following.
Let C be the set or class of some person’s mental contents. That person is C.
   There is an obvious problem with this. Like all sets, C is “modally frozen.” Let C* be some set that is just like C except that C* contains one mental entity that C does not have. C* is ipso facto a different set from C. Basically, sets are individuated by their memberships. So a set couldn’t have had members other than those it actually has.
   But a person obviously could have had mental contents different from those she actually has. In the metaphysical (though perhaps not the deterministic sense of “could have”) I could have watched “Love Boat” ten minutes ago, instead of reading Recanati’s book Literal Meaning. In that case, I would have had different mental contents from those I in fact had.
   So people are not modally frozen; anyone could have had different mental contents from those she actually had. But sets are modally frozen; a set could not have members other than those it in fact has. So people are not sets of mental contents. So people are not bundles of mental contents. So there is something to a person over and above the mental contents which that person  has – some self which underlies them and is distinct from them.
 
  The logic here is technically good, but superficial; and this argument demands a mere change of nomenclature. Consider the following analogue of that argument.
 
  There is something to the nation of France over and above the thoughts and deeds of the various people who compose that country. So France is something quite distinct from the set of those thoughts and deeds. Why? Let C be the set of all those thoughts and deeds. And let C* be some set very similar to C, except that C* contains one thought or deed not contained in C. In that case, C and C* are different sets. But surely some French person might have thought or done something other than what he actually did. So France is not modally frozen. Thus France is not a set of any kind. Thus
France is not the set of deeds and thoughts had by French people. Thus there is something to France over and above the activities of the people making up that nation.
 
 
  For the reason just stated, France cannot be identified with the set containing all and only the thoughts and deeds of citizens of France. But surely France is not something over and above those thoughts and deeds.  For it is impossible, in the strictest sense of the word, that France in world w should differ from France in w* unless some individual in France-in-w differs from his counterpart in France-in-w* (or fails to have any counterpart at all in France-in-w*). Obviously, if the individuals composing France-in-w are just like the individuals composing France-in-w*, then those two Frances are qualitatively identical. At the same time, for the reason the objector states,
France is not identical with the set of deeds and thoughts associated with French individuals.
   The relation is one of supervenience, not identity. Once it is fixed what each last French person has felt, thought, and done, it is fixed what properties France itself has. Facts about France supervene on facts about the biographies of French individuals. So the bundle-theory is true of the nation of France: there is nothing to France over and above facts about French individuals, and their interactions – facts about France are determined, in the strictest sense of the word, by facts about individuals.
   The bundle theory of personal (as opposed to national) identity is true in exactly the same way. For the reason the objector states, a person is not identical with any set. But if two people P and P* are identical in respect of what their mental contents are, then it is impossible, in the strictest sense of the word, that there should be any qualitative differences between them. Once the facts about a person’s mental contents are settled, everything about that person is ipso facto settled. So there is no reason to posit a self distinct from those mental contents. To do so would be to posit idle machinery; it would be like a positing a self underlying the activities of various French individuals – that self being the true nation of France. But such a manoeuvre would be absurd – would be metaphysical extravagance. There are various French people, doing and thinking various things. There is not some ur-entity – some Hegelian uber-geist – of which these various activities are manifestations. And positing some such ur-entity would be explanatorily worthless: it wouldn’t give us the “cohesion relation” that makes two acts both be constitutive of the nation of France. Surely we must look for that cohesion relation in some causal connection between the two acts – the cohesion relation holds between the acts themselves, and not by way of some mysterious national “self” underlying those acts. (Of course, other acts or states of affairs might be involved in that cohesion relation; but not, surely, some ur-entity – some national under-soul or whatnot.) The same logic applies to individual selves. It would be non-sensical to say: P and P* are qualitatively different people, but they are qualitatively identical in respect of their mental contents. So it would be idle, if not absurd, to posit a self underlying mental contents. We can (I think we’ve seen) explain the cohesion relation without positing some underlying self. And we must. Given that people cannot differ (qualitatively) unless they differ in respect of some specific mental content, it follows that everything constitutive of a person lies in her mental contents and, thus, that nothing constitutive of her lies in anything other than those same contents: so there is no “self” distinct from, or underlying, a person’s mental contents.

Blackburn, Simon

Carruthers, Peter
 
[1] Introducing Persons  Croom and Helm 1986
 
 
Hume, David
 
[1]  A Treatise Concerning Human Nature Edited, with an Analytical Index, by L.A. Selby-Bigge; Second Edition, with text revised and variant readings by P.H. Nidditch. Oxford at the Clarendon Press 1978
 
Olson, Eric
[1] The Human Animal, Oxford University Press 1997
 
Parfit, Derek
[1] Reasons and Persons Oxford University Press 1984
 
Sartre, Jean-Paul
 
[1] The Transcendence of the Ego : an existentialist theory of consciousness /
Translated and annotated with an introduction by Forrest Williams and Robert Kirkpatrick. -- New York : Noonday Press, [1957].
 
Stern, Cindy
 
[1] 'Hume and the Self at a Moment' in History of Philosophy Quarterly volume 4, number 2, April 1987

Functionalism incompatible with the causal efficacy of the mental qua mental
 
 
Abstract: According to functionalism, for x to be an instance of a particular mental type (e.g. the type belief that snow is white) just is for x to have certain causes and/or certain effects. Functionalism thus makes it impossible to explain how the representational and phenomenal contents of mental entities ground their causal properties. A consequence of this is that, if functionalism is right, no sequence of mental states constitutes an inference of any kind: functionalism allows that there are sequences of states that conform to logical rules, but does not allow (so I will argue) that those sequences embody a grasp of those rules.
 
 
 
    Given any type of mental entity, instances of that type characteristically have certain causes and effects. A belief that 22=4 is likely to result from certain things (e.g. certain sense-perceptions conjoined with certain beliefs and certain cognitive faculties) and is likely to result in certain things (e.g. the belief that 2 has an even square).
   A doctrine known as functionalism says: for something to be the belief that 
22=4  just is for it to have one of those causes or effects.  In general, according to functionalism, for x to be instance of mental type T just is for x to have certain causes or certain effects.
     Another illustration may be in order. A certain kind of sense-perception (i.e. sense-perception with a certain phenomenology and representational content) will characteristically have certain causes or certain effects. According to functionalism, for something to be that sort of sense-perception just is for it to have one of those causes or one of those effects. Put another way, x is (e.g.) a perception of such and such a type in virtue of having certain causes/effects.
        There are excellent reasons to be a functionalist. These are sufficiently
[254]
well known that they needn’t be stated here.
     The purpose of this note is to expose what I think is a serious defect on the part of functionalism – a defect that, it seems to me, warrants the complete rejection of that doctrine. 
     Suppose that you are driving along and you have a sense-perception of a stop-sign. Let us assume that you are cognitively normal, that you have assimilated the mores characteristic of our culture, that you do not wish to be stopped by a police-officer, that you know this particular intersection to be well patrolled by police-officers, and so forth. Under these circumstances, the perception is overwhelmingly likely to induce you to stop driving. More exactly, it is likely to result in an intention to stop driving (various things – e.g. nerve damage – may interfere with your discharging this intention). Surely this is just the kind of cause-effect relationship that functionalists have in mind when they say that for x to be (e.g.) a perception of such and such a type just is for x to have certain causes or effects.
     The question arises: why does the perception induce you to stop? It causes you to stop because it has a certain content: it bears certain information (roughly, it tells you that there is a certain kind of object in front of you); and on the basis of this information, you think there may be unpleasant consequences if you don’t stop. So the perception causes you to stop because it is a perception of such and such a kind – because it is a perception with such and such representational content.
     Of course, all of this is obvious, even trivial. Representational mental entities have the effects they do because (at least in part) they have a certain representational content. Your perception of the rabid dog causes you to flee because that perception has a certain content: it tells you that there is a rabid dog present; and you know that, because of that fact, you should flee. This point applies mutatis mutandis to any mental entity that has representational content. And I submit that a serious problem for functionalism lies in this innocuous point.
     Before proceeding we must be careful about one thing. The word
‘because’ has two very different meanings. It has what might be called  a
‘causal’ meaning and also what might be called a ‘logical’ meaning. In the sentence
 
(*) ‘there is smoke because there was a fire’,
 
the word ‘because’ has a causal meaning; that sentence more or less means ‘the cause of the smoke was a fire’.
    In the sentence
 
(**) ‘x has interior angles adding up to 180° because x is a triangle’,
 
the word ‘because’ does not have a causal meaning. It is not as though x was a triangle at time t1 and that caused it to have interior angles adding up to 180° at time t2. Such a claim would be nonsensical. Instead of saying (**), one ought to say
 
(***) ‘x has a interior angles adding up to 180° in virtue of the fact that it is a triangle’
 
 The ‘in virtue of’ locution eliminates the misleading causal connotations borne by (**).
     We noted a moment ago that one stops at the stop-sign because one has a perception of such and such a kind of (i.e. possessed of such and such a representational content). How is the word ‘because’ being used here? Surely it is being used in the causal sense. Your having a perception with a certain representational content is what causes you to stop.
    I wish to be as clear on this point as possible (it will soon become clear why). Let P1 be your perception of the stop-sign. The cause of your stopping is P1’s having a certain representational content.  So what causes you to stop is P1’s having a certain representational content.
    I do not see how this could be contested. Nor do I see how it could fail to generalize to virtually every other representational mental entity. Let P2  be your perception of the rabid dog. Surely the cause of your fleeing is (inter alia)  P2’s having a certain representational content (in effect, it is telling you that there is a certain kind of dog in front of you). Let P3 be your perception of a tall glass of ice-water in front of you (let us assume you are thirsty, know the water not to be poisoned, and so on). Surely the cause of your drinking the water is (inter alia) P3’s having a certain representational content.        But what does functionalism say about the relationship between your seeing the stop sign and your subsequently stopping (remember that P1 is your perception of the stop-sign)? We know what it should tell us: functionalism should tell us that it is P1’s having such and such representational content that causes you to stop. But what does functionalism actually tell us?  
     Functionalism tells us that us that P1 has the representational content that it has in virtue of (inter alia) causing you to stop. So P1 is a perception of (e.g.) a sign of a certain shape and color, a certain distance from one, under such and such lighting conditions, and so forth, in virtue of (inter alia) its causing one to stop. (To simplify discussion, let R1 be the representational
[255]
	content of P1 – so R1 is, we may suppose, information to the effect that an object with a certain shape and color is a certain distance from one, and so forth.)  So functionalism says that P1 has R1 in virtue of the fact that (inter alia) P1 causes you to stop.
    Now if P1 has R1 in virtue of the fact that P1 causes you to stop, then P1’s having R1 cannot be what causes you to stop. If x is to be a cause of y, then x must be distinct from y, and x must exist prior to (though perhaps contiguously with) y.  We agreed that P1’s having R1 is genuine cause of your stopping. Functionalism says: P1 has R1 in virtue of causing you to stop; P1’s having R1 is a kind of consequence (not a causal consequence, of course) of P1’s causing you to stop. So, if functionalism is right, P1’s having R1 cannot be a cause of your stopping.
     To elucidate this: if x holds in virtue of y, then x cannot cause y. If x is to cause y, then x’s existence must be entirely independent of y’s: otherwise x will not be able to precede y, and therefore won’t be able to cause y.  So if P1 has R1 in virtue of causing you to stop, then P1’s having R1 cannot be a cause of your stopping. If causing you to stop is what makes P1 have R1, then plainly P1’s having R1 cannot be what causes you to stop. If y is responsible for x’s being the case, then x’s being the case cannot cause y to happen. Analogously, if P1’s causing you to stop is responsible for P1’s having R1, then P1’s having R1 x cannot cause you to stop.
    But it is as plain as day that P1’s having R1 is what causes you to stop. You stop because you see a stop-sign. Functionalism says, in effect, you see a stop-sign because you stop.
    Functionalism thus gets the order of explanation the wrong way about. And functionalism gets the order of explanation wrong not just in the single case we’ve discussed, but in every instance of ‘intentional’ causation one might think of.
    Let P2 be your perception of the rabid dog. Let R2 be the representational content of P2 – so R2 is, we may suppose, information to the effect that there is a dog that is foaming at the mouth that is such and such distance away from you, and so forth.
    Your having P2 causes you to flee. And clearly your fleeing is caused by (inter alia) P2’s having R2: what causes you to flee is obviously that your perception (P2) is a perception of a growling, vicious dog.
    Functionalism says that P2 has R2 in virtue of causing you to flee. For functionalism, P2 has R2 because P2 causes you to flee. In other words, P2 has R2 in virtue of the fact that P2 causes you to flee. As we noted, if x exists in virtue of y’s existing, then x cannot cause y to exist. So, for functionalism, P2’s having R2 cannot be a cause of your fleeing.
    Functionalism says that P2’s causing you to flee grounds or underlies P2’s having R2. Now things cannot cause the things that underlie them. So, if functionalism is right, the P2’s having R2 cannot be a cause of your fleeing.
But obviously it is (or could be) a cause of your fleeing.
    To sum up, you flee because you have a perception with a certain content - your seeing a growling dog causes you to flee. Functionalism says, in effect, you see a growling dog because you flee. So functionalism gets the order of explanation wrong.
      Before moving on, let us apply these points to the cases of itches and pains. These days not too many people are functionalists about itches, pains, tickles, and so forth. (‘Phenomenal’ content is widely held to resist functionalist analysis, even by those who are otherwise hardline
[256]
	functionalists.) Nonetheless, if we apply what we said above to these things, it will render more perspicuous the structure of the argument given above.
     A sensation is, pretty much by definition, something which has a phenomenology. Indeed, for something to be a sensation essentially is for it to have a certain phenomenology. And for something to be a pain or a tickle or an itch (of a particular type) just is for that thing to have a particular phenomenology.
      The functionalist says that x’s causing you to scratch is (inter alia) what makes x be an itch – so x is an itch in virtue of (inter alia) causing you to scratch. Now, as we just noted, for something to be an itch just is for it to have a certain phenomenology. So, if the functionalist is right, x has a particular phenomenology in virtue of its (inter alia) causing to you scratch. If this is right, then x’s having that phenomenology cannot be what causes you to scratch. Remember what we said earlier: if S2 exists in virtue of S2, then S1 cannot cause S2 – not even a partial cause. If x’s being an itch exists in virtue of x’s leading you to scratch, then x’s being an itch cannot be a cause of your scratching. 
    But it is as clear as day that it is, not merely the itch, but the itch’s having a certain phenomenology that is a cause of your scratching. And if the x’s having a certain phenomenology is what causes you to itch, then it cannot be in virtue of x’s causing you to itch that x has a certain phenomenology. In other words, the functionalist analysis of what it is to have a certain phenomenology – of what it is to be an itch – fails. Obviously, exactly an exactly similar criticism applies to the
      Before moving on, I should head off one possible confusion:
 
     Let x be some mental entity – say, a belief that arsenic poisons, and let Joe be the person who has x. And let us suppose that x causes Joe to do such and such (e.g. to throw out a jug of water he believes to be arsenic-laced). You have made a big deal about the difference between x being the cause of Joe’s throwing out the water, on the one hand, and x’s being a belief that arsenic poisons  being the cause of this. But this is a purely verbal distinction. x is, after all, a belief that arsenic poisons; so I don’t really see what difference, apart from a purely nominal one, there is between x’s doing such and such, on the one hand, and x’s being a belief that arsenic poisons doing such and such, on the other hand.
 
  The difference mentioned here is not purely verbal. Any given entity or state of affairs will typically have a lot of different properties, and not all of these properties are implicated in a given causal transaction involving that object. The cause of the rock’s breaking the window is (inter alia) the rock’s having a certain momentum, not the rock’s having certain thermal properties or a certain color. On the other hand, the cause of the rock’s having an algae growth on it is (inter alia) the rock’s having certain thermal properties, not its having a certain momentum. Supposing that x is a belief that arsenic poisons, and that x causes such and such, it doesn’t follow that  x’s being a belief that arsenic poisons is what causes such and such. Suppose that x, being a brainstate, has certain thermal properties and thus raises the temperature inside my cranium by some small amount. In that case, x is causing the temperature in my cranium, but x’s being a belief that arsenic poisons is not doing that. So there very much is a distinction between x’s causing me to do such and such, on the one hand, and x’s being a belief that arsenic poisons causing me to such and such, on the other. x, like any other spatio-temporal entity, has a multiplicity of properties; among these is the property of being a belief that arsenic poisons. But it has various others: being a brain-state, it has various chemical and thermal properties, for example. And, strictly speaking, it is meaningless to say simply ‘x caused such and such’ – we must cite the specific fact about x, the specific property had by x, which caused such and such. (No self-respecting physicist would say simply ‘the moon is responsible for the tides’; he would say ‘the moon’s having such and such mass, and being thus and distance, relative to an object with such and such properties… causes such and such.’) So, yes, it is true that my discussion leans heavily on the distinction between ‘x caused such and such’ and ‘x’s being a belief that arsenic poisons caused Joe to throw out the water.’ But this is a distinction that bears the weight I’m putting on it.
    Let us move on. Oftentimes mental entities justify the things which they cause – this is especially apparent where the making of inferences is concerned – and functionalism breaks down in a fairly clear way in connection with this sort of phenomenon. 
     Suppose you believe that
 

	* snow is white
 
and you also believe that
 

	* white things reflect light.
 
Under these circumstances, no doubt, you will have some tendency to infer
 

	* that snow reflects light.
 
So your believing P and Q will no doubt cause, or tend to cause, you to believe R. Moreover, your believing P and Q will justify your believing R. So in this case – and this is by no means exceptional – mental causation coincides with justification.
   We must be careful about one thing. For an inference to be made is not just for one belief to cause another belief to occur: the contents of those beliefs must be implicated in a certain way. My believing P and Q could cause me to believe R without my inferring R from P and Q. My brain might just be wired in such a way that, if I believe P and Q, then I automatically believe R. (Or a belief in P and Q might generate a belief in R by way of purely associative or emotional, as opposed to rational, processes.) For me to infer R from [P and Q], I must see the bearing of [P and Q] on R. So for me to really infer R from [P and Q], a grasp of the content of [P and Q] must be implicated in a certain way in the generation of the belief R.
    So suppose that B1 is my belief in the conjunctive proposition [P and Q], and that B2 is my belief in R. For me to really infer R from [P and Q], it is not enough that B1 cause B2 to occur. It is necessary, also, that B1’s being a belief that [P and Q] be causative of B2. (In other words, B1’s being a belief that snow is white and white things reflect light must be causative of the belief that snow reflects light.) For if B1’s being that kind of belief isn’t operative in the generation of B2, then the representational content of B1 – viz. the conjunction [P and Q]  – won’t be implicated in the kind of way that it must be if the generation of B2 is to qualify as an inference from B1, rather than a mere product of B1. To put this another way: if the transition from B1 to B2 is to constitute an inference from [P and Q] to R, then surely it is necessary, not merely that B1 cause B2, but that B2’s having a certain representational content cause B2: to wit, it is necessary that B1’s being a belief that [P and Q] be operative in producing B2. If B1’a being a belief that P and Q is not causative of the occurrence of B2, then B2 obviously didn’t constitute an inference of any kind from the content of B1.
    What does functionalism say about the kind of situation where one belief not only causes, but also justifies, the occurrence of some other belief? For functionalism, x qualifies as the belief that (e.g.) snow is white because (inter alia) of its effects. x qualifies as the belief that snow is white because, when conjoined with certain other beliefs (e.g. the belief that white things reflect light), there are certain effects (e.g. the generation of a belief that snow reflects light). So for functionalism, what makes B1 be a belief that [P and Q] is (at least in part) that it, B1, causes the generation of a belief that R. So, for functionalism, what makes B1 be a belief to the effect that snow is white and white things reflect light is (inter alia) the fact that B1 generates a belief that snow reflects light.
    But if what makes B1 be a belief that [P and Q] is that it, B1, causes the occurrence of a belief that R, then one cannot really infer R from P and Q. As we said a moment ago, for the transition from B1 to B2 to constitute an inference, that transition must embody some understanding of the bearing of [P and Q] on R. So for the transition from B1 to B2 to constitute an inference from [P and Q] to R, it is not enough to that B1 cause B2: it is necessary that B1’s being a belief that [P and Q] be causative of B2. But, for functionalism, B1’s causing B2 underlies B1’s being a belief that P and Q. In other words, for functionalism, B1’s causing a belief that snow reflects light underlies B1’s being a belief that [snow is white and white things reflect light]. Put yet another way, for functionalism, B1 is a belief that P an Q in virtue of (inter alia) causing B2.
   But recall what we said earlier. A thing cannot cause anything that underlies it; x cannot cause y if y underlies x or (what is the same) if x exists in virtue of y. For functionalism B1 is a belief that [P and Q] exists in virtue of the fact that B1 causes a belief that R. It follows that, if functionalism is right, then B1’s being a belief that [P and Q] cannot be a cause of the belief that R. But if B1’s being a belief that [P and Q] is not operative in bringing about the belief that R, then the latter belief was not arrived by way of inference from the former. As we’ve said, for the transition from B1 to B2 (the belief that R) to be an inference, rather than a case of garden-variety causation, B1’s being a belief that P and Q must be causally efficacious in that transition. But if functionalism is right, it is in virtue of B1’s leading to B2 that B1 is a belief that [P and Q]. Therefore, if functionalism is right, B1’s being a belief that [P and Q] cannot be a cause of B2 (if x exists in virtue of y, x cannot cause y to exist). So functionalism doesn’t allow the generation of one belief out of another to embody an act of inference: functionalism cannot accommodate the existence of inferences, and is therefore false.        
 
 
 
Writer-based vs. Reader-based Prose: Analytic Summaries of three articles thereupon
 
Analytic Summary of Linda Flower’s “Writer-Based Prose: A Cognitive Basis for Problems in Writing.”
 
     This article focuses on the distinction between “writer-based” and “readerbased” writing. Some background points may help us define these terms.      Initially, when you learn about some new domain, e.g. organic chemistry or Bolivian military history, you aren’t able to see the logical and causal relations that hold among the data that you are assimilating. One always begins by learning “brute facts.” It is only later, after one has acquired a certain mastery of the domain in question, that one can impose the appropriate scaffolding on these brute facts.
       Even in the case of disciplines that consists of nothing but principles -purely a priori disciplines, such as math or philosophy – the neophyte sees those principles as brute facts. (Initially, the epsilon-delta definition of the limit is just a brute fact – to be memorized, not understood. Later one understands it.)
       The neophyte’s over-valuation of “brute facts” is reflected in the fact that, in her reasoning and discourse, she tends to rely heavily on formulas and truisms, along with the jargon in which they are embodied. There is little understanding of the concepts on which these para-truths are parasitic.         A consequence is that the neophyte’s discourse tends to be very subjective. It is reflects objective logical relations holding among the data far less than it does the peculiarities of the manner in which the neophyte assimilated that data. Instead of tracking relations of causality and entailment, the neophyte’s discussion tracks facts that have little objective significance,
e.g. the order in which she acquired this information and the relative degrees of emotional salience had by the data.
        One characteristic of writer-based prose is that it is excessively sequential. It has the form: “x happened; then y happened; then z happened…” Presumably this is because facts relating to chronology can be grasped relatively easily, whereas some sophistication is needed to grasp facts relating to relations of dependence (causality, probabilification). A related point is that, in neophyte prose, there is a relative absence of stratification and organization. Irrelevant details are left in, and relevant meta-data is left out.    
       A more objective and illuminating exposition of the subject-matter at hand might have a form like:
 
“Here are the general facts that define the domain under investigation. At time t, x happened. Here is how x’s occurrence connects with the aforementioned general facts. y happened right after x. It is still an open question whether x caused y to happen. Here are the considerations on both sides. Soon thereafter, z happened. It might look as though z happened as a result of y. But actually z came about, not because of y, but because of w. w’s relation to the those background facts is thus and such….”    
 
      Instead of putting forth a heap of data that is organized, if at all, along purely chronological or psychological lines, illuminating prose derives specific data from larger principles and, in connection with this, identifies the causal and logical links underlying the raw data.
      The essence of writer-based prose is that the organizing principles behind it are psychological, not logical. The essence of reader-based prose is that those principles are logical, not psychological. The reader-based author is able to step outside herself. She is able to distinguish subjective facts relating to the manner in which she learned the data in question from objective facts concerning the data itself. Consequently, reader-based prose tends to be more intelligible than writer-based prose. In the latter, the data is embedded in irrelevant psychological accretions that obscure the contours of that data. In the former, those contours are in sharp relief.
         But our attitude towards writer-based prose should not be punitive. In fact, it is probably necessary for first (even second and third…) drafts to be writer-based. Before the data can be organized, it must be put forth.
        There are two aspects to analytic writing: first the data is identified; then the data is organized, analyzed, and processed. It is not always possible – and it is often not even advisable – for the writer to collapse both of these phases into one. If the author allows herself to state the data only on the condition that she has integrated it into the appropriate theoretical framework, then the flow of data will be stanched off and the relevant data may not make onto the page. Writer-based prose is an essential first step in the composition. The problem is not that writer-based writing occurs. It is that it is not always followed by the appropriate reader-based working-over of the crude data deposited on the page during the writer-based phase.
       In conclusion,  as writing-instructors, we must encourage writer-based prose. But we must also encourage reader-based revisions of those writerbased efforts.
 
Analytic Summary of Joseph Williams’ “The University of Chicago.”
 
When someone is trying to master a new subject matter, her prose will inevitably involve errors. In fact, in its early phases, the acquisition of new information may lead to certain forms of regression. This is because what the author already knew has to be reconstituted within the framework defined by the knowledge now being acquired. Here is an example. Legal prose uses a number of terms not otherwise used, and it puts commonly used  expressions to a new, specialized use. When a neophyte legal writer is trying to use some quasi-technical term (e.g. “whereas” or “heretofore”) in its distinctively legal sense, she may momentarily forget the rules that govern its ordinary use: rules that are still applicable in legal writing, even though new rules have been superimposed on them.
     In many cases, errors are not just errors, but rather reflect the fact that the author is attempting to master a new sphere of knowledge and its associated terminology. This kind of regression applies in every case where a new skill is being learned – where old methods that have worked for us so far are being replaced with superior, but initially unwieldy, techniques. So when we encounter an “error” in student writing, we have to ask ourselves whether it is just a slip, on the one hand, or a sign of growth, on the other. If we insist on “perfection” – freedom for error – we are likely to encourage our students to produce flawless trivialities.
 
Analytic Summary of Richard Haswell’s “Solecism: Mistakes and errors.”
 
The basic theme of this article is similar to that of the previous one. We are inclined to see mistakes as simple failures. But in some cases mistakes correspond to a growth in knowledge and competence. As you develop the ability to construct increasingly complex and information-rich sentences, you also expose yourself to greater risk of error. Suppose that you only knew a handful of words and syntactical constructions. So you could say “the dog is hungry”, “the cat is sad”, and a few other things of this sort. Because your discourse is limited to such fatuities, it will probably never involve any syntactical errors. But the moment you enrich your prose with more complex constructions, you make error an inevitability. A Shakespeare is more likely to make errors than somebody who is telling you how to screw in a lightbulb.
     When people learn new syntactic rules – e.g. those governing accusatives like “whom” and the placements of prepositions – they are likely, at least initially, to make mistakes that they didn’t previously make. This is because, in the process of mastering these new constructions, they sometimes misapply them or use them where they are not warranted: it takes a while to internalize this new piece of information, and errors are a part of that process. For example, somebody who learns that “whom” is to be used in cases where the antecedent pronoun is the direct or indirect object is likely to mis-apply this rather complicated rule, and thus to mis-use that word. But she is not to be scolded for this. That would only instill a fear of error that would make it impossible to ever master the new rule. So “solecisms” (grammatical  or syntactical errors) aren’t always mere slips. Sometimes they are only relative slips – they occur in the context of an over-all gain in knowledge (just as a mountain-climber may falter in the context of a 20,000 foot ascent). If writing instructors make the absence of error be the main objective, then students will not do the kind of writing that benefits them – the kind where they try to move beyond what they already know – and the result will be formally correct empty shells. 
 
 
The Computational Theory of Mind: Five reasons why it fails
 
 
 
Abstract: This paper will put forth five reasons why the Computational Theory of Mind fails. These reasons are either under-emphasized in the literature or are altogether absent from it.
 
0.0  Introduction  According to the Computational Theory of Mind (CTM), to think is to compute. Thoughts are computations. A computation is a formal inference. So CTM is the view that any instance of thought is identical with the making of a formal inference.
     But what is a “formal” inference? To qualify as “formal”, a case of reasoning must be identical with a reaction, on the part of some creature or other, to symbolic-inputs. But not all such reactions qualify as cases of formal reasoning: only those reactions so qualify that aren’t to any degree be driven by a knowledge of the meanings of the symbol-tokens in question and are driven entirely by a sensitivity to their forms. So CTM is the contention that thought consists of responses to symbol-tokens that are driven entirely by the formal properties of those tokens and therefore embody no knowledge of what those symbol-tokens mean. In Section 1.2, we’ll give some examples of such responses, thereby eliminating any obscurity from the statement just made. 
     Why advocate CTM? Two reasons. First, CTM, if correct, solves the mind-body problem. When you add two numbers, you are ipso facto thinking. Computers presumably add numbers. (Computers presumably compute.) Therefore, computers, when adding numbers, are ipso facto thinking. We know how a computer’s software is related to its hardware. So CTM, if correct, solves the mind-body problem. (In other words, CTM, if correct, makes it clear how brains are responsible for the mental activity that they mediate.)
        Second, CTM, if correct, solves the “tracking problem” (or so CTMadvocates say and so we’ll momentarily assume). Brain-activity, though clearly 100% physics-driven, is also logic-driven (or, in any case, logicconsistent), at least to the extent that it mediates rational thought.  So, to the extent that it’s constitutive of rational thought, brain-activity, though governed by descriptive laws, embodies a sensitivity to prescriptive laws: where such activity is concerned, the descriptive “tracks” the prescriptive. Nothing that is obeying the laws of physics is, in virtue of that fact, doing anything that can be evaluated--- that can be described as “correct” or “valid” or “false.” (In moving hither as opposed to thither, the billiard ball isn’t doing anything right or wrong, valid or invalid.) And, it seems to follow, nothing that can be so described could be constituted by brain-activity. But brainactivity does constitute activity that can be so described.
      CTM (supposedly) solves this problem. It’s possible to create an environment in which there occur symbol-tokens whose logical properties are hewed to their physical properties in such a way that, within that environment, symbol-tokens occur in sequences that are consistent with the requirements of logic. In fact, not only is it possible to create such environments: we routinely do create them—and employ them. We call them “computers.” So it would seem that CTM, if correct, explains how activity that falls within the scope of physics can, at the same time, embody a sensitivity to the demands of logic and, more generally, of normativity.
 
0.1 Mentalese: the “language of thought” According to CTM-advocates, those symbol-tokens mediating our thoughts are held to belong to a hypothetical language. This hypothetical language is generally referred to as “Mentalese.”
   According to CTM, one doesn’t have to learn Mentalese. Brains are computers. Computers don’t function until they’ve been programmed.
Therefore, our brains don’t function until they’ve been programmed. Mentalese is that program. Thus, Mentalese must be programmed into a brain before that brain can mediate cognitive activity and, therefore, before that brain’s owner can learn a language or, indeed, do anything that involves having any awareness of anything. Mentalese is to a functioning brain what a computer’s operating system is to that computer. Thus, just your IBM came “bundled” with DOS, so your brain came “bundled” with Mentalese.      In light of what we’ve said, it might seem reasonable to say that, according to CTM, one innately knows Mentalese. But if CTM is right, one doesn’t know Mentalese at all, let alone innately. Knowing a language involves being able to correlate linguistic with non-linguistic entities. If I couldn’t correlate snow (the powdery substance) with “snow” (the word), I couldn’t possibly know what “snow” meant. In order to correlate “snow” with snow, I must have some way of being aware of snow that doesn’t involve knowing what “snow” means. Knowing Mentalese would involve being able to correlate the expressions belonging to it with non-linguistic entities. According to CTM, thoughts are identical with Mentalese expression-tokens, and such expressions must therefore be operational if one is to make correlations or, therefore, to know a language.
       So if CTM is right, a precondition for one's being aware of anything (or, therefore, for one's making correlations of any kind or, therefore, for one's knowing a language) is that one's brain be stocked with already operational Mentalese symbol-tokens. So it isn’t by virtue of one’s knowing Mentalese that expression-tokens belonging to it mediate one’s thoughts or otherwise do what CTM-advocates allege them to do.
     To sum up: Nobody knows Mentalese; nobody understands the expressions belonging to it; and it isn’t to any degree by being understood that such expression-tokens facilitate thought.
    In this respect, Mentalese is radically different from English and every other non-hypothetical language. The expression-tokens belonging to English, Urdu, etc. belonging to such languages do not, except in a purely accidental fashion, facilitate thought except by being understood. By contrast, the symbol-tokens of Mentalese, supposing such tokens to exist, need not be understood to facilitate thought. Indeed, it is inherent what Mentalese expression-tokens are that they be able to discharge all of their duties without being understood to any degree by anyone or anything.
     Because Mentalese, were it to exist, would differ in this respect from English, Spanish, and other bona fide languages, it follows (for reasons to be discussed in Section 4.0) that the very concept of a “language of thought” is not a coherent one. Given that CTM assumes there to be a language of thought, and given that (for reasons to be disclosed in Section 4.0) no doctrine that doesn’t assume this bears any resemblance to CTM, it follows that CTM is incoherent 
0.2 The concept of a formal inference: some illustrations We’ve seen, if correct, CTM explains much. But is it correct? We can’t answer that unless we make it clear what, in this context, the word “compute” means. And we can’t make that clear unless we make it clear what, in this context, it means to say of symbolic activity that it is “form-driven.”
      The following three stories will help answer these questions.
 
Story #1 (not an example of computation) Smith, who speaks English, is told: “Jones has two yachts.” On the basis of this information, along with his knowledge of the English language, Smith concludes that the following sentence is correct: “the number n such that Jones has n yachts is such that n has no rational square root.”
  
Commentary on Story #1:  Smith’s reasoning is cogent. But it is not in any sense “formal.” Smith’s thought process was a driven by an understanding of inter alia the meanings of the words he was hearing.
     
Story #2 (an example of a kind of computation) W is a wood-chipper. But W is no ordinary wood-chipper. Suppose that W is fed, in the following order, a wooden “2”, a wooden “+”,a wooden “9”, and, finally, a wooden
“=.” Suppose, in other words, that W is fed an instance of the sentence=fragment “2+9=.” In that case, driven solely by the morphological properties of the symbols that it was fed, W cranks out a wooden “11.” And, W does the same thing mutatis mutandis for any other two numbers. So given any whole numbers M and N, if W is fed the sentence-fragment “M+N=”, then, driven solely the morphologies of that fragment, W produces a wooden sign denoting the sum of those two numbers.  
  
Commentary: There would seem to be a sense in which W can compute sums. It is typically this sense of the word “compute” that advocates of CTM have in mind when they say that to think is to compute. Why only
“typically”? Why not “always”? Because sometimes what they have in mind is the prima facie quite different sense of the word “compute” that is illustrated by:
 
Story #3 (an example of a different kind of computation) Smith has no idea what “1,245”, “241”, “1,486”, etc. mean. But Smith has been told by a source whose testimony he rightly trusts that, when given ink-marks having such and such shapes, a correct sentence results when another ink-mark, having thus and shape, is placed in a certain position relative to the original ink-marks.
