In particular, Smith knows that, given their respective shapes, the ink-marks “1,486” and  “1,245+241=” form a correct sentence when (some isomorph of) the former is placed to the right of (some isomorph of) the latter. It must be emphasized that Smith has no idea what any of these inkmarks means. What Smith does know—and this is all he knows (that is of relevance of the present context)---are the rules of adding multi-digit numerals so far as those rules can be identified with the rules concerning the manipulation of shapes.
 
Commentary: What Smith is doing seems to be different from what W is doing. Smith’s applying the just-mentioned rule involves his having various sense-perceptions (e.g. he sees various ink-deposits) and various beliefs (e.g. he believes that those ink-marks are symbols of some kind or other, and he believes that a correct statement---albeit one of whose meaning he is ignorant —will result if, underneath them, he produces an ink-mark having a certain shape); and his having such beliefs involves his making quite delicate judgments (e.g. he must judge that the ink-deposits in question were produced by sentient beings with certain intentions---he would not see those ink-deposits as tokening the sentence-fragment “1,245+241=” were he to learn that their existence was the unintended result of some explosion involving an ink-filled urn).
      Nothing comparable holds of W. It isn’t because of any sense-perceptions or beliefs or intentions that it has that, having been fed a wooden token of the sentence-fragment “2+9=”, W spits out a wooden “11.” So what Smith is doing in writing a “1,486” seems not to be comparable to what W is doing in spitting out a wooden “11.” 
      And, while there is certainly a sense of the word “compute” in which Smith is computing a sum, this cannot possibly be the sense in which, according to CTM, to think is to compute. A precondition for Smith’s performing the just-described computation is his already being able to upload and process information. So CTM would be guilty of vicious circularity were it given by the thesis that, in this sense of the word “compute”, to think is to compute. So, supposing CTM coherent, the sense in which  to think is to compute is the sense in which W computes, and the sense in which Smith computes is irrelevant.
        We will now see that CTM is indefensible and that no doctrine at all similar to it can possibly be correct. There are five reasons for this. These reasons will given insections 1.0-5.0.
     
1.0 CTM’s failure to distinguish between shape and syntactic form  A story will help expose one reason why CTM is false. You shout the following at me: “if your nose starts to bleed in the next ten seconds, I’ll give you a million bucks.” Let T be the sentence-token in question. As a result of T’s being uttered, I do start to bleed out of my noise, and you duly give me $1,000,000. But it wasn’t because of what T meant that I had a nose-bleed; nor was it because of T’s syntax. It was T’s being loud that caused my nosebleed.
   My reaction here wasn’t symbolic. Even though T is a symbol (or, to be precise, a symbol-token) T’s being a symbol did nothing. For exactly similar reasons, W’s spitting out an “11” isn’t symbolic---even though its doing so was precipitated by events involving symbol-tokens.
 
1.1 This line of reasoning generalized  We’ve just seen that CTM is nonstarter if a symbol-token’s “form” is identified with its shape. But sometimes, when referring to a symbol-token’s “form”, advocates of CTM are (so they say) referring to its syntactic form. Given this use of the word “form”, CTM becomes the contention that thoughts are syntax-driven operations on symbols.
     This contention is easily refuted. Syntax is semantic structure. “Smith loves Mary” and “Sally hates Greg” have the same syntax because the semantics of the one has the same structure as the semantics of the other.      To be sure, those sentences have very different meanings. But they’re semantically isomorphic. Each constituent of the one sentence corresponds to exactly one constituent of the other (“Smith”, “loves”, and Mary” correspond to “Sally”, “hates”, and “Greg”, respectively); and the relationship borne by the semantics of any given constituent of the one sentence to the semantics of that sentence as a whole coincides with the relationship borne by the semantics of that constituent’s counterpart in the other sentence to the semantics of that sentence as a whole. So the relation borne by the semantics of “Smith” with respect to the proposition that Smith loves Mary coincides with the relation borne by “Sally” to the proposition that Sally hates Greg.      Given that syntax is semantic structure, syntax-driven operations are ipso facto meaning-driven. Being the contention that “formal” operations are not meaning-driven, CTM is therefore completely incoherent if taken to be the contention that “formal” operations are syntax-driven operations.
       At the same time, CTM is incoherent, as we saw, if “formal” operations are taken to be shape-driven operations. There is no third way to interpret the word “formal.” So CTM is incoherent.
 
1.2 Shape vs. syntax (revisited): the equivocation that lies at the heart of
CTM
 
 Here is the thinking embodied in CTM:
 
“Form-driven responses to symbolic inputs are ipso facto cases of thought. W has form-driven responses to symbolic inputs. Therefore, W is thinking (it is adding numbers.”
 
 But when this argument is stated in a clear and non-elliptical manner, it becomes clear that it involves an equivocation and is invalid for that reason:
 
 “Form-driven responses to symbolic inputs are ipso facto cases of thought. (In other words, syntax-driven responses to symbol-tokens are ipso facto cases of thought.) W has form-driven responses to symbolic inputs. (In other words, W’s responses to its inputs are morphology-driven.) Therefore W is thinking.”
 
    The second argument is clearly spurious. Presumably because they are aware of this, advocates of CTM typically hold that, even though a symboltoken’s shape isn’t identical with its morphology, syntax can be “coded” into morphology---that syntax can be “morphologized” in much the way that geometry can be arithmetized. This is both false and irrelevant.     It’s false because anything, no matter what it’s shape, can have any syntactic structure, and anything, no matter what it’s syntactic structure, can be tokened by anything, no matter what its shape. (In other words, given an arbitrary shape, and given an arbitrary syntactic structure, there is a possible language to which there belong expressions having that syntactic structure that are tokened by objects having that shape.) It’s irrelevant because, even if syntax can be morphologized, it isn’t, as we’ve already seen, in virtue of its having this as opposed to that shape that a symbol-token has this as opposed to that syntax. So in so far as one is responding to an object’s shape, one’s behavior is, to that extent, not the effect of, or otherwise to be understood in terms of, that object’s shape.
     To be sure, one knows what syntax an object has on the basis of its shape. A large part of the reason that I know the syntax of the following sentencetoken---“John is tall and grass is green”---is that I know what shape that inkdeposit has. But sentence-tokens with precisely the same syntax can be tokened by hand-movements or  by noises; and hand-movements and noises have no strictly morphological resemblance at all to any ink-deposit. (No inkdeposit that tokens “John is tall and grass is green” bears much resemblance to a stream of noises, or a series of hand-movements, that also tokened that same sentence, except relative to rules of projection that were contrived ex post facto to establish such a resemblance.)
    Also, the relationship that holds between (a) my knowledge of that inkdeposit’s shape and (b) my knowledge of its syntax is of a causal, and not of a constitutive, nature. I see that it has that shape. Given that knowledge, along with my background linguistic knowledge, I judge that it has a certain syntax.       To be sure, from an experiential (phenomenological) perspective, it may seem as though in knowing that it has that shape I ipso facto know that it has that syntax. But that’s not the case. What we have is one bit of knowledge (knowledge of shape) leading, by way of (rapid) judgments, to some other bit of knowledge (knowledge of syntax).
   Echoing what we just said, these two bits of knowledge may seem, at the level of consciousness, to come into existence simultaneously. But that appearance is misleading and, even if not misleading, irrelevant. It’s misleading because any knowledge of an object’s syntax must follow knowledge of its physical properties. To clarify these last two statements: If I judge that you’re angry, it’s on the basis of your facial expression, or some such. My judgment as to your emotional state may immediately follow my awareness of your expression. But given that the former is based on the latter and is also caused by it, the one awareness follows the other, however quickly. Exactly similar points hold of the relationship between my knowledge of a given object’s physical and my subsequent knowledge of its syntax: it isn’t possible for me to have the latter knowledge without having the former; it is possible for me to have the former without having the latter; and my knowledge of the former is the sole foundation for, and is also what leads to, my knowledge of the latter.
      And it’s irrelevant that, speaking from a strictly experiential
(phenomenological) perspective, the occurrence of the one bit of knowledge seems to coincide with the occurrence of the other. It is the purpose, or at the very least the effect, of consciousness to condense the intricacies of the cognitions underlying it into a single, seemingly homogeneous “experience.” If every articulation of pre-conscious cognition were faithfully represented in consciousness, if phenomenology faithfully duplicated every joint in the intricacies of the cognitions of which our conscious judgments are the outcomes, then consciousness would be so overburdened with information that it would cease to be able to perform the executive functions with which it is tasked. When seeing a rabid dog run towards me, my consciousness would present to me a richly articulated mosaic of judgments, whose consequences for my well-being would take much more time to figure out than was available to me. Fortunately, however, my consciousness presents me with a homogenous feeling that causes me,not a moment too soon, to bolt into action. Instead of giving me the psychological equivalent of a two-hundred page state-department report, consciousness gives me the equivalent of an electric cattle-prod in my back. And because the rich cognitive back-story is telescoped into that bolt of unpleasant and, aside from its distinctive affective nuances, homogeneous bolt of unpleasant phenomenology, I do the right thing (i.e. I run to the mini-van, lock the doors, roll up the windows, etc.) and, what is more, I do it in real time.
    In general, it is precisely because consciousness represents as homogenous “feelings” what are in fact  intricate networks of judgments that the contents of consciousness, unlike their cognitive underpinnings, are actionable. It is, I would conjecture, the very purpose, or at least one of the purposes, of consciousness to condense cognitive intricacies into affective simplicities. Therefore, it is inter alia its purpose to condense distinct, albeit adjacent, stages of intricate thought processes into a single, action-causing, survivalensuring feeling.
     In any case, if this is at all on the mark, then it’s of no relevance that my recognition of the ink-deposit’s shape seems to be temporally coincident with my recognition of its syntax. –It is to be pointed out that, if this isn’t on the mark, then much work in psychology crumbles.
   
1.3 A related point: CTM incompatible with the fact that distinct thoughts can be part of some one thought-process If CTM is right, my thinking 2 is a prime number and 2 is less than three cannot be responsible for my later thinking some prime number is less than three.  According to CTM, if B1 is the totality of brain-events constitutive of my thinking 2 is a prime number and 2 is less than three, and B2 is the totality of brain-events constitutive of my thinking some prime number is less than three, it cannot be B1’s being such a belief that brings about B2. So it cannot be B1’s being such a belief that leads me to believe that some prime number is less than three.
     So, if CTM is right, B1’s being such a belief has nothing to do with B2’s existence or a fortiori with B2’s being constitutive of a thought to the effect that some prime number is less than three. Thus, my believing that two is even and is less than three cannot, if CTM is right, have anything to do with my later believing that some even prime is less than three. So, if CTM is right, T1 has nothing to do with T2, notwithstanding that the brain-events constitutive of T1 brought about those constitutive of T2.
      So even though B1 occurs right before B2 and is causally responsible for it, and even though B1 and B2 are constitutive of, respectively, T1 and T2, nonetheless T1 and T2 cannot, if CTM is right, be installments in some one thought-process.
    In general, CTM is incompatible with fact that distinct thoughts can be part of some one thought-process. CTM is thus incompatible with the fact that thought-processes occur---with the fact that there are sequences of thoughts (setting aside such thought-sequences whose constituents have no thematic coherence, having at best the content-free coherence had any, e.g. a series of domino-fallings).
           
2.0 CTM’s dependence on the false assumption that syntax can mirror logical form CTM assumes that, under some conditions, morphology-driven activity is ipso facto syntax-driven. We’ve found this assumption to be false.
But in this section we will grant it for the sake of argument.
     Like all other natural languages, the English language is replete with context-sensitive expressions. And were it not for that fact, its expressive capabilities would be pitifully limited. There’s a big difference, semantically and prudentially, between saying (truthfully, we’ll suppose)
 

	* “that obviously rabid animal will soon start heading in our direction, andwe’ll be eaten alive if we don’t immediately get in that guy’s mini-van”
 
and saying (same qualification)
 

	* “at time t, a certain rabid animal r is in place p and at time t*, which issoon after t, x will start rolling towards place p*; and unless, during the interval between t* and when said animal arrives at p*, individuals x and y get into person z’s mini-van, x and y will be eaten alive.”
 
even if the values t, p, and p*  correspond to times and places indicated by somebody who uttered (i). Let’s assume that, in (i), the referent of “that obviously rabid animal” does in fact pick out a rabid and (for that reason, among others, dangerous) animal.
     Let T be a token of (i), and let T* be a token of (ii). It’s clear that, pretty much no matter what the circumstances are, the information borne by T is different—semantically and prudentially—from the information borne by T*.       For this reason, and countless others of its ilk, a language that didn’t contain expressions like “that”, “here”, “I’, “now”---context-sensitive (indexical) expressions—would be quite useless (for everything other than, suggestively, making time- and place-insensitive statements about numbers and other denizens of Plato’s heaven).
      Bearing this in mind, let T# be a token of the same sentence-type as (i). But let’s assume that the occurrence, in T#, of “that obviously rabid animal” refers to an animal that, though rabid, is one tenth the size of a shrew, and also has no teeth and thus no way of biting (or otherwise transmitting rabies to) anyone, and is therefore no threat at all. In that case, clearly, T# is false, whereas T (so we may suppose) is correct.
     T and T* have the same syntax—on any delineation of that term. (Same grammar; same depth-grammar; same logical form.) But the proposition meant by T has  very different entailment-relations from the proposition meant by T*. And, what is more on point, a creature that responded only to the forms of sentences would (other things being equal) respond to T in the same way that it would respond to T*. But (other things being equal) no person would respond to T in the same that he’d respond to T*. In general, beings that respond to sentence-token-form, and not (except in so far as sentence-form is (low-grade) sentence-semantics) to sentence-tokensemantics, are (i) not rational creatures and (ii) aren’t us (since, irrational though we often are, we tend to be irrational---we flee from tigers, but not from pebbles).
   Replace T and T* with their Mentalese counterparts. In other words, take them to be tokens, not of English, but of Mentalese sentences. It is evident that the resulting argument goes through, showing that we don’t think in Mentalese.
 
2.1 An objection to an objection to this line of thought    “There’s a problem with your argument”, it might be protested. “What if Mentalese is such that the context-sensitivity that, in English (and Spanish etc.) is accomplished through context-sensitive expressions, is accomplished by strictly syntactico-logico-formal means? In that case, the argument you just gave would lose whatever anti-CTM value it has.”
    This suggestion is a non-starter. Where  there is context–sensitivity, there is ipso facto a cleavage between sentential (grammatical) and logical (propositional) form. Being inherent in the nature of context-sensetivity, this fact nothing to do with the peculiarities of English or any other language. A context-sensitive expression is one whose referent varies from context to context. Reference is a quintessentially semantic function. So there is no way to de-semanticize context-sensitivity. 
   So if we think in Mentalese and, and if, moreover, Mentalese, like English, contains context-sensitive expressions, then our mental activity is semanticsdriven and consequently isn’t computational, an immediate consequence being that CTM is false. Human thought is context-sensitive. It follows that, if we think in a language, that language must be context-sensitive, and therefore semantics-driven. So if we think in a language, CTM is wrong. And CTM is wrong if we don’t think in a language, given that, according to CTM, thought consists entirely of formal operations on linguistic symbols.
 

	1. CTM’s reliance on the erroneous assumption that there are minimalunits of thought First a definition: a “morpheme” is an expression that cannot be decomposed into others. Bearing this in mine, let’s suppose that, just as CTM says, we think in a language. In that case, our concepts are identical with expressions.  Linguistic expressions consist of morphemes. (Any given complex expression (e.g. “the cat is on the mat”) decomposes into expressions that cannot, in their turn, be further decomposed (e.g. “cat”,
“hat”). So in contending that our thoughts are identical with (tokens of) Mentalese symbols, CTM is, in effect, assuming that we have simple concepts: concepts that cannot be decomposed in others. So CTM, if correct, entails that any given thought that one has can be decomposed into “simple” concepts. CTM thus has the radically implausible consequence that we have “simple” concepts. In other words, CTM has the consequence that some of our are no more capable of being decomposed into other concepts than a morpheme (e.g. the word “cat”) can be decomposed into other expressions. If this consequence of CTM is correct, it follows, as we’ll now see, that some of our concepts would be such that one could have them without also having other concepts.
    Let T be the token of the Mentalese word for “snow” that went off when, just a moment ago, I thought to myself that snow is white. We may assume that T is a morpheme. (If, for some reason, you reject that assumption, just map what we say about T onto some Mentalese expression-token that, in your judgment, is a morpheme—and you must, if you grant that we think in a language, grant that there is some such token, since morpheme-less language is a surd---and everything that we say about T will hold mutatis mutandis of this other expression-token.) Not being decomposable into other expressiontoken, T presumably exists independently of such tokens. Given any simple expression—given any morpheme—belonging to a language L, you can remove that morpheme without removing other morphemes. Of course, in removing that morpheme, you’ll remove all of the expressions of which it is a constituent. (And, if you choose a non-lexical item, e.g. “and” or “of”, you may thus do a lot of damage to L.) But you won’t, in removing that morpheme, be removing other morphemes.
   Therefore, if, as CTM alleges, we think in a language (“Mentalese”) , some of our concepts coincide with morphemes of a language, if follows (i) that if you strip Mentalese of the word-type of which T is a token, the only other expressions which, in so doing, you’ll be removing from Mentalese will be other morphemes, and it also follows (ii) that some of our concepts are such that one can have them without having others. This means that, if CTM is right, your concept of snow is primitive, the same being true of your concept of Smith, Jones, and Brown (assuming, for argument’s sake, that the Mentalese expressions for these individuals are morphemic).
 

	1. CTM’s reliance on the erroneous assumption that there are minimalunits of thought  (continued) But there are no primitive concepts. I couldn’t possibly have a concept of snow, or of Barack Obama, or (to take a more tendentious example) of the number three without having a network of other concepts---extension, spatiotemporal location, surface-area, sentience, etc.
     Concepts are necessarily contrastive; in order to have a concept of a thing, one has to be able to distinguish that thing from other things. A pre-requisite for distinguishing, say, that rock from, say, that tree is my being aware of some property had by the rock that isn’t had by the tree. And a prerequisite for my having such knowledge is my already having concepts. (Many contemporary theorists---some of them CTM-advocates, some of them not— reject this, saying that conception is a purely causal notion. Their view is that concepts are mental photographs. The relationship borne by my concept of Socrates to the Socrates is identical with, or to be understood in terms of, in terms of, the relationship borne by a photograph of Barack Obama to the events (the impact of certain light-rays with Barack Obama’s body) that, in due course, led to that photograph.
   This view, as we’ve seen, is false; and so are the modifications of put forth by CTM-advocates in their attempts to sidestep the glaring problems with it.
    What right have I to make such an encompassing claim? Every right. Here’s the idea that I am now claiming to be false and all of whose derivatives I am now claiming to be false:
 
(PM) My concept of Socrates is to Socrates what a photograph of Socrates is to Socrates.
 
That idea involves a failure to distinguish between (i) awareness of some entity and (ii) information that, if known, would lead to such awareness. I see discolorations of a certain kind on a photographic plate. Given that information, along with other pieces of background information that I have, I can make various inferences. I can infer that, at some point, light bounced off of a person who was bald and was wearing a toga (and so on). So the photographic plate is information in the sense that, to a creature with the requisite background and the requisite intelligence, its existence warrants the making of an inference that will eventuate in knowledge of some entity (e.g. a person) or state of affairs (e.g. one consisting of a person wearing a toga) that might otherwise have remained unknown. (Why “might otherwise have been unknown”, instead of “would otherwise have been unknown”? Because I might have been the one who took the picture and might therefore have already have known of the person and the corresponding state of affairs.) The discolorations on the photographic plate are “information” in the sense that, to a suitably endowed creature, they warrant the making of inferences that, in due course, lead to concepts. 
     But the photograph itself obviously isn’t a concept of Socrates---or of anything else. And the “photograph-model” of conception, to use Gareth Evans’ term, involves the grotesquely mistaken idea that concepts per se are identical with the evidences on the basis of which concepts are arrived at. There have been many attempts to refine the photograph model. But, in addition to being both ad hoc and devoid of intuitive force, they all involve this exact blunder; and, suggestively, the expositors of these views (e.g. Fodor (1990, 1998, 2006), Dretske (1982)) never so much as mention the distinction between (i) the concept and (ii) the information on the basis of which one generates the concept.
     In any case, it is massively to CTM’s discredit that it presupposes that there are representational atoms.
 
3.2 A similar argument Sentences are digital structures. Setting aside cases of ambiguity, any given sentence—any given complex expression, in fact--has  a unique decomposition into minimal units of significance. This means, as previously pointed out, that our thoughts decompose into minimal representational units. Which is radically implausible.
      In any case, sense-perceptions don’t have a digital structure, and neither, it would seem to follow, does the information that sense-perceptions encode. Given which, it would be very artificial to maintain that all post-perceptual cognition was digital or, therefore, sentential in nature.
     But, for argument’s sake, let’s suppose that the contents of our senseperceptions can, as come advocates of CTM maintain, be “digitized.” Supposing this hypothesis correct, all the problems previously posed for CTM by perceptual content are now posed by the post-perceptual thoughts involved in this (alleged) digitization-process. If I’m translating from Albanian to English, I must speak both Albanian and English. Moreover, supposing that I’m translating competently, I have some way of evaluating the degree to which my English outputs match my Albanian inputs. If my thinking is entirely mediated by English sentences, I won’t be able to do either of these things: I won’t be able to translate from Albanian into English; and, if per impossibile I were able to do so, I couldn’t verify the accuracy of my translations. By analogous reasoning, if the aforementioned postperceptual thoughts were themselves entirely digital, they would ipso facto be blind to the benchmarks relative to which their own translations were to be evaluated, supposing for argument’s sake that they could produce such translations to begin with.
     Of course, one could say that those processes are purely causal, i.e. that they don’t embody any awareness of what, given the relevant perceptual inputs, the relevant digital outputs ought to be. But in that case, our postperceptual thoughts are ex hypothesi merely the results of, and are in no way justified by, the contents of our perceptions. But that is surely too absurd a position to take seriously.
 
4.0 The regress-problem If CTM is right, then (“AS” is short for “for anything representational symbolic”
 
(ARS) anything that represents anything is a symbol.
 
If, as CTM holds, we think in sentences—if, as CTM says, our thoughts are sentence-tokens---then surely we understand those tokens. But understanding a sentence involves being able to pair it off with its meaning. Which means that one must be able to compare that sentence with something that isn’t a sentence. Which wouldn’t be possible if all of our thoughts were sentences (or sentence-tokens).
    “That doesn’t follow”, it might be said. “Suppose that you think that snow is white, and that your thinking this consists in there being an occurrence of some Mentalese sentence. Your understanding that sentenced could consist in there occurring, in your mind-brain, various sentences of some language— call it Mentalese2---such that, given those sentence-occurrences, you can duly interpret the original (Mentalese) sentence.”
     Yes, but by that logic, there must be tokens of Mentalese3 sentences before one can understand those Mentalese2 sentence-occurrences; and there , there must be tokens of Mentalese4 sentences before one can understand those Mentalese3 sentence-occurrences; and so on ad infinitum.
      So it’s viciously regressive to hold, as CTM does, that symbol-tokens mediate our thoughts. More precisely, it’s viciously regressive given the reasonable assumption that we understand those symbols.
 
4.1 How advocates of CTM deal with the regress-problem Aware of this line of thought, advocates of CTM say that we don’t understand the symboltokens that mediate our own thoughts. As William Lycan put it, we are simply “built to use those symbols” in the “right” ways, much as computers are “built” to use the symbols (or, rather, the things which are tendentiously and, we have seen, wrongly called “symbols”) on which it operates.      But, so far as a given thing isn’t understood, it isn’t functioning as a symbol. A story, similar to one told earlier, will make this clear. I have a wooden sculpture—which we’ll call “WS”---on my desk that tokens the sentence “haste makes waste.”  Even though WS tokens three words, all three word-tokens are carved from the same block of wood. So WS consists of one, solid object, not of a a lot of letter- or word-blocks. WS heavy; it’s made of solid oak, not pine or plywood or any other cheap sort of wood. It would thus serve as an excellent cudgel. A student of mine comes into my office. He reads it, understands it, and accordingly changes his, hitherto impetuous ways. In this context, WS is functioning as a symbol. In other words, if E1… En are the just-mentioned effects on the student, it is WS’s being a symbol (of quite a specific kind, in fact) that leads to E1…En. Later that afternoon, a colleague, whom I detest, come into my office. He doesn’t read WS. Because of his myopia, he sees a brown blur in the place that WS occupies. Gripped by a non-tenure-conducive rage, I strike my colleague with WS. If E1*… Em* are the subsequent bruises and fractures suffered by my colleague, it is WS’s having a certain mass, moving with a certain velocity, etc. that brings about E1….Em*. WS’s being a symbol is utterly irrelevant.  Why? Because WS’s being understood is essential to its functioning as a symbol.
 
4.1.1 This line of reasoning summed up   Languages are sets of semantic rules. Where there no such rules, there are no languages; and where there is no knowledge of such rules, there is no linguistic activity. The idea that there is a “language of thought” is incoherent, given that it is inconsistent with these basic truths, and so is CTM,  given that it assumes that there is a language of thought.
   
5.0 CTM self-refuting. CTM says that we think in sentence-tokens. CTM also says that, qua proposition-bearing entities, those sentence-tokens do nothing. For reasons that we’ll now see, it follows that, if CTM is correct, it cannot be known to be correct or even rationally accepted.
     We must start by remembering that no thing is a cause. The rock isn’t what breaks the window. What does so is the rock’s striking the window with a certain amount of force.  Bearing this in mind, let B be the brain-structure that encodes my belief that 1+1=2. Nobody denies that B has causal properties. But if CTM is right, B’s being (or constituting) a thought to the effect that 1+1=2 does nothing. The same thing mutatis mutandis holds of any content-bearing brain-state. If CTM is right, even if a given brain-state bears content C, it’s bearing that content is causally inert. This entails that, if a given person accepts CTM, it isn’t because of the contents of any of the thoughts that he does so; and, consequently, it isn’t because he knows of any reason to accept CTM. So, if CTM is correct, there is ipso facto no way that a person could be justified in accepting CTM (or, by obvious extensions of this reasoning, anything else). Which, while not showing that it’s false, does show that one cannot coherently advocate it.
 
 
[257] Berkeley and Contemporary Anti-foundationalism
 
 
Abstract: Wilfred Sellars destroyed the ‘myth of the given’ and thus began a revolution in epistemology. Foundationalism used to be the orthodoxy. Nowadays, because of Sellars, anti-foundationalism is the orthodoxy. This paper shows that, two hundred years before Sellars, George Berkeley destroyed the myth of the given by means of an argument very similar to Sellars’. Berkeley’s argument is actually a kind of generalization of Sellars’ argument. Berkeley explicitly shows how anti-foundationalism applies to a wide range of contexts. Sellars, by contrast, discusses only very special contexts, and leaves it entirely implicit how his discussion ought to be generalized. Also, Berkeley provides a non-metaphorical way of interpreting some of the metaphors that dominate contemporary anti-foundationalism (e.g. the idea that one’s belief system is an “arc” or a “web”).
 
  
Here is one conception of how we learn about external reality:
 
 
“No empirical background knowledge is needed to obtain knowledge of external reality. A given perception can do that on its own. All empirical knowledge rests on top of perceptions. So, in their turn, perceptions cannot, and therefore do not, rest on top of empirical knowledge. Therefore perceptions provide us with knowledge of the external world without the
[258]
assistance of any background knowledge.”
 
 
       Wilfred Sellars demolished this picture. In so doing, he destroyed ‘the myth of the given’. It must be made clear what the word ‘given’ means here.
Obviously Sellars isn’t denying that external realities are given to us, i.e. made to known to us, through sense-perceptions. No one would seriously deny that. Sellars is attacking the idea that, when a perception makes us aware of some external state of affairs, it does so without the cooperation of a manifold of preexisting empirical knowledge. So he is against the idea that we don’t have to deploy existing empirical knowledge to have a perceptual awareness of external reality.
    So there are two senses in which, for Sellars, knowledge acquired through a perception is not ‘given’. It is not a given in the sense its existence typically presupposes a background of empirical knowledge. Background knowledge must be mobilized if a sensory experience is to give us knowledge of an external state of affairs. What is given – the sensory experience, considered apart from the background knowledge with which it interacts - is not epistemic, i.e. it does not constitute knowledge of anything.  So information about the external world lies in what is given to us plus a pre-existing manifold of knowledge; such information is not located in what is given per se. Thus the given is not epistemic.
      But Sellars is also making a stronger claim. The significance of a quale – what it truly or falsely tells the subject, leaving aside what the subject knows in virtue of having it – is not given; it is not fixed, at least not by the intrinsic properties of the quale. The quale has to be filtered through background knowledge first: then the quale gives the subject a determinate message about the external world. So the epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed or ‘given’; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge. Sellars is against the idea that ‘raw sensations’ (as he puts it) by themselves have a fixed or ‘given’ message and, thus, don’t need the co-operation of ulterior knowledge to tell us anything, whether true or false, about the outside world. A fortiori Sellars is also against the idea that, by themselves, raw sensations constitute knowledge of the external world.
        So there are two myths of the given. (i) What is given is epistemic, i.e. constitutes knowledge. (ii) What is given is representational. i.e. it tells us anything, whether true or false. Sellars made a compelling case against both myths.
      It should be made clear that, according to Sellars, what is false is not the
[259]
	belief that there is a given. Obviously the perceiver is passive in some respects; some things are given to him. What is false is the belief that the given is epistemic, i.e. constitutes knowledge, and also (more radically) that what is given is even representational.
         I believe that, in An Essay Towards a  New Theory of Vision (1709), George Berkeley made essentially the same points that Sellars would make, over two hundred years later, in Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind. Further Berkeley’s attack on the given is more perspicuous, more radical, and more cogent than Sellars’ version of it.
      Sellars argument is basically this. Bob is in a tie shop where there is unusual lighting. Bob is looking at a tie. Because the lighting conditions are unusual, he cannot tell whether he is looking at a green tie or a blue tie. So he takes the tie outside, where the lighting conditions are ‘standard’, and Bob sees that it is (say) blue. Bob then goes back inside and realizes what a blue tie looks like under the lighting conditions that prevail there. He repeats this procedure with ties of many different colors. So, in due course, Bob doesn’t have to leave the shop to tell what a color a tie is; he can just see that it is blue or green – even though a blue tie in the tie shop gives off the same appearance as a green tie under more standard lighting conditions.      Let Post-Bob be our word for Bob after he has ‘acclimatized’ to the unusual lighting conditions in the tie-shop. And let Pre-Bob be our term for Bob before that acclimatization. Confronted with a tie in the tie-shop, PostBob can see that it is blue or green – even though it doesn’t look the way that blue or green ties look ordinarily. But obviously when Post-Bob sees what color a tie is, a great deal of back-ground empirical knowledge is at work. He knows a great deal about the conditions of perception that obtain in the tieshop, and how they affect the appearance of the ties. Of course, if Post-Bob is to ascertain what color a given tie is, he will simply look at it. But from this perception, Post-Bob is able to upload the color of the tie only because, operating in his cognitive background, there is a fair amount of existing empirical knowledge.
    There are two ways that this lesson can be generalized. (Sellars leaves implicit these much needed generalizations.) It can be shown to apply to sense-perception under standard conditions (i.e. under conditions where the lighting, and so on, is relatively ‘normal’). It can also be shown to apply to sensory apprehensions of properties other than colors.
    Consider the highly indirect way that Post-Bob ascertains the color of the tie (in the tie-shop). It would be possible to construct scenarios in which someone ascertains knowledge of other properties of physical objects in a similarly indirect way – in a way that involves the co-operation of background knowledge (concerning the conditions of perception). We could imagine Bob being in a place where – because of, say, the distorting effects of funhouse-style mirrors – Bob could not (at least not initially) see what shapes objects were. He’d have to look at a given object under ‘standard’ conditions to see what shape it was, and then look at it again under the unusual conditions just described: he would then know what (say) a square or triangle shaped object looked like under those circumstances. Of course, eventually, Bob would just be able to look at an object (in the place where the ‘bent’ conditions obtain) and, without further ado, know what shape it had: in effect, he would be able to see that it was a square. But whenever he did this, it would be, in part, because of the co-operation of background empirical knowledge.
   Given some ingenuity, it would be possible to construct scenarios that do for mass, temperature, speed, distance, or size what the scenarios we’ve just considered do for color or shape.
      What Sellars says about Post-Bob’s way of ascertaining the colors of ties applies to the way that we obtain knowledge of objects’ (perceptible) properties under ‘standard’ conditions. In other words, when we are just looking at an object and seeing that it is red, the perception therein involved is informed by background empirical knowledge in just the way that PostBob’s perception of the color of a tie is thus informed.
      First of all, the conditions of perception under which we in fact senseperceive objects are in a constant state of flux. In some cases those changes are quite dramatic. But unless the changes are highly unusual, we adjust automatically and unthinkingly. You simply see that (say) some tie is red in circumstances where the lighting conditions are quite non-standard (unless, of course, the conditions are exceptionally non-standard). Unless you are an artist, you are probably unaware how massive these differences are. For example, my apartment has excellent natural lighting. But my artificial lighting – the lighting I use after night-fall -- is extremely poor. Thus, the lighting conditions in my apartment at 3:30 p.m. are very different from the lighting conditions in my apartment at 10:00 p.m. (with the lights turned on). The way that a red book appears is in fact very different depending on the time. This became glaringly obvious when I took up painting again. The mix of paint that I must use to paint the book as it appears at 10:00 p.m. is very different from the mix I must use to paint the same book as it appears at 3:00 p.m. or even 8:30 p.m.
    But if I want to find out what color a book is, I don’t have to go through the rigmarole that Pre-Bob went through: I just look at the book. But does this mean that background knowledge is not in fact a factor in my ascertaining the color of the book? It seems much more natural to suppose that such knowledge is operative, but that I have so thoroughly internalized the correspondences in question – the correspondences that Post-Bob had to work so hard to learn, given the extreme unusualness of the lighting conditions in the tie-shop – that I am no longer aware of the role that this ulterior empirical knowledge plays.
     Sellars has shown that in non-standard conditions, one must rely (however unconsciously) on background knowledge if one is to learn, through one’s senses, how things are in the external world. But standard conditions are an idealization: no conditions are really standard. If there were perfectly ‘standard’ conditions, they would not be standard. If we could set up a situation that was distortion free, that situation would not be a typical one. So what Sellars says about Bob’s intake of color-facts in the tie-shop is true of our intake of color-facts in general.
      Further, it is true of our intake of shape-facts, size-facts, distance-facts, and so on. We can tell at a glance what shape an object has. But the appearance that a diamond-shaped object gives off when looked at from above is the same as the appearance that a square shaped object gives off when looked at from an oblique angle. But we instantly know, except in contrived circumstances, whether an object is diamond-shaped or square shaped. We see that the object is (say) square. How can we see this, given that its appearance, considered by itself, could just as well be that of a diamond-shaped object? Because we take into account a great deal of contextual information; in particular, we take into account the fact that we are not hovering above the object.
    A ten foot stop-sign, looked at from a hundred feet away, gives off the same appearance as 1,000 foot stop sign looked at from 10,000 feet away. But when one looks at a stop sign from a hundred feet away, one isn’t fooled for a second; one sees that it is a stop sign (of a certain approximate height); one isn’t fooled for a moment into thinking that it is 1000 ft stop-sign. (Of course, one cannot tell, just by looking at a stop-sign, exactly what height it is. But one is seldom off by orders of magnitude.) One can just see the approximate height of the stop sign. But how is this possible, given that a ten foot stop sign looked at from a hundred feet away gives off the same appearance as 1,000 ft stop-sign looked at from 10,000 ft away? Because one takes a great deal of contextual information into account. One compares the sign to the trees in its vicinity; and one knows, on independent grounds, that trees (at least outside of northern California) are usually between 15 and 80 ft tall: one can thus use these trees as benchmarks. And one uses various other benchmarks (e.g. houses that one sees, whose sizes and locations one knows one independent grounds) and, more generally, various other pieces of background or contextual knowledge.
     By exactly analogous arguments, it can be shown that any episode of taking in information about the external world – any episode of taking in the height or speed or shape…or color  of an object – involves the co-operation of contextual or background information. Such ulterior knowledge is needed to give content to one’s sensory episodes. Otherwise those episodes are indeterminate. If the contextual information that we just spoke of is left out, one sensory episodes – one’s visual sensations – don’t tell one whether one is seeing a thousand foot object ten-thousand feet a way or a ten foot object a hundred feet away; they don’t tell one whether he is seeing a diamond or a square; an oval or a circle; a nearby object moving 3 mph or a distant one moving at 150,000 mph. In the absence of background empirical knowledge, our sensory episodes become indeterminate to the point of meaninglessness –   to the point of having no representational content.
     It seems to me that this Sellarsian line of thought was put forth by Berkeley in 1709. We think we can simply see whether an object is ten feet away or a thousand feet away, whether it is oval or round. Of course, we do learn objects’ shapes, sizes, and so on, through perception, and through sight [260]
	in particular. Berkeley doesn’t deny this for a second. But he says that when we take in the shape of an object through sight, that is only because a great deal of background knowledge is co-operating.
       Berkeley begins by asking to us consider distance-perception. We think we see how far away objects are. Obviously, we can (up to a point) take in objects’ distances from us through sight. But one obviously cannot tell, just by looking at it, that the moon is this or that distance away (section 44). This is always true, in a very obvious way, of very distant objects. Given only one’s visual experience, one would have no idea whether the moon was a million light years away and very large, or a few miles away and very small.      Berkeley then says (correctly, in my view) that what is true of very distant objects is true, though less obviously, of not so distant objects. Given only what your eyes tell you – leaving aside background knowledge – do you really know that you are seeing a medium sized object fifty feet away or a massive object a mile away? What if you took a guess? What if you guessed that it was fifty feet away, but it took you half and hour to jog to that object? No matter how good your eyes are, and no matter how ‘standard’ are the conditions of perception, there is no reason why things couldn’t turn out that way. Your visual experience by itself is ambiguous between your seeing a massive object very far away and a medium sized object nearby. So you don’t really see how far away an object is. When you think you are doing that, you are really reading into your visual experience a lot of background empirical knowledge.
     You know, for example, that objects of that particular shape (say, a stopsign shape) are typically of such and such a height, and you use that information as a kind of benchmark. Given that background information, you can tell on the basis of your visual sensation that you are seeing an object that is less than a hundred feet away. But the visual sensation by itself is ambiguous between a nearby ten-foot tall stop-sign and a far-off hundredfoot stop-sign.
    Another example might help. The appearance given by of by a receding object is not different from the appearance given off by a shrinking gives. But when you see a person walk into the distance, you can see that he is not shrinking. How can you see this, given that the appearance in question could be that of a shrinking person? You know that people don’t shrink. You also know that if, by some miracle, a person were suddenly shrinking, he wouldn’t make the calm ambulatory motions made by the person you are seeing. Thus contextual information disambiguates what would otherwise be an ambiguous visual experience.
      According to Berkeley, what ultimately endows one’s visual sensations with information regarding the distances of objects is that different kinds of visual sensations have different kinds of kinesthetic and tactile concomitants. One reads these into one’s current visual sensations and it is this, in the final analysis, that gives your visual experiences the representational contents that they have. It is this that makes your current visual experience be one of (say) a man who is walking away as opposed to a man who is shrinking.
   A different example might help. You see what you take to be a pencil lying ten feet away from you. But you find that it takes you half an hour to walk there. And once you are there, that ‘pencil’ gives off the appearance of a fallen (pencil-shaped) tree. Finally, you return back to your starting point. Obviously you will then ‘recalibrate’; you will use the knowledge that you just acquired  as a way of establishing the comparative distances of other objects.  It must be pointed out that you acquired knowledge of the distance of the pencil not merely through sight, but with the help of kinesthetic and tactile sensations, and also sensations of duration. As we just said, you use your knowledge of the distance (from your original starting point) of the pencil as a kind of reference point: that information helps you know the comparative distances of other objects you are seeing. So, ultimately, it is not the visual sensation by itself that apprises you of the distances of all these objects; it is your visual sensation  plus various sensations of motion, resistance, touch (your feet touching the ground), and duration. If it weren’t for these non-visual concomitants of your visual perceptions, you would have no idea how far objects were from you: for your visual sensations by themselves cannot give you this knowledge.
   Berkeley’s basic point is that your visual experience by itself doesn’t apprise you of the size or distance of the object. What does that is your visual experience plus various pieces of background knowledge:
 
   “[T] judgment we make of the distance of an object viewed with both eyes is entirely the result of experience. If we had not constantly found that certain sensations [accompanied our visual sensations], we would never make those sudden judgments from them concerning the distance of objects; no more than we would pretend to judge of a man’s thoughts by his pronouncing words we had never hear before.” (section 20)
 
   Berkeley sometimes expresses this by saying that you simply don’t see distances at all  (section 46). This seems an overstatement. In some sense, surely, I can see that my pencil is less than 90 ft away. But there is a deep truth in these words of Berkeley’s. One’s visual experience, taken by itself, stripped of any contextualization, doesn’t tell one that is one is seeing a treesize pencil a half-mile off or a tiny pencil nearby.
   Berkeley generalizes this point (sections 121-147). Consider the kind of appearance that a square object gives off when looked at from directly above – a paradigmatic-‘square’ appearance (not the diamond-appearance that such an object gives off when looked at from oblique angles). Accordingly to Berkeley, it is only ‘past experience’ that teaches us that that kind of appearance betokens a square object. Berkeley’s argument is cogent. Let S be the kind of appearance just mentioned. (So S is the kind of appearance given off by a square-shaped object looked at from above, under optimal lighting conditions.) Consider the kinds of tactile and kinesthetic sensations that we in fact have in connection with a diamond-shaped object -- the kinds of sensations one has, for example, when running the palms of one’s hand along the periphery of such an object. Let us refer to those sensations as D. And suppose that you had D in connection with S. In that case, Berkeley says, S would betoken a diamond-shaped object, and not a square one.       (Berkeley thus has a very definite answer to Molyneux’s question: Consider a  man born blind who was one day given sight. Would he know on the basis of his visual perceptions – before having a chance to correlate them with tactile or kinesthetic or other sensations – whether he was seeing a round or an oval or a square object. Berkeley explicitly says ‘no’. (Section 132.) )       Berkeley gives analogues of this argument for every perceptible property an object might have. For example, it is not one’s visual perceptions by themselves that tell one whether one is seeing a slow or fast moving object. If one’s visual sensations are to apprise one of how fast some object is moving, they need the assistance of a great deal of ulterior information.  (If I thought that the plane I saw was only ten feet above me, then I would think it was only moving 3 mph. Since I know that it is thousands of feet above me, I can ‘see’ that it is moving very quickly.) Berkeley doesn’t explicitly make this point in connection with our perceptions of mass or of temperature. But it would be easy enough to adapt what he says about distance, shape, and so on, to apply to these other kinds of properties.
   Berkeley illustrates his major point with some clever analogies. When you hear somebody talk, you feel as though you directly grasp their meaning. Somebody says “it’s a lovely day”. You hear through the sounds to the meaning. So it is as though your auditory experience by itself apprised you of the significance of the sounds you were hearing. But of course that is not so. The relationship between the sounds ‘it’s a nice day’ and the corresponding meaning is arbitrary, and you could only know it through experience (you’ve been brought up in an English speaking country, or taken English classes). You ‘hear’ the meaning only with the help of a great deal of background knowledge. You are indeed aware that the person is asserting the proposition it’s a lovely day; but it is obviously not your auditory experience by itself that does this – it is your auditory experience plus a lot of background knowledge.    Berkeley says that your visual experiences apprise you of the squareness of objects only in the sense in which your auditory perceptions apprise you of the meaning of a spoken sentence. Once again, let S be the kind of visual experience that a square object gives off, when look at from (a certain distance) above, under good conditions. And suppose that O gives of S. You think you just see the shape of O – that your visual experience by itself tells you what shape O has. But you are reading a great deal of background information into your visual experience: at some cognitive level, you are indeed aware that O is a square, but not merely by virtue of the fact that O gives off S. Also at work is your knowledge of the tactile and kinesthetic concomitants of experiences of S.
    Berkeley gives another analogy. When a person’s face reddens (in a particular way) that indicates shame. When you see that sort of reddening, you feel as though you can actually see the shame. But surely your visual experience by itself doesn’t apprise you of the other person’s shame; a great deal of background knowledge – of how people’s emotions are given bodily expression – is at work. Similarly, when a visual experience makes you aware of the distance of some object, it is by way of contextual or background information: the experience by itself is ambiguous between a 10,000 foot stop-sign that is miles away and an eight foot stop sign that is 20 ft away – and that visual experience could indicate any number of other possibility. On the basis of cultural and other background information (you know that stop-signs are in fact 8 ft tall) the visual experience is
‘disambiguated’. Also, you have established, on independent grounds, that some neighboring tree is only ten feet tall, and you use that information as a kind of benchmark. The point is that it is the visual experience plus ulterior empirical information that apprises you of the height of the tree – just as it is visual experience of the person’s facial reddening plus ulterior knowledge of psychosomatic correspondences that apprises you of the person’s emotional state.
   Berkeley’s major point is that no sensory experience by itself tells one anything. Any such experience has to be put in the context of a lot of background knowledge if it is to bear any determinate message and if, therefore, it is to tell one anything about the external world. So no sensory experience is foundational: the senses tell us about the world only through the ‘mediation of various past experiences’ (an expression Berkeley himself uses frequently). So there is no given; there are no foundational sensory experiences. Knowledge of the external world is obtained by putting one’s current sensory experiences into the context of other sensory experiences and also in the context of previously obtained empirical knowledge. So empirical knowledge is obtained through coherencies obtaining among sensory experiences; thus it isn’t given through isolated sensory experiences; and thus, for Berkeley, empirical knowledge has no foundation, to use Sellars’ own expression. At bottom, this is just what Sellars was saying: it is Sellarsian anti-foundationalism.
    Actually, Berkeley’s argument for what I am alleging to be epistemic antifoundationalism is far more lucid and developed than Sellars’ version. There are, if I am not mistaken, two respects in which Berkeley’s argument is superior to Sellars’. First of all, Sellars only gives one example of how sensory experiences need the help of background knowledge to tell us about the external world: one example relating to perception of just one kind of a property – and a secondary property (color)  at that -- under non-standard conditions. Thus, if Sellars’ argument for anti-foundationalism is to be made cogent, it must be generalized to other properties – e.g. distance, shape – and shown to apply to standard (or, at any rate, not grossly unusual) conditions of perception. (In this paper, I tried to provide such generalizations; but, strictly speaking, I went beyond anything that Sellars himself said.) But Berkeley’s argument is not subject to these limitations of scope; his argument directly shows some kind of anti-foundationalism to hold for our perceptual intake of virtually every property (at least, every perceptible property: obviously properties like being composed of neutrinos are excluded) under standard conditions. So Berkeley’s argument doesn’t require much supplementation to be general. (In a New Theory of Vision Berkeley doesn’t talk about secondary properties.)
      There is another respect in which Berkeley’s argument is more developed than Sellars’. Sellars argues (rightly, in my view) that to ascertain the color of the tie you need existing empirical knowledge – you need to know something about the conditions of perception. But of course, the question arises: how do you acquire this existing empirical knowledge; a kind of regress appears to threaten. Sellars (164—170) gives a very condensed and obscure answer to this. I cannot assess the merits of what Sellars says here. But Sellars doesn’t really explain how representational mental entities (perceptions) are forged out of what he has compellingly argued to be non-representational mental entities (‘raw feels’, ‘qualia’, ‘sensations’ – all of these are terms Sellars himself uses). Sellars tries to stop the regress not by showing how ‘raw feels’ are synthesized into perceptions, but in some much more obscure way, which (frankly) I don’t fully understand. But Berkeley goes to great lengths to show how non-representational mental entities (qualia) are integrated into representational ones; Berkeley talks, in a detailed way, about how a confluence of non-representational mental entities belonging to different sensory modalities can bring about a representational entity (a bit like the way that looking through both lenses of a binocular microscope gives you a three-dimensional picture by combining two two-dimensional pictures). Obviously, I cannot off the cuff assess the merits of this aspect of Berkeley’s argument. But Berkeley has provided much more of a solution than Sellars’ – I myself am open on whether it is a correct solution --  to the regress that antifoundationalist seems to incur. Actually, where many contemporary antifoundationalists rely on the paper currency of obscure metaphors, Berkeley gives us the gold-backing of non-metaphor. For example, knowledge is often said to be an “arc”, in which the various parts support one another, not a skyscraper, in which some parts support others without being supported by them’(Blackburn 1984:161; Bonjour 1985). Our knowledge is said have the structure of a “four-dimensional curve”; and that, we are told, is why antifoundationalism isn’t viciously circular or viciously regressive (Bonjour 1985). These images may contain deep truths. But, as they stand, they are just metaphors. Berkeley has provided a very non-metaphorical way of interpreting these metaphors.
     It is important in this connection to distinguish two problems that arise on Berkeley-Sellars anti-foundationalism. One is the question how, on any antifoundationalist view, any belief manages to be justified. The other is how anything representational (perceptions) manages to arise out of what is not (so Berkeley and Sellars argue) representational, namely qualia, ‘raw feels’,
‘sensations’. It seems to me that Sellars, in the aforementioned obscure pages (164-170) deals to some extent with the former problem, but not with the latter problem: and the latter problem is the more fundamental one. For until we have perceptions, the problem of justification doesn’t even arise. Berkeley doesn’t deal with the problem of justification, but he does deal with the problem of how perceptions arise out of non-representational sensations. For reasons discussed earlier, I think that his solution must surely contain some truth, though it appears to be incomplete.
 
 
Conception as Knowledge of Uniquely Individuating Descriptions
 
I.
 
      Let me start by stating the picture I wish to call into question: a picture that is now an orthodoxy, thanks to some of the brilliant arguments found in Kripke’s Naming and Necessity.
      
    Many a person can refer to Socrates but not be able to produce a description that applies to Socrates and not also to many others. One can use the word “Socrates” with understanding and not know the truth of any proposition of the form: somebody uniquely has phi and “Socrates” refers to x. When asked who “Socrates” refers to, they may say “he was a great philosopher of ancient times” or “he wrote the Nichomachean Ethics”; and that may exhaust what they have to say (truly or falsely) by way of an answer to your question. What they “know” may be excessively general (“he was a great philosopher of ancient times”) or it may simply be false (“he wrote the Nichomachean Ethics”). In both cases, they will lack knowledge of any truth claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Socrates” refers to x. They will lack knowledge of the right kind of uniquely individuating description.
     But such people may still be able to produce sentences of the form “… Socrates…”, and really mean them. So apparently one can refer to Socrates, and also think about him, without knowing of any description that singles him out.
     
 
    The purpose of this essay is to argue for two related (but probably not coincident) points. First, in order to refer to an object, one does have to know of some description that singles it out: one has to have knowledge of the right kind of uniquely individuating description. Second, in order to think about an object, one does have to know of some description that singles it out. Without knowledge of a uniquely individuating description, there is no reference and there is no conception.
    In many cases, the ability to refer to, or think about, an object does involve one’s being causally connected to the object. But the causal connection, though perhaps essential, nonetheless has a subordinate role: it facilitates conception and reference by way of being an indispensable part of one’s knowledge of a uniquely individuating description.
     I have no doubt that Kripke’s major point about proper names is quite correct. “Socrates” is not a disguised definite description. Further, I concede that part of what makes tokens of “Socrates” refer to Socrates is (or, more accurately, can be) that those tokens stand in a certain causal relation to Socrates himself. Finally, I concede that part of what enables one to think about Socrates is (or, more accurately, can be)  that one stands in a certain causal relation to the man. But I will argue that these causal relations are always embedded in knowledge of a description that applies to Socrates and Socrates alone –knowledge of a uniquely identifying description. 
     None of Kripke’s important semantic insights requires an abandonment of the position that, if one is to think about x, one must know of some description or concept that applies uniquely to x. Indeed, I think that when we delineate what Kripke says, we will find that, on the contrary, Kripke’s story requires that one always have such knowledge.
 
§     I should make it clear what I will and will not be attacking, and it will help if I state my biases. First, I believe that direct reference theory is correct – that the sole semantic value of “Socrates” is Socrates. I do not think that, semantically, “Socrates” is a description. I do not advocate any kind of descriptivism with regard to the expression “Socrates”. (I will argue that it is not necessary to do so in order to accommodate the intuitions that motivate descriptivism.) So, in so far as it is concerned with semantic issues, this essay will operate very much within a Kripkean – or, at any rate, a direct-reference – framework.
     But semantics is not epistemology. Given only that “Socrates” is a label, and not a description, it does not necessarily follow that I can think about Socrates without knowing a description that singles him out. And, I will argue, thinking about Socrates does require knowledge of such a description. Indeed, being able to refer to Socrates requires knowledge of such a
[261]
	description – notwithstanding that “Socrates” itself has little or no descriptive content at all. The semantic relationship between “Socrates” and
Socrates is “pure” and non-descriptive. The relation between my concept of Socrates and Socrates is a different story.
    A consequence of these findings is that a popular and seemingly plausible analysis of conception is quite false. In fact, much contemporary philosophy of mind and epistemology is a projection of views that seem to have support in Naming and Necessity, but in fact have none.
 
§       Let us start with a very quick – and, inevitably, unsatisfactory -summary of some of the relevant points in Naming and Necessity. According to Russell, “Socrates” is synonymous with a definite description; this might be “the greatest philosopher to have died of hemlock poisoning”. To understand the word “Socrates”, and thus to understand sentences of the form “…Socrates…”, one must obviously know the semantics of “Socrates”. So one must know that “Socrates” is synonymous with that definite description. Consequently, anyone who uses the word “Socrates” with understanding is able to produce a description that applies to Socrates and Socrates alone. In general, if one knows the semantics of a referring term, then one knows some description that applies uniquely to the referent of that term. If I can use the word “Gilgamesh” with understanding, that means I know of some description that singles out the individual in question. If I know of no such description, then I cannot really know what is meant by sentences like “Gilgamesh was wise”.
     Supposedly, Kripke demolished this view. Consider any description of Socrates that applies to him uniquely, i.e. that truly singles him out. Here is an example: “the greatest philosopher to have died of hemlock-poisoning”. One can understand sentences of the form “…Socrates…” without knowing that the referent of “Socrates” consumed hemlock. One can understand “Socrates was wise” without knowing that “Socrates” picks out somebody who uniquely satisfies the description: greatest philosopher to have died of hemlock-poisoning. This point holds mutatis mutandis for any description that singles out Socrates. Consider the description “the person who figures as the protagonist in most of the platonic dialogues”. One can understand the sentence “Socrates was wise” without having the slightest idea that he was a protagonist in any philosophical dialogues. Given any description D that applies uniquely to Socrates, one can understand “…Socrates…” without knowing that D applies to the referent of “Socrates”.
      This point has many apparent consequences. Some of these are semantic in nature. Others are epistemological.
   Here is one of the semantic consequences. “Socrates” is not synonymous with any definite description. Given any description D, one can know that “Socrates was wise” is true without knowing that somebody uniquely instantiated D and that any such person was wise. So it isn’t tenable to maintain that “Socrates” is synonymous with “the greatest philosopher to have died of hemlock-poisoning” or with any other definite description. (As I said earlier, I accept this.)
     Here is one of the supposed epistemological consequences. One can think about Socrates without knowing of any description that singles him out – without knowing a UID. (As I said earlier, I will argue against this.)
 
§     There are other apparent consequences, both for semantics and epistemology. Let us start with a question: Why does “Socrates” refer to Socrates and not, say, Plato? Russell’s answer was this: “Socrates” is synonymous with a description that is true of Socrates and Socrates alone. Kripke made a powerful case against this answer. So how does Kripke answer our question? His answer is basically this: “Socrates” refers to Socrates because a certain kind of causal relation holds between tokens of “Socrates” and Socrates himself (or, more exactly, states of affairs involving Socrates).
    Kripke has more to say on this matter. Somebody – say Smith -- saw Socrates. So Socrates’ presence caused Smith to have certain visual experiences. Smith then gave a name to Socrates. Smith was able to pass that name along to people who did not themselves see, or otherwise senseperceive, Socrates. Of course, for Smith to pass along that name to someone, that person had to be causally connected to Smith. The process just described is repeated over and over. I myself am the 521st installment in a sequence of events like the one described. Inevitably, Smith’s original term for Socrates has undergone phonetic distortion. What I have been left with is the sound (or sound-type) “Socrates”. When I produce instances of that sound-type, my words refer back to Socrates precisely because I am connected to Socrates by way of a chain like the one just described. When I say “Socrates”, my words refer to Socrates because they are causally connected to him in a certain way.
In general, if an expression E refers to an object O, that is because tokens of E stand in a certain causal relation to states of affairs involving O.
 
II.
 
       Let us now evaluate the various claims just put forth. How do you learn what a given word refers to? There appear to be two ways: you can learn it by description and by ostension. (Soon we will see that there is a third.)      You are young; so you have never heard the name “Socrates”. Somebody says to you:
 
(*) “ ‘Socrates’ is the name of the most famous philosopher to die of hemlock poisoning.”
 
 
Here the word “Socrates” has been defined for you in a descriptive manner.
In effect, you were told: somebody O uniquely satisfies a certain description - most famous philosopher to die of hemlock poisoning   – and “Socrates” refers to, or names, O.
    On the face of it, there seems to be a second, entirely distinct way of learning what a term refers to: you can be given an ostensive definition.
   You are in a crowded market place. You see a man haranguing a crowd.
Your companion says:
 
(**) “that person over there [pointing to the orator] is named ‘Socrates’”.
 
  
    My own view is that ostensive definition actually collapses into a kind of descriptive definition. I will argue for this later on. But, of course, this is not a point that can be taken for granted. Right now, we need only register the fact that one can learn what a term refers to through descriptive and also through ostensive definition.
      When you give a descriptive definition of a referring term, the descriptive information must be taken to have wide-scope. Otherwise the definition turns out false, and Kripke’s compelling modal points are violated.  (*) defines “Socrates” by means of a description: most famous philosopher of antiquity to die of hemlock poisoning. But the descriptive information in (*) is used to fix the referent of “Socrates”; that descriptive information is not itself part of the meaning of “Socrates”.    The following statement is true:
 
(s1) “Somebody O was a unique most famous philosopher of antiquity to die
[262]
	of hemlock poisoning and, for any predicate *…x…*,  *…Socrates…* means:…O…
 
The following statement is false:
 
 
(s2) “…Socrates…” means: Somebody O was a unique most famous philosopher of antiquity to die of hemlock poisoning and…O…
 
  
   By way of clarification: “Socrates smoked” does not mean: somebody O was a unique most famous philosopher of antiquity to die of hemlock poisoning and O smoked.
    But there is some object O such that O was a great philosopher who died of hemlock poisoning and such that “Socrates smoked” means: O smoked.  “Socrates smokes” means Socrates smoked. And Socrates was a great philosopher who died of hemlock poisoning. So there is an object O such that
O was a great philosopher who died of hemlock poisoning and such that “Socrates smoked” means: O smoked.  
     The descriptive information in (*), and in (s1), is given wide-scope with respect to the “means that” operator. That is why such statements are true. And that is also, of course, why Socrates drank hemlock is not analytic and is also contingent (false in some, but not all, possible worlds).
 
§     It seems that, in a certain class of cases, one is able to acquire the ability to use a referring term without ever having been given either an ostensive or descriptive definition of it. Suppose you and two other people (Smith and Jones) are talking. All of a sudden Smith and Jones start talking about somebody named “Argo”. They never say who “Argo” refers to. They never say: “Argo was the president of our fraternity back in college” or “Argo was my divorce lawyer; and by sheer coincidence he’s Smith’s racquetball partner.” They do not ostensively define “Argo”; for he is not present.  Smith and Jones simply prattle on about “Argo”; and you are too polite to ask them who that person is.
     Nonetheless, as Gareth Evans pointed out, it seems that you can still use the word “Argo” in a meaningful way. You can say “it sure sounds like Argo is an awful person”; and you can ask questions like “did Argo mean to do that to you, or was it just an accident?”
    So prima face it seems that you can acquire the ability to use “Argo” in a meaningful way without ever having been given an ostensive or descriptive definition of it. When you say “it sounds as though Argo is an evil person”, you are using the expression “Argo” with understanding; you are not in the same category as a parrot that mindlessly says “Argo was a cad”. So it seems as though you can simply “pick up” the ability to use “Argo”, and names
[263] generally: there needn’t be an ostensive or descriptive definition.
  
§   Let us take stock. There seem to be three ways that a proper name N can be inducted into one’s lexicon:
 
(i) one can be given an ostensive definition of N; (ii) one can be given a descriptive definition of N; or (iii) one can just “pick up” the use of N.
 
 
§       Now let us further consider each these three categories. Suppose that somebody ostensively defines “Socrates” for me. I see somebody haranguing a mob. My companion says: “that person is named ‘Socrates’”.
      Under this circumstance, I know that there is some individual x such that x uniquely has certain properties (he is uniquely a person that I am seeing on this particular occasion behaving in a certain way, dressed in certain clothes, and so on), and I know that “Socrates” refers to x.
    Ostensive definitions work by way of knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions. Somebody points to some person (or object) O and says: “that guy is named ‘Fred’”. For the definition to work – for you to learn what “Fred” refers to – you must have some way of singling out the person ostended. Suppose your companion points in a certain direction and says “that is Fred”, but there are thirty different equally salient objects. In that case, the definition won’t work. You must be able to pick out the right object.
    Picking out a single object involves knowing a uniquely individuating description. An extreme case will bring out my meaning. Suppose that there are thirty numerically different, but (leaving aside location) qualitatively identical men in a certain place. Your companion Bob goes up to one of them, put his hand on his shoulder, and says “this guy is named ‘Fred’”. Even though the person just named is qualitatively just like many others, you know of some description that applies to him and to no one else.
