You know that: There is some individual x such that x is uniquely a person whom Bob just picked out – such that x uniquely has the property that Bob just put his hand on his shoulder – and “Fred” names x.
    Now imagine a slightly different scenario. You and Bob are in the presence of thirty qualitatively identical individuals. (They are in different places of course.)  Bob doesn’t actually put his hand on anyone’s shoulder. But there is some person x such that Bob is able to use an act of pointing to distinguish x from the other people (and objects) in his vicinity and such that Bob tells you that “Fred” refers to x.
    Bob’s definition works. It works only because you know of some existence claim that Fred, and Fred alone, satisfies. You know that: there is some specific person x such that x uniquely is such that Bob just pointed him out. You also know that “Fred” refers to that person. But your being able to know “Fred” refers to that specific person involves your knowing the truth of some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to phi. You know what “Fred” refers to only because you know of some description that singles out Fred: some “uniquely individuating description”.    The description is not one that tells you much about what kind of person Fred is. In fact, that description doesn’t tell you anything about how Fred is psychologically or (leaving aside facts about spatio-temporal location) physically different from other people. The description in question gives you enough information to cognitively single out Fred, and it gives you very little, if anything, beyond that. But that is neither here nor there. In this context, there is only one important point. Your knowing what “Fred” refers to depends essentially on your knowing the truth of some proposition of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” names x.     
      This is not to deny that your knowing what “Fred” refers to involves your having some kind of causal connection to Fred.  You do have some kind of causal connection to Fred: you see him, and this involves your being causally connected to him. You acquire the ability to use the word “Fred” in consequence of (among other things, I will argue) this causal connection.  So your subsequent uses of “Fred” refer to Fred in virtue of, possibly among other things, this causal connection.
     But the causal connection is not the primary thing; the causal connection is a component of something more important. It is a component of your knowledge of a uniquely individuating description. How is the meaning of “Fred” given to you? It is given to you ostensively. But, even so, it is, at least in effect, given to you through an existence claim. You know the truth of some claim of the form: there is some x such that x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to x. Now, your knowing the truth of that claim involves your being causally connected to Fred. For the claim in question involved visual perception (or, at any rate, some kind of sense-perception); and seeing (or otherwise sense-perceiving) a thing involves being causally connected to it. But how is vision (sense-perception) involved? It is involved in exactly this sense: it enables you to know the truth of some existence claim of the kind described a moment ago; sense-perception is involved in the sense it apprises you of the truth of a uniquely individuating description. A causal connection to Fred is involved in your knowing what “Fred” refers to: but this causal connection is involved only to the extent that is constitutive of your knowing the right kind of uniquely individuating description.
 
§    What we’ve established so far is this. In some cases, not all, we learn what a term refers to through ostensive definition. When we acquire the ability to use a term through ostensive definition, our ability to use that term with understanding consists in our having knowledge of some uniquely individuating description of the referent: it involves our knowing the truth of some claim of the form something x uniquely has phi and N refers to x, where N is the word in question.
 
§     Here one point should be made explicit. One’s uniquely individuating description of an object need not be, and almost never is, “pure”: there is almost always an indexical component. Suppose Bob points to somebody and says “that is Fred”. Here, as we’ve just seen, I assign a referent to “Fred” by way of my knowledge of some claim of the form: something x uniquely has phi and “Fred” names x. In this case phi would be some property like: man wearing plaid shirt over there, on whom I am uniquely focused…The uniquely individuating description will thus be loaded with context-sensitive components (whose linguistic counterparts are indexicals). This fact might lead to a conclusion. Suppose my doppelganger on twin-Earth is in a situation exactly like mine except that he is talking with twin-Bob and he is seeing twin-Fred (who is standing next to twin-tree, and so on). It might seem that the uniquely individuating description through which I acquire a concept of Fred is identical with that through which my twin acquires a concept of twinFred: both descriptions are linguistically expressed by the same phrase: “the unique person wearing the plaid shirt…on whom I am at this moment focusing…” Thus, it might appear that neither my conception, nor my twin’s, is uniquely individuating. A Strawsonian “massive reduplication” has occurred.
   So it seems that my uniquely supposed individuating description applies equally to Fred and twin-Fred – and thus isn’t a uniquely individuating description at all. The same is true mutatis mutandis of my twin’s “uniquely” individuating description of twin-Fred. Thus it seems that a uniquely individuating description is not enough for conception. The reason I acquire a concept of Fred, and not twin-Fred, is that I am causally connected to Fred. So, once again, the causal theory of conception trumps the descriptive theory of conception.
    This viewpoint is based on a simple failure to understand some points about demonstratives that were clearly articulated by Frege, and improved by Kaplan, Perry and others. On Monday, in Amsterdam, I say “the man over there is rich”. Focus on my token of “the man over there”. On Tuesday, in Madrid, I say “the man over there is rich”. I have used the expression “the man over there” twice. But different uniquely individuating descriptions were expressed. In the one case, I was talking about the man in place p, at time t (where p is some part of Amsterdam, and t is some time on Monday). In the other case, I was talking about the man in place p*, at time t* (where p* is some part of Madrid, and t* is some time on Tuesday). Different uniquely individuating descriptions were expressed and were thought. Mutatis mutandis this point applies exactly to the scenario described concerning me and my twin.
     Now it is true, at least in part, that I upload a concept of Fred, as opposed to twin-Fred, because I have a causal connection to Fred that I don’t have to twin-Fred. But notice that this causal connection enters into the story by way of some feature of the relevant uniquely individuating description. That description has an indexical component; and the causal connection fixes what that component picks out. So the causal connection is indeed essential: but it is essential as a mere component of a fundamentally descriptive epistemic modality.
 
III.
 
    As we saw, there seem to be three ways that a proper name N can be inducted into one’s lexicon:
 
(i) one can be given an ostensive definition; (ii) one can be given a descriptive definition of N; or (iii) one can just “pick up” the use of N.
 
 
  We’ve already dealt with (i). Let us now deal with (iii). We will soon see why we are skipping to (iii), and not dealing right away with (ii).
    Once again, consider the case where you are talking with Smith and Jones. They suddenly starting talking about somebody named “Argo”. They are acquainted with Argo, but you are not. At no point in the conversation do they ever say anything like “Argo was my divorce lawyer” or “Argo was the best man at my wedding”. They never enunciate a uniquely individuating description; they never give you a definite description that applies to Argo.      Of course, given that they are producing sentences of the form “… Argo…”, it follows that you are, in effect, given many indefinite descriptions that apply to him. Smith says “Argo is a real cad.” So here you are being given an existence claim of the form: somebody x is a cad and “Argo” refers to x. But, of course, many people are cads; so given only that you know the truth of this existence claim, it doesn’t follow that you know which specific person – which specific cad – “Argo” refers to.
       But the truth is: merely by virtue of the fact that you overheard Smith and Jones using the word “Argo”, you have been given a definite description that applies to Argo, and you have learned some true proposition of the form: some thing or some person x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x.
     Unlike you, Smith is personally acquainted with Argo. Thus, for reasons we’ve covered, Smith knows some true proposition of the form: some thing (or some person) x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x.
     In the course of your conversation with Smith and Jones, you often hear Smith make statements like “Argo was a cad”, and “maybe Argo wasn’t so bad”. On each such occasion, there was one person to whom Smith was referring by means of the word “Argo”. Suppose that, on occasion t, Smith says “Argo was a cad”. Obviously the description “x is a cad” is indefinite, and applies to many. But on that occasion, there was exactly one person whom Smith was describing as being a cad; and you know this, merely by virtue of overhearing Smith’s statement. So, just by virtue of being in colloquy with Smith, you do pick up knowledge of some claim like: on occasion t, there was exactly one person who Smith described as being a cad, and “Argo” refers to x.
 
§   To test the mettle of my thesis, let us make things as difficult as possible for it. Suppose that Smith goes on a rant. He says “Flipper is a cad; Argo is a cad; Ichabod is a cad; Peewee is a cad…” You have never heard any of these names before; you have not even heard Smith (or Jones) use any of those names in the context of the conversation in which you are currently engaged. Let us further suppose that you never hear anyone use any of these names again; so on no later occasion are you given any further information about them or their referents. Nonetheless, merely by virtue of overhearing these words on that one occasion, you can appropriate them into your lexicon, and use them meaningfully: you can make statements, and ask question, about Argo and Flipper and Peewee; for example, you can say “Peewee and Argo probably didn’t have very nurturing parents”.
   This fact seems to confute the theory I just put forth. You hear Smith use the name “Argo” just once; and what Smith is saying about “Argo” is identical with what he is saying about “Peewee” and “Flipper” and all the rest. So, under these circumstances, you do not know some true existence claim of the form: on such and such occasion, there was exactly one person whom Smith was describing as a cad, and “Argo” refers to x. For that claim isn’t true; on the occasion in question, Smith was describing several people as cads.
    Despite all of this, I submit, you still know of some true existence claim of the form. In fact, you know several such existence claims. First of all, we must take care not to define the term “occasion” too broadly. The term “occasion” can refer to a three week period or a three nanosecond period. Suppose you go to three-day long party and you meet many people. You can truly say “I met two hundred people on that occasion”. But within that occasion, there were other occasions. Perhaps you went to the veranda and met some people there. On that occasion you met forty people. And within that occasion, there were yet others. There was the time that so and so spilled his drink: referring to that incident, you could truly say “on that occasion I seriously regretted leaving my house that day.”
   Terms like “occasion” and “context” are (pun intended) context-sensitive. An occasion (or context) could comprise nothing more than a two millisecond, three cubic millimeter of space-time. But an occasion could conceivably comprise an entire galactic era.
    Given this, let us reconsider your discussion with Smith and Jones. The statement “on that occasion, there was no one person whom Smith described as a cad” is true, if by “that occasion” you mean the whole discussion. But there were many occasions within the discussion. There was the time Jones spilled his beer; the time Smith made an unseemly pass at the waitress; the awkward moment when you realized that you hadn’t brought any money with you; the time Smith used the name “Yaroblinsky”. Within that discussion Smith described many people as cads. But given any one of those people, there was indeed some occasion, within the discussion in question, such that, on that specific occasion, Smith described that person, and only that person, as a “cad”. Let x be any one of the unfortunates who, in that conversation, Smith described as a cad. Within that conversation, there was some occasion such that, on that occasion, Smith described x, and x alone, as a cad. Of course, Smith’s referring to x as a cad involved Smith’s using some name: “Argo” or “Peewee” or “Ichabod” or “Beezer”. Smith had to say “Argo is a cad” or “Beezer is a cad”. He couldn’t just say “__ is a cad” or “x is a cad”. Let N be any one of the names Smith used, in the discussion in question, to ascribe the property of being a cad to somebody; and, as before, let x be any of the people to whom Smith  ascribed that property.  Within the conversation in question,  there was some occasion such that, on that occasion, Smith described x, and x alone, as a cad and such that Smith used N to refer to Smith. Thus, within the conversation in question,  there was some occasion such that, on that occasion, Smith described some person x, and x alone, as a cad and such that Smith used “Argo” to refer to x. Within that same conversation, there was some other occasion such that, on that occasion, Smith described some person x, and x alone, as a cad and such that Smith used “Peewee” to refer to x. Exactly the same thing (mutatis mutandis) is true of “Ichabod” and “Beezer”, and each of the other aforementioned names.
     Let us focus on “Argo”. You are a part of the conversation in question; in any case, you overhear it. Within that conversation, there was some specific occasion when Smith described some single person x as a cad, and Smith referred to x as “Argo”. Here, of course, the term “occasion” is covering a small window of time. But, uncontroversially, within that narrow window, there was some one person whom Smith described as a cad, and to whom Smith referred as “Argo”. Since you are part of the conversation, you know this. When you hear Smith say “Argo is a cad”, you know that Smith is referring to a single person; and you can distinguish the occasion – the narrow window of time – in which Smith produced that sentence from the narrow window of time in which Smith said “Peewee is a cad”. And you can distinguish both occasions from the narrow window of time in which Smith said “Beezer is a cad”. You can cognitively keep all of these occasions separate. Given any one of these occasions, you know that Smith was describing exactly one person x as a cad; and you also know which name Smith used to make that statement. So there is some specific occasion O such that, on O, Smith describes a single person x as a cad, and Smith used “Argo” to refer to x. And you know this: you know it merely by virtue of being a part of the colloquy in question. So merely by virtue of being a part of that discussion – nay, merely by virtue of over-hearing it – you know the truth of some claim of the form:
 
(*) on such and such occasion, somebody x was uniquely such that Smith described x as a cad, and Smith used “Argo” to refer to x. 
 
There is only a trivial difference between (*) and:
 
(**) on such and such occasion, somebody x was uniquely such that Smith described x as a cad, and “Argo” refers  to x. 
 
  
 
    So merely by virtue of being in a position to “pick up” use of the term “Argo”, you are ipso facto in a position to know the truth of (**). Thus merely by virtue of being in a position to “pick up” use of the term “Argo”, you know some existence claim of the form: there is some x such that x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x.
    It is plain that what enables you to pick up the term “Argo” is your knowledge of some claim of the sort just described. Your picking up a term like “Argo” -- i.e. your appropriating it in manner (iii), as opposed to manner (ii) or (i) – involves your witnessing a sentence of the form “…Argo…” It involves your encountering a case of somebody’s ascribing a property to Argo. (This is true even if you read such sentence: you are still, in effect, encountering somebody’s using that sentence to make such a statement.) Whenever you witness a token of “Argo has phi” you are witnessing an occasion such that, on that occasion, there is somebody x such that, on that occasion, the property of being a phi is being ascribed to x and x alone; and you also witness that, on said occasion, “Argo” is being used to refer to x. So if you “pick up” use of the word “Argo”, that involves the following: there is some specific occasion O such that you know that, on that occasion, exactly one person x is being described as having phi and “Argo” refers to x.
 
§    We must be careful to distinguish the following claims:
 

	* Exactly one person has phi.

	* Exactly one person is being described, on some particular occasion t, as having phi.
 
   There are many cads. But there are many occasions where only one person is being described as a cad
    Your picking up the word “Argo” doesn’t involve your learning the truth of some claim like: exactly one person x is a cad, and “Argo” refers to x. Such a claim is false; there are many cads. Your picking up “Argo” involves your learning the truth of some claim: on some specific occasion, exactly one person x is being described as a cad, and “Argo” refers to x.
    We must take care to make one other distinction. Smith himself never uttered an existence claim of the form:  there is some x such that x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x.  Smith himself never uttered an existence claim of the form:   on occasion t, I (Smith) referred to somebody x as a cad and “Argo” refers to x. Smith said only “Argo is a cad”, “Peewee is a cad”, and so forth. But the information that you are given, by virtue of being in discussion with Smith, is not confined to what Smith himself says. When Smith says “Argo is a cad”, the information that is encoded in his words is quite threadbare. But you are given information above and beyond that information; you witness Smith’s speech act. You put that speech act within a larger context; you have an enormous amount of information about when that speech act occurs. You know that it occurred after certain other events (e.g. before Smith spilled his beer) and before certain other events (e.g. before Jones made the unseemly pass at the waitress). In any case, even though what
Smith was saying might have been minimal, the information you have about Smith’s saying it  – about the context in which that speech-act occurred -- is enormous; and that information does suffice to give you the right kind of uniquely individuating description. Smith’s words do not by themselves give you a uniquely individuating description that applies to Argo or Peewee or Ichabod. But there is something that does give you such a description: that something is your perception of the conversational context in which Smith uses the word “Argo”.
 
§    There is no vicious circularity in this account. Smith personally met Argo.
He learned the meaning of “Argo” through an ostensive definition. Maybe Smith himself gave Argo the name “Argo”. (For cultural reasons, this is not likely. But that is not relevant here.) In any case, Smith saw Argo, and then learned (or possibly stipulated) that the thing he was seeing was named “Argo”.
     You meet Smith. You have a conversation with him.  On some specific occasion within that conversation, Smith says “Argo was a cad”. You thus know that, on that occasion, there is somebody x such that Smith is describing x, and only x, as a cad, and that “Argo” is the term Smith is using to refer to x. the uniquely individuating description you associated with “Argo” is not: “the unique person x such that x is named ‘Argo’”. Rather, it is: the unique person x such that, on such and such occasion, Smith was describing x as a cad.”
    In the circumstance just described, you are only at one remove from somebody who was directly acquainted with Argo – with somebody to whom “Argo” was defined ostensively.
    But what we’ve said applies equally to the case where you are at five hundred removes from the referent of the word in question. Consider this scenario. Smith doesn’t personally know Argo. But Smith knows Brown, and Brown personally knows Argo. Smith is not given an ostensive or descriptive definition of “Argo”. But Smith overhears Brown saying “Argo is a cad” or whatnot; and on this basis, Smith is able to add “Argo” to his own lexicon: we just described the principles governing such an addition. You then overhear Smith saying things like “Argo is a cad”, “Argo is a mean person”, or whatnot. You are not given an ostensive or descriptive definition of “Argo”. But on the basis of what you overhear, you are able to add “Argo” to your lexicon: the principles that govern Smith’s appropriation of “Argo” obviously apply to your appropriation of that name. By exactly similar reasoning, it wouldn’t matter if you were five hundred removes from somebody who was actually acquainted with Argo: the same principles would apply; and in each case, what would enable you to use “Argo” to refer to Argo would be your knowledge of some claim of the form: something x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x (where phi would be some property of the form: is a person who, on such and such occasion is being described as having thus and such property).
 
§    Of course, words undergo phonetic degradation and alteration as they change hands. The first person who uses the word “Argo” might pronounce it one way; the people who “pick up” that name from that person might pronounce it differently. But this fact obviously doesn’t affect the principles governing appropriation of that word. Brown might pronounce “Argo” one way; Smith might pronounce it differently; you might pronounce it a third way; the people to whom you transmit this word might pronounce it a fourth way. After a few transmissions, what is left might bear extremely little resemblance to Brown’s pronunciation. In some contexts, that fact is of importance. But that fact has no bearing on our point: that, whenever somebody “picks up” a name – whenever they add it to their lexicon in manner (ii) – it is in virtue of their having knowledge of a uniquely individuating description that applies to the referent. It is obvious how these points apply to names like “Socrates”. The word that Socrates’ own acquaintances used to refer to him was not “Socrates”; that word probably had some phonetic similarities to “Socrates”; but there are also non-trivial differences. Nonetheless, however distorted “Socrates” may be relative to the word that the Ancient Greeks used, the principles governing the “picking up” of that word – or any one of its ancestors or descendants, no matter how much phonetic distortion is involved – are the same. In each case, whenever one adds it to their lexicon in manner (ii) – it is in virtue of their having knowledge of a uniquely individuating description that applies to the referent, namely Socrates.
     So suppose that “Sukrat” is the Ancient Greek word for Socrates. Glaucon learns what “Sukrat” means through an ostensive definition. Glaucon is engaged in a discussion with Zenon. Glaucon never gives Zenon any ostensive or descriptive definition of “Sukrat”. But Glaucon does produce a sentence of the form “…Sukrat…” Thus, for reasons discussed, Zenon acquires the ability to use “Sukrat” to refer to Socrates; and, for reasons discussed, Zenon’s ability to do this involves his knowing a uniquely individuating description that applies to Socrates. Zenon has a conversation with Phoebus. Zenon slightly mispronounces “Sukrat”. In a manner exactly analogous to that just described, Phoebus acquires the ability to use that, slightly mispronounced version of “Sukrat” to refer to Socrates. In this way, variants of “Sukrat” are transmitted from person to person, from generation to generation. What we are left with, two thousand years later, is a word that is quite different (at least phonetically) from “Socrates”. But one’s acquiring the ability to use that word, however distorted it might be relative to the original word for “Socrates”, involves one’s learning some uniquely individuating description that applies to Socrates; it involves one’s learning some true claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Socrates” has x. But, in most cases, “phi” will be some property like is described, on such and such occasion, by so and so, as having thus and such property. “Phi” will not be a property of historical moment; it will not be a property like great philosopher of antiquity who drank hemlock or philosopher who figured as the protagonist in most of Plato’s dialogues. The property in question will be some highly contextual one, some property that doesn’t connect in any significant way with Socrates’ intellectual or historical countenance.
 
IV.
 
   As we’ve noted, there are three ways you can add a referring term to your lexicon: We’ve found that whenever (i) or (iii) is the case, your ability to use the word in question involves your having knowledge of a uniquely individuating description of the referent of that word. Let us now consider the second of these three categories: descriptive definition.
     Here it is very easy to fall prey to a confusion. Imagine the following. You have never heard the word “Socrates” before. You are talking with your friend Charlie; he says “Seymour is second only to Socrates in philosophical ability”. You don’t know who “Socrates” refers to? So you ask: “Who is
Socrates?” Charlie says: “Socrates was the author of the Nichomachean Ethics and the Posterior Analytics”.
    Of course, Charlie is wrong; Socrates did not write either of those works; and “Socrates” does not refer to the author of either of those works. At the same time, in consequence of your having this exchange with Charlie, you can use the word “Socrates” to refer to Socrates.
    Here it seems as though you are able to use the word “Socrates” to refer to Socrates, even though your only belief about him is wrong – even though the only thing you “know” about him isn’t true. But this appearance is misleading. What we have here is a case where you add a word to your lexicon in manner (iii). You do know some uniquely individuating description that applies to Socrates. But that description is not “the unique author of the Nichomachean Ethics and the Posterior Analytics”. Rather, it is: *the person to whom Charlie, on occasion t, ascribed the property of writing
[264]
the Nichomachean Ethics and the Posterior Analytics* , for some value of t.
     In most cases where we seem to be appropriating a name in manner (ii), we are in fact appropriating it in manner (iii). But we can certainly construct a case where, unmistakably, we are appropriating a name in manner (iii).
[265]
 Suppose you and Charlie are having a conversation. Neither of you has any idea who invented the zipper. You and Charlie decide that, at least when speaking to each other, you will refer to that person, whoever it is, as “Julius”. So you have no idea who invented the zipper. But you know that somebody did so, and you have stipulated that “Julius” is to refer to that person.  Thus you have added a semantic rule to English (or, at any rate, to a certain idiolect of English). It must be made clear what that rule is. The rule is given by the following:
 
(Z) Somebody x uniquely invented the zipper, and “Julius” refers to x.
 
The descriptive information is given wide-scope with respect to the “refers to” operator. So if Smith was a unique zipper-inventor, then “Julius was a millionaire” means Smith was a millionaire. That sentence does not mean: somebody x uniquely invented the zipper and x was a millionaire. “Julius” is a name, not a quantifier.
    You and Charlie don’t know who “Julius” refers to (nether do I). But it does refer to somebody. On the face of it, it certainly seems as though you can use it significantly: you can, with understanding, say things like “Julius was probably a talented inventor” and “Julius must be worth a fortune”.
     Some people have said that, under the circumstances, you cannot say things like “Julius must be worth a fortune” and really mean them. This may or may not be true (I will weigh in on this shortly). But what everybody will agree on is this. If you and I can use the term “Julius” with understanding, it is only because we know some true claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi, and “Julius” refers to x. Here, of course, phi is the property of inventing the zipper.
 
§     I do not wish to be misunderstood. A strong case can be made that unless you know who invented the zipper, you don’t know which proposition is semantically encoded in “Julius must be worth a fortune”, and other such sentences.   What you actually know, it could be argued, is some proposition like: for some object O, the sentence “Julius must be worth a fortune” is true exactly if O must be worth a fortune. Since you don’t know which object invented the zipper, you don’t know who “Julius” refers to; and you therefore don’t know which proposition is encoded in that sentence. But, at the same time, you have a kind of metalinguistic knowledge about “Julius must be worth a fortune” which, in some respects, simulates real understanding of it.      Be all of this as it may, what is clear is that if, under the circumstances described, you or Charlie understand “Julius must be worth a fortune” – so if, under those circumstances, you understand “Julius” – it is entirely because you know the truth of some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi [the property of inventing the zipper], and “Julius” refers to x.
    Everyday life there are many cases where we seem to be adding a name to our lexicon in manner (ii). Suppose little Timmy has never heard the name “Shakespeare” before. You say to him: “Shakespeare is the person who wrote Romeo and Juliet”. Here it seems that the three year old is appropriating the name “Shakespeare” in manner (ii); for what you are telling him is, in effect: there is some x such that x uniquely wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x.
   But really little Timmy has appropriated “Shakespeare” in manner (iii). A
Kripke-style argument shows this. After your conversation with him, little Timmy can make statements about Shakespeare; they may be wrong and illinformed; but they are wrong and ill-informed statements about Shakespeare. Let us suppose he does so; he asks “did Shakespeare like French fries?”, and says “Shakespeare must have been weird, because his writing is so funny”.     But what if it turns out that Shakespeare did not write Romeo and Juliet? What if it turns out that, although he wrote Hamlet and King Lear and Timon of Athens, he didn’t write Romeo and Juliet? Does that mean that little Timmy’s statements were blanks? Was the three year old not referring to anybody? It seems not; it seems that little Timmy did manage to ask whether Shakespeare liked French fries.
    But if Little Timmy’s ability to refer to Shakespeare depended on Shakespeare’s having written Romeo and Juliet – if little Timmy’s ability to refer to Shakespeare depended on the accuracy of the statement: somebody uniquely wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x – then his statements would indeed have been abortive.
   What is going on here is that little Timmy added “Shakespeare” to his lexicon in manner (iii). He heard you refer to him; so the existence claim through which he added “Shakespeare” to his lexicon is something like: there is some x such that, on such and such occasion, Daddy said that x wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x.  And that existence-claim remains true, even though the other one -- somebody uniquely wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x – turns out false.
     What role did this other existence claim – the one that turned out to be wrong – have? Suppose you see meet somebody at a party; you don’t know him; but he acts as though he is very important. You ask your companion: “Who is that guy? What gives him the right to be so self-important?” You are told: “He is the dean”. Before you know who that person was, you were able to refer to him, and also to have thoughts about him. You were able to think that he is obnoxious and to wonder what gives him the right to be so haughty. But, despite this fact, there is still some sense in which you don’t know who he is. You can be able to think about, and refer to, somebody, without knowing quite who they are. When you tell little Timmy “Shakespeare is the guy who wrote Romeo and Juliet”, you are telling him (or trying to tell him) who Shakespeare was: and this, as we’ve just seen, is different from transmitting to Timmy the ability to think about, or refer to Shakespeare. (Of course, what we’ve said about Shakespeare and “Shakespeare” applies to inanimate objects and the words that label them.) Most “descriptive definitions” are really cases where one is learning who somebody is, or which object something is; they are not cases where one is acquiring the ability to refer to, or think about, that thing. Usually, the ability to refer to, and think about, the object in question seems to pre-exist knowledge of who somebody
[266]
is or which object something is.
      There are cases where one is genuinely acquiring a name in manner (ii); but they are not easy to produce; and they tend to be somewhat artificial.       But here there is only one really important point. Whenever one adds a referring term to one’s lexicon, that involves one’s knowing some uniquely individuating description of the referent: for any name N, then one’s adding N to one’s lexicon involves one’s knowing some true claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi, and N names x. (This is true, we found, even in the case where one acquires the name through ostensive definition.) The existence claims usually are not ones of historical moment; they are not ones like somebody x wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” names x. They are usually highly specific to the peculiarities of one’s own situation. But what is important is that knowledge of some such claim, historically trivial though it may be, is needed to use a name to refer to a thing. I wish to be clear on one point. Even though we learn what a name refers to through some existential-descriptive claim, the name itself is just a label. Semantically, “Shakespeare” simply labels Shakespeare; it doesn’t have any descriptive content (except such as it has in virtue of being a mere label of Shakespeare). But one always learns which thing a name labels through some existentialdescriptive claim. The semantics are not existential-descriptive; but the act of learning the semantics is existential-descriptive.  The semantic rule for “Shakespeare” must be given to you in some way or other. But what  is given is not the same thing as how it is given. The following statement is false:
 
(S1) The semantic rule for “Shakespeare” is this: somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and “Shakespeare” names x.
 
  S1 is false because “Shakespeare” refers to Shakespeare in worlds where Hamlet was never written. So the semantic rule for “Shakespeare” cannot have anything to do with Hamlet.   But the following statement is true:
 
(S2) Somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and, and the semantic rule for “Shakespeare” is this:  “Shakespeare” names x.
 
   The operator “the semantic rule for__ is” must be given narrow-scope. Otherwise we end up committed to a false descriptivism. The name is just a label. The literal meaning of “Shakespeare was prolific” is simply:
Shakespeare wrote Hamlet. It is not: somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and x was prolific.
    Though false, S1 is not, so to speak, as false as the following:
 
(S3) The semantic rule for “Shakespeare is this: for any predicate *…x…*,
*…Shakespeare…* means: somebody O uniquely wrote Hamlet and…O…
 
    What is literally meant by “Shakespeare was bald” is simply Shakespeare was bald; it is not: somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and x was bald.     To avoid running afoul of Kripke’s correct points, we must take care to give the relevant operators – “refers to”, “is the semantic rule for__” – narrow scope. We must make sure that they are safely to the right of potential descriptive, and therefore modal, contaminants. We’ve seen that, whenever you learn the semantics of a name, it is through descriptive information. But whenever we learn the semantics of a name, we apparently give the descriptive content wide-scope. That, presumably, is why you don’t regard *N has phi* as analytic, or as true in all possible worlds, even though you learned N’s semantics by being told that something x uniquely has phi and N names x.
 
§     Dummett (1973) argues for wide-scope descriptivism. “Socrates was necessarily bald” means: there was some x such that x was a unique great philosopher to drink hemlock and necessarily: x was bald. It is pretty clear, I think, that this doctrine is false. (See Soames 2001 for an excellent discussion.) “Socrates was bald” doesn’t entail “somebody drank hemlock”. Dummett’s analysis deals with some of Kripke’s modal points, but not with Kripke’s compelling point that there is no analytic connection between
“Socrates was bald” and “somebody drank hemlock.” It will be noticed that
(S2) is true only because, in it, the “the semantic rule for__” operator is given narrow scope, so that no descriptive information falls within its clutches. By being careful about where we put that operator, we avoid any kind of descriptivism --narrow-scope or wide-scope --and our analysis remains Kripke-friendly.
 
V.
 
    There is a point that we must address. It will help if we first define a bit of terminology. Let
 
(^) something x has phi
 
be a true proposition. Of course, what makes it true is that, indeed, some particular thing O has phi: the truth of any generalization supervenes on the truth of some singular proposition. Let us refer to O as the “verifier” of (^). Consider the claim “somebody is bald”. This is true because some particular person is bald – because Fred is bald  or Bob is bald. So Bob and Fred are verifiers of “somebody is bald”. An existence claim can have many verifiers.
(False existence claims have none.) A true existence claim of the form “somebody uniquely has phi” has exactly one verifier.
     Now let us state the problem that my analysis faces. One typically forgets the existence-claim through which one added a name to one’s lexicon. One typically forgets the first time one heard “Shakespeare” or “Aristotle”; one often forgets one’s first meeting of a person. Given this, one is tempted to say:
 
   “You don’t necessarily associate any uniquely individuating description with “Aristotle” or “Smith” or “Jones”. Such a description was needed to enable you to refer to those people, and to think about them. But once that ability is in place, the description drops out. At that point, there can be pure thought about the entities in question. You can just think about Aristotle and Smith; you don’t have to think about them through a uniquely individuating description.
 
       This, I believe, is not how it works: conception is not such a psychologically or epistemically impoverished phenomenon – it is replete with descriptive information. What happens, I would argue, is not that one ceases to have knowledge of a uniquely individuating description, but rather that one replaces one such description with a related but distinct one.         Remember what we said earlier about “Fred”. If you add “Fred” to your lexicon in manner (i), i.e. through an ostensive definition, that involves your knowing some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” names x.
  Suppose you and a friend are at a party. You see somebody wearing a bowler hat, talking animatedly. At time t, your friend points to that person and says “that is Fred”. Your adding “Fred” to your lexicon involves your knowing some existence claim, something like:
 
(e1) there is now somebody x whom I am sense-perceiving and attending to, and who is wearing a bowler hat, and “Fred” names x.
 
    Let us suppose that, a minute or so after “Fred” is ostensively defined for you, you go up to him and start talking. Now you have new information about Fred; you have a new uniquely individuating description of him. There are a number of reasons for this. First of all, the mere lapse in time between your current situation – your now talking with Fred – and the initial ostensive definition by itself guarantees that you will have a new uniquely individuating description of him. At time t, (e1) was your uniquely individuating description. But now that time has passed, (e1) has been replaced. By itself, the mere passage of time replaces (e1) with:
 
(e2) there is somebody x whom, a minute or two ago, I was  sense-perceiving and attending to, and who was then wearing a bowler hat, and “Fred” names x.
 
 
  notice that (e2) “interlocks” with (e1). The thing having the property specified in (e2) is the same as the thing having the property specified in (e1). The uniquely individuating description changes. But the new one is related to the old one in such a way that something x uniquely makes both of them true. The new one “inherits” the verifier of the old one. In a moment we will say more about this process of inheritance or transmission.
   But other things, besides the mere passage of time, will replace (e1), with a new uniquely individuating description. You are now engaged in conversation with Fred. You can see him more clearly (although from afar he looked hale and strong, you now see that he is puffy and out of shape); he is saying certain things to you (he is talking about the national debt and the current administration). As a result, you generate a new uniquely individuating description of Fred. Your new one is something like:
 
(e3) there is somebody x whom, a minute or two ago, I was  sense-perceiving and attending to, and who was then wearing a bowler hat; and I am not attending to x, and conversing with him, x is now talking about the national debt, and x looks puffy and unhealthy, and “Fred” names x.
 
Notice that (e3) and (e2) interlock; (e2) transmits its verifier to (e3).     Now that you have (e3), you can drop (e2) and (e1). You can completely forget them; and that will not jeopardize your ability to think about Fred. Suppose a moment passes; you have stopped talking with Fred. By itself, the mere passage of time replaces (e3) with a slightly different claim:
 
(e4) there is some x such that, a moment ago,  x was  talking about the national debt, and x looked puffy and unhealthy, and “Fred” names x.
 
 
  Suppose that you have completely forgotten (e1)-(e3). You still have some uniquely individuating description of Fred. And, so long as you are able to think about Fred, this will continue to be the case. You go home at night. (e4) is now replaced with:
 
(e5)  there is some x such that, several hours ago, at a party,  x was  talking about the national debt, and x looked puffy and unhealthy, and “Fred” names x.
 
  This process can continue ad infinitum. One’s ability to think about, and refer to, something can only be started up by one’s acquiring knowledge of the right kind of existence claim. Typically, that specific claim is forgotten. But it is replaced by another “interlocking” existence claim – another interlocking uniquely individuating description. And that second one will, in its turn, be replaced by a third; and that third by a fourth, and so on.      The point is that the ability to think about, and refer to, an external object always involves possession of a uniquely individuating description that applies to it.
     The objector says that there can be “pure”, i.e. non-descriptive, conceptions of objects. But conception is surely not so innocent; and this becomes clear when we consider the phenomenon of recognition. To recognize something is not, at least not merely, to register the truth of a bare identity proposition – a proposition of the form O=O. To register the truth of Smith is Smith is not, by itself, to recognize anything, and to recognize something is not (merely) to register the truth of O=O. Recognition is obviously replete with knowledge of descriptive content. When you recognize the man in the distance as the man who insulted you at the restaurant, a great deal of descriptive, and therefore existential, knowledge is involved. You know that there was some x such that x insulted me at the restaurant…You also see that there is some y in the distance such that…Your recognizing the man in the distance as the man from the restaurant involves your “integrating” or putting together this information: you see that both descriptions – man in the distance and man from the restaurant – connect somehow; you see that there is some one thing such that both descriptions apply to it. In other words, you recognize the truth of some existential claim like: there is some x such that x is a man who insulted me at the restaurant and is also a man in the distance whom I am now seeing. Once it is granted that recognition has a descriptive, and therefore an existential, component; and once it is granted that recognition involves putting together this existential-descriptive information; it becomes highly plausible to see recognition as consisting in one’s registering the truth of the kind of existence-claim described a moment ago. The alternative is to see recognition as stripped of any descriptive content: but this is not psychologically (or, I think, epistemologically) plausible.
    Let us relate these points about recognition to our analysis of conception – the two things are closely related. When you recognize something, what is happening is that two conceptions converge. Your recognizing the man in the distance as the man at the restaurant involves your putting together different pieces of descriptive information; it involves your realizing that some one conception (the awareness you are having now, of the man in the distance) and some other conception (the one you have of some lout whom you dealt with at a restaurant) both pick out some one thing. Now if conceptions were “pure”, i.e. were non-descriptive and therefore non-existential, then the just mentioned convergence of conceptions would be stripped of any descriptive content. Descriptive information wouldn’t be involved; and recognition would be reduced to the registering of some bare claim of the form O=O. But that is not what recognition is. Recognition is obviously replete with descriptive, and therefore existential, content; and given the essential role that conceptions have in recognition, it becomes necessary to ascribe some of this descriptive knowledge to conceptions. So it becomes necessary to see conceptions as being paved with descriptive-existential knowledge. This fact, combined with the fact that we often forget the description which starts up a conception, gives plausibility to the analysis we gave a moment ago regarding the sustaining of a conception: a conception is sustained by a series of interlocking existence claims.
     None of this belittles the role that causal connections play in conception and reference. I am able to think about, and refer to, Fred precisely because I saw him: and seeing something involves being causally connected to it. But how is the causal connection involved? What enables me to think about Fred is my knowledge of some uniquely individuating description: there is some guy whom I am now seeing and attending to, who is wearing a bowler hat, and “Fred” names that guy. The causal connection is involved in my seeing Fred; and my seeing Fred, in its turn, is involved in my having a uniquely individuating description of him. So what is doing the work is my knowledge of a uniquely individuating description of Fred; the causal connection, though essential, has a role that is subordinate and internal to my knowledge of that description.
    The most important reason not to think of conception as “pure”, i.e. as descriptively vacant, is that such a conception makes it impossible to deal with Hesperus/Phosphorous cases. And the most important strike in favor of our analysis is that it enables us to deal precisely with such cases – in a way that is Kripke-friendly (and Putnam-friendly) but also psychologically viable.
Let us now turn to this.
      Here we need to be very clear about a certain distinction: the distinction between literal meaning and cognitive content. “Fred” is just a label. The following statement is true:
 
(F1) There is somebody x who I met on such and such occasion,  and who looked pale and talked about communism; and the semantic rule for “Fred” is: “Fred” names x.
 
The following statement is false:
 
(F2) The semantic rule for “Fred” is this: There is somebody x who I met on such and such occasion,  and who looked pale and talked about communism; and “Fred” names x.
 
The following is even more false
 
    
 (F3) The semantic rule for “Fred” is this: for any predicate *…x…*, *… Fred…* means: There is somebody O who I met on such and such occasion, and who looked pale and talked about communism and…O…
 
  The literal meaning of
 
(*) “Fred looked puffy and pale”
 
is simply:
 
(*LM) Fred looked puffy and pale.  
 
   But remember that one knows what “Fred” refers to only in so far as one knows some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to x. For one to know what “Fred” refers to is, or at least necessarily involves, one’s knowing some such claim. When you hear a sentence like (*), you have to interpret it. There is a difference between hearing the sounds and knowing their meaning. To interpret it, you have to exploit your background knowledge. You know what “Fred” refers to only in so far as you know some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to x. To interpret (*), you have to exploit that knowledge. So even though the literal meaning of (*) is simply (*LM), nonetheless you access that literal meaning only by way of some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to x. So what (*) conveys to you – not what it literally means, but what it conveys to you (what it means to you, we might loosely put it) – is some claim of the form:
 
(*CC) somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to x, and x looked puffy and pale.
 
 
  
    Here we have to be very careful if we are to stay on the right side of Kripke’s discoveries.
    The sentence
 
(fa) “I am looking at Fred and he looks puffy and pale,”
 
   is not analytic; it doesn’t matter how you added the word “Fred” to your lexicon. Everybody who speaks English knows that (fa) is not definitionally true (or otherwise analytic). Everybody knows that (fa), though true, could have been false. Now suppose somebody points to a puffy, pale person and says “that guy is named ‘Fred’”. In that case, as we’ve seen, “Fred” is being added to your lexicon by way of your learning some existence claim like:
 
(pp) there is some x such that I am looking at x and x looks puffy and pale, and “Fred” refers to (names, means) x.
 
    Of course, your friend did not explicitly say pp; but pp was the import of his ostensive definition; speaking very loosely, we might say that it was the implicature borne by his words. Notice that, in that implicated message, the semantic operator (“names”, “refers to”, “means”) is given the narrowest possible scope. Because of this, you know that what (fa) literally means is some proposition of the form
 
(x) O looks pale and puffy,
 
   for some individual O. And, for the same reason, you know that (fa) does not encode some existence claim.
   Thus you will have no temptation to regard as analytic sentences like (fa); you will know that (fa) encodes something of the form O looks pale and puffy and, thus, that it does not encode something like anything pale and puffy is pale and puffy or any other analytic proposition.
   Let us sum up. Whenever you add a referring term N to your lexicon, you do so by way of learning the truth of some claim of the form: something x uniquely has phi and N names (refers to, means) x. The semantic operator is given the narrowest possible scope. That is the reason why “N has phi” is not analytic. Further, at some level, you know that it must be given the narrowest possible scope.  That is the reason you will rightly judge “N has phi” not to be analytic. Given any predicate *…x…* -- with some trivial exceptions – the preceding discussion makes it clear why you rightly judge *…Fred…* not to be analytic.
     The exceptions I have in mind are those in which “Fred” occurs only vacuously or trivially, for example: “thing x such that x is either flat or not flat”, “extended object”, “thing x such that 1+1=2”. Let us describe such predicates as “vacuous”. (Our usage of this term is related to, but distinct from, the usage it has in logic.) A “vacuous” predicate is one that applies to any spatiotemporal entity. So for any non-vacuous predicate *…x…*, our discussion makes it clear why *…Fred…* is not analytic, and also why anyone who knows the semantics for “Fred” rightly judges it not to be analytic.
 
VI.
 
     Kripke pointed out that “Aristotle was a great philosopher”, “Napoleon was a great general”, and the like are not analytic. Given what we just said, it is clear why our analysis is consistent with this fact, and why it is on the right side of Kripke’s well substantiated anti-descriptivism.
     At the same time, our analysis explains why “Hesperus is Phosphorous” and “Fred is identical with Tommy” can communicate non-trivial propositions. We already explained why (fa) communicates (pp).
    Now suppose that a few days later, you are at another party; this time it is a costume party. Somebody is dressed up in a suit of armor. Your companion happens to be acquainted with that person; but he knows him only by his street name, which is “Squiggy”. In this case, the word “Squiggy” is being added to your lexicon. For reasons that we’ve covered, that addition is effected by way of your learning some true claim of the form:
 
(^^) something x uniquely has phi and “Squiggy” refers to (names) x.
 
The actual claim in question is something like:
 
(^^^) Right now, there is somebody x that I am attending to, and x is wearing a suit of armor, and “Squiggy” names x.
 
   The literal meaning of
 
(s) “Squiggy is drunk”
 
is simply some claim of the form
 
(s2) O is drunk.
 
   But for reasons that we’ve discussed, what (s) communicates to you is not a bare ascription of drunkenness to some individual. Under the circumstances, what (s) communicates to you – what it means to you – is some existence claim, something of the form:
 
(s3) Right now, there is somebody x that I am attending to, and x is wearing a suit of armor, and “Squiggy” names x, and x is drunk.
 
Now we’ve already established that the literal meaning of
 
(f1) “Fred is drunk”
 
is simply:
 
(f2) Fred is drunk.
 
 But we’ve also established that what (f1) communicates to you is some existence claim. The existence claim which it communicates is a function of the peculiarities of the circumstances under which you added “Fred” to your lexicon. If those circumstances are sufficiently different from the circumstances under which you added “Squiggy” to your lexicon, then the propositions that  (f1) and (s1) will communicate to you (not the ones they literally mean) will be radically different; the one needn’t entail the other.
(f1) might communicate the claim:
 
(f3) there is somebody x whom I saw at a party ten days ago and x looked puffy and pale and “Fred” names x, and x is drunk.
 
Of course, (f3) doesn’t entail, and isn’t entailed by, (s3).
  It is pretty clear how to apply to this to the Hesperus-Phosphorous case. You learn what “Hesperus” means through some existence claim:
 
(h1) there is some lovely celestial object x such that x is the only body to have yet appeared in the evening sky and “Hesperus” names x. 
 
“Phosphorous” is added to your lexicon through a different existence claim:
 
(p1) there is some lovely celestial object x such that x is the last body to remain in the morning sky and “Phosphorous” names x. 
 
 
A consequence is that
 
(h2) “Hesperus is lovely”
 
communicates  to you (not what it literally means) is
 
(h3) there is some lovely celestial object x such that x is the only body to have yet appeared in the evening sky and “Hesperus” names x, and  x is lovely,
 
whereas the proposition that
 
(p2) “Phosphorous is lovely”
 
communicates to you is
 
 
(p3)  there is some lovely celestial object x such that x is the last body to remain in the morning sky and “Phosphorous” names x, and x is lovely.
 
 
  Thus the propositions that (h2) and (p2) communicate to you are entirely different; neither entails the other.
  But, in (h1) and (p1), the semantic operators are given the narrowest possible scope. So “Hesperus” is just a label – not a description quantifier – and the same is true of “Hesperus”. Thus for any non-vacuous predicate *… x…* -- including “celestial body that appears before any other in the morning sky”, and “celestial body that disappears after any other from the evening sky” --  what *…Hesperus…* literally means is non-analytic; the same is true of what *…Phosphorous…* literally means.   Further, as a competent speaker of English, you know (if only tacitly) that the semantic operators in question are to be given narrow scope; so you will rightly judge that *… Hesperus…* and *…Phosphorous…* are non-analytic, for all non-vacuous choices of *…x…*.
     So everything works out exactly as we want it to. We have a semantics that is consistent with Kripke’s well confirmed point that names are not descriptions. But notwithstanding that fact, we have a pragmatics (or an epistemology, perhaps) that explains why  *…Hesperus…* may communicate  something different from *…Phosphorous…*. Given that “Hesperus” and “Phosphorous” are not descriptions, it is hard to believe that they are anything other than mere names, mere labels. Given that they name the same thing, it follows that (h2) and (p2) have  the same proposition for their literal meanings. This is all fine. But we need to reconcile that fact with the fact that  (h2) and (p2) communicate different propositions. This reconciliation is not so hard to make; we simply need to identify the facts about how we learn semantics. The difference in cognitive value between (h2) and (p2) is not to be explained semantically; it is not to be explained by tinkering with the semantic rules for “Phosphorus” and “Hesperus”; it is to be explained by carefully identifying the facts surrounding our coming to learn those rules.
 
VII.
 
     If you accept the thesis that “Hesperus” and “Phosphorous” are mere labels, then (supposedly) you have a devil of a time accounting for the obvious cognitive difference between (h2) and (p2). At the same time, given what Kripke said, nobody wants to deny that these names are mere labels.
This is quite a puzzle: let us refer to it as the Direct- Reference Theorist’s
Dilemma (DRTD).
   Some have dealt with DRDT by advocating a “two-dimensionalism” about names. Different tokens of “you” refer to different things. The type “you” does not refer to anybody. But that type still has a meaning: it is a function that assigns referents to tokens of that word, on the basis of facts about the context of utterance. This function is the character of the type “you”. A given token of “you” has content: this is the thing to which that token refers. (So if I say “you are tired” to Smith, the content of that token of “you” is Smith.) Thus “you”, and indexicals generally, have a “two-dimensional” semantic structure.
  The character of “you” is associated with descriptive content (addressee of the speaker’s words). The content of a token of you has no descriptive content; it is simply an individual. But because indexicals have a twodimensional structure, they can be both directly referential and have
[267]
descriptive content.
     Some have dealt with DRDT by saying that proper names, like indexicals, have a two-dimensional semantic structure. So tokens of “Hesperus” and “Phosphorous” are indeed mere labels. But the types corresponding to those tokens have characters, or something similar to characters; and those characters are associated with different descriptive contents. And the difference in cognitive value between (p2) and (h2) is rooted in the fact that “Hesperus” and “Phosphorous” have different characters; in any case, they
[268]
differ with respect to some character-like semantic dimension.
 
§     I don’t think that this two-dimensionalism is necessary to account for that cognitive difference. (I also don’t think it is an available option.) We’ve seen that reference is always fixed by descriptive information. The description is given wide scope (with respect to the semantic operator). Because of that, the name in question is a mere label. But given only that semantically the descriptive information takes wide-scope, it doesn’t follow that it is cognitively inert. You will still associate that descriptive information with the name. You cannot access word meaning in a vacuum. The meaning of “Hesperus” is simply Hesperus (Venus/Phosphorous). But there is a difference between hearing “Hesperus” and assigning it the right meaning. Even though the meaning of “Hesperus” is simply Hesperus, your knowing that fact consists in your knowing some proposition of the form: something x uniquely has phi and “Hesperus” names x. To assign the right referent to a token of “Hesperus” you must exploit this knowledge. Thus, inevitably, sentences of the form “…Hesperus…” will communicate something descriptive, something existential, even though what they semantically encode has the form: …O…
     Differences in cognitive value don’t always have a strictly semantic basis. Sometimes they do – but not always. The sentence “snow is white” has a different cognitive value from “grass is green”; and that fact has a semantic basis. But that is not always how it works. Suppose you look through a microscope at Alpha, and you are told by your lab partner: there is some x such that you are looking at x, and let “Smith” refer to x and let “Smith” have no other semantic content. Later, without your knowledge, you are again looking at Alpha, this time with the naked eye, and you are told: there is some x such that you are looking at x, and let “Jones” refer to x and let “Jones” have no semantic content other than x. By our stipulation, “Smith” and “Jones” have exactly the same semantic content. So “Smith is lovely” and “Jones is lovely” have the same proposition for their literal meaning. But, also obviously, they have different cognitive values. This is because reference cannot be fixed, or accessed, in a vacuum. Even though “Smith” is a mere label, the act of putting that label on a thing, and the act of figuring out which thing that label is on, is necessarily paved with descriptive information. The semantics of an expression is one thing; figuring out its semantics is another thing. Instead of taking refuge in dubious twodimensionalism, we need only distinguish semantics proper from the epistemology of semantics.
 
 
VIII.
 
 
    It has often been said that to think about an object, one has to be causally connected to it. This has been held both by semanticists and also by philosophers of mind. Kaplan (1968) held it early in his career (though he later retracted it); so did Donnellan. Much of Fodor’s work is devoted to arguing that to be aware of an object – to have a concept of it – just is to stand in a certain kind of causal relation to it.
     This view seems to conflict with the fact that we can refer to things to which we have no causal connection. The famous example is “Newman 1”, which is defined thus: if there is an x such that is borne before anyone else in the 3rd millennium A.D., let “Newman 1” refer to x. So if Brown has that property, then
 
(N1) “Newman 1 will be a genius”
 
 semantically encodes the proposition:
 
(BG) Brown will be a genius.
 
 
     It seems pretty clear that we can make our expressions refer to anything we want; it doesn’t matter whether we have the right causal liaisons or not. But, for whatever reason, many have also held that one must be causally connected to a thing to think about it. They have dealt with this situation by saying that we don’t grasp the proposition semantically encoded in (N1); we are not causally connected to Brown (at least not in the right way); therefore we cannot think about him; therefore we cannot assign the right referent to “Newman 1”. For in order to do that, we’d have to grasp Brown; but we cannot, owing to our not having the right causal relation to him.
      Given what we’ve said in this paper, this reasonable-seeming view should be reconsidered. It is undeniably true that, in many cases, our ability to think about a thing involves our having a certain causal relation to that thing. But we’ve seen that, in every such case, the causal connection between subject and object is simply an ingredient in one’s knowledge of the right kind of uniquely individuating description. In all cases, one’s conception of a thing consists in one’s knowing some existence claim of which that thing is the sole verifier. If you acquire a concept of Fred by seeing him (or otherwise sense-perceiving him), that consists in your acquiring knowledge of an existence claim of which Fred is the unique verifier. If you acquire a concept of Fred by being told about him, or by hearing about him, that too consists in your acquiring knowledge of an existence claim of which Fred is the unique verifier. In all cases, then, knowledge of a thing consists in knowledge of a uniquely individuating description that applies to that thing. In some cases, a causal connection between subject and object is an ingredient in that knowledge. But it is never the causal connection per se that supports conception; it is always knowledge of a uniquely individuating description.        If I am able to think about Socrates, it is – we have found, in direct contradiction to the contemporary orthodoxies – entirely because I know some uniquely individuating description that applies to him. Conception is knowledge of a uniquely individuating description. The presence of a causal relation between subject and object, when present, is simply a means to that end. Obviously we can know of a uniquely individuating description that applies to Brown (Newman1). So it seems wrong, or at least arbitrary, to say that we can think about Socrates but that we cannot think about Newman 1. For the very thing that enables us to think about Socrates is present in the
[269]
case of Newman 1.

Intentionalism and Foundationalism
 
Abstract: Intentionalism is the doctrine that mental states cannot differ in phenomenal content unless they differ in respect of what they represent: phenomenology “supervenes” on representational content. Intentionalism is thus committed to the view – in fact, it is the view – that a given kind of phenomenal content intrinsically has a certain representational content: nothing must be added to that kind of phenomenology to  associate it with that kind of representational content; no contextualization, no back-ground knowledge, no ulterior factors are needed to secure that association. (Compare: given that the aesthetic properties of the statue supervene on its physical properties, it follows that nothing must be added to those physical properties to secure the connection between those physical properties and those aesthetic properties.) Wilfred Sellars argued compellingly that what makes a given bit of phenomenal content have a given kind of representational content is precisely the addition of such background knowledge – of such contextualizing information: to think otherwise, said Sellars, is to be guilty of “the myth of the given” – a spurious epistemic foundationalism. In this paper, I merely bring out the connection between intentionalism and the myth of the given. I argue that, unless Sellars is completely wrong, intentionalism must be completely wrong.
 
 
 
    The purpose of this paper is to show that a doctrine known as
intentionalism is guilty of what Wilfred Sellars called ‘the myth of the given’, and is therefore untenable.
    What is intentionalism? Some mental entities have both phenomenal content (phenomenology) and representational content. My perception represents the world as being a certain way; so it has representational content. And there is ‘something it is like’ to have that perception; so it has phenomenal content (it has ‘phenomenology’). 
    Intentionalism says that two experiences cannot have different phenomenal contents unless they have different representational contents. So phenomenal content ‘supervenes’ on representational content.
    I submit that intentionalism is guilty of the ‘myth of the given’. Let me say what this means by way of a Sellarsian story.
    You are in a tie shop in which the lighting conditions are a bit unusual.
[270]
 You are looking at a tie in a display case. The tie induces various visual sensations in you. On the basis of these sensations, you can’t quite tell whether the tie is orange or red or maroon. You take the tie outside to examine it in better lighting. You see that it is maroon. Now you know what a maroon tie looks like under the lighting conditions that obtain in the tie shop. So the next time you see what is in fact a maroon tie in the tie shop, you don’t have to take it outside to determine that it is maroon.
   But if a tie is some color other than maroon– say, burgundy or maroon -you cannot know that on the basis of the visual sensations you have in the tie shop – for the same reason that, earlier, you couldn’t tell that a tie was maroon on the basis of the sensations you had in the tie shop. Let me illustrate my meaning with a new story. You are again in the tie shop, and are looking at what is in fact a burgundy tie. You can’t tell what color it is. So you take it outside. There you see that it is burgundy. You take it back inside and attend to its appearance. You then know that that is what a burgundy neck-tie looks like in the conditions that obtain in the tie shop.
    You repeat this process over and over again, until you can tell for any color C what an object with C looks like in the lighting conditions that obtain in the tie shop. The correspondence that obtains between objects’ colors in the tie shop and one’s visual sensations is different from the correspondence that obtains between objects’ colors and one’s sensations outside the tie-shop. By repeating the processing described a moment ago, you learn the former correspondence-rule. And you no longer have to go outside to know what color a tie is. After a while, if you manage to internalize this rule of correspondence, you will, while inside the tie-shop, be able to just see what color a tie is. No doubt somebody who has been working in the tie-shop a long time can see what colors the ties have; he doesn’t have to go through a laborious process of inference (or, at least not a conscious one).
    What does this tell us? When you are in the tie shop, your visual sensations do not by themselves tell you what color a given object is. What tells you this is your visual sensation plus knowledge of various environmental conditions that obtain. By itself, your visual sensation is color-indeterminate. What is color-determinate is the visual sensation plus a great deal of background knowledge.
    So, when you are in the tie-shop, your visual sensations (at least so far as they relate to color-facts) are not ‘foundational’; in order for them to tell you what colors objects are, they must rely on ulterior knowledge that you have: their ability to tell you anything presupposes knowledge, on your part, of various environmental conditions.
   Let us sum up. In some contexts, your sensations do not by themselves tell you what colors objects are; only those sensations coupled with background knowledge about the conditions of perception tell you that.
     It is easy to generalize this argument – to make it apply to any perceivable property P. (By a ‘perceivable’ property, I mean one that we sense-perceive objects to have. We don’t sense-perceive that an object consists of atoms with three electrons. So that property is not perceivable. But we do sense-perceive that an object is more than ten feet away from us. So that is a perceivable
[271]
	property.)
     Ordinarily we think that we can just see how distant an object is from us. But when I just see that a certain tree is less than a hundred feet from me, a lot of background information is at work. For example, you take it for granted that the tree is not 10,000 feet tall. If you thought that the tree was 10,000 feet tall, then a phenomenally identical perception would lead you to think that you were seeing a tree was miles away, as opposed to 80 ft away. Let us amplify and substantiate these remarks through a Sellars-type thought experiment.
       When you look through a microscope, small things appear big. When you look through a telescope, big things appear small. Imagine that, every morning, you woke up wearing a pair of goggles that either magnified or diminished the strength of your sight. On Monday, you wake up wearing a pair of microscope-goggles – so it would be as though you were looking through a microscope. Another day, you wake up wearing a pair of telescope goggles – so it would be as though you were looking through a telescope. And everyday it would be different; the magnifying power of the goggles would be different every day. (So one day it would be as though you were looking through a weak magnifying glass. Another day, it would as though you were looking through a moderately powerful telescope.)
     Under these circumstances, your visual perceptions at the start of any given day would be distance-indeterminate and, therefore, size-indeterminate. You wouldn’t know whether you were seeing an object that was 100 feet tall and a light-year away or an object that was ten feet tall and was ten feet away. You would have to learn what correspondence obtained between the character of your visual perceptions, on the one hand, and the distances and sizes of objects.
   One way you could do this is as follows. You look at a given object; you don’t know whether it is a ten foot object that is 100 ft off or a ten-thousand foot object that is ten miles off. You take off the goggles and you simply see how far off, and how tall, the object was; you see that it is a building that is approximately 100 ft tall that is 100 ft away. You then put the goggles back on and, now knowing the distance and size of the object, you look at it again: you know now that an object that, when you are wearing the goggles, looks like that is really an object of such and such dimensions and thus such distance away from you. You repeat this process, with objects of other sizes and distances. And eventually you learn the correspondence that obtains between, on the one hand, the character of the visual perceptions that you have while wearing the goggles and, on the one hand, the distances and sizes of the objects you are seeing. Eventually, you will, while wearing the goggles be able to simply see that the object your are looking at is (say) ten feet tall and a 100 ft away – just as somebody who works in the tie-shop can simply see that a given tie is burgundy, even though the lighting conditions are nonstandard. But, of course, when you simply see (while wearing the goggles) that a given object is ten ft tall and a 100 ft away, it is not your visual sensations by themselves that apprise you of the object’s size and distance; what really does this is your visual sensations plus a great deal of background knowledge about the conditions of perception.
    It is important to note that, before you learn the just mentioned correspondence, your visual sensations are distance- and size-indeterminate. A given sensation could tell you either that an object is 10,000 ft tall and 100,000 ft away or that it is 20 ft tall and 10 ft. away. Until you acquire the relevant background knowledge, your visual sensations are simply indeterminate in these respects; your visual sensations don’t tell you either that the object is 10,000 ft tall and a 100,000 ft away or 20 ft tall and 10 ft away. In response to this, one might say:
 
     Under these circumstances, your visual sensations would give you determinate messages, but these messages would be wrong. You wake up in the morning wearing goggles that, let us suppose, quadruple the strength of your vision. In that case, your visual sensations give you systematically false messages: you see objects as being four times larger than they are and, thus, four times closer than they actually. So it isn’t that your visual sensations are size- and distance-indeterminate; it is that they are size- and distancedeterminate but that they are determinate in the wrong way.
 
    
    At first this seems like a reasonable view. But really it is very arbitrary. As
[272]
	Tyler Burge said, a perception to the effect that P is necessarily prima facie evidence that P. If you see a red chair in front of you, that is necessarily prima facie evidence that there is a red chair in front of you. In the story we are telling, you wake up every morning with goggles of a different level of magnification attached to your eyes, and you never wake knowing what the level of magnification is. Under those circumstances, your initial sensations are not even prima facie evidence of facts relating to the sizes or distances of objects. Given only your initial sensations, you would be equally justified in believing that you were seeing 100 ft object 100 ft away or a ten thousand foot object 10,000 feet away.
