So your initial sensations wouldn’t be prima facie evidence of either state of affairs – or, by analogous reasoning, of any other state of affairs relating to the distance or size of the object in question. Thus your initial perceptions wouldn’t tell you that the object was this as opposed to that size or distance; you wouldn’t, veridically or non-veridically, see the object as being of this or that size or distance.
   The objector’s point can be confuted in another way. Again, suppose you wake up wearing goggles that strengthen your vision four-fold, but when you wake up you don’t know what magnification these goggles have. After you ‘acclimatize’ to your goggles, you will simply see objects as having the dimensions that they in fact. (We are leaving aside cases of objects that are extremely distance or extremely small. One doesn’t really see a star to a million light years away; one doesn’t see it, veridically or non-veridically, to be any determinate distance away from one. And of course one doesn’t see a proton, veridically or non-veridically, to have this or that size; for one doesn’t see protons at all.) After this acclimatization, when you look at an object that is ten ft tall and twenty ft away, you won’t first see it as forty ft tall and eighty ft away; you will see it for the size and distance that it actually has – just as the veteran of the tie-shop, even while in the tie-shop, will see ties for the colors they actually have: he won’t see a burgundy tie as being orange and then consciously figure out, on the basis of his background knowledge, that what he is seeing is in fact burgundy. He will see the tie for the color it has.
    Let us refer to the person who has acclimatized to his goggles (with magnification × 4) as Post-Bob, and let us refer to that same person, after waking up but prior to that acclimatization, as pre-Bob. We’ve agreed that Post-Bob sees objects as having the sizes and distances that they actually have. (That is, Post-Bob has size-right and distance-right perceptions in so far as any one does. Whether we’re dealing with Post-Bob or with a ‘normal’ person of 20/20 vision, there will inevitably be perceptual vagueness and error, especially where extreme sizes or distances are concerned). Now the objector says that pre-Bob simply sees objects as being 4 times their actual size: so his perceptions are not size-indeterminate, but systematically sizewrong. But that puts the objector in an awkward position. Pre-Bob’s visual sensations don’t change as he metamorphoses into Post-Bob. But it is very hard to see how a determinately false perception could become a determinately correct perception simply as a result of a change in background knowledge. It seems that if, when you woke up, you had perceptions that were systematically false, as opposed to indeterminate, a change in background knowledge wouldn’t result in veridical perception: it would
[273]
	simply enable you to intellectually  correct for your non-veridical perceptions. But this isn’t what happens: Post-Bob sees things the right way; he doesn’t see things the wrong way and then make a mental note to himself along the lines of ‘I see that tree as being 80 ft tall, so it must really be 20 ft tall’. No – he sees the tree as being the height that it actually is.
   So it is hard to see how systematically false perceptions could be turned into veridical ones through a change in background knowledge. But it is easy to see how indeterminate perceptions can be turned into determinately veridical ones once background knowledge is filled in. If one’s perceptions are indeterminate (in respect of, say, size or distance), then there is a kind of openness to correction built into them: there is a parameter in it that has yet to be set and that consequently can be set. But if a perception is determinately false, it is frozen; background knowledge won’t turn it into a veridical one; the perception will continue to give one its wrong message (though, armed with the right background knowledge, one will be able to intellectually superimpose the right message).  So it is very hard to see how a determinately wrong (or, to use Quine’ word, a falsidical) perceptions can become veridical through a change in background knowledge. But it is very easy to see how a change in background knowledge can turn indeterminate perceptions (for example, size- or distance-indeterminate perceptions) into determinate ones.
We are taking the latter position. The objector is committed to the former.
Therefore the objector is wrong. Pre-Bob’s perceptions are size- and distance-indeterminate, not size- and distance-false.
     Let us sum up thus far. Under non-standard conditions of perception, one’s sensations do not by themselves apprise one of the sizes or, therefore, the distances of objects. What does this is those sensations operating in conjunction with a great deal of background knowledge. Absent this background knowledge, one’s visual sensations are simply size- and distanceindeterminate.
      Exactly similar reasoning shows that, under non-standard  conditions, our perceptions are mass-indeterminate, temperature-indeterminate, velocityindeterminate, and so on. Given any perceivable property P, under nonstandard conditions, our sensations do not by themselves tell us to what degree, if any, x has P; only our sensations operating in conjunction with background knowledge (about the conditions of perception) do that. Under non-standard conditions, our sensations, taken by themselves, are temperature-indeterminate, mass-indeterminate, and so on. They become temperature- and mass-determinate only in so far as they are put in the context of a great deal of back-ground knowledge. In general, under nonstandard conditions, perceptions are indeterminate. For any kind of perceptible property P – P could be size, distance, color…-- it would be possible to create non-standard perceptual conditions such that, under those conditions, one’s perceptions were P-indeterminate. And, under such conditions, what makes one’s perceptions become P-determinate is the acquisition of background knowledge – knowledge of facts about the conditions of perception.
   Another way of putting this is to say: for any kind of perceptible property
P, it would be possible to create circumstances in which one’s perceptions are P-determinate only with the help of background knowledge. Under such circumstances, when one saw an object O as having P (or as having P to degree n), a great deal of background knowledge would be implicated in that perception. Consequently one’s perception of O as having P would not be foundational; it would be built on top of, so to speak, a great deal of background knowledge about the conditions of perceptions. Under those circumstances, it would not be given to one that O was P; not even a false message to the effect that O was P would be given to one. One would be ‘given’ (if that is the right word) only a non-epistemic sensation; one’s background knowledge would be needed to assign that sensation a P-value.    So far we’ve spoken about non-standard perceptual conditions. But it is easy to show that what we’ve said applies equally to standard perceptual conditions. For standard conditions are just non-standard conditions that one has got used to; and the distinction between standard and non-standard conditions is quite arbitrary.  In fact, no conditions are quite standard; if we make conditions perfectly standard – the way they might be in a surgical theatre or in the kind of room where they make computer chips – the result is a situation where the perceptual conditions are so good that they are not standard any more. And one is always doing in a small way what, in the anecdote above, Bob was doing in a big way: one is always making allowances for background knowledge.
    Let us once again think about Bob. One morning Bob wakes up fitted with goggles of magnification ×2. But this time the goggles stay on for years and years. This time, since Bob wouldn’t be able to take off his goggles, it would not be an option for him to compare his goggle-produced perceptions with his non-goggle perceptions: so he couldn’t’ he would no longer have that way of figuring out what his visual modality was telling him. But he would still acclimatize. From his pre-goggle days, he obviously knows the sizes of objects – of stop signs and baseball bats, and so forth – and he could use these as benchmarks. Initially, he would consciously correct for his perceptions by using these benchmarks; he see an object, not know how big it was, compare it to a baseball bat, see that it was the same size, and then know how big it was. But eventually, no doubt, Bob would simply see objects for the sizes they were. (At least in so far as anybody does: nobody’s vision is without significant indeterminacy in many respects; one doesn’t see very distant or very large objects as being specifically this or that size or, derivatively, as moving with this or that speed.)
    Of course, in some ways, Bob’s vision will be much better than that of an ordinary person’s, and in other ways, it will be worse. (He will have superb far-sight, but terrible near-sight.) But this doesn’t matter to our discussion. What matters is this.  Bob’s ×2 vision will become standard for Bob – just as your vision, with its ×1 magnification, is standard for you. It is clear, given what we’ve so said so far, that Bob’s perceptions acquire determinate content (at least in respect of distance and size and related properties, like speed) only with the co-operation of background knowledge. Not only does Bob’s ability to acquire knowledge (of distance, size, and related properties) presuppose a great deal of background knowledge. So during this ×2 phase of Bob’s vision, sizes and distances (and related properties) would not be given to Bob; his perceptions would be size- and distance determinate only by courtesy of a great deal of background knowledge. So distances and sizes would be given to Bob in the sense that he could, within limits, see what sizes and distances objects had; they would be made known to him. But sizes and distances would not be given in the sense that his distance- and size-perceptions would be foundational; he would have size- and distance-perceptions only because there was a lot background knowledge at work. Of course, in so far as a hefty body of background knowledge must lend its help to make perceptions represent things as having determinate sizes and distances, to that extent sizes and distances are not given to one; one has to earn them, so to speak. So in a special, but by no means arbitrary, sense of ‘given’, distances of and sizes are given to Bob during this ×2 phase of his visual career.
   But now suppose that, after all these years, Bob’s revision reverts back to how it used to be. So it is no longer ×2, it is ×1. His vision now would not be standard for him, even though it used to be. He would have to do now what he had to do before when he first shifted to ×2 vision. He would acquire new background information, and this new background information would be implicated in making his new perceptions be size- and distance-determinate. So, just as distances and sizes were not given to Bob in his ×2 phase, so they are not given to Bob in his new ×1 phase. Exactly similar considerations apply.
   But what about Bob’s old ×1 phase? Maybe, it might be thought, sizes and distances were just given to him then. But it would be highly arbitrary to say that. There are two reasons for this. First, it is very hard to believe that Bob’s new ×1 perceptions function in a completely different way from his old ×1 perceptions. We know that his new ×1 perceptions are size- and distancedeterminate only by courtesy of a great deal of background knowledge concerning the conditions of perception. But if, during Bob’s old ×1 phase, distances and sizes were just given in perception (in our special sense of ‘given’), then the epistemic liason between Bob and the world constituted by Bob’s old ×1 perceptions would very different from that constituted by his new ×1 perceptions. But there seems no reason to believe this.
   There is a second reason to think it arbitrary to say that during Bob’s old ×1 phase distances and sizes were given to him (in our special sense of ‘given’), whereas during his ×2 phase they are not given. We’ve been discussing extreme changes in the conditions of perception. But one’s visual career is ordinarily characterized by much smaller, but still very genuine, changes perceptual conditions. And what we said in connection with artificially dramatic change in these conditions is just as true of the smaller versions of such changes that actually occur. One can scarcely walk ten feet, or even rotate one’s head, without the lighting conditions changing. But usually (though not always) one doesn’t have to make a conscious adjustment. One automatically makes the adjustments, and sees green objects as green and red objects as red.
   The kind of sensation that mediates a perception of a particular shade of red is heavily dependent on highly variable conditions. One doesn’t realize this until one tries one’s hand at painting, and has to reckon with the setting of the sun or the uneven light cast by a lamp. To reproduce in painting two different objects that one sees to be of a single shade of red, one may have to use two very different shades of paint. When one looks at the painting, one sees the two objects as being of the same shade of red – just as the artist, when he was having the actual perception which he reproduced in the painting, saw the two objects as being the same shade. But when one looks at the paint – not the painting, not the things depicted by means of the paint – one sees two different shades of red. The differences in shade correspond to differences in quale, in sensation. The identity of color of the objects represented in the painting corresponds to the identity in representational content of the perceptions reproduced in the painting.
    Thus one makes innumerable adjustments to ever changing perceptual conditions. So one is perpetually adjusting to non-standard conditions. We can only assume, by arguments analogous to those given earlier, that one’s background knowledge is implicated in these perceptions. Colors (for example) are not given to one; what is given to one is a non-epistemic sensation – a sensation with no determinate color- (or distance- or size-…) content. What does constitute a color- (or size-…) determinate perception is that sensation in conjunction with a great deal of back-ground knowledge.
   Or course, arguments exactly analogous to those that we’ve given in connection with size, distance, and color apply to mass, temperature, and any other kind of perceptible properties: perceptible properties are not given (at least not in our special sense of the word). Whenever one has a perception that is mass- or size- or temperature or color-determinate – that is, whenever one has a perception that even purports to tell one what color or temperature or mass… an object has – that is, in part, because one’s quale sensations are interacting with a great deal of background knowledge. The sensations by themselves are not color- or size- or temperature-determinate. The sensations themselves – the ‘raw feels’ or quale -- are not representational. The sensations plus the background knowledge is what is representational.    Of course, a perception is, by definition, representational; a perception necessarily is either size- or color-… or mass-determinate; a perception necessarily gives one some kind of message and is thus not wholly indeterminate. So what we have seen is not, obviously, that perceptions are not representational (that would be absurd) or that facts about the world are not given through perceptions (that too would absurd: there is no other way that facts about the external world are given to us). What we have seen is that the very existence of any single perception presupposes the co-operation of background empirical knowledge. (This raises the question how we can ever have a first perception: a question handles very delicately. There isn’t room to address this problem here. But I don’t think it constitutes any significant obstacle to the anti-foundationalism sketched here.) 
    The ‘myth of the given’ is that a given sensation by itself constitutes some kind of awareness of an external reality, and that no background knowledge is presupposed. Of course, if this were the case, then sensations would be epistemic rock-bottom: they would constitute the foundations of all knowledge. In sensation, certain bits of information would be given to us – in our special sense of ‘given’ – and all knowledge would be built on top of this given information. (And, in this context, to say that piece of information is ‘given’ to us in a sensation is to say that no background knowledge would be implicated in the acquisition of this information.)
   Actually, what we’ve seen is not only that no knowledge is ‘given’ (in our special sense), but that nothing representational is given: background knowledge is implicated in the generation of anything that even purports to give information about the world. So not only is no knowledge given; nothing even representational is given. There are thus two myths of the given: one is that knowledge is given; the other is that there are perceptions in a vacuum of background knowledge – in other words, that in some cases one’s sensual experiences do not need the co-operation of background knowledge to constitute perceptions (or even misperceptions). I submit that intentionalism is guilty of the second ‘myth of the given’ and thus a fortiori is guilty of the first.
   We’ve seen that the perception results when the quale interacts with background knowledge: before that happens, there is nothing representational – the quale is size- and color- and temperature--…indeterminate. So there is an extremely strong sense in which nothing is given: nothing that even purports to give true information about the world exists without the cooperation of background knowledge. A fortiori there is no actual awareness of what is going in the external world without the co-operation of background knowledge. Sensations by themselves are not just epistemically, but representationally, inert; they are, as we put it, ‘indeterminate’ until background knowledge sets the relevant parameters. And different bodies of background knowledge can ‘set’ these parameters differently.
   All of this is very inconsistent with intentionalism. Intentionalism says that there cannot possibly be a difference in phenomenology unless there is a difference in representational content. Intentionalism thus assimilates the phenomenological to the representational. Given that there cannot possibly (in any possible world) be a difference in phenomenology without one in representational content, it follows phenomenology is realized or constituted by something have representational content. (Otherwise the supervenience of the phenomenology would be inexplicable.) And it also follows that, if any bit of phenomenology was non-representational, it would have to be the only kind of phenomenal content was non-representational. (For if there were two non-representational types of phenomenal content, then there would be a difference in phenomenal content that was, vacuously, not matched by a difference in representational content: obviously two bits of phenomenal content that represent noting don’t represent different things.)
   But the picture we’ve sketched contradicts these contentions in a number of way. First, we’ve seen that phenomenology is not typically realized by (let alone identical with) something representational. Perception involves the cooperation of sensations (quale) and back-ground knowledge; in such cases, the sensation is not inherently representational, but becomes so only with the help of background knowledge. Thus at least some sensations are not by themselves representational. So this contradicts the contention that phenomenal content is always realized by something having representational content.
   Also, it would seem that the inherently non-representational qualia that are involved in one perception can be dramatically different from those involved in another perception. So this contradicts the idea that there can be at most one kind of non-representational phenomenal content. Thus intentionalism is contradicted on two levels.
   To sum up, the intentionalist maintains that a quale by itself typically constitutes a representation; for the intentionalist maintains that the thing having phenomenal content is identical with, or realized by, the thing having representational content. (Thus, for the intentionalist, the thing having phenomenal content cannot possibly fail to be representational– just as the statue cannot fail to be, say, wet if the clay that realizes the statue is wet.) But to say this is fall squarely into the myth of the given: the spurious belief that perceptual representations do not implicate background knowledge and sensations by themselves are epistemic.
   In one place, Sellars himself writes: “Sensations are no more epistemic in
[274]
	character than are trees or tables…” My guess (though the context of that quotation makes it unclear whether this guess is correct or not) is that he had in mind points like the ones we’ve just stated.
   We arrived at these points by doing a great deal of theory. But they are borne out by examples. Under certain lighting conditions, you see a tie – literally see it – as being burgundy. Under different lighting conditions, in having a phenomenologically identical perception,  you see – literally see that  tie as maroon (or, in any case, some color other than burgundy).  You see a tree as being moderately tall and being (about) twenty feet away. But, given different background knowledge, a phenomenologically identical perception could tell you that you were seeing a gigantic tree that was (about) a hundred feet away.
   Suppose that Bob is in his × 1 phase, and that P is a bit of phenomenal content that mediates a perception of a small tree nearby. When Bob is in his
×2 phase, or his ×10 phase, a bit of phenomenal content qualitatively just like P will mediate a perception of a large but distant tree. The same bit of phenomenal content was associated with different representational contents. 
This is inconsistent with intentionalism.
    Intentionalists tend to defend their position by seizing on facts like the following. Suppose that in circumstance C1, some sensation is involved in seeing that a tie is burgundy. And suppose that in C2, some qualitatively different sensation is involved in seeing that a tie is burgundy. (This will happen if the lights are dimmed somewhat, or if the over head light is replaced with a  less pure, more yellow light: it could happen under any number of circumstances.) Of course, prima facie this seems to favor the anti-intentionalist: different representational contents, same phenomenal content. But the intentionalist always responds by saying:
 
The two perceptions don’t have the same representational contents. In one case, part of what you are seeing is a light casting an impure yellowish light. In the other case, you may not be seeing that, and you may be seeing a light that is casting a very pure, white light. Or in the one case, the tie may be better illuminated than in the other case. So the two qualitatively identical perceptions are representing different things: in the one case a well illuminated patch of burgundy is represented; in the other, a poorly illuminated patch of burgundy is represented. And that is why there is a difference in phenomenal content: for there is a difference in representational
[275]
content.
 
 
  
   But this doesn’t apply to Bob. Depending on whether he is in his ×1 phase or his ×10 phase, a given a bit of phenomenal content may mediate perceptions with very different representational contents. So there is sameness of phenomenal content and a difference in representational content. The same bit of phenomenal content is deployed once in seeing a small nearby tree, and another time in seeing distant large tree.
    These considerations help us identify the shortcoming in a well known argument for intentionalism due to (or at least stated by) Alex Byrne. Byrne gives the following argument for intentionalism.
     
  Suppose you are looking at a blue chip. Your seeing the blue of the chip obviously involves your having some kind of phenomenal content. Now imagine a change in the phenomenal content that is involved in your seeing the blue of the chip. If there is such a change, then there is necessarily a change in the color that the chip is represented to as having; it goes from being represented as blue to being represented as (say) green. The same point (mutatis mutandis) applies to any perception. If you imagine a change in the phenomenal character of your gustatory perception of the honey, then the honey goes from being represented as sweet to being represented as (say) bitter. One last example: suppose you hear a certain pitch as a middle C (you have perfect pitch); if the phenomenal content involved in your hearing that pitch is changed, then ipso facto you no longer hear that sound as a middle C but as (say) a middle D. So: no difference in phenomenal content without a
[276]
different in representational content.
 
 
   But there are obvious counter-examples to this. You can feel the roundness of the ball and also see it (a bat could hear it, a mole could smell it). But these perceptions have no phenomenal overlap, despite considerable (though my no means total) representational overlap. You can see distances, and you can also learn distances kinesthetically. Obviously a visual perception has no phenomenal overlap with a series of kinesthetic sensations, despite a certain overlap in representational content.
   Also non-occurrent memories have no phenomenal overlap with perceptions whose representations they store (or can store, in principle) in their entirety. Total overlap of representational content: no phenomenal overlap. (Of course intentionalism is defined as the position that two experiences cannot differ in phenomenal content without differing in representational content. So it may see that intentionalism doesn’t say anything about whether a non-occurrent memory can have the same representational content as, say, a perception without having any phenomenal overlap with it. But this is not the case. Consider a perception P with phenomenal content C and representational content R. Intentionalism says that having P has C wholly in virtue of having R. So, for intentionalism, having R is a sufficient condition for having P. So, if intentionalism, then nothing other than having R is needed to have C. So intentionalism is committed to the view that anything has P as long as it has R. But a nonoccurrent memory has R but not P.)
    Byrne’s argument proves at most that within a single sensory modality there cannot be phenomenal variation without representational variation. But this thesis is false, it turns out, if we consider different sensory modalities or memories.
   But we’ve seen that Byrne’s thesis is false even within a single modality. At the same time, it is not an accidental fact, surely, that within a single modality, differences in phenomenal content tend to co-vary with differences in representational content. And, admittedly, the most obvious way to explain this is by advocating some kind of intentionalism. So we owe Byrne an nonintentionalist explanation of this co-variation.
   What Byrne has shown is not that phenomenal content co-varies tout court with representational content, but that phenomenal content co-varies with representational content all other things being equal. And I submit that, in this case, the ‘other things’ consist of one’s background knowledge.     Obviously phenomenal content is involved, in an essential way, in our perceptions; and, obviously, perceptions are involved in an essential way, in our acquiring knowledge of the external world. Now if phenomenal contents are to be of assistance in our acquiring empirical knowledge, then presumably they must be paired off in a consistent with way their (proximal) causes. If a given kind of sensory disturbance (i.e. a given kind of disturbance of one’s retina or epidermis or eardrum…) result now in one kind of phenomenal content, and now in some totally different kind of phenomenal content, then one’s phenomenal contents wouldn’t be much use in helping us acquire knowledge of the external world. We would be lost. (We can tolerate occasional shifts of this kind. But these shifts cannot be the norm: they must occur against a background of stability.) So there must be a reasonably consistent relationship between our phenomenal contents and their (proximal) causes. There must be some rule R that pairs off tissue disturbances (of our sensory organs) with phenomenal contents (and does so in some not ridiculously Byzantine way).
   But is there only one possible value of R? Do your perceptions have to be associated with their causes in exactly the way they are in fact associated with them to tell us what they do about the world? Under certain conditions, sound-wave oscillations of 440 Hz cause a certain kind of phenomenal content (call it P1); under those same conditions, sound-wave oscillations of 480 Hz cause a certain kind of phenomenal content (call it P2), and so on. Let R1 be the rule that pairs off phenomenal contents with disturbances of your eardrum in that particular way. Must R1 be the operative rule of projection? Would a being whose auditory system involved R2 (some rule other than R1) necessarily be mis-hearing everything? It seems that, if R2 is as consistent as R1, it can be as good a rule of projection, i.e. it can be involved in the generation of perceptions that are as accurate (if not more so) than those had by a being with R1. In fact, R2 might be better than R1 in this respect. R1 may assign the same phenomenal content to sound-wave oscillations of 440 Hz that it assigns to those of 445 Hz. (Human beings are not even remotely capable of registering such minute differences, though other creatures are. So R1 might the rule operative in human hearing.) If R2 is more sensitive to differences in sound-wave oscillations – and clearly non-human creatures are better able to hear differences in pitch than we are (and this presumably involves having different phenomenal contents in response to different pitches in cases where we would have the same phenomenal content in response to both pitches) – and R2 is just as consistent, then it seems extraordinarily arbitrary to say that creatures whose hearing-system uses R2 are just mis-hearing all the time. But that is just what the intentionalist is committed to. Obviously humans hear things the right way, at least some of the time. And obviously our hearing things involves having certain phenomenal contents in response to sound-wave oscillations. The intentionalist says that a creature that has a different phenomenal response to the same sound-wave oscillations. The intentionalist also says that a difference in phenomenology means a difference in representational content: so those other creatures are hearing things as being different and thus – since we are hearing things the right way and they are hearing things differently – as hearing them wrong. To clarify this: Suppose a human’s  hearing (under certain circumstances) a middle C involves having phenomenal content P, and that human a C correctly under those circumstances. For an intentionalist, a creature that has phenomenal content P* (different from P) under those same circumstances is not hearing a middle C; it is hearing some other pitch. So that creature is hearing the wrong thing. Thus if that human’s audition involves R1, then every other right-hearing creature’s hearing must involve R1 as well. No other correspondence rule, no matter how finegrained (even if it is much more nuanced than ours) or consistent will do.
  But again this seems deeply arbitrary. If another creature’s phenomenal responses to sound-wave oscillations are just as consistent as ours and just as fine-grained, then by any reasonable conception of information, it can acquire as much information about the world through hearing as we can; and it then seems arbitrary to say that it systematically mis-hears just because it is employing R2 and not R1. And if a creature’s hearing involves a more finegrained, and more internally consistent rule than ours, then by any reasonable conception of information, it can acquire more information (through hearing) than we can about the world; and it then becomes all the more arbitrary to say that such a creatures is always hearing things the wrong way just because it uses R3 not R1. And there is no doubt that there are, in principle, rules other than the one operative in human hearing that are more fine-grained than ours and as consistent than ours. (to say that a rule R is more ‘fine grained’ than a rule R* is to say that, for some n, if sound-waves differ from each by less than n, but still differ, R will, whereas R* will not, pair off those sounds with different phenomenal contents. There can be no doubt that, by this definition, there are creatures whose hearing involves much more fine-grained rules of correspondence than ours – bats, dogs, rabbits.) So there seems no reason in principle to deny that creatures that hear better than us might have different phenomenal contents from us in response to a given sound-wave under a given circumstance. But intentionalism says no difference in phenomenal content without a difference in representational content. And the motivation for this view is that the phenomenal reduces, after a fashion, to the
[277]
representational. But apparently it does not. 
         I would suggest that what Byrne has shown is that as long as a given rule of projection is operative, then the phenomenal ‘tracks’ the representational, i.e. if perceptions have different phenomenal content, then they have different representational contents. This is to be expected since an inconsistent rule of projection – one that assigned different phenomenal contents to the same sound (heard under the same circumstances) – would not be of much use (in learning about actual sound-phenomena). But what Byrne doesn’t register is that if the rule of projection is changed, then the representational value of a given phenomenal content can change. Suppose that Bob is a human being who has (by human standards) good hearing. Let R1 be the operative rule projection. Suppose that neurosurgeons change Bob’s auditory system. Now the rule of projection that is operative in his hearing is the one operative in a bat’s. Obviously Bob’s hearing a lot better than it used to be. But given what we said a moment ago, it seems highly likely that, in this new and improved version of Bob, a phenomenal content that used to be involved in hearing (say) a middle C is now involved in hearing a middle D. So when the rule of projection is changed, Byrne’s thesis no longer applies: phenomenology tracks differences in representational content only given a certain rule of projection. In any case, this seems plausible.
   We’ve said a lot about the role of ‘rules of projection’ in the assigning of representational contents to phenomenal contents. What we’ve said on this matter is consistent with Sellars’ attack on the myth of the given. Sellars’ attack, we’ve seen, comes in two strengths. Weak version: it is not typically true that qualia, by themselves, constitute awarenesses (knowledge) of anything external – something extra is needed to make a quale be epistemic. Strong version: it is not typically true that qualia, by themselves, constitute representations – something extra is needed to give them representational content.
   We’ve seen reason to hold that both versions are correct.  But we seem to have a problem. We’ve apparently given two different answers to the question ‘what is that extra something which makes a non-representational (or non-epistemic) quale be representational?’ One answer we gave is: background knowledge. The other answer is: a rule of projection.     To deal with this, we need only be clear on what we’ve said so far. The rule of projection doesn’t assign representational contents to disturbances of our sensory surfaces. The rule of projection assigns only phenomenal contents – qualia – to such disturbances. It is background knowledge that assigns representational contents those qualia. So the ‘rule of projections’ that we’ve been talking about have an altogether different function from background knowledge, though of course the two are part of a co-operative enterprise.
   
   Conclusion
 
      Intentionalism says that, typically, qualia by themselves have determinate representational content: background knowledge isn’t needed to endow qualia with representational content. And, of course, in so far as qualia have representational contents ab initio, background knowledge cannot affect what representational content they have. For if background knowledge did have a hand in endowing a quale with representational content, it could only be by way of some openness, some representational indeterminacy, on the part of the quale; and, by definition, a quale with a ‘fixed’ representational content has no such indeterminacy or openness. Thus the picture given to us by the intentionalist is that, typically, qualia don’t need background knowledge to fix what they represent, and they won’t let background knowledge fix what they represent. Qualia thus become foundational, performing their representational and epistemic roles in splendid isolation of any epistemic context. But it is just this kind of foundationalism that Sellars (and, after him, many others) have shown not to be tenable. Intentionalism is a strong form of foundationalism; it is guilty of the myth of the given, in both its forms. Therefore either intentionalism is to be rejected or the anti-foundationalism of Sellars and others – now so widely held – must be false.
 
 
 
Burge, Tyler. 1993. “Content Preservation”. The Philosophical Review, Vol.
102, No. 4, (Oct., 1993) 457-488.
 
Byrne, Alex . 2001.  ‘Intentionalism Defended’. The Philosophical Review.
Vol. 110, No. 2 . (April 2001).
 
Sellars, Wilfred. 1963a.  “Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind”. In
Science, Perception and Reality. New York: Routledge and Kegan Paul. -- 1963b. “Some Reflections on Language Games”. In Science, Perception and Reality. New York: Routledge and Kegan Paul.
 
Propositions, Logical Truth, and the Analytic-Synthetic Distinction
 
 
Abstract
 
     It is hotly debated whether or not there are non-spatiotemporal entities. It is not debated whether the so-called linguistic theory of logical truth is correct: everybody (nearly enough) agrees that it is false. This paper shows that one must either accept the existence of propositions (conceived as platonic entities of some kind) or one must accept the linguistic theory of logical truth. So propositions, and therewith a realm of platonic entities, must be countenanced. Given this last fact, Quine’s argument against the analyticsynthetic distinction proves to involve a fatal non-sequitur. Further, given that there are propositions, it becomes possible to give a viable analysis of “analyticity”.
 
I.   The sentence “snow is white” is meaningful. But is there some object that is its meaning? We know tables and chairs exist. But do the meanings of “snow is white” and “grass is green” exist alongside them?
    Given only that sentences are meaningful, it doesn’t follow that there such things as meanings. An analogy might help. For a work of art to be beautiful isn’t for it to be associated with some object. It isn’t as though the work of art is one thing, its beauty another, and the work of art is beautiful because it is somehow associated with this other entity. One might say that the property of being meaningful is like that of being beautiful: for a sentence to be meaningful is no more for it to be associated with some object than a painting’s being beautiful consists in its being associated with some object. [278]
    The meanings of sentences, if such things exist, are referred to as
“propositions”. So if in fact there is some object that is the meaning of “snow is white”, that object is a “proposition”.
     Many philosophers deny the existence of propositions. In their view, it is as absurd to suppose that there is some object that is the meaning of “snow is white” as it is to suppose that there is some object that is the beauty of the Mona Lisa.
     The purpose of this note is to show that propositions do exist. I will show that, if one denies the existence of propositions, one is committed to a doctrine that is now (rightly) believed false: the so-called “linguistic theory of logical necessity.”
   If anything is universally agreed on among philosophers, it is that the linguistic theory is false. What is not agreed on is whether there are such things as propositions: that issue is maximally controversial. This paper will show that, if one denies the existence of propositions, one has no choice but to advocate the linguistic theory. So this paper will try to tackle a controversial issue (whether there are propositions) by attempting to draw a tight connection between it and a non-controversial issue (whether the linguistic theory is correct).
    If I am not mistaken, we will find that Quine’s celebrated argument against the analytic-synthetic distinction is a failure, as it is implicitly committed to
[279]
	the linguistic theory of logical necessity. Thus the present paper, if cogent, will rehabilitate the analytic-synthetic distinction – or, at least, will undermine one of the more prominent arguments against that distinction.
 

	* The sentence “triangles have three sides” is in a different category fromthe sentence “Smith is bald.” It would be incoherent to deny the former; it would be coherent to deny the latter. Consequently, what the former says must be the case, and what the latter says need not be the case.
    It is through sense-perception that we know Smith to be bald. We see that Smith is bald or we sense-perceive evidence of his baldness. But how do we know of the truth of what is said by “triangles have three sides”? We obviously don’t know it by inspecting triangular objects. It isn’t through empirical research that we know it.
    Rationalists say: it is through “pure reason” – through some non-sensory cognitive faculty – that we know that triangles have three sides. Empiricists cannot take this position. For empiricism is, by definition, the view that all knowledge is acquired through the senses.
   One way empiricists have dealt with necessary truths is by turning them into linguistic truths. Sentences like “triangles have three sides” are plausibly seen as being true “by definition”. If one were to say “triangles do not have
[280] three sides”, one  would be “sinning against language”, as Ayer put it ; one would be using words in deviant ways. So “triangles have three sides” is made true by facts about language – facts about how people use words. It is true wholly in virtue of “linguistic convention”.
 

	* This theory is now (rightly) rejected. Later on we will discuss why it iswrong. What I’d like to do now is to show that, unless one believes in propositions – unless one believes that, in addition to tables and chairs and iguanas, there are propositions – one must advocate this false theory.    Let us refer to people who believe in propositions as “propositionalists”, and to people who do not as “anti-propositionalists”.
      Once again consider the sentence:
 
(T) “Triangles have three sides.”
 
 A propositionalist says:
 
(T) is necessarily true because it has for its meaning a necessarily true proposition, namely: triangles have three sides. That proposition is made true by facts about mind-independent concepts. The concepts triangle, and three and side are so interrelated that (T) must come out true, given that it bears the proposition triangles have three sides. So language makes (T) be true only in the sense that it associates that sentence with a necessarily true proposition. That proposition is true independently of anything having to do with language.
 
 
 An anti-propositionalist cannot say that. He cannot say that what makes (T) be necessary is that it is associated with a necessarily true proposition. For the anti-propositionalist doesn’t believe in propositions at all. So the antipropositionalist has to figure out some other way of answering the question:
What makes (T) be true?
    What options does the anti-propositionalist have? He cannot say that (T) is made true by facts about the interrelations of platonic entities – of properties or concepts (in the non-psychological sense). Why can he not say this? To take this line would be to grant the existence of propositions. Presumably, the proposition triangles have three sides, if it exists, just is some structure consisting of the concepts (or properties) triangle, side, and so forth; so it just is these objects, interrelated in a certain way. So if an anti-propositionalist says that interrelations among platonic entities are what make (T) be true, then he is conceding that propositions do exist, and he is no longer an antipropositionalist.
    Surely triangles have three sides, if it exists at all, is built up out of the concepts triangle, three, side  and so on. The propositions triangles have three sides and Jim’s pool has the shape of a triangle – if they exist at all -have something in common, corresponding to the fact that triangle is a constituent of both of them. So I don’t see how one could deny that triangles have three sides consists of the concepts (or properties) triangle, three, and side. And it is truistic that, if that proposition exists at all, these objects are arranged in a certain way in it.
  
   So what else is there, besides platonic entities and the relations that hold among them? There is also the spatio-temporal world. (And for reasons we’ve just noted, anti-propositionalists tend to say that the spatio-temporal world is all there is.) So the anti-propositionalist must look to facts about that domain, in his search for the truth-maker of (T). Trivially, there are two kinds of spatio-temporal facts: those that have to do with language – facts having to do with what expressions mean and with how people use them  – and those that do not. Let us see if the anti-propositionalist can find what he needs in either of these domains.
   Suppose the anti-propositionalist says that non-linguistic spatio-temporal facts are responsible for the truth of (T). To say that non-linguistic empirical facts are what make (T) be true is to say that (T) is in the same category as (B) “Bachelors are emotionally unfilled”. To say that non-linguistic spatiotemporal facts are what make (T) be true is to say, or at least imply, that to know that (T) is true, one has to examine the non-linguistic portion of the spatio-temporal world. And if one has to examine that portion of the world to know that (T) is true, then it is contingent (more exactly, it is epistemically contingent) that (T) should be false. For if one must study the non-linguistic part of the spatio-temporal world to know the truth of (T), then it is by all means possible to coherently conceive of (T)’s turning out false; for the negation of anything that can only be known through empirical inquiry is coherently conceivable, practically by definition. But everyone admits that (T) is not contingent, epistemically or otherwise; (T) is not – and no one (with the possible exception of Mill) denies this - in the same category as “bachelors are emotionally unfulfilled”.
    So if spatio-temporal facts are what make (T) be true, the facts in question cannot be non-linguistic facts. So they must be linguistic facts. So (T) is true because of facts about language. There are right and wrong ways to use expressions. Ultimately, whether it is right or wrong to use an expression in a certain way is a matter of convention. (I say “ultimately” because, although there are no conventions directly governing how to use complex expressions like “penguins would be able to fly if they had bigger wings”, there are conventions that directly determining how to use the corresponding simple expressions: “penguin”, “fly” and so on.) If you say “triangles do not have three sides” or “triangles have two sides”, you “contravene” these conventions, as Ayer put it. Your statement is counter-linguistic and ungrammatical.
    In a word, if one rejects propositions, one must embrace the linguistic theory of necessity.
 
IV. The linguistic theory is not without merit. One doesn’t need any empirical knowledge, apart from knowledge of semantic facts (linguistic conventions, semantic rules), to know that (T) is true and that the sentence “triangles have four sides” is false. The linguistic theory seems to account for this fact. So that theory escapes the absurd doctrine (sometimes attributed to Mill) that (T) is in the same category as “bachelors are emotionally unfulfilled.” Further the linguistic theory seems to show how a strictly empiricist epistemology can account for our knowledge of necessary truths.       But if anything is known with certainty in philosophy, it is that the
[281] linguistic theory is false. Its faults are extremely well-documented. Nonetheless it might be appropriate to give a few of the many cogent arguments that have been directed against it. I will also put forth an argument of my own. My argument isn’t as air-tight as some of the existing ones, but it is not wholly without force.
[282]
	   A famous argument is due to Quine. There are infinitely many logically true sentences. Convention can be responsible for, at most, a finite number of these. We haven’t existed long enough to have enacted infinitely many conventions. (We couldn’t exist long enough for that.) So the rest are not directly made true by convention. They are, at most, indirectly made true by convention. So they follow from conventions. But to say that they follow from conventions is to say that conventions plus logic are what make them true. So conventionalism reduces logic to conventions plus logic, and thus doesn’t reduce logic to conventions at all.
   Butcharov has a clever argument against the linguistic theory. [283]  (T) could have meant that penguins are good at chess. After all, semantic facts are obviously quite contingent. So (T) is necessary only if it means that triangles have three sides. So what is necessary is not (T); what is necessary is the statement:
 
(*) If (T) means that triangles have three sides, then (T) is necessary.
 
But (*) cannot be made true by linguistic facts. To deny this is to incur a vicious regress.  For obviously the sentence
 
(**) “If (T) means that triangles have three sides, then (T) is necessary”
 
could have meant that aardvarks are good at miniature golf or that the moon is made of cheese. So that sentence is not necessarily true. What is necessarily true is:
 
(***) If (**) means (*), then (**) is necessary.
 
If we say that (***) is made true by linguistic convention, then we are embarking on a regress. If we deny that (***) is made true by linguistic convention, we are rejecting the linguistic theory of necessity.
[284]
	   Another argument against the linguistic theory is this. According that theory, sentences like “triangles do not have three sides” contravene the rules of language. Now a string of verbiage that contravenes the rules of language is ipso facto not well-formed and is therefore nonsense. But “triangles do not have three sides” is not nonsense; for it is false, and what is false is not nonsense. “Bob triangles gladly the” is nonsense. “Triangles do not have three sides” is not nonsense. No linguistic fact makes “triangles do not have three sides” be false, and no linguistic fact makes “triangles have three sides” be true. To break a convention associated with language L is to produce something that is not a sentence of L. “Triangles do not have three sides” is a sentence of English: a false one. So that sentence breaks no conventions of English; therefore it is not false by reason of its breaking any conventions of English; therefore its negation (“triangles have three sides”) is not true by reason of its conformity to any conventions of English. 
   There is a more fundamental reason why the linguistic theory fails. Triangles had three sides before there was language, and they will have three sides after there is language. And this obviously isn’t a contingent fact. So language cannot be responsible for this necessity.
   I would like to give an original argument against the linguistic theory of
[285]
	necessary truth. I submit that, embedded within the concept of language, is the notion of necessity. Consequently to say that “language” underlies necessary truth is to speak in a circle.
   I warn that this argument is not as cogent as the others. This is because it presupposes a certain conception of what a language is.
    What is a language? One answer is this: a set of rules that (inter alia) associate expressions with truth-conditions: rules like
 
“…Socrates…” is true iff Socrates has the property…x…
 
and
 
“x is red” is true iff the object  denoted by “x” is red.
 
(So “Socrates smokes” is true iff Socrates has the property of smoking. And
“Jim’s wig is red” iff the object denoted by “Jim’s wig” is red.)
   Any human language must be learnable. Any learnable language contains only finitely many primitive rules. So any human language must contain finitely many primitive rules. But any human language contains infinitely many sentences that are assigned truth-conditions by those rules. Those rules cannot directly assign truth-conditions to all of those sentences. So the fact that those sentences have those truth-conditions follows from those rules, while not being directly established by them. In other words, those rules assign those truth-conditions to those sentences via principles of logic, and thus via necessities. So the concept of language – at least a language that, like English or Albanian, contains infinitely many sentences and finitely many primitive rules – is to be defined in terms of the concept of necessity. Thus one cannot non-circularly attempt to trace necessities to language.
   It must be said that the very people who propounded the linguistic theory of necessity – Ayer, Carnap, Schlick – did think of language in exactly the way I have just said. They thought of language as a formal calculus. Primitive expressions are assigned meanings by simple rules, and complex expressions are assigned meaning by way of derived rules or theorems of that calculus. Thus my argument shows that the linguistic theory fails on its own terms or, at least, on the terms of those who propounded it. So to that extent, the argument just given is not question-begging.
 
V.  This discussion makes us aware of an interesting irony the history of analytic philosophy. Quine, as we noted a moment ago, gave a compelling argument against the linguistic theory of necessary truth. But a few years later, in a publication that would come to be considered one of the two greatest works 20th century philosophy[286], Quine rejects the idea that there are propositions. He says that the notion of “meaning” (and a fortiori the notion of sentence-meaning or propositionality) is incorrigibly “obscure” and cannot pass methodological muster. Having rejected the notion of meaning, Quine then attempts to prove that there is no principled way to distinguish between analytic and synthetic sentences.
   His argument is basically this. Consider the sentence “all bachelors are unmarried”. Supposedly this sentence is analytic. If it is analytic, what makes it so? The obvious answer is this: the meaning of “bachelor” is related in a certain way to the meaning of “unmarried”. “Unmarried” means unmarried and part of what “bachelor” means is unmarried. So “all bachelors are unmarried” is synonymous with some sentence of the form “anything that is an F and a G is a F”, and obviously such a sentence is logically true, and thus a necessary truth.
     But Quine says that, because the notions of “meaning” and “proposition” are so bankrupt, we cannot countenance this analysis. Thus we must look for some other way to ground the analyticity of “all bachelors are unmarried”. The only possibility is that “bachelor” is synonymous with some expression of the form “…unmarried…” But it turns out that for two expressions to be synonymous is for them to be intersubstitutable salva analycititate. In other words, E and E* are synonymous only if, given an analytic sentence of the form “…E…”, replacing E with E* results in an analytic sentence.    So we end up defining analyticity in terms of synonymy and synonymy in terms of analyticity. This definition will not do, as it is viciously circular. We must conclude that analyticity is not non-circularly definable and is therefore a bankrupt concept.
    We’ve seen that if one rejects the notion of a proposition, one is committed to the linguistic theory of necessary truth. And Quine himself showed that theory to be untenable. So Quine has hoisted himself up by his own petard.     As we have seen, given that the linguistic theory is false, it follows that there are propositions and thus meanings. Once this is granted, then Quine’s argument against the analytic-synthetic distinction is blocked. Why is “bachelors are unmarried” analytic? Because the meaning of “bachelor” is related in a certain way to the meaning of “unmarried”: the concept expressed by “bachelor” is such that, if x falls under that concept, then as a matter of epistemic necessity, x must fall under the concept expressed by “unmarried.” Quine rejects this answer because he rejects the notion of meaning. But we’ve seen that this rejection commits him to the linguistic theory of truth.
So the notion of meaning must not be rejected.
       There is another point to make about Quine’s attack on the analyticsynthetic distinction. In Two Dogmas, Quine concedes that formally true sentences (what he calls “truths of logic”) are analytic. He concedes that “anything that is both an F and a G is an F” is analytic. (Obviously if Quine denied this, he wouldn’t have many followers.) What Quine denies is that any sentence that is not formally true can be analytic. “Bachelors are unmarried” has the same form as “bachelors are grumpy”. So, for Quine, “bachelors are unmarried” is not analytic.
     In saying that “anything that is an F and G is an F” is logically true, Quine is making a very modest concession. But he cannot make this concession without undermining the point he is arguing for (in Two Dogmas). We can show this by using Quine’s own argument against conventionalism against him.
   There are infinitely many formally true sentences. (Quine concedes this.) Non-linguistic spatio-temporal facts cannot be what is responsible for the truth of a formally true sentence. A formally true sentence is, by definition, one whose truth is guaranteed by its form and whose truth is, therefore, not a function of any non-linguistic spatio-temporal entity. Obviously Quine cannot say that such sentences are true in virtue of what meanings
(propositions) they are associated with. Since non-linguistic spatio-temporal fact don’t make them true, and since meanings (and thus facts about platonic entities: for as we’ve seen, meanings/propositions just are structures consisting of such entities) don’t make them true, the only thing left to make them is true is language: facts about semantics and word-usage and the like. But such facts – to echo Quine’s argument against conventionalism – can be directly responsible for the truth of only finitely many formally true sentences. But there are infinitely many such sentences. Let S be the infinitely large set of formally true sentences for whose truth linguistic facts are not directly responsible. So such facts are, at most, indirectly responsible for the truth of the members of S. The truth of those sentences is not directly guaranteed by linguistic facts, but follows from such facts. This means that such facts, plus truths of logic, are what make the members of S be true. But, on pain of incoherence, those truths of logic cannot themselves be seen as holding in virtue of language. Nor can they be seen as holding in virtue of non-linguistic spatio-temporal facts. (For if those truths of logic held in virtue of non-linguistic spatio-temporal facts, then the truth of the members of S true would itself turn on matters of spatio-temporal fact. But it doesn’t, as we’ve seen.) So those truths of logic cannot be regarded as holding in virtue of linguistic spatio-temporal fact or in virtue of non-linguistic spatiotemporal fact. They can only be seen, then, as holding in virtue of facts of a non-spatio-temporal kind: facts about platonic entities and their interrelations. As we saw earlier, once we concede the existence of such facts, we have in effect conceded the existence of propositions. 
   I will end by considering an objection to this line of thought:
 
   A formally true proposition isn’t made true by anything other than its form.
So it isn’t made true by (a) non-linguistic spatio-temporal matters of fact, or (b) linguistic matters of spatio-temporal fact, or (c) facts about platonic entities. The argument you just gave assumes that formally true propositions are made true by one of those three things, and that assumption is false.
 
  That assumption is not false, and this becomes clear when we examine the concept of sentential form. When you say that a sentence is true in virtue of its “form”, that obviously doesn’t mean that it is true in virtue of its shape. Nothing would be easier to imagine a language in which the following sentence token “anything that is an F and a G is an F” meant grass is orange. And, of course, in such a language   “anything that is an F and a G is an F” wouldn’t be true at all, let alone “formally” true. Basically, “form” doesn’t mean “morphology”, at least not in this context.
   When it is said that “anything that is green and bald is green” is “formally” true, that is an extremely loose way of saying that the only terms in that sentence whose meanings are relevant to its truth are the so-called “logical constants”: “anything”, “is”, “and”, and so on. Why those particular terms are held to be form-defining and not, say, “green” or “bald” is a matter of
[287]
	considerable debate. But the basic idea is that, no matter what terms we
[288]
	substituted for “bald” and “green”, the resulting sentence would be true. Thus “bald” and “green” figure only vacuously in that sentence. But, of course, the “logical constants” cannot typically be replaced without loss of truth; replacing the “and” with an “or”, for example, would result in a falsity.     The basic idea is that what we (misleadingly) describe as “formal” truth is actually a certain kind of truth in virtue of meaning. “Anything that is green and bald is green” is “formally” true because of facts about the meanings of certain of its terms – “and”, “anything”, and so on – guarantee its truth. Thus what makes that sentence be true are certain facts about its meaning. This, of course, is consistent with our point that logical truths hold in virtue of facts about platonic entities and their interrelations.
 
VI. I have argued that, if one denies the existence of propositions, one is committed to the linguistic theory of logical truth (a theory everyone agrees is false). An important part of my argument was the following statement:
 
  (*)  [T]he proposition triangles have three sides, if it exists, just is some structure consisting of the concepts (or properties) triangle, side, and so forth; so it just is these objects, interrelated in a certain way. So if an antipropositionalist says that interrelations among platonic entities are what make (T) be true, then he is conceding that propositions do exist, and he is no longer an anti-propositionalist.
 
      Obviously (*) is a reasonable enough point. But it has been denied. So to make my argument cogent, I must give a defense of (*).
        First of all, on what grounds has (*) been denied?  Some have held that propositions are sets of worlds or are functions from worlds to truth-values: the so-called possible-worlds conception of propositions. And an advocate of that view would, indeed, not hold that the proposition triangles have three sides consists of the concepts triangles and three and so on.
      But that view has notorious problems. The main problem, of course, is that it doesn’t distinguish between analytically equivalent propositions. (So, on the possible worlds approach,  2+2=4 and triangles have less than seven sides are the same proposition. For they are true in exactly the same worlds: all of them.) Another is that it is circular if it construes worlds as sets of propositions. For then a proposition is analyzed as a set of sets of truth-values or as a function from sets of propositions to truth-value: both analyses are blatantly circular.  On the other hand, the possible worlds approach is false, or at least radically implausible, if it construes propositions as sets of concrete worlds. For it is very hard to see how we would know anything
[289]
	about concrete objects lying outside this world. And, of course, we must be suspicious of semantic theories that require us to posit entities for which there is no independent corroboration.
      But we’ve just encountered yet another problem with that view. It is clear that triangles have three sides and squares have four sides and Jim’s pool has three sides all have something in common, corresponding to the fact that side is a constituent of all of them. But the possible-worlds analysis of propositions strips propositions of any constituent-structure or, at any rate, of the kind of constituent structure that would guarantee – what we know to be true – that side is a constituent of all of these propositions. For the possible worlds view says: all of these propositions are just sets of worlds. But the concept side is not in any clear sense a constituent of a set of worlds. So our analysis of propositions – that they are structures consisting of properties (or concepts) and objects (that triangles have three sides consists of the concepts/properties triangle, side and so on, interrelated in a certain way) – doesn’t beg questions against the possible worlds approach but, on the contrary, provides an additional independent reason to reject that approach.    A related problem with the possible worlds approach is that it isn’t consistent with the compositionality of thought. Obviously one’s grasping (a) triangles have three sides is cognitively related to one’s grasping (b) squares have four sides and also to (c) Jim’s pool is triangle-shaped. One’s grasp of the concept side is deployed in one’s grasping both (a) and (b), and one’s grasp of the concept triangle is grasped both in one’s grasping (b) and (c). Now unless both (a) and (b) had as a constituent the concept/property side, and  unless both (b) and (c) had as a constituent the concept triangle, these facts would be inexplicable. The fact that a grasp of a single concept or property is used in grasping different propositions suggests that propositions are built up out of concepts or properties. And this fact is completely inexplicable on a possible worlds view. So we are vindicated, I think, in holding that propositions – if they exist – just are structures consisting of properties (concepts). Thus, the anti-propositionalist cannot say that interrelations among concepts/properties are what make “triangles have three sides”, and other sentences of its kind, be true.
       Most importantly, practically no anti-propositionalists would want to say that “triangles have three sides” is made true by facts about platonic entities.
For belief in such entities is very much not in the spirit of antipropositionalism. Typically, one is an anti-propositionalist precisely because one doesn’t countenance platonic entities. Propositions come under suspicion because they are typically seen as being platonic entities.
    To sum up, the anti-propositionalist is barred from saying that facts about platonic entities make (T) be true. And the anti-propositionalist doesn’t even wish to take that view.

Blackwell.
 
Bonjour, Laurence. 1998. In Defense of Pure Reason. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
 
Dummett, Michael. 1978. “The Significance of Quine’s Indeterminacy
Thesis”. In Truth and Other Enigmas. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
 
Pap, Arthur. 1958. Semantics and Necessary Truth. New Haven: Yale University Press.
 
Peacocke, Christopher. 1999. Being Known. Oxford: Clarendon Press.
 
Quine, Willard van Orman. 1935/1966.  “Truth by Convention” in The Ways of Paradox and Other Essays. Cambridge: Harvard:.
--1951/1990. “Two Dogmas of Empiricism”. In The Philosophy of Language (A.P. Martinich ed.) Oxford: Oxford University Press.
