-- 1958. The Blue and the Brown Books. New York: Harper and Brothers.
 
Causal Efficacy and the Erroneousness of Functionalism and Content-externalism
 

	A. There are some compelling prima facie reasons to think that functionalism and certain forms of externalism strip mental content of any causal powers. If that is the case, then we have a powerful to reject those doctrines. Jackson and Pettit have produced a brilliant argument purporting to show that, in fact, functionalism and the relevant forms of externalism are compatible with the presumption that mental content is causally efficacious. Their argument involves an original and (I believe) correct point about causation. But I believe that their application of this correct point to this particular set of problems is flawed: they have not, I will argue, given us any reason to think functional and the relevant forms of externalism are in fact compatible with the presumption that mental content has causal powers. 
 

	* It seems clear that, in some cases, brain-states realize mental contents. (Iwish the word “state” to be taken as broadly as possible – to apply to both enduring brain-structures and occurrent phenomena.)  My belief that 1+1=2 is realized by certain brain-states. My belief that water is wet is realized by a different set of -brainstates.
    Let x be an arbitrary brain-state  According to functionalism, for x to realize mental content C is for x to have a certain causal role. For x to have a certain causal role is, at least in part, for x to have such and such effects. So x realizes a belief that bread nourishes at least partly in virtue of the effects that x has – for example, it leads to my choosing to eat bread (in certain contexts).      There is an obvious prima facie problem with functionalism. Mental content is causally efficacious. In any case, this is what we are inclined to think. My believing that bread nourishes is causally effective: it leads me to drive to the story and buy bread, to eat said bread, and so on. Given this, suppose that brain-state x has effects E1…En. x’s having C presumably has a causal hand in bringing about at least some of E1…En. As we just saw, supposing that x is a brain-state realizing your belief that bread nourishes, x’s being such a belief is what causes you to buy bread, eat it, and so forth. But if x’s having those effects is what x’s realizing that content consists in, then x’s realizing that content cannot possibly be what causes E1…En to come about. If x’s realizing a belief that bread nourishes consists in its causing me to drive to the store and buy bread, and to eat bread, and so on, then x’s realizing that belief cannot possibly be what causes me to drive to the story, to eat the just purchased bread, and so on. So if functionalism is right, my belief that bread nourishes ends up not having a causal hand in my going the store to buy bread; and, by an exactly similar argument, it ends up not having a causal hand in my wanting to eat bread, or bake bread, and so on. It ends up not having a causal hand in any of the contexts where, quite obviously, it does have a causal hand.
       The nature of this apparent problem for functionalism becomes clear if we are careful to make a certain distinction. Strictly speaking, it is not things that have causal powers. It is not the rock which breaks the window, but the rock’s moving with a certain velocity, and having a certain mass, and so on. The rock doesn’t do anything. What does the work is really the rock’s having certain properties – a certain mass, solidity, velocity, and so on – along with various other things having various properties (e.g. the window’s having a certain micro-structure).
    Not every one of the rock’s properties is causally effective in every causal transaction involving the rock. Suppose the rock has a certain dimple on one of its sides. In some contexts, the rock’s having that property will be causally effective. (For example, if you pour water down that side of the rock, the presence of the dimple will affect the course of the water.) But in other contexts, the presence of that dimple will not be causally effective. (For example, if you drop the rock in a vacuum, the presence of the dimple won’t have any effect on the trajectory of the rock.)
    Suppose, once again, that x is a brain-state realizing my belief that bread nourishes. Strictly speaking, x doesn’t do anything: what does the work is x’s having certain properties – e.g. x’s having certain electrical, chemical, and cellular properties. Not every causal transaction involving x is one where x’s electrical properties are causally effective. Perhaps in certain contexts it is x’s mass, not its electrical properties, that are causally relevant. Similarly, not every causal transaction involving x is one where x’s mental properties are causally effective. In some contexts, x’s mental properties might be causally irrelevant: what is doing the work in those contexts might be x’s having a certain electrical charge or its having a certain specific shape. So there is a difference between x’s being involved in some causal transaction, on the one hand, and x’s realizing a belief about bread being causally effective in that context. The latter might or might not be causally effective in that context.     But, of course, we want to believe that, in at least some cases, my believing that bread nourishes is causally effective. So, in effect, we want to believe that x’s having a certain mental content is specifically what is causally effective in certain contexts. What leads me to eat the bread in front of me is my believing that bread nourishes. Here what is effective is not just x, but is x’s having the right mental properties.
     Here is where the problems for functionalism begin. The functionalist says that x’s realizing that belief consist in its having certain effects: it consists  in, for example, its leading me to eat the bread in front of me (instead of putting it in a lead box). But if x’s realizing that belief consists in x’s having those effects, then x’s having that content cannot cause those things to happen – it cannot be what causes me to eat the bread. 
    Let us sum up. Functionalism says that for x to such and such mental content is for x to have such and such a causal role – it is, at least in part, for x to have such and such effects, to bring about such and such states of affairs. If that is right, then x’s having that content cannot be what causes those states of affairs to come about. x’s being a belief cannot be what causes me to choose to eat the bread; for x’s being such a belief consists in its causing me to make that a choice. So x’s being such a belief cannot be what causes me to make that choice. By an exactly argument we can show, for any mental state x* realizing content C* that, if functionalism is right, x*’s realizing C* becomes causally inert.
         So it seems that, if functionalism is right, then  mental content is inert. If content is identified with causal role, then content cannot be what brings about causal role. But in that case, content doesn’t do anything; it becomes inert, a free-wheel or epiphenomenon. But plainly content is not inert; plainly content does a lot. So functionalism must be wrong.
 
 

	* Another doctrine – content externalism – also seems to make contentinert. Smith and Twin-Smith are atom for atom duplicates. But Smith is thinking about Mary, while twin-Smith is thinking about twin-Mary. The reason is that Smith’s brain-state has one distal cause (Mary), while twinSmith’s has another (twin-Mary). The difference in distal cause makes for a difference in content. But this difference in content seems to be inert. What does all the work is local: the spatially and temporally local property of Smith’s brain are what cause him to pick up the phone and dial those numbers; the same is true (mutatis mutandis) of Twin-Smith. The differences in distal causes are irrelevant: everything that does causal work is in the here and now – is lodged inside Smith’s and twin-Smith’s crania.
     But if the externalist is right, Smith and twin-Smith have different mental contents, corresponding to the differences in distal causes. So, if externalism is right, that content is inert: the fact that Smith is thinking about Mary, as opposed to twin-Mary, about water as opposed twin-water, is inert. What is not inert – what does all the causal work – is precisely what Smith and twinSmith have in common; and what they have in common is neutral between Mary and twin-Mary. So to the extent that mental content is to be understood in externalist terms, mental content doesn’t do anything.
 

	* Jackson and Pettit deal with these problems in a brilliant way. Wemust distinguish causal efficacy from causal relevance.     In everyday discourse, we say things like the following.
 
“The liquid in the glass froze (thus expanding); and that is what is caused the glass to shatter.”
 
The truth is: what caused the glass to shatter is something much more specific; it is the fact that, in certain very specific places, certain very specific pressures were put on the walls of the container.
     Consider the statement:
 
“The presence of a flame under the container caused the liquid to boil.”
 
Well, what really caused the container to heat up is much more specific: certain specific displacements of energy led to some other specific displacements of energy; and so on. Not every displacement of energy constitutive of the flame caused the increase in temperature. It wasn’t really the flame which did the work: it was certain very specific micro-events constitutive of the flame.
    One last example: 
 
“The pianist hit a wrong note because somebody coughed too loud.”
 
    Well, what really caused the pianist to hit a wrong note is much more specific. Smith coughed too loud – it wasn’t just somebody
   Causes are   much more specific than our statements typically indicate; and the things we describe as “causes” – somebody’s coughing too loud, a flame’s being underneath the container, the freezing of the liquid in the glass – are not really what is doing the causal work; there is always something much more specific going on; some specific molecule (or atom or quark…) bouncing off of some other molecule (or atom…). In fact, in the end, the only things that are doing causal work are specific, minute displacements of massenergy. The flame is much too expansive and gross an entity to be responsible for the fact that this, that, or any other specific part of the pan heats up; what heats up place x on the pan is always some specific mass-energy displacement
    But when we say things like “someone’s coughing caused the pianist to hit a wrong note”,  “the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up”, and “the freezing of the liquid caused the vessel to shatter”, what we are saying is surely not altogether wrong. There is plainly a sense in which it is true to say that somebody’s coughing is what caused the pianist to error, a sense in which it is true to say that the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up, and so on.
     Here is how Jackson and Pettit deal with it. The presence of the flame programs for the heating-up of the pan. Put another way, it is causally relevant without being causally efficacious in the heating up of the pan. What does this mean? Given that there is a flame present, it necessarily follows that something which is causally efficacious in the heating up of the pan will be present. The flame is constituted by the specific displacements which did the causal work. And the presence of a flame in that place guarantees that some such displacements will be present which will do the causal work. So even though the flame per se is not what does the work, the presence of the flame is causally relevant to the heating up of the pan: the presence of the flame guaranteed (not in a causal sense) the presence of something which would do said work.
    Similarly for the other cases. What causes the glass to shatter is not the fact that the liquid inside has a certain temperature or volume. It is something more specific: the impact of certain molecules on certain other molecules (actually it is eve more specific than that). But the temperature of the glass is causally relevant. Given that the glass has such and such temperature, it is guaranteed (not causally, but in some other, deeper sense) that there will be the kind of thing which is causally efficacious in the shattering of the glass.     The fact that somebody or other coughed isn’t what caused Horowitz to err. But that fact does guarantee the existence of the sort of thing which would do that. Given that somebody or other coughed, it follows that, for some specific x, x coughed: and the fact that x coughed is causally efficacious in causing Horowitz to err. So somebody or other’s coughing is causally relevant, though not causally efficacious, to Horowitz’s erring. It programs for the existence of something which is causally efficacious, even though it does not itself have that property.
      Jackson and Pettit say that, if we take into account the distinction between efficacy and relevance, we can be functionalist or externalists and hold onto the idea that content has an important causal role. What is causally
efficacious in Smith’s reaching for the phone and dialing those numbers is not the fact that Smith is thinking about Mary. But Smith’s thinking about Mary is causally relevant. His doing so “programs for” the kind of thing that will do the trick. So content has causal relevance (though not causally efficacy).
    Similarly for the functionalist-case. (For the moment, let us forget about the problems relating to differences between thinking about water/twin-water, and the like.) For the reasons we described earlier, Smith’s wanting water (or being in pain or believing that there is arsenic in the glass…) cannot be causally efficacious in Smith’s reaching for the glass: it cannot, strictly speaking, what causes Smith to do that. But it can be causally relevant. Smith’s being thirsty “programs for” his doing that sort of thing; the presence of thirst guarantees the presence of the kinds of things which would to the causal work in Smith’s reaching for the glass.
 
           First we will deal with the functionalist case. Let us start with some platitudes. Nothing can be “causally relevant” to itself. A state of affairs cannot be “causally relevant” to its own existence. Of course, the term “causal relevance” is an invented one; so we can give it any meaning we wish. But surely it would be wrong to say describe the kind of relevance that event E has to itself as causal. The relation is better described as logical (or perhaps metaphysical). E is not causally related to itself; and it doesn’t matter, obviously, whether we are taking about causal efficacy or causal relevance. Obviously the kind of relation Jackson and Pettit have in mind, when the talk about “causal relevance” is some kind of causal relation; the word “causal” is there for a reason. So nothing can be “causally relevant” to itself.
      The functionalist says that x’s causing E1…En is what x’s having C consists in. There is an identity here, not a causal relation. At the same time, it is clear, from a common-sense point of view, that x’s having content C –
e.g. x’s being a desire for water – has some kind of causal hand in bringing about E1…En (in bringing it about that Smith reaches for the glass or tries to melt the icicle or whatnot). If x’s having C is identical with x’s bringing about E1…En, x’s having C cannot be causally effective in bringing about E1…En: after all, x’s bringing about E1…En cannot cause x’s bringing about E1…En. By the same token, x’s bringing about E1…En cannot be causally relevant in bringing about x’s bringing about E1…En. Nothing can be causally relevant to itself. If the functionalist is right, then x’s bringing about E1…En is identical with x’s having C. So if the functionalist is right, then x’s having C – i.e. its bringing about E1…En – cannot be causally relevant to its bringing about E1…En: not causally relevant, not causally effective. So the Jackson and Pettit maneuver fails.
     To deal with the externalist-case, a background point is in order. Sometimes Jackson and Pettit analyze (or define) the notion of causal relevance in counter-factual terms.  x is causally relevant to the occurrence of y if, in any counterfactual circumstance where x exists, there also exists something causally effective in bringing about y. The problem is that this is too generous. My striking the glass with the hammer is sufficient, in the counterfactual sense just defined, for the breaking of the glass. The same is true my of striking the glass and wearing a yellow hat and having green teeth and wearing a spacesuit…But surely my wearing a yellow hat/spacesuit/having green teeth…is not in any sense “causally relevant” to the breaking of the glass. The counterfactual analysis is too broad, too expansive.      It needs to be tightened. But we don’t want to tighten it too much; we don’t want to say that (e.g.) the program-cause (the thing that is causally is relevant) is the smallest thing x such that x counterfactually guarantees the presence of something causally efficacious. After all, the smallest thing is the mass-energy displacement itself: we don’t want to shrink causal relevance down to causal efficacy.
       The notion of causal relevance is, I believe, to be understood in terms of the notion of redundancy. Let x be the particular mass-energy displacements (constitutive of the fire) which did the trick. The flame is causally relevant because in any case where you have the flame, but where x (for some reason) didn’t do the trick, the flame guarantees that some other mass-energy displacements y will do the trick. So causal relevance can be understood in terms of “back-up” mechanisms. In any situation where someone or other coughed loud enough, but where Smith (the actual cougher) did not cough, that is enough to make Horowitz hit the wrong key. Now Smith’s wearing a yellow hat is not causally relevant, because it doesn’t constitute the right kind of back-up mechanism; it doesn’t amplify the range of cases where something does the trick. By contrast, the whole flame is causally relevant because, if the flame were smaller, that would eliminate some back-up mechanisms; it would shrink the range of mass-energy displacements that would step into the breach in situations where X isn’t being causally efficacious. But Smith’s wearing a yellow hat, the flame’s coming from a green as opposed to a blue lighter – or its coming from a lighter as opposed to a newspaper – doesn’t provide this sort of counterfactual reinforcement. It is inert in this respect.
    The same is true of the fact that Smith’s brain-state has its origin in Mary, as opposed to twin-Mary, or Mary3, or Robo-Mary, or hologram-Mary or a Cartesian demon or bent light-rays. What is causally efficacious is some congeries X of mass-energy displacements at various contact-points in Smith’s nervous system. What is causally relevant are the structures that guarantee, in counter-factual situations where X didn’t do the trick, some congeries Y would. What is not causally relevant is anything that doesn’t provide this sort of reinforcement; where that ends, so does causal relevance. Now consider the things going on outside Smith’s cranium. Are any of these things going to step into the breach in counter-factual situations where X isn’t doing the trick? Consider a counter-factual situation where X isn’t doing the trick. Is the fact that Smith’s brain-state originates with Mary (as opposed to twin-Mary or Mary3) going to help out? Is it going provide needed back-up? No. It is inert. It would provide back-up only to the extent that it led to the right kind of brain-structure or, in any case, the right kind of local phenomenon that would provide back-up.
 
 
Program-causes and Mental Efficacy
 

	A. It seems reasonable to suppose that, in some cases, brain-states realizemental contents. (I wish the word “state” to be taken as broadly as possible – to apply to both enduring brain-structures and occurrent phenomena.)  My belief that 1+1=2 is realized by certain brain-states. My belief that water is wet is realized by a different set of brainstates.
    Let x be an arbitrary brain-state of mine; and suppose that x is identical with, or realizes, my belief that bread nourishes.  According to functionalism, for x to realize that belief is for x to have a certain causal role. For x to have a certain causal role is for it to be caused by certain things (e.g. visual perceptions of people eating bread and subsequently appearing sated) and for x, in its turn, to cause certain other things (e.g. my choosing to eat bread when hungry). So, for functionalism, x is a belief that bread nourishes  in virtue of (inter alia) the fact that x leads to my deciding to drive to the store to buy bread, to my eating said bread, to my teaching loved ones how to bake bread, and so forth.
      There is an obvious problem for functionalism. If x’s realizing a belief that bread nourishes consists in (inter alia) its leading to certain states of affairs – e.g. my choosing to eat bread, my deciding to drive to the breadstore when hungry, and so forth – then x’s having that content cannot be what causes those states of affairs to come about. If x’s having that content is its having a certain causal role, then x’s having that content cannot affect or govern its causal role; it cannot be what brings about my choosing to eat bread or my teaching my loved ones how to bake it. In a word, if content is causal role, then content cannot affect causal role: content ends up not having
[290] a causal hand in contexts where, quite plainly, it does have such a hand. 
 

	* Another doctrine – content externalism – also seems to make contentinert. Smith and Twin-Smith are atom for atom duplicates. But Smith is thinking about Mary, while twin-Smith is thinking about twin-Mary. The reason is that Smith’s brain-state has one distal cause (Mary), while twin-
Smith’s has another (twin-Mary). The difference in distal cause makes for a
[291]
difference in content.
    But this difference in content seems to be inert. What does all the work is local: the spatially and temporally local properties of Smith’s brain are what cause him to pick up the phone and dial those numbers; the same is true (mutatis mutandis) of Twin-Smith. The differences in distal causes are causally irrelevant: everything that does causal work is in the here and now – is lodged inside Smith’s and twin-Smith’s respective crania. It is irrelevant
[292]
	that Smith’s state was distally caused by Mary, as opposed to twinMary or hologram-Mary or Robo-Mary. Smith’s state might as well have been caused by any one of them, so far as the causal properties of that state are concerned.
    So to the extent that mental content is to be understood in externalist terms – to the extent that Smith and twin-Smith have qualitatively different mental contents in virtue of their differing causal liasons --  mental content doesn’t do anything. Externalism thus appears to strip mental content of causal
[293]
power.
 
III.   Jackson and Pettit deal with these problems in a brilliant way. First, they distinguish causal efficacy from what they refer to as causal relevance. They then attempt to show that, given this distinction, we can reconcile externalism and functionalism with the presumed causal potency of mental content.      First let us discuss the distinction between efficacy and potency. Consider the statement:
 
“The presence of a flame under the container caused the liquid to boil.”
 
Well, what really caused the container to heat up is much more specific: 
certain specific displacements of energy led to some other specific displacements of energy; and these displacements happened in a very specific region – a region coincident with, or vanishingly close to, the region occupied by the under-surface of the pan. Not every displacement of energy constitutive of the flame caused the increase in temperature. It wasn’t really the flame which did the work: it was certain very specific micro-events constitutive of the flame.
   Causes are much more specific than our statements typically indicate; and the things we describe as “causes” – e.g. a flame’s being underneath the container – are not really what is doing the causal work; there is always something much more specific going on, e.g. some specific molecule (or atom or quark…) bouncing off of some other molecule (or atom…).     But when we say things like  “the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up”, what we are saying is surely not altogether wrong. There is plainly a sense in which it is true to say that the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up.
     Here is how Jackson and Pettit deal with these facts. The flame is constituted by the specific displacements which did the causal work – which are causally efficacious. And the presence of a flame in that general region guarantees that some such displacements will be present which will do the causal work. So even though the flame per se is not what does the work, the presence of the flame is causally relevant to the heating up of the pan: the presence of the flame guarantees or “programs for” the presence of something which would do said work. Sometimes Jackson and Pettit describe the thing which is causally relevant, but not causally efficacious, as the
[294]
	“program cause”. To sum up, the flame is causally relevant, but not causally efficacious. What is causally efficacious is the activity – the dance of mass-energy displacements - at the meeting point of the flame and the underside of the pan.
 
IV.      Jackson and Pettit say that, if we take into account the distinction between causal efficacy and causal relevance, we can be functionalists or externalists and hold onto the idea that mental content has an important causal role. What is causally efficacious in Smith’s reaching for the phone and dialing those numbers is not the fact that Smith is thinking about Mary. But Smith’s thinking about Mary is causally relevant. His doing so
“programs for” the kind of thing that will be causally efficacious in his hitting those seven numbers. So content has causal relevance (though not causal efficacy).
    So as far as what is causally efficacious is concerned, it is irrelevant whether the distal cause of his current condition was Mary, twin-Mary, roboMary, or a hallucination. Thus Smith’s thinking about Mary – as opposed to twin-Mary or robo-Mary – is not causally efficacious. But Smith’s thinking about Mary is still causally relevant, as it programs for his dialing those seven numbers.
      The same principle applies in the case of functionalism. For the reasons we described earlier, Smith’s wanting water cannot be causally efficacious in
Smith’s reaching for the glass: it cannot, strictly speaking, be what causes
Smith to do that. But it can be causally relevant. Smith’s being thirsty “programs for” his doing that sort of thing; the presence of thirst guarantees the presence of the kinds of things which would to the causal work in Smith’s reaching for the glass.
   
IV. I believe that Jackson and Pettit have had a profound insight into causality and causal explanation. But I don’t think that insight helps out functionalism or externalism in the way that they think.     
     Let us start with a platitude. Nothing can be “causally relevant” to itself. A state of affairs cannot be “causally relevant” to its own existence. Obviously things are relevant to themselves. But the relevance isn’t causal.
     Of course, the term “causal relevance” (as Jackson and Pettit are using it) is an invented one; so we can give it any meaning we wish. But surely it would be deeply misleading to describe the kind of relevance that event E has to itself as causal. The relation is better described as logical or perhaps metaphysical. E is not causally related to itself; and it doesn’t matter whether we are talking about causal efficacy or causal relevance. Obviously the kind of relation Jackson and Pettit have in mind, when they talk about “causal relevance” is some kind of causal relation; therefore it is not a relation which something can have to itself -- the word “causal” is there for a reason. So nothing can be “causally relevant” to itself.
    The functionalist says that x’s having content C identical with or realized by x’s having causal role R. So, for the functionalist, x’s having C is realized by (inter alia) x’s leading me to bake bread when hungry, and so forth.  Since we are here dealing with a relation of identity or realization, we cannot say that the relation between x’s having C and x’s having causal role R is any sense causal. It doesn’t matter whether we are talking about causal relevance or causal efficacy. Both causal relevance and causal efficacy are causal relations (of some kind or other); and thus do not hold between identicals or between things one of which realizes the other. So x’s having content C cannot possibly be causally relevant to x’s having causal role R. It is no more possible for the one to be causal relevant with respect to the other than it is for the one to be causally efficacious with respect to the other.
   Let us sum up. For the functionalist, x’s having C is identical with, or realized by x’s causal role R. If the relation between x’s having C and x’s having R is one of identity or realization, then there is a categorical ban on any kind of causal relation – whether one of efficacy or relevance – holding between the two. So the Jackson-Pettit maneuver fails to reconcile functionalism with the intuition that my believing that bread nourishes has causal potency.
 
V.     To deal with the externalist-case, a background point is in order. Sometimes Jackson and Pettit analyze the notion of causal relevance in counter-factual terms:  x is causally relevant to the occurrence of y if, in any counterfactual circumstance where x exists, there also exists something causally effective in bringing about y.
     The problem is that this is too generous. My striking the glass with the hammer is sufficient, in the counterfactual sense just defined, for the breaking of the glass. The same is true of my of striking the glass while wearing a yellow hat and having green teeth and wearing a spacesuit…But surely my wearing a yellow hat (or having green teeth) is not in any sense “causally relevant” to the breaking of the glass.
    The counterfactual analysis is too inclusive, and thus needs to be tightened. But we don’t want to tighten it too much. For example, we don’t want to say that the program-cause is the smallest thing x such that x counterfactually guarantees the presence of something causally efficacious. After all, the smallest thing that gives that guarantee is the mass-energy displacement itself. But we don’t want to say that only that mass-energy displacement is causally relevant: surely we want to allow that the flame of which it is a part is causally relevant; we don’t want to shrink causal relevance down to causal efficacy.
       The notion of causal relevance is, I believe, to be understood in terms of the notion of redundancy – in terms of the notion of a back-up mechanism. Consider the case where, as we loosely say, the presence of the flame caused the pan to heat up. Let x be the specific mass-energy displacements constitutive of the fire which, in the actual case, did the trick. The flame is causally relevant because in any case where you have the flame, but where x (for some reason) didn’t do the trick, the flame guarantees that some other mass-energy displacements y will do the trick. So, it seems, causal relevance can be understood in terms of “back-up” mechanisms.
    Suppose that the wall-paper in the kitchen where the flame occurs is yellow. That isn’t causally relevant to the heating of the pan, because  it doesn’t amplify the range of cases where something is causally efficacious in the heating of the pan. By contrast, the flame as a whole is causally relevant to the heating because, if the flame were smaller, that would eliminate some back-up mechanisms; it would shrink the range of mass-energy displacements that would step into the breach in situations where x  (the totality of mass-energy displacements that in fact did the trick) isn’t being causally efficacious.
      The same is true of the fact that Smith’s brain-state has its origin in Mary, as opposed to twin-Mary, or Mary-7, or Robo-Mary. What is causally efficacious is some flurry X of mass-energy displacements at various contactpoints in Smith’s nervous system. What is causally relevant are the structures that guarantee that, in counter-factual situations where X wasn’t there to do the trick, some other flurry Y would have been. What is not causally relevant is anything that doesn’t provide this sort of reinforcement. Where that sort of reinforcement ends, so does causal relevance.
    In light of this, consider the things going on outside Smith’s cranium. Are any of these things going to step into the breach in counter-factual situations where X isn’t doing the trick? Consider a counter-factual situation where X isn’t doing the trick. Is the fact that Smith’s brain-state originates with Mary (as opposed to twin-Mary or Mary-7) going to help out? Is it going to provide the needed back-up? No. It is inert. It would provide back-up only to the extent that it led to the right kind of brain-structure or, in any case, the right kind of local phenomenon that would provide back-up.
      There are events which, while not themselves being causally efficacious in making Smith dial those seven numbers, do yet program for his doing so. What is it that is causally efficacious in making Smith dial (or at least choose to dial) those numbers? Answer: certain specific mass-energy displacements at, or vanishingly near, certain neural contact points. So what is causally efficacious isn’t exactly some chemical (or electrical) storm in Smith’s brain – some flurry of z-fibers or whatnot. The storm is much too encompassing an entity to be causally efficacious (just as the flame is too encompassing an entity to be causally efficacious in heating the pan): causal efficacy resides at (or vanishingly near) contact points; the storm includes things that happen at those contact points, but it also includes things that are (relatively speaking) far away from them. Nonetheless, that chemical storm – the thing that neurologists speak of as “the cause” of Smith’s number-pushing musclespasms – in some sense guarantees that the right kind of events will happen at those contact points. What is the nature of that guarantee? The chemical storm consists of those events (and others). The occurrence of the storm guarantees the existence of the right events at the contact points because the storm consists of events that will do the trick. In the actual world, the storm comprises E1…En – these being the relevant events at the contact-points. But if the storm hadn’t comprised specifically E1…En, it would have comprised E*1…E*n, where E*1…E*n would have done the trick. It would have done this because the chemical storm is composed of the right kind of events – not because it would have caused the right kind of events. So what is causally relevant to, but not causally efficacious in, Smith’s dialing those numbers is not some spatiotemporally remote state of affairs involving Mary: it is some contemporaneous state of affairs which comprises the causally efficacious events.
    Events buried in the past (even the very recent past) – whether they involve Mary, twin-Mary, or Robo-Mary – are not, in Jackson and Pettit’s technical sense of the phrase, “causally relevant” at all. They are causes; but they are not “causally efficacious”, Jackson and Pettit’s technical sense – for causal efficacy resides in what is doing the work right now. And they are not “causally relevant”, in the technical sense  – for they are too remote to provide the kind of counterfactual reinforcement we spoke of earlier. That sort of reinforcement is provided by brain-events which are contemporaneous with, and (relatively speaking) very close to, the events which are causally efficacious. These (relatively) local events – and not some remote state of affairs involving Mary (or Alpha Centauri) --  are the ones that will pick up the slack in counterfactual cases where the events that are in fact causally efficacious are truant.

Externalism and the Veil of Perception
 
          There are two opposed conceptions about our perceptual relation to external reality. Some  (e.g. Hume, Ayer) say that we perceive representations of external objects, and not the objects themselves: there is thus a “veil of perception” lying between ourselves and the out world. Others (e.g. Reid) say that we perceive the objects themselves.
    Sometimes the former position is known as “indirect realism”: there really are external objects, but we are only indirectly aware of them – we are aware of representations of them. Predictably, the latter position is sometimes referred to as “direct realism”: there really are external objects, and we are directly aware of them, not of representational  intermediaries. (In this context, I am taking for granted the existence of the external world; so it isn’t worth discussing the relations of internalism or externalism to anti-realism.)          On the face of it, it might seem as though externalism is associated with direct realism, while internalism is associated with indirect realism. According to the externalism, Alpha Centauri itself is a veritable constituent of my thoughts. No Alpha Centauri, no thought. Thus, given that the thought exists, there is no need to connect the thought to external reality:  if it exists at all, the thought exists connected to the external world.
   By the same token, indirect realism seems to be associated with internalism. The internalist says that the content of our mental states is confined to what is internal to the “Cartesian theatre”. So it would seem that, for the internalist, the content of our states does not, at least not directly, have anything to do with anything that lies outside the Cartesian theatre: Alpha Centauri is not itself a constituent of our thoughts. What is a constituent of our thoughts is, at most, something that represents Alpha Centauri. So internalism appears to be committed to the view that perceptual awareness is mediated by a veil of representations. (Let us refer to this view as VOP for “veil of perceptions.)     There is some historical tendency for internalists to accept VOP – for example, Descartes accepted VOP and was an internalist, so far as he can be classified either as an internalist or as an externalist. This is not universally true. John Searle is a direct realist who is also an internalist. 
     I think that this debate needs to be re-examined in light of some of the points we’ve discussed. Thus re-examined, it turns out that, ironically, externalism is committed to a rather extreme form of VOP. A good point of entry into this debate is “Brentano’s thesis”:
 
(BT) All awareness is awareness of something.
 
  (BT) seems reasonable enough. It is hard to imagine a “pure” awareness – an awareness that wasn’t an awareness of this or that.
    But there is a famous problem with (BT). Suppose you hallucinate a cat. What is the object of your awareness? A cat? There is no cat – at least, no real cat. Yet in having the hallucination, you are obviously aware. So here, it will be said, we have an awareness that is not an awareness of anything. Thus, it seems, we have a counter-example to BT.
     Brentano, and others, have dealt with this by saying that, when you hallucinate a cat, you are aware of a cat: a non-existent (or merely
“subsistent”) cat. But this is obviously not good reasoning. Either there is a cat or there isn’t. If there isn’t, then there isn’t any cat to be aware of. Either we are simply playing with labels or we are ontologizing to cover up deficits in our reasoning.
      But hallucinations are no counter-examples to BT. For reasons earlier discussed, the content of your perception is existential. When you ‘see Fido’, as we put it, what your perception tells you is existential: there is a creature with such and such properties. The perception is made true by some fact about Fido. But Fido is not himself a constituent the content of that perception. To think otherwise, we saw, is to confuse perceptual content with meta-perceptual content. Given only the information encoded in your perception, you have no way (no matter how intelligent you are) of knowing whether you are seeing Fido or twin-Fido or Android-Fido (or nothing at all). The only information that could help you decide that is meta-perceptual – information obtained through some source other than that very perception. What is given to you in that perception is neutral between Fido’s being in front of you and twin-Fido’s being in front of you and android-Fido’s being in front of you. There is nothing in that perception itself that could possibly warrant a decision as to which, if any, of these three things (Fido, twin-Fido, Android-Fido) is the one in front of you. Thus the perception cannot deliver a message of the form… Fido…(as in Fido is looking ill or Fido is panting heavily). For if the perception did deliver such a message, it would not leave it open, even epistemically, whether it was Fido or twin-Fido (or neither) that was in front of you. So Fido cannot be a constituent of the information conveyed to you that perception.
      What is given to you in that perception is Fido-neutral. What is given to you is that there is some creature with such and such properties, and is thus purely existential. So objects are not the content of perceptions; the content of a perception is made true, in favorable cases, by an object; but the object is not itself lodged in that content. Objects are the objects of perception only in the attenuated sense in which “Sally met a man” is about Frank or Harry or Doug (whoever it was that Sally met). We must distinguish content from truthmaker.
    If we maintain that external objects or even states of affairs are constituents of the information borne by your perceptions, then we end up guilty of selfcontradiction. As we noted, given only the information that is in the perception, it is possible that you are seeing android-Fido or even that there is no external world at all. So the content of the perception leaves it open whether Fido is there – whether anything is there, for that matter. That content, as we said, is Fido-neutral: that specifically is what it means to make the true claim, given that perception, it is epistemically possible that Fido isn’t there. Given – what nobody denies -- that the perception leaves is epistemically open whether Fido even exists, we must acknowledge that the content of the perception is Fido-neutral – Fido is no part if of it. So if we say that Fido himself is part of the content that perception, then we are forced to say, absurdly, that Fido both is and is not part of the information encoded in that perception.
    Uncontroversially, given only what the perception tells you, it is epistemically possible that you are seeing android-Fido, or twin-Fido. So if, with the externalist, we say that Fido is a constituent of the content of your perception, then we must say, absurdly, that the content of the perception is not part of what the perception tells you. But what is the content of a perception if not what it tells the percipient? If we separate the content of the perception from what the perception tells you – and this is exactly what the externalist must do – then we end up operating with an incoherent or vacant notion of content.. So we don’t want to make that separation. But if we don’t make that separation, then as we saw, Fido himself ends up not being anywhere in that content, in which case externalism is false. So to avoid incoherence, we are forced to say that the content of your perception does not include Fido at all. That content is not Fido, nor anything of the form…Fido…Rather it is, for reasons that are independently argued, some existence claim that is made true by the Fido.
    Let us relate this point on Brentano’s thesis. When you have a hallucination of a unicorn, the content of your condition is not simply Pegasus. It is (say) there is a horse-like creature with a horn on its head and white fur…The content of your perception is not a non-existent unicorn. If there were a unicorn there, the content of your perception wouldn’t be an existent unicorn, as we, in effect, just saw when discussing Fido. The content of your perception is given by an existence claim. What your perception is saying is: there is a being with such and such properties…You don’t see a non-existent unicorn. At the same time, your state is obviously representational: its representational content is given by an existence claim, and is not identical, even in part, with an unicorn (existing or not existing). So the existence of hallucinations doesn’t threaten BT, and we don’t have to ontologize to protect BT.
         Once we acknowledge the fundamentally existential nature of senseperception, it becomes clear that, ironically, externalism is a form of VOP and that internalism is not. The externalist says that the relation between a perception and its content is (epistemically) contingent. According to the externalist, your perception has Fido for at least part of its content. At the same time, everybody agrees that it is epistemically possible that you are seeing twin-Fido, and not Fido. In fact, it is epistemically possible that there is no dog (or dog-like entity) there at all. In that case, according to the externalist, the content of your perception doesn’t exist or, at least, it has a gap in it.    The situation is dire. It is epistemically possible, as Descartes and Hume pointed out, that there is no external world at all. (I doubt anyone would deny this, even though few would accept the skepticism to which this fact drove Hume and Descartes.) Now the externalist identifies content with something extra-cranial. So if the externalist is right, then it is epistemically possible that your perceptions don’t have any content at all.   
     Evans, MacDowell, and other externalists maintain that, where there is no object, there is no content. They are being consistent here – true to their own externalism. If externalism is right, then the very content of your perception of the dog includes that dog itself. If that is right, then the  representational content of a hallucination of a dog has a gap in it where there should be a dog. To the extent that a state is a hallucination, it is missing content. Given this, suppose that all of our waking life is a dream – this is obviously epistemically possible. In that case, the externalist must hold that are experiences are content-free: the (would-be) perceptual states of a brain in a vat or the victim of an Evil Demon become devoid of content.
     But this is very hard to believe; in fact, it is self-contradictory. When we say that it is epistemically possible that a given perception is a hallucination, we mean that it is possible given the information that is encoded in the perception. So talk of what is epistemically possible presupposes that perceptions have content. Everybody, externalists included, wishes to admit that it is an epistemic possibility that, right now, I’m seeing twin-Fido, as opposed to Fido, or even that I’m having a hallucination and am not seeing anything at all Since everybody, externalists included, countenance the idea that certain things are epistemically possible relative to the perception, it follows that everybody, externalists included, are committed to the idea that the perception has a resilient content – a content that exists in all epistemically possible counter-factual scenarios where that perception exists: scenarios where Fido doesn’t exist, scenarios where we are dupes of Evil Demons. So it makes no sense at all to say that it is epistemically possible that our perceptions have no content. When we say that such and such is epistemically possible with respect to our perceptions, we are saying precisely that the content of our perceptions doesn’t rule it out. The externalist says that the content of the perception is extra-cranial. So the externalist is forced to make the false, indeed the absurd, claim that it is not epistemically possible that I am seeing twin-Fido (as opposed to Fido) or that I am a hallucinating.
      Let us use the term “perceptual state” to describe perceptions and hallucinations alike. (So the word “perceptual” is being used as a mnemonic device, not as a way of denoting the property of really being a hallucination.)     The contentfulness of our perceptual states cannot be doubted. If we say of some perceptual experience that it could be a hallucination, we are saying that given its content, it is an open question whether it is a hallucination or not. (This is an open question where every perceptual state is concerned.) So scepticism presupposes contentfulness. So if the externalist wishes to be coherent, he must accept the contentfulness of our perceptual states – the veridical perceptions and the hallucinations alike. The Evans-MacDowell view is that, in so far as perceptual state is a hallucination, it has a gap in it. A consequence of this view is that, if we are victims of Evil Demons, then our perceptual states would turn out to be altogether content-free. But we’ve just seen that our perceptual states do have content, even if it turned out they were all hallucinatory, and that it is incoherent to maintain otherwise. The epistemic possibility of hallucination presupposes the contentfulness of our perceptual experiences. Therefore the Evans-MacDowell view is incoherent, given the very notion of epistemic possibility. So to avoid incoherence, the externalist must actually hold onto the idea that the contentfulness of our perceptual experiences is not jeopardized by the epistemic possibility of global hallucination. But Ian externalist could not do this. For what survives sceptical doubt is precisely what is internal. So in so far as contentfulness is Demonproof (or vat-proof) it follows that contentfulness is not external, but is inseparable from the perceptual experience itself.
    For the externalist, the relation between a perceptual experience and its content becomes epistemically contingent. You can have the perceptual experience: even so, the content of the experience might or might not exist. After all, the content, if it exists, will be some external state of affairs – some star that might be long gone or might never have existed to begin with. So the perceptual experience is one thing, its content – what it tells the percipient – is another. And the relation between the two is fragile. It is possible, at least epistemically, that that very perception might have had a very different content. So for the externalist, the perception has an external relation to its own content: the perception is a veritable intermediary, a veil; its content is on the other side of that veil. When that veil is peeled away, so to speak, the content might be there – or it might not. The root-commitment of externalism thus turns out to be the idea that perceptions are intermediaries: the content of the perception is quite separable from the perception itself. The Humean view, powerfully critiqued by Reid, recrudesces in externalism.
      With the internalist the story is different. The content of the perception, for the internalist, is Demon-proof, vat-proof, and generally hallucination-proof. For the internalist, you cannot have the perceptual experience without the content. So there is no layer of perceptions between subject and content. Once there is a perceptual experience, there ipso facto is the content. In a way, there ceases to be any intervening of layer of representations at all. There is not, on the one hand, a perception and, on the other hand, a separable content of perception. Where the perception is, the content is as well: the perceptual experience just is an awareness of content. So there is not, except nominally, a distinction between the existence of the perceptual experience, on the one hand, and awareness of content. There is just one thing – an awareness of content.
 
Representationalism
 
      We intuitively or pre-theoretically divide the world into two types of entities: those that are mental and those that are not. Emotions, beliefs, perceptions and intentions are mental. Rocks, stars, chairs, and items of clothing are not.  This dichotomy plays an enormous role in everyone’s ideation: in what they believe, what they feel, what they wish for, and so on. (For example, our feelings about, and conduct towards, a given thing are determined first and foremost by whether we believe that thing to have a mind -- to have perceptions, feelings, etc.) Given this, it is worthwhile to ask:  What is it that all and only mental entities have in common? With regard to all those things that we categorize as ‘mental’, what is it that sets them apart from those things that we categorize as ‘non-mental’?
       One of the more promising answers is this: something is mental just in
[295] case it has the property of being non-derivatively or intrinsically representational. Let us refer to this position as representationalism. So, to be clear, representationalism (as I will be using this expression) is the doctrine that the essence of the mental lies in the property of
[296]
representationality	. Equivalently, representationalism is the view that
[297]
all 	distinctively mental properties are representational properties. What sets the mental apart from the non-mental is that everything in the former category is (non-derivatively) representational, while everything in the latter is not representational, except perhaps derivatively. (Henceforth, whenever I say ‘representational’ I will mean non-derivatively representational, except in the few cases where the context doesn’t make it clear whether derivative or non-derivative representationality is being discussed.)
     Representationalism was, to my knowledge, first advocated by Franz
[298]
	Brentano. It was held by the so-called ‘phenomenologists’ (Husserl, Heidegger, and Sartre, among others). It is highly popular to this day, being vigorously defended by, among others, Fred Dretske (‘All mental facts are
[299]
	representational facts’) and William Lycan (‘[T]he mind has no special
[300] 	properties that are not exhausted by its representational properties…’). Though representationalism is a popular doctrine, its merits are fiercely disputed. Ned Block, in what has become an oft-quoted statement, says of this dispute that it constitutes ‘[t]he greatest chasm in the philosophy of
[301]
mind’.
           My main purpose in this essay is to prove that representationalism is false. For something to be mental, it is not necessary that it be
representational (though it is probably sufficient). So although the property of being representational is a distinguishing mark of the mental, it is not the distinguishing mark.
     A couple of clarificatory remarks are in order. I defined representationalism as the doctrine that all ‘distinctively mental’ properties are representational properties. What exactly is a ‘distinctively’ mental property? A distinctly mental property is one that only a mental entity could have. Any given mental entity has to occur at a particular time and, probably, in a certain place. For example, the wave of sorrow I just felt occurred at 3:00 p.m. But obviously things that are non-mental can occur at 3:00 p.m. Representationalism is not the absurd view that all properties had by a mental entity are representational entities. (Every mental entity will have some properties that non-mental entities can have: as just noted, every mental entity has spatio-temporal properties, which, of course, non-mental things can have.) Rather, representationalism is the view that any property which only mental things can have are representational properties – that, to use our new jargon, all distinctively mental properties are representational properties.       One more clarificatory remark is in order. ‘Representationalism’, as I will be using this term, is not the doctrine that, given any mental entity, there is some existing object or state of affairs that it picks out. Such a doctrine would
[302]
	be patently untenable. For presumably there is no (real) object or state of affairs picked out by e.g. a hallucination of a pink elephant.
Representationalism is the view that any mental entity is representational in the sense that it is the kind of thing that (in a non-derivative way) could pick out an object or state of affairs. A hallucination of a dagger is representational in the sense that it could apply to an object. More precisely, such a hallucination is representational in the sense that it has conditions of satisfaction: we can speak of what the world would have to be like if that hallucination were to be veridical -- if that mental entity were, so to speak, to be ‘satisfied’. (We obviously cannot speak of what the world would have to be like for e.g. a rock to be veridical: such talk – unless meant metaphorically or derivatively – would be non-sensical.) A property is ‘representational’ (as we will be using the term) if it is such that, by virtue of having that property, something has conditions of satisfaction. So representationalism is the view that all distinctly mental properties are representational in the sense that, if something has one of those properties, it ipso facto has conditions of satisfaction or – to use an alternate locution – it ipso facto has representational content. (To be clear: I will be using the terms
‘representational content’ and ‘conditions of satisfaction’ interchangeably: for something to have representational content is for it to have conditions of satisfaction. Not all authors use the term ‘representational content’ in quite this way. So my usage  of this expression is, at least to some extent, stipulative) So representationalism can be formulated as the view that, given any distinctly mental property –  e.g. the property of being euphoric – for something to have that property is for it to have certain conditions of satisfaction/representational content.
        Now if representationalism is correct – if all distinctly mental properties are representational properties – then it follows quite trivially that two mental entities cannot differ in any of their distinctly mental properties unless they differ in their representational properties.  (If two mental entities x and y differ in some of their distinctly mental properties, but do not differ in their representational properties, then ipso facto there are some distinctly mental properties other than representational properties, and consequently representationalism is false.) This consequence of representationalism will be the focal point of much of the following discussion.
       Prima facie representationalism has much to recommend it. First of all, it seems pretty clear that only mental things are (non-derivatively) representational. Rocks, trees, items of clothing, etc. do not represent
[303] anything, except by virtue of their association with mental processes. Consequently it seems reasonable to suppose that if something is (nonderivatively) representational, then in virtue of that fact alone that thing qualifies as mental. So for something to be mental, it is probably sufficient that it be representational: in a word, all representational things are mental.       But is the converse true? Are all mental things representational?  This is where the controversy begins. To be sure, most mental entities are indisputably representational. Perceptions, desires, intentions, beliefs, regrets, and hopes have representational content. (One cannot just intend; one must intend that something be the case. I must intend to go to the store, or to stay at home, or to write poetry. I cannot just regret; I must regret not having become an artist or not having majored in medieval studies.) These things all have propositions as their complements; and propositions have conditions of [304]
	satisfaction and thus representational content. 
     But there are reasons to doubt whether representationalism is a correct doctrine. The most obvious problem for representationalism – though not, as we will see, the only problem for it – has to do with the existence of ‘phenomenal content’.  For a mental entity to have phenomenal content is (to use Nagel’s expression) for there to be ‘something it is like’ to have that entity. There is something it is like to taste mustard, something it is like see a sunset; something it is like to smell strong coffee, something it is like to have a tickle or an itch. By contrast, there doesn’t seem to be ‘anything it is like’ to believe that pi is transcendental; so this belief doesn’t have phenomenal content,  though its conscious manifestations presumably do.  It is a matter of great controversy whether the existence of phenomenal content can be brought into line with representationalism. Why is this exactly? Remember that, for the representationalist, there is nothing to being mental besides being representational. The  way it feels – ‘what it is like’ -  to have a woozy feeling is at least a part of what it is for that feeling to be mental: the phenomenology of that experience is at least part of its being something mental – is a ‘distinctly mental’ property of that experience. So the representationalist is committed to something that is arguably quite counterintuitive: he must hold that the phenomenal component of a mental entity reduces in some sense to the representational component of that entity; more precisely, he must hold that what it is like to have M is a function entirely of M’s representational content. So suppose that M is your olfactory perception of strong coffee: the representationalist must hold that ‘what it is like’ to experience M is a function entirely and exclusively of M’s having a certain representational content – in effect, of M’s being rendered veridical by the existence of certain states of affairs, and rendered non-veridical by the non-existence of such.
      So the representationalist must hold the following: the phenomenal content of a mental entity is determined wholly by its representational content. Now if this is true, then two entities cannot differ in phenomenal content without differing in representational content: to use the current jargon, phenomenal content ‘supervenes’ on representational content.
   To  sum up, the representationalist must hold that the phenomenal supervenes on the representational -- i.e. that if two mental entities differ in terms of what it is like to have them (in terms of their ‘phenomenal content’) then they must necessarily differ in terms of what their conditions of
[305] satisfaction are (in terms of their ‘representational content’). 
     Before we examine the merits of representationalism, we must distinguish it from a very closely related doctrine – a doctrine we will refer to as intentionalism. Intentionalism is the doctrine the phenomenal character of an
[306]
	experience does indeed supervene on the representational content of that
[307]
	experience.  In other words, intentionalism is the position that the phenomenal content of an experience is wholly determined by its representational content , and thus that phenomenal content (at least after a fashion) reduces to representational content. It may seem that intentionalism coincides with representationalism. But, as we will see in a moment, this is not the case: intentionalism is a narrower doctrine than representationalism.        Intentionalism might seem to have bearing only on phenomenally pregnant mental entities (on what we are calling ‘experiences’: see endnote
12). But, by implication, it concerns all mental entities, not just phenomenally pregnant ones. More specifically, if intentionalism is right, it follows that given any two mental entities, those two entities cannot differ in their phenomenal content unless they differ in the representational content. (So intentionalism says, by implication, that e.g. a non-occurrent memory that has representational content R must have the same phenomenal content as an occurrent perception that has representational content R.) Why exactly does this follow? If the phenomenal content of an experience M1 is wholly a function of its representational content, that means, among other things, that M1’s having the representational content that it has is sufficient for its having the phenomenal content that it has. And from this it obviously follows that, given any other mental entity M2 that has the same representational content as M1,  M2 has satisfied a condition that is sufficient for its having the same phenomenal content as M1; so that M2 must therefore have the same phenomenal content as M1.
     Perhaps the following will clarify the point just made. Suppose that M1 is an experience that has representational content R and phenomenal content P. Intentionalism, by definition, says: ‘whatever phenomenal content M1 has, it has that phenomenal content entirely in virtue of its having the
representational content that it has.’ So intentionalism says that the one thing about M1 in virtue of which it has P is that it has R: having R is sufficient for having P. (If having R were not sufficient for having P, then clearly M1’s having P wouldn’t be a function wholly of its having R.) So, by implication, intentionalism says that any mental entity that has R also has P. So intentionalism is committed to the view that, if (e.g.) some non-occurrent memory has R, it also has P. To sum up, intentionalism  requires that given any two mental entities, those entities cannot differ in phenomenal content unless they differ in representational content; and therefore that if they have the same representational content, they also have the same phenomenal content.
       How is intentionalism different from representationalism? Intentionalism says only that the phenomenal properties of a mental entity are wholly determined by its representational properties. Representationalism, on the other hand, says that all of the distinctly mental properties of a mental entity are determined by its representational properties. It follows (as we’ve noted) that representationalism is committed to the view that two mental entities cannot differ in any of their distinctly mental properties (not just their phenomenal properties) without differing in their representational content: it thus holds that all distinctly mental properties supervene on representational properties. By contrast, intentionalism is committed only to the view that two mental entities cannot differ in their phenomenal properties without differing in their representational properties.
      That said, it might appear that intentionalism and representationalism are, in effect, the same doctrine. For it might seem that the only distinctly mental properties that might be non-representational are phenomenal properties. So it might seem that, if the phenomenal properties of a mental entity content could be shown to supervene on (and thus, in some sense, reduce to) is representational properties, then representationalism would ipso facto be proven correct. (In other words, It might seem that if phenomenal content could be shown to supervene on representational content, then representationalism would ipso facto be proven correct.) We will see (in section IV) that, in fact, this is not the case : even if intentionalism were correct – even if the phenomenal supervened on the representational -- it would still not follow that representationalism was correct: for representationalism to be correct it is necessary but not sufficient that intentionalism be correct. On the other hand – what is a consequence of the last point – if intentionalism is false, then so a fortiori is representationalism.      My primary purpose in this paper is to show that intentionalism and (therefore) representationalism are false. Given this, the plan of the present paper is as follows. In sections II and III, I will attempt to show that intentionalism is false. (Of course, the arguments set forth in these sections, if cogent, will indirectly show that representationalism is false.) In section IV I will set forth an argument that (if cogent) directly shows that
representationalism is false. (In other words, the argument in that section will not show that representationalism is false by way of showing that intentionalism is false; the argument there will bear directly on representationalism.) In section V, I will try to identify the mis-step in an
[308]
	argument for intentionalism given by Professor Alex Byrne.         One caveat is in order. There may be various ways of weakening intentionalism, so as to make it immune to the kinds of arguments I will set forth. My arguments will bear – not against every weakening of intentionalism – but against intentionalism tout court; that is, against unrestricted intentionalism: the doctrine that, for any two experiences e and e’ (regardless of e.g. what, if any, perceptual modalities they respectively belong to) they be they cannot differ in phenomenal content unless they differ in representational content. It seems to me that unrestricted intentionalism is the most (perhaps the only)  significant kind of intentionalism: for to admit that only a restricted kind of intentionalism holds is to admit that there can be phenomenal diversity where there is representational identity. And to admit this is to admit that there is something to having intentional content other than having representational content: and this, of course, scuttles any hope of a strictly representational theory of mind (or even of consciousness). Notwithstanding this disclaimer, I will set forth an outline of an argument to the effect that some of the more plausible ways of weakening intentionalism – so as to immunize it from the kinds of assaults waged in his paper – are not viable. (I will do this in section V; and my discussion of this problem will be connected with my evaluation of Byrne’s argument.)
        Although not all of this paper will be concerned with intentionalism,
Byrne’s just mentioned argument for that doctrine crystallizes and exposes themes that will be present at every phase of our inquiry. So we would do well, I think, to state Byrne’s argument right now. That argument takes the form of two premises and a conclusion (this is how he himself presents it). I quote:
 
Premise A
 
     Assume the following: A subject enjoys two consecutive experiences: e, that ends at t, and then e*. e and e* differ in phenomenal character. The subject is competent: if she tries to retrieve information (or misinformation) in memory, then her attempt will be successful, and she has no other cognitive shortcoming. The subject tries to detect a change in phenomenal character after t. The subject’s memory is perfect: all the (mis)information supplied to her by e is available when she later enjoys e*.
     Then, solely on the basis of her current experience e* and the memory produced by her past experience e, the subject will notice a change after t: if she gives an accurate report when e* is over, she will say that there was a change in phenomenal character after t. (pp.207-208)
 
Premise B
 
     Assume that a subject enjoys an experience e that ends at t and then experience e*, and that after t the subject notices a change in phenomenal character, solely on the basis of her current experience e* and the (perfect) memory produced by her past experience e. Then the way things seem to the subject when she enjoys e differs from the way things seem when she enjoys e*. That is the [representational] content of e differs from the content of e*.
[309] (p. 210) Conclusion C
 
  If a competent subject whose memory is perfect and who tries to detect a change in phenomenal character enjoys consecutive experiences e and e* that differ in phenomenal character, then the content of e differs from the content of e*. (p. 213)
 
   Premise A is innocuous. All it really says is: If someone has two experiences e and e* that differ in phenomenal character, then that person will remember them as differing in phenomenal character, if he is ‘competent’, i.e. if his memory is accurate.
   Premise B is not innocuous. Indeed, it contains the essence of Byrne’s argument. (Arguably, it is Byrne’s argument.)  B basically says this. Suppose that some subject S has two experiences e and e*, and that e and e* differ in phenomenal content. In that case, the way the world seems to S in  virtue of his having e differs from the way the world seems to S in virtue of his having e*. Of course, this is supposed to hold for any two experiences e and e* that differ in phenomenal content. So there can be no difference in phenomenal content without a concomitant difference in how the world seems to the subject – without a difference in representational content.
     If I understand it correctly, conclusion C says, essentially, the following. Again, let S be some subject who has experiences e and e*, and suppose that e and e* differ in phenomenal content. Given premise B, e and e* differ in representational content. Therefore, if S is competent, he will remember e and e* as being different in representational content. Of course, C does follow from premises A and B.
     The really controversial move in Byrne’s argument is premise B. (Again, A is non-controversial; and C non-controversially follows from A and B.  So we needn’t focus too much on A or C.) B makes a strong claim: where two experiences are concerned, there can be no difference in phenomenal content without a difference in representational content. Now if Byrne provided no argument for B – if he just took its truth for granted – then his argument would almost be question begging. But Byrne does provide an argument for B. It is as follows.
     Suppose you are looking at a blue chip and, what is more, that you are
[310]
perceiving it as 	blue. Your perception of the blue of the chip obviously involves your having a certain kind of phenomenal content. (The perception of color clearly involves the experiencing of phenomenal content: there is something it is like to see an object as being red or blue.) Now imagine that dimension of your perception – viz. the dimension of your perception that mediates your awareness of the blue of the chip – as changing; i.e. imagine that that bit of phenomenal content is replaced by some other, qualitatively different bit of phenomenal content. In experiencing such a change in the phenomenal character of your experience, you are ipso facto experiencing a change in how the chip is given to you; more specifically, you are ipso facto experiencing a change in what color the chip is given to you as having. So with regard to your perception of the color of the chip, it is not possible for there to be a change in the phenomenology of that experience without there being a concomitant change in what that experience represents –- i.e. without there being a change in respect of what color the chip is represented to you as being. In general, a change in the phenomenal content of an experience necessarily involves a change in the representational content of that experience. So the phenomenal content of an experience is wholly determined by its representational content.
     A non-visual example may make this point more starkly. Suppose that you are tasting a drop of honey.  Obviously, your having this experience involves your experiencing a certain kind of phenomenal content. Now suppose that that bit of phenomenal content changes – i.e. is replaced by a qualitatively different bit of phenomenal content. Ipso facto the way that the honey is represented to you has changed; more specifically, the taste that the honey is represented to you as having has changed. It is not possible for the phenomenal dimension of your gustatory experience of the honey to change without the representational dimension changing as well: if the former is changed, then so ipso facto is the way the honey is represented to you: in virtue of the said phenomenal change, there is a change in the taste that the honey is represented to you as having. So there can be no change in the phenomenal dimension of an experience without a change in its representational dimension: the former supervenes on the latter. Hence the phenomenal content of an experience is wholly determined by the representational content of that experience.
 
II. This section will provide just one reason to think that a difference in phenomenal content doesn’t necessarily correspond to a difference in representational content, and consequently that both intentionalism and representationalism are false.
      Suppose that you are having a veridical perception of a certain car that is a certain shade of red. Let P be this perception. Presumably, the redness of the car is represented in P by some bit of phenomenal content (by some kind of visual sensation). Surely you can have beliefs about the colour of the car. In fact, you can have non-occurrent beliefs about the colour of the car. Let B be some non-occurrent of belief of yours about the colour of the aforementioned car. Non-occurrent beliefs (by definition) don’t have any phenomenal content. So B doesn’t have any phenomenal content. At the same [311]
	time, there is something in B – some feature or constituent of B - which represents the colour of the car. That something cannot itself be a bit of phenomenal content. (Being a non-occurrent belief, B doesn’t have phenomenal content.) So it follows trivially that something other than phenomenal content represents the colour of the car, at least where B is concerned.
    This establishes that two mental contents can have the same representational content without having the same phenomenal content. There is some constituent of P which represents the redness of the car, and that constituent has phenomenal content (in fact, it is a bit of phenomenal content). At the same time, there is some constituent of B which represents that same shade red, and that constituent has no phenomenal content. So these two bits of mental content have exactly the same representational content – they both represent the specific shade of red– but they differ in phenomenal content. (One of these bits of mental content has phenomenal content, while the other does not; so they clearly differ in phenomenal content.) And this, as we’ve seen, is inconsistent with intentionalism. And, because phenomenal properties are distinctly mental properties, it is inconsistent with representationalism.
      The argument just given can be generalized. It seems that ‘standing’ or ‘non-occurrent’ mental entities (e.g. my belief that pi is irrational) do not have phenomenal content.
