(They have manifestations in consciousness that have phenomenal content. But they themselves do not.) A fortiori nonoccurrent memories have no phenomenal content. You have countless memories stored away in the depths of your psyche. Surely they do not all have phenomenal content: there is not something it is like to have each and every one of them. (In fact, in so far as they are non-occurrent, none of them has phenomenal content.) Sense-perceptions, of course, do have phenomenal content (at least conscious sense-perceptions do). As we have noted, nothing that has phenomenal content can have the same phenomenal content as something that has no phenomenal content: this is vacuously, or trivially, true. So, in particular, no conscious sense-perception can have the same phenomenal content as any non-occurrent memory. Consequently, the intentionalist must hold that no non-occurrent memory can have the same representational content – can encode the same information – as any (conscious) perception.  (For, as we’ve noted, the intentionalist cannot allow that mental entities differ in their phenomenal content without differing in their representational content.)This means that, if intentionalism is correct, any sense-perception encodes some information that simply cannot be remembered; that, as a matter of principle, cannot be stored in a nonoccurrent memory. But this is highly counter-intuitive.
    Permit me to clarify this argument. It seems pretty clear that, because of our cognitive limitations, we cannot remember everything that we experience: few, I think, would deny this. But we also tend to think that, given any particular conscious experience, the content of that experience could, at least in principle, be stored in memory.  As we’ve just seen, if intentionalism is correct, then – for reasons of principle, not reasons having to do with our cognitive limitations --  given any conscious experience, the content of that experience cannot  (in its entirety) be stored in memory. So intentionalism is really committed to the idea that some information, by its very nature, cannot be stored; that some information can be housed only in consciousness and, thus, that it can be housed only in one medium. This idea would seem to be quite counter-intuitive. It would seem that any bit of representational content can be stored in different media; can be transferred from (e.g.) the medium of sense-perception to the medium of non-occurrent memory. To be sure, as we noted a moment ago,  a person’s memory banks are limited and they probably cannot store everything that that person has sense-perceived. But, if the argument just given is cogent, then intentionalism is committed to the idea that as a matter of principle nothing with a phenomenology – in particular, no conscious perception – can have the same representational content as something lacking a phenomenology – in particular, a non-occurrent memory. So intentionalism is committed to the view the content of your current visual perception cannot, at least not in its entirety, be stored in memory: some of the information borne by that perception simply cannot be remembered. And (if intentionalism is correct) the same is true of every conscious experience.  But this idea is radically implausible and possibly even incoherent.
[312] 	    An intentionalist might respond to this argument with the following:
 
   Let C be some conscious sense-perception. And let N be a non-occurrent memory of C; and suppose that N is as good a memory of C as is metaphysically possible. As you’ve pointed out, N and C don’t have the same phenomenology. And it follows – as you’ve also made clear – that if N and C had exactly the same representational content, then intentionalism would be false, given that intentionalism cannot allow a difference in phenomenology that doesn’t correspond to a difference representational content. But maybe the truth is that N and C don’t have quite the same representational content: maybe, in general, no conscious sense-perception has quite the same representational content as any non-occurrent memory. To be sure, N and C overlap in representational content; but, perhaps, they don’t quite coincide in representational content.
    If this is the case, then there is a way out for the intentionalist. For maybe this slight divergence in representational content accounts for the massive divergence in phenomenal content. To be sure, the divergence in phenomenal content seems out of proportion with the difference in representational content. (The latter is relatively small; the former is large – indeed, it might even be said to be total.) But there is no a priori reason why the relationship between the two should be linear. In fact, there is independent reason to believe the kind of relationship in question is not linear. A thing’s aesthetic properties supervene on its natural properties. So two performances of a certain work of music cannot differ in their aesthetic properties unless they differ in their natural (basically, acoustical) properties. But a slight difference in natural properties might correspond to a massive difference in aesthetic properties. Suppose that P1 and P2 are both performances of the Moonlight Sonata. P1 and P2 are very similar, in their subvenient (natural) properties, except that the piano involved in P1 is ever so slightly out of tune and the performer mis-hit one or two key notes, while the piano involved in P2 is in perfect tune, and the performer didn’t mis-hit any notes. P1 may be absolutely impossible to listen to (especially to someone with perfect pitch), while P2 will be divine. So here we have a case of a slight difference in subvenient properties corresponding to an almost total difference in supervenient properties. Another analogy might clarify this. It is a clear that thing’s biological properties (if it has any) supervene on its physical properties; so that creatures cannot differ in biological properties without differing in physical properties. Given this, suppose O1 and O2 are two organisms that are physically exactly a like, except that one of them has cancerous cells in some part of the brain responsible for a lot of vital functions. The strictly physical difference between O1 and O2 will be miniscule. But the biological difference is nearly total: one of the organisms is flourishing, while the other is on the brink of non-existence. Again, a minute difference in subvenient properties can correspond to an almost total different in supervenient properties. So the slight representational difference between N and C is more than enough to guarantee a massive phenomenal difference, without jeopardizing the claims of intentionalism.
 
    This response is a total failure. To fix our ideas, let us suppose that C is a visual perception of a bright red apple, and that N is a non-occurrent memory of that perception. (Also suppose that N is a relatively accurate and exhaustive memory.) As we’ve noted, the intentionalist must hold that the total divergence in phenomenal character between N and C is due to some marginal difference in representational content. But if we focus on the mass of representational content that N and C unquestionably do have in common – if we concede that they differ, however marginally, in representational content, and we confine our attention to the area of representational overlap between them – the data we are confronted with runs counter to intentionalism. Consider the bit of phenomenal content that, in C, is associated with its being a perception of something bright red; and let P be this bit of phenomenal content. The intentionalist must say that P’s presence in C is due wholly to C’s being a perception of something bright red. Now obviously N contains that same bit of representational content: so why doesn’t N have the corresponding phenomenal property?
     The force of this argument may be more apparent if it is stated slightly differently. If we confine ourselves to the representational content that N and C do have in common – and everyone must agree that there is a mass of it -- it is clear that the intentionalist must hold that, where C is concerned, this representational content corresponds to a mass, a deluge, of phenomenal content. So how is it that, where N is concerned, this same representational content is so utterly neutralized as regards its ability to subserve the same phenomenal content? Even if we concede that C has some extra little bit of representational content that N lacks, how could this fringe of representational content simply cancel out the power of the remaining bit of representational content to subserve phenomenal content?
     Another possible intentionalist counter-response to my argument is this:
 
     A non-occurent memory is really just a disposition to have certain occurrent experiences, that is, to be in certain kinds of phenomenally pregnant states. Now if indeed non-occurrent memories are dispositions to have certain phenomenally pregnant experiences, then (in effect) non-
[313]
occurrent memories do have phenomenal content.
 
 
     I concede that, if non-occurrent memories are just dispositions to have phenomenally pregnant experiences, then (in effect) non-occurrent memories do (at least after a fashion) have phenomenal content. (Of course, technically dispositions per se do not have phenomenal content. But this is a subtlety which, I concede, probably doesn’t ultimately have much bearing on the objector’s point.) I concede that if this analysis of what non-occurrent memories were correct, it would undermine that argument of mine for intentionalism. And I also concede that I cannot decisively refute that analysis within the confines of this particular inquiry.
     What I can say is this: the objector’s point – while, perhaps, a reasonable enough dialectical manoeuvre – commits him to some extremely dubious psychology and presupposes the falsity of some extremely hardy and fecund research programs in psychology. If cognitive science and psychoanalysis are to be given any credence (some say they aren’t: but if they are), then there is much more to a non-occurrent memory (i.e. a memory which is not a conscious reminiscence) than a disposition to have certain conscious experiences. There is certainly some reason to believe that, at a level far below that of consciousness,  mental contents – including, non-occurrent memories – interact and generate new mental contents;  and that their representational contents are very much implicated in these transactions. A banal example: before you go to sleep you non-occurently remember P and you non-occurently remember that if P then Q; but, for whatever reason, you haven’t formed the belief that Q. You wake up believing that Q. Presumably the two aforementioned beliefs were ‘inferentially’ integrated and, obviously, this integration was sub-conscious; and, even more obviously, the representational contents of your non-occurrent memories were implicated in this integration. In any case, this is a plausible enough explanation. (In my view, it is inconceivable how anyone could deny that this sort of subconscious ideation occurs. But I acknowledge that the idea there is subconscious ideation has been vicious attacked and that, consequently, what I’m saying has as conditional character.) Now the representational contents of your belief that P and your belief that if P then Q may heavily overlap with the representational contents of sense-perceptions. Your belief that P may be your belief that green apples have that appearance (where the appearance in question is visual) and your belief that if P then Q may be to the effect that if an apple has that appearance one day, then it will have that other appearance ten days later, if it is not refrigerated. (The two ‘that’s here are, of course, supposed to correspond to different visual demonstrations and thus to different sense-perceptions.) Nonetheless, even though your belief that P and your belief that if P then Q have a great deal of representational overlap with perceptions, nonetheless they themselves may be non-occurrent (indeed, one has countless non-occurrent to the effect that such and such looks like that where the ‘that’ corresponds to a visual, olfactory etc. presentation); and - this is the rub – the contents of such non-occurrent memories can, at least by the lights of some plausible psychological models, interact at a sub-conscious level. So there is certainly excellent reason to believe the objector’s analysis of non-occurrent memories (viz. that they are just dispositions to have certain conscious experiences) does not do justice to the psycho-dynamics of such things.
 
III.   This  section will set forth another argument that is directed specifically against intentionalism.  Obviously perceptions that are associated with different sensory modalities have different phenomenal contents.
(Phenomenally, visual perceptions are different from auditory perceptions; tactile perceptions are different from auditory perception and visual perceptions; and so on.) Now some bits of information can be given to one through different sensory modalities. I can learn that a certain object is spherical through sight or through touch (and a bat could learn this through hearing – through sonar – and a mole could learn this through smell). But surely no visual perception of mine has any phenomenal overlap with any tactile perception of mine. But, it would seem, if intentionalism is true, then there ought to be some overlap, given that there is overlap (if not identity) in terms of representational content.
   The intentionalist could respond to this as follows:
 
     Suppose that T is a tactile perception of the ball’s roundness and that V is a visual perception of the ball’s roundness. T and V (by hypothesis) overlap in representational content. But, inevitably, they will not coincide in representational content. For example, T will give the subject information about the firmness and the temperature of the ball, whereas V will not provide such information; and V will provide the subject with information about the ball’s color, whereas T will not provide this information. So we have a divergence in representational content; and maybe this divergence accounts for the divergence in phenomenal content.
 
   We have, in effect, already seen how to respond this sort of criticism. By hypothesis, T and V overlap, to a large degree, in representational content. But T and V plainly have no phenomenal overlap at all. No visual perception is phenomenally at all like any tactile perception. But given how much T and V overlap in representational content, we’d expect there to be at least minimal phenomenal overlap between them. This argument can be made more explicit. Let R be the bit of representational content that T and V unquestionably do have in common. (So R is information to the effect that the ball is round.) Now where T is concerned, R corresponds to one kind of phenomenal content; whereas where V is concerned, R corresponds to a very different kind of phenomenal content. The kind of phenomenal content you have in virtue of seeing the roundness of the ball is very different from the kind of phenomenal content you have in virtue of feeling the roundness of the ball. So here we have a certain bit of representational content – viz. R – that is subserving quite different phenomenal contents. And this, of course, is just what intentionalism says cannot happen.
      I should consider another objection to this argument:
 
 
      These days a distinction is widely made between ‘‘propositional’ and
[314]
	‘non-propositional’ content.  The idea is roughly this. Consider an arbitrary proposition e.g. Bob is tall and Fred is short. This is obviously neatly decomposable into discrete parts (Bob, __is tall, Fred etc.) Put in positive terms, this proposition is obviously built out of ‘minimal’ representational units; there is a unique and correct decomposition of this proposition. Now consider a visual perception (or a photograph). This is, quite plainly, not divisible into minimal representational units; and, what is connected, the representational content of such a thing – i.e. what it represents – is not decomposable (in any natural way) into minimal units: is not decomposable into units like Bob and __is tall etc. (Propositions are ‘digital’; visual perceptions are analogue.) So the representational content of a visual perception cannot be embodied in a proposition: the representational content of a  visual perception is, at least in part, non-propositional (such that it cannot be embodied in a proposition).
        Now you’ve said a great deal about propositional representational content. But you’ve said nothing about non-propositional representational content. Your argument was essentially: one’s visual perception of the ball has a great deal of representational overlap with one’s tactile perception of the ball – specifically, they both bear the representational content the ball is round – but there is no phenomenal overlap corresponding to this representational overlap. Now the representational overlap is propositional; both visual perceptions bear the proposition the ball is round. So you’ve made some case that, where propositional representational content is concerned, intentionalism is false, i.e. that there may be phenomenal diversity where there is propositional identity. But you’ve left open the possibility that intentionalism holds where non-propositional representational content is concerned; i.e. you’ve left open the possibility that, if two mental entities coincide in non-propositional representational content, then they coincide in phenomenal content.
 
   
     There are a couple of things to say in response to this: some obvious, some less obvious. Let’s start with the obvious – with what the objector himself concedes. Propositional content is a kind of representational content.
Given what we’ve already said, it seems pretty clear that perceptions with non-overlapping phenomenologies can overlap in propositoial content and thus in some kind of represnetaitonal content. (To use another example: an olfactory perception can tell you the fish is rotten  and a gustatory perception tell you the same thing, notwithstanding that there is no phenomenal overlap between the two perceptions.) So this by itself is enough to refute intentionalism: any identity in representational content —whether this content is propositional or not – that subtends a diversity in phenomenal content is enough to refute intentionalism. This obvious point constitutes the bulk of my counter-response.
        Now given only what I’ve said it is possible that intentionalism is true of non-propositional content; I do concede that the argument I gave above is subject to this limitation of scope. And I cannot think of any neat argument that would show that intentionalism doesn’t  hold for non-propositoial content. But I can make a couple of points that, while proving nothing, have some force against even this restricted kind of intentionalism. (What I’m about to say consists, I fully admit, of highly contentious speculations. I am permitting myself these contentious speculations since – having shown that intentionalism is false where a kind of representational content is concerned, viz. propositional content  – I have made some case that unrestricted intentionalism is untenable.)
        First of all, with regard to those who do distinguish between propositional and non-propositional content, it is pretty clear that they are on to some kind of important distinction. But the distinction is, I submit, a distinction between ways of representing things; it is not a distinction in what is represented. Put another way, it is a distinction between ways of
‘packaging’ information: what is in the packages doesn’t vary. There is only one kind of represnetaitonal content; but there are different ways of transmitting this one kind of content. 
         Once again, consider an arbitrary visual perception. (Supposing that, indeed, some representations have non-propositional content, visual perceptions are paradigm cases of such representations; so we might as well focus on them.) Uncontroversially, the represnetaitonal content of a visual perception can to some degree be put into words and, thus, embodied in a proposition. People can tell you what they saw, at least up to a point (‘I saw a man in an orange shirt smoking a pipe…’) So obviously the represnetaitonal content of a visual perception overlaps to some extent with the representational content of a sentence (‘I saw a man in orange shirt…’): a paradigmatically ‘digital’ representation. Again, I do not think this is controversial: who could possibly maintain that the representational content of a visual perception is utterly ineffable – is totally incapable of being embodied in a sentence? Surely when I say ‘I saw a red apple sitting on a desk…’ I am succeeding in transmitting some of the representational content of a visual perception of mine.  (Now a hardliner might say that the representational content of e.g. my perception of the man in the orange shirt cannot to any degree be embodied in a proposition; that when I give a verbal report of what perception tells me, I am really only giving you some kind of analogue of some bit of information that is encoded in that perception, but that I am not really giving you any of that information in propria persona. Again, the obvious problem with this line of thought is that, if it is taken seriously, it forces us to take the obviously false position that, strictly speaking, our perceptions are completely and totally incommunicable. But that isn’t so. In any case, I will proceed on the understandable assumption that it isn’t so.)
      Now the next step is also, I think, fairly uncontroversial. Visual
[315]
	representations are, in an important sense, homogeneous. When we consider a visual perception, there is no reason to believe that it has two, totally different kinds of representational content; visual perceptions seem to be (in this respect) ‘seamless’; the representational content of a visual perception seems not to be patchwork of totally different kinds of content – of propositional and non-propositional content. Visual perceptions are not cobbled together out of discrete parts. Now if analogue representations had both propositional content and some other totally different kind of content, then, presumably, there would be a very big ‘seam’ in them; they would then have a ‘cobbled together’ quality which they obviously don’t have.  To clarify this: what it is for something to be an analogue representation is for its represnetaitonal content to have a kind of seamlessness, a kind of imperviousness to neat separation. Now obviously if a visual perception had two totally different kinds of content – propositional and other – then it would be about as capable as anything of just this kind of decomposition. So, to sum up, there is certainly a lot of intuitive support for the idea that the analogue representations (e.g. visual perceptions) have but one kind of representational content.
       So the facts we have to work with are as follows. (i) The content of an analogue (e.g. a visual) representation can, at least up to a point, be expressed by a sentence and thus, presumably, embodied in a proposition. (ii) An analogue representation does not bear two, completely distinct kinds of represnetaitonal content.
      Now given both (i) and (ii), it seems to follow that the represnetaitonal content of a visual perception is in its entirety propositional. But this conclusion is in deep tension with the following fact, viz.: (iii) There is, plainly, some kind of important distinction between analogue (e.g. visual) and digital representations (e.g. propositions): the latter are, whereas the former are not, decomposable into minimal represnetaitonal units.
     The best way to make sense of these three facts is, I would suggest,  as follows: the difference between propositions and e.g. visual representations is not a difference in what is represented but in how it is represented. Each of (i)-(iii) is correct. The difference between e.g. a sentence and a visual perception lies not in what is represented, but in how what is represented is packaged. A sentence tidies everything up, putting it in discrete parcels. A visual representation leaves it, as it were, strewn all over the floor. A proposition is not a special kind of information; it is a special packaging of information.
    I think that this line of thought does less violence to our intuitions than the alternatives. First of all, we do want to say that the information borne by a visual perception can (at least up to a point) be embodied in a proposition. But we don’t want to say that the representational content of a visual perception is a proposition (or conjunction of propositions), for the simple reason that propositions are, whereas the contents of visual representations are not, neatly decomposable into minimal units. (Surely the proposition Bob is smarter than Fred is decomposable into discrete parts while the representational content of a visual perception of a forest is not thus decomposable.) We also probably don’t want to say that a visual perception has two wholly distinct kinds of representational content: propositional and other. Given these data, the only way to go is to say: A visual (more generally, an analogue) representation bears only kind of representational content; and this content can be packaged in a proposition, but it doesn’t have to be.
      So it is true that sentences bear propositions while visual perceptions do not; but it is also true that the content of a visual perception can be embodied in propositions. If propositions were one kind of represnetaitonal content while the representational contents of visual perceptions were some totally different kind of content, this would not be possible. But propositions are not a kind of content; they are a way of packaging content. Visual representations don’t package content in this way; but what they do package can be packaged propositionally.
      Now if this is even remotely on the mark, then there are two quite distinct dimensions to the ‘representational load’ of a representation: there is the representational content of that representation; and there is also the packaging of that content. Now the packaging of this content has too often been identified with the representation itself. But this is a mistake. A visual perception of a round ball and the sentence ‘that ball is round’ obviously overlap in what they represent; but the way they package this common content differs. So what is borne by a sentence is not just representational content, but a certain way of packaging this content; and the same is true of a visual perception. (The sentence itself is not identical with the packaging. The sentence ‘Bob is intelligent’ packages the same representational content in the same way as the sentence ‘Bob is smart’. But these sentences are obviously different.) But what it is that is packaged is not a proposition: and that is why visual representations – and, more generally, analogue representations: representations which do not have propositions for the representations contents – can have their contents embodied in propositions.      Now let us bring these thoughts to bear on the topic of intentionalism. We have seen, I think, that where a kind of representational content is concerned, two perceptions can share that content and yet have no phenomenal overlap. Now if – as we have just seen some reason (however minimal) to believe – there is only one kind of representational content, then – what follows trivially - if intentionalism is false for a kind of representational content, it is
[316]
false for all of them.
          
 
IV. In this section I will not be directly concerned with phenomenal content. I will show that mental entities can differ in some of their distinctly mental properties -- though not necessarily their phenomenal properties -- without differing in their representational properties (i.e. in their representational content). So my target here is representationalism, not (except perhaps indirectly) intentionalism.
   Prima facie it seems that different propositional attitudes can have the same representational content. I can doubt whether Mary is coming home, believe that Mary is coming home, suppose that Mary is coming home, hope that Mary is coming home, fear that Mary is coming home, and so on. Basically, I can have various different attitudes towards the proposition Mary is coming home. In general, given any proposition P, one can have various different attitudes towards that proposition. This fact is of singular importance in connection with the question whether representationalism is correct. The intentionalist holds that there is nothing to the having of any mental content besides the grasping of representational content. So, in particular, the representationalist must hold that, given any propositional attitude, there is nothing to one’s having that propositional attitude above and beyond one’s grasping of some representational content. Basically, the representationalist must assimilate the attitudinal component of propositional attitudes to their representational or propositional component.
       But it is not hard to show that, for any propositional attitude A (with the possible exception of merely contemplating some proposition), there is no thing x (no proposition, no object: generally, no bit of representational content) such that, in order for that person to be in A, it is enough that x be represented to that person (i.e. that that person grasp x). Basically, in order for someone to have a certain propositional attitude, it is not in general enough that something be represented to him: not enough that he grasp some representational content  -- the attitudinal component of a propositional attitude cannot, at least not in general, be reduced to its representational  component.
     The argument for this is fairly simple. Suppose that I fear that Mary will come home. Is there any proposition P such that, merely by virtue of P’s being represented to me – by virtue of my grasping P – I ipso facto fear that Mary will come home? No. What proposition would this be? I can certainly grasp the proposition Mary will come home without fearing that Mary will come home. Even if there is nothing that would cause me more horror than to believe that Mary is coming home, my merely grasping the proposition Mary will come home needn’t be attended by my fearing that Mary will come home. For I could, at least in principle, grasp this proposition without believing it. (For me to entertain hypothetical propositions involving this proposition, I must obviously grasp this proposition; but my entertaining such hypothetical propositions doesn’t involve my believing it. To entertain the hypothetical proposition ‘if snow is green, then pigs fly’ I must grasp the propositions snow is green and pigs fly; but obviously I can entertain the former hypothetical proposition without believing either that snow is green or that pigs fly.)
     Is there any other proposition such that, merely by virtue of grasping it, I fear that Mary will come home? It doesn’t seem so. For I can consider, and thus grasp, virtually any proposition without believing that there is the slightest chance of its being true and thus without having any fear in connection with it; I can, for example, consider the proposition Mary will come home and torture me and firmly believe that Mary will not come home. So I can consider, and thus grasp, virtually any proposition without feeling any fear of anything in connection with it.
    Is there some object such that, merely by virtue of that object’s being represented to me, I fear that Mary will come home? First of all, it seems to me that objects can’t be represented to people without propositions being represented to them. An object cannot just be represented to me; it must be represented as having this or that characteristic – so the proposition that it has this or that characteristic must be represented to me if the object is to be represented to me. But even if this isn’t true – even if objects can be represented to someone without propositions being represented to that person – this still doesn’t help the representationalist. For there is no object O such that, merely by virtue of grasping O – by virtue of O’s being represented to me – I have any propositional attitude (besides, perhaps, that of merely considering O). For what object is it the case that, merely by virtue of my grasping O, I fear that Mary will come home? None; for I can think about any object without fearing anything. I can think about a grinning Mary holding a blood-encrusted chainsaw without fearing anything. (Of course, my psychology might be such that, if I so much as contemplate such a horrifying object, I automatically feel some kind of dread. But surely this has to do with the peculiarities of my psyche. It is not logically or metaphysically necessary that I feel such dread upon thinking about this kind of object.) In general, I can think about any object without having any propositional attitude (other than, perhaps, that of merely considering the object).
      Of course, what we’ve said about fearing that Mary will come home applies to propositional attitudes generally. There is no proposition P, no object O, such that merely by virtue of my grasping P or O I doubt that Mary will come home or believe that Mary will come home or am sad that Mary will come, and so on. Basically, there is something to propositional attitudes besides their having representational content; the attitudinal component of propositional attitudes is not in general assimilable to representational content.  Of course, the attitudinal component of a mental entity is a distinctly mental component of it. It follows that what is distinctly mental does not coincide with, and doesn’t supervene on, what is representational: so representationalism is false.
    
   Once again you have spoken a great deal about propositional content, but not about non-propositional content. I grant what you’ve said: there seems to be no proposition P such that merely in virtue of grasping P one has this as opposed to that propositional attitude. (And, I suppose, the same is true of any object that one might grasp.) So – as you said – the having of propositional attitudes isn’t wholly assimilable to the mere apprehending of propositions; so (again, as you said) there is something to having propositional attitudes besides the mere apprehending of propositions (and objects): to have a propositional attitude is not just to be in a mental state with a certain propositional content. – Fair enough: you’ve made some case for this. But you haven’t ruled out the possibility that to have a certain propositional attitude is just to apprehend some non-propositional representational content and that, consequently, the having of propositional attitudes does reduce to being in a mental condition that has a certain represnetaitonal (albeit non-propositional) content.
 
 
       Fair enough; the objector has pointed out a lacuna in my argument. (Of course, if our earlier remarks about representational content are on the mark, they may to some extent vitiate what the objector is saying. But, admittedly, those remarks were much too contentious for me to use against the objector in the present context.) Let is fill this void. Suppose I fear that Mary will come home. Now is there some kind of representational content R such that merely in virtue of my grasping R I have fear that Mary will come home? Is there any represnetaitonal content R – whether analogue or digital -- such that merely by virtue of my apprehending R I ipso facto am afraid that Mary will come home? Or suppose I (like Hilbert) believe that arithmetic is complete.
Now is there some representational content – leaving it totally open whether R is a proposition, a non-proposition, a combination proposition/nonproposition – such that merely by virtue of my being in a mental state that encodes R (i.e. that is a grasping of R), I ipso facto believe that arithmetic is complete? Surely not. So the having of propositional attitudes very much seems not to be assimilable to the mere grasping of any kind of representational content. Conclusion: there is, at least in some cases, more to having a propositional attitude than being in a mental state that has a certain represnetaitonal content. (Now this leaves it open that in some cases the having of a propositional attitude reduces to the grasping of some representational content. It might be held – though I think it would be false to do so – that one cannot have a visual perception without ipso facto having some kind of belief: David Armstrong held this. Now a case might be made that to have a visual perception is just to apprehend a certain kind of content. Given these points,  a case might be made– that, where visual perceptions are concerned, the having of a belief, and thus of a certain propositional attitude, supervenes on the mere grasping of a certain bit of representational content. Now I don’t know whether this line of thought is correct or not. But it doesn’t matter for our purposes. We have, I think, established that where some propositional attitudes are concerned, there is more to having those attitudes than just grasping a certain representational content; and, therefore, that propositional attitudes are not in general consistent with the claims of
Representationalism.)
         Importantly, we’ve seen in this section that even if intentionalism is
true, it doesn’t follow that representationalism is true. Not all propositional attitudes have phenomenal content. For example, a person’s believing that pi is transcendental has no phenomenal content, and neither does a person’s doubting that pi is transcendental. We’ve seen that the difference in the attitudinal components of these propositional attitudes does not correspond to a difference in their representational components. At the same time, the difference in their attitudinal components cannot possibly correspond to a difference in their phenomenal components, since they have no such components. So someone’s doubting that pi is transcendental is different in its distinctly mental properties from a person’s believing that pi is transcendental; but this difference corresponds neither to a difference in phenomenal properties nor to a difference in representational properties. So even if intentionalism were correct –even if the phenomenal  generally reduced to the representational – representationalism would still be false.
 
        “You are arguing against a straw man,” it will be said. “I can think of no one who thinks that the attitudinal differences between e.g. fearing that Bob is coming home and hoping that Bob will come home correspond to differences in the representational contents that they encode; I know of no one who holds that ‘the attitudinal can be assimilated to the representational’.”
 
       It may be true that no one has ever maintained specifically that (as we have put it) the difference between fearing that Bob will come home and hoping that he will come home corresponds to a difference in the proposition encoded in these attitudes. Nonetheless, anyone who holds a strictly representationalist view of the mind – and there is no shortage of thinkers who (at least if we go by the letter of what they so) hold such a view – is, as I have shown, committed to holding just this. (That they have failed to see that they were entangled in this commitment is to their discredit, not mine.)
 
   
V.   We’ve seen already that, contrary to what intentionalism says, a difference in phenomenal content does not necessarily correspond to a difference in representational content. For we’ve seen what, by all appearances, are counter-examples to that thesis; and we have, if I am not mistaken, discredited the more plausible ways of trying to neutralize these counter-examples.
At the same time, the main premise of Byrne’s argument for intentionalism seems to be true: if you focus on (say) your gustatory perception of the sweetness of the honey, and you imagine a change in the phenomenology of that perception, you are ipso facto imagining a change in what that perception represents.  If you imagine a change in the phenomenology of your perception of the blue of the chip, you ipso facto imagine a change in what color the chip is represented to you as having. How is what we have seen – viz. that there are reasons for holding that intentionalism is false – to be reconciled with the apparent truth of this point of Byrne’s?
 One way to respond is by advocating a restricted intentionalism. Permit me to clarify this. We have noted, and made much of the fact, that if intentionalism is correct – i.e. if the phenomenal content of an experience is wholly determined by its representational content -- then for any pair of mental entities x and y (whether x and y are experiences or not), x and y must have the same phenomenal content if they have the same the same representational content. Of course, given what we’ve seen, it is very hard to believe that that this is the case. But, it might be argued, what might still hold is a form of intentionalism that is so weakened, so circumscribed, that it entails only that for some pairs of mental entities x and y,  x and y  cannot differ in phenomenal content without differing in representational content. So, it might be thought, a properly restricted form of intentionalism might still hold: one that bears not on all pairs of mental entities, but only on pairs drawn from certain sub-classes of the mental.
     The question then becomes: what are the appropriate restrictions? First of all, if what we’ve said is correct, then intentionalism must be restricted to experiences. As we’ve seen, a non-occurrent memory can have the same representational content as a perception. But clearly no perception has any phenomenal overlap with a non-occurrent memory or, indeed, with any mental entity that is not an experience. So the first restriction is this: a properly restricted intentionalism is not concerned with mental entities that are not experiences and that, consequently, have no phenomenal content (viz. ‘dispositional’ mental entities and also the deeply unconscious computational processes posited by Marr, Chomsky and other cognitive scientists).
   The second restriction is not hard to identify.  We’ve noted that perceptions belonging to different sensory modalities can overlap to a large degree in representational content, while having no phenomenal overlap; and we’ve also seen that this fact is inconsistent with (unrestricted) intentionalism. So a suitably restricted form of intentionalism is to hold within sensory modalities but not between them; a suitably restricted form of intentionalism will entail only that, given two perceptions belonging to the same sensory  modality, those perceptions cannot differ phenomenally unless they differ representationally.
  So, to sum up, our new, restricted form of intentionalism entails only that, if x and y are perceptions belonging to the same sensory modality, then x and y cannot differ phenomenally without differing representationally. Byrne
[317]
does seem to have made a good case for this 	position. 
   In a moment, I will try to show that even this restricted kind of intentionalism is probably not viable; more specifically, that even within a single sensory modality there can be phenomenal variation without any representational variation. But even if we grant that this restricted form intentionalism is correct, this would cast only a very limited light on the nature of the mental and, more specifically, on the nature of phenomenal content: indeed, it would say much less about the mental, and about the nature of phenomenal content specifically, than the fact that unrestricted intentionalism is false. Our restricted intentionalism allows that there can be phenomenal variation without representational variation. (It allows that e.g. a non-occurrent memory and a perception can have the same representational content while having no phenomenal overlap.) So it straightforwardly concedes that phenomenal content is not, at least not in general, reducible to representational content. Consequently  it leaves us in the dark as to what phenomenal content is. Indeed, supposing that the only correct form of intentionalism is restricted intentionalism, the only thing that fact teaches us is that phenomenal content is not the same thing as representational content
(at least not in general)
   Also our restricted form of intentionalism is quite incoherent.  As just noted, our restricted form of intentionalism allows for phenomenal variation that does not correspond to representational variation. (It prohibits phenomenal variation without representational variation only where perceptions belonging to the same sensory modality are concerned.) Given this, let R be some bit of representational content that, in perception P1, is associated with phenomenal content C1. (Recall that the same bit of representational content can be ‘associated with’ different phenomenal contents in different perceptions. I can see that the ball is spherical and I can also feel that the ball is spherical. This representational content – viz. that the ball is spherical -- is ‘associated with’ one bit of phenomenal content in my visual perception, and a very different one in my tactile perception.) Our restricted intentionalism allows for the possibility that some perception P2 also has R but does not have C  (our restricted intentionalism allows this so long as P2 belongs to a sensory modality different from P1). Now if a perception P2 has R but does not have C, it follows that having R is not sufficient for having C. (If having R were sufficient for having C, then P2 would have C.)  Since having R is not sufficient for having C, it follows, in turn, that P1’s having C is not wholly a function of its having R. (Since having R is not sufficient for having C, it cannot be that P1 has C wholly because it has R.) Now remember that (unrestricted) intentionalism is the view that the phenomenal content of an experience is a function wholly of its representational content. Now as we’ve just noted,  our restricted intentionalism allows that any given bit of representational content can be associated with different phenomenal contents. So, it follows, our restricted form of intentionalism allows that no bit of representational content is sufficient for having any particular bit of phenomenal content. (If any bit of representational content were sufficient for having this or that kind of phenomenal content, then given any two mental entities sharing that representational content  – regardless of whether those entities belonged to the same sensory modality or not; regardless, indeed, of whether they were both perceptions – that bit of representational content could not give rise to different phenomenal contents in the two entities. But, as we’ve just seen, our restricted intentionalism allows that one and the same bit of representational content can be associated with different phenomenal contents in different perceptions.) But if the latter is the case, it follows that a mental entity’s having a particular phenomenal content is never wholly a function of its having a particular representational content. So, to sum up, our restricted intentionalism allows (by implication) that given any perception (indeed, given any mental entity), the phenomenal content of that perception (or entity) is never wholly a function of its representational content, But , of course, if the latter is the case, then no form of intentionalism – restricted or unrestricted – holds. For surely any form of ‘intentionalism’ worthy of the name holds that, in at least some cases, a mental entity has the phenomenal content it has wholly in virtue of having the representational content that it has: but it is just this, as we’ve just seen, that our restricted intentionalism implicitly denies. So our restricted ‘intentionalism’ really collapses into nonintentionalism.
However, even if we leave the contents of the last two paragraphs aside, it is still doubtful whether even a restricted intentionalism of the kind considered is correct: and this is so notwithstanding the strong prima facie case Byrne has made for it. (That said, I must to some extent disclaim what I am about to say: it is meant only to be suggestive, not probative. But I think that a rigorous refutation of even the restricted kind of intentionalism just considered could be coaxed out of the following considerations.)
  The view to be defended is as follows.  First of all, the relationship between our phenomenal contents and their physical causes is, presumably, a relatively consistent one; if our sensory surfaces are affected in the same manner on two different occasions, we don’t experience radically different phenomenal contents as a result. So identity in physical input is (or tends to be) reflected in identity of phenomenal output. (At any rate, it is to be hoped that this is true. In so far as identity of physical input is followed by wild diversity of phenomenal output, then it seems our ability to obtain knowledge about the physical world is to that extent jeopardized. The viability of a representational system is predicated on, among other things, its consistency.)
And, by the same reasoning, similarity of physical input is, presumably, followed by similarity of phenomenal output. Consider the phenomenal output you have in response to your eardrums being disturbed by sound-wave oscillations of 440 hertz: let P1 be this phenomenal output. If your eardrums are disturbed by oscillations of 460 hertz, the resulting phenomenal output – call it P2 -- will be much closer to P1 than the phenomenal output resulting from noise of 700 hertz would be. In general  there is a certain
commensurability between them and their physical causes (in any case, this is what we must suppose if our phenomenal contents are to be of help in gaining knowledge of the outside world); the relationship between these two classes of events must be systematic – governed by some rule (a kind of ‘rule of projection’). (Of course, there are different ‘rules of projection’ for different sensory modalities, since different modalities involve different types of phenomenal contents.)
    Given all of this, suppose for the sake of argument  that R is an arbitrary one of these rules. Here is what I suggest. If R is held constant – i.e. if the overall manner in which phenomenal contents (belonging to some one sensory modality) are paired off with their physical causes is held constant -then any particular phenomenal shift will correspond to a representational shift. However if R is changed – if what is changed is the overall manner in which phenomenal contents are paired off with their physical causes – then a particular phenomenal shift need not correspond to a representational shift. Byrne, in effect, considers only cases of phenomenal shift that take place within a context where R has remained constant: thus he has made it appear as though phenomenal shift (a shift in the phenomenal content of one’s experience) always corresponds to a representational shift (a shift in the representational content of one’s experience). But when we consider cases where R itself is changed, then we see some reason to believe that a phenomenal shift does not always correspond to a representational shift.
   These condensed and obscure remarks may make more sense if we further delineate the sound-example. Suppose that you have perfect pitch ( so that whenever you hear a sound that is in fact, say,  a middle C, you hear it as being a middle C – you don’t have to consult some reference-point to figure out that what you are hearing is a middle C.)  Given this, consider the kind of phenomenal content that you experience, when (under ‘standard’ acoustical conditions) a middle C (440 hertz) is played on a piano. Let p1 be this bit of phenomenal content. Now consider the kind of phenomenal content that you experience when (under standard conditions) a middle C# is played; let p2 be this phenomenal content. Let p3 be the kind of phenomenal content you have when a middle D is struck – and so on for all the other notes.  Let R1 be this rule. (So, just to be clear, R1 is the rule that assigns p1 to a middle C, p2 to a middle C#, and so on.) Now if R1 continues to hold – in other words, if your auditory phenomenal contents are paired off with sounds in accordance with R1 -- then a shift in the phenomenal content of your auditory experience – say, a shift from having p1 to having p2 – will correspond to a shift in the representational content of your auditory experience (you will go from hearing a C to hearing a C#.) Up to this point we are in agreement with Byrne.
   But now suppose that you have neurosurgery; and that, as a result, your ‘pitch-spectrum’ is altered. So now, whenever a middle C is played, you experience p2 (instead of p1); whenever a middle C# is played you experience p3 (instead of p2); and so on. So, in effect, the surgery would replace R1 with a different rule – with a different pairing of phenomenal
[318]
	contents with disturbances of your eardrums. (Let R2 be this new ‘rule of projection’.)  Right after the operation, you would probably be thrown off by your phenomenal contents; when experiencing p2, you would think (wrongly) ‘I am hearing a C#’, when in fact you were hearing a D. But there doesn’t seem to be any reason why you couldn’t adjust. Presumably you would, or at least could,  become acclimatized to this shift; and after this acclimatization, when experiencing p2, you would automatically know  (i.e. you would know without having to perform any conscious inference) that you were hearing a C: in effect, as a result of the said acclimatization, you would, in having p2, hear a C  Thus, it seems to me --- and I admit that what I’m about to say is contentious – that, if you had such surgery, and if you became ‘acclimatized’ to the resulting shift in phenomenal contents, then the representational content associated with (say) p2 really would have shifted from a C# to a C (the same being true mutatis mutandis of p3, p4 and so on) So here, at least arguably,  we have a case where, within a single sensory modality, there is a shift in phenomenal content that is not accompanied by a
[319]
	shift in representational content. Before the surgery, p2 represented a C#; after the surgery, p2 represented a C. So because the overall rule of projection has changed – because the overall manner has changed in which phenomenal contents (of a certain sort) have been paired off with physical disturbances – a particular difference in phenomenal content doesn’t correspond to a difference in representational content.
       The basic idea here is this. It is not any bit of phenomenal content per se that corresponds to a bit of representational content. Rather it is the phenomenal content as part of a larger pattern that has representational content: a pattern of having certain phenomenal contents in response to certain stimuli. An analogy might help: any point in space can be represented by any number (actually, by any triple of numbers; but let us just speak of single numbers for the sake of expository ease).  But if a given number is to represent a point in space, it must be part of some principled and consistent way of assigning numbers to points. It would be meaningless to assign a number to just one point: you wouldn’t learn anything about the location of that point from its number; and this is because there is no intrinsic relation between any number and any point in space. And it would also be meaningless to assign numbers to points in space if the arithmetical relations between the numbers did not have some kind of structural similarity to (some ‘isomorphism’ with) the geometric relations between the points thereby numbered. A given number meaningfully (informatively) labels a point in space iff it is part of a general assignment of numbers to points in space satisfying the following condition: for any two numbers x and y, if P(x) and P(y) are the points in space which x and y label, then one can infer the arithmetical relationship between x and y on the basis of the geometric relationship between P(x) and P(y) and vice versa. The idea is, roughly, that the ‘rule of projection’ – the rule pairing off numbers with points – must correspond to a kind of abstract, structural similarity holding between the two sets in question. And it is not anything intrinsic to a certain triple (say <45, 87, 44>) that makes it represent a particular point P in space: that triple is just a kind of place-holder; it represents P only because some rule of projection is countenanced, not because of anything intrinsic to that triple. The same arguably seems to be true of phenomenal contents. Given a particular bit of phenomenal content, it is not because of anything intrinsic to that content that it represent, say, a middle C; it is only because some rule of projection is operative. If a different one were operative, that same phenomenal content might represent a middle E. For a given phenomenal content to represent a middle C, or certain shade of pink, a certain temperature, it is necessary and sufficient that there be a certain abstract, structural similarity holding between your phenomenal contents and their respective physical causes. But different pairings of phenomenal contents and physical causes could, presumably, realize this abstract similarity: so a given phenomenal content could betoken a C or a C# or a D; and, consequently, a given representational content could be associated with different phenomenal contents belonging to the same modality. So, if we are right,  there is no absolute correspondence between phenomenal and representational content; and different phenomenal contents, even within the same modality, can bear the same representational content, contrary to what even the restricted intentionalist holds.

C. Rancurello, and Linda L. McAlister. London and New York: Routledge, 1995.
 
Byrne, Alex

 The Philosophical Review, Vol. 110, No. 2  April 2001
 
 
Dretske, Fred
 
[1]  Naturalizing the Mind  (The M.I.T. Press 1995) chapter 3, section 2  Harman, Gilbert

Review of Erin McReady’s review of Conceptual Atomism and
the Computational Theory of Mind
 
Introduction     Erin McReady, a distinguished linguist, recently published a review of my (2007) book Conceptual Atomism and the Computational Theory of Mind: A Defense of Content Internalism and Semantic Externalism (CAC). While I do not question Dr. McCready’s excellence as a scholar, I submit that he did not do himself justice in this review of his, which consists of shoddy arguments directed against positions that McCready either mischaracterizes or that I simply didn’t advocate. For example, McCready says that my book is an attempt to refute semantic externalism, even though the book is subtitled: A Defense of Semantic Externalism and Content Internalism. This was not a slip of the pen on McCready’s part: his criticisms of my book are hewed to the assumption that semantic externalism is, indeed, one of my targets.
      In this ‘counterreview,’ as it were, I will summarize what I said correct those distortions by outlining some of the main contentions of that book. Whenever we put forth a view with which McCready took issue, we will pause to determine the merit’s of McCready’s position.
       In Part 1, we’ll make a case for semantic externalism and against content internalism. In  Part 2, we’ll make a case against CTM, having first shown that, given the falsity of content externalism, it loses much of its credibility. In Part 3, we’ll put forth and defend an answer to the question “what are propositions?,” which, if correct, provides further support for the anti-CTM points to be made in Part 3 and which also, unlike rival analyses, establishes a natural and data-consistent between the structures of propositions, on the one hand, and, on the other, those of the sentence(-tokens) that express them.
In Part 4, we’ll address, and refute, McCready’s superficially plausible contention that there are bona fide sentences that are utterly meaningless, in the process of doing which we’ll find possible ways of dissolving some semantic and logical antinomies that have bedeviled foundationalist programs in mathematics.
 
 
Part 1 1.0 Is linguistic meaning a strictly psychological notion?    In Naming and Necessity, Kripke decisively showed that proper names are not definite descriptions. In doing this, Kripke was making a specific point concerning the semantics of a specific class of expressions. It might therefore seem that what Kripke was doing in NN, though non-trivial, was too narrow to be of great philosophical importance.
        But implicit in what Kripke said about proper names are many deep and important principles concerning  the very nature of meaning and the relationship between language and thought.  In 1975, Hilary Putnam published an article titled The meaning of ‘meaning’ (henceforth, ‘MM’) in which he explicitly stated one of these principles and cogently argued for it. What he showed is that what we think does not, by itself, establish what our words and sentences mean.
       It’s obvious that what we think  largely determines what it is that our expressions mean. The word ‘snow’ could refer to anything; it would be easy to create a language in which it referred, not to so snow, but Julius Caesar. (Let’s create such a language right now. Let L be a language that is just like English except that, in L, ‘snow’  refers to Julius Caesar. L is a perfectly good language – it’s as good as a language as English.) It’s obviously at least partly because of what some people were thinking at certain times that ‘snow’ refers to snow, and not to Julius Caesar.
       But Putnam made it clear that there is an important non-psychological dimension to linguistic meaning. Given only that, any given moment,  person X is psychologically and behaviorally indistinguishable from person Y, it does not follow that the words leaving X’s mouth have the same meanings as the words leaving Y’s mouth.  So, supposing that at any given moment  X is having a given thought if and only if Y is having an exactly similar thought or feeling, and that X is producing a given utterance if and only if Y is producing an exactly similar utterance, it does not follow that what is meant by X’s utterance coincides with what is meant by Y’s. Even though the psychological state that gave rise to the one utterance is just like the psychological state that gave rise to the other, the meaning of the one may diverge from that of the other.
 
1.1 Putnam’s argument  Let Twin-Earth be a planet in some distant galaxy that satisfies the following conditions. Given any person x on Earth, there is a person y in W who is an atom-for-atom duplicate of x. At any given moment, y has a given thought if and only if x has that thought; y has a given feeling if and only if x has that very feeling. y acts a certain way if and only if x acts in an exactly similar way; y makes a certain  noise if and only if x makes an exactly similar noise. Thus, Earth people are psychologically and behaviorally exactly like Twin-Earth people.  They think, feel, do, and say the very same things at the very same times.
     It is merely coincidence that Earth people are in lock-step with Twin-Earth people. There is no causal interaction between Earth-people and Twin-Earth people. No messages are sent from the one planet to the other; nobody on either planet in any way influences anyone on the other.
       Even though Earth and Twin-Earth are extremely similar, there is an important difference between them. On Twin-Earth, the liquid in bathtubs, drinking-glasses, lakes, etc. isn’t H20 – it’s XYZ. (‘XYZ’ is an abbreviation for some long chemical formula.) With that qualification, W is, at any given moment, exactly like Earth.
        Let’s continue our story. Smith is a psychologically normal, English speaking, adult Earthling who lives in the 1600’s.     One day, after doing back-breaking work for several hours, Smith is desperately wants to drink some cool water. Addressing his companion, Smith says:
 
[320]
	(SE) ‘When people are thirsty, they find it more refreshing to drink cool, glacial water than warm, swamp-water; if there were no clean water, people couldn’t survive .’
 
     This utterance takes place at time t.
      Important point: SE doesn’t refer to a sentence. It refers to a specific utterance of a sentence. It refers to the specific burst of noise produced by Smith at time t. (Different people can utter a given sentence; different people can utter the sentence uttered by Smith (viz. ‘when people are thirst, they find it more refreshing to drink cool, glacial water than…’)
       Bear in mind here that, in Smith’s time, nothing was known about the chemical composition of water. People obviously had thoughts about water; they wanted to drink it; bathe in it, and so on. But they didn’t know that it was H2O; they didn’t even grasp the concepts needed to grasp the concept of an H2O-molecule.
     On Twin-Earth, there is somebody who, at any given moment, is psychologically and behaviorally just like Smith.  (This follows from what we said earlier.) Let Twin-Smith be that person. At any given time, TwinSmith makes the very noises as Smith and, in so doing, expresses the very sentiments.  (This too follows from our earlier points.) Thus, at time t, TwinSmith says:
 
[321]
	(TS) ‘When people are thirsty, they find it more refreshing to drink cool, glacial water than warm, swamp-water; if there were no clean water, people couldn’t survive.’
 
Important point: TS doesn’t refer to a sentence. It refers to a specific utterance of a sentence -- to the specific burst of noise produced by TwinSmith at time t.
        Question: Does SE have the same meaning as TS? I am not asking whether Smith and Twin-Smith coincide in respect of what they mean by their respective utterances, but whether SE and TS coincide in respect of what they mean. The question doesn’t concern what Smith and Twin-Smith are  trying to convey through their respective utterances; it concerns what
[322]
those utterances themselves mean.
        SE and TS don’t have the same meaning.  They have different propositions for their respective meanings, and the one proposition is true in circumstances where the other is false, and false in circumstances where the other is true.
        ‘Water’ refers to the substance whose chemical composition is H2O. That’s a simple fact. A thoroughly competent speaker of English can easily fail to know that ‘water’ refers that substance. Newton didn’t know it, even though he was an exceptionally intelligent person who spoke perfect English.  But that doesn’t matter. Here on earth, there is a certain liquid x such that x is found in bathtubs, drinking glasses, lakes and oceans, and such that that is referred to as ‘water.’ That substance was referred to as ‘water’ for many hundreds of years before anything was known about chemistry or, in particular, about the chemical composition of that substance. When, finally, that substance was analyzed, it turned out to consist of H2O molecules. Thus,
 
(WAT1) there is some substance x such that x is found in bathtubs, drinking glasses, lakes and oceans, and such that x consists of H2O molecules, and such that: ‘water’ refers to x.
 
Of course, we now know that the substance referred to as ‘water’ is H2O. And if we were to discover some substance  that consisted of XYZ, not H2O, but was otherwise just like water, at least as far as the conditions that are likely on the surface of the Earth are concerned, that other substance wouldn’t be H2O.  The chemists who discovered XYZ would not come conclusion that water is sometimes H2O and is sometimes XYZ. No – they’d say that water is always H2O, but that a different substance, namely, XYZ is extremely water-like, at least within certain horizons.
     When they weren’t referring to XYZ by its chemical name, chemists would not refer to it as ‘water.’ Maybe they’d refer to it pseudo-water’ or as ‘fool’s water’ – but not ‘water.’  This practice of theirs wouldn’t be a case of hair-splitting pedantry. If chemists did refer to this other substance as ‘water’, their doing so would violate beliefs that are deeply embedded in commonsense. Even the most philistine, intellectually narrow human being desperately wants real diamonds, not Zirconium imitation-diamonds, and thus knows that being diamond-like isn’t the same thing as being a diamond. Similarly, everybody knows that being water-like isn’t the same thing as being real water. And even if some people don’t know it, they’d quickly learn it, no matter how scientifically uninformed they were, if the distinction between water and XYZ became a financially significant one, like the distinction between diamonds and chunks of zirconium paste resemble diamonds.
    For the same reasons mutatis mutandis, on Twin-Earth ‘water’ would refer to XYZ, not H2O. And it would always have referred to XYZ – even before scientists on their planet discovered its chemical composition.
      Before proceeding, let’s deal with an objection that is likely to be heard:
 
       An English-speaking  physical chemist obviously knows a lot about water that other English-speakers don’t. But what the physical chemist that other English speakers don’t has nothing to do with the English language or, therefore, with semantics. Given only that somebody doesn’t have a PhD in physical chemistry, it doesn’t  follow that they have any linguistic deficits – that they don’t really know the identities of the semantic rules governing expressions like ‘water’, ‘gold’, ‘lead’, etc. This is all quite uncontroversial.
       But it’s inconsistent the view you’re advocating. You say that, for something to be water, it isn’t enough that it have certain macrocharacteristics: it must have specific chemical composition – it must be H2O. Given that, as a matter of semantics, ‘water’ refers to water, what you’re saying entails that, as a matter of semantics, ‘water’ refers to H2O. But if that were right, one couldn’t master the English without knowing the chemical composition of water or, by obvious extensions of this argument, the chemical composition of gold, aluminum. But that’s preposterous. 
 
      One doesn’t have to know anything about chemistry to have a complete mastery of English (or any other natural language), and it would be preposterous to deny that. But the view I’m describing doesn’t have that consequence. There is some individual x such that the semantic rule for the expression ‘Barack Obama’ is to the effect that:
 
(BO)  ‘Barack Obama’ refers to x.
 
BO pairs off a name with an individual. If one doesn’t know which individual that is, then one doesn’t know the semantic rule for ‘Barack Obama’ and, therefore, one doesn’t know all of the semantic rules constitutive of the English language in 2009.
    But given any entity, there are many ways of knowing which thing it is. There are infinitely many ways of singling out any given entity. This is a consequence of the fact that, as a matter of logic, any given object satisfies each of infinitely many different descriptions. Let P be the region of space you were occupying the instant you began reading this sentence, and let t be that instant. You uniquely satisfy each of the following predicates: ‘thing that occupied p one minute before time t+one minute’, ‘thing that occupied p two minutes before time t+two minutes’,  and so on. We’ll henceforth abbreviate the first of these predicates as ‘P1’, the second as ‘P2’, etc. 
         For argument’s sake, let’s suppose that your name is ‘Jack Jones.’ There is some x such that x uniquely satisfies each of P1, P2, P3, etc.  and such that, in order to the know semantic rule governing that expression, one must know that:
 
(JJ)  ‘Jack Jones’ refers to x.
 
If Smith knows that:
 
(JJ75) there is some x such that x uniquely satisfies P75 and such that:  ‘Jack Jones’ refers to x
 
and Jones knows that:
 
(JJ143) there is some x such that x uniquely satisfies P143 and such that: ‘Jack Jones’ refers to x,
 
Smith and Jones are to that extent in complete semantic accord.  There is some one x such that x satisfies each of P75 and P143, and such that, given any property psi, when Smith says
 
(JJ1) ‘Jack Jones has psi’
 
he is affirming that
 
(JJ2) x has psi,
 
and such that  when Jones utters JJ1, he too is affirming that x has psi. Further, it is each individual’s intention in uttering JJ1 to affirm JJ2. Each wishes to do is to attribute psi to some person  – nothing more. Neither wants to say anything about his way of thinking about that person. Neither wishes to say of P75 or P143 or any other property that it is uniquely instantiated or that all its instances are psi’s.  
         Points exactly similar to those just made about ‘Jack Jones’ hold with respect to ‘water.’ At time t, bathtub B is filled with pure water, on which your rubber ducky is floating. Your mother points to that B and says:
 
(*) The liquid in the tub is known as ‘water.’
 
A few days later, at time t*, you burn your finger in scalding water. Given that water is H2O, it follows that each of the following statements is true:
 
(1) there is some liquid x such that, at time t, x is what your rubber ducky is floating on; moreover, ‘water’ refers to x. (2) there is some liquid x such that, at time t, x is what your bathtub is full of;  moreover, ‘water’ refers to x.
(3) there is some liquid x such that  x and x alone is H2O, and such that
‘water’ refers to x

	* there is some liquid x such that  x and x alone is H2O, and such that‘water’ refers to x.

	* there is some liquid x such that , at time t, x and x alone is what scaldedyour finger; moreover, ‘water’ refers to x.

	* there is some liquid x such that x and x alone is H2O and such that, attime t, x and x alone is what scalded your finger; moreover, ‘water’ refers to x.
 
And so on.
      To know what ‘water’ refers to, it is necessary only that you know some truth of the form:
 
(n)  there is some substance x such that x uniquely has property phi; ‘water’ refers to x.
 
      Since water uniquely has each of infinitely many different properties, (n) is true for each of infinitely many values of phi. Where any given one of these truths is concerned, knowing it is sufficient, but not necessary, for knowing what ‘water’ refers to and, therefore, for knowing the semantics of that expression. 
       Since (n) is a sentence-schema, not a sentence proper, it does not itself express any one of these truths. But  in what follows, take (n) to stand for an arbitrary one of them.
     Only the underlined part of n describes a semantic rule. The rest describes the information through which one grasps that rule. Anyone who knows the semantics of water knows this (though they might recognize what it is that they know in the statements just made).
      Let’s tell another story about Smith and Jones. Both are competent speakers of English. Smith knows that:
 

	* there is some liquid x such that x is what is in bathtubs and drinkingglasses; moreover, ‘water’ refers to x.
 
Jones, who is more scientifically minded than Smith, knows that:
 

	* there is some liquid x such that x is H2O and such that creatures with gillscan breathe when immersed in x and creatures with lungs cannot; moreover, ‘water’ refers to x.
 
There is some liquid x such that individual’s sole intention in saying
 
(w2) ‘water covers most of the Earth’s surface’
 
is to say:
 
(w3) x covers most of the Earth’s surface.
 
Neither wishes to affirm either that
 
(w4) there is some liquid x such that x is what is in bathtubs and drinkingglasses, and such that ‘water’ refers to x; moreover, x covers most of the Earth’s surface,
 
or that
 
(w5) there is some liquid x such that  x is H2O and such that creatures with gills can breathe when immersed in x and creatures with lungs cannot; moreover, x covers most of the Earth’s surface.
 
 Each individual’s intention in uttering w2 is to ascribe a certain property to a certain substance. They have the same substance in mind. They wish to attribute the same property to it.  Neither wants to say anything about how he thinks about that substance. Neither wants to attribute any property to anything other than that substance. Thus, what Smith means  when he says ‘water covers most of the Earth’s surface’ is exactly what Jones means when he utters the same sentence. And so long as each knows that the other agrees with him about what it is ‘water’ that refers to, any difference between them in respect of how they think about its referent will in no way jeopardize the one person’s ability to understand the other.  To put it more formally: provided that, for some x, each believes that ‘water’ refers to x and each knows that the other believes this, the differences between these to individuals in respect of how they think about this substance won’t jeopardize their ability to communicate with each other.
 
1.2 Putnam’s semantic externalism (continued)  These points make it clear why it is that Smith and Twin-Smith, though driven to make the very same noises by the very same internal conditions, are nonetheless affirming different propositions. Let’s suppose that when Smith was a child, his mother pointed to the  liquid in the tub in which Smith regularly bathed, which Smith recognized as the liquid that he had to drink in order to live, and said: ‘That is water.’ The message that is communicated to Smith is along the lines of:
 
(8) There is some liquid x such that x is what I bathe in and must also drink in order to survive and ‘water’ refers to x.
 
Given that liquid indicated by Smith’s mother is, of its very nature, H2O, it follows that when, at time t, Smith utters SE, his utterance is true exactly if:
 
(SE*) ‘When people are thirsty, they find it more refreshing to drink cool, glacial H2O than warm, swamp-H2O; and if there were no clean H2O, people couldn’t survive
 
      Because he lives hundreds of years before the birth of modern chemistry known, Smith has no idea what it would even mean  to identify water with H2O. Moreover, nobody who is alive at the time has any such idea.
Nonetheless, the statement he is making does concern H2O. This shows that:
 
(PTM) the meanings borne by our utterances are not determined solely by the thoughts we have; there is a strictly non-psychological, strictly environmental dimension to linguistic meaning.
 
      Given what we know about Twin-Smith and Twin-Earth, it follows that, when Twin-Smith utters TS, what is saying is true exactly if:
 
(TS*) ‘When people are thirsty, they find it more refreshing to drink cool, glacial XYZ than warm, swamp-water; if there were no clean XYZ, people couldn’t survive.’
