   And this is obviously consistent with PTM.
    The doctrine that PTM is true known as semantic externalism. It is socalled because, according to PTM, the determinants of the semantics of our expressions are (in some cases, in some respects) external to us.
  
2.0 Burge’s blunder – the (mis)step from semantic to content externalism
 
      PTM is a deep, important, and original insight, and deserves sole credit for it. And unlike many of the philosophers who were influenced by his important article, Putnam’s views as to what PTM does and does not imply were correct. In MM, Putnam says that Smith’s words don’t have quite the same meanings as Twin-Smith’s words, even though Smith and Twin-Smith have the same thoughts.
[323]
	     Under pressure from other philosophers, especially Tyler Burge,
Putnam later rejected this correct and profound insight, and he came to accept Burge’s position, which is that, not only do Smith’s words have different meanings from Twin-Smith’s, Smith’s thoughts don’t have the same contents as Twin-Smith’s.
    Burge’s work has been enormously influential. It didn’t just influence Putnam, but  analytic philosophy as a whole. Thanks largely to Burge’s work, it came to be widely held  for twenty years or so that Smith and Twin-Smith have different thoughts. This must be understood aright. Nobody denies that Smith and Twin-Smith have numerically different thoughts. Burge is making the much less innocuous claim that what Smith is thinking is different from what Twin-Smith is thinking. In Burge’s view, just my thought that it’s hot during the summer has a different content from your thought that it’s cold during the winter, so, according to Burge, the thought that Smith expresses in saying, for property psi, ‘water has psi’ is different from the thought that Twin-Smith expresses by means of that same utterance.
     This interesting chapter in the history of analytic philosophy began in 1979, four years after Putnam published MM, with the publication of 
[324] 	Burge’s article  ‘Individualism and the mental’ (henceforth, ‘BI’). Here is what Burge argues. There is a planet, which we’ll call ‘Twin-Earth’, that is exactly like Earth, with one qualification to be stated in a moment. The events on Twin-Earth are in lockstep with those on Earth. So given that earthling Smith sneezes at a certain time, Twin-earthling Twin-Smith sneezes in the exact same way at the exact same time.
     Given what we’ve said, it follows that English is spoken by many people on Twin-Earth. Twin-Smith is one of these people. On our planet – on Earth, in other words -- ‘arthritis’ refers to a disease exclusively of the joints. On Twin-Earth, ‘arthritis’ refers to a malady not only of the joints, but also of certain bones (as opposed to the cartilaginous joints linking bones to one another). So, on Twin-Earth, ‘arthritis’ doesn’t refer to the same disease that it refers to on Earth. It refers to a similar, but distinct ailment. Let us refer to that ailment as ‘twin-arthritis.’
      On Earth, Smith regards the sentence:
 
[325]
	(AU) ‘arthritis is unpleasant’
 
as expressing a truth. And because he personally suffers from arthritis, he often utters AU. (In this context, it is to be assumed that Smith is speaking sincerely, is cognitively competent, etc., and these same assumptions are to be made about Twin-Smith).
      Like Smith, Twin-Smith regards AU as expressing a truth. But, according to Burge,  the thought underlying Twin-Smith’s utterance of AU is different from the thought underlying Smith’s utterance of it. Twin-Smith is thinking about twin-arthritis, not arthritis, and Smith is thinking about arthritis, not twin-arthritis. In a moment, we’ll evaluate this important claim.       Burge concludes from this that two people who are atom-for-atom duplicates of each other, each a perfect physiological and psychological clone of the other, may have thoughts with different contents. Twin-Smith is thinking Descartes (or Twin-Descartes, rather) was a great philosopher, whereas Smith is thinking Ted Danson is a great philosopher, notwithstanding that Smith and Twin-Smith are, by Burge’s hypothesis, psychologically exactly the same.
         Is Burge right? First of all, he’s right that, on Twin-Earth, ‘arthritis’ does not refer to arthritis, and instead refers to Twin-arthritis. This is precisely what Putnam showed. But is Burge right that Smith and TwinSmith are cognitively different?
         No. How does Smith learn what ‘arthritis’ refers to? Here’s a possible answer (and it’s representative, in the relevant respects, of all the other possible answers). Addressing Smith, so and so says:
 
(A1) ‘the unpleasant inflammation in your knees is due to arthritis; arthritis can do terrible damage to one’s joints.’
 
A1 is to the effect that:
 
(A2) there is some x such that the swelling in your knees is due to x and such that x can do terrible damage to one’s joints; moreover, ‘arthritis’ refers to x.
 
For now familiar reasons, it follows that when Smith hears someone say:
 
(A3) ‘arthritis has psi’,
 
the message that is communicated (not literally meant) is:
 
(A4) There is some x such that the swelling in your knees is due to x, such that x can do terrible damage to one’s joints, and such that ‘arthritis’ refers to x; moreover, ‘arthritis’ refers to x.
 
Remember that Twin-Smith’s life precisely parallels Smith’s. It therefore follows that, when Twin-Smith hears someone utter (A3), (A4) is the message that is communicated (not literally meant) is (A4).
      Thus, contrary to what Burge says, Smith’s thoughts do have the same content as Twin-Smith’s. It’s true that, for the reasons given by Putnam, the sentences they use to express those thoughts don’t always have the same literal meanings. But unless one countenances the obvious false assumption that what we think coincides exactly with what our expressions mean, it doesn’t follow that Smith’s thoughts have the same contents as TwinSmith’s.
 
2.1 Literal meaning vs. cognitive content  An utterance on Earth of ‘arthritis is painful’ does have a different literal meaning from such an utterance on Twin-Earth. There is some malady x, namely arthritis, such that x only afflicts the joints, such that an utterance on Earth of
 
(A5) ‘arthritis is painful’
 
is true just in case:
 
(A6) x is painful,
 
it being irrelevant whether some disease that afflicts things other than the joints is also painful. And there is some y, namely twin-arthritis, such that  y does not afflict only the joints and such that an utterance on Twin-Earth of
 
(A5) ‘arthritis is painful’
 
is true just in case:
 
(A6) y is painful,
 
it being irrelevant whether some disease that afflicts only the joints is also painful.
        But, contrary to what Burge assumes, this doesn’t mean that
 
[326]
2.2 A second Burge-style argument	  Let W1 be the actual world and let W2 be some other possible world. In each of W1 and W2, my friend Max has an identical twin Gary. Gary and Max are cosmetically, physiologically, and behaviorally completely and totally indistinguishable. To know that one is seeing Max as opposed to Gary, or vice versa, one has to rely on ulterior knowledge (e.g. that Gary is now in Finland and that he couldn’t possibly be the person with whom one is now lunching in New York).
      In W1, at time t, my friend Sally and I are ten feet away from Max, and
I’m looking right at him. But in W2, at time t,  Sally are ten feet away from Max’s identical twin, Gary.  Otherwise, W1 at t and W2 at t are indistinguishable (at least at time t). Given only the information available to me by virtue of having the perception involved in my seeing Max, it is not a even a theoretical possibility that I might encounter some evidence or have some experience on the basis of which I could rationally conclude I was in the one world as opposed to the other.
      Moreover,  the experiences that I have in W1 had up until time t have been qualitatively identical with those that I’ve had in W2 up until time t. So neither my current experiences nor my memories nor the two combined could possibly enable me  to determine whether I’m in the one world as opposed to the other.
      It is to be assumed in what follows that all my utterances are sincere – they express beliefs that I actually have.        In W1, while pointing at Max, I tell Sally:
 
[327]
	(U1) ‘That entity is wearing a plaid shirt.’
 
(In due course, it’ll be clear why I’m using the word ‘entity’, as opposed to individual.) In W2, while pointing at Gary, I tell Sally:
 
(U2) ‘That entity is wearing a plaid shirt.’
 
   U1 and U2 are specific utterances. So U1 is an utterance that occurs in Max’s presence in W1,  and U2 is an utterance that occurs in Gary’s presence in W2. In each world, I know that I’m seeing either Gary or Max, but in neither world do I know which of the two I’m seeing.
      In W1, there is some individual x, namely x, such that such x¹Gary and such that U1 is true exactly if:
 
[328]
	(MP) x is wearing a plaid-shirt.
 
In W2, there is some other individual y, namely Gary, such y¹Max and such that U2 is true exactly if:
 
(GP) y is wearing a plaid-shirt.
 
 MP is true just in case Max is wearing a plaid-shirt, it being irrelevant whether Gary is wearing one. And GP is true just in case Gary is wearing a plaid-shirt, it being irrelevant whether Max is wearing one. Neither entails the other; neither entails the negation of the other. MP and GP are different propositions.
        U1 expresses what I’m thinking in W1, and U2 expresses what I’m thinking U2. U1’s truth-conditions coincide of the thought I’m having in W1, and are therefore given by MP; and U2’s truth-conditions coincide of the thought I’m having in W2 and are therefore given by GP. Thus, the belief expressed by U1 has a different content from the belief expressed by U2.         Of course, in W1, my  visual experience results from light bouncing off
Max, not Gary; and in W2, it results from light bouncing off of Gary, not Max. But apart from that, there is absolutely nothing that at that time distinguishes my situation in the one world at time t from my situation in the other world . My intracranial situation in W1 is just like your intracranial situation in W2.
        But we just saw that the content of what I’m thinking in W1 at t is different from the content of what I’m thinking in W2. This difference must derive from the fact that, in W1, my  mental state has a certain external cause (light bouncing off of Max), whereas in W2 it has a different external cause (light bouncing off of Gary).
 
2.3 Burge’s failure to distinguish what we know directly from perception from what we infer from perception  
 
     The conclusion of this argument is false, and there is thus something wrong with the argument itself. The problem with it is that it assumes that the relationship between linguistic meaning and cognitive content is much tighter than it actually is.
       Let’s suppose the following. I’m in some world W3 (not identical with W1 or with W2). I’m with my friend Sally.  I get her ten dollars that, sometime this day, we’d see somebody wearing a plaid shirt. She doesn’t know, or know of, Max or Gary.  W3 is exactly like each of W1 and W2 except that, in W3, the thing standing in front of me isn’t Max or Gary: it’s a robot that looks exactly like both of them. I don’t (yet) know that such a robots exists. I’m friends with Max and Gary. I happen to know that Gary is out of the country. I also know that Max is somewhere in the vicinity. So, given that I’m looking at something that looks exactly like Max, I believe that I am seeing Max. I’m with my friend Sally. I see that that the thing I’m beholding is wearing a plaid shirt, and I say:
 
(U3) ‘That entity is wearing a plaid shirt.’
 
[329]
	      Let VR be the visual perception that in which my seeing this thing consists. VR is utterly high-resolution and veridical. I’m seeing the thing before me, whatever it is, as it is. Given that this thing looks exactly like Max and Gary, my seeing it as it is involves my having a perception exactly like the one that I’d have in that very situation if ceteris paribus, it was Max or Gary I was seeing.
       Thus, VR does not itself tell me who it is that I’m seeing. Given only what VR tells me, that thing could be Max or Gary or some third person (or thing) . VR does tell me  that I’m seeing somebody with such and such characteristics, among them that of wearing a plaid shirt.
       I’m wrong about who that entity is. But that doesn’t affect the belief I’m trying to get across.  I don’t care who or what that entity is, and neither does Sally. All we care about is whether it’s wearing a plaid-shirt. I correctly believe that it is wearing a plaid shirt, and that’s the belief I’m trying to get across by uttering U3. Therefore, the belief embodied in U3 is correct.        This has two very important consequences, each of which is incompatible with Burge’s position.
       Consequence #1: There is no particular x such that VR tells me that it’s x I am seeing. This follows from the fact, just noted, that VR does not itself apprise me of the identity of the thing  I’m seeing.
      Consequence #2: There is no particular x such that the belief embodied in U3 is correctly only if x is plaid shirt. This follows from the fact, earlier noted, that the belief embodied in U3 is correct as long as the thing we’re seeing is wearing a plaid shirt, it being irrelevant who or what thing is.        It is a fact that Max is the person I’m seeing -- that he’s the object of VR (or one of them). But given only what VR is telling me, I could be seeing any number of different individuals. What VR tells me is that there is somebody having such and such characteristics – that there is somebody standing in a certain place  and wearing a plaid shirt. So the content of VR is existential. It tells me that:
 
[330]
	(CVR)  There is some entity x such that x has such and such characteristics, such that x is standing is in a certain place  and such that x is wearing a plaid shirt.
 
      Obviously, CVR is at least one of the things that, on the basis of VR, I believe to be true. And it’s the relevant belief in this context, since it’s the one embodied in U3. 
        Supposing that VM is the perception I’m having in U1 of Max, and that VG  is the perception I’m having in U2 of Gary, it follows that the belief embodied in U3 has the very same content as the belief embodied in U1 as well as the belief embodied in U2.  Remember that, from an experiential standpoint, no two of these situations are distinguishable, even in principle.
      Let’s state as clearly and explicitly as possible how Burge goes wrong. Burge says that what VR is telling me is different from what VM is telling me and also from what VG is telling me. Burge thinks that there is some x, namely a certain robot, such that VR is correct just in case:
 
(bx) x is wearing a plaid shirt.
 
And Burge thinks that there is some y, namely Gary, such that VG is correct just in case:
 
(by) y is wearing a plaid shirt.
 
Finally, Burge thinks that there is some z, namely Max such that VM is correct just in case:
 
(bz) z is wearing a plaid shirt.
 
Of course, none of these three propositions is equivalent with other; none so much as entails either of the others. So if Burge is right, then the proposition encoded in my visual perception in W3 is different from my visual perceptions in W1 and W2, and the propositions encoded in the latter two perceptions are different from each other.
       But Burge is not right. Given only what VR is telling me – in other words, given only what I know on the basis of VR without the help of preexisting, background knowledge derived from some source other than VR – I can’t possibly know that I’m seeing robot x as opposed to person y as opposed to person z as opposed to Martian w. the content of my perception on W3 is, quite obviously, neutral with respect to the identity of the object of that perception, and its content is therefore, in that respect, general and, more specifically, is given by CVR.
     Russell (1927) makes this point very clearly.
 
      “Prejudice tells you that you see the same [Russell’s emphasis] table on two different occasions; you think that experience tells you this. If it really were experience, you could not be mistaken; yet a similar table may be substituted without altering the experience…there is nothing to
[331]
show that one identical entity causes the two sensations.” 
 
 
        The message embodied in VR goes through regardless of who it is that I am seeing to be wearing a plaid shirt. That identity-independent message  is embodied in the belief underlying in my utterance of ‘that guy is wearing a plaid shirt’, and it’s embodied in that utterance. Therefore, Burge is simply wrong to identify the content of that belief with bx. For exactly similar reasons,  Burge is just plain wrong to identify bx with what VM tells my and with the belief embodied in U1, and he’s just plain wrong g to identify by with what VG tells my and with the belief embodied in U1.
      Of course, there are differences between those situations. In one of them, it’s Max who’s standing in front of me; in the second, it’s Gary; in the third it’s a robot. But these differences don’t lead to any experiential differences, since those three things all look exactly the same. In none of these worlds can the content of my visual perception, taken by itself, register that it’s Max, Gary, or some third thing that’s in front of me.  Given that CVR is the content of my visual perception in W3, it follows that CVR is also the content of my perception in U1 and also of my perception in U2.  (The content of my visual perception in the one world coincides with the content of my visual perception in each other.) Given that, in W3, it’s my belief that CVR is true that leads me to utter U3, it follows that it is that same belief that prompts to utter U1 and also U2.
 
2.4 Burge’s failure to distinguish literal meaning from cognitive content U3 does indeed have  different truth-conditions from each of U1 and U2. But it doesn’t follow that the thought underlying my producing U3 is different from either of the thoughts that prompted my producing those other two utterances.
        Not only does it not follow: it isn’t true. What VR is telling me, and what I believe strictly on the basis of it, is CVR. It’s true that I have other beliefs. I believe (incorrectly) that it’s Max I’m seeing. But that belief is a derivative of my belief that CVR is true. And the belief that prompts to utter U3 – the belief I’m expressing – is true, no matter who or what the plaid-shirt wearer turns out to be.
        An extension of our story about W3 makes this clear. In plain view of Sally and myself, this entity takes its face-plate off, revealing a complex web of circuitry, as opposed to various organic tissues.   I now know that it’s a robot,  and, given my pre-existing knowledge that Max isn’t a robot, that it therefore isn’t  Max.  Now that I know that it was a robot that I was seeing, am I to conclude that I the belief embodied in U3 is wrong? No. If I look at what is in fact a green car and say ‘that car is green’, what I’m saying is correct and the belief embodied in that utterance is correct, even I also happen to have the false belief the car belongs to Smith when, in fact, it belongs to Jones. For exactly similar reasons, the belief embodied in U3 is correct.
       Nor am I conclude that VR wasn’t veridical. VR was high-resolution and veridical. The problem had to do with the fact that, in having VR, the thing I was accurately seeing,  though not identical with Max, looked just like him, and with the consequent fact that, on the basis of my correct belief in CVR, I erroneously assumed that it was Max I was seeing.
     
2.4.1 Burge’s failure to distinguish literal meaning from cognitive content (continued) Let us now develop what we said earlier about my situation in W2.  This will clarify and substantiate the points just made.        Remember that, in W2, I’m looking at somebody who looks just like
Gary because it really is Gary, and I also correctly believe that thing to be Gary. I have pre-existing knowledge to the effect that Max, Gary’s identical twin,  is in another country and also to the effect that, apart from Gary himself, no person and no thing other than Gary looks just like him. Thanks to this knowledge, along with the information encoded in my current perception, I know that Max is the person who you’re seeing.
        Let VG be that perception. Further, let’s continue to suppose that, from an experiential standpoint, VG is completely indistinguishable from the perception that prompted me to utter U1 and also from the perception that prompted me to utter U2. Finally, let’s suppose that VG is the perception that prompts me to utter U2.
            Given these suppositions, it follows that from a purely experiential standpoint VG is completely indistinguishable from VM and also from VR. It also follows that the belief embodied in U2 is identical with the belief embodied in U1 and also in U3. U1-U3 all express the same belief. So CVR is the belief embodied in each of these three utterances.
             Although I know that it’s Gary I’m seeing,  VG itself obviously doesn’t tell me this.  Nor does it tell me that, apart from Max, nothing in the universe looks just like Gary. These things were learned independently of VG. My knowledge of them is background knowledge.
           Thus, there is no individual x such that x is identical with Larry and such that by itself VG tells me that it’s x specifically that I’m seeing.  I do indeed know who I’m seeing. But it’s VG plus my background knowledge that gives this information, not VG by itself. Given only what VG is telling me, I could be seeing Gary or Max or some third thing, and the correctness of what I believe strictly on the basis of VG doesn’t depend on who (or what) it is that I’m seeing. 
 
3.0 The gappiness of Burge-thoughts The wrongness of Burge’s position becomes painfully clear when we register it’s most immediate consequences. Of those consequences, here’s the one I find most striking. Given two people who are psychologically identical, one of them may be having all sorts of thoughts while the other is a zombie – a mental blank who is no more having
[332]
thoughts than a tomato.
      Remember that,  in W1, there is some individual x such that x=Max and such that U1(my utterance of ‘that guy is wearing a plaid shirt’) is true exactly if:
 
[333]
	(MP) x is wearing a plaid-shirt.
 
This is true. Notice that it’s a claim about  language, about literal meaning – about what is literally meant by an utterance. It isn’t, at least not directly, a claim about the content of my visual perceptions or my thoughts.
   But Burge holds that, indeed, positions exactly similar to the one just stated about that utterance hold with respect to my perceptions and thoughts. Burge’s holds that, in W1, there is some individual x such that x=Max and such that the content of  VM (the visual perception I’m having) is true exactly if
 
[334]
	(MP) x is wearing a plaid-shirt
 
Burge also  holds that, in W1, there is some individual x such that x=Max and such that the content of  what I believe on the basis of my visual perception is true exactly if MP.
         This last claim has a very interesting corollary, as a short a extension of our comments about worlds W1-W3 makes clear.  Let W4 be a world that, with one qualification,  is like each of W1-W3  The qualification is that, at the time in question, Sally and I are hallucinating. In other words, I’m not really seeing a man who is wearing a plaid shirt; there’s only empty space in the place where, so I believe, I ‘see’ there to be such a person, and Sally isn’t having any such perception either. But I am having a hallucination that is phenomenologically (experientially) just like VM (and, therefore, VR and VG). We’ll refer to that hallucination as ‘VH’(short for ‘visual hallucination’).  And, prompted by that hallucination, I say:
 
(U4)  ‘That entity is wearing a plaid shirt.’
 
If U4 were correct, it would be because, in the place in question (the one at which I’m pointing) there was some individual w, such that w was wearing a plaid-shirt; and the proposition that U4, if it were correct, would encode would be:
 
(bw) w is wearing a plaid shirt.
 
But U4 is not correct. It’s not true or false. It’s abortive. If I point to a nonexistent gnome on my bed, and I say
 
(G1) ‘that gnome weights 8 lbs’,
 
 my utterance presupposes that here is such a gnome, and since that presupposition is false, m statement is neither true nor false; it’s abortive. If I pointed to the bed and said
 
(G2)  ‘there is a gnome on my bed, and that gnome weights 8 lbs’,
 
that statement would be false. (G1 and G2 are supposed to be utterances of
[335] sentences, not sentences per se – sentence-tokens, not sentence-types.) But G2 is very different from G1 that’s a very different statement from the first one. U4 is abortive for the same reason. It is neither true nor false. And it therefore encodes no proposition.  Anything that is true or false is ipso facto a proposition, and any proposition is ipso facto true or false. So U4 fails to encode a proposition.
        Burge rightly believes that U4 fails to encode a proposition. But he believes – partly on the basis, it seems – that VH has no content. In other words, he believes that VH isn’t giving me any message – or, at least, that it’s not giving me any complete message. The message it’s giving me, thinks Burge, has a ‘gap’ in it. That message, Burge thinks, is like – nay, it is – the message encoded in U4. And that message is not complete (as Burge rightly believes), as it has a gap in it, thus having the form:
 
(b_) __is wearing a plaid-shirt.
 
The underlining (the ___) is meant to denote a gap or blank of some kind.       Burge also thinks that the though I’m having on the basis of VH has a blank in it – that it’s like b__In Burge’s view that thought (or non-thought, or whatever ) is identical with b__
      So, if we accept Burge’s theory, I’m not really thinking anything in U4 – at least not to the extent that what am (or would be) thinking depends on  my visual experience of the place in question.
      Burge’s position is preposterous. It’s obvious that VH gives me complete message. It tells me that there is an individual in a certain place wearing a plaid shirt (etc.). That message is false, of course. But a precondition for being a false message is being a complete message.
      ___is wearing a plaid shirt isn’t true or false. The expression ‘__is wearing a plaid shirt’ (or just ‘is wearing a plaid shirt’) isn’t true or false. It’s just a predicate. It’s no more true or false than ‘north of’ or ‘lemon grass.’ And the meaning of that predicate (which we may represent as: ___is wearing a plaid shirt isn’t true or false) isn’t true or false. But VH is true or false. It’s false. It tells me that there’s a plaid-shirt wearing man in a cetain place. There’s no such man in that place. So VH is wrong. It isn’t like G1. It’s a complete, wrong message. And the thought I have on the basis of it is wrong. That thought isn’t (b_). It’s
 
(CVR)  There is some entity x such that x has such and such characteristics, such that x is standing is in a certain place  and such that x is wearing a plaid shirt.
 
4.0  A corollary of Burge’s externalism: the impossibility of knowing one’s conscious thoughts any better than one knows facts about the spatially and temporally remote past  Let’s continue to think about my situation in W4. In that world, I think that I’m seeing somebody – and I’m wrong. But there’s something I’m not wrong about. In W4, if, at the time I was having VH, I were asked ‘are you having a thought and, if so, what it is?’, I’d say without any hesitation: ‘yes, I’m having a thought; I’m thinking that the fellow standing over there is wearing a plaid shirt.’ Surely my answer to the second question is right. I know what I’m thinking. What I’m thinking is wrong, since there’s no man there. But I’m right to think that I’m thinking it. 
         But Burge’s position entails the opposite. In the context in question, I’m not thinking anything. There’s a blank where, had I been in W1-W3, I would have been having a thought. A consequence is that, when you ask me ‘are you having a thought and, if so, what it is?’, I’d be wrong to say:  ‘yes, I’m having a thought; I’m thinking that the fellow standing over there is wearing a plaid shirt.’ Why would I be wrong? Two reasons. First, I wouldn’t be having a thought at all. I’d be having a would-be thought, a pseudo-thought, but not a thought. Second, since I wouldn’t be having any thought, my belief as to what specifically I was thinking would also be wrong.
           But that’s obviously false.
 
4.1 The  causal conception of conception To appreciate the depth and severity of this problem, we have to make a few points about Burge explicit.          According to Burge, in W1, the reason I’m thinking about Max, as opposed to Gary or someone else, is that I’m on the receiving end of a certain causal process that begins with Max. My current thought about Max (that he’s wearing a plaid shirt, or whatnot) resulted from a perception of him. That perception obviously resulted from light bouncing off of him. Thus, light bouncing off of him caused me to have certain experiences, that at least part of the reason why those experiences are perceptions of Max, and that also being at least part of the reasoning my the thoughts in which those perceptions eventuated were thoughts about Max, and not Gary (or whoever). So my current thought – the one embodied in U1 – concerns Max, and no one else, because it ‘tracks back’ to Max, meaning that they bear a causal relation of the kind just described.
    In Burge’s view, conception is not to be understood in causal, not in descriptive, terms. Why does he thinks this? Remember Putnam’s story about Smith and Twin-Smith. Smith’s mental contents are descriptively just like Twin-Smith’s. s identical. So far as he has a mentally encoded description that picks out H2O, it’s ‘liquid that we bathe in, drink, is found in lakes [etc.’]’, and so far as Twin-Smith has as a mentally encoded description that picks out XYZ, it coincides with Smith’s. So given that, when Smith says ‘water covers most of my planet’s surface’, he’s making a statement about H2O, not XYZ, and that Twin-Smith says the same thing, he’s making a statement about XYZ, not H2O, it can’t be because Smith’s thoughts are descriptively different from Twin-Smith’s. The only relevant difference between the two is that Smith is, whereas Twin-Smith is not, on the receiving end of a causal chain beginning with H2O, whereas, Twin-Smith is, whereas Smith is not, on the receiving end of a causal chain beginning with XYZ, not H2O. Of course, Burge believes the same thing mutatis mutandis to be true of Oscar and Twin-Oscar.
        The essence of conception isn’t description; it’s the causal back-tracking relation just described. Smith is thinking about H2O because his thoughts track back to H2O, not XYZ. Supposing that you’re right now thinking about Descartes, not Locke, that’s because you’re thoughts track back to Descartes, as opposed to Locke. I right now, am thinking about Descartes, and not
Locke, because my thoughts
      A  story makes it clear how untenable this is. Right now it’s 5:38 p.m., April 11, 2009). Let t our abbreviation for that time. Right now, at t, I’m thinking about Descartes. More specifically, I’m thinking: 
 
(D*) Descartes was a fine philosopher.
 
I must emphasize that I’m doing a very a thorough job of reflecting on what’s going on in my head right now; and, on that basis, I can say with complete confidence that  D* is among the things that I’m thinking.  Next year, historical research makes it clear that Descartes never existed – that there was no Descartes. It was all a hoax, we find out; the documents – all forgeries. According to Burge, I’m thinking about Descartes only in so far as my thoughts track back to him in the relevant way. They can’t do that if he didn’t exist. So when it’s discovered that Descartes never did exist, it turns out, not only that, at t, I wasn’t thinking D*.  But I wasn’t, if Burge is right.        If Burge is right, D* doesn’t even exist to be thought. Supposing (for a moment) that Descartes did exist, there is some x such that x=Descartes, and such that D* is correct if, and only if, x is a fine philosopher and – Burge concludes form this  -- such that, for that very reason, if x doesn’t even exist, D* doesn’t exist either. Burge thinks that Descartes is an actual constituent of the proposition – of the (supposing for the duration of this sentence that Descartes did exist and was in fact a fine philosopher) truth – that he was a fine philosopher. (I myself don’t think this. I discuss this in Chapter__, where I identify the fallacies concerning the nature of propositions that underlie this view of Burge’s.)
        So, supposing (as we were doing a moment ago) that Descartes turns out never to have existed, despite years of thought to the contrary, it will turn out, in Burge’s view, that D* doesn’t even exist to be thought. So I can’t even think that I’m thinking it – it doesn’t exist, after all.
         And that’s a pretty strange view.
         But it gets worse. Consider the various mental events and brain events (and mental and neural conditions etc.) involved in (what I thought was) my failed to attempt, at time t, to think about a certain French philosopher.  If Burge is right, it turns out, not only that I wasn’t thinking D*, but that the aforementioned neuro-mental states of affairs didn’t constitute any thought. I was shooting a cognitive blank.
 
[336]
4.1.2 	Burge’s response Burge became of aware of this problem quite some time ago. He denies that his position is inconsistent with the presumption that people know what they are consciously thinking. Let’s start with what Burge admits. Burge admits three things, which we’ll refer to ‘B1’, ‘B2’, and ‘B3’:
 
(B1) We can’t know for sure that Descartes existed. No matter what mental states I have, it’s a possibility that he didn’t.  The documents on which my belief is based could have  been forged (etc.).
      Thus, even though (so I think, and so let us assume), I do know that
Descartes existed (at least in so far as I know anything about the what happened in France centuries ago), I don’t know for sure that he did. Moreover, given only what my own mental states are,  it’s a theoretical possibility, that he never did exist.
 
(B2) For argument’s sake, suppose that, in reality, Descartes really did exist.  Let’s also suppose that I’m now thinking:
 
(D*) Descartes was a fine philosopher.
 
A consequence of Burge’s position that there existed some individual x, namely Descartes, such that D* is correct if, and only if,
 
(D1*) x was a fine philosopher
 
and such that the mental events (or structures or whatever) involved in my having thought are correct if, and only if, D1* is correct.
 
   
(B3) B2 entails that  if I were to be in the very same mental state I was in when I was thinking D*, but it happened to be the case that Descartes didn’t exist, then I would not be thinking D*. In other words D2 entails that the very mental events and brain-events that in fact constituted my thinking D1* would fail to constitute any thought. By virtue of having those mental and neural events, I’d be shooting a blank, not having a thought – I’d no more be having a bona fide thought than a tomato.
 
      B1-B3 are all correct. B1 is correct, since  I can’t know for sure that my mental states correctly represent the external world or a fortiori that inferences involved in my believing in Descartes existence are correct – inference that are made on the basis of possibly faulty perceptions of possibly faulty records concerning 17th century France. B2 is correct, since Burge’s position does entail Descartes must have existed if anyone is to think that he was a fine philosopher. And B3 is correct since Burge’s position does entail that the very mental events involved in my thinking D1* would fail to constitute my having any thought at all if, supposing that everything else were the same, Descartes had never existed.
         B1-B3  entail that:
 
(B4) If I’m now thinking that
 
(D*) Descartes was a fine philosopher,
 
I can’t know it with any more certainty than I can know that Descartes existed.
         But that’s wrong. I obviously know what I’m consciously thinking with greater certainty than I know about medieval France.
          
      I want to make it as clear as possible why  B1-B3 entail B4.  Given B2 , I can think D* only to the extent that Descartes really did exist. Burge admits this. (He has to. B2 is Burge’s whole position.)
         Given B1, I can know that he existed only to the extent that various beliefs of mine concerning the external world to be accurate – beliefs that presuppose the accuracy of many perceptions of mine and also of many historical documents (concerning France in the 17th century). Burge admits this as well.
         B3 entails that three is no experiential difference – no difference that is even theoretically detectable – between how I am when I’m actually thinking D*1 and how I am in a world where Descartes never existed but is otherwise like the world where I’m actually thinking D*1.
          B3 entails that, if I am to know that I’m thinking D*1, or anything else about Descartes, I’d jolly well be know that he existed; and I’d therefore jolly well better know that various perceptions of mine were accurate and, in addition, that various inferences of mine concerning various records of mine were also accurate.  Which means that a precondition for m thinking about Descartes is my knowing that Descartes existed Which, in its turn, means that, supposing that I’m consciously thinking about Descartes right now,  I can’t possibly know that fact with very much certain at all. I can know it only with the certainty with which I know that Descartes existed.
      But that’s false.
      Since knowing that Descartes existed obviously involves a lot of other things about the external world – it involves knowing that I was in fact reading certain books at certain terms, that certain records in fact exist and were made under certain circumstances, etc. – my knowing a huge amount about the external world is a pre-requisite to knowing that I’m thinking this or that about Descartes.
        But that’s false.
    This reasoning is easily generalized to show that, given anything x that is in the external world, my knowledge that I am consciously thinking about x is no more certain than my knowledge that x existed and, therefore, is no more certain than my knowledge of the various things on which that belief is based (which, where almost anything concerning the external world is concerned, is vast).
        But that’s false.  I know what I’m consciously thinking. Burge’s position entails otherwise.  Burge’s position is wrong.
       Burge is aware of this problem. He became aware of it around six years after he wrote ‘Individualism and the Mental.’ He and various followers of his have spent the last twenty-three years attempting to show that, even though B1-B3 are all correct, Burge’s position is completely compatible with the presumption that we know our conscious mental states better than we know about Descartes existence.
[337]
	       To those who would join Burge in this heroic quest, I must say, quoting Sponge bob square pants and : ‘Good luck with that!’
     
5.0 The consequences of Burge’s big blunder: the need to deny independently known truths about causation But there are problems with Burge’s position far worse than any thus far mentioned. To see what they are, let’s revisit the situation involving Smith and Twin-Smith – the one where, according to Burge, one of them, but not the other, believes that he has arthritis.
         By supposition, Smith and Twin-Smith are psychologically and physiologically exactly the same. Given this, it follows that the causal properties of Smith’s thoughts coincide with those of Twin-Smith’s thoughts.
This means that the suppose difference in content doesn’t make a difference. At all.  It is completely and totally inert. Although Smith’s belief in the proposition expressed by A3 (or whatever) obviously has effects (on what Smith does, etc.), and although the same is obviously true of Twin-Smith’s corresponding belief, the alleged difference between these beliefs is absolutely without any consequences. It has no consequences for anybody’s overt behavior or for anybody’s internal, psychological condition.
 
5.1  Fodor’s insight    Jerry Fodor (1987) was one of the first people to note this consequence of Burge’s view. Fodor’s argument is  (characteristically for Fodor) a brisk and incisive one.  What is it, Fodor asks, for two numerically distinct things, x and y, to be causally different, i.e. to differ in respect of their causal properties? It is for them to be such that, were they to switch places with one another but all other factors were left unchanged, the one would behave in the way in which, in actuality, the other behaves.           Here’s the idea. Suppose that x and y are two billiard balls that are atom-for-atom duplicates of each other. At time t, x collides with a green billiard ball and causes that billiard ball to move. At the same time, y collides with a red billiard ball and causes that billiard ball to move. 
        It’s clear that the effect of the one collision  are different from those of the other. In the one case, the effect is to make a green ball move; in the other, it is to make a red ball move. But this doesn’t mean that the two billiard balls differ in their causal properties. It means that a given causal property has different effects in different contexts. Suppose that I’m moderately strong. In some contexts, that will have the effect that I easily lift the barbell I’m trying to bench-press. (Such contexts include those where the barbell weighs under 100 lbs.) In other  contexts, that will have the effect that I can barely make the barbell budge. (Such contexts include those where the barbell weighs over 350 lbs.).
         But, assuming that my level of strength hasn’t changed in the intervening time-period,  the difference between a situation where I’m trying to lift 50 lbs and one where I’m trying to lift 350 lbs isn’t that my causal properties have changed; it’s that one and the same set of causal properties are sufficient for certain jobs but insufficient for others. (You can’t make a rocket out of plywood. But you can make a bird-house out of plywood. That doesn’t mean that the causal properties of ply-wood change, depending on whether they’re composing a rocket or a bird-house. It means that those causal properties, though sufficient for certain purposes (e.g. bird-house building) are insufficient for others (e.g. rocket building).
         In his landmark work, A system of Logic, John Stuart Mill made it clear that the just-described criterion of causal identity is (i) presupposed by all experimentation and (ii) is, setting aside the empirical fact that scientists rely on it, correct as a matter of logic.
        This is not to detract from Fodor’s achievement. Fodor stated that criterion more sharply and clearly than any author that I know of who preceded him. Plus, Fodor deserves credit for seeing the bearing of this principle on Burge’s views. Fodor deserves a lot of credit for a lot of positive developments in recent analytic philosophy, as we’ll soon see.
     
5.1.2 Why thoughts must have causal powers  Causality is indistinguishable from spatiotemporal existence. To spatiotemporal is to occupy some region of space-time. It makes no sense to say that x occupies a certain region of space time but has no causal properties, since occupancy is itself a causal notion. My occupying the chair I’m in is indistinguishable from my altering the conditions that other things, e.g. you, must satisfy if they are to occupy the chair. If I weren’t in the chair, then (other things being equal), you wouldn’t have to displace me to occupy the chair. Given that I am occupying the chair, you would have to displace me to occupy it yourself.
And that, though certainly possible, would be a hassle for you.
       Given that Smith and Twin-Smith are absolutely the same in respect of their causal properties, it follows that the alleged differences between the one person’s mental content and the others is causally impotent. A moment ago we saw that it makes no sense to posit the existence of anything spatiotemporal that has no causal powers at all. The just-cited alleged difference has no causal powers. Therefore it makes no sense to supposed that it exists. Therefore it doesn’t exist. Therefore Burge is wrong.
 
5.2 Burge’s  response to Fodor Burge’s response to Fodor is rather curious. Burge denies that billiard balls x and y are causally identical. Burge says that the causal properties of an object are to be understood in terms of what it actually does, and not at all, contrary to what Fodor says, in terms of what it would do in different circumstances.  On Monday, let us suppose, I run a six minute mile without wearing a twenty pound backpack. On Tuesday, a run a seven minute mile wearing such a backpack. On both days, I run on the same path. The weather is the same. I’m no worse and no better rested or nourished on the one than on the other. Etc. According to Burge, my level of fitness has declined, the reason being that I ran the mile more slowly on Tuesday than on Monday. It’s irrelevant, says Burge, that, on Tuesday, I would have run the mile as quickly as I did on Monday if I hadn’t been wearing the backpack. Why is it irrelevant? Because, says Burge, the causal properties of physical objects are to be understood in terms of the peculiarities of the environments in which they happen to be embedded.
      Let’s look at the example that Burge himself uses. Let A and B be two celestial bodies that are atom-for-atom duplicates of each other. A is revolving around a star.  So A is a planet. B is not revolving around any star. So B is not a planet. Burge says (rightly) that the concept of a planet is an explanatorily important one. We explain at least some things in terms of the fact that some things are planets. From this, Burge concludes that A and B have different causal properties. It is not, says Burge, that A and B merely differ in their behavior. It is that, by virtue of being a planet – albeit one that is exactly like B down to the last atom – A has causal virtues that B lacks.         Is Burge’s argument a good one? No. Suppose that Smith and Jones are atom-for-atom duplicates of each other, but that Smith has a nephew whereas
Jones does not. Obviously there are, or at least could be, behavioral differences between Smith and Jones that  that are to be explained in terms of the fact that the one, but not the other, is an uncle. Why did Smith spend an hour shopping for toys?’ Because he’s six-year old Timmy’s uncle, and Timmy loves toys, as Smith knows. Why didn’t Jones spend an hour shopping for toys? Is it because Jones is mean and stingy, whereas Smith is kind and generous? No. It’s because Jones, unlike Smith, isn’t an uncle and thus does not (at least not for that reason) have go toy-shopping. Burge’s position concerning planets, if transposed to this other context, is that Jones is in fact a very different person from Smith. Smith is a nice guy. (Let’s assume for argument’s sake that his toy-shopping is an expression of genuine love for his nephew.) But Jones, not having gone to the trouble of buying toys for his non-existent nephew, is not such a nice guy, even though Jones is just as likely as Smith to buy a present (or otherwise behave amicably towards) the people in his life who, unlike his nephew, actually exist.
      Let’s get back to A and B. Because A is embedded in a certain way in a certain solar system, it’s going to do things that B won’t do. It’ll move in ways in that B will not. It’ll draw the astronauts who land on A towards itself, whereas B will not do that, since (we may supposed) no astronauts bothered to go to B.
     This is all very true. But does it entail that A has different causal properties from B? No. In describing A as a ‘planet’, one is  saying that it is embedded in a certain way in a certain environment. In describing B as a non-planet, one is  one is  saying that it is not embedded in that way in that sort of environment. Burge is quite right what things do depends on the circumstances. If I’m underwater I don’t breathe; if I not, I do. Since A is part of a solar system, it does certain things; since B isn’t, it doesn’t. But this doesn’t show that A and B differ in respect of their causal properties from each other. It shows that:
 

	* A’s being embedded in a certain environment in a certain way
 
has different effects from
 

	* B’s being embedded in a totally different way in a completely differentsort of environment.  
 
(i) is not identical with A. (ii) is not identical with B. (I am sitting in a chair right now. But I’m not identical with the state of affairs of JMK’s sitting in a certain chair at 1:22 p.m. on April 9, 2009.)  A’s being  planet is identical with (i)’s being the case. (To be a planet is to be a thing of certain dimensions (etc.) that is embedded in a certain way in a certain sort of environment.) Since A’s being a planet is no more identical with A than I am identical with the fact that, at this instant, I’m sitting in a certain chair, and since the same thing mutatis mutandis holds of B, it would be deeply illogical to accept Burge’s judgment that A and B differ in their causal properties. In order for that judgment to be correct, A would have to be identical with the fact that it was  embedded in a certain way in a certain sort of environment, and by parallel reasoning you would  be identical with the fact that, right now, you are holding a certain book in your hands. But so far as it isn’t obviously false, this position borders on meaninglessness.
     Despite all these problems with content-externalism, and despite some
[338]
	comparably gruesome ones that I haven’t even mentioned, contentexternalism still has some loyal followers, who are indefatigable in their attempts to make content-externalism work. To these tenacious individuals, I can only say, quoting the great Marion Barry: ‘Let it go!’
 
The Computational Theory of Mind
 
      These days, a doctrine known as the “Computational Theory of Mind” (CTM) is very popular, both among scholars (especially philosophers and computer scientists) and among the laity. CTM is a form of materialism, for reasons that will become clear.
     One would think that this doctrine would be informed by the same intellectual progressiveness that led to the creation and subsequent development of computer science. And, because of its liberal and confident use of words such as “compute” and “algorithm,” CTM has an impressive sheen of rigor.
      But we will find that, ironically, CTM involves a regression to archaic, animistic forms of thought---that, more specifically, it represents the recrudescence of the primitive, and spurious, thinking that the grumbling of thunder represents the wrath of the gods.
     Speaking more philosophically and less psychoanalytically, we’ll find that CTM involves some basic ratiocinative failings.  For example, CTM embodies an ignorance of the fact that it is events that have effects, not objects. These events often involve objects. But objects per se cause nothing. The rock didn't break the window;  what did so was the rock’s striking the window (with a certain degree of force). We’ll also find that, if CTM were true, we couldn’t know it to be true and couldn’t have any legitimate reason to advocate it.
 
1.1  What is CTM?
 
     According to CTM, to think is to compute. Thoughts are computations. A computation is a formal inference. So CTM is the view that any instance of thought is identical with the making of a formal inference.
     But what is a “formal” inference? To qualify as “formal,” a case of reasoning must be identical with a reaction, on the part of some creature or other, to symbolic-inputs. But not all such reactions qualify as cases of formal reasoning: only those reactions so qualify that aren’t to any degree driven by the knowledge of the meanings of the symbol-tokens in question and are driven entirely by a sensitivity to their forms. So CTM is the contention that thought consists of responses to symbol-tokens that are driven entirely by the formal properties of those tokens and therefore embody no knowledge of what those symbol-tokens mean. In Section 1.2, we’ll give some examples of such responses, thereby eliminating any obscurity from the statement just made. 
     Why advocate CTM? Two reasons. First, CTM, if correct, solves the mind-body problem. When you add two numbers, you are ipso facto thinking. Computers presumably add numbers. (Computers presumably compute.) Therefore, computers, when adding numbers, are ipso facto thinking. We know how a computer’s software is related to its hardware. So CTM, if correct, solves the mind-body problem. (In other words, CTM, if correct, makes it clear how brains are responsible for the mental activity that they mediate.)
        Second, CTM, if correct, solves the “tracking problem” (or so CTMadvocates say and so we’ll momentarily assume). Brain-activity, though clearly 100% physics-driven, is also logic-driven (or, in any case, logicconsistent), at least to the extent that it mediates rational thought.  So, to the extent that it’s constitutive of rational thought, brain-activity, though governed by descriptive laws, embodies sensitivity to prescriptive laws: where such activity is concerned, the descriptive “tracks” the prescriptive. Nothing that is obeying the laws of physics is, in virtue of that fact, doing anything that can be evaluated--- that can be described as “correct” or “valid” or “false.” (In moving hither as opposed to thither, the billiard ball isn’t doing anything right or wrong, valid or invalid.) And, it seems to follow that nothing that can be so described could be constituted by brain-activity. But brain-activity does constitute activity that can be so described.       CTM (supposedly) solves this problem. It’s possible to create an environment in which there occur symbol-tokens whose logical properties are hewed to their physical properties in such a way that, within that environment, symbol-tokens occur in sequences that are consistent with the requirements of logic. In fact, not only is it possible to create such environments: we routinely do create them—and employ them. We call them “computers.” So it would seem that CTM, if correct, explains how activity that falls within the scope of physics can, at the same time, embody a sensitivity to the demands of logic and, more generally, of normativity.
 
1.2 Mentalese: the “language of thought”
 
    According to CTM-advocates, those symbol-tokens mediating our thoughts are held to belong to a hypothetical language. This hypothetical language is generally referred to as “Mentalese.”
   According to CTM, one doesn’t have to learn Mentalese. Brains are computers. Computers don’t function until they’ve been programmed.
Therefore, our brains don’t function until they’ve been programmed. Mentalese is that program. Thus, Mentalese must be programmed into a brain before that brain can mediate cognitive activity, and therefore before that brain’s owner can learn a language or, indeed, do anything that involves having any awareness of anything. Mentalese is to a functioning brain what a computer’s operating system is to that computer. Thus, just as your IBM came “bundled” with DOS, so your brain came “bundled” with Mentalese.      In light of what we’ve said, it might seem reasonable to say that, according to CTM, one innately knows Mentalese. But if CTM is right, one doesn’t know Mentalese at all, let alone innately. Knowing a language involves being able to correlate linguistic with non-linguistic entities. If I couldn’t correlate snow (the powdery substance) with “snow” (the word), I couldn’t possibly know what “snow” meant. In order to correlate “snow” with snow, I must have some way of being aware of snow that doesn’t involve knowing what “snow” means. Knowing Mentalese would involve being able to correlate the expressions belonging to it with non-linguistic entities. According to CTM, thoughts are identical with Mentalese expression-tokens, and such expressions must therefore be operational if one is to make correlations or, therefore, to know a language.
       So if CTM is right, a precondition for one's being aware of anything (or making correlations of any kind or, knowing a language) is that one's brain be stocked with already operational Mentalese symbol-tokens. So it isn’t by virtue of one’s knowing Mentalese that expression-tokens belonging to it mediate one’s thoughts or otherwise do what CTM-advocates allege them to do.
     To sum up: Nobody knows Mentalese; nobody understands the expressions belonging to it; and it isn’t to any degree being understood that such expression-tokens facilitate thought.
    In this respect, Mentalese is radically different from English and every other non-hypothetical language. Expression-tokens belonging to English, Urdu, etc. do not facilitate thought except by being understood. By contrast, the symbol-tokens of Mentalese, supposing such tokens to exist, need not be understood to facilitate thought. Indeed, it is inherent in what Mentalese expression-tokens are that they be able to discharge all of their duties without being understood to any degree by anyone or anything.
     Because Mentalese, were it to exist, would differ in this respect from English, Spanish, and other bona fide languages, it follows (for reasons to be discussed in Section 4.0) that the very concept of a “language of thought” is not a coherent one. Given that CTM assumes there to be a language of thought, and given that (for reasons to be disclosed in Section 4.0) no doctrine that doesn’t assume this bears any resemblance to CTM, it follows that CTM is incoherent. 
 
1.3 The concept of a formal inference: Some illustrations
 
     We’ve seen, if correct, CTM explains much. But is it correct? We can’t answer that unless we make it clear what, in this context, the word “compute” means. And we can’t make that clear unless we make it clear what, in this context, it means to say of symbolic activity that it is “form-driven.”       The following three stories will help answer these questions.
 
Story #1 (not an example of computation) Smith, who speaks English, is told: “Jones has two yachts.” On the basis of this information, along with his knowledge of the English language, Smith concludes that the following sentence is correct: “the number n such that Jones has n yachts is such that n has no rational square root.”
  
Commentary on Story #1:  Smith’s reasoning is cogent. But it is not in any sense “formal.” Smith’s thought process was a driven by an understanding of inter alia the meanings of the words he was hearing.
     
Story #2 (an example of a kind of computation) W is a wood-chipper. But W is no ordinary wood-chipper. Suppose that W is fed, in the following order, a wooden “2,” a wooden “+,” a wooden “9,” and, finally, a wooden “=.” Suppose, in other words, that W is fed an instance of the sentence-fragment “2 + 9 =.” In that case, driven solely by the morphological properties of the symbols that it was fed, W cranks out a wooden “11.” And, W does the same thing mutatis mutandis for any other two numbers. So given any whole numbers M and N, if W is fed the sentence-fragment “M + N =,” then, driven solely the morphologies of that fragment, W produces a wooden sign denoting the sum of those two numbers.  
  
Commentary: There would seem to be a sense in which W can compute sums. It is typically this sense of the word “compute” that advocates of CTM have in mind when they say that to think is to compute. Why only
“typically”? Why not “always”? Because sometimes what they have in mind is the prima facie quite different sense of the word “compute” that is illustrated in the following section.
 
Story #3 (an example of a different kind of computation) Smith has no idea what “1,245,” “241,” “1,486,” etc. mean. But Smith has been told by a source whose testimony he rightly trusts that, when given ink-marks having such and such shapes, a correct sentence results when another ink-mark, having thus and so shape, is placed in a certain position relative to the original ink-marks. In particular, Smith knows that, given their respective shapes, the ink-marks “1,486” and  “1,245 + 241 =” form a correct sentence when (some isomorph of) the former is placed to the right of (some isomorph of) the latter. It must be emphasized that Smith has no idea what any of these ink-marks mean. Smith knows nothing of relevance to this situation other than the rules as to how certain shapes ought to be manipulated or complemented. Those rules in fact describe how to do sums involving multidigit numbers. But Smith doesn't know that. He knows only that, when given ink-marks having such and such a shape, another ink-mark must be placed beneath them if a true statement (as to whose identity he is quite ignorant) is to result.     
 
Commentary: What Smith is doing seems to be different from what W is doing. Smith’s applying the just-mentioned rule involves his having various sense-perceptions (e.g., he sees various ink-deposits) and various beliefs (e.g., he believes that those ink-marks are symbols of some kind or other, and he believes that a correct statement, albeit one of whose meaning he is ignorant, will result if, underneath them, he produces an ink-mark having a certain shape); and his having such beliefs involves his making quite delicate judgments (e.g., he must judge that the ink-deposits in question were produced by sentient beings with certain intentions---he would not see those ink-deposits as tokening the sentence-fragment “1,245 + 241 =” were he to learn that their existence was the unintended result of some explosion involving an ink-filled urn).
      Nothing comparable holds of W. It isn’t because of any sense-perceptions or beliefs or intentions on its part that, having been fed a wooden token of the sentence-fragment “2 + 9 =” W spits out a wooden “11.” So what Smith is doing in writing a “1,486” seems not to be comparable to what W is doing in spitting out a wooden “11.” 
      And, while there is certainly a sense of the word “compute” in which Smith is computing a sum, this cannot possibly be the sense in which, according to CTM, to think is to compute. A precondition for Smith’s performing the just-described computation is his already being able to upload and process information. So CTM would be guilty of vicious circularity were it given by the thesis that, in this sense of the word “compute” to think is to compute. So, supposing CTM coherent, the sense in which  to think is to compute is the sense in which W computes, and the sense in which Smith computes is irrelevant.
        We will now see that CTM is indefensible and that no doctrine at all similar to it can possibly be correct. There are five reasons for this. These reasons will given in Sections 2.0-6.0.
     
2.0 CTM’s failure to distinguish between shape and syntactic form 
 
    A story will help expose one reason why CTM is false. You shout the following at me: “if your nose starts to bleed in the next ten seconds, I’ll give you a million bucks.” Let T be the sentence-token in question. As a result of T’s being uttered, I do start to bleed out of my noise, and you duly give me $1,000,000. But it wasn’t because of what T meant that I had a nose-bleed; nor was it because of T’s syntax. It was T’s being loud that caused my nosebleed.
   My reaction here wasn’t symbolic. Even though T is a symbol (or, to be precise, a symbol-token), T’s being a symbol did nothing. For exactly similar reasons, W’s spitting out an “11” isn’t symbolic, even though its doing so was precipitated by events involving symbol-tokens.
 
2.1 This line of reasoning generalized 
 
     We’ve just seen that CTM is a non-starter if a symbol-token’s “form” is identified with its shape. But sometimes, when referring to a symbol-token’s “form,” advocates of CTM are (so they say) referring to its syntactic form.
Given this use of the word “form,” CTM becomes the contention that thoughts are syntax-driven operations on symbols.
     This contention is easily refuted. Syntax is semantic structure. “Smith loves Mary” and “Sally hates Greg” have the same syntax because the semantics of the one has the same structure as the semantics of the other.      To be sure, those sentences have very different meanings. But they’re semantically isomorphic. Each constituent of the one sentence corresponds to exactly one constituent of the other (“Smith,” “loves,” and Mary” correspond to “Sally,” “hates,” and “Greg,” respectively); and the relationship borne by the semantics of any given constituent of the one sentence to the semantics of that sentence as a whole coincides with the relationship borne by the semantics of that constituent’s counterpart in the other sentence to the semantics of that sentence as a whole. So the relation borne by the semantics of “Smith” with respect to the proposition that Smith loves Mary coincides with the relation borne by “Sally” to the proposition that Sally hates Greg.      Given that syntax is semantic structure, syntax-driven operations are ipso facto meaning-driven. Being the contention that “formal” operations are not meaning-driven, CTM is therefore completely incoherent if taken to be the contention that “formal” operations are syntax-driven operations.
       At the same time, CTM is incoherent, as we saw, if “formal” operations are taken to be shape-driven operations. There is no third way to interpret the word “formal.” So CTM is incoherent.
 
2.2 Shape vs. syntax (revisited): The equivocation that lies at the heart of
CTM 
 
Here is the thinking embodied in CTM:
 
Form-driven responses to symbolic inputs are ipso facto cases
of thought. W has form-driven responses to symbolic inputs.
Therefore, W is thinking (it is adding numbers).
 
 But when this argument is stated in a clear and non-elliptical manner, it becomes clear that it involves an equivocation and is invalid for that reason:
 
 Form-driven responses to symbolic inputs are ipso facto cases of thought. (In other words, syntax-driven responses to symboltokens are ipso facto cases of thought.) W has form-driven responses to symbolic inputs. (In other words, W’s responses to its inputs are morphology-driven.) Therefore W is thinking.
 
    The second argument is clearly spurious. Presumably because they are aware of this, advocates of CTM typically hold that, even though a symboltoken’s shape isn’t identical with its morphology, syntax can be “coded” into morphology---that syntax can be “morphologized” in much the way that geometry can be arithmetized. This is both false and irrelevant.     It’s false because anything, no matter what its shape, can have any syntactic structure, and anything, no matter what its syntactic structure, can be tokened by anything, no matter what its shape. (In other words, given an arbitrary shape, and given an arbitrary syntactic structure, there is a possible language to which there belong expressions having that syntactic structure that are tokened by objects having that shape.) It’s irrelevant because, even if syntax can be morphologized, it isn’t, as we’ve already seen, in virtue of its having this as opposed to that shape that a symbol-token has this as opposed to that syntax. So in so far as one is responding to an object’s shape, one’s behavior is, to that extent, not the effect of, or otherwise to be understood in terms of, that object’s shape.
     To be sure, one knows what syntax an object has on the basis of its shape. A large part of the reason that I know the syntax of the following sentencetoken---“John is tall and grass is green”---is that I know what shape that inkdeposit has. But sentence-tokens with precisely the same syntax can be tokened by hand-movements or  by noises; and hand-movements and noises have no strictly morphological resemblance at all to any ink-deposit. (No inkdeposit that tokens “John is tall and grass is green” bears much resemblance to a stream of noises, or a series of hand-movements, that also tokened that same sentence, except relative to rules of projection that were contrived ex post facto to establish such a resemblance.)
    Also, the relationship that holds between (a) my knowledge of that inkdeposit’s shape and (b) my knowledge of its syntax is of a causal, and not of a constitutive, nature. I see that it has that shape. Given that knowledge, along with my background linguistic knowledge, I judge that it has a certain syntax.       To be sure, from an experiential (phenomenological) perspective, it may seem as though in knowing that it has that shape I ipso facto know that it has that syntax. But that’s not the case. What we have is one bit of knowledge (knowledge of shape) leading, by way of (rapid) judgments, to some other bit of knowledge (knowledge of syntax).
   Echoing what we just said, these two bits of knowledge may seem, at the level of consciousness, to come into existence simultaneously. But that appearance is misleading and, even if not misleading, irrelevant. It’s misleading because any knowledge of an object’s syntax must follow knowledge of its physical properties. To clarify these last two statements: If I judge that you’re angry, it’s on the basis of your facial expression, or some such. My judgment as to your emotional state may immediately follow my awareness of your expression. But given that the former is based on the latter and is also caused by it, the one awareness follows the other, however quickly. Exactly similar points hold of the relationship between my knowledge of a given object’s physical shape and my subsequent knowledge of its syntax: it isn’t possible for me to have the latter knowledge without having the former; it is possible for me to have the former without having the latter; and my knowledge of the former is the sole foundation for, and is also what leads to, my knowledge of the latter.
      Plus, it’s irrelevant that, speaking from a strictly experiential
(phenomenological) perspective, the occurrence of the one bit of knowledge seems to coincide with the occurrence of the other. It is the purpose, or at the very least the effect, of consciousness to condense the intricacies of the cognitions underlying it into a single, seemingly homogeneous “experience.” If every articulation of pre-conscious cognition were faithfully represented in consciousness, if phenomenology faithfully duplicated every joint in the intricacies of the cognitions of which our conscious judgments are the outcomes, then consciousness would be so overburdened with information that it would cease to be able to perform the executive functions with which it is tasked. When seeing a rabid dog run towards me, my consciousness would present to me a richly articulated mosaic of judgments, whose consequences for my well-being would take much more time to figure out than was available to me. Fortunately, however, my consciousness presents me with a homogenous feeling that causes me, not a moment too soon, to bolt into action. Instead of giving me the psychological equivalent of a two-hundred page state-department report, consciousness gives me the equivalent of an electric cattle-prod in my back. And because the rich cognitive back-story is telescoped into that bolt of unpleasant and, aside from its distinctive affective nuances, homogeneous bolt of unpleasant phenomenology, I do the right thing (i.e., I run to the mini-van, lock the doors, roll up the windows, etc.) and, what is more, I do it in real time.
    In general, it is precisely because consciousness represents as homogenous “feelings” what are in fact  intricate networks of judgments that the contents of consciousness, unlike their cognitive underpinnings, are actionable. It is, I would conjecture, the very purpose, or at least one of the purposes, of consciousness to condense cognitive intricacies into affective simplicities. Therefore, it is inter alia its purpose to condense distinct, albeit adjacent, stages of intricate thought processes into a single, action-causing, survivalensuring feeling.
     In any case, if this is at all on the mark, then it’s of no relevance that my recognition of the ink-deposit’s shape seems to be temporally coincident with my recognition of its syntax. It is to be pointed out that, if this isn’t on the mark, then much work in psychology crumbles.
   
3.0 A related point: CTM incompatible with the fact that distinct thoughts can be part of some one thought-process
 
     If CTM is right, my thinking 2 is a prime number and 2 is less than three cannot be responsible for my later thinking some prime number is less than three.  According to CTM, if B1 is the totality of brain-events constitutive of my thinking 2 is a prime number and 2 is less than three, and B2 is the totality of brain-events constitutive of my thinking some prime number is less than three, it cannot be B1’s being such a belief that brings about B2. So it cannot be B1’s being such a belief that leads me to believe that some prime number is less than three.
     So, if CTM is right, B1’s being such a belief has nothing to do with B2’s existence or a fortiori with B2’s being constitutive of a thought to the effect that some prime number is less than three. Thus, my believing that two is even and is less than three cannot, if CTM is right, have anything to do with my later believing that some even prime is less than three. So, if CTM is right, T1 has nothing to do with T2, notwithstanding that the brain-events constitutive of T1 brought about those constitutive of T2.
      So even though B1 occurs right before B2 and is causally responsible for it, and even though B1 and B2 are constitutive of, respectively, T1 and T2, nonetheless T1 and T2 cannot, if CTM is right, be installments in some one thought-process.
    In general, CTM is incompatible with the fact that distinct thoughts can be part of some one thought-process. CTM is thus incompatible with the fact that thought-processes occur---with the fact that there are sequences of thoughts (setting aside such thought-sequences whose constituents have no thematic coherence, having at best the content-free coherence had by a series of domino-fallings).
           
4.0 CTM’s dependence on the false assumption that syntax can mirror logical form
 
      Context-sensitivity drives a wedge between syntax and logical form. If I say:
 

	* "it is snowing now and it is not snowing now,”
 
what I'm saying might be true---it might stop snowing before I utter the second conjunct---even though it has the same syntax as:
 

	* "n is even and n is not even."
 
 Similarly, if I say:
 

	* "that guy is identical with that guy,”
 
 
 what I'm saying might be false, even though it has that same syntax as
 

	* "n is identical with n."
 
          If our thinking were syntax-driven, we couldn't recognize the differences in respect of logical form between (1) and (2) or between (3) and (4). We can recognize those differences. So our thinking is not syntax-driven. So CTM is wrong.
        Here is a similar line of thought. If, on July 1, 2010, in Richmond, VA, I say:
 

	* "right now, Jim is three thousand miles from here,"
 
the information encoded in my utterance is very different that encoded in an utterances of:
 

	* "On July 1, 2010, Jim is 3,000 miles from Richmond VA."
 
       The information encoded in (i) doesn't follow from the information encoded in (ii), or vice versa. In general, when the context-sensitive expressions in a true statement are replaced with context-insensitive expressions, the result is a statement that, although true, neither entails the first statement not follows from it.
     For an expression to be context-sensitive is for its referent to vary with the context. What an expression refers to is determined by its semantics, not its syntax. CTM says that thought is to no degree semantics-driven. If that were true, we couldn't grasp perspectival truths, such as that expressed by (i). Since we can grasp such truths, CTM is false.
 
     
  5.0 CTM’s reliance on the erroneous assumption that there are minimal units of thought
 
    First a definition: a “morpheme” is an expression that cannot be decomposed into others. Bearing this in mind, let’s suppose that, just as CTM says, we think in a language. In that case, our concepts are identical with expressions.  Linguistic expressions consist of morphemes. (Any given complex expression; e.g., “the cat is on the mat,” decomposes into expressions that cannot, in their turn, be further decomposed; (e.g., “cat,” “mat”). So in contending that our thoughts are identical with (tokens of) Mentalese symbols, CTM is, in effect, assuming that we have simple concepts: concepts that cannot be decomposed in others. So CTM, if correct, entails that any given thought that one has can be decomposed into “simple” concepts. CTM thus has the radically implausible consequence that we have “simple” concepts. In other words, CTM has the consequence that some of our concepts are no more capable of being decomposed into other concepts than a morpheme (e.g., the word “cat”) can be decomposed into other expressions. If this consequence of CTM is correct, it follows, as we’ll now see, that some of our concepts would be such that one could have them without also having other concepts.
    Let T be the token of the Mentalese word for “snow” that went off when, just a moment ago, I thought to myself that snow is white. We may assume that T is a morpheme. (If, for some reason, you reject that assumption, just map what we say about T onto some Mentalese expression-token that, in your judgment, is a morpheme—and you must, if you grant that we think in a language, grant that there is some such token, since morpheme-less language is a surd---and everything that we say about T will hold mutatis mutandis of this other expression-token.) Not being decomposable into other expressiontokens, T presumably exists independently of such tokens. Given any simple expression—given any morpheme—belonging to a language L, you can remove that morpheme without removing other morphemes. Of course, in removing that morpheme, you’ll remove all of the expressions of which it is a constituent. (And, if you choose a non-lexical item; e.g., “and” or “of,” you may thus do a lot of damage to L.) But you won’t, in removing that morpheme, be removing other morphemes.
