If those wrinkles are of such and such a type – if those wrinkles have the right properties – then Smith exists in that world; if not, not. So Smith, I would suggest, is a property of states of affairs.
       On similar grounds, I would argue that the things we call “properties” – redness, roundness, and the like – are really properties of properties. Actually, they are, I belive, properties of properties of properties -- 3rd order properties!     First of all, you never find instances of redness in isolation of states of affairs. The same is true of instances of roundness, sweetness, and anything else that we refer to as a “property”. What you find is a red (or sweet or round) state of affairs.
    What is a state of affairs? Pick some state of affairs. (To facilitate things, choose one that you can see or feel.) Consider the fact that there is a tree in such and such place at such and such time. Let S be that state of affairs. What is it for a world to comprise S? S’s existence in a world supervenes on the existence of innumerable displacements of mass-energy – ultimately, on the presence of certain “wrinkles in the quantum” of that world. So that state of affairs exists in a world w if some of the wrinkles in that world’s quantum are of the right type, i.e. if those wrinkles have the right properties. So a state of affairs is a property of a property. Instances of redness, tallness, and the like – the things we are used to describing as “properties” – are properties of states of affairs. So they are properties of of properties of properties.
   
 
Propositions as sets of properties, truth as set-memberinstantiatedness (the short version)
 
 
       By a proposition I mean the truth-evaluable entity meant by a sentencetoken – by, e.g. an utterance of “that man is a scoundrel” or “it’s hot in here
[384]
right now.”
       It is fiercely debated what propositions are. Some say that they are sets of worlds or functions from worlds to truth-values; others that they are facts; others that they are possible (but not necessarily actual) facts; others that they are sets of their own consequences; others that they are structures that contain the same parts as the facts that, if they were true, would make them so, but in which those parts are arranged very differently from the way in which they would be arranged in the corresponding facts. Finally, some say they don’t exist.
       My purpose here is to propose a positive answer to the question “what are propositions?” Here is that answer: Propositions are sets of properties, a proposition is true just in case the properties that are members of it are instantiated; and a corollary is that truth is identical with instantiatedness (or, more accurately, that truth is the property of being a set containing only instantiated properties). Aside from a few brief remarks, I will leave it open whether all sets of properties qualify as propositions. But a case will be made that only such sets are propositions.
        A few words will be said as to why the alternative theories are unsatisfactory; but my remarks on that matter will be brief, since the deficiencies of the existing alternatives have been thoroughly discussed elsewhere.
       The argument presented here will not be airtight. But, I hope, it has sufficient prima facie plausibility that it is worth investigating, despite its not being cogent in every respect.
       Here is an outline of an argument for our analysis. Given any proposition P, there is some set S of properties such that P is true if and only if all the members of S are instantiated. The “if and only if” is to be taken to have the strongest possible force – to denote conceptual or, in any case, metaphysical necessity. This suggests that a proposition is a set of properties and that a proposition’s truth is the joint instantiatedness of its members. Hence my proposal: a proposition is a set of properties and a proposition’s being true is identical with its members’ being instantiated. 
      This analysis, I will argue, holds for all propositions; but special measures must be taken to deal properly with molecular, especially quantified, propositions.
      Our analysis will enable us to see what, exactly, is meant by the obscure metaphors that dominate semantic discourse – metaphors embodied in terms such “saturate”, “synthesize”, and “constituent.”
       Our analysis is intended to do justice to the fact that propositions have decompositional structure. The proposition Harry owns a dog has a certain structure corresponding – in some way, to some degree – with the structure(s) of the sentences that express it. Indeed, there much be such correspondence, else people couldn’t assign that proposition to those sentences and therefore couldn’t understand them. Not all analyses of propositions, as we will see, do justice to the humdrum facts that sentences can be understood and that propositional structure must therefore have some kind of systematic relation to sentential structure.
 
Section I. A Dogmatic Statement of the Basics
 
      In this section I will list the conceits that underlie the present analysis. Argumentation for these conceits will be given in Section II and will be quite absent from this section. There may be, and probably are, some redundancies on the list. (Eliminating the redundancies would decrease clarity less than it would increase cogency or expository elegance.)
       Conceits #2 and #7 will be initially seem quite counterintuitive. But the raison d’être for them will become apparent in Section II.
       I realize that this method of presentation is unusual. But I feel that, ultimately, it is for the best that, as soon as possible and with as little obfuscation, I lay bare the machinery driving my analysis (so that, if nothing else, my biases are exposed at the outset).
 
Conceit #1. A proposition is a set.
 
Conceit #2. Every member of such a set is a property. In the proposition
Plato snores, what occurs is the property of being identical with Plato, not Plato per se. (For a proposition containing that property to be true, the property of being identical with Plato must be instantiated. For, for example, for “Plato is happy” to be true, the property of being identical with Plato must be instantiated – Plato must exist. But Plato per se is not a constituent of the
[385]
proposition itself.)
     
Conceit #3. A proposition is true iff each of the properties in the set identical with that proposition is instantiated. A proposition is a set and a proposition’s being true is that sets’ members’ being instantiatedness.
 
Conceit #4. Each “constituent” of a proposition is either identical with or in some obvious way corresponds to a member of the set with which that proposition is identical. Give or take some nuances, propositionalconstituency is set-membership.
 
Conceit #5. The logical properties of a proposition are perspicuously represented by facts about the membership of the set with which that proposition is identical. The proposition Plato snores entails something snores and also Plato does something and, finally, something does something. Among the members of the set with which Plato snores is identical are the property of Plato’s doing something and the property of something’s snoring as well as the property of something’s doing something.
      What the proposition does in the way of entailing the set does in the way of instantiating.
 
Conceit #6. Facts about the structures of the decompositions of propositions are readily and transparently equated with facts about the memberships of the sets with which they are identical. So the proposition Aristotle snores must have a discrete, easily identified component in common with Plato snores
[386]
and with 	Bill Clinton snores.  
 
Conceit #7. Let p be a proposition that is a proper constituent of another proposition P. (So if P is “if Smith comes home early, then Jerry will be mad”, then p might be “Jerry will be mad.”) Let s be the set that is identical with p, and let S be the set that is identical with P. In that case, what occurs as a member of S is not s but is rather the property of being identical with s. [387]
 
Conceit #8. It has long been known that the “constituents” of propositions sometimes “synthesize” with one another to form new, more “complex” constituents (these are all terms whose meanings have been left opaque).      I would like to make a proposal as to the nature of that synthesis. Consider the sentence “Plato snores.” According to the analysis to be put forth, among the constituents of this proposition are “the property of being identical with Plato” and “the property of snoring.” Now consider the property of being identical with Plato and also consider the property of snoring. To
“synthesize” those two things  –or, to use Frege’s term, for Plato to “saturate”
[388]
	the property of snoring – is to identify a property p3 each one of whose instances is an instance both of snoring and of being Plato. In general, the synthesizing of propositional constituents consists of two things: first, realizing that all such constituents are properties; second, supposing that p1 and p2 are the two properties that you wish to synthesize, identifying some third property p3 each of whose instances are instances both of p1 and p2. (Synthesizing new properties out of old ones doesn’t consist in creating new properties, but only in identifying properties whose properties combine those of the old ones.)
 
Conceit #9. grammatical inflections encode ordinal information. Given a series of properties p1….pn, the grammatical inflections on the
corresponding terms will say, for which j and k, to look for a property P such that each instance of P is an instance of both pj and pk; and those grammatical inflections will also specify when, relative to other operations of the kind just described, a given one is to occur.
 
Conceit #10. As a rule, discrete parts of sentences must correspond to discrete parts of propositions and, therefore, to discrete members of the sets with which propositions are identical. It must be possible to puts facts about the structures of propositions into a transparent relation with facts about sentences.
 
Conceit #11: Existing propositions cannot contain non-existent parts (e.g. Socrates, Plato), this being a special case of the general principle that philosophical analyses cannot defy the laws of logic.
 
Conceit #12: “Plato” refers to Plato; “Plato” does not refer to the property of being identical with Plato. Contrary to first appearances, this is consistent with my analysis.. For “Plato” to refer to Plato is for the property of being identical with Plato to be a member of the set identical with the proposition meant by ┌…Plato…┐ and it is therefore for Plato  per se, as opposed to property of being identical with Plato, to be a constituent of the fact that makes that sentence true (if it is true).
 
 
Section II. The Arguments
 
         Now I will try to provide demonstrative support for the statements just made.
    Consider the proposition:
 
1. Tommy is smoking.
 
 
     Intuitively, this proposition seems to consist of at least three components: Tommy (or, perhaps, the property or concept of being Tommy), the property of smoking, and some kind of “synthesis” of the two – some complex constituent that involves Tommy’s smoking. (We will try to state precisely what this synthesis involves.)
     If 1 is true, then
 

	A. the property of being identical with Tommy
 
 is instantiated, and so is
 

	A. the property of smoking.
 
     But, of course, those two properties could be instantiated in a world where Tommy is not smoking – in a world where, for example, Larry is smoking and Tommy is playing golf (and also not smoking). We thus need a third property – a property such that, if a set S contains that property along with A and B, then 1 will be true just in case all of S’s members are instantiated.
That third property is not hard to identify. It is:
 

	A. The property of being a person who is smoking and is identical with
Tommy.
 
     Before moving on, we must address some possible unease that C may awaken. Few will doubt that the property of being identical with Tommy is a
[389]
	perfectly acceptable one. But some might resist signing off on C. We mustn’t be dismayed, however; for we must remember that Tommy cannot just be instantiated. An unpropertied Tommy – a Tommy who does nothing, feelings nothing, has no features – is a surd. What must be instantiated is a happy Tommy, an anxious Tommy or a smoking Tommy.
    Before we further discuss the legitimacy of these properties – whether they exist and whether we can use them if they do in fact exist – let’s look at the apparatus that we’ve been developing. Once again, let S be a set that contains
[390]
	all and only A, B, and C; and remember that we have identified S with 1 (the proposition that Tommy is smoking). 
     First of all, if C is instantiated, so are B and A. Further, if C, and therefore B, and A, are instantiated, then, and only then, is 1 true. It follows that 1 is true if, and only if, A, B, C are each instantiated. This suggest, though it may fall short of proving, that 1 is S that and that 1’s being true is S’s members’ being jointly instantiated.  
       Here we come to some crucial points. It is true that 1 is true if, and only if, all of S’s members are instantiated. But there is another reason to identity 1 with S and 1’s truth with S’s members’ being instantiated. 1 and S have comparable decompositions. 1 has the following constituents. Tommy; smoking; Tommy’s smoking. S has the property of being identical with Tommy; the property of smoking; the property of being a smoking Tommy. (Actually, each of 1 and S has more constituents than this. We will deal with these remaining constituents in a moment; and when we examine them, we’ll see more evidence 1 and S stand in a sufficiently natural correspondence to each other that we are guilty of no artifice in identifying them.)
     If 1 is true, that entails that Tommy exists, that something smokes and, of course, that Tommy smokes. If S’s members are instantiated, those very same propositions hold. 
       1 and S have other constituents in common. For example, 1 has as a
[391] 	constituent the function Tommy does something (or Tommy  does x) and also something does something (or x does y). And S, we may suppose, comprises the property of being something that does something (x does y) and also the property of being a Tommy that does something (Tommy does
x). So the fact that 1 entails something does something is neatly reflected in a fact about S, namely that one of S’s members is the property of something’s doing something. So just as P, when true, entails something does something, so S, when its members are instantiated, instantiates the property of something’s doing something. To echo what we said earlier: what P does in the way of entailing, S does in the way of instantiating. And this, of course, corroborates the view that propositions are set and are true when they members are instantiated.
       
The problem of synthesizing two propositional constituents.
 
      Everybody knows that, in 1, the two simple constituents, which are (or are similar to) Plato and the property of snoring, are “synthesized” in some way which forms a something truth-evaluable – something that is therefore radically unlike the meaningless heap “Plato, the property of snoring.” Frege used the term “saturation” to denote this special process – to denote this I know-not-what that distinguishes propositions, with their characteristic internal unity, from semantically unstructured rubbish, like “Plato, the property of snoring.” But, as Davidson observed, the term “saturate” only identifies the problem, and fails to solve it. We are in a position to step into this breach and to say with some precision what this saturation amounts to. Let p1 be property of being identical with Tommy, and let p2 be the property of smoking. Now try to find some property p3 such that any instance of p3 is an instance of p1 and also of p2. So any instance of p3 smokes and is
Tommy.
       I’m going to make a bold suggestion. In at least many cases, the “synthesizing” (or “saturating”) that occurs in propositions, by means of which (relatively) simple constituents are combined into complex ones, are instances of exactly the operation just described: given two simple properties p1 and p2, a third property p3 is identified each one of whose instances is an instance both of p1 and p2.
       Here one might ask: ‘Why not just identify  
     
 
1. Tommy is smoking
 
with
 
C The property of being a smoking Tommy?
 
After all, 1 is true iff C is instantiated.’
     Here’s why not. Consider an instance of the property of being a smoking Tommy. Obviously that instance will involve Tommy smoking. But it will not, at least obviously, contain a discrete part corresponding to Tommy or a discrete part corresponding to smoking. And what is true of an instance of that property is, quite possibly, true of the property itself. It cannot be taken for granted that C has a discrete part corresponding to Tommy or to smoking or to anything else. In fact, being a non-spatiotemporal entity, C won’t have discrete parts in any straightforward sense at all. And the impression that C is part-less, or lacking in the right kind of parts, is reinforced when we look at what an instance of C is like. Such an instance is, to adapt Kenneth Taylor’s apt expression, a dent or ripple in the quantum; it is a shift in the movement of mass-energy. Of course, that mass-energy is (by hypothesis) sufficient for the existence of Tommy and of smoking and, indeed, of a smoking Tommy. But you would have a devil of a time isolating some part of that distribution that corresponding to Tommy, distinguishing that from some other part corresponding to smoking, and then finding a third that fused those two, otherwise discrete entities into a discrete instance of a smoking Tommy.       By contrast, the proposition
 

	1. Tommy is smoking
 
is, of its very nature, nearly parsed into Tommy, the property of smoking, and a third constituent that synthesizes the two just mentioned. The neat articulations found in 1 are found, in some form, in S. Those articulations, though found in S’s membership has a whole, are not found in C taken by itself, making S, but not C, a suitable mirror for the decompositional structure of 1.
      States of affairs (or ‘facts’, as they are sometimes called) do not, as Ian Hacking long ago put it, have the same kinds of “articulations” as propositions. The quantum-ripples on which the truth of a proposition supervenes don’t have anything like the structure of that proposition. In fact, the concept of structure isn’t applicable in the case of the former.
Propositional structure consists of discrete entities that are “synthesized” (in a way that we tried to describe a moment ago) into new entities by means of recursive operations. Actual states of affairs, actual mass-energy coursings, obviously don’t have such a structure. (Obviously they have some kind of structure. But that structure is identified by giving the locations and forces and of their fundamental particles, not by describing some of their parts as outputs of functions, in the Cartesian sense, of some of their other parts.)         There is a corollary. Consider the proposition:
 

	1. Tommy is snoring.
 
Let D be the property of being a snoring Tommy. It is obvious that
 

	1. Tommy is smoking
 
and
 

	1. Tommy is snoring
 
have much in common. They have in common the constituent Tommy (or, in any case, something corresponding thereto). They have in common the functions (or, if you prefer, properties) the property of being Tommy who is doing something and the property of being a something that is doing something.
     In light of this, consider some instance of D. In other words, consider the kind of property-instance, the kind of mass-energy distribution, on which the truth of 2 supervenes. That instance will, of course, suffice for the existence of Tommy, as will an instance of C. But will those instances, in virtue of that fact, have some discrete part in common? Unlikely. In neither case do we have Tommy simpliciter. We have Tommy smoking (while sweating profusely and worrying about his algebra test and his nascent nicotine addition, all the while throwing a baseball to his cousin Albert); in the other we have Tommy snoring (while having terrible dreams about his future as a second string pitcher on a mediocre time). There is no such thing, in either case, as Tommy simpliciter. An unpropertied Tommy is, to use our old expression, a surd. There is only Tommy doing this or that, having this or that property. A corollary is that two situations that comprise Tommy do not, in virtue of that fact, have in common some discrete, isolable entity. So while it is true that C
[392]
	and D both comprise Tommy, the one does not, in comprising that
thing, comprise anything which has anything other than a very rough counterpart in the other.
      But now we must consider what we’ve said about the composition of 1 and, by given obvious extensions of what we’ve said about 1, about 2. 1 is a set S whose members are:
 
a: the property of being Tommy b: the property of smoking
C: the property of being a smoking Tommy
 
And, by similar reasoning, 2 is a set S* whose members are:
 
a: the property of being Tommy b*: the property of snoring
D: the property of being a snoring Tommy
 
S and S* do have well-defined, discrete parts in common. Indeed, they have in common precisely what is had in common by
 

	1. Tommy is smoking
 
and
 

	1. Tommy is snoring.
 
    If we were to be really precise about it, we’d say each of S and S* comprised, not only a-c, but also
 

	a. the property of being a Tommy that does something (i.e. the property beinga Tommy that does something or, in any case, has some property),
 
and also
 

	a. the property of being a something that does something (i.e. the propertybeing a something that does something or, in any case, has some property),
 
       Let’s look at 1 for a second. It immediately and formally implies:
 
i Tommy smokes; ii something smokes; iii Tommy does something; iv Tommy exists; v something does something.
 
And 2 immediately implies:
 
i* Tommy snores; ii* something snores; iii Tommy does something; iv Tommy exists; v something does something.
 
Now let’s look at S and at S*. The members of S are:
 
I The property of being Tommy
II The property of snoring

	* The property of being a Tommy that snores.

	* The property of being a Tommy that does something.

	* The property of being a something that does something.
 
The members of S* are:
 
I The property of being Tommy
II* The property of smoking
III* The property of being a Tommy that smokes.

	* The property of being a Tommy that does something.

	* The property of being a something that does something.
 
    Having identified 1. with S and 2 with S*, everything we know about those propositions – about what they entail, about  what their components are, and about  how their higher-level components are “forged” out of their lower level components – is accounted for.
      
     Another desideratum satisfied by our analysis
 
     Many semanticists today hold that Plato and  Socrates are veritable objects are constituents of propositions that concern them. So according to Kaplan (1989),who is following and agreeing with Russell (1903), Timmy – the person, not some Fregean concept thereof – is a constituent of both 1 and

	1. Other adherents of this view are Scott Soames, Robert Moore, Jeff King,John Perry, Joseph Almog, and (to my knowledge) Michael Thau. (Opponents are J. Searle, M. Dummett, and – with some very heavy reservations to be stated later – the present author.) There are two problems with this view. First, it makes it hard (though by no means impossible) to [393]
deal with Hesperus-Phosphorous problems.
    But there is another problem. Consider, not 1 or 2, but rather
 

	1. Plato snores.
 
At this point in time, Plato doesn’t exist. So if he’s a (necessary) constituent of 3, then 3 doesn’t exist either. Both hard-line direct reference-theorists, Salmon and Soames deal with this by taking a desperate measure, saying that 3 exists and that its existence constitutively depends on Plato’s existence, and that that these two can be reconciled with each other --- by saying that 3 exists, albeit as a non-existent proposition.
     This is not necessary or plausible or helpful. 3 does exist. Plato does not. But the property of being identical with Plato, whatever it is, does exist. What is it to be Plato? To be Plato is, perhaps, to be a causal sequence that is initiated by the fertilizing of a certain egg by a certain spermatozoa. To be Plato is, perhaps, to have a soul of a certain kind. What we know is that, if something is Plato, it’s being Plato supervenes on something probably having to do with the mass-energy distribution in the cosmos – on its mode of origination, on the quotient of godliness in the particle-interactions that constitute it, on who knows what. In any case, even though Plato does not exist, the property of being identical with Plato does; and that’s why we can meaningfully say that Plato does not exist. For, in making such a statement, we aren’t picking out a non-object – which would, for that reason, cease to be a non-object  – and then saying of it that it doesn’t exist. We are saying of an existing  property, that of being identical with Plato, that it is uninstantiated.     But our analysis is still consistent with the heart of direct-reference-theory, this being the idea that, for some x such that x is identical with Plato, the proposition meant by “Plato snores” is true just in case x snores, it being completely irrelevant what properties (other than being a snorer) x has. (The Fregean indirect-referentialist holds that for “Plato snores” to be correct is necessary that, for example, a unique great philosopher to die of hemlockpoisoning snore.) It is clear why our analysis is consistent on this matter with the viewpoint of the direct referentialist. According to our analysis, 3 is true exactly if the following properties are instantiated:
 

	a. the property of being identical with Plato

	b. the property of snoring.

	c. the property of being a Plato who snores.

	d. the property of being something that snores.

	e. the property of being something that does something (or has someproperty).
 
It is readily seen that, on our analysis, there is some x, such that x is Plato, such that 3 is true exactly if x snores, it being irrelevant what other properties x has. This is exactly what the direct-referentialist holds. At the same time, our analysis guarantees the existence of the proposition that Plato snores  -after all, the property of being Plato exists, even though it is now uninstantiated. So our analysis of that Plato snores gives the direct-referencetheorist the truth-conditions that he wants and that (given certain compelling arguments due to Kripke 1980 and Soames 2003, 2004) he probably deserves. At the same time, our analysis doesn’t put the direct-referencetheorist in the awkward, logic-bending position of having to say that the proposition that Plato snores exists despite the failure of existence of entities on whose existence its own existence is constitutively necessary.
 
III. Molecular propositions
 
       Our analysis applies to molecular propositions, no less than to atomic propositions. But making this transposition go through will involve a certain amount of sensitivity to details and technicalities. A certain amount of “engineering”, as opposed to philosophy “proper”, will be needed.
      
Existence-claims: an introduction
 
   In keeping with tradition, I will treat generalizations as molecular propositions. So
 
4. something snores
 
is an existential generalization. Given what we’ve said, the most obvious analysis of 4 would be to say that 4 is the property of snoring (or a set whose sole member is that property) and that 4’s being true is identical with that property’s being instantiated.
     That would not be the correct analysis. Even though 4 is true just in case the property of snoring is instantiated, 4 is not identical with that property and its truth is not identical with that property’s being instantiated. We know from Frege that 4, unlike the property of snoring, has a rather distinctive decompositional structure, and that 4 thus consists of (at least) three or four
[394]
	constituents. We also know from Frege what the first two constituents are:
 

	a. the property of snoring

	b. the property of being instantiated
 
   Using Conceit # 8, it is not hard to generate some (if not all) of the remaining constituents of 4, these being:
 
 

	a. the property of being an instantiated function each of whose instancessnores.

	b. the property of an instantiated function each of whose instances has someproperty or other.
  
      Let S be a set containing all and only a-d.  4 will be true iff a-d are instantiated. So, from the viewpoint of truth-conditions, there is no barrier to identifying 4 with S or to identifying 4’s being true with S’s members’ being instantiated. Further, 4’s structure is easily mapped onto S’s. 4, if true, entails that there exists some property that has some instances; that there exists at least one snorer; that at least one property is instantiated; and that at least one property exists. And all of this is precisely what S’s members’ being instantiated involves.
     Now consider the proposition:
 
5 Something smokes.
 
By reasoning similar to that just given, the constituents of this proposition are:
 
a* the property of smoking b the property of being instantiated
c.* the property of an instantiated function each of whose instances smokes.
d. the property of an instantiated function each of whose instances has some property or other.
 
   We know pre-theoretically that 4 and 5 have certain constituents in common (e.g. the property of being instantiated or, in any case, some property expressed by “something”). Our analysis of 4 and 5 validate everything we know, theoretically and pre-theoretically, about the decompositions and logical forms of the propositions.
    Before considering “nothing snores”, I want to consider a negative, but non-quantified, proposition:
 
6. Timmy is not smoking,
 
in other words,
 
6. It is not the case that Timmy is smoking.
 
   (The reason for the underlining will be clear in a moment.) Here we need to remember Conceit #7. The two immediate constituents of 6 would appear to be “It is not the case” and “that Timmy is smoking.” But there’s a problem here. We have said that propositions are sets of properties that are true when instantiated. In any case, this is what we have said about atomic propositions and, for uniformity’s sake, this is what we must say about molecular propositions. But if we say that, in 6, the underlined proposition is instantiated, i.e. that all its members are instantiated, then that Timmy is smoking will be true and 6 will be false and indeed self-negating.
     Not-P is true just in case P is false. So “not” can be though as expressing a function that assigns truth to all and only false propositions or (what, in this context, is scarcely different) as a property of all and only false propositions.
       For the reason given a moment ago, we don’t want to say that that Timmy is smoking is a constituent of 6, and will instead say that the property of being identical with that proposition is such a property. We will also say that the property of being a false proposition is such a constituent. Then, following Conceit #8, we synthesize those two components into: the property of being the false proposition that Tommy is smoking. That property, it will be noticed, is instantiated exactly if the proposition that Tommy is smoking is false. So, according to our analysis, the constituents of 6 are:
 

	a. the property of being a false proposition

	b. the property of being identical with the proposition that Tommy is smoking

	c. the property of being identical with a proposition that is false and that isidentical with that Tommy is smoking.
 
Let S be the set containing all and only a-c. Let us consider what happens when each of S’s members is instantiated. First, suppose that c is instantiated. In that case, there is an instance of a proposition that is false and that is identical with the proposition that Tommy is smoking. So 6 is true just in case c is instantiated. Since, if c is instantiated if the other members of S are instantiated, it follows that 6 is instantiated if, and only if, each of the members of S is instantiated. Thus, there are, as of yet, no bars to identifying 6 with S and 6’s truth with S’s members’ being instantiated.
     Next, suppose that b is instantiated. In that case, the property Tommy is smoking exists -- but it isn’t necessarily true. And if 6 should be true – which, according to our analysis, would mean that all of a-c were instantiated – we’d be stuck with the existence, but not the truth of the proposition that Tommy is smoking. Which is precisely what we want.
     Finally, suppose that a is instantiated. In that case, the property of being a false proposition is instantiated. And, of course, if 6 is true – if, in other words, the members of S are all instantiated – then that property is instantiated. Which, again, is precisely what we want. So our analysis most of our intuitions about the decomposition of 6 (the one exception that being that, where our pretheoretic intuition wants to that Tommy is smoking in 6, our analysis puts the property of being identical with that proposition in its place), and is inconsistent with the logical properties of that sentence.
   Let us now return to quantified propositions. Consider:
 
   7. Everything snores.
 
    By reasoning similar to that already given, the main constituents of this are:
 
a the property of snoring b the property of being universally instantiated c the property of being identical with a universally instantiated property that is identical with the property of snoring.
 
   Notice that, as always, we just used Conceit #8 to generate the third constituent. c is a property each of whose instances is an instance both of (a) the property of snoring and (b) of the property of being universally instantiated.
   Let us now consider:
 
8. Nothing snores.
 
     I will treat this is as the negation of 5. I will treat it, in other words, as:
 
8: It is not the case that something snores.
 
For reasons now already clear, the constituents of 8 include (but are not confined to):
 
a the property of being a false proposition b the property of being identical with the proposition that something snores c the property of being identical with a false proposition that is identical with the proposition that something snores.
 
Notice that, if c is instantiated, so are b and a. And notice that, if c is instantiated, then the proposition that something snores is false. Finally, notice that c is generated from a and b by conceit #8. Any instance of 6 is an instance both of (a) the property of being a false proposition and (b) the
[395]
property of being identical with that Tommy smokes.
 
Non-quantified molecular propositions
 
Let’s finish up by considering two non-quantified molecular propositions. First,
 
9 Tommy is smoking or Tommy is snoring.
 
Vaguely in the spirit of Montague (who was vaguely in the spirit of Frege), I see 9 as basically saying of a certain pair of propositions (that pair consisting of that Tommy is smoking and that Tommy is snoring) that at least one its members is true. I thus see 9 as consisting of:
 
a the property of disjunction, which in this context we may regard as the property of being a pair of sentences at least one of which is true,
 
and
 
b. the property of being a pair of propositions, one of them being that Tommy is smoking, the other being that Tommy is snoring.
 
Of course, 9 could be false even if both a and b were instantiated. (This would be the case if both Tommy is smoking and Tommy is snoring were false, but some one member of some other pair propositions were true.) So, using Conceit #8, we look for a third constituent. That constituent must be a property c such that each instance of c is (a) an instance of a pair of sentences, at least one of which is true, and (b) an instance of a pair of propositions, one them being that Tommy is smoking, the other being that Tommy is snoring. So our final properties are:
 
a the property of being a pair of sentences, at least one of which is true;

	a. the property of being a pair of propositions, one of them being that Tommy is smoking, the other being that Tommy is snoring;

	b. the property of being a pair of sentences, at least one of which is true, andat least one of which is that Tommy is smoking and at least one of which is that Tommy is snoring.
 
Of course, if c is instantiated, then so are b and c. And if c is instantiated, then either Tommy is snoring or Tommy is smoking. So c, and therefore a-c, are instantiated exactly if 9 is true. So if S is the set containing a-c, then 9 is true iff all of S’s members are instantiated.
 
     We’ve thus made it clear (i) what it is for something to be a “constituent” of a proposition”, (ii) what it is for an argument to “saturate” a function, (iii) more generally what it is for two propositional constituents to “synthesize” into a third constituent, (iv) what it is to be a proposition, and (v) what it is for a proposition to be true. And our analysis is, with some minor exceptions, consistent with what pretheoretic intuition and common sense have to tell us about propositions.
 
Section III   Alternative analyses
 
      According to Russell (1903), Salmon (1986), Kaplan (1989). R. Moore (1995), J. Perry (1996), J. King (1996, 1997), to name but a few, a proposition is some kind of “structure” consisting of “objects and “properties.” So, according to this view, “Socrates is bald” is some kind of structure consisting of Socrates – the man himself, not some property that he has or some concept that he satisfies – and the property of baldness. Little if anything is said beyond that. It is usually said that the structure is not an unordered pair – that it is not (Socrates, baldness) – but has some kind of ordinal structure and is therefore <Socrates, baldness> or < the relation of having <Socrates, baldness>>, or some such.
[396]
	      Two questions arise. The ordered pair <2,7> isn’t true or false. Neither is the ordered pair <2,7 <less than>>. Given that these ordered pairs aren’t true or false, why is <Socrates, the relation of having <baldness>> true or false? There’s no denying that we could use this as a expressing the proposition now expressed by the sentence “Socrates is bald.” We could obviously invent a code whereby “<the relation of having <Socrates, baldness>>” meant Socrates is bald. But this fact – the fact that “Socrates is bald” can be expressed by this new notation -- doesn’t tell us anything about the structure of the corresponding proposition that we didn’t already know from the fact that it can be expressed by “Socrates is bald.”
    There is another concern. Obviously the brackets are meant to be symbolic of some kind of order that holds among Socrates and baldness (and the relation of having). But what is that ordinal relation? If that ordinal relation bears no resemblance to the relation that would actually be had, by Socrates, with respect to the property of baldness, in a situation where he was bald, then it wouldn’t be clear, at least not obviously, why what relation was the right one: some kind of reason – the likes of which have never been provided by advocates of this model – would have to be provided why this particular ordinal relation (whose nature, by the way, has not, to my knowledge, been disclosed) was the right one. So, thus construed, the analysis in question is highly programmatic. On the other hand, if that relation is the very relation that would be had by Socrates, with respect to the property of baldness, in a situation where he was bald, then Socrates’ baldness – his actual baldness – would be built into the very existence of the proposition that he was bald. In other words, the proposition that Socrates was bald would, by virtue of its own configuration, make him bald, and would thus predetermine its own truth. But obviously the truth of Socrates is bald isn’t self-determining. Basically, if propositions model facts too well, then they force contingent propositions to be true. If we turn the proposition Socrates is (or was) bald into a model consisting of Socrates standing in the relation of having with respect to baldness, then the proposition itself is the fact of Socrates’ being bald, and no way is left open for the obvious possibility that that proposition might well be false.
     There is another problem with the view in question. Though is now false, the  proposition Socrates is alive obviously exists. In any case, it would be very artificial to maintain that that proposition didn’t exist. What if, unbeknownst to you, your friend Joey died some time during the last five minutes? Surely you wouldn’t want to say that the proposition Joey loves to read suddenly ceased to exist. Apart from an acceptance of a certain version of direct-reference theory, there is no reason to accept that view.
      According to the view that I am advocating, what is a constituent of the proposition Joey likes to read is the property of being identical with Joey.
[397]
 And that property doesn’t go away even when Joey passes on (it only ceases to be instantiated), leaving my analysis without the problem had by the
[398] Russellian analysis just mentioned.
     Frege held it wasn’t Socrates per se that was a part of the proposition Socrates is alive but was instead some concept that Socrates uniquely satisfied. (Frege’s analysis is therefore consistent with the fact that “Joey
[399]
	likes to read” holds onto its meaning even if Joey ceases to exist.) But, apart from that, Frege’s view is quite as vague as Russell’s. Frege was extremely opaque about the nature of the structure of this proposition; and what he failed to provide in the way of clear formulations he tried, unsuccessfully, make up for with rather unhelpful terms such as “saturate.” .      What is good about the Russell-Frege-Kaplan-King view is that it insists that propositions resemble the sentences that express them. So that view is, at least, consistent with the fact that languages can be learned and used (after all, learning and using languages involves there being systematic ways of hooking up meanings to sentences). And, as we’ll now see, other analyses don’t do such a good job of satisfying this requirement.
      For a while, it was widely held (by e.g. Clarence Lewis and Rudolph
Carnap) that the “intension” (what we would now call a “meaning” or “proposition”) of a sentence was identical with the class of all propositions that could be inferred from that sentence. So (a natural extension of this view would be that) the proposition John knows that corn is yummy is the class of all propositions deducible from that proposition, e.g. John believes that corn is yummy, John knows something, John has some kind of attitude towards the proposition that corn is yummy. There are a few problems with this view, some minor, some major. A minor problem is that, as it was stated by Lewis and Carnap, it is viciously circular, since many propositions that can be deduced from John believes that corn is yummy that involve that very proposition, e.g. John believes that corn is yummy and either John believes that corn is yummy or there are square circles. This particular problem is not, I believe, insuperable, since the position can be amended to avoid it. The right emendation would seem to be: A proposition is identical with the class of propositions that don’t comprise that proposition that can inferred from it.        Even so, the position in question isn’t very plausible. Consider the class of all propositions that follow from John believes that corn is yummy. That class doesn’t have a structure corresponding even remotely to the structure that we would expect that proposition to have, give that it almost certainly has a structure similar (in some non-trivial ways) to the sentences that express it. Also, in order to figure out whether a given proposition is a consequence of John believes that corn is yummy, one must, it seems, grasp that proposition itself. The set of propositions that follow from John believes that corn is yummy is infinitely large. One can grasp that set only in the sense that one grasps some rule that generates its members – obviously one cannot grasp them all one by one. And grasping that rule would involve grasping John believes that corn is yummy or some other similar proposition.     Now we turn to what is, these days, perhaps the most popular analysis of propositions and, indeed, of modality: the possible worlds analysis.
According to possible worlds semantics (PWS) a proposition is necessary if true in all (possible) worlds, and a proposition is a function that assigns truths-values to worlds or, alternatively, is a set of worlds. So the proposition grass is green is a function that assigns truth to all the world where grass is green, falsity to worlds where grass is not green, and either assigns falsity or no truth-value to grass-free worlds.
       In this context, the first question to ask is: what is meant by the term “world?” Oftentimes, advocates of PWS say that “worlds”, as they are using the term are propositions (or sets of propositions). In that case, as David Lewis (1986) was quick to point out, the PWS slogan that “a proposition is a set of worlds” becomes “a proposition is a set of propositions”, which is not only false but viciously regressive, the same thing mutatis mutandis holding of the statement “a proposition is a function that assigns truth-values to worlds.” (This is one of the reasons Lewis, an advocate of PWS, chose to use the word “world” literally.)
       Some advocates of PWS – aware that treating worlds as propositions (or sets thereof) eviscerates PWS – say that worlds are just that – worlds:
concrete objects like our own, “maximal states of affairs.” Not – nota bene – properties that, if instantiated would be worlds. But actual worlds.         Here we run into several problems. First, not too many are going to grant the existence of bona fide alternative worlds. Second, even if they do exist – and maybe they do (who knows?) – we can’t know anything about them except what we can figure out on the basis of  modal knowledge obtained  independently of our knowledge of those worlds. In On the Plurality of Worlds, Lewis says, rightly, that we don’t know about alternative worlds by taking a tour of them. We know about them by considering materials that are available to us here and “employing a principle of recombination” – by, basically, applying modal principles that we already know to hold and then seeing if those principles square with the proposition whose modal status we wish to know  (e.g. there might be square circles in other worlds). But in that case, the worlds answer to us, not us to them. Our modal knowledge is the tail that wags the dog of these other worlds; and from the viewpoint of explaining (or validating) our modal knowledge, those extra worlds are useless (though there may be other good reasons for positing
[400]
them).
      There are other problems with PWS (considered as an analysis of what propositions are). The class of worlds where 1+1=2 is identical with the class of worlds triangles have three sides. But those propositions are obviously
[401]
	distinct. That’s you can think the one without thinking the other. (And there’s no intensional fallacy here, since propositions are intensions.) In its most primitive form, PWS can’t distinguish analytically equivalent propositions. Some advocates of PWS deal with this by saying the following:
 
There are two ways of thinking of what functions are. A function can be though of as a a set of ordered pairs. So, from that viewpoint, the function F(x)=x+1 just is the set of pairs: <1,2>, <2,3>….And from that viewpoint, F(x)=x+1 is identical with the function F(x)=x+(90-89). This is the extensional view of functions: functions just are the pairs they generate – how they generate them is irrelevant. But extensionalist view of functions isn’t the only one, since there’s also the intensionalist view. The intensionalist says that functions are individuated by how they generate the pairs they generate. So, for the intensionalist, for functions to be identical, it is necessary but not sufficient that they generate the same ordered pairs. To avoid falsely identifying distinct, analytically equivalent propositions, PWS must take an intensionalist view of functions. So propositions are functions, and those functions are individuated by their intensions, not their extensions.
 
       There are two problems here. First, this view still demands that there be other worlds. If those worlds are propositions, then we’re no further along. If those worlds are concrete, then we’re stuck with some dubious (and, I believe, demonstrably useless) metaphysical lumber. But leaving those problems aside, the solution just proposed collapses on itself. Propositions are intensions (though not all intensions are propositions, e.g. the propositional function x is a human being is not a proposition, even though it is an intension). This by itself is a problem for PWS since much of its raison d’etre is that it replaces intensions, which for various reasons are seen as inimical to scientific thought, with extensions, which are seen as methodologically unimpeachable. So in taking an intensionalist view of functions, PWS is undermining itself. For, in taking such a view, PWS is letting properties back in – properties are no longer to be identified with sets of their instances. But, by parity of reasoning, propositions needn’t be identified with sets of their instances, i.e. with sets of worlds where they hold. So PWS cannot, without arbitrariness, take an intensionalist view of functions but it cannot, without failing to distinguish between obviously distinct propositions, take an extensionalist view of them either. 
        Here’s a similar problem. Consider the proposition grass is green. As we know, PWS identifies that proposition with a function (that assigns truth to worlds where grass is green) or with a set of worlds (containing all and only those worlds where grass is green). If it isn’t thought of as a set of ordered pairs, that function must be thought of as a rule of some kind. What kind of rule? One  that assigns truth to certain worlds on the basis of their satisfying some condition. What condition is that? The condition that, in those, grass is green. So the function in question, understood intensionally, must be understood in terms of the very proposition in question. Thus, unless the advocate of PWS wants to falsely identify 1+1=2 with triangles have three sides, he must take an intensionalist view of functions, which means that he must circularly understand the functions with which he aspires to identify propositions with the very propositions that aspires to identify them with.
        Frege made it clear that propositions are not ideas; they are the contents of people’s ideas, but are not themselves psychological entities. Since Frege, many attempts have been made to say what propositions are. (Some, e.g.
[402]
	Quine, have, at least at times, denied their existence. But that is a topic for another paper.) Those attempts have either been programmatic to the point of near-emptiness or demonstrably false or both.
         But given a certain healthy dose of Platonism, it is not impossible to identify structures that model the properties that know, on both theoretical and commonsensical grounds, propositions to have. Given any proposition P, it is clear that there is some set of properties p1…pn that will be instantiated just in case P is true. Supposing that S is the set containing those properties, this suggests that S is P and that P’s being true is S’s members’ being instantiated.
        We found that, taking this approach, we could give non-metaphorical meanings to terms that, though liberally used, have thus far been used in a purely metaphorical way – terms like “constituent” and “synthesize.” A “constituent” of a proposition, we found reason to believe, is a member of the set of a properties whose joint-instantiatedness is necessary and sufficient for that proposition’s truth. As for the term “synthesize”: since all components of propositions are properties, only properties can, in any relevant sense. be synthesized. And two properties p1 and p2 are “synthesized” into another component when a third property p3 is identified each of whose instances is an instance of both p1 and p2. Though no doubt imperfect and incomplete, it seems to me that this conception of what propositions are has sufficient promise to warrant its being considered and, perhaps, its being further developed.
 
Fodor on Concepts: How to be a non-Atomist without being a Holist
 
        By a “concept”, I mean one’s ability to think about a thing. I am able to have thoughts about Socrates; therefore I have a concept of the man. I am able to have thoughts about the number four; therefore I have a concept of that entity.
       Jerry Fodor argues that, with a few trivial exceptions, our concepts are “atoms”. A grasp of any one thing presupposes a grasp of nothing else. I can have a concept of knowledge without having a concept of truth or belief or justification. I can have a concept of causality without have a concept  of space or time or persistence. I can have a concept of Socrates without having a concept of  corporeality, location in space or time, movement in space, or causality, personal identity, or sentience.
    To sum up: For Fodor, one can have a concept of (practically) any one thing without having a concept of anything else. A grasp of (practically) anything presupposes a grasp of nothing. Our concepts are “atoms”; they are indivisible and ultimate; they cannot (typically) be broken down into other concepts.
      Fodor provides three ingenious arguments for this astonishing position. The purpose of this paper is examine those arguments. I believe that all three arguments involve non-sequiturs. Where the first two are concerned, the nonsequiturs are, I believe, fairly obvious. But the non-sequitur involved in the third is by no means obvious; and to expose it, we will have to put forth some substantive positive theses about the nature of concepts.  
 
§    Let us start with a terminological point. The term “concept” is ambiguous. The word “concept” can refer to some platonic, non-mental entity, as in: “anything falling under the concept square also falls under the concept closed figure.” But the word “concept” also has a psychological sense; it can refer to one’s grasp of something, as in: “Locke identified concepts with mental images” or “before 1930, nobody had a concept of a quark”.   
     We need two different words here, if we are to avoid intolerable
[403] confusion. To denote concepts in the non-mental sense, let us use the word “concepto” (plural: “conceptso”).  To denote concepts in the psychological sense, let us simply use the word “concept” (no subscript). [404]
    I will talk about “having” concepts and “grasping” conceptso. I have a concept (no subscript) of the number two. And I grasp the corresponding concepto.
 
§     Here is a view about concepts that certainly has at least some initial plausibility. It is the view that I hold and that Fodor rejects.
    Possession of any one concept presupposes possession of others. To grasp any one thing, one must be able to grasp others. One cannot think about, or mentally represent, a given thing unless one think about others. Consider the concepto of a square. Suppose some creature had no idea what it was for a figure to have four sides, or what it was for an edge to be straight. Would that thing have any idea what it was for something to be a square? Intuitively, the answer seems to be “no”. So to grasp the concepto square, one must grasp the conceptso of the number four, of straightness, of flatness, and so on.       Of course, what we just said about the concepto square applies to a grasp any one of these concepts. Consider the concepto of the number four. To have a concept of that thing, one presumably has to have a concept of the numbers three, two and so on. To have concepts of those things, one must presumably have concepts of magnitude, order, and who knows what else.      The concepto of a square might seem like a tendentious one. A square is a structure; to be a square just is to have certain structural or ordinal features. So given only that a grasp of that concepto presupposes a grasp of others, perhaps no general truths follow regarding the nature of conception.       But what is obviously true of the concepto square is, at least arguably, true of all other conceptso – even those that seem that most devoid of structure. Consider the concepto of redness. One might naively think that an otherwise conceptless creature could grasp this concepto. All the creature needs is the ability to have a certain kind of phenomenal content – it doesn’t need an articulated network of background concepts.
      But such a view is dubious. An object that really is red -- i.e. that has the microphysical properties common to stop-signs, apples, and the like – can be given to a person of good eyesight through very different sorts of phenomenal contents. You have 20/20 vision. You look at the apple from place p1. The phenomenology of your perception of its color is one way. You look at the apple from place p2. Now the phenomenology of your perception of its color is different. This is the case even if you are looking at the apple under optimal conditions – you’re in a brightly lit room, your eyes in perfect working order, and so on. No matter how “optimal” or “standard” the conditions of perception are, there will never be a one-one correspondence between things’ actual colors and your phenomenology. A given shade of red will given to you through different phenomenal contents.
    Any artist knows this. If you want to depict its color as it appears to you from p1, you use one mix of paint. If you want to depict its color as it appears to you from p2, you use a different mix of paint. This is the case, as any artist knows, not just if you are in a room with bad or uneven lighting: it holds even in circumstances where the lighting conditions are optimal – where they are unnaturally good.
    To see something as having a certain color isn’t just to have an experience with a certain phenomenology. When you just see, so to speak, that something is red, a wealth of background information is operative. Phenomenology is certainly part of the story, but not all of it. The phenomenology has to be appropriately contextualized. And this contextualization seems to presuppose some understanding of the conditions of perception; it thus presupposes an articulated picture of the world. So even a concept of redness – surely our best candidate for a “simple” concept, a concept that doesn’t presuppose a wealth of other concepts  – is available to only to a creature with a formidable representational endowment.     What about purely phenomenal concepts? Consider the experience of tasting honey. Consider what it is like to have that kind of experience. Perhaps an otherwise conceptless creature could have a concept of what it is like to have that kind of experience. So here, it will be thought, we have found a genuinely simple and foundational concept.
    But even here there is room for doubt. First of all, there is a difference between, on the one hand, being able to have an experience with that sort of phenomenology, and on the other hand, having a concept of that sort of experience. Perhaps the ability to have that kind of phenomenal content doesn’t require any sort of conceptual background. But that doesn’t mean that the same is true of the ability to have a concept of that kind of experience. Having a concept of that kind of experience would seem to involve being able to recognize that occurrence of states with that sort of phenomenology
[405]
	and also have thoughts about such states. Even though (perhaps) little or no cognitive wherewithal is needed to have the phenomenology, it is hard to believe that the same is true of the ability to recognize the phenomenology
for what it is. To recognize is to single out. Singling a thing out seems to involve knowing how that thing is different from other things. So, at least on the face of it, recognizing a thing involves having a concept of how thing differs from other things. So having a concept of a certain kind of phenomenology would seem to involve being able to compare it with other things, and thus to presuppose that one has concepts of those other things. So while the ability to experience a certain kind of phenomenal content may be conceptually innocent, the same appears not to be true of the ability to have concept of that sort of experience.
       Let us state what this extremely brief survey has told us. There does not appear to be any concept  that we can have without having others. There does not appear to be any concepto that one can grasp without grasping many others.
     But there is more to say. Obviously we don’t just grasp conceptso; we also grasp spatiotemporal objects – rocks, trees, and the like. Let us briefly talk about our concepts of these things.
   We know about external objects entirely through sense-perception. A sense-perception necessarily presents things as having various properties – as having a certain color, shape, location, state of motion. Strictly speaking, what is given to one in sense-perception is never (just) a thing: it is a state of affairs. You don’t just see the rock. You see a state of affairs involving the rock: you see an object of a certain shape, color, relative location, and so on. If a thing is to be represented to you as having a certain color, location, state of motion, and so on, it seems to follow that – at some level, in some way – you have cognitive access to these properties: concepts of these properties constitute your representational palette.
    So any sense-perception has a great deal of “descriptive structure”, and also presupposes some kind of cognitive access to a wealth of properties.
Since sense-perception is essentially involved in our being able to think about external objects, it would seem to follow that our concepts of such objects are replete with conceptual structure.
     To sum up, there is at least something to be said for the following view. A concept of a conceptso always seems to presuppose networks of background concepts. The same is true of our concepts of external objects. Attempts to find genuinely foundational concepts – concepts an otherwise conceptless creature can have – seem to bear no fruit. Our best candidates for that honor (e.g. the concepto of what it is for something to be red, the concepto of what it is to have an experience with such and such phenomenology) turn out to bristle with exactly the sort of structure we were hoping they wouldn’t have.      So, on the face of it, there seem to be no atomic concepts – no concepts that are not to some degree constituted by other concepts. There seems to be no concept C such that a creature could have C without also having various other concepts. There are no foundational concepts. After all, a foundational concept is one such that possession of it doesn’t presuppose possession of others.
 
§      In Concepts, Jerry Fodor argues for the exact opposite of this view. He argues that, with some trivial exceptions, all concepts are atoms. For any concept C, possession of C does not presuppose possession of other concepts. In principle, one could have a concept of knowledge without a concept of belief or truth (this is one of Fodor’s own examples); of justice without having a concept of sentience; of existence in the external world without having a concept of persistence in space and time or of causality; of Tuesday without having a concept of Monday (again, one of Fodor’s own examples).      Fodor’s overall view is generally rejected. Most hold that atomism is false. But it has not yet been said, to my satisfaction, just where his arguments for that view go wrong. In this respect, Fodor is a latter day Berkeley. Everybody thinks that Berkeley is wrong: of course there are mindindependent objects. But it is not often that one hears it clearly stated just where Berkeley’s reasoning goes astray. Similarly, no one has, in my view, pinpointed the non-sequiturs in Fodor’s arguments, though many take it for granted that his conclusion is false.
     In this paper, I will present Fodor’s three arguments, and I will try to show where  they go astray. One those arguments involves a fairly blatant nonsequitur. But the other two are quite sturdy. Identifying the fallacies in them involves producing some positive alternative theories about the nature of conception, and  is therefore not a zero-sum affair.
     
§  First of all, Fodor actually uses the term “conceptual atomism” to refer to two distinct (though related) doctrines.
 
 

	* One’s grasp of a given thing does not typically presuppose a grasp of other things.  No concept presupposes possession of any other concept.
 
 

	* Conceptso (note the subscript) are atoms. They cannot be broken down into other conceptso. Consequently, there are (with some trivial exceptions)
[406]
no analytic truths.
 
 
    As we discussed, it certainly seems that, if one grasps the concepto knowledge, one also grasps the concepto true belief. This is exactly what Fodor denies. In his view, one could grasp the concepto knowledge without grasping any other conceptso.     
    Fodor admits that there are some exceptions to this. A grasp of the concepto red cow is not an atom, as it plainly consists of a grasp of the concepto red and also the concepto cow. The same is true of the concepto prime number. If the concepto one is grasping is patently synthesized out of
[407]
other conceptso, then a grasp of it is not an atom. But with these exceptions, one’s grasp of a concepto is always an atom.
      Fodor’s denial of (i) is connected with his denial of (ii). Fodor thinks that conceptso (with the trivial exceptions just given) have no internal structure. The concepto knowledge has no constitutive connections to the conceptso belief or truth or justification. Of course, if Fodor is right about that, then we can see why a grasp of knowledge wouldn’t presuppose a grasp of these other conceptso.
     Fodor obviously admits that conceptso typically appear to have a great deal of analytic structure. Obviously knowledge is always true appears to be analytic; and so do 2 comes before 3 and causes precede their effects. He goes to great and ingenious lengths to explain away this appearance of
[408]
	analyticity. We will consider these efforts soon enough.
     Fodor grants that there are some analytic truths. The concepto red cow is “patently phrasal”, as Fodor puts it. It is obviously built out of other conceptso (red and cow). Any such concepto will clearly be associated with various analytic truths. (x is a red cow implies, and is implied by, the conjunction x is red and  x is a cow.) Fodor grants the existence of analyticities of that kind.  And Fodor grants that x is a cow entails x is a cow.  Notice that those analyticities are trivial. They don’t expose any hidden depths on the part of the relevant conceptso. In Fodor’s view, all analytic truths are in the same category as:
 
(*)  if x is a red cow, then x is a cow.
 
    We can be a little more precise about this. (Here we are going beyond what
Fodor himself says.) In (*), the non-logical terms occur inessentially. Suppose you replace “cow” with “horse”. The result will be a truth. Suppose you replace “red” with “green” or “square”: what results will be a truth. The truth of (*) doesn’t turn on anything peculiar to the conceptso red and cow. Any other concepts could take their place. Since (*) doesn’t turn anything peculiar to those conceptso, it doesn’t really tell you anything about them. It doesn’t tell you how those conceptso are different from the conceptso horse and green.
     Now consider the proposition:
 
(**) Any case of knowledge is a case of true-belief (but not vice versa).
 
If you replace “knowledge” with “justice”, or if you replace “true” with
“green”,  what results is a falsehood (or possibly nonsense). So in (*), “knowledge” occurs essentially. The truth of (**) turns on something peculiar to the conceptso knowledge and belief and so forth.  
        Fodor grants analytic status to propositions like (*) – propositions whose truth doesn’t turn anything peculiar to the conceptso occurring therein. Fodor denies analytic status to propositions like (**) – propositions whose truth does turn on the peculiarities of the conceptso involved. He appears to grant analytic status to propositions that are formally true. But apart from that, he seems to think that there are no, or very few, analytic truths. (Fodor seems to think that bachelors are unmarried males is analytically true. But even here he has reservations.)
 
§ Fodor provides three arguments for atomism. Let us turn to Fodor’s first of these. Two thousand years of work have yielded no unexceptionable definitions of ‘knowledge’, ‘justice’, or ‘number’. In fact, even the most pedestrian conceptso are indefinable. Consider the concepto associated with
[409]
the verb ‘to paint.’ Fodor goes through a number of reasonable-seeming definitions of this concepto, and shows that they all fail. For example, it might seem that ‘to paint’ something is just to cover it with paint. But this is not so. If you dip your paint-brush in a paint-bucket, you are not painting your brush, even though you are covering it with paint.
      Analogous remarks apply to attempted definitions of practically any concepto. Try giving a definition of ‘knowledge’ or ‘justice’. You’ll probably find that there is a counter-example to it.
      Given the apparent indefinability of most conceptso, Fodor infers that they have no structure: they are simples. The idea is that, if a concepto is not simple, then it is built out of other things, presumably other conceptso. If it is built out of other things, then there is obviously some true proposition saying how it is built out of those other things: there is a definition or analysis of that concepto. Since there are no adequate analyses of conceptso, it follows that they are not built out of other conceptso.
      On the face of it, this argument concerns conceptso, not concepts. It shows that conceptso – not conceptso – are atoms. But it indirectly supports the idea that conceptso are atoms. If two conceptso are not analytically related, then it is hard to see why a grasp of the one would involve a grasp of the other. So if no two conceptso are thus related, then it is hard to see why a grasp of any one concepto would presuppose a grasp of others.  The other side of the coin is that if any concepto is individuated by its analytic relations to various other conceptso, then presumably one must have some grasp of these analytic relations to grasp any given concepto: so one would have to grasp a multiplicity of conceptso to grasp a single one of them. So given that Fodor wants to defend the view that concepts (no subscript) are atoms, he is probably right to attack the view that conceptso (note the subscript) are atoms.
 
Evaluating Fodor’s 1st Argument
 
 
   This argument involves a non-sequitur. Given his premises, what Fodor should have concluded  is that conceptso have an infinite amount of internal structure. Fodor has made a case that it is hard to give conceptuallyo necessary and sufficient conditions for a thing’s falling under a concepto.
[410]
 But for practically any concepto, it is extremely easy to give conceptuallyo necessary conditions. (In effect, Fodor himself shows this.) Conceptuallyo necessary  conditions obviously correspond to analyticities. For x to be an act of painting, it is conceptuallyo necessary that x be an act of putting paint on something. This by itself shows that there is an internal or constitutive relation between ‘Bob painted y’ and ‘Bob put paint on y’ and, therefore, that the concepto ‘to paint’ has conceptual structure – is not an
[411]
atom.
     Fodor goes through several attempted definitions of the concepto paint (the concepto corresponding to the verb, not the noun, ‘paint’). He points out that, for each one of them, there is something that is not an act of painting that falls under that definition. What Fodor does not say is that each of these attempted definitions gives a necessary condition for x’s being an act of painting. So the evidence suggests that it is hard to give conceptuallyo necessary and sufficient conditions for x’s falling under the concepto paint. But the evidence also suggests that we can generate ad infinitum conceptuallyo necessary conditions for something’s being an act of painting. So given that necessary conditions indicate conceptual structure, it follows that paint has an infinite amount of conceptualo structure.
      This point applies mutatis mutandis to practically any other concepto one cites. Consider the concepto knowledge. It is easy to generate conceptually necessary conditions for x’s falling under that concepto. Gettierologists have generated countless such conditions. This is not to mention the ones that have always been known: x must be true and justified and a belief. So it seems possible to generate conceptuallyo necessary conditions ad infinitum for x’s being a case of knowledge. If that is right, then the concepto knowledge has an infinite amount of analytic structure, contrary to what Fodor says. If that is wrong, then Fodor is again wrong. Suppose that, after adding some more epicycles, Gettierologists produce a correct analysis of knowledge (x is knowledge iff x is reliably caused, justified, true, well-entrenched….belief). In that case, once again, Fodor is wrong to say that the concepto knowledge  has no analytic structure. 
   
§  Let us now turn to Fodor’s second argument. Right now, let us focus on one’s grasp of the concepto knowledge. Let us focus one’s concept (no subscript) of that concepto.  
     Suppose that one’s concept of knowledge really did implicate concepts of truth, justification, and belief – along with whatever concepts are presupposed by these concepts. In that case, we would expect cognitive operations concerning knowledge to be slower, requiring of more acumen, and generally more unwieldy than cognitive operations concerning justification or truth. But we find no such thing. Thought processes involving one’s concept of knowledge are at least  as speedy and energy-efficient as thought processes involving the concepts that – if the non-atomist view is correct – are constitutive of one’s knowledge-concept. Thoughts about knowledge are at least as speedy and efficient as thoughts about truth,
[412]
justification, belief, sentience, and so on.
    Of course, we must ask: why must it be the case that, if a grasp of knowledge implicates a grasp of truth, reliability, belief, and so on, then cognitive operations with knowledge would be slower than those with (say) truth? Here is Fodor’s answer. First of all, when it is said that one’s ability to think about knowledge ‘implicates’ or ‘presupposes’ an ability to think about (e.g.) truth, what is meant is not that there is some merely causal connection between the two abilities, but that there is some kind of metaphysical relation: what it is to be able to think about x as being a case of knowledge is (inter alia) to see that x has the properties of being a  belief that is nonaccidentally true and reliably caused …So for there to be some kind of constitutive relation between one’s ability to think about knowledge and one’s ability to think about  justification or truth is for there to be some metaphysically necessary relation between these two capacities.
    Given what Hume said, it seems that there can be no metaphysically necessary relation between x and y unless x makes up y or vice versa. (Identity can be seen as a limiting case of this relation.) If x and y are spatiotemporal entities – and surely concepts  are such things, for they are realized by configurations of neural matter – then no necessary relation can hold between them unless one of them literally makes up the other, unless, in effect, one of them is a part of the other. But if one’s 998-concept, and one’s 997-concept… make up one’s 999-concept, then presumably in exercising the latter, one is exercising the former. Of course, to ‘exercise’ one’s 999concept just is to think about 999. So it seems to follow that, if there are constitutive relations among one’s concepts of 999, 998, 997…then in thinking about 999, one is ipso facto thinking about 998, 997, 996…2 and 1.
But, as Fodor says,  it seems unlikely that I must simultaneously think about 1000 numbers to think about 999. Therefore, my 999-concept is not constitutively related to my 998-concept , my 997-concept …or to any other concepto of mine to which it might initially appear to be constitutively related.
 
Evaluating Fodor’s 2nd Argument
 
     This is a very clever argument. But it covertly assumes the very atomism
[413]
that it is meant to establish. What the non-atomist maintains is specifically that there are no atomic concepts: there are no concepts that are not constituted by other concepts. So there are no concepts “at the bottom” (for there is no bottom). What the non-atomist maintains is specifically that we mustn’t think of the body of our concepts as having a structure like that of a building – where there is a ground floor, a second floor resting on the ground floor, a third floor resting on the first two, and so on. What he maintains is specifically that our concepts support one another. The right metaphor is a web or arc, not a skyscraper.
     Fodor’s argument presupposes that, if non-atomism is right, the relation between one’s grasp of the concepto knowledge and one’s grasp of (say) the conceptso truth or justification is like the relation of the third story of a building to the second story: the one supports the other but not vice versa. Fodor seems to think that, if non-atomism is correct, then the relation between one’s grasp of the concepto and one’s grasp of the other is thus asymmetrical.
But this is exactly what the non-atomist denies. The non-atomist maintains specifically that there are no concepts at the bottom supporting everything else and that everything supports everything.
