Exactly the same thing (mutatis mutandis) is true of “Ichabod” and “Beezer”, and each of the other aforementioned names.      Let us focus on “Argo”. You are a part of the conversation in question; in any case, you overhear it. Within that conversation, there was some specific occasion on which Smith described some single person x as a cad; moreover, Smith referred to x as “Argo”. Here, of course, the term “occasion” is covering a small window of time. But, uncontroversially, within that narrow window, there was some one person whom Smith described as a cad, and to whom Smith referred as “Argo”. Since you are part of the conversation, you know this. When you hear Smith say “Argo is a cad”, you know that Smith is referring to a single person; and you can distinguish the occasion – the narrow window of time – in which Smith produced that sentence from the narrow window of time in which Smith said “Peewee is a cad”. And you can distinguish both occasions from the narrow window of time in which Smith aid “Beezer is a cad”. You can cognitively keep all of these occasions separate. Given any one of these occasions, you know that Smith was describing exactly one person x as a cad; and you also know which name Smith used to make that statement. So there is some specific occasion O such that, on O, Smith describing a single person x as a cad, and Smith used “Argo” to refer to x. And you know this: you know it merely by virtue of being a part of the colloquy in question. So merely by virtue of being a part of that discussion – nay, merely by virtue of over-hearing it – you know the truth of some claim of the form:
 
(*) on such and such occasion, somebody x was uniquely such that Smith described x as a cad, and Smith used “Argo” to refer  to x. 
 
There is only a trivial difference between (*) and:
 
(**) on such and such occasion, somebody x was uniquely such that Smith described x as a cad, and “Argo” refers  to x. 
 
  
 
    So merely by virtue of being in a position to “pick up” use of the term “Argo”, you are ipso facto in a position to know the truth of (**). Thus merely by virtue of being in a position to “pick up” use of the term “Argo some existence claim of the form: there is some x such that x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x.
    It is plain that what enables you to pick up the term “Argo” is you knowledge of some claim of the sort just described. Your picking up a term like “Argo” -- i.e. your appropriating it in manner (iii), as opposed to manner (ii) or (i) – involves your witnessing a sentence of the form “…Argo…” It involves your encountering a case of somebody’s ascribing a property to Argo. (This is true even if you read such sentence: you are still, in effect, encountering somebody’s using that sentence to make such a statement.) Whenever you witness a token of “Argo has phi” you are witnessing an occasion such that, on that occasion, there is somebody x such that, on that occasion, the property of being a phi is being ascribed to x and x alone; and you are also witness that, on said occasion, “Argo” is being used to refer to x. So if you “pick up” use of the word “Argo”, that involves the following: there is some specific occasion O such that you know that, on that occasion, exactly one person x is being described as having phi and “Argo” refers to x.
    We must be careful to distinguish the following claims:
 

	* Exactly one person has phi.

	* Exactly one person is being described, on some particular occasion, as having phi.
 
   There are many cads. But there are many occasions where only one person is being described as a cad
    Your picking up the word “Argo” doesn’t involve your learning the truth some claim like: exactly one person x is a cad, and “Argo” refers to x. Such a claim is false; there are many cads. Your picking up “Argo” involves your learning the truth of some claim: on some specific occasion, exactly one person x is being described as a cad, and “Argo” refers to x.
    We must take care to make one other distinction. Smith himself never uttered an existence claim of the form:  there is some x such that x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x.  Smith himself never uttered an existence claim of the form:   on occasion t, I (Smith) referred to somebody x as a cad and “Argo” refers  to x. Smith said only “Argo is a cad”, “Peewee is a cad”, and so forth. But the information that you are given, by virtue of being in discussion with Smith, is not confined to what Smith himself says. When Smith says “Argo is a cad”, the information that is encoded in his words is quite threadbare. But you are given information above and beyond that information; you witness Smith’s speech act. You put that speech act within a larger context; you have an enormous amount of information about when that speech act occurs. You know that it occurred after certain other events (e.g. before Smith spilled his beer) and before certain other events (e.g. before Jones made the unseemly pass at the waitress). In any case, even though what
Smith was saying might have been minimal, the information you have about Smith’s saying it  – about the context in which that speech-act occurred -- is enormous; and that information does sufficient to give you the right kind of uniquely individuating description. Smith’s words do not by themselves give you a uniquely individuating description that applies to Argo or Peewee or Ichabod. But there is something that does give you such a description: that something is your perception of the conversational context in which Smith uses the word “Argo”.
    There is no vicious circularity in this account. Smith personally met Argo.
He learned the meaning of “Argo” through an ostensive definition. Maybe Smith himself gave Argo the name “Argo”. In any case, Smith saw Argo, and then learned (or stipulated) that the thing he was seeing was named “Argo”.      You meet Smith. You have a conversation with him.  On some specific occasion within that conversation, Smith says “Argo was a cad”. You thus know that, on that occasion, there somebody x such that Smith is describing x, and only x, as a cad, and “Argo” is how Smith is referring to x. the uniquely individuating description you associated with “Argo” is not: “the unique person x such that x is named ‘Argo’”. Rather, it is: the unique person x such that, on such and such occasion, smith was describing x as a cad.”     In the circumstance just described, you are only at one remove from somebody who was directly acquainted with Argo – with somebody to whom “Argo” was defined ostensively.
    But what we’ve said applies equally to the case where you are at five hundred removes from the referent of the word in question. Consider this scenario. Smith doesn’t personally know Argo. But Smith knows Brown, and Brown personally knows Argo. Smith is not given an ostensive or descriptive definition of “Argo”. But Smith overhears Brown saying “Argo is a cad” or whatnot; and on this basis, Smith is able to add “Argo” to his own lexicon: we just described the principles governing such an addition. You then overhear Smith saying things like “Argo is a cad”, “Argo is a mean person”, or whatnot. You are not given an ostensive or descriptive definition of “Argo”. But on the basis of what you overhear, you are able to add “Argo” to your lexicon: the principles that govern Smith’s appropriation of “Argo” obviously apply to your appropriation of that name. By exactly similar reasoning, it wouldn’t matter if you were five hundred removes from somebody who was actually acquainted with Argo: the same principles would apply; and in each case, what would enable to use “Argo” to refer to Argo would be your knowledge of some claim of the form: something x uniquely has phi and “Argo” refers to x (where phi would be some property of the form: is a person who, on such and such occasion is being described as having thus and such property).
    OF course, words undergo degradation and alteration as they change hands. The first person who uses the word “Argo” might pronounce one way; the people who “pick up” that name from that person might pronounce it differently. But this fact obviously doesn’t affect the principles governing appropriation of that word. Brown might pronounce “Argo” one way; Smith might pronounce it differently; you might pronounce it a third way; the people to whom you transmit this word might pronounce it a fourth way. After a few transmissions, what is left might bear extremely little resemblance to Brown’s pronunciation. In some contexts, that fact is of importance. But that fact has no bearing on our point: that, whenever somebody “picks up” a name – whenever they add it to their lexicon in manner (ii) – it is in virtue of their having knowledge of a uniquely individuating description that applies to the referent. It is obvious how these points apply to names like “Socrates”. The word that Socrates’ own acquaintances used to refer to him was not “Socrates”; that word probably had some phonetic similarities to “Socrates”; but there were also non-trivial differences. Nonetheless, however distorted “Socrates” may be relative to the word that the Ancient Greeks used, the principles governing the “picking up” of that word – or any one of its ancestors or descendants, no matter how much phonetic distortion is involved – are the same. In each case, whenever one adds it to their lexicon in manner (ii) – it is in virtue of their having knowledge of a uniquely individuating description that applies to the referent, namely Socrates.
     So suppose that “Sukrat” is the Ancient Greek word for Socrates. Glaucon learns what “Sukrat” means through an ostensive definition. Glaucon is engaged in a discussion with Zenon. Glaucon never gives Zenon any ostensive or descriptive definition of “Suktrat”. But Glaucon does produce a sentence of the form “…Sukrat…” Thus, for reasons discussed, Zenon acquires the ability to use “Sukrat” to refer to Socrates; and, for reasons discussed, Zenon’s ability to this involves his knowing a uniquely individuating description that applies to Socrates. Zenon has a conversation with Phoebus. Zenon slightly mispronounces “Sukrat”. In a manner exactly analogous to that just described, Phoebus acquires the ability to use that, slightly mispronounced version of “Sukrat” to refer to Socrates. In this way, variants of “Sukrat” are transmitted from person to person, from generation to generation. What we are left with, two thousand years later, is a word that is quite different (at least phonetically) from “Socrates”. But one’s acquiring the ability to use that word, however distorted it might be relative to the original word for “Socrates”, involves one’s learning some uniquely individuating description that applies to Socrates; it involves one’s learning some true claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Socrates” has x. But, in most cases, “phi” will be some property like is described, on such and such occasion, by so and so, as having thus and such property. “Phi” will not be a property of historical moment; it will not be a property like great philosopher of antiquity who drank hemlock or philosopher who figured as the protagonist in most of Plato’s dialogues. The property in question will be some highly contextual one, some property that doesn’t connect in any significant way with Socrates’ intellectual or historical countenance.      Let us take stock. There are three ways you can add a referring term to your lexicon:
 

	* you can be given an ostensive definition; or

	* you can be given a descriptive definition; or

	* you can witness use of that word, and simply “inherit” it.
 
  We’ve found that whenever (i) or (iii) is the case, your ability to use the word involves your having knowledge of a uniquely individuating description of the referent of that word. Let us now consider the second of these three categories: descriptive definition.
     Here it is very easy to fall prey to a confusion. Imagine the following. You have never heard the word “Socrates” before. You are talking with your friend Charlie; he says “Seymour is a latter day Socrates”. You don’t know who “Socrates” refers to? So you ask: “Who is Socrates?” Charlie says:
“Socrates was the author of the Nichomachean Ethics and the Posterior Analytics”.
    Of course, Charlie is wrong; Socrates did not write either of those works; and “Socrates” does not refer to the author of either of those works. At the same time, in consequence of your having this exchange with Charlie, you can use the word “Socrates” to refer to Socrates.
    Here it seems as though you are able to refer to use the word “Socrates” to refer to Socrates, even though your only belief about him is wrong – even though the only thing you “know” about him isn’t true. But this appearance is misleading. What we have here is a case where you add a word to your lexicon in manner (iii). You do know some uniquely individuating description that applies to Socrates. But that description is not “the unique author of the Nichomachean Ethics and the Posterior Analytics”. Rather, it is: *the person to whom Charlie, on occasion t, ascribed the property of writing
[435]
the Nichomachean Ethics and the Posterior Analytics* , for some value of t.
     In most cases where we seem to be appropriating a name in manner (ii), we are in fact appropriating it in manner (iii). But we can certainly construct a case where, unmistakably, we are appropriating a name in manner (iii). (Here I basically repeating a point made, in different forms, by Kripke,
Kaplan, and Evans.) Suppose you and Charlie are having a conversation. Neither of you has any idea who invented the zipper. You and Charlie decide that, at least when speaking to each other, you will refer to that person, whoever it is, as “Julius”. So you have no idea who invented the zipper. But you kow that somebody did, and you have stipulated that Julius refers to that person.  Thus you have added a semantic rule to English (or, at any rate, to a certain idiolect of English). It must be made clear what that rule is. The rule is given by the following:
 
(Z) Somebody x uniquely invented the zipper, and “Julius” refers to x.
 
The descriptive information is given wide-scope with respect to the “refers to” operator. So if Smith was a unique zipper-inventor, then “Julius was a millionaire” means Smith was a millionaire. That sentence does not mean: somebody x uniquely invented the zipper and x was a millionaire. “Julius” is a name, not a quantifier.
    You and Charlie don’t know who “Julius” refers to. (nether do I.) But it does refer to somebody. On the face of it, it certainly seems as though you can use it significantly: you can, with understanding, say things like “Julius was probably a talented inventor” and “Julius must be worth a fortune”.      Some people have said that, under the circumstances, you cannot say things like “Julius must be worth a fortune” and really mean them. This may or may not be true (I will weigh in on this shortly). But what everybody will agree on is this. If you and I can use the term “Julius” with understanding, it is only because we know some true claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi, and “Julius” refers to x. Here, of course, phi is the property of inventing the zipper.
     I do not wish to be misunderstood. A strong case can be made that unless you know who invented the zipper, you don’t know which proposition is semantically encoded in “Julius must be worth a fortune”, and other such sentences.   What you know, it could be argued, is some like: for some object O, the sentence “Julius must be worth a fortune” is true exactly if O must be worth a fortune. Since you don’t know which object invented the zipper, you don’t know who “Julius” refers to; and you therefore don’t know which proposition is encoded in that sentence. But, at the same time, you have a kind of metalinguistic knowledge about “Julius must be worth a fortune” which, in some respects, simulates real understanding of it.
     Be all of this as it may, what is clear is that if, under the circumstances described, you or Charlie understand “Julius must be worth a fortune” – if, under those circumstances, you understand “Julius” – it is entirely because you know the truth of some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi [the property of inventing the zipper], and “Julius” refers to x.
    In everyday life, there are many cases where we seem to be adding a name to our lexicon in manner (ii). Suppose little Timmy has never heard the name “Shakespeare” before. You say to him: “Shakespeare is the person who wrote Romeo and Juliet”. Here it seems that the three year old is appropriating the name “Shakespeare” in manner (ii); for what you are telling him is, in effect:
there is some x such that x uniquely wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x.
   But really little Timmy has appropriated “Shakespeare” in manner (iii). A
Kripke-style argument shows this. After your conversation with him, little Timmy can make statements about Shakespeare; they may be wrong and illinformed; but they are wrong and ill-informed statements about Shakespeare. Let us suppose he does so; he asks “did Shakespeare like French fries?”, and says “Shakespeare must have been weird, because his writing is so funny”.     But what if it turns out Shakespeare did not write Romeo and Juliet? What if it turns out that, although he wrote Hamlet and King Lear and Timon of Athens, he didn’t write Romeo and Juliet? Does that mean that little Timmy’s old statements were blanks? Was the three year old not referring to anybody?
It seems not; it seems that little Timmy did manage to ask whether Shakespeare liked French fries.
    But if Little Timmy’s ability to refer to Shakespeare depended on Shakespeare’s having written Romeo and Juliet – if little Timmy’s ability to refer to Shakespeare depended on the accuracy of the statement: somebody uniquely wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x – then his statements would indeed have been abortive.
   What is going on here is that little Timmy added “Shakespeare” to his lexicon in manner (iii). He heard you refer to him; so the existence claim through which he added “Shakespeare” to his lexicon is something like: there is some x such that, on such and such occasion, Daddy said that x wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x.  And that existence-claim remains true, even though the other one -- somebody uniquely wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” refers to x – turns out false.
     What role did this other existence claim – the one that turned out wrong – have? Suppose you see meet somebody at a party; you don’t know him; but he acts as though he is very important. You ask your companion “who is that guy? What gives him the right to be so self-important?” You are told: “he is the dean”. Before you know who that person was, you were able to refer to him, and also to have thought about him. You were able to think he is obnoxious and ask “what gives him the right to act in such haughty manner?” But, despite this fact, there is still some sense in which you don’t know who he is. You can be able to think about, and refer to, somebody, without knowing quite who they are. When you tell little Timmy “Shakespeare is the guy who wrote Romeo and Juliet”, you are telling him (or trying to tell him) who Shakespeare was: and this, as we’ve just seen, is different from transmitting to Timmy the ability to think about, or refer to Shakespeare. (Of course, what we’ve said about Shakespeare and “Shakespeare” applies to inanimate objects and the words that label them.) Most “descriptive definitions” are really cases where one is learning who somebody is, or which object something is; they are not cases where one is acquiring the ability to refer to, or think about, that thing. Usually, the ability to refer to, and think about, the object in question pre-exists
   There are cases where one is genuinely acquiring a name in manner (ii); but they are not easy to produce; and they tend to be somewhat artificial.
   But here there is only one really important point. Whenever one adds a referring term to one’s lexicon, that involves one’s knowing some uniquely individuating description of the referent: for any name N, then one’s adding N to one’s lexicon involves one’s knowing some true claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi, and N names x. (This is true, we found, even in the case where one acquires the name through ostensive definition.) The existence claims usually are not ones of historical moment; they are not ones like somebody x wrote Romeo and Juliet and “Shakespeare” names x. They are usually highly specific to the peculiarities of one’s own situation. But what is important is that knowledge of some such claim, historically trivial though it may be,  is needed to use a named to refer to a thing.     I wish to be clear on one point. Even though we learn what a name refers to through some existential-descriptive claim, the name itself is just a label. Semantically, “Shakespeare” simply labels Shakespeare; it doesn’t have any descriptive content (except such as it has in virtue of being a mere label of Shakespeare). But one always learns which thing a name labels through some existentialdescriptive claim. The semantics are not existential-descriptive; but the act of learning the semantics is existential-descriptive.  The semantic rule for “Shakespeare” must be given to you in some way or other. But what  is given is not the same thing as how it is given. The following statement is false:
 
(S1) The semantic rule for “Shakespeare” is this: somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and “Shakespeare” names x.
 
  S1 is false because “Shakespeare” refers to Shakespeare in worlds where Hamlet was never written. So the semantics for “Shakespeare” cannot have anything to do with Hamlet.
  But the following statement is true:
 
(S2) Somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and, and the semantic rule for “Shakespeare” is this:  “Shakespeare” names x.
 
   The operator “the semantic rule for__ is” must be given narrow-scope. Otherwise we end up committed to a false descriptivism. The name is just a label. The literal meaning of “Shakespeare was prolific” is simply:
Shakespeare wrote Hamlet. It is not: somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and x was prolific.
    Though false, S1 is not, so to speak, as false as the following (the asterices are to be taken as quasi-quotation marks, i.e. as being just like quotationmarks except that they don’t quote any variables that they enclose):
 
(S3) The semantic rule for “Shakespeare is this: for any predicate *…x…*,
*…Shakespeare…* means: somebody O uniquely wrote Hamlet and…O…
 
    What is literally meant by “Shakespeare was bald” is simply Shakespeare was bald; it is not: somebody x uniquely wrote Hamlet and x was bald.     To avoid running afoul of Kripke’s correct points, we must take care to give the relevant operators – “refers to”, “is the semantic rule for__” – narrow scope.
    Another point is worth bringing up. One typically forgets the existenceclaim through which one added a name to one’s lexicon. One typically forgets the fist time one heard “Shakespeare” or “Aristotle”; one often forgets one’s first meeting of a person. Given this, one is tempted to say:
 
   “You don’t necessarily associate any uniquely individuating description with “Aristotle” or “Smith” or “Jones”. Such a description was needed to enable you to refer to those people, and to think about them. But once that ability is in place, the description drops out. At that point, there can be pure thought about the entities in question. You can just think about Aristotle and Smith; you don’t have to think about them through a uniquely individuating description.
 
       This is not how it works. What happens is not, I propose, that one ceases to have knowledge of a uniquely individuating description, but rather that one replaces one such description with another one: a related, but distinct one.         Remember what we said earlier about “Fred”. If you add “Fred” to your lexicon in manner (i), i.e. through an ostensive definition, that involves your knowing some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” names x.
        Suppose you and a friend are at a party. You see somebody wearing a bowler hat, talking animatedly. At time t, your friend points to that person and say “that is Fred”. Your adding “Fred” to your lexicon involves your knowing some existence claim, something like:
 
(e1) there is now somebody x whom I am sense-perceiving and attending to, and who is wearing a bowler hat, and “Fred” names x.
 
    Let us suppose that, a minute or so after “Fred” is ostensively defined for you, you go up to him and start talking. Now you have new information about Fred; you have a new uniquely individuating description of him. There are a number of reasons for this. First of all, the mere lapse in time between your current situation – your now talking with Fred – and the initial ostensive definition by itself guarantees that you will have a new uniquely individuating description of him. At time t, (e1) was your uniquely individuating description. But now that time has passed, (e1) has been replaced. By itself, the mere passage of time replaces (e1) with:
 
(e2) there is somebody x whom, a minute or two ago, I was  sense-perceiving and attending to, and who was then wearing a bowler hat, and “Fred” names x.
 
 
  notice that (e2) “interlocks” with (e1). The thing having the property specified in (e2) is the same as the thing having the property specified in (e1). The uniquely individuating description changes. But the new one is related to the old one in such a way that something x uniquely makes both of them true. The new one “inherits” the verifier of the old one. In a moment we will say more about this process of inheritance or transmission.
   But other things, besides the mere passage of time, will replace (e1), with a new uniquely individuating description. You are now engaged in conversation with Fred. You can see him more clearly (although from afar he looked hale and strong, you now see that he is puffy and out of shape); he is saying certain things to you (he is talking about the national debt). As a result, you generate a new uniquely individuating description of Fred. Your new one is something like:
 
(e3) there is somebody x whom, a minute or two ago, I was  sense-perceiving and attending to, and who was then wearing a bowler hat; and I am not attending to x, and conversing with him, x is now talking about the national debt, and x looks puffy and unhealthy, and “Fred” names x.
 
Notice that (e3) and (e2) interlock; (e2) transmits its verifier to (e3).
  Now that you have (e3), you can drop (e2) and (e1). You can completely forget them; and that will not jeopardize your ability to think about. Suppose a moment passes; you have stopped talking with Fred. By itself, the mere passage of time replaces (e3) with a slightly different claim:
 
(e4) there is some x such that, a moment ago,  x was  talking about the national debt, and x looked puffy and unhealthy, and “Fred” names x.
 
 
  Suppose that you have completely forgotten (e1)-(e3). You still have some uniquely individuating description of Fred. And, so long as you are able to think about Fred, this will continue to be the cases. You go home at night.
(e4) is now replaced with:
 
(e5)  there is some x such that, several hours ago, at a party,  x was  talking about the national debt, and x looked puffy and unhealthy, and “Fred” names x.
 
  This process can continue ad infinitum. One’s ability to think about, and refer to, something can only be started up by one’s acquiring knowledge of the right kind of existence claim. Typically, that specific claim is forgotten. But it is replaced by another “interlocking” existence claim – another interlocking uniquely individuating description. And that second one will, in its turn, be replaced  by a third; and that third by a fourth, and so on.     The point is that the ability to think about, and refer to, an external object always involves possession of a uniquely individuating description that applies to it.
    None of this belittles the role that causal connections play in conception and reference. I am able to think about, and refer to, Fred precisely because I saw him: and seeing something involves being causally connected to it. But how is the causal connection involved? What enables me to think about Fred is my knowledge of some uniquely individuating description: there is some guy whom I am now seeing and attending to, who is wearing a bowler hat, and “Fred” names that guy. The causal connection is involved in my seeing Fred; and my seeing Fred, in its turn, is involved in my having a uniquely individuating description of him. So what is doing the work is my knowledge of a uniquely individuating description of Fred; the causal connection, though essential, has a role that is sub-ordinate and internal to that my knowledge of that description.
    Here we need to very clear about a certain distinction: the distinction between literal meaning and cognitive content. “Fred” is just a label. The following statement is true:
 
(F1) There is somebody x who I met on such and such occasion,  and who looked pale and talked about communism; and the semantic rule for “Fred” is: “Fred” names x.
 
The following statement is false:
 
(F2) The semantic rule for “Fred” is this: There is somebody x who I met on such and such occasion,  and who looked pale and talked about communism; and “Fred” names x.
 
The following is even more false
 
    
 (F3) The semantic rule for “Fred” is this: for any predicate *…x…*, *… Fred…* means: There is somebody O who I met on such and such occasion, and who looked pale and talked about communism and…O…
 
  The literal meaning of
 
(*) “Fred looked puffy and pale”
 
is simply:
 
(*LM) Fred looked puffy and pale.  
 
   But remember that one knows what “Fred” refers to only in so far as one knows some claim of the form: somebody x uniquely has phi and “Fred” refers to x.
 
 
 
 
    
 
 
 
 
 
    
  
 
     
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

[1]
 If there were no sentient beings, it would still be true that triangles have three sides. Therefore it would still be a truth that that triangles have three sides. Therefore it would still be a true proposition that that triangles have three sides. If we try to say that truths and falsehoods come into existence with the onset of awareness, we must say that – even though there are no truths per se in a world devoid of mind – nonetheless such a world provides the grounds for truth. Though there were no truths a billion years, the grounds were still present for the truth that there were a certain number of planets. That is why, when a mind enters such a world, it finds itself surround by objective truths. 
    But to say that the grounds for truth are present is just to say that the truths themselves are present. So I don’t see that the foregoing argument eliminates the existence of mind-independent truth.
[2]
 Quine (1990: 26).
[3]
 Richard Montague (1974) showed how to convert any sentence into one of subject-predicate form; arguably, he thus showed that any proposition is given by a sentence of that form. So the trouble with Kant’s definition isn’t exactly that it presupposes that all sentences (or propositions) are of that form. But after we use Montague’s method to convert (say) “if P, then P” into subject-predicate form, Kant’s definition of analyticity turns out to be false. After the conversion, that sentence becomes “if* <P, P>”, where “if* denotes a function assigning truth to an ordered pair of propositions exactly if the second proposition is a consequence of the first. So the subject becomes the ordered pair <P, P>, and the predicate becomes the second-level function denoted by “if*”. But this doesn’t help Kant. There is no sense, not even a metaphorical one, in which <P,P> is “contained” in the concept denoted by “if*”.

[15]
 Arguably, a talented mathematician wouldn’t have to base his answer on this kind of play of imagery. Instead he might be able to use his knowledge of correspondences between geometry and number-theory: just as number-theoretic truths can be learned through spatial intuition, so perhaps geometrical truths could, in principle, be learned through number-theoretic intuition. But this only reinforces my point: usage of imagery is a mere vehicle for some kind of conceptual analysis.
    For the record, I myself don’t think that geometrical reason could ever be completely “arithmetized”. I don’t mean to deny the existence of any objective correspondence between those two disciplines. I mean only that, if one is really thinking about geometry, one eventually has to relate one’s results to shapes. Even though shapes can be represented by sets of numbers, one isn’t thinking of a thing as a shape if one thinks of it as a set of numbers. Geometrical thought eventually involves thinking of something as a shape. So, in my view, geometrical thought does ineliminably involve some component of visual intuition (though given enough mathematical acumen, there is no limit to how marginal that component can be).
    At the same time, even in geometrical thought, the element of visual intuition is still a vehicle for conceptual analysis; it is a way of analyzing the relevant geometrical concepts. It doesn’t have the quasi-empirical role that Kant attributed to it. So even though Kant may have been right to insist that geometrical thought necessarily involves visual imagery, the conclusion he drew from that – geometry teaches us about our forms of thought, not about objective relations among concepts -- was quite wrong.

[22]
 ‘[O]nly communities, not individuals, can be interpreted as having original intentionality.’ [Brandom (1998), p. 61].
[23]
 Actually, Brandom holds that for a creature to have any kind of intentionality at all, it must first know a language: ‘[My view] deserves...to be called a linguistic [Brandom’s italics] view of intentionality...because linguistic practice is nonetheless accorded a certain kind f explanatory priority over rational agency. The intentionality of non-linguistic creatures is presented as dependent on, and in a specific sense derivative from, that of their linguistically qualified interpreters, who as a community exhibit a non-derivative, original intentionality.’ [Brandom (1998), p. 152].
This point implies a vicious regress. Knowing a language is itself a form of intentionality. So if intentionality could be correctly attributed only by some creature that already had intentionality, then that creature, qua creature possessed of intentionality, could exist only if some other language speaker existed. But then that that language speaker, qua creature possessed of intentionality couldn’t exist unless some third language speaker existed; and so on ad infinitum. There couldn’t be a single intentional creature unless there were an infinity of them.
Also Brandom’s point is false on purely empirical grounds. Dogs and infants obviously have intentional mental states. Finally, Brandom’s own account of how creatures learn language clearly presupposes that pre-linguistic creatures have intentionality of some kind. According to Brandom, creatures learn a language by entering into communal practices. But how a could a non-intentional creature enter into communal practices? (Of course, a non-intentional robot could simulate being engaged in communal practices. But it couldn’t really have entered into such practices.) Brandom’s position begins to make sense only if we take him to mean cognitive intentionality by ‘intentionality’. (By ‘cognitive intentionality’ I mean the kind of intentionality one has in being aware of propositions).

 One error in this argument is the idea that anything mediating information is ipso facto a language. That thesis obliterates the distinction between distinctly linguistic representation and non-linguistic (e.g. perceptual) representation, and thus trivializes the idea that thought is symbolic.

[28]
At this point some important disclaimers must be made. Wittgenstein is notoriously difficult to interpret. It is a matter of special controversy how to interpret his ‘rule-following’ and ‘private language’ arguments. And it is with these arguments specifically that a great deal of this paper will be
[28] concerned. To say the least, I cannot guarantee that my interpretations of Wittgenstein are correct. (They are, I think, fairly orthodox criticisms — at any rate, they are orthodox relative to a certain tradition of Wittgenstein scholarship.) Given this alone, it might seem as though my whole project is in peril. But this is not so. Although I cannot be sure that my interpretations of Wittgenstein are correct, I do think that my interpretations of Wittgenstein correspond very well to Brandom’s interpretations of him. (I submit that a close reading of Making it Explicit will quite bear this out.) Given that, in so far as I am concerned to refute any author, it is Brandom and not Wittgenstein, it is enough if we have a grip on how Brandom understands Wittgenstein. Also, even if (what I have some confidence is not the case) we have misunderstood how Brandom misunderstands Wittgenstein, that would not still invalidate our project: for the main purpose of that project — over and above refuting Brandom — is to show that the ability to learn a language presupposes the ability to grasp propositions. Our case for this position will not presuppose the correctness of this or that interpretation of Brandom or of Wittgenstein. (Nonetheless it is to be hoped that I have understood Brandom correctly since I frame many of my arguments for cognitive realism in terms of what I have taken to be Brandom’s criticism of it; and my arguments would thus lose a certain rapport with current discussion if I have mis-understood Brandom.) In any case, readers who are worried about Wittgenstein’s views being mis-represented, might do well to mentally replace each occurrence of ‘Wittgenstein’ with an occurrence of ‘WittgensteinB’ or ‘WittgensteinK’, where the former means ‘Wittgenstein as understood by Brandom’ and the latter means ‘Wittgenstein as understood by the author’.

 How could one give and ask for reasons without previously grasping reasons? Of course, Brandom has a reason for saying this: one must engage in communal, linguistic practices to grasp propositions. So - paradoxical though it may sound - giving and asking for reasons is prior to grasping reasons. Well, we have seen that this central contention of Brandom’s is false and that it really is a paradoxical assertion, as it first appears. Nevertheless, with a slight amendment, what Brandom is saying here is basically correct. What Brandom must say here, if his analysis is to be correct, is - not that a human being, whereas a parrot cannot, ‘given and ask’ for reasons - but simply that a human being can, whereas a parrot cannot, grasp reasons at all. I am ignoring this odd feature of Brandom’s explanation. Thus amended, Brandom’s analysis is correct.

Brandom: ‘The use of sentences is prior in the order of explanation to the use of subsentential expresses because sentences are the only expressions whose utterance “makes a move in the language game.”‘ [Brandom (1998), p. 82] ‘Referring to something, indicating or naming it, is also something one do with linguistic expressions; it is a speech act one can perform. But these belong to a class of speech acts that is in an important sense derivative from or parasitic on speech acts involving sentences, paradigmatically claiming, asserting, or putting forward as true. The significance of taking or treating something as a name, as purporting to refer to an object, consists in how one takes it to be proper to use the expression, and the use of the expressions as names is unintelligible except in the contest of using expressions containing them as sentences.’ [Brandom (1998), p. 82].

 Of course, given a non-assertoric sentence containing ‘Bill Clinton’ — e.g. ‘Does Bill Clinton
smoke?’ and ‘Make Bill Clinton come home’ — the term ‘Bill Clinton’ refers in that sentence to Bill Clinton because, and only because, the assertoric sentence corresponding to that sentence is such that it is true if and only Bill Clinton has a certain property. So ‘Bill Clinton’ refers to Bill Clinton in ‘Does Bill Clinton smoke’ because, and only because, ‘Bill Clinton Smokes’ is true if and only Bill Clinton smokes.

 Note that this is a parallelism between Brandom’s account of how people acquire intentionality and how words acquire meaning. It is initially society that has intentionality; the individual’s intentionality is derivative of that of the collection. Analogously, it is originally sentences that have meaning; the individual word’s meaning is derivative of that of the sentence’s.
[41]
 I believe Chomsky says as much. [Chomsky (1990)]. I don’t think that Putnam-Burge externalism bears against this. What Putnam-Burge externalism shows is not that there cannot be a set of privately grasped linguistic rules, but that the linguistic rules that we do privately grasp — and that are, in effect, private — sometimes make reference to the activities of other people. I can have a private language whose semantic rules are sometimes of the form let “gold” refer to whatever it is that Charlie discovered. A rule that makes reference to other people’s thoughts and deeds may still be a private rule — may still be a rule that belongs to a private language. A ‘private’ language is not necessarily one that has to exist in a void of other people. It is one that one can subject oneself to. Obviously the semantic rules for such a language could refer to other people without ceasing to be private.

 Of course, all of these authors found additional reasons for believing that creatures must know a language to be able to think. But I think that they sought these reasons to rationalize an existing belief that linguistic competence underlies thought; and surely this existing belief was motivated by the obvious fact that we are so much more developed cognitively than other creatures and that we are the only creatures who really have language. My own view is that Brandom’s and Wittgenstein’s arguments are much too obscure to have commanded any agreement, even by their creators, had people not already believed that the ability to think somehow supervened on the ability to speak — had people not already assented to the conclusions of those arguments.

 Of course, the classic proponent of this view is Hume. Hume maintains that moral sentences are neither true nor false, and that, in believing them to be true or false, we are guilty of a kind of delusion. As human beings, we tend to project our feelings onto the world and mistake these feelings for objective realities. Moral sentences embody these projective delusions. (Hume [1], Book II; Hume [2].)  Simon Blackburn defends a Humean view of morality in Blackburn [1], chapter 6; and in the entirety of Blackburn [2].
    In Language, Truth, and Logic Ayer advocates emotivism. It doesn’t occur to Ayer to consider the possibility that because ethical judgments express emotion, they are true or false. Ayer takes it for granted the opposite inference holds: because ethical judgments express emotion, they are not true or false.
 
[46]
 Inevitably, some will say that this point presupposes the correctness of a “speech-act” conception of semantics, as opposed to a tractarian conception.
   This is completely erroneous; my point above doesn’t presuppose such a conception.   It would be nonsense to say:
 
“snow is white” bears the proposition snow is white. But if you want to express the belief that snow is white, then you’d better use some other locution; for “snow is white” won’t do the trick.
 
 No if “snow is white” bears the proposition snow is white then ipso facto it enables one to express the corresponding belief.
   And if one “snow is white” enables one to express that belief, then ipso facto it (or uses of it) bear that proposition. Suppose someone said:
 
If you want to express the belief that snow is white, then use the locution “snow is white”. But if you want some locution that bears the proposition, then you’d better look elsewhere: “snow is white” isn’t what you want.
 
   Again, that would be patent nonsense. In so far as tokens of “snow is white” are suitable vehicles for expressions of the belief that snow is white, they bear that proposition.
   So it is surely not too far off the mark to say that “snow is white” bears the proposition snow is white in virtue of its being an apt way of expressing that belief.
[47]
 This doesn’t mean that whenever one makes a moral statement one is in the throes of emotion. If I say “letting children starve (when there is plenty of food to give them) is evil”, I don’t necessarily have to be in a fit of rage or of outrage. But emotions are not always occurrent. I can hate somebody for forty years and not always be in a fit of anger. The emotion shouldn’t be confused with the occurrent manifestations of that emotion. Now if somebody felt nothing – had no emotion in connection with the phenomenon of children gratuitously starving – then it is a bit hard to see how that person could sincerely say “letting children starve is evil”.
    I will operate on the assumption that this point is correct. I admit that this is an arguable point. But it is, I think, reasonable enough to warrant our investigating the consequences of it. And one of those consequences, I submit, is that Emotivism is a form of moral realism.
[48]
 In The Emotions: An Outline of a Theory Sartre argues for a view that is, at the very least, similar to the view that emotions are beliefs: “emotions are…a way of apprehending the world” (Calhoun and Solomon [1]). Robert Solomon argues for a similar view: “my emotions are judgments I make…” (Calhoun and Solomon [1]: 316, Solomon’s emphasis).  Calhoun’s and Sartre’s arguments are not quite the same as those that I give, though there are unmistakable similarities.
     Hume epitomizes the opposing position – the view that emotions are absolutely incapable of being, in any non-derivative sense, true or false. See Hume [1], Book II, Section III (“Of the Influencing Motives of the Will”, especially page 414:”’tis impossible…that [an] emotion can be oppos’d by, or contradictory to, truth and reason…” ). This is, I think, connected with his ethical anti-realism. For if you see emotions as true or false; and if you see ethical statements as embodiments of emotion; then you must see such statements as themselves being true or false – you are therefore an ethical realist.

[50]
 There are some superficial exceptions to this. One might say:
 
 “The word ‘Socrates’ represents Socrates. But that word doesn’t predicate anything of Socrates. So not all representation is predicational.”
 
  Very well. But what does it mean to say that “Socrates” represents (denotes/ refers to) Socrates? It means this. Sentences of the form
 
“…Socrates…”
 
mean
 
…Socrates…
 
For “Socrates” to represent (denote) Socrates is, ultimately, for sentences containing “Socrates” to be about Socrates. “Socrates” denotes Socrates because “Socrates was bald” is made true by Socrates’ being bald, not Plato’s. Suppose that “Socrates was bald” was made true by Plato’s being bald (but that otherwise the semantics of English was the same). In that case, “Socrates” would denote Socrates (at least in that sentential context). It would be nonsense to say:
 
(*)“Socrates” denotes Socrates, but “Socrates was bald” says that Plato was bald – it doesn’t say anything about Socrates.
 
The absurdity of (*) shows that, when we have a case of a non-predicational symbol, we are really dealing with an “incomplete” symbol: something that, in some sense, is sub-symbolic.

 It might also be said that properties are invariant from world to world; the property of being an even number is the same world 5 as it is in world 37. This is true: properties are world-invariant. But necessary facts about properties, and their interrelations, are reflected in facts about concepts. The proposition anything red is colored is necessarily true because of facts about the properties of being red and colored. But this fact corresponds to a fact about the concepts red and colored. We can, I think, analyze the necessity of anything red is colored as a relation between the concepts red and colored or between the corresponding properties; we can talk either about concepts or about properties. I think it more convenient to talk about the concepts which express properties.

And if ‘x falls under C1 and not under C2’ is possible, and one knows that, then one knows, or can immediately deduce, that ‘if x falls under C1, x falls under C2’ is not necessary.

 In this paper, I will use the term ‘supervenes’ to refer to what is sometimes called metaphysical supervenience, not causal – or any other – kind of supervenience. To say that x ‘supervenes’ on y – in the sense in which we are using this term – is to say that x is wholly determined  by y; which is in turn, roughly, to say that there is no possible world where there is a change in x without a change in y.  
[79]
 Intentionalism has recently experienced a surge of popularity. Consider the following three formulations (cited by Byrne: Byrne [1]):
 
Dretske: ‘All mental facts are representational facts.’ (Dretske [1]: xiii)
 
Lycan: ‘The mind has no special properties that are not exhausted by its representational properties, along with or in combination with the functional organization of its components. (Lycan [1]: 11)
 
Tye: ‘Phenomenal Character (or what it is like) is one and the same as a certain sort of intentional content. (Tye [1]: 137)
 
     Tye is explicitly articulated what I am calling ‘intentionalism’. Dretske and Lycan are articulating a position that is stronger than intentionalism, and that entails intentionalism: they are articulating the position that all mental facts are representational. Now if it is true that all mental facts are representational, then given that phenomenal facts and (non-derivatively) representational facts are obviously mental, it follows that there can be no difference in the phenomenal properties of a mental state of affairs without a difference in the representational properties of that state of affairs. So Dretske and Lycan are, at least by implication, endorsing what I am calling ‘intentionalism.’
 
 
[80]
    In the contemporary literature, the term ‘intentionalism’ is used to denote two related, but distinct, doctrines: (i) the doctrine that all distinctly mental properties are representational properties; and (ii) the weaker doctrine that phenomenal properties are representational properties.  Of course, (i) entails (ii), but not vice versa. So – though they are interrelated – (i) and (ii) are quite distinct doctrines.       
      In this essay, I will use the term ‘intentionalism’ to refer to (ii). Of course, if (ii) is false, it follows that (i) is false. Consequently, many of my arguments will be directly aimed at  (ii), and therefore only by implication aimed at (i). But some of my arguments will be directly aimed at (i).
       (i) and (ii) are not carefully distinguished in the literature. For example, in his important article “Intentionalism Defended”, Alex Byrne (Byrne [1] p. 204) seems to identify (i) and (ii): for he explicitly says of the following statements that they are but different formulations of the same thesis:
 

	* ‘All mental facts are representational facts’ (Dretske)
 

	* ‘Phenomenal character (or what it is like) is one and the same thing as a certain sort of intentionalcontent. (Tye)
 
 
   First of all, (b) seems to correspond to (ii), and (a) to (i). So, in effect, Byrne is failing to distinguish between (i) and (ii). In any case, it is clear that (a) and (b) should not be identified; for (a) says (essentially) that everything mental is representational, while (b) says only that the phenomenal is representational.

[83]
 In this paper,  I will use the terms “propositional” content to refer to the kind of representational content that can be embodied in propositions; and I will use the term “non-propositional” content to refer to any kind of  representational content that cannot be embodied in propositions. But this is not the general practice. Usually, what I am calling “propositional” content is referred to as “conceptual” content, and I what I am call “non-propositional” content is referred to as “non-conceptual” content.     But my choice of nomenclature is, I think, to be preferred. This is because propositions can have things other than concepts as constituents, and therefore can have something that deserves to be call “non-conceptual” content. In any case, this is almost universally held these days. The idea is that the proposition Socrates is bald is de re about Socrates, and thus has Socrates himself – who is obviously not a concept – as a constituent. If Socrates himself can be a constituent of propositions, then some of the content of some propositions is something other than a concept, and is thus non-conceptual. In general, if propositions can have things other than concepts as their constituents – and it is practically universally agreed that they can – then propositions can have things other than concepts for their constituents and thus have something that might legitimately called “non-conceptual” content.  So there is certainly some reason to believe that the kind of content that can be embodied in propositions is sometimes non-conceptual in nature.
   Consequently, the distinction between propositional and non-propositional content is different from that between conceptual and non-conceptual content. In fact, the people who use the terms ‘conceptual content’ and ‘non-conceptual content’ to mark the distinction I  am talking about – the distinction between, as I am putting it, propositional and non-propositional content – almost always hold that there are object-involving propositions, i.e. that non-concepts – e.g. Socrates, Plato – can be constituents of propositions. Given this, it is odd that, when they are discussing the question whether all representational content can be embodied in propositions, they often state this question as ‘is all representational content conceptual?’ Again, it seems to me that (often, though probably not always) what is really being asked is ‘is all representational content propositional’’  (or ‘is all representational content capable of being embodied in a proposition?’) and not ‘is all representational content conceptual?
      I should make one absolutely clear. In this paper, whenever I say ‘non-propositional content’, I mean non-propositional representational content. I mean the kind of content that is representational but that cannot be embodied in a proposition. I will question whether this kind of content exists. But, just to be clear, my term for this kind of content (if it exists) will be simply ‘non-propositional content’ – the term ‘representational’ is to be taken as implicit.
 
  
 
[84]
 The idea that there is ‘non-propositional content’ (usually the term ‘non-conceptual content’ is used – see last footnote) is very widely held. Evans, Peacocke, Heck, and Michael Tye are some of the prominent believers in non-propositional content. (See Evans [1], Peacocke [1], Heck [1], and Tye [1] and [2].) Peacocke is not himself an intentionalist (see Peacocke [2]). Michael Tye is an intentionalist. (See Tye [1] and [2].) Evans did not weigh in on this particular issue and so far as I know, neither has Heck. [85]
 I would like to make one point absolutely clear. Throughout this paper, by ‘non-propositional content’, I mean ‘non-propositional representational content.’ So the term ‘non-propositional content’, as I am using it, is really just an abbreviation for ‘non-propositional representational content.’ So the term ‘non-propositional content’ will be our term to refer to that kind of representational content that cannot be embodied in propositions.
     Later on, I will argue that there is no such thing as representational content that cannot be embodied in propositions. But if only for discursive reasons, we must have a term to denote that kind of representational content, nonexistent though it may be; and that term, to reiterate, will be ‘nonpropositional content.’

[90]
 Byrne then formalizes the argument just given as follows. To ensure that I don’t misrepresent Byrne’s views, I will quote his own words:
 
Premise A
 
     Assume the following: A subject enjoys two consecutive experiences: e, that ends at t, and then e*. e and e* differ in phenomenal character. The subject is competent: if she tries to retrieve information (or misinformation) in memory, then her attempt will be successful, and she has no other cognitive shortcoming. The subject tries to detect a change in phenomenal character after t. The subject’s memory is perfect: all the (mis)information supplied to her by e is available when she later enjoys e*.      Then, solely on the basis of her current experience e* and the memory produced by her past experience e, the subject will notice a change after t: if she gives an accurate report when e* is over, she will say that there was a change in phenomenal character after t. (pp.207-208)
 
Premise B
 
     Assume that a subject enjoys an experience e that ends at t and then experience e*, and that after t the subject notices a change in phenomenal character, solely on the basis of her current experience e* and the (perfect) memory produced by her past experience e. Then the way things seem to the subject when she enjoys e differs from the way things seem when she enjoys e*. That is the content of e differs from the content of e*. (p. 210)
 
Conclusion C
 
If a competent subject whose memory is perfect and who tries to detect a change in phenomenal character enjoys consecutive experiences e and e* that differ in phenomenal character, then the content of e differs from the content of e*. (p. 213)

 To my knowledge, the position that representational capacities are non-atomistic – that they come only in articulated bundles – was first defended by Wittgenstein in On Certainty. (See Wittgenstein [1], especially section 141: “When we first begin to believe anything, what we believe is not a  single proposition, it is a whole system of propositions. (Light dawns gradually over the whole.)”
Wittgenstein’s emphasis.) It – or a position similar – was famously given a brilliant defence by Wilfred
Sellars. Some form of non-atomism is employed in connectionist theories of the mind. (See Bechtel [1].) (see Fodor [1]) Fodor’s argument does not address the argument set forth here for representational non-atomism and, so far as I can tell, nothing Fodor says impugns this argument.

 I should reiterate a clarification made earlier. In the literature, what I am calling ‘propositional content” is typically referred to as “conceptual” content, and what I am calling “non-propositional” content is generally referred to as “non-conceptual content.” (See e.g. MacDowell [1].}  But, as I said in an earlier footnote, this nomenclature is deeply misleading. For it is generally agreed propositions can have things other than concepts as their constituents, and thus can have something that might legitimately be called “non-conceptual” content. Now if this is correct, then propositional content – i.e. the kind of content that can be embodied in propositions – is sometimes something other than a concept, and is thus sometimes non-conceptual. So the distinction between conceptual content and nonconceptual content is not the same as the distinction between propositional content and nonpropositional content. Consequently, the terms “conceptual” content and “non-conceptual” content should not be used to mark the distinction between propositional content and non-propositional content.

[101]
 A classic discussion of the difference between real and simulated thought is found in Searle (1980). Searle’s “Chinese room” experiment is meant to show that something can perfectly simulate the ability to speak Chinese without actually knowing Chinese. A man inside a room is given orders to make certain ink-marks when given other ink-marks. Unbeknownst to the man, the ink-marks in question are Chinese sentences, and the sequences of ink-marks form a meaningful and coherent discourse. According to Searle,  the man’s behavior simulates knowledge of Chinese without embodying any such knowledge. Therefore a simulation of knowledge doesn’t add up to knowledge. The main response is to say that, while the man per se doesn’t know Chinese, the system of which he is a part does know Chinese. (See Fodor 1980.) Searle counter-responds by describing other systems (e.g.
robots) that simulate knowledge of Chinese but that, to Searle’s mind, clearly don’t have such knowledge. Searle’s general approach is to say: (a) it is intuitively clear that the system described doesn’t know Chinese, even though (b) that system simulates knowledge of Chinese; therefore (c) simulated knowledge (or thought) isn’t actual knowledge. I happen to agree with Searle.  But the problem with this line of thought is that the opponent can always generate contrary intuitions; he can say “I think that the system in question (e.g. the man with the translation manual, the robot) does know Chinese; I think you are begging the question against my viewpoint by saying, on the mere strength of your intuitions, that the system in question doesn’t think: if the system reliably produces the right representations, then ipso facto it thinks.” (See Fodor 1980.) What we need is some way to break this circle of bare intuitions. In this paper, I will try to provide such a way.
[102]
 In this paper, when I talk about “thought”, I mean some mental entity, something spatio-temporal and presumably realized by neural events. I am not using the term “thought” to denote propositions or other (Fregean-Platonic) abstracta.
[103]
 It is, of course, generally held that representational content is causally effective. But, surprisingly, a number of otherwise seemingly reasonable positions appear to be inconsistent with this. For example, these days it is widely held that mental properties are “multiply realizable” (Putnam 1967, Fodor 1968, Davidson 1970, Lewis 1972). Causal role, not material composition, is said to be what realizes mental properties. Jaegwon Kim (1993: 339-367) has argued compellingly that this position renders mental properties causally inert – mental phenomena become epiphenomena. The underlying physical properties are doing the causal work. The mental phenomena don’t add anything to the causally effective underlying processes. But, at the same time, they are not (ex hypothesis) identical  with those processes. So, argues Kim, to avoid “epiphenomenalizing” the mental, we have to see mental properties not merely as realized by, but as identical with, physical phenomena.  Kim rejects the idea that the mental could be “de-epiphenomenalized” by positing “downward causation”. If the mental is realized by something non-mental, then the mental is powerless. So, in Kim’s view, given that the mental is not powerless, the relation between it and brain-events is one of identity, not supervenience or realization. In any case, Kim has exposed a genuine prima facie tension between, on the one hand, the presumption that mental properties are effective and, on the other hand, the truth of the multiple-realizability thesis.     Kim comes very close to saying that, unless mental entities have causal powers, they don’t exist at all! He says “to be real is to have causal powers” (Kim 1993: 348). So any kind of epiphenomenalism – and, in Kim’s view, that means anything other than “reductive” materialism – is inconsistent with the very existence of mental entities.
     Kim’s dictum (to be real is to have causal powers) appears to have a far-reaching consequence. If representational content is real, then it has causal powers; and it doesn’t have such powers, it isn’t real. Some forms of externalism would appear to render representational content causally inert, and it would be interesting to see how they deal with Kim’s suggestion that spatiotemporal reality involves causal efficacy. McGinn (1998: Chapter 2) makes a concerted effort to deal with this very problem.      Frank Jackson and Philip Pettit (2004) discuss a related issue that arises in connection with functionalism. According to functionalism b (an arbitrary brain-state) has such and such content wholly in virtue of its causal role. On the face of it, functionalism seems to give causal properties to the mental: it makes causal properties essential. But, at least arguably, the exact opposite is the case. Suppose that b encodes the proposition snow is white. If b encodes that belief in virtue of its causal role, then its encoding that belief cannot be what causes b to behave as it does. If content supervenes on causal role, then causal role is more basic than, and is independent of, content.  So, ironically, functionalism would seem to strip the representational of causal efficacy. (This has a certain similarity to Kim’s point.) Jackson and Pettit argue that, notwithstanding this point, functionalism is consistent with the potency of representational content. The relevant point here is that functionalism – a reasonable, some would say an inevitable, view – is, at least arguably, in tension with the causal effectiveness of the mental; and that tension becomes apparent only when we distinguish b itself from b’s having such and such representational content.
      Many have thought it strange to deny that the representational is causally effective (for example, see McGinn 1998: Chapter 2). But nobody has said (though Kim came close: see above) that representational content must effective if there are to even be thought-processes or therefore (since a single thought is presumably a limiting case of a thought-process) any thought at all. That is part of what I will argue here. I will argue that, unless representational content is effective, representations cannot “molecularize” into thought-processes, or therefore into single thoughts.

 Davidson 1973: 79.

 Gettier 1963.

 Here I am using these terms in a broad sense. I am using the term “logical” to cover not just formally but also informally correct reasoning.
[107]
 Before going any further, let us be clear on one thing: there will be such a property as p. It does seem pretty clear that, in at least some cases, our brain-states have representational content. But not every physical property of a brain-state will be involved in its mediating a certain representational content. Among other things, it would make possession of representational content far too fragile. Let b be a brain-state (or, better, an enduring brain-condition) that mediates your standing belief that two is even. Like any other spatiotemporal structure, b has many different causal properties. And like practically any other spatiotemporal structure, b will, in the course of its existence, undergo many changes in those properties. It will undergo changes in its specific shape, its specific mass, its specific location, its specific temperature. All of these are causally effective properties. If b should have temperature 99.8674345 as opposed to 99.8674346, that is a causally significant fact: it will change, however minutely, what b does to certain other things.
     Clearly b can undergo changes – perhaps not overly drastic changes, but some changes – in these properties without ceasing to mediate a belief that two is even. In the time you’ve been reading this sentence, every one of your brain-states has undergone innumerable, causally significant changes: no one of those brain-states has kept exactly the same temperature throughout that interval; no one of them has kept exactly the same micro-morphology. But most, if not all, of them have continued to do their representational jobs. You still believe that Paris in France; you still believe that snow is (usually, more or less) white. The brain-structures that realized these beliefs two seconds ago are numerically identical with the ones that now realize those beliefs, even though, as we just said, those brain-states have undergone innumerable (small, but non-Cambridge) changes. 
     So some of B1’s causally effective properties can be changed without jeopardizing B1’s ability to mediate a belief that grass is green. It follows that not every one of B1’s causally effective properties is involved in B1’s realizing a belief that grass is green. We have thus established that p exists, where p is some causally effective property of B1 that is not involved in B1’s mediating a belief that grass is green.
[108]
 Nonetheless, even if your thinking Socrates is what causes you to think hit and Plato (in that order), it still doesn’t follow that you have thought Socrates hit Plato. We could imagine an analogue of the scenario discussed earlier. For some reason, whenever you have a Socrates-thought, your heart starts to race (because, let us suppose, you love his works so much). A hypnotist had previously programmed you to think hit and Plato (in that order) whenever your heart-rate goes above 90 beats per minute. So you have b1, and b1’s being a Socrates-thought causes you (however “deviantly”) to think hit and then Plato. Still, even under that circumstances, you have not thought Socrates hit Plato. You have thought Socrates and then hit, and so on.

 I will refer to this position as CTM* in order to mark its obvious similarity to the computational theory of mind. But the “*” is meant to show indicate that I wish to leave it open, at least in those context, whether  CTM* is quite the same thing as the computational theory of mind.

 Fodor (1990a: 22) “You connect the causal properties of a symbol with its semantic properties via its syntax…To a first approximation, we can think of its syntactic structure as an abstract feature of its (geometrical or acoustic) shape [Fodor’s emphasis]. Because, to all intents and purposes, syntax reduces to shape [my emphasis], and because the shape of a symbol is a potential determinant of its causal role, it is fairly easy to see how there could be environments in which the causal role of a symbol correlates with its syntax. It’s easy, that is to say, to imagine symbol tokens interacting causally in virtue of [Fodor’s emphasis] their syntactic structures. The syntax of a symbol might determine the causes and effects of its tokenings in much the way that the geometry of a key determines which locks it will open.”

“[W]e know from formal logic that certain of the semantic relations among symbols can be, as it were, “mimicked” by their syntactic relations; that, when seen from a very great distance, is what prooftheory is all about. So, within certain famous limits, the semantic relation that holds between two symbols when the proposition expressed by the one is implied by the proposition expressed by the other can be mimicked by syntactic relation in virtue of which one of the symbols is derivable from the other. We can therefore build machines which have, again within famous limits, the following property: the operations of such  a machine consist entirely of transformations of symbols; in the course of performing these operations the machine is sensitive only to syntactic properties of the symbols; and the operations that the machine performs on the symbols are confined entirely to alterations of their shapes. Yet the machine is so devised that it will transform one symbol into another if and only if the symbols so transformed stand in certain semantic relations; e.g. the relation that the premises bear to the conclusion in a valid argument. Such machines – computers, of course, just are [Fodor’s emphasis] environments in which the causal role of a symbol is made to parallel the inferential role of the proposition it expresses.”
 
Fodor hedges his points with phrases like: “within certain famous limits”, “as it were”,  “from a very great distance”, and “again within famous limits”. But, as I hope to show, these hedges turn out either to be empty or to conceal systemic problems with Fodor’s analysis.

 For the record, this is not my own view. I think that the syntactic structure of a sentence is so deeply in facts about its semantics, that it is not clear whether “Bill is a green duck, therefore Bill is duck” has the same syntax as “Bill is a decoy duck, therefore Bill is a duck”. Chomsky (1965) argues persuasively that “John expected the visitors to leave” has a very different syntax from “John wanted the visitors to leave”. Obviously this point is meant to generalize. If it does, then we must rethink the traditional view that, in English (and other natural languages), there is a misalignment of syntax with the semantics.

[132]
 One conceivable way out is to say that our mental processes are over-determined: they are determined entirely by the laws of physics (for they are realized by brain-events, and brain-events are determined by the laws of physics). But they are also determined by consciousness of norms.    But this is a radically implausible thesis. Let E be an arbitrary brain-event that is identical with, or that realizes, a mental-event. For the sake of argument, suppose that E is “over-determined” in the relevant sense. This would mean that E was entirely caused by some state of affairs S (some purely physical or physiological state of affairs)  and also that E was caused by some state of affairs S* (some awareness of the canons of rationality), such that S and S* were completely distinct. But the idea of an event’s being entirely caused by two distinct states of affairs  is of doubtful coherence. Also, if each brain-event that realized a mental event were entirely caused both by some awareness of norms and also by some physiological state of affairs, then we’d have innumerable cases of two entirely different kinds of things eventuating in the exact same thing: we’d have innumerable cases where two entirely distinct things – one a consciousness of norms, the other a physiological state of affairs – independently eventuated in the exact same thing (some brain-event). But to accept this is to accept innumerable unexplained coincidences. By contrast, if we suppose that mental states of affairs are neuro-cerebral states of affairs, then it is no longer a coincidence that brain-events realizing mental entities have physiological causes and mental causes: the former are the latter, at least in some causes. So it would not be good methodology to accept the idea that brain-states are over-determined. And practically no one does accept. (I myself do not.)
[133]
 I should make one point very clear. I am not opposed to the idea that some thought consists in computation. I could perform a computation right now. And I am not opposed to the idea that many of our cognitive achievement derive from sub-personal acts of computation (like those posited by Chomsky and Marr). What I am opposed to is the idea that computation might constitute the foundation of cognitive activity. Computation, I will argue, exists only in a rich background of cognitive and representational accomplishment. So even though computation might be a pervasive feature of our cognitive lives, it cannot be the basis of it; it necessarily has a sub-ordinate (though perhaps deeply important) role in cognition.

 See Fodor (1987: 19) “The operations of the machine [on which I am modeling the human mind] consist entirely of transformations on symbols; in the course of performing these operations, the machine is sensitive solely to syntactic properties of the symbols; and the operations that the machine performs on the symbols are entirely confined to altering their shapes.”
   See also: Fodor (1990a: 22) “You connect the causal properties of a symbol with its semantic properties via its syntax…To a first approximation, we can think of its syntactic structure as an abstract feature of its (geometrical or acoustic) shape [Fodor’s emphasis]. Because, to all intents and purposes, syntax reduces to shape [my emphasis], and because the shape of a symbol is a potential determinant of its causal role, it is fairly easy to see how there could be environments in which the causal role of a symbol correlates with its syntax. It’s easy, that is to say, to imagine symbol tokens interacting causally in virtue of [Fodor’s emphasis] their syntactic structures. The syntax of a symbol might determine the causes and effects of its tokenings in much the way that the geometry of a key determines which locks it will open.
   But, now, we know from modern logic that certain of the semantic relations among symbols can be, as it were, ‘mimicked’ by their syntactic relations; that, when seen from a very great distance, is what proof-theory is about. So, within certain famous limits, the semantic relation that holds between two symbols when the proposition expressed by the one is entailed by the proposition expressed by the other can be mimicked by syntactic relations in virtue of which one of the symbols is derivable from the other. We can therefore build machines which have, again within famous limits, the following property:
  
    The operations of the machine consist entirely in transformations of symbols;
   in the course of performing these operations, the machine is sensitive solely to syntactic properties of the symbols;    and the operations that the machine performs on the symbols are entirely confined to altering their shapes.
 
    Yet the machine is so devised that it will transform one symbol into another if and only if the propositions expressed by the symbols that are so transformed stand in certain semantic relations – e.g. the relation that the premises bear to the conclusion in a valid argument. Such machines – computers, of course, -- just are [Fodor’s emphasis] environments in which the syntax of a symbol determines its causal role in a way that respects its content. This is, I think, a pretty terrific idea; not least because it works.”
   
   Contrary to what Fodor holds, we will see that building a syntax-driven machine is difficult as building a semantics-driven machine. For syntax is an aspect of semantics; and the connection between the morphology of a symbol and its syntax is as remote and conditional as the connection between a symbol’s morphology and its semantics. 
  See also: Fodor (1981a: 13-17); Fodor (1994: 294-298);  Fodor (1987: 18-20); Fodor 1990a; and Pylyshin (1984).
