Expression-tokens can be spoken or realized by hand-signals or light-beams. They needn’t be realized by ink-marks or by anything else that has “shape” in the narrow sense. In this paper, I will use the term “morphology” in a generalized sense – to describe acoustical (or hand-signal) counter-parts of the physical shape had by written expression-tokens.
[140]
 Compare Fodor (1981: 226-227). Having written that “[mental processes] are formal because they apply to representations in virtue of (roughly) the syntax [Fodor’s emphasis] of the representations” – in other words, having identified “formal” with “syntactic” operations --  Fodor then goes onto write: “Formal operations are the ones that are specified without reference to such semantic properties of representations as, for example, truth, reference, and meaning.”  
    This, I will argue, is dead wrong. Formal, in the sense of syntactic, operations are a kind of semantic operation.

 I should reiterate that this is in no way meant to conflict with the important discoveries of
Chomsky and Marr. Obviously people can compute; and people may well engage in the sub-conscious (and sub-personal) computations posited by Chomsky and Marr. So in that sense, computations may have a very important role in our cognitive lives. What I am saying is that, if Chomsky and Marr are right (as they may well be), the computations they posit presuppose an even more fundamental stratum of cognitive functioning: for any computation, in a relevantly robust sense of the word, presupposes a considerable cognitive and representational background, as I will argue.

[143]
 Quine (1970: 58) wrote: “[A] logical truth is a truth that cannot be turned false by substituting lexicon [lexical items] for lexicon.”  In other words, a logical truth is one that cannot be made false by replacing lexical items with lexical items. And a “lexical item” is defined as one that picks something out or, at any rate, is supposed to pick something out, given its grammatical role. (“Socrates” and “fat” are lexical, because they pick out an individual and a property, respectively. “Pegasus” is lexical because it is supposed to pick something out; its grammatical role is like that of “Socrates”.) Carnap (1947: 85-88) described any sign that was “descriptive” – i.e. that picks something out or expresses a property – as being “non-logical”. In his view, purely “logical” terms – by which he means ‘or’, ‘not’, ‘and’ and so on – do not pick out or describe or express anything. They are purely “formal”. We will take issue with this view in due course.

Richard Montague (1974) used them to great advantage in his work on natural language quantification. See MacCawley

[147]
 There is a sense in which a spoken of token of “I am tired” is isomorphic with a written token and with a token in hand-signals. But that sense of “isomorphic” does not have to do with morphology; it has to do with semantics. Given that any two of those three tokens have certain semantic similarities, the written “I” can be put into a certain kind of correspondence with its spoken (or hand-signaled) counterpart,  the same being true (mutatis mutandis) for the spoken “tired”, the spoken “am”, and so on. But absent that semantic similarity – if we just focus on physical morphology  – those three tokens have about as little in common as any three things. Any “isomorphism” that holds between them is underwritten by semantic similarities, not (mere) morphological similarities.

[156]
 My own view is that, even here, there is no purely syntactic characterization of logical truth. It is true that, in (a)-(c), the indexicals are not important. But the reason they are not important has to do with the peculiarities of the concepts involved – it has to do with the fact that, whether members of a species are mortal is not a function of time: if members of a species are mortal at t, they will be mortal at time t*. That fact, in its turn, turns on peculiarities of the property of mortality. Not all properties are like that. For example, whether all members of a species are thirsty or are in Antarctica is a function of time. The relevant differential facts about the concept of mortality are not coded in the syntax of (a)-(c). So the irrelevance of the tense-markers in (a)-(c) is a function of subtleties buried in the semantics of the terms involved in that argument. So even where artifacts like (a)-(c) are concerned, there is a gap between syntax and logical form, and that gap is bridged only by semantics.

[161]
 Conceivably, one might take a line like the following:
 
    “Consider the sentence-token:
 
(*)“Bob now looks tired, and Bob now does not look tired”.
 
     The syntactic form of (*) is a function of whether the two occurrences of “Bob” co-refer; and it is a function of whether the indexicals (“now”, “-s”) refer to the same bit of time. If the expression in question don’t co-refer, (*) has one syntactic form; if they do co-refer, it has some other syntactic form. So the facts you mention about indexicality, and about ambiguity, do not create a gap between syntactic and logical form. They show only that syntactic form is more fine-grained than you allow.”
 
    
     First of all, this response is completely ad hoc, and is contradicted by everything we know about the concept of syntax. But even if correct, this response isn’t available to CTM; for it amounts to saying that syntax is even more a matter of semantics than even we previously said. The objector is saying that the very syntax of (*) is a function of the specific referents of the indexicals, and of the singular terms, in it. So, if the objector is right,  to know the syntactic form of (*), it is not enough to know generic facts about the semantics of its expressions; it is not enough to know that “Bob” is a singular term, and that each occurrence of “now” refers to time of utterance: one has to know to which specific person “Bob” refers, and what the exact times of utterance are. The objector’s response thus makes syntax be totally inaccessible to anything that lacks fairly high-resolution knowledge of semantics; it thus makes syntax-drivenness presuppose the existence of various representational and cognitive abilities. Thus the objector’s point makes it even harder for syntax driven operations to form the foundation of our cognitive lives.   
 
 
[162]
 See Fodor 1994a (22-23): 
 
 
“[W]e know from formal logic that certain of the semantic relations among symbols can be, as it were, “mimicked” by their syntactic relations; that, when seen from a very great distance, is what prooftheory is all about. So, within certain famous limits, the semantic relation that holds between two symbols when the proposition expressed by the one is implied by the proposition expressed by the other can be mimicked by syntactic relation in virtue of which one of the symbols is derivable from the other. We can therefore build machines which have, again within famous limits, the following property: the operations of such  a machine consist entirely of transformations of symbols; in the course of performing these operations the machine is sensitive only to syntactic properties of the symbols; and the operations that the machine performs on the symbols are confined entirely to alterations of their shapes. Yet the machine is so devised that it will transform one symbol into another if and only if the symbols so transformed stand in certain semantic relations; e.g. the relation that the premises bear to the conclusion in a valid argument. Such machines – computers, of course, just are [Fodor’s emphasis] environments in which the causal role of a symbol is made to parallel the inferential role of the proposition it expresses.”
   
 
       Fodor hedges his points with phrases like: “within certain famous limits”, “as it were”,  “from a very great distance”, and “again within famous limits”. These hedges turn out either to be empty or to conceal systemic problems with Fodor’s analysis.
      The “famous limits” Fodor has in mind have to do with incompleteness results, the most famous being the two of Gödel’s. An apparent (and, in the view of most, an actual) implication of these results is: the bearing relations that hold among number-theoretic statements cannot be reconstituted within the confines of the concepts corresponding to so-called syntax-defining terms like “not”, “or”, “and”, “for some”, and the like. Admittedly, the implications of such incompleteness theorems is a matter of great controversy.
     But such exotic results in mathematical logic are the least of the problems affecting a mirroring of semantics in syntax. Remember what we said earlier. The syntax of a sentence is a function of the more generic facts about its semantics. “Bob is tired” has a certain syntax because “Bob” is a singular term, “tired” is a predicate (a one-place function), and so on. For this reason “Tim is angry” and “Bob is tired” have the same syntax. Logicians have created (or outlined) languages in which, supposedly, logical form is made perspicuous by syntactical structure. But no matter how perspicuous a language is (from the view point of its syntax reflecting its semantics), sentences having very different semantics will have the same syntax. In any language having any expressive power at all, there will be semantically different sentences having the same syntax. So a mind that tracks syntax will inevitably fail to do justice to semantic relations.
   (Henceforth, to facilitate discussion, sentences in boldface are supposed to be the Mentalese translations of their English counterparts.)
     Fodor would not necessarily be moved by these points. For he seems to have held that “Mary is nervous” and “Fred is angry” do have different syntaxes. His reason, if I understand him correctly, is they have different morphologies and morphology is, or reduces to, syntax. (This point is crucial to Fodor’s way of dealing with Frege-cases and also with the apparent truth of externalist theories of content, like Putnam’s. See Cain 2002 (135); Fodor 1994d.)
       But, as we’ve seen, morphology doesn’t have remotely the kind of connection to syntax that it would have to have for “Mary is nervous” and “Fred is angry” to have different syntaxes. And, plainly, they have the same syntax, the reason being that they are like in the relevant semantic respects (“Mary” and “Fred” are both singular terms, “angry” and “nervous” are both one-place predicates, and so on). Perhaps Fodor can circumvent this problem. But it is quite clear that, for any one syntactic form, there are many sentences having that form that have different semantics. And this seriously problematizes the idea, so crucial to CTM, that semantics can be mirrored  in syntax.
       In response, one could say (in effect, Fodor (1994d) does say) that the morphological differences between “Mary is nervous” and “Fred is angry” give them different causal roles, explaining why they lead to different beliefs.
       But this leads back to the problem we were discussing earlier (pages 2-3). A morphology-driven operation is not cognitive at all – is merely simulated thought --  except in so far as syntax (or semantics) is realized by morphology. But morphology, by itself, to no degree realizes syntax (or semantics), as we’ve seen time and time again. So if the differences in causal role between “Mary is nervous” and “Fred is angry” are purely morphology-based, then those differences are not cognitive at all. Quite plainly, there is a cognitive basis to my willingness to infer somebody is nervous or tired from
Mary is nervous, but not from Fred is angry. So if, as Fodor supposes, our thoughts are mediated by Mentalese expressions, then there is a cognitive basis to the different causal roles had by “Mary is nervous” and “Fred is angry”. So the difference between “Mary is nervous” and “Fred is angry” cannot be purely morphology-based.
        Conceivably, Fodor counter-reply by saying this:
   
    “For the reasons you give, where symbols of natural language are concerned, any shape can be associated with any syntax at all, given the right background facts. But things are different where Mentalese symbols are concerned. In Mentalese, morphology does realize syntax.”
 
 
      Since, as we have seen, syntax is an aspect of semantics, this reply amounts to saying:  “In
Mentalese, morphology realizes semantics.”
      But no advocate of CTM, and definitely not Fodor, would say that morphology realizes semantics, even where Mentalese is concerned. CTM is a form of functionalism. Functionalism says that the semantics of a brain-state supervenes not on its morphology but on its causal role. So given that syntax supervenes on semantics, functionalism says, in effect, that the syntax of a brain-state does not supervene on its morphology.
     (In many places, Fodor vehemently argues that the semantics of brain-states don’t supervene on any of their intrinsic properties, let alone on their shapes. So Fodor himself would never say that, where
Mentalese is concerned, semantics supervenes on morphology. See Fodor 1981b, 1994a-1994d, 1998.)
 
 
[163]
 Fodor 1994a (23) writes:
 
“There must be mental symbols because, in a nutshell, only symbols have syntax, and our best available theory of mental processes…needs the picture of the mind as a syntax-driven machine.”
 
 Fodor is quite right to say that only linguistic expressions have syntax. So he is quite right to say that if thinking consists in syntax-driven operations, then there is an internal language (a “language of thought”). But, unfortunately for Fodor’s position, syntax doesn’t adequately reflect logical form, for the reasons we’ve just been considering. So if we were syntax-driven machines, we would be logicblind.

 Barwise and Perry 1999 (22).
[165]
 This point, or one like it, is famously found in Wittgenstein 1958, though Wittgenstein’s point seems to be less mentalistic. Similar points are found in Putnam 1975 and Burge 1979.
[166]
 A line of thought concerning linguistic meaning that has certain similarities to this one – but that has a far less mentalistic orientation – is found in Wittgenstein 1958.
 
[167]
  Since Frege, it has been generally assumed that, in natural language, syntax is a poor indicator of logical form. Consider:
 

	* “Bill is a green duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”

	* “Bill is a decoy duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”
 
     The stock line on this sort of phenomenon is as follows. In (a), syntax tracks logic; in (b), syntax does not track logic. But (a) and (b) have the same syntax. Therefore syntax does not track logic, at
least not in natural language. (In artificial languages, syntax may reflect logical form.)      By itself, this is not a problem for CTM. CTM can say:
 
 Thought consist in syntax-driven operations; but those operations involves symbols of what we might call a “well-behaved” language – the kind that Frege and Russell talked about: a language in which there is a kind of coincidence between logical and syntactical form. In English “Bill is a decoy duck” has the same syntax as “Bill is a green duck.” But “Bill is a green duck” means: “Bill is a duck and Bill is green”, whereas “Bill is a decoy duck” does not mean “Bill is a decoy and Bill is a duck”. If thinking consists in syntax-driven operations, the medium of computation is a language in which doesn’t contain distortion like “Bill is a decoy duck” – everything is made perspicuous.
 
    This is a reasonable response; but it leaves some important issues untouched. No speaker of English would regard (b) as a legitimate inference. Why not? Because anyone who knows the meaning of (b) knows that it is not equivalent to: “Bill is a duck and Bill is a decoy, therefore Bill is a duck”. A knowledge of meaning is what prevents faux-inferences like (b).
    But a knowledge of meaning is always involved in determinations of syntactic structure, even in cases of the idealized languages referenced by Russell and Frege. Suppose we spoke a language like English except that, in this other language, syntactical form mirrored logical form. Let English* be this other language. The English*-translation of “Bill is a green duck” is “Bill is green and Bill is a duck”. The English*-translation of  “Bill is a decoy duck” is not “Bill is a decoy and Bill is a duck”; it is (roughly) “Bill is an object that looks like a duck, but is not a duck”.  So English* doesn’t contain the devices that, in English, make syntax diverge from logical form.
     We know that, in actual English, a knowledge of semantics is needed to avoid faux-inferences like (b): if one relies only on syntax, one is thrown off. But the same is always true; it is true of English* no less than English. Consider the sentence:
 
(c) “Bill is green and Bill is a duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”
 
This sentence is valid; and its validity is (reasonably well) reflected in its syntax. (I say “reasonably well” because, for reasons discussed earlier, the context-sensitive components in the sentence prevent its logical form from being completely reflected in its syntax.) But you couldn’t possibly know what syntax it had unless you knew that “Bill” were a singular term (i.e. denoted an individual), “green” were a one-place predicate (i.e. denoted a function of one variable), and so on. If these terms had different denotations, then (c) would have an entirely different syntactic form. There is no knowledge of the syntax of (c) without knowledge of some facts about its semantics’. It doesn’t matter whether (c) is considered as a sentence of English or English*. Taken as a sentence of English*, (c) is well-formed only if “Bill” denotes an individual, “green” is a one-place predicate, and so on. So even in English*, syntax-driven operations – so-called “formal” inferences -- are semantics-driven. The difference between English and English* is not that, in the latter one needs no semantic knowledge to make formal inferences, whereas, in the former, one does need such knowledge. The difference lies in how much semantic knowledge is needed. In English, one needs knowledge of the specific meanings of predicates to make the right inferences. In English*, one needs only fairly generic knowledge; one doesn’t need to know the specific meanings of expressions; one need only know that (e.g.) “small” denotes some one-place predicate or other. But in any language, no matter how well-behaved, syntaxdriven operations are semantics driven. When you say that a language is well-behaved, you aren’t saying that, in it, the set of semantic facts is reflected in non-semantic facts; you are saying that the set of semantic facts is reflected in a certain subset of that same set. 
   There is another way to look at all this: a way that, if correct, is even more problematic for CTM. Again consider:
 

	* “Bill is a green duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”

	* “Bill is a decoy duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”
 
   As we noted, the standard diagnosis is that, in English and other natural languages, syntactic categories don’t appropriately line up with semantic categories; and, for that reason, syntax-based inferences are often erroneous, when we are dealing with sentences of natural language.
    This is certainly one way to look at things. There is another possibility. It is a distinct possibility that “decoy duck” and “green duck” are syntactically different. As we saw, the syntactic profile of a sentence is a function of the  more generic facts about the semantics of its constituents: it is a function, not of what specific things its constituents mean, but of the kinds of thing they mean. “Jerry snores and Mary does not snore”  has a certain syntactic structure; it has it because “Jerry” is a singular term, “snores” is a first-order one-place predicate, “and” is a certain kind of functor, and so forth. Given this, consider:
 

	* “Something is tall”.

	* “Bob is tall”.
 
      “Bob” denotes an individual; it is a singular term. “Something” does not denote an individual. It is not a singular term. It is a second-level predicate, one that (arguably) denotes a second-level function. “Tall” (if Frege is right) denotes a function from individuals to truth-values: so it denotes a first order function. “Something” denotes a function from first order functions (functions from individuals to truth-values) to truth-values. Supposing that the Frege-Montague analysis is even remotely right, “something” denotes  a function F that assigns truth to a first-order function f exactly if, for some x, f assigns truth to x. “Something” and “Bob” denote such different things that they are plausibly seen as falling into different syntactic categories; so (A) and (B) are plausibly seen as being syntactically different. Of course, (A) and (B) are grammatically parallel. But, as Chomsky pointed out long ago, grammatical categories make for very superficial taxonomy. Grammar is folk-syntax; grammatical descriptions are shallow and, at best, approximate, syntactic descriptions. (When I talk about “grammar”, I am referring to the taxonomic system that we are taught in school: the system that includes categories like “noun”, “adjective”, “determiner”, “conjunction”, and that regards “a man” and “Socrates” as both being “noun phrases” and thus in the same syntactic category.  So when I talk about “grammar”, I am not using the term that it bears in expressions like “generative grammar”, “universal grammar”, or in any of the theories that aspire to replace the taxonomy we learn in school with a deeper characterization of language.)
      It is a possibility worth considering that “decoy” and “green”, like “Bob” and “something”, denote entirely different kinds of things. If this is right, then
 

	* “Bill is a green duck”,
 
and
 

	* “Bill is a decoy duck”,
 
  do not have the same syntactic structure. The sentence “Bill is a green duck” is true exactly if Bill is both green and duck. For (C) to be true, it is necessary that Bill fall into a sub-class of the class of ducks. So the term “green” can be seen as a function that maps a predicate (in this case “duck”) onto a restriction of itself.  But the term “decoy” does not function in this way at all.  For (D) to be true, Bill must fall outside the class of ducks. So “decoy” does not denote a function from predicates onto restrictions of themselves. It has for its meaning an entirely different sort of function.
      Given that “decoy” and “duck” denote such different things, it is not out of the question that they might be syntactically very different. Remember that the syntax of an expression consists in very generic facts about its semantics. Where “decoy” and “green” are concerned, those generic facts might be sufficiently different to warrant putting those expressions in different syntactic categories. If that is right – I am not saying that it is, but I am saying that it is a possibility worth looking into --  then the syntax of (C) is entirely different from the syntax of (D). In that case, the difference between
 

	* “Bill is a green duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”

	* “Bill is a decoy duck, therefore Bill is a duck.”
 
is reflected in a difference in syntax. So the fact that (a) is valid, while (b) is not, does not necessarily reflect a failure for English semantic categories to line up with English syntactic categories. We are quick to see English, and other natural languages, as badly behaved. We take the invalidity of inferences like (b), and like “Bill is a small elephant, therefore Bill is small”, to indicate that English lacks a certain transparency – that it is, in some respect, “badly behaved”. What I am suggesting is that, arguably (though not definitely), those cases of bad behavior are merely apparent. When we look at the syntax of the expressions involved, we find that English is no less well-behaved than English* or any formal language. Syntactic facts are so deeply embedded in semantics facts that there no hope of a syntax-driven entity that isn’t also semantics-driven.  I am suggesting that, in English, semantic and syntactic categories quite possibly do line up as well as they do in formal languages. The view that they do not is based on a confusion of grammar (in the sense of what we learn in middle school, not in the sense of “generative grammar”, “transformational grammar” and the like), which is a superficial theory about syntax, with syntax itself. Because of sentences like (b), it is obvious that there is no way for a semantics-blind entity to track logical relations among English sentences. So if English is wellbehaved, as I am suggesting it might be, then it is obvious that a semantic-blind entity cannot track logical relations holding among sentences of a well-behaved language. Semantic knowledge will always be involved.
         A different example might clarify my point. Traditional grammar sees the following two sentences as having the same form:
 
(A) “John touches a boat.” (B) “John wants a boat”.
 
    But there is every reason to believe that “wants” and “touches” are syntactically very different: the first takes a sentence (or open sentence) for its complement; the latter takes a subsentential expression. Permit to explain my meaning. (A) is famously ambiguous between de dicto and de re readings (Quine
1966). The de dicto reading is: John wants that there is some boat x such that John has x. According to Quine (1966), the de re reading is: There is some boat x such that: John has x. But if Quine is right, then “wants” sometimes denotes a relation to a proposition (de dicto reading) and sometimes denotes a relation to an object, and not a proposition (de re reading). But it is quite clear that, even in the de re case, what is wanted is the truth of a certain proposition. John does not simply want a boat. There is some specific boat x such that what John wants is: that John has x. So the de re reading is: There is some boat x such that John wants that John has x. What is wanted is always the truth of a proposition, even in de re cases of wanting. In the de re case, there is some specific object x such that one wants the truth of a proposition of the form:…x…In the de dicto case, there is no such object; the truth of the proposition in question doesn’t turn on facts about this or that specific boat.
   But one touches an object, not a proposition. So “wants” denotes a relation between a person and a proposition; “touches” denotes a relation between an individual and an object. So a case can be made that, when we make perspicuous the syntax of (A) and (B), it turns out that (A) has the form for some x, aRx, while (B) has the form a wants that: for some x such that phi(x), a has x or for some x such that phi(x),  a wants that: a has x. So (A) and (B) do have different syntactic structures. Many linguists hold, for more or less the reasons just given, that (A)’s syntactic form – not simply the form that some logical reconstruction of it has – is different from (B)’s  Similar remarks favor the view that (1) “John knows that snow is white” and (2) “John thinks that snow is white” have different syntactical structures, and that this difference in syntax is responsible for the different logical properties of those sentences (e.g. that the first implies that snow is white, while the second does not). For related remarks, see Chomsky 1975 (93-95).
    The point I am making is that syntax is so deeply embedded in semantics that, until we have fairly high resolution knowledge of semantics, we cannot make judgments about the extent to which syntax and semantics line up; and we cannot make syntactic judgments at all. See Chomsky 1975 (95).  So, even when we are dealing with “perspicuous” formal languages, sensitivity to syntax presupposes fairly  high-resolution semantic-knowledge.
   In many places, Chomsky has argued compellingly that (1) “John expected Bill to leave” and (2) “John persuaded Bill to leave” have very different syntactic structures, even though, from the viewpoint of the grammar we learned in school,  they have the same syntactic structure. (See Chomsky 1965.) This bears out our position.
     Our position is further confirmed by consideration of the problematic relationship between phonetics and semantics. Sentences of natural language are typically replete with phonetically unrealized constituents. Here is an extreme example. You ask Bob “who killed Caesar?”. Bob says: “Brutus”. The naïve and false thing to say is:
 
“The semantics of Bob’s utterance was a proposition of the form aRb. But the syntactic form of Bob’s utterance was simply a. So Bob’s utterance involved a misalignment of semantics with syntax.”
 
   The first sentence is correct. But it is easy to make a case against the second two sentences. Bob’s utterance is plausibly seen as elliptical for – as a mere phonetic condensation of --  “Brutus killed Caesar.” If that is right, then that utterance is simply an abbreviated – a phonetically condensed – way of saying “Brutus killed Caesar”. From the viewpoint of semantics, though not of phonetics, Bob did say “Brutus killed Caesar”. So when we undo the distortions of phonetics, we find that Bob’s utterance did have the form aRb. In general, when we undo phonetic distortions, we find, arguably, that there is an alignment of semantics and syntax. I suspect that our folk-syntactic theories embody a failure to undo the distortions of phonetics; they put too much syntactic stock in what are really just methods of abbreviation that have no syntactic significance (e.g. saying “Brutus” instead of “Brutus killed Caesar”). In my view, that is why folk-syntax (the grammar we learn in school) is so out of alignment with semantics. Folk-syntax lumps together (A) and (B) because in natural language, for reasons of efficiency, important syntactic differences are telescoped, hidden beneath phonetic condensations, and we naively mistake the chaff of ellipsis for the wheat of semantics.
      At one point in the Tractatus, Wittgenstein says that, where natural language is concerned, “everything is in order”. I myself do not know quite what he means. But one possible interpretation lies in the points just made. The Russell-Frege view is that sentences of natural language are inherently obscure: there is a divergence between what they seem to say and what they actually say, and this divergence owes to there not being a perfect alignment, in natural language, of the syntactical with the semantic. The point I was making in response is that what is at fault is not natural language, but our crude theories about how natural language functions – theories that are embodied in the grammar we are taught at school. Because these theories are so approximate (because, for example, that theory puts “some man” and “John” in the same syntactic category), we end up believing that the “syntax” of natural language is out of alignment with its semantics. But what is out of alignment is our theory of the syntax of natural language, not the syntax itself.

 To block this line of argumentation, CTM must say this:
 
         “Where symbols of natural language are concerned, any shape can be associated with any syntax at all, given the right semantic background. But things are different where Mentalese symbols are concerned. In Mentalese, morphology does realize syntax.”

[169]
 Advocates of CTM often talk about how semantics can be “coded” in morphology; and they say that, because Mentalese semantics is appropriately “coded” in Mentalese morphology, morphologydriven operations on such symbols constitute content-driven operations. The word “coded” here is ambiguous; and neither disambiguation is favorable to CTM.
      On one interpretation, to say that Mentalese semantics is “coded” in Mentalese morphology is to say that there is a correspondence – a one-one function (or, at any rate, some kind of function) – from Mentalese semantics to Mentalese morphology. As we just saw, in this sense of the term “coded”, given only that Mentalese semantics is coded in Mentalese morphology, it does not follow that a morphology-driven operation on Mentalese symbols is a computation or inference of any kind. What drives the play of symbols must be a knowledge of that correspondence, a knowledge of that codingrelation; and such knowledge is obviously semantic (and, indeed, extra-semantic).
    On another interpretation of the word “coded”, to say that Mentalese semantics is “coded” in Mentalese morphology is to say that Mentalese morphology is Mentalese semantics or, in any case, that  Mentalese semantics supervenes on Mentalese morphology. But, as we saw in footnotes 35 and 41, it is probably not open to CTM to say that Mentalese semantics supervenes on Mentalese morphology.

 I don’t know whether, at the level of detail, this characterization is accurate. [173]
 Even the use of truth-tables to perform a computation is not, strictly speaking, a mechanical process. For every language in which a given shape – say, “P or not P” -- expresses the disjunction of a proposition and its negation, there are infinitely many in which it expresses the conjunction of a proposition and its negation, and infinitely many in which it expresses nothing at all.  The same is true mutatis mutandis of “if P, then P”, “P and not P”, “if P, then P or Q”, and so on. If those shapes are taken to have certain meanings, then there is a function -- embodied in the method of truth-tables -assigning truth or falsity to certain expressions depending on their shapes. So using truth-tables to perform a computation (to determine truth-values) thus presupposes semantic background knowledge; it presupposes a knowledge that certain semantic conventions are operative.

(This is not my own belief; but I do not wish to deny, at least not in this context, that this might turn out to be the case.)

For a computation is not a manipulation of symbols; a computation is not a morphology-driven sequence of symbols. A computation is a judgment regarding the validity of strings of symbols. Such a judgement may, or may not, result in a manipulation of shapes.

[194]
 Although the word ‘concept’ is ambiguous, that ambiguity is not as radical as that associated with words like ‘bank’ and ‘rent’. Presumably, a mental entity qualifies as a concepto in the psychological sense – as a grasp of something – if it somehow encodes a concepto in the objective sense. I grasp the concepto of triangularity – which is a non-mental entity – by virtue of having a mental content which somehow encodes that concepto. So a concept in the psychological sense is a mental entity which encodes a concepto in the objective sense.
   Also both concepts and conceptso are modes of presentation. The concepto class of all points equidistant from a given point is a mode of presentation of the property of sphericity, and so is the concepto closed three-dimensional figure of uniform curvature. So underneath the superficial ambiguity of the word “concept”, there are identities of meaning.

 The reason is that we give “wide scope” to the descriptive information. I tell you “some guy stole my wallet.” You then think to yourself: he didn’t have to become a thief – he might have become a police officer. Here you are not thinking: it is possible that somebody x uniquely stole __’s wallet and also that x did not become a thief. What you are thinking is:  somebody x uniquely stole __’s wallet and there is a possible circumstance where  that x did not become a thief. So the descriptive information is given wide scope with respect to the modal operator. Even though it is always through descriptive information that we acquire concepts of objects (or so I will argue), that doesn’t corrupt our modal intuitions; for we give the descriptive information “wide scope” with modal operators.

[211]
 In fact, it is arguable that all such descriptions do, except when the description in question refers to some abstract object, like the number two. The (often hidden) presence of indexicals is needed to prevent problems relating to what Strawson called the “massive reduplication”. Your friend Fred says to you “somebody uniquely invented bifocals; his name is ‘Ben Franklin’”. As it happens, on a distant planet, some other person (or intelligent creature) also invented bifocals. Is Fred wrong? Not if we take him to mean: in this context – in the context of the world we occupy – somebody uniquely invented bifocals. Surely we would not take Fred to rule out the possibility that on some distant planet there were intelligent, bifocal-inventing life-forms. So, in effect, we attribute a hidden indexical to Fred’s statement. For reasons of this kind, we must see our discourse as permeated by indexicality, hidden though it may often be.

 Of course, the term “occasion” has to be defined somewhat narrowly. One can refer to twenty different people in a single conversation and thus on a single “occasion”. But at any specific juncture of that occasion – at any one time (leaving aside ambiguity) – one is referring to just one person or object. When I say “occasion” I mean a specific juncture of a discourse.

[215]
 It isn’t even clear if Russell was wrong about the nature of the uniquely individuating descriptions. It could be that he was simply using historically pregnant descriptions to illustrate his basic point, which is that one must have some uniquely individuating description of Socrates to think about, or refer to, Socrates. If he had illustrated his point with some uniquely individuating description that didn’t obviously apply to Socrates – e.g. the guy to whom Seymour was referring on occasion C…-nobody would have followed what he was saying. So his use of uniquely individuating descriptions like the philosopher who drank Hemlock may not really indicate his belief that that is an actual uniquely individuating description through which one might refer to, or think about Socrates. It might just be a superficial expository device. But I am not a Russell scholar; so I remain open on this.

[217]
 In fact, you don’t really see that it is Fido. Given only the information embodied in your senseperception, what you are seeing could be twin-Fido or Android-Fido. Your judgement that you are seeing Fido is meta-perceptual; it involves background knowledge and plausibility-considerations, and so forth.
[218]
 Kant, Brandom, and others have stressed that the veritable objects of mental representations are truth-evaluable contents: things that correspond more closely to sentences or whole propositions than to nouns, adjectives, and the like. Even if you are just hallucinating, or seeing, an apple, the content of your state is not just: an apple – it is more like there is an apple of such and such color in such and such place…The objects of linguistic representation are often mere objects: “Socrates, “Plato”, and so on. But it would be unwise to suppose that there existed such a perfect parallel between facts about public systems of communication and facts about conception. Even though, semantically, “Plato” is a simple, it is far from obvious that my concept of Plato is correspondingly “atomic” (though Fodor 1998 argues just this. In __ I counter-argue.) 
[219]
 I am not convinced that this is true of one’s grasp of objects in general. For, at least arguably, it would be viciously regressive to say that one grasped everything this way. After all, to grasp a description, one must grasp its constituents; and if one had to grasp each of these constituents by a description, we’d obviously be launched on an endless regress. So it seems to me (as it did to Russell, for nearly enough the same reasons) that we grasp something “directly” (non-descriptively). It also seems to me (as it did to Russell, for nearly enough the same reasons) that certain states of one’s own consciousness and at least some universals fall into this privileged category. But obviously the question “which things do we grasp non-descriptively?” is a large one, and deserves a discussion of its own.     (It should be observed that Sellarsian anti-foundationalism might suggest that, in fact, everything is grasped “descriptively” – that there are no unmediated, non-descriptive graspings. So perhaps the line of thought just put forth is naively foundationalist. If that is the case, then it would be generally true that, to think about object O, one must know some uniquely individuating description that applies to it. Of course, if one counts trivial descriptions like the unique x such that x=O, then perhaps it follows trivially that one must know such a description to grasp O. But here I am leaving aside descriptions of that sort – descriptions that, to be understood, presuppose a grasp of the thing in question.)

 I say “may” for a couple of reasons. After one learns that (so to speak) Hesperus=Phosphorous, then *Hesperus has phi* may end up coinciding in cognitive value with *Phosphorous has phi*. (Of course, this point has to be adjusted for speakers of other languages.)
  Also, depending on how one initially learns the meaning of “Hesperus” and “Phosphorous”, *Hesperus has phi* *Phosphorous has phi* might never have had different cognitive values (for that person) to begin with. This will be the case if am introduced to the words by somebody who points to Venus and says: “that  is called both ‘Hesperus’ and ‘Phosphorous’”.
[221]
  Let me end by considering an objection to this last line of thought (I will put the objection in the mouth of an imaginary locator):
 
“You have ex nihilo produced this strange theory of conception as being sustained by knowledge of interlocking existence claims. And you claim that recognition consists in seeing that some one object satisfies two existence claims. But all of this seems very ad hoc – something you’ve confabulated to get your bankrupt theory off the hook.”
 
    I think that this comment has force only to the extent that we’ve been jaded by wrong theories of sense-perception and, more generally, of objectual awareness.
    When you see Bob, embedded in your sense-perception is existential information. You cannot get rid of that existential information without eliminating the perception. This suggests that that existential information is constitutive of the content of the perception. Granted, Bob himself is (part of) the representational content of that perception. But he is given to you via this existential information.    So when you see Bob on some occasion t, the content of that perception is given by some bit of existential information like: there is some chap whom I’m now seeing, wearing a bowler hat…    You see Bob again, on occasion t*. Again, the content of your perception is given by some existence claim: there is some chap I’m seeing, wearing a baseball cap…
   On both occasions, the content of your perception is existential.
    Suppose that, on t*, you recognize the person you are seeing is the person you saw on t. Your tperception is given by existential information, and so is your t*-perception. So if, on t*, you recognize that you are seeing the same person you saw on t, that must consist in your realizing that the same entity satisfies both existence-claims are satisfied – that there is some one entity who satisfies both. Once a few platitudes are granted about sense-perception – that sense-perceptions have existential content -- our theory of conception and recognition proves to be far from ad hoc.

[225]
 Some qualifications are in order. First, in this paper, by ‘meaningful’, I mean ‘literally
significant’; I mean, essentially, ‘is such that, by virtue of its literal meaning, it is true or false.’ So I am using the term ‘meaningful’ in a narrow sense. I will, if I am not mistaken, be using the term ‘meaning’ and ‘meaningful’ to denote what used to be called cognitive meaning. No one denies that valuative sentences have a kind of significance: they are surely significant indicators of the mental states of those who utter them. What is in question is whether they are significant in the sense in which ‘Socrates was bald’ is significant; what is in question is whether they encode propositions – whether they are significant at the level of literal meaning. Any sentence that is significant at the level of literal meaning is a conventionalized way of expressing a potential belief. ‘Snow is white’, ‘2+2=4’, ‘2+2=5’ are conventionalized ways of expressing things that could be the object of belief. That is why such sentences are literally significant. It might be said: But “I do not exist” does not express a proposition that could be the object of belief, but it is literally significant. Fair enough: but the negation of what is expressed by “I do not exist” could be believed. And it is clear that ‘I do not exist’ has literal significant precisely because what it expresses can be disbelieved. So it would be fair to say that a sentence S is significant if it is such that it is a conventionalized way of encoding a potential belief or disbelief. In this paper, our primary focus is not the nature of literal meaning. I think it would lead to unnecessary complications and obscurity if I repeatedly said ‘a sentence is a conventionalized expression of a belief or a disbelief’; so I will just say – even though technically it may be inaccurate – ‘a sentence is significant if it is a conventionalized way of expressing a belief.’ Also, a disbelief is surely a kind of belief. So it may turn out to be technically accurate to say that a sentence is meaningful if it is a conventionalized way of expressing a belief.
   Some may balk at my claim that anything that is a conventionalized way of expressing a belief/disbelief is a sentence. “If I use smoke signals to indicate that I am in danger, have I produced a sentence?” My answer is: yes. You have a produced a sentence that belongs to a language that, instead of using phonemes, uses smoke-signals. There is, ultimately, nothing to being a sentence other than being part of an artificial and systematic means of encoding propositions and, therefore, of expressing beliefs/disbeliefs.
    In any case, whatever complications may connect with my analysis of literal meaning, I would be very surprised if these really undermined what I have to say about the relationship between emotivism and moral realism. To be sure, what I say about that relationship may be wrong or under-argued – but not in virtue of any deficits in my discussion of literal meaning.

 There is also the very real psychological possibility that, although they rejoiced in their evil deeds, Bundy and Dahmer – and other serial killers – at some level did have negative emotions towards them. The self-destructiveness evinced by many – though by no means all – serial killers is often chalked up to their own (unconscious) disgust at their deeds. There does seem to be the possibility, then, that if a serial killer sees an act that he committed as wrong, that is because, at some level, he does have the kind of emotion towards that act that, according to the emotivist, is expressed by sentences of the form ‘x is wrong.’  There is a striking anecdote about Ted Bundy. Before he was unmasked as a killer, he once asked a friend of his where in the United States a murderer was most likely to be put to death. The answer he was given was Florida. Bundy committed his final murders, was caught, and executed in Florida. Of course, these considerations do not show that it is not possible for someone to see something as wrong without having a negative emotion in connection with it. I bring up this point simply keep this highly abstract ethical discussion in contact with some psychological realities or, at any rate, possibilities.

  Sartre was a cognitivist: ‘Emotion is a certain way of apprehending the world…’ (in Calhoun and Solomon: 246) And so is Robert Solomon: ‘My emotions are judgments I make…’ (Solomon’s emphasis) (Calhoun and Solomon: 316).  See also the section entitled ‘Affectivity’ in Sartre’s The Psychology of the Imagination. The argument I set forth below for cognitivism is quite similar to Solomon’s. And I think that, ultimately, notwithstanding certain superficial dissimilarities, it is not so different from Sartre’s argument. Ultimately, all arguments for cognitivism devolve on considerations like those set forth below, though there is of course some variation at the level of detail.    If I am not mistaken, the entire ‘phenomenological’ school of thought endorses, and may be committed to, some kind of cognitivism about emotions. Cf. Merleau-Ponty The Phenomenology of Perception. And among analytic philosophers, cognitivism is one of the dominant views (though it may not be the dominant view). Cf. Calhoun and Solomon What is an Emotion? (Oxford 1993) especially the introduction.

 Of course, some people will say that there cannot be object-less moods. Indeed, some people say that everything mental has an object. But such people, I think, are forced to say that ‘mere’ moods and feelings are really emotions. This of course does not mean that emotions are beliefs. But it means that we should take seriously the idea that they are beliefs and, therefore, that we should take seriously the implication I am drawing from ‘emotions are beliefs’ to ‘emotivism is a form of realism.’

     The paradigm anti-cognitivist is Hume: “A passion is an original existence…and contains not any representative quality, which renders it a copy of any other existence or modification. When I am angry, I am actually possest with the passion, and in that emotion have no more reference to any other object, than when I am thirsty, or sick, or more than five foot high. ‘Tis impossible , therefore, that this passion can be oppos’d by, or be contradictory to, truth and reason; since this contradiction consists in the disagreement of ideas, consider’d as copies, with those objects, which they represents.’ (Treatise p.414) It is obvious, at the very least, Hume is quite wrong to say that (e.g.) anger contains no ‘reference to any other object’:  I am angry, I am angry at Bob or Sally or Fred. There is inevitably a ‘reference’ to an object. In What is an Emotion? (Calhoun and Solomon, editors) numerous attacks are waged on the Humean position.

   The English word ‘feeling’ is, I think, ambiguous between phenomenally pregnant state and attitude. I think that a similar ambiguity occurs in other languages: the verb ‘sentir’ has, I believe, a corresponding ambiguity. It is understandable why there is this ambiguity: presumably it stems from the fact that if one ‘feels’ a certain way about something in the sense that one has a certain attitude towards that thing, then one tends to have certain feelings – in the sense of phenomenally pregnant mental state – in connection with that thing. There is some kind of connection between e.g. hating someone – which is non-occurrent and, in and of itself, has no phenomenal content – and having certain negative ‘feelings’ in the narrow, purely phenomenal sense of this word. (The exact nature of this connection is unclear and has been the subject of heated debate.) But, for our purposes, it is enough to know that the word ‘feel’ is ambiguous between these two senses and that I am using this word to refer to attitudes, not phenomenally pregnant states (except in so far as some attitudes happen to be phenomenally pregnant).

[246]
         Some clarifications are in order. First of all, when I talk about the mental contents which a person has, I don’t mean the ones he has at a particular moment; but the totality of mental contents he has throughout his lifetime. Obviously a person cannot be identified with the mental contents which he has at some particular moment.
                Second – and probably more importantly -- I do not want to say that, according to the bundletheorist, a person is strictly speaking identical with the totality of mental contents which he has. For, presumably, the person has modal properties which the class of mental contents which he has does not. That class is modally frozen: if it were to contain a different member, it would ipso facto be a different class. By contrast, a person could obviously have different contents from the ones he has. (Compare: the statue is not identical with the clay of which it is composed. For the statue and the clay have different modal properties. The destruction of the statute doesn’t necessarily involve the destruction of the clay.) So a person cannot strictly speaking be identified with the class of contents which he has throughout his life. But what can be argued for is that a person is wholly constituted by the totality of mental contents which he has throughout his life. It is this view that I shall refer to as the ‘bundle theory’.
[247]
         Hume of course was a great proponent of the bundle theory. (Indeed, he may – though I’m not sure about this – have invented it.) 'All [of one's mental contents] are different, and distinguishable, and separable from each other, and may exist separately, and have no need of any thing to support their existence. After what manner, therefore, do they belong to the self; and how are they connected with it? For my part, when I enter most intimately into what I call myself, I always stumble on some particular perception .When my perceptions are remov'd for any time, as by sound sleep; so long am I insensible of myself, and may be truly said not to exist...I  may venture to affirm...that [people] are nothing  but a bundle or collection of different perceptions.’ Hume [1]  p.252.
[248]
         See, for example, Carruthers [1] pp. 54-57..
[249]
        There is another, perhaps a more perspicuous, way to state what I am trying to do. If (i) is true, then selves are built out of mental contents, just as building are built out of bricks: a self can no more exist independently of the mental contents that belong to it than a building can exist independently of the bricks that make it up. But a given self is not just built out of just any mental contents: it is built out of mental contents that cohere in a certain way, that stand in a certain relation of interdependence. Our building metaphor might illuminate this point. We cannot say of any two bricks that they are constituents of a single building; we can say this only of pairs of bricks that cohere in a certain way, that are physically related to each other in a certain way. Analogously, we cannot say of just any two contents that are constituents of a single person; we can say this only of two mental contents that cohere in a certain way: that stand in a certain coherence-relation to one another.                    Many have said that there is no non-circular way to define this coherence-relation. What is essentially equivalent:  that, with regard to the coherence-relation that holds between two contents belonging to a given person, in order to define that relation, we must invoke the idea of the self to whom both those contents belong. If this is correct, then selves are more basic than the coherencerelation in question. In that case, of course, selves are more basic than bundles of mental contents, and therefore cannot be identified with bundles of mental contents. As against this, I will try to show that we can give a non-circular definition of the aforementioned coherence-relation and that we can therefore rescue the idea that selves are wholly constituted by the mental contents which (as we say) they ‘have’.

         By purely physical interactions I mean physical interactions that do not have a mental component. By no means do I wish to suggest mental interactions are not themselves physical interactions. (I wish to remain neutral, at least in this context, on the question whether materialism or dualism is correct.)
[252]
       Before proceeding, I should make one point explicit. I have said that, when we are
dealing with the interaction of mental entities, we can speak (in a literal, non-metaphorical way) of the outcome of such an interaction as being appropriate to the mental entities involved. (My visual perception of Mary holding a chainsaw and my knowledge that Mary wants to kill me in some sense ‘combine’, and thus interact, to form an intention to flee from Mary. Surely the resulting intention is, in a non-metaphorical, non-artificial sense, appropriate to the aforementioned perception and knowledge.) So mental entities seem to have a normative (or, as I will henceforth say, thematic)  content. We can, non-metaphorically, say that a given mental entity M would appropriately occur in such and such a context.  In saying that mental entities have this sort of content, I am not saying that they have representational content (roughly, that they have conditions of satisfaction – that they are nonderivatively true or false). It is a hotly disputed question whether all mental entities have representational content. But, if what we’ve said is correct, it is relatively uncontroversial to suppose that they all have a certain kind of content – what I am calling ‘normative’ or ‘thematic’ content. For (so it seems) any given mental entity is non-derivatively appropriate in certain contexts (and thus nonderivatively appropriate) in others: ipso facto mental entities non-derivatively have a normative dimension or, as we might also say, normative (thematic) content.
 
[253]
         This definition of what a self is may seem unable to survive thought-experiments like the following. Suppose that, one day, Joe 'divided' into two people A and B (just as amoebas divide into two people), and A and B were equally well connected, both psychologically and physiologically, to Joe. It is said that Joe couldn't' be identical with both: for if he were, then given that identity is a transitive relation, it would follow that A was identical with; and it is clear that A is not identical with B. However, A's mental contents are I-related to Joe's mental contents, and so are B's mental contents. So our analysis seems to identify A and B.
                  How are we to respond to this? First of all, this kind of scenario poses a problem for every criterion of personal identity; it poses just as much of a problem for those who espouse a bodily theory of personal identity as it does for those who espouse a Humean theory; and it is certainly problematic for those who hold that a and b are identical in virtue of sharing a common 'transphenomenal' or 'transcendental' ego. So this kind of consideration is no more problematic for our theory than it is for any other.
                But for argument's sake, let us concede that this kind of consideration disproves our theory. Even granting this, we have still, I think, given a satisfactory analysis of what it is for two mental contents to belong to a single person-branch. What do I mean by a 'person-branch'? Suppose that Joe splits into A and B at time t. Consider the four dimensional  object composed of Joe up until t and of A after than: this object is a single person branch. (So therefore is the object composed of Joe up until t and then of B after that.) Our analysis does,  I think, give a satisfactory analysis of what it is for two mental contents to belong to a single person-branch; and therefore of what a single person-branch is. (A person-branch may be defined as the class of mental contents I-related to a particular mental content.) Of course, in actuality, people-branches always coincide with people. So our analysis of personal identity is at least extensionally correct.
         There is an altogether different class of objections to any Humean (or, more generally, any mentalistic) analysis of personal identity. Bernard Williams and others have set forth thought experiments that suggest, if they do not actually prove, that personal identity is to be analysed in terms of purely bodily continuity. There simply isn't room enough here to consider this type of objection. (See Williams [1].) But prima facie it would seem much more plausible to suppose that personal identity is to be analysed in terms of mental continuity, and not in terms of bodily continuity (except ins o far as, of course, mental continuity is a special case of bodily continuity); so it is certainly worth our while to try to come up with a reasonable mentalistic criterion of personal identity. In particular, it seems especially to come up with a mentalistic criterion of personal identity that is Humean in character. For any non-Humean, mentalistic criterion would, presumably, assume the existence of some kind of transcendental ego; and there is some reason to believe that the very conception of such an entity is an incoherent one.

 It is a matter of great controversy whether the representational content of a perception can be embodied in a sentence – whether e.g. the representational content of your perception can be fully captured by some locution like ‘stop-sign of such and such color thus such distance away…’ Purely for expository reasons, I am pretending that the representational content of your perception of the sign can, at least in part, be embodied in a proposition. (Incidentally, this is not an unreasonable assumption: one can always say what one has seen, at least up to a point: ‘I saw a man in red sweater…’) But what is not controversial is that, whatever causal properties the perception has, it has these at least partially in virtue of bearing a certain representational content. And this is the important point in the present context. Whether that representational content can be embodied in sentences/propositions is a secondary question. And I am only pretending that it can be so embodied in order to make the overall outlines of my argument more perspicuous.

[263]
 Of course, one could say this:
 
    Because you haven’t been given any kind of definition of “Argo”, you cannot really use that term with understanding, and you cannot really know what is meant by sentences containing it. When you produce the sounds “Argo sounds like a bad person”, you are really making some kind of metalinguistic statement, some statement like: “ ‘Argo’ refers to somebody who is bad”. And when you hear sentences like “Argo was a cad”, you cannot really understand them; what you understand is some related meta-linguistic claim like: “‘Argo’ refers to somebody who was a cad”.
 
    This position cannot be summarily dismissed; and I will not dismiss it. But, for our purposes, it is enough to note that the objector’s point seems quite false. Cases like the one just described are pervasive. There are many cases where no ostensive or descriptive definition is involved in our appropriation of a proper name. We hear the term being used; and – presto! – can use it ourselves. If the objector’s point is correct, we are not really using any of these terms: we are merely mentioning them; when we produce sentences containing them, we are talking not about people, but about symbols denoting people. But this seems false. I have never been given a descriptive or ostensive definition of the term “Charlemagne”. But it certainly appears as though I can make statements about Charlemagne, and not just about “Charlemagne”. For reasons of philosophical modesty, I will operate on the assumption that this appearance is veridical.

[269]
 We have said that to have a conception of x is to know some true proposition of the form…C…, where C is a uniquely individuating description of x.  There are, of course, cases where a causal connection to x is essentially involved. But, as we have seen, the causal connection is always embedded in knowledge of a proposition of the kind just described.
     But there is an obvious problem with this view: a problem that doesn’t threaten the things we’ve said, but must still be dealt with. I myself do not know who invented the fugue. Let O be that person, whoever it is. (To simplify discussion, let us suppose that exactly one person invented the fugue.) I certainly know some true proposition of the form:…C…, where C is a description that applies uniquely to O. I know that the following are true:
 

	* Somebody x uniquely invented the fugue and he had at least some musical ability.

	* Somebody x uniquely invented the fugue and he lived before the 19th century.

	* Somebody x uniquely invented the fugue and x invented the fugue.
 
 
   Obviously knowing some uniquely individuating description that applies to O isn’t enough to know who O is. And it therefore isn’t enough to know which proposition is semantically encoded in sentences like:
 

	* “O was a talented composer”.

	* “O died of scurvy.”

	* “O incurred the wrath of his less talented contemporaries.”
 
    Remember what we said earlier about “Julius” and “Newman I”. Unless one knows which individuals these terms refer to, one doesn’t know which propositions are encoded in “Julius was tall” and “Newman 1 will be a genius”; one has a simulated, but not an actual, understanding of what is meant by such sentences. One has knowledge of a description of the proposition that is encoded in such a sentence, but one doesn’t know which proposition is thus described. One knows that “Julius was tall” is true exactly if somebody x uniquely invented the zipper and x was tall. So it is clear that knowing who so and so is, and thus knowing the literal meanings of terms that refer to so and so, does not consist (merely) in knowing some uniquely individuating description that applies to so and so.     What else is needed? The short, very approximate answer is:  To identify is to re-identify. To know who so and so is, one must know of two existence-claims that are uniquely verified by so and so and, further, one must know that some one person uniquely verifies them. Suppose you meet Bob on Monday. Since you have just met him, there is a sense in which you don’t know who he is. If somebody asks you, “do you know who this is?”, you must say: “I am afraid I do not.”  But, of course, in meeting him, you are uploading information that enables you to think about him – you are acquiring a concept of him. As we saw, this information is existential. Suppose that, a day later, you see Bob again. This time, there is a sense in which you know who you are seeing. As we saw earlier, your recognizing Bob consists in your knowing two existence claims of which he is the sole verifier, and
also in your knowing that he uniquely verifies those propositions.
    That is the short answer to the question “what is it to know who somebody (or something) is?”. Here is the long answer. Identification is a contextual notion; it is always relative to some background question, or relative to some body of knowledge, that one knows, or fails to know, who somebody is. Suppose you have been living next door to Bob for years. You know very little about Bob. He doesn’t talk much. He politely waves at you when he mows his lawn. But beyond that, he is a mystery. Later you and your wife are at the beach. You see somebody in the distance. Mary, who has poor vision, asks: “do you know who that is?” You, have better vision, say: “yes: it is Bob, our neighbor.” From some viewpoint, you know who it is that you are seeing: you can identify that person.
  The next day, C.I.A. agents come to your house. They brusquely ask you: “Do you have any idea who your neighbor is?” You say: “I don’t understand. He’s just some guy who waves at me when he mows the lawn.” They say: “Your neighbor is really the ringleader of an extensive terrorist organization. The government has been looking for him for years…”
   When you saw Bob at the beach, you did know who he was, at least from one viewpoint. But, from some other viewpoint, you have never known who Bob is, at least not until you were briefed by the C.I.A. agents. So you did, and you did not, know who Bob was.   
    What happened here? As we saw earlier, having a conception of an external world object involves two things: having knowledge of existence claims of which that object is the sole verifier; having a certain kind of  knowledge about those existence claims – more specifically, knowing that some one entity satisfies them all.
     Whenever somebody verbally, or ostensively, indicates an object, some existence claim, of which that object is the unique verifier, is implicated. Mary points out Bob to you. You see Bob: in seeing Bob, what is given to you is some existence claim like: there is somebody x to whom I am attending, and x is standing in such and such place, and has such and such appearance…When Mary asks you “do you know who that is?”, what is really being asked is something like: there is somebody x over there, to whom we are attending, and x has such and such features: do you know who x is? And in being asked do you know who x is? you are being asked to identify a more comprehensive set of interlocking existence claims of which x is the unique verifier. Because your vision is good, you are able to do this: you are able to say something  like somebody y is uniquely our neighbor and x is identical with y. (Of course, these are not the words you would use. But this would be the import of your statement.) In saying “that is Bob, our neighbor”, you are conveying (though this isn’t what your words literally mean):
 
(*) somebody x uniquely lives on the left side of our house, mows his lawn frequently, goes by “Bob”, and x THAT PERSON  over there is identical with x.
 
The only qualification is the person who you are now seeing on the beach – the person whom you can see sharply, and whom Mary can see only blurrily – is given to you through an existence claim: there is somebody y to whom we are now  attending…So (*) really amounts to this:
 
(**)somebody x uniquely lives on the left side of our house, mows his lawn frequently, goes by “Bob”, there is somebody y (over there, building a sand-castle)  to whom we are now  attending, and  y  is identical with x.
 
  Your background knowledge of Bob consists in your having knowledge of a set of interlocking existence claims. So your being able to identify the man in the beach consists in your being able to generate knowledge another such existence claim, and in your knowing of that new existence claim that it is satisfied by the same individual who satisfies the others (i.e. in knowing some one individual uniquely satisfies that new existence claim and the other ones). So relative to that background knowledge – to your knowledge of those existence claims – you know the answer to the question “who is that?”
    But relative to other bodies of background knowledge, this is not the case. You know that there were various bombings, in various cities. You know that somebody or other headed the organization responsible. So you know something like:
 
(^) Somebody x is responsible for such and such atrocities.
 
   You also know that you have a harmless-seeming neighbor. So you know something like:
 
(^^) Somebody y lives in the house to the left, and y waves at me while he mows the lawn.
 
   When the C.I.A. agents say to you “you have no idea who Bob is”, the import of their words is:
somebody x is your neighbor, and somebody y committed such and such atrocities, and you don’t know that x=y. Relative to (^) you don’t know the identity of the man who waves at you as he mows his lawn. But relative to some other existence claim, you do know the identity of the person whom you and Mary are seeing at the beach. To identify someone (or something) is to connect one existence claim to some other existence claim. Identification is a relative notion. Suppose that Bob is given to you through existence claim E1. You may be able to relate E1 to E2, i.e. you may know that someone uniquely satisfies both E1 and E2. But you may not be able to relate E1 to E3, i.e. you may not know that someone uniquely satisfies both E1 and E3.
     There is a sense in which any three year old knows what water is. But there is also a sense in which any three year old (except for a few prodigies) do not know what water is. Suppose you point to water and ask little Timmy, “what is that?” He says: “that is water.” He has correctly identified the substance in the glass. So, in that sense, he knows the identity of the liquid in the glass.
 
(w1)  There is some substance x such that Timmy drinks x, bathes in x, and so forth.
 
 
Timmy knows that w1 is true. Timmy also knows that
 
 
(w2) there is some substance y such that y is in the glass being indicated.
 
 
Further, Timmy knows that
 
(w3) There is some substance x such that Timmy drinks x, bathes in x, and so forth; there is some substance y such that y is in the glass being indicated; and y=x.
 
 
 
So relative to w1, Timmy can identify the substance in the glass. But relative to other existence claims, this is not the case.
 
 
(w4) There is a substance z such that z has thus and such chemical structure.
 
 
Obviously non-prodigy Timmy doesn’t know that:
 
 
(w5) There is a substance z such that z has thus and such chemical structure; and there is some substance y such that y is in the glass being indicated; and y=x.
 
 
So relative to (w4), Timmy doesn’t know what is in the glass. There is no paradox here. Identification is relative to background knowledge. Being able to identify an object is being able to connect it to background knowledge. Timmy can connect the liquid in the glass to certain bodies of knowledge, but not to others. So, from some certain viewpoints, but not all, Timmy knows what is in the glass.    Being able to understand
 
 
(J) “Julius was tall”
 
 
involves knowing who “Julius” refers to. (Here we are using “Julius” in Evans’ sense, as a descriptive name that refers to that person, whoever it might be, that invented the zipper.) Knowing who “Julius” refers to involves knowing not one existence claim that he satisfies: it involves knowing (at least) two such claims, and also knowing that some one person satisfies them both. Further, knowing who “Julius” refers to is contextual: relative to some existence claims, you might know it; relative to others, you might not. So the concept of knowing what a term refers to, and therewith the concept of being able to assign meaning to a term, is contextual: so, therefore, is the concept of understanding a sentence-token.

Some of what I say goes beyond what Sellars (1963a) says or, perhaps, even implies. But I would like to think that what I say here does develop some of the inner meanings of that great work.

But, rough and ready though it is, the concept of a perceivable property is not without its utility; and the fact that it is subject to qualifications does not have any bearing in this context.

[277]
 Of course intentionalists might say: ‘ no one is mad enough to suppose that different species have the same kind of phenomenal content in response to a different kind of sound (experienced under a given set of circumstances). And, of course, no one denies that creatures that have different
phenomenal contents (in response to a given kind of sound under a given set of circumstances) can hear just as veridically, if not more so, than we. Intentionalism – at least any sane version of it – applies within species, not between species.’
  But this concession eviscerates intentionalism. Intentionalism wants a metaphysically necessary relationship between the representational and the phenomenal; not a merely causal, contingent one. Obviously if intentionalism is not true across species, then a given bit of representational content can be realized by very different phenomenal contents, and there is no long any kind of reduction of the phenomenal to the mental, and thus no explanation of the phenomenal in terms of the representational (at least none along intentionalist lines). But the interest  of intentionalism is surely not that it register the idiosyncrasies of species, but that it captures some kind necessary fact about the relationship between phenomenal and representational content. And if this relationship doesn’t hold across species, then that relationship isn’t necessary. And it probably – almost assuredly -  doesn’t hold across species.

[295]
 Things that are non-mental can in some sense be representational. The following deposit of ink – ‘snow’ – represents snow, even though that deposit of ink is non-mental. But it seems to represent snow only by virtue of its association with mental entities that represent snow. So the word ‘snow’ represents snow only derivatively of its connection with mental entities that represent snow. In general, whenever something non-mental is representational, it is that only derivatively of its association with something mental: with something that is intrinsically representational. In any case, this is the generally held view.

[303]
 Admittedly, some philosophers (e.g. Fred Dretske) have said that things like thermometers and weathervanes – things that we would tend to characterize as ‘non-mental’ – are non-derivatively representational; that the thermometer really is, in and of itself, saying that it is 35; that the weathervane really is, in and of itself, indicating the direction of the wind. But if it is true that e.g. the thermometer per se is literally saying that it is 35 degrees outside, then it seems to follow that the thermometer per se has a kind of rudimentary mentality. And indeed, those philosophers who hold that thermometers, weathervanes, etc. are non-derivatively intentional, also tend to say that that have some kind of mentality. For example, Dretske says that, because the thermometer non-derivatively represents the temperature, there is ipso facto no categorial difference between it and (e.g.) and an indisputably representational, and therefore mental, entity like Joe’s belief that it is 35.
