[305]
 It must be pointed out that the word ‘necessarily’ here corresponds to metaphysical, as opposed to causal, necessity. To clarify this: The representationalist wishes to reduce phenomenal content to representational content. So if it is merely causally impossible, but still metaphysically possible, that two mental entities should have the same representational content while having different phenomenal contents, that would be inconsistent with representationalism: the mere metaphysical possibility that variation in phenomenal content might be independent of variation of representational content would be enough to show that there was something to phenomenal content over and above representational content. So, throughout this essay, whenever I mention any kind of necessity, it will be to metaphysical, not causal, necessity; when I use the terms like ‘supervene’ and ‘necessary’ and ‘is wholly a function of’, and the like,  I will be using them in their metaphysical, not their causal, senses. (So when I say e.g. that x ‘supervenes’ on y, I mean that it is  metaphysically impossible that there should be a change in x without a change in y. When I say that it is ‘necessary’ that a change in x correspond to a change in y, I mean that metaphysically – quite apart from the laws that happen to govern our universe -- a change in x must correspond to a change in y. And when I refer to the view that e.g. phenomenal content is wholly a function of  [or is wholly determined by] representational content  – or (what is the same) to the view that a mental entity has the phenomenal content it has entirely in virtue of  its having the representational content that it has --  I am referring to the view that it is metaphysically, not merely causally, impossible that a difference in phenomenal content should fail to correspond to a difference in representational content.)

 In the present context, an ‘experience’ is an occurrent mental phenomenon having phenomenal content. So e.g. the occurrent phenomena posited by Chomsky and Marr and mediate visual and linguistic processing are not – as we are using this word – experiences (though, conceivably, others might describe them as such); and the non-occurrent mental contents – e.g. my belief that 2 is even – are not (as we are using the word) ‘experiences’.

[314]
 Sometimes – indeed, usually -- the terms ‘conceptual’ and ‘non-conceptual’ are used instead. But I think that the distinction I have in mind is best understood as one between propositional and nonpropositional contents, not between conceptual and non-conceptual content. For it is fairly clear – and, in any case, it is generally  held --  that propositions can have non-conceptual content. The proposition Socrates is bald is de re about Socrates, and thus has Socrates himself – who is obviously not a concept – as a constituent. So the distinction between propositional and non-propositional content is different from that between conceptual and non-conceptual content – notwithstanding that some people talk of the distinction between ‘conceptual and non-conceptual content’ when they are discussing whether the content of a representation can be embodied in a proposition.  Actually, the people who use the terms ‘conceptual content’ and ‘non-conceptual content’ to mark the distinction I  am talking about – the distinction between, as I am putting it, propositional and non-propositional content – almost always hold that there are object-involving propositions, i.e. that non-concepts – e.g. Socrates, Plato – can be constituents of propositions. Given this, it is odd that, when they are discussing the question whether all represnetaitonal content can be embodied in propositions, they often state this question as ‘is all representational content conceptual?’ Again, it seems to me that (often, though probably not always) what is really being asked is ‘is all representational content propositional’’  (or ‘is all represnetaitonal content capable of being embodied in a proposition?’) and not ‘is all represnetaitonal content conceptual?’
[315]
 What I mean by this can best be understood by contrasting visual representations with patently hybrid –patently heterogeneous -- representations. A comic strip is a patently hybrid kind of representation: there is a picture (e.g. of a superhero performing some great feat) and there are also words (which are put in a bubble emanating from the mouth of the featured character). So comics are both analogue and digital and are thus, in an obvious way, heterogeneous representations. Now when we consider purely analogue representations – e.g. visual perceptions – there seems to no such internal division.

 It must be noted that Byrne makes it very clear that he wishes to defend the position that, given any two experiences – regardless of whether they are associated with the same sensory modality and, regardless of whether they belong to any sensory modality (e.g. itches and tickles, arguably, do not belong to any of the five senses) – those two experiences cannot differ phenomenally without differing representationally. This is the pillar of Byrne’s argument; but it obviously supports, at most, the claim that within a particular modality phenomenal variation supervenes on representational variation.
[318]
 There has been a great deal of discussion in the literature as to whether so-called ‘spectruminversion’ is possible. I do not know whether it is possible. But there seems to me nothing impossible about the spectrum-shift just described. It seems perfectly possibly – metaphysically, if not medically – to alter someone’s brain in such a way that, in response to physical disturbance x1, they have phenomenal content y2, even though previously that person had phenomenal content y1 in response to x1. In fact, there seem to be cases where such spectrum-shift has actually happened. For example, the pianist Rosalyn Turek claims that the sensation which she associates with hearing (e.g.) a middle C has changed in the course of her life. (See Reflections from the Keyboard by David Dubal; Schirmer Books;
2nd edition; Nov. 1997.)
[319]
 I say ‘at least arguably’ because many will disagree with my contention here: they will say that, after the operation, p2 (for example) will continue to represent a C#; that, in general, for any n, pn will continue to represent what it did before the operation. There is not really enough space for me to give this point of view the consideration that it deserves, but one criticism that can be made of it – and that surely cannot be summarily dismissed – is this. If that objection is right, then after the surgery, the person’s perceptions of pitch are systematically false: p2 is associated with the representational content middle C#, when in fact the sound in question is a middle C; and so on mutatis mutandis for p3,p4 ...But the person in question could, post-operatively, recover his ability to make correct judgments about what pitch he was hearing. He could figure out that, when had that sort of phenomenal experience, the cause of it was a C#, not a C. He could, indeed, become every bit as adept at identifying what note was being struck as a Mozart. And, of course, he would make these identifications on the basis of his acoustical perceptions. So, given this, it seems arbitrary to maintain that those perceptions would all be delusive – i.e. that, as a result of the operation, he was simply mis-hearing pitches. It seems more natural to say he is perceiving pitches veridically,  but that the way in which his phenomenal contents involved in these perceptions are paired off with their physical causes changed as a result of the operation. But, I grant, this is just an intuition of mine and will not meet with universal acceptance.

[343]
  Finally, others have tried to use theorems of (Bayesian) probability theory to solve this problem. (Bayes’ Theorem: [P(A/B)=P(B/A)×P(A)]÷P(B).) (See Trout (2000).)
     The term  ‹P(x)› is not defined by the Bayesian. (The brackets are to be taken as quasi-quotation marks. Cf. the next footnote.) It has an assumed, but unidentified, meaning. So Bayesian probabilitytheory is an uninterpreted formal calculus; and, like any such calculus (setting aside those that are inconsistent), it admits of many different interpretations, at least some of which are unintended (meaning that, relative to those models, the term(s) that it was the purpose of that calculus to clarify are given meanings that are at odds with the intuitions by those terms, as ordinarily used, are, in effect, defined).
      The term “probability theory,” it must be pointed out, may refer to one of two things: the mathematical theory of probability, which aspires to identify the mathematical consequences of axioms in which expressions like “confirm” (“probabilify”) and “probability” itself are undefined; and “probability theory” may also refer to the branch of philosophy that aspires to say what is meant by “confirm,” “probability,” and other expressions of their ilk. Carnap (1950) makes a similar point.      I won’t revisit this point. Given the technicalities involved in doing so, the result would be wordinflation not counterbalanced by content-inflation. And this puzzle is inherently non-technical. Philosophical problems are ipso facto not formal problems. For, once a problem is formal, it becomes part of mathematical logic.
  In any case, the Bayesian attempts to solve these problems all involve the same two mistakes. First, those theories take the term “probability” (and “confirms,” etc.) as being undefined (or as being defined only in the sense in which the term “point” is defined in an uninterpreted system of geometry). From the viewpoint of the mathematical (and therefore the Bayesian) probability theorist, such terms are uninterpreted. But the very question raised by Hempel’s paradox is: What is meant by “probability,” “confirm,” and other such terms? An uninterpreted formal theory is ipso facto incapable of answering that question, since that question amounts to this: Given a model (that, if duly interpreted, might apprise us of the meanings of “confirm” etc.), what is the right interpretation of it?
    Second, such theories take the word-order and, more generally, the strictly linguistic properties, of (i) and (ii) (or of whatever pair of sentences they’re considering, when dealing with Hempel’s paradox) as being material to the manner in which they are to be confirmed. But do “Brutus killed Caesar” and “Caesar was killed by Brutus” have different confirmational properties? Surely not.
[344]
 After we put forth our own solution to Hempel’s paradox, we’ll examine those put forth by Hempel and Quine. But, since I don’t want this paper per se (as opposed to this paper plus the footnotes, which ex hypothesi deal with (semi-)peripheral matters, our discussion of alternatives views of the raven-paradox will, like the material you are now reading, be footnoted.
         In any case, most of what we’ll say can be summed up in a few words. Their solutions are either counterintuitive or simply incoherent. Given what it is for sentences P and Q to be equivalent, it makes no sense, I submit, to say that P and Q be logically but not confirmationally equivalent. (‹P and Q are
[344]
	equivalent›  is true iff there is no world, metaphysically or epistemically possible, in which P is true and Q is false, or vice versa. If a given datum D confers more support on the one sentence than on the other, the one is ipso facto possible in some epistemically possible worlds in which the other is false.)  But even if it can be shown that an internally consistent logic could be invented relative to which logical and confirmational equivalence pull apart, it seems excessive to throw out classical logic to solve this one problem. Suppose that, having been charged misrepresenting their financials to their shareholders, the owners of Enron said to the judge: “Your honor, we didn’t misrepresent anything.
Relative to the non-classical logic that we invented, our records are perfectly consistent with the facts.” Not the best legal strategy. Hempel’s solution---though ingenious, as we’ll see, and though not involving ad hoc (meta)logical views---involves acceptance of the contention that red carpet fibers are no less, and no more, probabilistically relevant to “all ravens are black” than are black ravens (or nonblack ravens). Even if Hempel is right, is it not worth trying to produce a solution to his paradox that is more congenial than his to commonsense, however myopic may sometimes be? In this paper, we’ll see that Hempel’s problem can (which is not to say “should”) be solved in a manner congenial to commonsense-friendly and also with classical (meta)logical principles. [345]
Bearing this in mind, let now (in Section 1.1) discuss an assumption we’ll make concerning the semantics of categoricals. 
     The philosophers and logicians who write about (i) and (ii) (or other comparable sentence-pairs) make the following assumption as to what those sentences mean, to wit:
 
(#) (i) is to the effect nothing is both a metal and also a thing that fails to expand when heated. (ii) is to the effect that nothing is both a thing that isn’t expanding isn’t also a thing that is made of metal and is being heated.  
 
      The people who write about Hempel’s paradox tend to be logicians and philosophers of science who aren’t interested in the semantics/pragmatics distinction and therefore, when talking about what a sentence S “means,” don’t say whether they’re discussing, on the one hand, what S literally means or, on the other hand, what its occurrences convey. (And there is a big distinction to be made hear: what a sentence conveys is a function, not just of its literal meaning, but also of background understandings and other pragmatic factors. “I’m coming over to your house,” may, when uttered, convey a threat (you’ll soon be dead, because I’m coming over to kill you) or an assurance (contrary to what you fear, you won’t soon be dead, because I’ll soon be at your house with your heart-medication). At the level of literal meaning, such utterance is to the effect that x (the speaker) is going to place y (the addressee’s home).
      Bearing this in mind consider both
 
(TS) “triangles have three sides”
 
and
 
(i) “metal expands when heated.”
 
As they are ordinarily interpreted, those sentences are to the effect that, for reasons of logic (or mathematics) a thing can’t be a triangle without having three sides and that, for reasons of natural law, a thing can’t be metal if it doesn’t expand when heated.
    Given only that that this is how occurrences of those sentences are typically understood, it does not follow that this is what such tokens literally mean.
      My inclination is to think that, at the level of semantics, these sentences don’t have logical or nomic force, and it is through implicature, not explicature, that utterances of them transmit the logically/nomically pregnant claims just describes. I say this because those implicatures, if that’s what they are, can be cancelled and are therefore, by Grice’s (1975) plausible criterion, pragmatic epiphenomena (to use Kent Bach’s (1987) expression) as opposed to semantic explicatures. Cf.:
 
[345]
	(iC) “All metal objects expand when heated. But there’s nothing inherent in what it is to be a metal object that disposes such objects to expand when heated.
Long ago, some alien prankster, hoping to mislead future scientists, destroyed all
[345]
metal things that didn’t expand when heated.”
 
    
    Cf. also:
 
(TSC) “triangles have three sides. But triangles could have four-sides. This would happen if some triangular living creature grew a fourth side.”
 
 
     (iC) is a highly fanciful claim, for which there is no evidence. And TSC is, to be blunt, a really stupid claim. But neither claim is tautologically false. In other words, it isn’t solely in virtue of facts about definitions and semantic rules (and the like) that either claim is false.
     This is obvious in where (iC) is concerned. (iC) is empirical claim; it could be true. Therefore it isn’t tautologically (definitionally/semantically) false.
       What about TSC? TSC is a statement that an actual student of mine---a superb writer, by the way--made in class. In fact, every semester, I get around 15 students who make statements not in any relevant way different from TSC, e.g. “1+1=3’ would be true if we found that two 1lb rocks jointly weighed 3lbs.” (In fact, this was Mill’s position, as well as the later Wittgenstein’s.) Most of these students have at least as good a command of the English language as I do. So it isn’t linguistic incompetence that leads them to utter the likes of TSC. It’s intellectual incompetence. Stupidity, in other words. (Sorry fellas!) Which means that TSC isn’t linguistically non-kosher. Which in turn means that it is not solely virtue of definitions (or semantic rules, etc.) that TSC false and, therefore, that it is in virtue, in part, of extra-linguistic truths. And these truths, clearly, are of a logical or otherwise non-empirical nature.     Here’s where this leaves us. (i) and TS, as they (or their tokens, rather) are customarily interpreted, don’t make purely extensional claims; they don’t just say that all the things in one category are also in some other category. As ordinarily understood, they say, not just that certain classes are sub-classes of others, but that there is some kind of principled basis for these facts about class-inclusion. But we’ve seen that the intension-related propositions typically conveyed by (i) and TS are cancelable.
[345]
	Which suggests that, at the level of semantics, TS and (i) and their likes are to be interpreted, not as intensionally pregnant claims, but as affirming sterile, purely extensional ones.
    Of course, the points just made by no means settle the delicate question of whether, in some contexts or some values of phi and psi, ‹all phi’s and psi’s›  is, at the level of literal meaning, to the effect that a thing’s a being phi is connected in some robust, not purely statistical way, to its being a psi. But, when taken in conjunction with the points we’re about to make, they do suggest that (i) and (ii), if read as being such that tokens of the one semantically but not pragmatically parallel tokens of the other. Hempel’s paradox is readily solved.   
        Or, to make a similar, but non-coincident, claims: Hempel’s paradox is readily solved if we suppose that, although (i) and (ii) do coincide in respect of literal meaning, they have hidden
(phonetically/orthographically unrealized) context-sensitive parameters, in virtue of which tokens of the one differ in respect of what they convey from tokens of the other. (In Russian, omission of a tensemarker has the same semantic function that, in English, is had by non-omission of such a marker. if one says “ya vam blagadarem”---“I grateful to you” (no (phonetically realized) tense-indicator)---one is, at the level of literal meaning, saying that one is grateful to one’s interlocutor.” It’s not out of the question that, in English, there are phonetically unrealized context-sensitive parameters.     
    Supposing that, indeed, tokens of (i) are semantically parallel to tokens of (ii), my thesis is that Hempel’s paradox can be solved in a way congenial to classical logic and commonsense, the reason being that we’re falsely assuming that tokens of (i) are tokens of (ii) in respect of what they affirm, the consequence being that we wrench a fine system of logic and spurn one of our best (and, in a sense, our only) instrument for detecting truth (viz. our faculty of intuition), when what we should be doing is scratching the surface of language. So, as far as logicians and philosophers of science are concerned, there is no significant difference between the contention that
 
($) Hempel’s paradox is to be solved by taking pragmatics into account,
 
and the contention that
 
($$) Hempel’s paradox is be solved by taking hidden (semantic) contextsensitive parameters into account.
 
Of course, ($) and ($$) do (presumably) differ from a linguist’s perspective.  Even so, the present paper, if cogent, shows that some branch of linguistics can solve puzzles to which linguistics has always been assumed to be irrelevant.

 4.0 Hume-internal solutions to the raven paradox: Quine’s solution
 
      Quine’s (1977) solution is to say that that logical equivalence doesn’t guarantee confirmational equivalence. This idea is totally incoherent. P and Q are equivalent if they are true in exactly the same worlds. Thus, supposing that P and Q are equivalent, it immediately follows that, given any proposition R, the likelihood of R’s being true in a world where P is true is identical with the likelihood of R’s being true in a world where Q is true. Quine’s proposed solution is thus a non-starter.
 
4.1 Hume-internal solutions to the raven paradox: Hempel’s solution
 
           Hempel proposes a more plausible solution. It obviously seems as though the existence of a pink piano provides less support for:
 

	* “All ravens are black”
 than does the existence of a black raven. And it obviously seems as though the existence of pink pianos provides more support for:
 

	* “All non-black things are non-ravens"
 than it does for (1). But, says Hempel, these intuitions are misleading. Under ordinary circumstances, if we know that something is a piano, we almost certainly already know that it isn’t a raven.
But imagine the following. You have bet your friend Smith $1,000,000 that all ravens are black. There is some object x such that, although you and Smith don’t yet know it, x is a piano. All you know about x is that it’s pink. In that case, when you discover that x is a piano, and thus a non-raven, you (but not Smith) will breathe a sigh of relief; and your confidence in (1) will surge, and so, of course, will your confidence in (2).
Now imagine a different scenario. You have bet your friend Smith $1,000,000 that all non-black things are non-ravens. There is some object y such that, although you and Smith don’t yet know it, y is black. All you know about y is that it’s a raven. When you discover that y is black, you will breathe a sigh of relief; and your confidence in (2) will surge, and so, of course, will your confidence in (1).
Thus, to Hempel, the confirmational disparities between (1) and (2) are illusory. When we imagine ourselves trying to confirm (2), we assume that we are looking at things that we already know to be non-ravens, but we don’t make the same assumption mutatis mutandis when we imagine ourselves to be trying to confirm (1).
Hempel’s solution is better than Quine’s, but it’s still no good. The problem is that, if it’s known that there is no nomic or causal relationship between a thing’s being a raven, on the one hand, and its being black, on the other, then there is ipso facto no reason to believe that the next raven you see will be black. Maybe you’ve seen a million ravens, all of them black. It’s doesn’t matter. Unless you have reason to believe that a thing’s being a raven is connected somehow to its being black, you’re guilty of the gambler’s fallacy if, on the basis of that data, you believe that the next raven you see is (likely to be) black. But if you do believe that a thing’s being a raven is connected in some way to its being black, then your confidence in (1) is derivative of your confidence in:
 
(1*) a thing’s being a raven provides a basis of some kind for its being black.
 
We’ve already seen why. And we’ve already see why (1*) isn’t equivalent with:
 
(2*) a thing’s being non-black provides some kind of a basis for its being a nonraven.
 
If the existence of a black raven is to provide any legitimate support for (1), there must be a causal or nomic connection between ravenhood and blackness. Once this is realized, two things immediately become obvious. First, Hempel’s solution is spurious, since it presupposes that black ravens can confirm (1) without there being any connection of the sort just described. Second, (1) must be read as having nomic force. Since, thus read, it is no longer equivalent with (2), the paradox vanishes.  
[352]
 Republished in Quine (1966).
[353]
  It is sometimes propositions that are described as “formally true,” but this is quite rare, and it’s almost always expressions that are so described. But, even though the terms “formally true,” “formally entails,” etc. are typically used in connection with sentences, there are, I believe, propositional analogues of the concepts they express. Consider the proposition (not any one of the corresponding sentences/sentence-tokens): 
 
 (i) 1+1=2.
 

	* entails each of:
 

	* for some x, 1+x=2,
 
and
 

	* there is some x such x is even and x is 1’s successor
 
and, finally,
 

	* there are continuous functions that cannot be differentiated at any point.
 
    It’s only in a thoroughly sterile, strictly model-theoretic sense that (i) entails (iv). The way in which (i) entails (ii) isn’t so antiseptic, and neither is the way in which it entails (iii). But, it seems to me, the way in which (ii) follows from (i) is more transparent than the way in which (iii) does so; and a viable theory of propositions ought to validate that point. In my book__, and my paper__, I argue that, whereas first entailment holds in virtue of the structures of the immediate constitutents of the propositions involved, the second entailment holds in virtue of structures of those constituents---it holds in virtue of, as it were, the constituencies of those propositions’ constituencies. 
       Moving onto another point: It is, I believe, sentence-tokens, never sentence-types, that are true or false. My reasons for this, which I state at length in my book__, are extensions of arguments put forth by Strawson (1950), Barwise and Perry (1983), and Kaplan (1989). Long story short: It’s incontrovertible that no sentence-type containing a context-sensitive parameter is true or false. Consider the sentence-type “that guy is a threat to our way of life.” Some instances of that sentence-type are true or false, but the sentence-type per se is neither. All sentences of natural language contain contextsensitive component. In some cases, e.g. “there are infinitely prime numbers,” that component (in this case, the present-tense marker) aren’t doing any work. But that has to do with the non-semantic fact that mathematical reality doesn’t change. If, as Mill and other hyper-empiricists hold, it does change, then whether “there are infinitely primes” is true or false is a function of the time (and possibly the place) of utterance. Sentence-tokens are spatiotemporal objects. Sentence-types, being things of which there are instances, are properties and therefore aren’t spatiotemporal objects. So, where natural language is concerned, it is always spatiotemporal entities that have truth-values. Of course, there could exist, and presumably do exist, context-insensitive languages (cf. the artificial language, or languageextension, to which “1+2=3” belongs). But this would not be a good move. No difference is greater than that between the spatiotemporal and the Platonic. Given this fact, along with the fact that the term
“truth-evaluable expression” corresponds to an explanatorily fecund category, it’s hard to see how that class could contain both expression-tokens and expression-types. For an extensive defense of this position, see___.
 
[354]
 Some would hold that any given sentence of natural language ipso facto fails to be formally true and that, so far as one isn’t speaking false in describing (i)-(iv) as “formally true,” one is saying elliptically that, given their syntactic structures, it’s obvious how to associate them with sentences, belonging to artificial languages, which, unlike them, really are formally true.
     Supposing, if only for argument’s sake, that this is correct, it has no bearing on the analysis which we’ll be defending. For that analysis, as we’ll see, is no less consistent with the assumption “if snow is white, then either snow is white” is formally true than it is with the corresponding assumption concerning their artificial counterparts.
[355]
 More precisely, (#) and (##), taken jointly, satisfy two conditions. First, there is a one-one correspondence between the one’s (proper) constituents and the other’s. (Actually there are 9 such correspondences; but, of course, the relevant one, which is the one we’ll discuss, is the one that pairs off “Bill” with “Laura,” “hates” with loves,” etc.) Second, supposing that P# and P## are the propositions borne by (#) and (##), respectively, the relation borne by the meaning of “hates” to P# coincides with the relation borne by the meaning of “loves” to P##, the same thing mutatis mutandis being true of each of the other two constituents of (#).
     The reason that (#) does not have the same syntax as:
 
(###) “either Igor went swimming or the U.S. economy is probably going to continue to deteriorate”
 
is that, unless (###) is parsed in a patently artificial manner, its parts cannot be put into a correspondence with those of (#) and a fortiori there is no correspondence R such that, relative to R, the relation borne by any given (proper) constituent of the one sentence to the proposition thereby meant coincides with the relation borne by that constituent’s R-counterpart to the proposition meant by its host-sentence.
    Syntax, in the linguist’s sense of the word, is semantic structure. Two sentences are syntactically identical (or isomorphic) iff the semantic relation borne by a given constituent of the one sentence to the meaning of that sentence as a whole coincides with the semantic relation borne by that constituent’s counterpart in the other sentence. So it’s true---indeed, it’s a truism---that syntax is expression-form. But it’s a blunder to conclude from this old saw, as so many do, that syntax has nothing to do with semantics. Syntax is semantic structure. So one is contradicting oneself if one argues, as Fodor (1987, 1987b, 1990, 1994) and Davidson do, that a semantics-insensitive entity (e.g. a Turing-machine) can be syntax-sensitive. 
      Also, syntax is but one kind of expression form, as Strawson (1952) long ago made clear. For there is at least arguably a sense in which “Brutus killed Caesar” and “Caesar was killed by Brutus” have the same form---they have the same logical form, presumably, given the one sentence’s inferential liaisons--what, and by way of what intermediate steps, it entails and is entailed by---coincide with the other’s
(with some minor qualifications, e.g. that “Caesar was killed by Brutus” follows more directly from “Caesar was killed by Brutus” than does “Brutus killed Caesar.”) Thus, it isn’t because of any structural differences between them that they have different meanings.

[359]
 These brackets are known as “quasi-quotation marks.” They are like quotation-marks except that they don’t quote the free variables that they enclose. What is the purpose of quasi-quotation marks? Consider the expression: “if P and Q and R, then R.” That expression isn’t true or false. So the sentence “For any propositions P, Q, and R, the sentence ‘if P and Q and R, then R’ is true” is not true. But the sentence “for any propositions P, Q, and R, a true sentence  results when, given the open-sentence “if P and Q and R, then R,” the variables are uniformly replaced with arbitrary sentences” is true. And (A) is a concise way of saying this. In general, quasi-quotation marks make it possible to express generalizations about sentences in a concise way. Quine (1940) was the first to see the need for quasiquotation marks and duly introduced them in his (1940) book Mathematical Logic.

[364]
 Why sometimes? Because one must have an assurance that one is dealing with sentence-tokens whose actual structures aren’t hidden or distorted by their surface structures. One can infer “Bill is a duck” from “Bill is a big duck,” but not from “Bill is a decoy duck.” One can infer “Bill is good” from “Bill is a good person” but not from “Bill is a good torturer.” When dealing with sentences of English, or of any other natural language, one has to know what a sentence means in order to know to what degree its surface structure is representative of its logical form. So, where sentences of natural language are concerned, judgments about form must be checked against knowledge semantics. Which means that, when given a sentence belonging to a natural language, any legitimate judgment concerning its truth-value or inferential liaisons must be semantics based. Which in turn means that form-driven judgments are legitimate only if its assumed that the surface-structures of the sentences in question do justice to their actual structures. And it’s only in very specific, and very artificial contexts that one has any such assurance.

 The viewpoint I am advocating, though by no means particularly non-obvious and by no means heterodox (relative to certain a certain tradition of thought, beginning with Leibniz (cf. the Leibniz/Clarke Debates) and including Einstein) isn’t even in considered (so far as I can tell) in the contemporary leading works on this topic. See Gale (1968), Gribbin (1985), Pagels (1985), Lewis (1986), Nahin (1997, 2001), Miller (2005). Pickover (1999), Davies (1996, 2002), Randles (2005) Toomey (2007). That said, that viewpoint is anticipated, though not explicitly endorsed, by Poincaré
(1913), Einstein and Infeld (1959), Einstein (1962), Russell (1928, 1948), and Reichenbach (1956,
1958). I was, frankly, a bit surprised that Lewis didn’t mention it, given his high level of interest in the subject and his unparalleled level of logico-philosophical acumen. Whatever demerits might afflict my contention and my argument for it, it seems sufficiently consonant with intuition that it should be considered, if only to be rejected. But much of what the aforementioned contemporaries say simply assumes its falsity, much to the detriment of their argumentation, making it hard to believe that they’ve given this viewpoint their due. I apologize in advance to any author who has made points identical to or coincident with mine and welcome a dialogue with her or him.

 Sentence-types – the types of which those tokens are instances -- seldom if ever encode propositions.  Nonetheless, not everything in a sentence (or, sentence-token, rather) expressing a  proposition denotes a property. Some sentential material denotes nothing, and merely encodes material – usually identifiable with so-called “grammatical inflections” -- saying how to identify a third property on the basis of two previously identified properties. This is further discussed in Conceit # 8 and extensively further discussed in the rest of the paper. Basically, grammatical inflections encode functions that assign properties to n-tuples of properties; and it is these n-tuples that distinguish “Aristotle strikes Socrates” from the meaningless heap “Aristotle, the relation of striking, Plato.” So even though everything in a proposition is a property, not all the information in the sentence that expresses a proposition a property.

 This is, of course, not the only analysis of nothing snores. We can also identify that proposition with a set S whose members are the following: a The property of being universally uninstantiated.

	a. The property being identical with the property of snoring.

	b. The property of being identical with the universally uninstantiated property of snoring.
 
First of all, notice that c is derived by Conceit# 8 from a and b. Any instance of c is an instance of (b) the property of being identical with the property (which is not the same as being an instance of snoring) and is also an instance of (a) the property of being universally uninstantiated.  So if c is instantiated, so are b and a. Thus, if c is instantiated,  then there is an instance of the property of being identical with a universally uninstantiated property of snoring. In other words, there exists a universally uninstantiated property and that property is identical with the property of snoring. Since c cannot be instantiated without a and b being instantiated, that means that if a-c are instantiated, then there exists a universally uninstantiated property, that property being the property of snoring. And that, of course, is equivalent (if it isn’t outright said) by “nothing snores.”

 It was Donald Smith who brought it to my attention that my analysis avoids this pitfall of direct reference theory. I am sympathetic to many aspects of direct reference theory. I think that there is some x such that, if true, the sentence “Socrates is bald” is true exactly if the same is true of the singular proposition x is bald. So I hold that, for that sentence to be true, it is necessary that Socrates – not the great hemlock-drinking philosophers and not the sarcastic main protagonist in most of Plato’s dialogues – be bald.  Basically, I was, and am, a card-carrying direct-reference theorist. But, independently of that, I held the view, described in this paper, about propositions. It was not until talking with Donald, some weeks ago, that I could use theory of propositions to produce a form of direct-reference theory wouldn’t be stuck with the embarrassing (because so implausible) consequence that the meaning of “Joey likes to read” vanishes when Joey does – a consequence that Soames and Salmon deal with by saying that “Joey likes to read” does indeed encode a proposition: a non-existence one. (So, in their view, there exists a proposition that is the meaning of “Joey likes to read” that doesn’t exist.)

 Here’s a more graphic way of putting it. We want to find out if there could possibly be square circles. Lewis rightly says that we can figure this out, and that our doing so doesn’t involve leaving our own world. All we have to do is manipulate the materials – the properties, presumably – that are available to us right here: the properties square, circle, and maybe a few others. Having done the combinatorics, it’s clear that, no, there can’t be square circles. But this suggests that it is because is defectively put together, not because of what is going on (or not) in other worlds, that there are square circles is incapable of being true. What is going on in other worlds, if anything, is, at best, a reflection of these inter-property relations.

 Although the word ‘concept’ is ambiguous, that ambiguity is not as radical as that associated with words like ‘bank’ and ‘rent’. Presumably, a mental entity qualifies as a concepto in the psychological sense – as a grasp of something – if it somehow encodes a concepto in the objective sense. I grasp the concepto of triangularity – which is a non-mental entity – by virtue of having a mental content which somehow encodes that concepto. So a concept in the psychological sense is a mental entity which encodes a concepto in the objective sense.
   Also both concepts and conceptso are modes of presentation. The concepto class of all points equidistant from a given point is a mode of presentation of the property of sphericity, and so is the concepto closed three-dimensional figure of uniform curvature. So underneath the superficial ambiguity of the word “concept”, there are identities of meaning.

[414]
 The reason is that we give “wide scope” to the descriptive information. I tell you “some guy stole my wallet.” You then think to yourself: he didn’t have to become a thief – he might have become a police officer. Here you are not thinking: it is possible that somebody x uniquely stole __’s wallet and also that x did not become a thief. What you are thinking is:  somebody x uniquely stole __’s wallet and there is a possible circumstance where  that x did not become a thief. So the descriptive information is given wide scope with respect to the modal operator. Even though it is always through descriptive information that we acquire concepts of objects (or so I will argue), that doesn’t corrupt our modal intuitions; for we give the descriptive information “wide scope” with modal operators.
[415]
 Or seemed to argue: see below
[416]
 Jerry Fodor (1998) has gone so far as to say that a causal connection to x is all that is involved in having a concept of x. So I can have no beliefs about the number and yet have a conception of it: I need only have a casual connection to it (or, more accurately, some instance of it). I need only have a causal connection to Socrates to be able to think about him. I needn’t know anything about him. My book__ is a discussion of Fodor’s atomism and his arguments for it.

 It is possible that what Kripke says is not so much that people know of no individuating descriptions of the things they think about and refer to. His point is that the individuating descriptions are not the ones that Russell (and possibly Frege) thought they were. I think that Kripke himself says something similar to what we say below – when we argue that one does need an individuating descriptions of a very special kind to refer to an object. (I won’t press these exegetical points. I will argue only for the point that none of Kripke’s cogent points to any degree warrant the rejection of the “descriptivism” I have been urging.)

 More exactly, that person gives Socrates the Ancient Greek equivalent of “Socrates”, whatever that is. In this discussion, we will ignore the fact that, over the years, names may undergo considerable phonemic change. Obviously “Confucius” sounds very little like the name of the old sage. These phonemic changes introduce no philosophical mysteries, but allowing for them would clutter up the exposition considerably.
[420]
 In fact, it is arguable that all such descriptions do, except when the description in question refers to some abstract object, like the number two. The (often hidden) presence of indexicals is needed to prevent problems relating to what Strawson called the “massive reduplication”. Your friend Fred says to you “somebody uniquely invented bifocals; his name is ‘Ben Franklin’”. As it happens, on a distant planet, some other person (or intelligent creature) also invented bifocals. Is Fred wrong? Not if we take him to mean: in this context – in the context of the world we occupy – somebody uniquely invented bifocals. Surely we would not take Fred to rule out the possibility that on some distant planet there were intelligent, bifocal-inventing life-forms. So, in effect, we attribute a hidden indexical to Fred’s statement. For reasons of this kind, we must see our discourse as permeated by indexicality, hidden though it may often be.

 Of course, the term “occasion” has to be defined somewhat narrowly. One can refer to twenty different people in a single conversation and thus on a single “occasion”. But at any specific juncture of that occasion – at any one time (leaving aside ambiguity) – one is referring to just one person or object. When I say “occasion” I mean a specific juncture of a discourse.

[423]

[424]
 It isn’t even clear if Russell was wrong about the nature of the uniquely individuating descriptions. It could be that he was simply using historically pregnant descriptions to illustrate his basic point, which is that one must have some uniquely individuating description of Socrates to think about, or refer to, Socrates. If he had illustrated his point with some uniquely individuating description that didn’t obviously apply to Socrates – e.g. the guy to whom Seymour was referring on occasion C…-nobody would have followed what he was saying. So his use of uniquely individuating descriptions like the philosopher who drank Hemlock may not really indicate his belief that that is an actual uniquely individuating description through which one might refer to, or think about Socrates. It might just be a superficial expository device. But I am not a Russell scholar; so I remain open on this.
[425]
 I say “may” for a couple of reasons. After one learns that (so to speak) Hesperus=Phosphorous, then *Hesperus has phi* may end up coinciding in cognitive value with *Phosphorous has phi*. (Of course, this point has to be adjusted for speakers of other languages.)
  Also, depending on how one initially learns the meaning of “Hesperus” and “Phosphorous”, *Hesperus has phi* *Phosphorous has phi* might never have had different cognitive values (for that person) to begin with. This will be the case if am introduced to the words by somebody who points to Venus and says: “that  is called both ‘Hesperus’ and ‘Phosphorous’”.
[426]
  Let me end by considering an objection to this last line of thought (I will put the objection in the mouth of an imaginary locator):
 
“You have ex nihilo produced this strange theory of conception as being sustained by knowledge of interlocking existence claims. And you claim that recognition consists in seeing that some one object satisfies two existence claims. But all of this seems very ad hoc – something you’ve confabulated to get your bankrupt theory off the hook.”
 
    I think that this comment has force only to the extent that we’ve been jaded by wrong theories of sense-perception and, more generally, of objectual awareness.
    When you see Bob, embedded in your sense-perception is existential information. You cannot get rid of that existential information without eliminating the perception. This suggests that that existential information is constitutive of the content of the perception. Granted, Bob himself is (part of) the representational content of that perception. But he is given to you via this existential information.    So when you see Bob on some occasion t, the content of that perception is given by some bit of existential information like: there is some chap whom I’m now seeing, wearing a bowler hat…    You see Bob again, on occasion t*. Again, the content of your perception is given by some existence claim: there is some chap I’m seeing, wearing a baseball cap…
   On both occasions, the content of your perception is existential.
    Suppose that, on t*, you recognize the person you are seeing is the person you saw on t. Your tperception is given by existential information, and so is your t*-perception. So if, on t*, you recognize that you are seeing the same person you saw on t, that must consist in your realizing that the same entity satisfies both existence-claims are satisfied – that there is some one entity who satisfies both. Once a few platitudes are granted about sense-perception – that sense-perceptions have existential content -- our theory of conception and recognition proves to be far from ad hoc.

The property of being perceivable is a matter of degree, and also of context. Therefore, the same is true of the property of being theoretical. What you can see is a function, at least in part, of what your background theories are. (This is a very Sellarsian point.) But, rough and ready though it is, the concept of a perceivable property is not without its utility; and the fact that it is subject to qualifications does not have any bearing in this context.

[434]
 Of course intentionalists might say: ‘ no one is mad enough to suppose that different species have the same kind of phenomenal content in response to a different kind of sound (experienced under a given set of circumstances). And, of course, no one denies that creatures that have different phenomenal contents (in response to a given kind of sound under a given set of circumstances) can hear just as veridically, if not more so, than we. Intentionalism – at least any sane version of it – applies within species, not between species.’
  But this concession eviscerates intentionalism. Intentionalism wants a metaphysically necessary relationship between the representational and the phenomenal; not a merely causal, contingent one. Obviously if intentionalism is not true across species, then a given bit of representational content can be realized by very different phenomenal contents, and there is no long any kind of reduction of the phenomenal to the mental, and thus no explanation of the phenomenal in terms of the representational (at least none along intentionalist lines). But the interest  of intentionalism is surely not that it register the idiosyncrasies of species, but that it captures some kind necessary fact about the relationship between phenomenal and representational content. And if this relationship doesn’t hold across species, then that relationship isn’t necessary. And it probably – almost assuredly -  doesn’t hold across species.
